questions.question: Which of the following refractive errors, if left uncorrected, is MOST likely to lead to a headache due to eyestrain?
questions.explanation:
Although some patients will note that they experience a dull brow ache or increased tension with low amounts of myopia or astigmatism associated with squinting, uncorrected hyperopia is most often association with headaches due to constant accommodative effort. 

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12010381

questions.question: According to Hofsetter's data, a 44-year old patient with an amplitude of accommodation of 4.00 D would be expected to have a reading add of what dioptric value?
questions.explanation:
Hofsetter's data is very useful clinically to compare the findings you have determined for a particular patient to theoretical ranges. Generally: 
Age____________Minimum amplitude range__________Expected reading add 
40-44___________5.00 -4.00 D____________________+0.75 to +1.00 D 
45-49___________3.75-2.75 D_____________________+1.00 to +1.50 D 
50-54___________2.50-1.50 D_____________________+1.50 to +2.00 D 
55-59___________1.25-0.25 D_____________________+2.00 to +2.25 D 
Older than 60_____0 D___________________________+2.25 to +2.50 D 

Is it necessary to memorize the above table? No-just get a basic idea for the expected reading add and the correlated age range.

questions.question: A 1.50 D uncorrected myope views an object at 25.0 cm. What degree of accommodation is required at the corneal plane to achieve a clear retinal image?
questions.explanation: An object located at 25.0 cm has a vergence demand of 1/0.25= 4.00 D. The above patient has a far point vergence of 1.50 and therefore only needs to accommodate +2.50 D to achieve a clear retinal image of the object (4.00 D- 1.50 D = +2.50 D). An uncorrected myope requires less accommodation to achieve a clear retinal image for a near target when compared to an emmetrope or a hyperope. For this reason many presbyopic myopes will remove their distance glasses to read in lieu of bifocal or progressive addition lenses.

questions.question: An object is located 50 cm from the corneal plane of an eye with 2.00 D of myopia. What degree of accommodation is required to achieve a clear retinal image of the object with no corrective lens in place?
questions.explanation: A 2.00 D myope has a far point of 50 cm (1/2.00 D= 0.50 m or 50.0 cm). Because the object is located at the far point of the eye, no accommodation is required to bring the image into focus.

questions.question: A +3.00 D hyperope is corrected with a +1.50 D contact lens bilaterally. If he views a near object located at 22.0 cm, what degree of accommodation is required to achieve a clear retinal image (rounded to the nearest 0.25 D)?
questions.explanation: The target requires +4.50 D of accommodation to be viewed clearly, which is determined by the taking the reciprocal of the target distance (in meters) (1/0.22= 4.55 D or +4.50 D). However, in addition to the target demand, he must also accommodate 1.50 D more as he is undercorrected by this amount at distance in order to ensure a clear retinal image.

questions.question: A +4.00 D hyperope when fully corrected for distance with contact lenses views an object located at 18 cm. How much accommodation is required for the patient to obtain a clear retinal image (rounded to the nearest 0.25 D)?
questions.explanation: Because the patient is fully corrected for distance, the only value that is required to calculate the accommodative demand is the viewing distance of 18cm which is determined by taking the reciprocal of the target distance (in meters) yielding 1/0.18 = 5.56 D or +5.50 D.

questions.question: Most patients have a resting level of accommodation (also known as tonic accommodation) that is typically equivalent to which of the following values?
questions.explanation: At rest, the eyes typically have some amount of residual or resting level of accommodation. This is also known as tonic accommodation; it is sometimes referred to as a lead of accommodation. The amount of tonic accommodation in a normal individual is typically between 0.50 and 1.50 diopters.

questions.question: While attempting to determine the amplitude of accommodation via the push up method on your patient, she reports that the target is blurry at a distance of 14 cm for the right eye and at 13 cm for the left eye. What is her amplitude of accommodation in diopters for the right eye and the left eye respectively (to the nearest 0.25 D)?
questions.explanation: In order to determine the amplitude of accommodation, one must take the reciprocal of the blur point in meters. For the above example, 1/0.14 = 7.14 and 1/0.13 = 7.69. Do not forget to convert to meters!! Also, the question asked that the answer be rounded to the nearest 0.25 D. Be sure to read questions carefully to avoid careless mistakes. Clinically, one always rounds to the nearest 0.25 D.

questions.question: You are comparing the measurements of the back vertex power and front vertex power of a high plus lens using the lensometer. The back vertex lens power reads +8.50 -1.25 x 170. When you flip the glasses around to measure the front vertex power, what do you expect the cylinder axis to read?
questions.explanation:
For higher-powered plus lenses, there is often a difference between the front and back vertex powers. This is due to the increased thickness of a plus lens. It is important to note that the cylinder axis for the front vertex power will be the mirror-image of the back vertex cylinder axis (therefore it is acceptable to refocus the lens by adjusting the cylinder wheel). For the example above, if the back vertex cylinder axis is 170, the mirror of this will be a cylinder axis of 010. 
This aforementioned fact is important because during the measurement of an add power of high plus lenses, one may not obtain an accurate reading of the add power because of this difference in vertex powers. Therefore, one must re-measure the distance power of the lens using the front vertex power and then measure the power through the near add. The difference between these two measurements will represent the most accurate add power.

questions.question: You are measuring accommodation on your 22 year-old male patient. He is a 1.50 diopter hyperope and is tested outside of the phoropter with no spectacle correction. He notes blur at 10cm with both the right and left eyes. What is his amplitude of accommodation?
questions.explanation:
To determine the amplitude of accommodation for each eye in adults, one eye is occluded while the subjective findings are left in place, and the patient is asked to focus on one or two lines above their visual acuity threshold on the reduced Snellen chart. The chart is brought closer to the patient until he reports that the line first becomes blurry. This measurement is repeated with the other eye; the results are then converted from cm to diopters, yielding the near point of accommodation. 

In younger patients, accommodation testing often cannot be performed in the phoropter because their amplitudes of accommodation are typically greater than 10cm (which is off of the scale of the phoropter rule). If the patient is not corrected with the subjective refractive data, this must be taken into consideration. For example, the above patient reported that the chart became blurry 10cm from his eyes; 1/0.20= 10.0 diopters. Because he is also a 1.50 diopter hyperope, he actually must accommodate an initial 1.50 diopters at near; therefore, this must be added to the initial measurement, rendering his true amplitude of accommodation as 11.50 diopters for both the right and left eyes.

questions.question: You are measuring accommodation on your 8 year-old male patient. He is a 0.75 diopter myope, and is tested outside of the phoropter with no spectacle correction. He notes blur at 8cm with both the right and left eyes. What is his amplitude of accommodation?
questions.explanation:
To determine the amplitude of accommodation for each eye in adults, one eye is occluded while the subjective findings are left in place, and the patient is asked to focus on one or two lines above their visual acuity threshold on the reduced Snellen chart. The chart is brought closer to the patient until they report that the line first becomes blurry. This measurement is repeated with the other eye; the results are then converted from cm to diopters, yielding the near point of accommodation. 

In younger patients, accommodation testing often cannot be performed in the phoropter because their amplitudes of accommodation are typically greater than 10cm (which is off of the scale of the phoropter rule). If the patient is not corrected with the subjective refractive data, this must be taken into consideration. For example, the above patient reported that the chart became blurry 8cm from his eyes; 1/0.08= 12.5 diopters. Because he is also a 0.75 diopter myope, he is actually accommodating 0.75 diopters less at near; therefore, this must be subtracted from the initial measurement, rendering his true amplitude of accommodation as 11.75 diopters for both the right and left eyes.

questions.question: A patient with an AC/A ratio of 8/1 and 4 prism diopters of exophoria views a target at 6.0m and uses 1.0 diopter of accommodation. What is the MOST likely resulting heterophoria?
questions.explanation:
The AC/A ratio conveys the amount of change to convergence resulting from a change in accommodation. The patient's AC/A ratio is 8/1. Therefore, because the patient's accommodation system was altered by 1.00 diopter, it is expected that the patient's heterophoria will change by 8 prism diopters. Because the accommodative system is stimulated, one would expect the heterophoria to become less exophoric or more esophoric. Given the above values, the patient's initial heterophoria is 4 prism diopters of exophoria, the AC/A ratio is 8/1, and the patient experienced 1.00 diopter of accommodation; therefore, the resultant heterophoria would be 4 prism diopters of esophoria.
PowerPage
Accommodative System Norms

questions.question: You are testing accommodation on your 44 year-old female patient. With an add power of +1.50 in place, the patient reports blur of the near target at 20cm in both the right and left eyes. Which of the following represents her true amplitude of accommodation?
questions.explanation:
To determine the amplitude of accommodation for each eye in adults, one eye is occluded while the subjective findings are left in place, and the patient is asked to focus on one or two lines above their visual acuity threshold on the reduced Snellen chart. The chart is brought closer to the patient until they report that the line first becomes blurry. This measurement is repeated with the other eye; the results are then converted from cm to diopters, yielding the near point of accommodation. 

If the amplitude of accommodation is measured with an add power in place, this amount must be subtracted from the initial findings to give the true amplitudes of accommodation. For example, the above patient reported that the chart became blurry 20cm from her eyes; 1/0.20= 5.0 diopters. Because she was looking through an additional reading power of 1.50 D, this must be subtracted from the total of 5 diopters, rendering her final amplitude of accommodation for both the right and left eye as 3.50 diopters.

questions.question: The near phoria at 40 cm for a patient wearing their spectacle lenses is 6 exophoria. +1.00 D is then placed over the patient's spectacles and the resulting phoria at 40 cm is measured as 9 exophoria. Based upon these clinical findings, what is the gradient AC/A ratio?
questions.explanation:
The gradient AC/A ratio allows for the determination of the magnitude of change in the ocular deviation as a result of stimulation or relaxation of the accommodative system by the introduction of ophthalmic lenses. The patient is asked to view a target at near (typically 40 cm) through the lenses that achieve the best corrected visual acuity, and the phoria is measured. +1.00 or -1.00 is then placed in front of the ophthalmic corrective lenses and the resultant phoria is re-measured (some clinicians use a +3.00 D lens). Plus-powered lenses relax the accommodative system, resulting in a decrease in accommodative convergence, while minus-powered lenses stimulate the accommodative system, thereby causing increased accommodative convergence and an increased eso deviation or a decreased exo deviation. The resulting AC/A ratio is then determined via the following formula: gradient AC/A= (deviation-deviation with lens)/power of lens in diopters. For the above question, the gradient AC/A is calculated as follows: (6-9)/1=-3/1. Conventionally, a minus sign indicates an increase in exodeviation or a decrease in esodeviation. Typically, AC/A ratios are given in absolute values. 

Pediatric Ophthalmology and Strabismus 2nd ed. Wright K. & Spiegel, P. Springer, 2003, page 199-200. 

Primary Care Optometry 5th edition. Grosvenor, T. Butterworth-Heinemann, 2007, page 235.

questions.question: The vertical recti muscles are inserted in front of the equator, creating what angle with the visual axis?
questions.explanation: The medial and lateral walls of the orbit are positioned at an angle of 45 degrees from each other. The orbital axis then forms an angle of 22.5 degrees with the medial and lateral walls (for the sake of simplicity, this angle is usually regarded as 23 degrees). Therefore, in primary gaze, the visual axis also forms an angle of 23 degrees with the orbital axis. The actions of all of the extraocular muscles depend on the position of the eye as each undergoes contraction. The vertical recti muscles run along the same line as the orbital axis, thereby also creating an angle of 23 degrees with the visual axis at their attachment point anterior to the equator. When the globe is abducted 23 degrees, the vertical recti muscles act purely to elevate or depress the eye.

questions.question: A patient is seen at your office reporting intermittent distance diplopia that is worse towards the end of the day. The diplopia is not present upon awakening. The patient was previously prescribed eye exercises but reports that he does not have time to perform them and wishes to purchase glasses with prism. Pertinent clinical findings include: Cover test 16 exophoria at 6 m and 4 exophoria at 40 cm. Vergences: Negative fusional convergence (NFC) at 6 m: x/12/8, Positive fusional convergence (PFC) at 6 m: x/4/2, Worth-4-Dot at 6 m: crossed diplopia that is neutralized with 6 base-in prism diopters. Based upon the above information, what amount of prism should be prescribed to help alleviate the patient's symptoms of diplopia?
questions.explanation:
Divergence excess presents with a high exophoria (or intermittent exotropia) at far and a smaller amount of exophoria (with a difference in magnitude between the distance and near phoria of roughly 10 prism diopters) or orthophoria at near. The patient will demonstrate decreased distance second degree fusion (they may experience suppression or diplopia), a high AC/A ratio and decreased distance positive fusional vergence ranges. Patients will report occasional distance diplopia or suppression (therefore likely asymptomatic), an eye that turns out when looking at distant targets (usually this will be noted by friends or the patient's parents) or squinting/ closing one eye in bright illumination. Patients may also experience asthenopia. 

When attempting to determine the appropriate amount of prism to prescribe, the majority of clinicians will opt for the smallest amount of prism that allows for fused and confortable binocular viewing by the patient. In the above question, the patient reported fusion on the Worth-4-Dot test with the placement of 6 base-in prism. 

Some clinicians follow Sheard's criterion, which states that the compensating relative fusional vergence reserve (blur point) should be at least twice the magnitude of the deviation in order to maintain comfortable binocular vision. 

Reference: http://www.revoptom.com/content/d/ophthalmic_lenses_and_dispensary/c/15234/

questions.question: What is the vergence demand using a Variable Tranaglyph when the separation is measured as 4 cm at a distance of 80 cm when training divergence?
questions.explanation:
The equation to calculate vergence demand is: 
demand = target separation in centimeters/training distance in meters 
demand = 4 cm/0.80 m 
demand = 5 prism diopters 

Because divergence is being trained in the above patient, the demand will be base-in. If convergence was being trained, the demand would be base-out.

questions.question: A patient who is orthophoric wears plano DS glasses with 3 base-out prism over each eye for three weeks. Which of the following phorias is this patient MOST likely to exhibit after three weeks of continuous wear?
questions.explanation:
The majority of patients will experience prism adaptation in which the vergence system will adapt to a small amount of lateral prism placed before the eyes. After several weeks of wear, the patient will manifest a phoria that is roughly the same magnitude as the adapting prism. The resulting phoria will be more esophoric (less exophoric) if the patient wears base-out prism and will be more exophoric (less esophoric) if the glasses contain base-in prism.
PowerPage
Vergence System Norms

questions.question: What term describes the process of maintaining foveal fixation between two objects that are separated by space?
questions.explanation: A saccade is defined as the situation in which one maintains foveal fixation between two objects (or more) that are separated by any distance. The objects can be static or moving but it is the rapid altering of fixation between the targets that is known as a saccade. A pursuit describes the event in which a person maintains foveal fixation on a single moving object. Pursuits tend to be smooth and fluid. A vergence is known as the situation in which the eyes move in opposite directions, as opposed to versions where the eyes both look left or right. In convergence both eyes turn in (nasal movement). With divergence both eyes turn outward (temporal movement). A phoria is known as the event that occurs when there is a deviation from conjugate gaze and occurs only in the absence of fusion.

questions.question: While examining a patient with diplopia, you ask her to look upward and toward her ear. She is able to move the eye toward her ear (laterally) but not up (while looking laterally). Based on the isolated agonist model of eye movement by extraocular muscles, which nerve and muscle are not functioning appropriately?
questions.explanation:
The oculomotor nerve has two divisions. The inferior division innervates the inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus; the superior division innervates the superior rectus and levator palpebrae superioris. The trochlear nerve (CN IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle. The abducens nerve (CN VI) innervates the lateral rectus. 

The functions of the extraocular muscles on the globe are as follows: 
Superior rectus - supraducts, adducts, and medially rotates the eye (intorsion) 
Inferior rectus - infraducts, adducts, and laterally rotates the eye (extorsion) 
Lateral rectus - abducts the eye 
Medial rectus - adducts the eye 
Superior oblique - medially rotates (intorsion), abducts and infraducts the eye 
Inferior oblique - laterally rotates (extorsion), abducts and supraducts the eye 

In the case described here, when the patient abducts the eye laterally with the lateral rectus as well as the superior and inferior obliques, only the superior rectus and inferior rectus can move the eye up or down respectively because the superior and inferior oblique muscles are already contracted. The same is true if a patient abducts the eye with the superior and inferior rectus muscles and the lateral rectus: only the superior and inferior obliques can move the eye down or up respectively.

questions.question: While examining a patient with diplopia, you ask him to look downward and toward his nose. He is able to move the eye toward his nose (medially) but not down. Based on the isolated agonist model of eye movement by extraocular muscles, which nerve and muscle are not functioning appropriately?
questions.explanation:
The trochlear nerve (CN IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle. The abducens nerve (CN VI) innervates the lateral rectus, which is not involved in the motion described in this question. The oculomotor nerve has two divisions; the inferior division innervates the inferior rectus, inferior oblique and medial rectus, while the superior division innervates the superior rectus and levator palpebrae superioris. 

The functions and anatomy of the extraocular muscles are as follows: 
Superior rectus - turns eye up, adducts, and medially rotates (intorsion) 
Inferior rectus - turns down, adducts, and laterally rotates (extorsion) 
Lateral rectus - abducts eye (laterally) 
Medial rectus - adducts eye (medially) 
Superior oblique - medially rotates (intorsion), abducts and turns eye down 
Inferior oblique - laterally rotates (extorsion), abducts and turns eye up 

In the case described here, when the patient adducts the eye medially with the medial rectus as well as the superior and inferior rectus, only the superior oblique and inferior oblique can move the eye down or up respectively because the superior and inferior rectus muscles are already contracted. The same is true if a patient abducts the eye with the obliques and lateral rectus: only the superior and inferior rectus can move the eye up or down respectively.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the secondary actions of the inferior rectus muscle?
questions.explanation:
The inferior rectus muscle originates at the lower portion of the annulus of Zinn and courses to its insertion site, which lies 6.8mm behind the inferior region of the limbus. The primary action of the inferior rectus is depression of the globe; its secondary actions include adduction and extorsion. 

It is also important to note that when the globe is abducted 23 degrees, the inferior rectus will act solely as a depressor. This is the optimal position of the globe if one wants to isolate the action of the inferior rectus.

questions.question: If a patient scores low on both the horizontal and vertical portions of the Developmental Eye Movement test (DEM), but the ratio and error scores are normal, what may be concluded regarding the patient's oculomotor function?
questions.explanation:
The DEM test consists of 3 subtests that should be given in a specific order. Subtests A and B are the vertical components, and Subtest C is the horizontal component. 
° The vertical time score is determined by adding the total time it takes to complete tests A and B 
° This score determines the automaticity of number calling ability 
° Does not require oculomotor control for vertical eye movements 
° The horizontal time score is determined by compensating the time it takes to complete test C for the presence of omission and addition errors 
° Horizontal time = Test C time x [80/(80 - o + a)] (wherein o = omission, a = addition) 
° This score evaluates number calling ability in a spatial array 
• Requires a sophisticated level of oculomotor control 
° The total errors are calculated by adding the occurrence of all individual errors 
° Total errors = (s + o + a + t errors) 
° s = substitution, o = omission, a = addition, t = transposition 
° The ratio score represents a convenient method for evaluating horizontal and vertical time simultaneously 
° Ratio scores that are significantly greater than expected normal values suggest a much greater difficulty in number naming when horizontal eye movements are required 

° If a patient scores low on the vertical subtest, this simply indicates a problem with naming numbers out loud (automaticity) 
° If the horizontal subtests are also lower than expected, this could indicate that the patient has difficulty with automaticity and/or oculomotor dysfunction 
° In these instances the ratio score helps differentiate the two 
• If ratio is normal -> patient has equal difficulty with horizontal and vertical subtests and the problem is automaticity 
• If the ratio is abnormal -> patient has more difficulty with the horizontal subtest as compared to the vertical subtest and the problem is both automaticity and oculomotor dysfunction
PowerPage
Ocular Motility Evaluation

questions.question: What is the MOST common accommodative dysfunction seen in the general population?
questions.explanation: Accommodative insufficiency is the most common accommodative dysfunction that the clinician will encounter, with accommodative excess and paralysis of accommodation being the least frequent.

questions.question: While performing the alternating occlusion balance test, your patient reports that her right eye is clearer than her left eye. Which of the following actions is the MOST appropriate at this time?
options: Add -0.25 D to the right eye
Add +0.25 D to the right eye
answers: Add +0.25 D to the right eye
questions.explanation: Alternating occlusion is frequently utilized as a binocular balance test and is performed during subjective refraction. Once each eye has undergone refraction, +0.50 is added to the spherical findings of each eye for fogging purposes. A line with the patient's threshold visual acuity is used as a target, and the patient is asked if the vision in each eye appears equal or if one eye yields a clearer visual acuity when the eyes are alternately occluded. If the patient reports that one eye affords a sharper image, +0.25 D is added to that eye. This process is continued until reversal occurs (the clearer eye now sees a blurrier image when compared to the other eye) or the patient reports that the images appear equally clear. Once equality is achieved, the patient is unfogged binocularly to achieve maximal visual acuity.

questions.question: You ask your patient to place a red lens in front of their right eye and proceed to perform the red lens test. Your patient reports seeing two images, with the red image being perceived to the right of the white light. What direction should you place the prism over the right eye to neutralize the phoria?
questions.explanation: The above scenario depicts an esophoria because the diplopia is uncrossed. Esophorias are neutralized with base out prisms. Remember, with tropias one must place the red lens over the fixating eye otherwise the chances are greater that the deviating eye will suppress the image.

questions.question: A 6-year old white male presents with a mild left head turn. Wet retinoscopy reveals OD: +0.25 OS: +0.50 with best corrected acuities of 20/20 in each eye. Extraocular movements show limited adduction of the left eye in right gaze. It is also noted that the left eye retracts with a narrowing of the eyelid fissure. What is the most appropriate diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
In this case, Duane Syndrome is suspected due to the presence of an extraocular muscle deficit and the additional sign of eye retraction and narrowing of the eyelid fissure. Duane Syndrome Type III is the most appropriate diagnosis due to the limited ADDuction of the affected eye on right gaze, along with the left head turn, which also implies limited ABDuction as well. 
Duane Syndrome Type I describes limited ABDuction of the affected eye (the most common) as well as a possible compensatory head turn toward the involved side. 
Duane Syndrome Type II describes limited ADDuction of the affected eye, as well as a possible compensatory head turn toward the uninvolved side. 
Duane Syndrome Type III describes limited ABDuction AND limited ADDuction of the affected eye. It also usually presents with a compensatory head turn toward the involved side. 
A good way to remember the difference between the three types is that type I results in an aBDuction deficit (aBDuction has one D therefore it is type I). 
Type II causes an aDDuction deficit (aDDuction has two Ds therefore it is type II). Type III has three Ds, aBDuction and aDDuction-the number of the types matches the number of Ds in the deficit. 

Brown syndrome describes a limitation of elevation in adduction. It is a limitation of the superior oblique tendon.

questions.question: You are performing an alternating cover test on your 15 year-old patient with a history of strabismus surgery as a young child. Her eyes now appear straight in primary gaze; however, you notice that as you uncover the right eye, it drifts down to re-fixate. The same occurs when you uncover the left eye. What is the name of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Dissociated vertical deviation (DVD) is an ocular condition that is commonly accompanied by a history of strabismus, most notably infantile esotropia. The exact etiology and pathophysiology of a dissociated vertical deviation is unknown; however, we do know that 'dissociation' refers to the idea that the innervation of one eye causes it to move involuntarily and independently of the contralateral eye. This process does not obey the common laws of innervation, in which both eyes typically move together. 

Characteristics of a dissociated vertical deviation include the presence of an up-drift with accompanying excyclorotation of the eye that can occur either spontaneously or when under cover (during a cover-test). When the cover is removed, the eye will then move down to fixation without a simultaneous corresponding down-drift of the fellow eye. This condition is most commonly bilateral, although it may be asymmetrical.

questions.question: A 23-year old female is seen at your office with concerns of eye fatigue, diplopia and headaches after 30 minutes of computer use. Her subjective refraction is +0.25 D OU. Her near point of convergence is 15 centimeters. What is the most likely diagnosis based solely upon this information?
questions.explanation:
The most notable of the exam findings is the near point of convergence (NPC) -generally one expects an NPC of less than 6cm (closer is better with NPC). Her NPC is receded to 15 cm. Normally, if patients display a receded NPC but they are asymptomatic, no treatment is necessary. In the above case, the patient is experiencing diplopia and asthenopia with prolonged near work which infers some type of intervention may be required (likely vision therapy). Brain tumors typically present as headaches that are present in the morning and worsen over a time period of weeks to months. Latent hyperopia normally presents as blurry vision and headaches with prolonged near work, but diplopia is generally absent.
PowerPage
Vergence Dysfunctions

questions.question: Evaluation of extraocular motility (versions) tests the integrity of the motor function of which of the following nerves?
options: Cranial nerves III, IV, and VI
Cranial nerves II, III and V
Cranial nerves II, IV and V
Cranial nerves I, VII and X
Cranial nerves VI, VII and X
answers: Cranial nerves III, IV, and VI
questions.explanation: Extraocular motility (versions) assesses the integrity of the motor aspect of cranial nerves III (oculomotor), IV (trochlear), and VI (abducens).

questions.question: A patient with a high AC/A ratio (8/1) displays esophoria at a 6 m distance. Based on the AC/A ratio, how would you expect the phoria to change as the target is brought closer to the patient?
questions.explanation: The AC/A ratio denotes the amount of change to convergence resulting from a change in accommodation. If a patient possesses a high AC/A ratio (6/1 is considered the normal range), a one-diopter increase in accommodation will theoretically cause a greater increase in convergence. Regardless of the initial phoria, with decreasing viewing distance the phoria will become more eso (or less exo). The opposite holds true for a low AC/A ratio (less than 6/1); as the target gets closer, the resultant phoria becomes more exo or less eso.

questions.question: A patient with a low AC/A ratio (2/1) displays exophoria at a 6 m distance. Based on the AC/A ratio, how would you expect the phoria to change as the target is brought closer to the patient?
questions.explanation: The AC/A ratio denotes the amount of change to convergence resulting from a change in accommodation. Regardless of the initial phoria, with decreasing viewing distance the phoria will become more exo (or less eso) for a patient who exhibits a low AC/A ratio. The opposite holds true for a high AC/A ratio (greater than 6/1); as the target gets closer, the resultant phoria becomes more eso or less exo.

questions.question: In addition to accommodation, which 2 of the following physiological responses comprise the near reflex (accommodative triad)? (Select 2)
questions.explanation: In an effort to focus at near, a young eye will undergo three physiologic responses: accommodation, constriction of the pupils (miosis), and convergence of the eyes. These three changes are known as the near reflex, or accommodative triad. Studies have also shown that intraocular pressure (IOP) can increase in response to accommodation (which is why we ask patients to look in the distance when measuring IOP), but this is not part of the classic triad.

questions.question: When asking your patient to 'look up and to the right,' which of the following types of versions must your patient make?
questions.explanation:
Versions are eye movements that are considered binocular, simultaneous, and conjugate (in the same direction) and are described below. 
Dextroversion: gaze right; Levoversion: gaze left 
Elevation: upgaze; Depression: down gaze 
Dextroelevation: gaze up and right; Levoelevation: gaze up and left 
Dextrodepression: gaze down and right; Levodepression: gaze down and left 
Dextrocycloversion: torsional movement right; Levocycloversion: torsional movement left

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an ocular vergence?
options: Directing the patient to maintain their focus on the target of regard while assessing the patient's near point of convergence (NPC)
Placing 3.0 base-out prism over the patient's right eye and 3.0 base-in prism over the patient's left eye and directing the patient's gaze to maintain fixation on a centrally located target
Having the patient look upwards when performing forced duction testing
Asking the patient to look to their left when performing an assessment of the patient's extraocular motility
answers: Directing the patient to maintain their focus on the target of regard while assessing the patient's near point of convergence (NPC)
questions.explanation: Binocular eye movements are categorized as versions or vergences. A version is characterized by movement of both eyes that is equal in magnitude and in the same direction (for example, looking to the left) for both eyes. A vergence is the movement of both eyes in opposite directions; for example, when reading a book, binocular fixation is maintained by convergence (the rotation of both eyes towards the mid-line). In the above question, the only example of a vergence would be the resulting convergence during evaluation of the NPC. Directing the patient's gaze superiorly or to the left are examples of versions. Placing prism over the patient's eyes can result in vergence but only if the prisms cause the image to move in different directions or unequal magnitudes for each eye. In the above instance, the prism will shift the image in the same direction for each eye, producing a version of equal magnitude for each eye in order to maintain fixation.

questions.question: In order to maintain binocular fixation and fusion on a target that is moved away from the patient in a linear fashion, assuming the target moves in one plane only, which of the following ocular movements must occur?
options: Dextroversion of the right eye and levoversion of the left eye
questions.explanation: In order to maintain fixation on a target that is moved away from the patient, his eyes must diverge (rotate outwards away from the midline). A vergence is a binocular movement of the eyes such that the eyes move in opposite directions. A version is a binocular eye movement in which the eyes move in the same direction and of equal magnitude. Infraversion is a movement where both eyes look downwards. Although during divergence, the right eye technically moves slightly to the right (away from the midline) and the left eye moves slightly to the left (away from the midline) these movements cannot be termed dextroversion and levoversion respectively as a version infers movement of the eyes in the same direction. Supravergence is the movement of one eye upwards with respect to the other.

questions.question: While performing the Worth-4-dot test (red lens placed over right eye), your patient reports seeing 3 green circles to the left of two red circles. Based on the above findings, what is the correct extrapolation?
questions.explanation: In the Worth-4-dot test, the red lens is generally placed in front of the right eye. Four dots are then projected onto the screen. The two horizontal circles are green, the top circle is white and the bottom circle is red (in most cases). Assuming the patient possesses simultaneous perception, the right eye alone views the bottom and the top circle as red and pink/red respectively. The left eye views three green circles. Combined, both eyes view four circles, two appear green, one lower appears red and the upper one appears red/green. Three green circles viewed to the right of two red circles indicate crossed diplopia (exophoria). The perception of three green circles viewed to the left of two red circles is indicative of uncrossed diplopia (esophoria). The perception of three green circles alone is indicative of right eye suppression. If the patient reports viewing two red circles, this indicates suppression of the left eye.

questions.question: What is the MOST common type of oculomotor deviation?
questions.explanation: By far the most common oculomotor deviations are exo in nature ( about 95%), however most do not pose a problem. The least common type of deviation is vertical.

questions.question: Convergence of the eyes occurs with which of the following?
options: Extortion of one eye and intorsion of the other
Adduction of one eye and abduction of the other
questions.explanation: In vergence movements, the eyes move in opposite directions. In convergence, both eyes adduct (move medially). In divergence, both eyes abduct (move laterally). Intortion of both eyes is known as incyclovergence. If the left eye abducts and the right eye adducts, both eyes are moving to the patient's left; this is called levoversion. If the right eye abducts and the left eye adducts, both eyes are moving right and this is called dextroversion.

questions.question: During administration of the red lens test your patient initially reports a red light and a white light which then fuse and appear as a pink light after 5 seconds of viewing. This type of response is classified as what grade of fusion?
questions.explanation: Grade B fusion describes the event in which fusion is preceeded by momentary diplopia. Grade A fusion is the normal response and is depicted by instant fusion. Grade C fusion is defined as constant diplopia with the absence of fusion. Grade D is observed when one eye is suppressed or the eyes alternately suppress resulting in the perception of only one light at a time.

questions.question: Accommodative testing on your 8 year-old male patient while wearing his distance correction reveals the following: negative relative accommodation (NRA): +2.75 D; positive relative accommodation (PRA): -0.75. Amplitudes of accommodation are OD/OS respectively 7D/7D. Which of the following should be considered in the above patient's care when prescribing vision correction?
options: He should be prescribed contact lenses in lieu of glasses
He should be prescribed bifocal or progressive addition lenses (PALS)
He should be prescribed CR-39 lenses because of his high ametropia
He should be advised to remove his glasses when performing near activities
answers: He should be prescribed bifocal or progressive addition lenses (PALS)
questions.explanation:
Because the patient displays low accommodative capabilities (due to a low PRA and low amplitudes of accommodation), he should be prescribed a reading addition, whether it be via PALS or a bifocal lens. Patients with accommodative insufficiency will report blurry vision, headaches, avoidance or irritability, or a lack of concentration with sustained near tasks. Having the patient perform near activities through his full distance correction causes strain and stress on his accommodative system, resulting in the above symptoms. In the presence of decreased accommodative amplitudes (lower than what is expected for the patient's age) and low PRA readings, which indirectly measures fusional vergence (less than -1.50 D, taking into account the patient's age) it is best to prescribe a reading addition to decrease the strain on his accommodative system. For patients with lower amounts of ametropia it is appropriate to have them remove their glasses to read; however, in the above case the patient's near point is roughly 17cm (1/-5.75 OD only), and this is too close for the patient to hold his reading material/homework. Therefore, this is not an appropriate option for him. He should be prescribed polycarbonate lenses for both aesthetic and safety purposes. Lastly, although he would benefit from an increased field of view and less image minification if he were to be fit with contact lenses, the accommodative demand would be increased; and wearing of reading glasses over his contact lenses or bifocal contact lenses would be necessary to keep him symptom-free.
PowerPage
Accommodative System Norms

questions.question: Which of the following laws describes the concept of equal innervation, in which equal and simultaneous innervation flows to the yoke muscles during conjugate eye movements?
questions.explanation: During conjugate eye movement, equal innervation is supplied to the yoke muscles (contralateral synergists), which both act to move the eyes into the same direction of gaze. This concept is known as Hering's law.

questions.question: How will over-correction of myopia change the observed near phoria?
options: Increase esophoria or reduce the exophoria measured
Decrease esophoria or increase the exophoria measured
Increase exophoria and increase the esophoria measured
The resultant phoria will not change
answers: Increase esophoria or reduce the exophoria measured
questions.explanation: Over-correction of myopia stimulates accommodation. As the viewing distance decreases, the eyes will converge reflexively (accommodative convergence). In addition to the expected accommodative convergence, there will be increased convergence as the eye accommodates to bring the target in focus compensating for the distance over-correction. This over-convergence will either cause increased esophoria or reduce the amount of exophoria present.

questions.question: Which of the following subnuclei of the third cranial nerve innervates its corresponding contralateral muscle?
questions.explanation:
The nuclear complex of the oculomotor nerve resides in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus. It is composed of paired and unpaired subnuclei that innervate their corresponding muscles on either the ipsilateral or contralateral sides. 

The medial rectus subnuclei, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique subnuclei are paired subnuclei (meaning that there is one on each side) and they innervate their corresponding muscles on the ipsilateral side. Lesions involving this area will result in ipsilateral medial rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique weakness. 

The superior rectus subnuclei are also paired; however, they innervate their respective contralateral superior rectus muscle. Therefore, a lesion affecting the third nerve nuclear complex will spare the ipsilateral superior rectus and will involve the contralateral superior rectus. 

The levator subnucleus is the only subnucleus that is unpaired. It lies in the caudal midline and innervates both levator muscles. Lesions in this area will result in bilateral ptosis.

questions.question: The tendon of which extraocular muscle courses through the trochlea?
questions.explanation: The superior oblique muscle originates on the lesser wing of the sphenoid near the frontoethmoid suture. The tendon of insertion begins about 1 cm behind the trochlea (a U-shaped piece of cartilage attached to the orbital plate of the frontal bone) and changes directions as it passes through the trochlea to run in a posterior direction, causing the trochlea to act as the effective origin of the superior oblique muscle, acting as a pulley. The superior oblique muscle is innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV).

questions.question: A 57-year old woman has developed signs of ophthalmoplegia, maxillary sensory loss, and a fixed dilated pupil. These signs are most consistent with damage to which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
The cavernous sinus is a large venous channel on each side of the body of the sphenoid extending from the medial end of the superior orbital fissure to the petrous portion of the temporal bone and lateral to the sella turcica. The internal carotid artery and the abducens nerve (CN VI) are located within the medial portion of the sinus. The oculomotor (CN III), trochlear (CN IV), ophthalmic, and maxillary branches of the trigeminal (CN V) are found within the lateral portion. The cavernous sinus is the only location where an artery travels through a venous structure such that a rupture of the internal carotid artery within the cavernous sinus creates an arteriovenous fistula. Cavernous sinus syndrome usually results from pituitary masses or other masses compressing this region although it can also occur secondary to infectious, inflammatory, vascular, or traumatic causes that disrupt the nerves travelling through the sinus causing ophthalmoplegia, maxillary sensory loss, and a fixed, dilated pupil. Tolusa-Hunt syndrome (THS) is an inflammatory condition within the cavernous sinus or superior orbital fissure causing damage to the structures in those regions. 

The internal auditory (or acoustic) meatus is a canal in the petrous portion of the temporal bone through which the facial (CN VII) and vestibulocochlear nerves (CN VIII) and the labyrinthine artery travel. Damage to these structures can result in deafness and facial muscle paralysis. Acoustic neuromas will commonly expand the internal auditory meatus and damage these structures. Other signs may include tinnitus or vertigo. 

The crus cerebri is the anterior portion of the cerebral peduncle containing the efferent motor tracts. Damage to the crus cerebri usually results in paralysis to a region of the body. The other tract of the cerebral peduncles is the tegmentum. This coordinates movement and when damaged, results in jerky movements. 

The supraorbital foramen lies under the eyebrow above the orbit and transmits the supraorbital nerve, artery, and vein. It is believed by some to be an important acupressure point for relief of headache pain. 

The annulus of Zinn, also known as the common tendinous ring, is a ring of fibrous tissue around the optic nerve where it enters at the apex of the orbit. It is the origin of several of the extraocular muscles. The annulus of Zinn can be divided into an upper and lower portion. The lower portion is known as the ligament (or tendon) of Zinn which gives rise to the rectus inferior and part of the rectus internus and rectus lateralis. The upper portion is known as the superior tendon of Lockwood and is the origin of the rectus superior, rectus medialis, and part of the rectus lateralis.

questions.question: What is the primary action of the inferior oblique extraocular muscle?
questions.explanation: The inferior oblique muscle originates just behind the orbital rim lateral to the lacrimal sac. It courses backwards and laterally to its insertion point, which lies in the posterior inferior temporal quadrant of the globe. The primary action of the inferior oblique is extorsion, while its secondary actions include elevation and abduction.

questions.question: Torsional eye movements account for the maintenance of an upright image when a person tilts his or her head to either side. Upon head tilt to the right, which of the following torsional movements occur in the right and left eye, respectively?
questions.explanation: Also known as righting reflexes, torsional eye movements occur in order to maintain upright images when a person tilts his or her head either right or left. In the case of right head tilt, the superior limbus of each eye will rotate to the left. This causes intorsion of the right eye and extorsion of the left eye. The opposite will occur when the head is tilted to the left.

questions.question: Nerve fibers from the trochlear nucleus innervate which of the following extraocular muscles?
questions.explanation:
The trochlear nucleus is located at the level of the inferior colliculus. Nerve fibers from this area decussate to innervate the contralateral superior oblique muscle via the cavernous sinus and superior orbital fissure. 

The abducens nucleus innervates the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle. 

The oculomotor nucleus innervates the ipsilateral medial rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique, as well as the contralateral superior rectus. 

Localization in Clinical Neurology (Sixth Edition). Brazis, P.W., Masdeu, J.C., Biller, J. 2011. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. Philadelphia, PA. 

The Neurology of Eye Movements (Third Edition). Leigh, R.J, Zee, D.S. 1999. Oxford University Press Inc. New York, NY.

questions.question: Nerve fibers from the abducens nucleus innervate which of the following extraocular muscles?
questions.explanation:
The nucleus of the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) is located in the dorsal lower portion of the pons. Motor neuron axons from the abducens nerve course from this location to the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle via the cavernous sinus and superior orbital fissure. Additionally, interneurons also traverse from the abducens nucleus to the opposite medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) and terminate at the oculomotor nucleus, thus coordinating horizontal gaze movements of both eyes. 

The trochlear nucleus innervates the contralateral superior oblique muscle. 

The oculomotor nucleus innervates the ipsilateral medial rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique, as well as the contralateral superior rectus. 

Localization in Clinical Neurology (Sixth Edition). Brazis, P.W., Masdeu, J.C., Biller, J. 2011. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. Philadelphia, PA.

questions.question: Which 4 of the following are innervated by cranial nerve III? (Select 4)
questions.explanation:
Cranial nerve III (oculomotor nerve) controls the levator palpebrae superioris, the iris sphincter, the superior rectus, the medial rectus, the inferior rectus, the inferior oblique, and the ciliary muscle. The lateral rectus is innervated by cranial nerve VI (the abducens). The superior oblique is controlled by cranial nerve IV (trochlear nerve). 

A cranial nerve III palsy will result in an eye that appears down (hypotropia) and out (exotropia) with a large ptosis, which may or may not be accompanied by a dilated pupil. Pupil involvement generally signals the presence of an aneurysm; an aneurysm requires an immediate referral to the emergency room.

questions.question: If accommodation is increased by adding minus powered lenses while the patient is fixating a stationary target, what occurs to the resulting phoria?
options: It becomes more exophoric in nature
It becomes less esophoric in nature
It becomes more esophoric in nature
The resultant phoria will not change
answers: It becomes more esophoric in nature
questions.explanation: In a normal visual system convergence and accommodation work together. If accommodation is increased convergence is stimulated as well. This causes the measured phoria to become more esophoric or less exophoric.

questions.question: As the interpupillary distance increases what happens to the amount of convergence (in prism diopters) needed to maintain fusion for a near target ?
options: In decreases, but only for targets closer than 4 cm
It increases, but only for targets closer than 4 cm
questions.explanation: There is a direct correlation between the amount of convergence necessary to maintain fusion on a near target and interpupillary distance (IPD). As the IPD increases, so does the amount of convergence required to maintain fusion. Logically, this makes sense: if the eyes are further apart then they must rotate to a greater degree around the horizontal axis to maintain fusion if the target distance remains the same.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the angle subtended by the visual and anatomical axes of the human eye?
questions.explanation: Angle kappa represents the angle subtended by the visual and anatomical axes of the eye. The visual axis is a line that passes from the center of the fovea, through the nodal point of the eye, and to the point of fixation. The anatomical axis of the eye is a line that passes from the center of the posterior pole through the center of the cornea. Because of the fact that the fovea is typically slightly temporal to the anatomical center of the eye, these 2 axes do not usually line up perfectly. The difference between these is angle kappa. Angle kappa is commonly about 5 degrees and is positive when the fovea is aligned temporally to the center of the posterior pole (resulting in a nasal displacement of the corneal reflex).

questions.question: While performing the bichrome test with the left eye occluded, the patient initially reports that the letters on the red side appear bolder, blacker and sharper. -0.25 D is then placed before the right eye and the patient reports that the letters on the green side now appear clearer. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate next step?
options: Leave the findings in the phoropter, occlude the right eye and proceed to the left eye
Add +0.25 D over the right eye
Re-explain the goal of the test, as the patient is likely unclear as to the test instructions
Add an additional -0.25 D over the right eye
answers: Add +0.25 D over the right eye
questions.explanation:
The bichrome test is performed by occluding one eye and projecting letters on a red and green background. The patient is initially fogged by roughly + 0.50 D. Fogging over-plusses the patient and shifts the chromatic interval forwards (causing objects projected on a background with longer wavelengths (red) to be bolder) such that the patient should report that the letters are blacker and bolder on the red side of the chart. The addition of minus lenses should equate the two sides such that the letters appear equally black and bold on the red and green sides. If the patient initially reports that the letters on the green side are bolder, then either plus lenses need to be added or minus powered lenses need to be reduced to shift the chromatic interval forwards. If the patient does not report equal boldness/blackness/sharpness of the letters on the green and red sides of the chart but instead instantly reports reversal upon switching lenses, the majority of clinicians will leave the power of the lens in the phoropter at the setting where the patient last reported that the letters on the red side of the chart appeared bolder/blacker to minimize the chances of over-minussing the patient. 

Clinical Optics and Refraction. A Guide for Optometrist, Contact Lens Opticians and Dispensing Opticians. Evans, B., Franklin, A. & Harvey, W. Bailliere, Tindall and Elsevier, 2007, page 108.

questions.question: Which of the following extraocular muscles is considered the antagonist pairing to the right lateral rectus?
questions.explanation: Agonist-antagonist extraocular muscle pairs are those muscles of the same eye that move the eye in opposite directions. The agonist muscle is the primary muscle that contracts to move the eye in a given direction. The antagonist is the muscle of the ipsilateral eye that acts to move the eye in the opposite direction when contracted. Therefore, in this question, the agonist is the right lateral rectus, which moves the eye to the right, and the antagonist is the right medial rectus, which will move the eye to the left if contracted.

questions.question: Which of the following presentations of Duane's retraction syndrome occurs most frequently?
options: Limited abduction and adduction, straight or slight esotropia in primary gaze
Limited abduction, nearly normal adduction, straight or slight esotropia in primary gaze
Limited adduction, nearly normal abduction, straight or slight esotropia in primary gaze
Limited abduction, nearly normal adduction, straight or slight exotropia in primary gaze
Limited adduction, nearly normal abduction, straight or slight exotropia in primary gaze
Limited abduction and adduction, straight or slight exotropia in primary gaze
answers: Limited abduction, nearly normal adduction, straight or slight esotropia in primary gaze
questions.explanation:
The most common form of Duane's retraction syndrome is Type 1 (~85%), which is characterized by either straight eyes in primary gaze or a slight esotropia. These patients will also exhibit limited or absent abduction of the affected eye during extraocular muscle evaluation, with normal or mildly limited adduction of the same eye. 

Type 2 is the least common presentation of Duane's retraction syndrome in which the eyes are either straight or slightly exotropic in primary gaze. Adduction is more limited than abduction in these patients. 

Duane's retraction syndrome Type 3 is characterized by a significant limitation of both adduction and abduction, accompanied by either straight eyes in primary gaze or a slight esotropia. 

Duane's retraction syndrome is often bilateral; however, the involvement of one eye is typically much less apparent. Some children will also present with other congenital defects such as perceptive deafness or a speech disorder.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following signs are commonly associated with a third cranial nerve palsy? (Select 3)
options: Limited depression of the involved eye
Eye is adducted in the primary position of gaze
Intact accommodation in the involved eye
Weakness of Mueller's muscle causing profound ptosis
Intorsion of the eye, which increases on attempted downgaze
Normal abduction of the involved eye
answers: Limited depression of the involved eye
Intorsion of the eye, which increases on attempted downgaze
Normal abduction of the involved eye
questions.explanation:
Third cranial nerve palsies will involve weakness of the superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique extraocular muscles, along with involvement of the levator, pupil sphincter, and accommodative fibers. Common signs of a third nerve palsy include the following: 
- Profound ptosis due to weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris 
- The involved eye is abducted in primary gaze due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus (medial rectus is weak) 
- The eye will also exhibit intorsion at rest that increases on attempted downgaze due to the superior oblique muscle remaining intact 
- Abduction is normal due to the lateral rectus remaining intact, while adduction is limited due to involvement of the medial rectus 
- Elevation is limited due to involvement of the superior rectus and inferior oblique (in primary gaze the eye will appear depressed in addition to abducted) 
- Depression is also limited due to weakness of the inferior rectus 
- A dilated pupil, along with defective accommodation, is also possible due to damage of parasympathetic fibers 
- These signs will vary in severity due to the degree of involvement of the nerve fibers

questions.question: Which of the following muscle pairings and actions follows Sherrington's law of reciprocal innervation?
options: Looking to the right causes contraction of the right medial rectus and contraction of the left medial rectus
Looking to the right causes contraction of the right medial rectus and inhibition of the right lateral rectus
Looking to the right causes contraction of the right lateral rectus and inhibition of the left medial rectus
Looking to the right causes contraction of the right lateral rectus and inhibition of the right medial rectus
answers: Looking to the right causes contraction of the right lateral rectus and inhibition of the right medial rectus
questions.explanation: Sherrington's law of reciprocal innervation states that when a muscle is stimulated to contract, its antagonist is inhibited. Based upon this law, looking to the right causes contraction of the right lateral rectus and inhibition of the right medial rectus.

questions.question: The diagnosis and classification of a phoria requires quantification of which of the following? (Select three)
options: Direction of the deviation (exo, eso, hyper)
answers: Direction of the deviation (exo, eso, hyper)
questions.explanation: Phorias are typically specified by magnitude (amount measured in prism diopters), location (distance or near), and direction (esophoria, exophoria, hyperphoria). Phorias are equal between the eyes and are constant; therefore, frequency and laterality are classifications that apply only to the quantification of tropias.

questions.question: Which of the following congenital extraocular muscle disorders occurs as a result of failure of innervation of the lateral rectus muscle by the sixth cranial nerve, accompanied by anomalous innervation of the lateral rectus by fibers from the third cranial nerve?
questions.explanation:
Duane's retraction syndrome occurs as a result of a developmental error in innervation of the lateral rectus muscle. The sixth cranial nerve fails to innervate the lateral rectus muscle, while at the same time fibers from the third cranial nerve inappropriately innervate the lateral rectus. It is common for this dysinnervation to affect both eyes; however, the involvement of one eye tends to be much more subtle. 

The clinical signs leading to the diagnosis of this condition include the following extraocular motility defects of the affected eye: 
- Restricted abduction, which may be partial or complete. 
- Restricted adduction, which is usually partial. 
- This occurs secondary to opposing muscles (lateral and medial recti) being innervated by the same nerve, limiting the eye's ability to move. 
- Retraction of the globe on adduction, which occurs as a result of co-contraction of the medial and lateral rectus muscles, leading to narrowing of the palpebral fissure; on abduction the globe will assume its natural position and the palpebral fissure will open. 
- Up-shoots or down-shoots on attempted adduction can occur in some cases. This is thought to be caused by a tight lateral rectus muscle that can slip either over or under the globe, producing an anomalous vertical movement of the eye upon co-contraction of the medial and lateral recti. 
- Convergence deficiency, in which the affected eye remains fixed in primary position while the contralateral eye converges.

questions.question: During case history, your 47 year-old Caucasian female patient reports to you that she occasionally manifests double vision in certain fields of gaze. She is taking Tapazole® for Grave's disease and has no other ocular or systemic health issues. Restriction of which of the following extraocular muscles would you MOST likely expect to be causing her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Thyroid-related orbitopathy associated with Grave's disease (hyperthyroidism) manifests itself through several pathologic features, including the progressive enlargement of the extraocular muscles. This inflammation is mediated through release of cytokines, fibroblast proliferation, increased deposition of extracellular matrix, and differentiation and proliferation of adipocytes, and tends to target the muscles of the eye. Studies have shown that the inferior rectus muscle is preferentially affected in these patients, often resulting in diplopia on upgaze. The second most commonly affected muscle is the medial rectus, followed by the superior rectus then lateral rectus (obliques are rarely targeted). These patients often experience diplopia, proptosis, and orbital pain, and may require surgical intervention. 

An easy way to remember the order of affected muscles in thyroid eye diseases is 'I MuScLes': Inferior, Medial, Superior, Lateral.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following extra-ocular muscles are supplied by the LATERAL muscular branch of the ophthalmic artery? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
The medial muscular branch of the ophthalmic artery supplies the medial rectus, inferior rectus, and the inferior oblique extra-ocular muscles, while the lateral muscular branch supplies the superior rectus, superior oblique, lateral rectus, and levator palpebrae superioris. 

Surgical Techniques in Ophthalmology: Pediatric Ophthalmic Surgery. Garg, A., Alio, J.L. (2011). Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers

questions.question: Which of the following is considered the GREATEST advantage to performing a cycloplegic refraction/retinoscopy?
options: Minimized brightness of the red reflex thereby enhancing contrast
Decreased resultant spherical aberration during retinoscopy
Better control of the patient's accommodative response
Increased accuracy of cylinder axis refinement with retinoscopy
answers: Better control of the patient's accommodative response
questions.explanation:
Cycloplegic agents are used to inhibit the action of the ciliary body, thereby essentially temporarily eliminating the ability to accommodate. A cycloplegic refraction/retinoscopy is useful for non-verbal, non-cooperative, or non-responsive patients. In the event that the patient's reflex fluctuates during retinoscopy, retinoscopy reveals more 'plus power' than the refraction, or the patient's visual acuity is less than expected in the absence of pathology or developmental issues, cycloplegic drops should be instilled. The drops should also be used if the patient is esotropic or if latent hyperopia is suspected. When performing cycloplegic retinoscopy/refraction, it is important to focus on the center of the pupil, as spherical aberrations increase with pupil mydriasis; this can make it difficult to obtain an accurate retinoscopy assessment as well as cause difficulty with axis refinement. 

Ophthalmic Clinical Procedures: A Multimedia Guide. Eperjesi, F., Bartlett, H. & Dunn, M. Butterman, Heinemann & Elsevier, 2007, page 47.

questions.question: Which 3 tests directly examine the accommodative system? (Select 3)
options: Monocular facility testing with +/- 2.00 D lenses
answers: Monocular facility testing with +/- 2.00 D lenses
questions.explanation:
MEM measures the accuracy of the accommodative response to a given target. Monocular amplitudes and monocular facility also evaluate the performance of the accommodative system. 

PFC measures the interaction between the accommodative and the vergence system. 

Stereopsis is a product of binocular retinal disparity. Stereopsis is not a measure of accommodation but serves to evaluate the capability of the eyes to work in unison. Although accommodation must be accounted for when performing this test, stereopsis will not quantify any type of accommodative dysfunction. Stereopsis as a cue to depth works best if the objects are not too far away. In order for stereopsis to occur, the retinal disparity must be within a certain limit to result in a perception of depth. 

Second-degree fusion is the ability to superimpose like objects (not necessarily identical objects), with the end result being the perception of a single object that is a composition of the two separate images. The Worth 4 dot is an example of a test that evaluates second-degree fusion. Second-degree fusion evaluates if the eyes are capable of working together and does not measure accommodative capability.
PowerPage
Accommodative System Norms

questions.question: Retraction or lagging of the upper eyelid while looking in down gaze is referred to as which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
Von Graefe's sign occurs in Grave's disease (thyroid dysfunction). This term refers to the incomplete ability of the eyelid to move down when the globe is directed in a down gaze. It is often described as a lagging of the upper eyelid-not because it sags but because it lags behind movement-wise. The greater the down gaze, the greater the bearing of the sclera. Von Graefe's sign results from excessive innervation of the sympathetic system which causes upper lid retraction via the muscle of Mueller. 

Collier's sign is also known as a tucked lid due to extreme upper lid retraction in primary gaze which stems from a lesion of cranial nerve III at the posterior commissure. This is very rare. 

Myerson's sign occurs in people who are suffering from Parkinson's disease and in all infants younger than 2 months of age. Most people when tapped between the eyes can inhibit themselves from blinking. Patients with Parkinson's cannot inhibit the facial reflex and will always blink, which is referred to as Myerson's sign. The facial reflex is as follows: tap proximal to orbit-> ophthalmic division or maxillary division of trigeminal (depends on the location of tapping) ->midbrain->pons->stimulation of orbicularis, inhibition of levator palpebrae superioris. 

Horner's syndrome results from a disruption of the sympathetic innervation to the eye either due to a lesion or mass located either post-ganglionically or pre-ganglionically. The classic triad of signs seen in a patient suffering from Horner's syndrome is miosis, a small ptosis and anhidrosis (lack of sweat) on one side of the head.

questions.question: A patient diagnosed with a fusional vergence dysfunction presents to your office. If a forced vergence fixation disparity curve were to be plotted for this patient, which of the following curves would one MOST likely expect to see?
options: Normal curve width, but shifted up
Normal curve width, but shifted down
Very narrow curve with a small flat zone
Very wide curve with a large flat zone
answers: Very narrow curve with a small flat zone
questions.explanation:
Forced vergence fixation disparity curves are used to evaluate the efficiency of a patient's disparity vergence system by observing how fixation disparity changes when different amounts of base-in and base-out prism are introduced to the eyes. 

Patients with fusional vergence dysfunction typically exhibit the following: 
°Normal phorias at distance and near 
°Normal AC/A ratio 
°Reduced positive fusional vergence and negative fusional vergence at both distance and near 
°Reduced positive relative accommodation and negative relative accommodation (indirect measurement of fusional vergence) 
°Reduced accommodative facility 

Studies have shown that the prevalence of fusional vergence dysfunction is just under that of convergence excess and convergence insufficiency (1-2%). Patients often first notice this problem when asthenopia occurs, usually at near. Patients may complain of eyestrain and headaches after short periods of reading, blurred vision, difficulty concentrating, and sleepiness when performing near tasks. The etiology of this condition remains uncertain; also, it can easily be overlooked due to the fact that accommodation and phorias typically present within normal ranges. 

Important points regarding forced vergence fixation disparity curves: 
°The Y-intercept represents fixation disparity 
°Eso fixation disparity is a positive value (shifted upward) 
°Exo fixation disparity is a negative value (shifted downward) 
°The X-intercept represents the associated heterophoria 
°Base-out is to the right 
°Base-in is to the left 
°The flatter the slope, the better the eyes are able to adapt to vergence demands 
°A steeper slope indicates poor adaptation 

In a patient with fusional vergence dysfunction, a plotted fixation disparity curve will typically exhibit a very narrow curve with a small flat zone, indicating poor vergence adaptation and a relatively small zone of clear and single binocular vision.
PowerPage
Vergence System Norms

questions.question: While performing the monocular crossed cylinder test on your patient in order to properly balance accommodation, he reports a difference of 1.50 D between the right and left eye. Based upon these results, what should be your next step?
options: Nothing, this is an expected result
Re-check the distance subjective refraction balance test
Conclude that the patient has 1.50 D of anisometropia
answers: Re-check the distance subjective refraction balance test
questions.explanation: When performing the monocular cross cylinder balance test, there should be no more than 0.50 D difference between the eyes. If the resultant difference is higher, then one should re-balance the subjective refraction as one eye is likely over-accommodating. Even if the patient does require unequal adds, given the above results one should first confirm by re-checking the subjective refraction balance. It is very rare that a patient requires unequal adds. Lastly, anisometropia will not affect the results for the monocular crossed cylinder test (unless a large degree of amblyopia is present). Any anisometropia should have been discovered and balanced in the subjective refraction.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following areas of the brain are responsible for the control of saccadic eye movements? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
Studies have shown that cells residing in the superior colliculus and frontal eye fields respond vigorously with increased firing rates immediately before saccadic eye movements are conducted. Therefore, it is believed that these regions of the brain are responsible for the control of saccadic eye movements. 

The Brain and Behavior: An introduction to Behavioral Neuroanatomy (3rd edition). Clark, D.L., Boutros, N.N., Mendez, M.F. 2010. Cambridge University Press. 

Human Motor Control (2nd edition). Rosenbaum, D.A. 2010. Academic Press Elsevier. San Diego, CA.

questions.question: A patient reports horizontal diplopia. Cover testing reveals 16 prism diopters of exophoria at distance. Which of the following will MOST likely cause the phoria to become less exophoric or more esophoric?
options: Vision therapy with an emphasis on convergence training
Vision therapy with an emphasis on divergence training
questions.explanation: Vision therapy generally does not change the value of the measured phoria but instead serves to increase the compensatory mechanisms so that the patient no longer experiences symptoms. Prisms or spectacles can alter the value of the measured phoria. In a pre-presbyopic patient, prescribing minus-powered glasses causes stimulation of the accommodative system, which in turn activates the vergence system and results in convergence and therefore a decrease in exophoria or an increase in esophoria.

questions.question: Which of the following binocular balancing tests CANNOT be performed on a patient with visual acuities of 20/50 OD and 20/50 OS?
options: There is no restriction upon which binocular balance test may be utilized on this patient
answers: There is no restriction upon which binocular balance test may be utilized on this patient
questions.explanation:
If the best-corrected acuity is equal between the eyes, even if it is reduced, any binocular balance testing procedure may be utilized, since the patient is subjectively comparing the acuities between the eyes so that the clinician can confirm equal accommodative states between the eyes. In the event that the acuities are not equal between the eyes, the majority of examiners will opt to use the bichrome balancing test. 

Primary Care Optometry 5th edition. Grosvenor, T. Butterworth-Heinemann, 2007, page 217.

questions.question: Which of the four involuntary vergence stimuli is driven by neural innervation?
questions.explanation: Tonic vergence is caused by baseline innervation. This type of vergence is generally maintained when all other vergence stimuli are absent. Proximal stimuli are driven by near objects. The response increases as the distance from the object decreases. Accommodative response results from target defocus. Fusional involuntary vergence is provoked by retinal disparity.

questions.question: Which type of involuntary accommodation is stimulated by blurring of the retinal image?
questions.explanation: There are four known involuntary accommodative stimuli. Reflexive or defocus stimulates accommodation in the presence of retinal defocus (when the image on the retina is blurred). Proximal cues also stimulate the accommodative system. This type of stimulus occurs when there is an increased awareness of a near target. This can result from visual cues such as overlap, increased visual angle and brightness to name a few. The third involuntary stimulus to accommodation is tonic. This stimulus is present in the absence of visual stimulation and derived from baseline neural innervation. Tonic accommodation tends to increase in the dark to a resting state of 1.00 to 1.50 D. This state is occasionally referred to as the dark focus of accommodation. Lastly, convergence is another type of involuntary accommodative stimulus. When convergence is stimulated, so is the accommodation system.

questions.question: How does one clinically differentiate between a true Von Graefe's sign and a pseudo Von Graefe's sign?
options: Ptosis is not present in straight-ahead gaze
Ptosis is not evident in adducted gaze
Ptosis is less prominent on abduction
answers: Ptosis is not evident in adducted gaze
questions.explanation:
Pseudo Von Graefe's sign occurs due to aberrant regeneration of cranial nerve III. After incurring an insult (paralysis), upon recovery, instead of innervating the levator palpebrae superioris, fibers now connect to the medial rectus. Therefore, when one adducts the eye on the same side of the palsy, the ptosis is not evident. In straight-ahead gaze a ptosis is present on the same side of the palsy. 

Von Graefe's sign occurs in Grave's disease (thyroid dysfunction). This term refers to the inability of the eyelid to move down when the globe is directed in a down gaze. It is often described as a lagging of the upper eyelid-not because it sags but because it lags behind movement-wise. The greater the down gaze, the greater the bearing of the sclera. Von Graefe's results from excessive innervation of the sympathetic system causing upper lid retraction via Muller's muscle.

questions.question: Why do many absolute presbyopes appear to possess some ability to accommodate?
questions.explanation: The smaller the pupil diameter, the greater the depth of focus. Depth of focus can sometimes account for up to 1.00 D of accommodation in aphakes! Therefore when determining the add power for reading, the results may be lower than you would expect. In general, macular changes, decreased tear film and poliosis (whitening of the eyelashes) do not increase or perceive to increase accommodation.

questions.question: Which of the following procedures is NOT typically performed binocularly?
