questions.explanation: During subjective refraction, cylindrical axis refinement is performed monocularly in order to achieve the most accurate results. The Worth-4-dot, prism dissociation, and Randot Stereoacuity Test are all completed binocularly.

questions.question: Looking to the right (dextroversion) requires simultaneous movement of both eyes. Which extraocular muscles coordinate this movement?
options: Right lateral rectus and left medial rectus
Right medial rectus and left lateral rectus
answers: Right lateral rectus and left medial rectus
questions.explanation:
To look to the right, the right eye must move laterally (abduction) and the left eye must move medially (adduction). 

The functions of the extraocular muscles on the globe are as follows: 
Lateral rectus - abducts the eye (laterally) 
Medial rectus - adducts the eye (medially) 
Superior rectus - supraducts, adducts, and medially rotates the eye (intorsion) 
Inferior rectus - infraducts, adducts, and laterally rotates the eye (extorsion) 
Superior oblique - medially rotates (intorsion), abducts and infraducts the eye 
Inferior oblique - laterally rotates (extorsion), abducts and supraducts the eye

questions.question: Using the Von Graefe method to determine the amount of phoria present at near on your patient he reports that the targets are lined up horizontally with 5 base up prism before the left eye. What conclusion can you deduce from the above results?
options: Right hyper deviation or left hypo deviation
Left hyper deviation or right hypo deviation
answers: Right hyper deviation or left hypo deviation
questions.explanation: When performing the Von Graefe method, a 4 base up dissociating prism is placed before the left eye and an 18 base in prism (biasing prism) is placed before the right eye. A single letter or target is projected at far (or near). The patient should initially perceive two targets with one being up and to the right and the other down and to the left . The 4 base up prism is then slowly reduced (either via intermittent occlusion or no occlusion) until the patient reports that the two targets are directly beside one another lined up horizontally. When the targets are aligned horizontally, the amount of prism before the left eye is recorded. If there is base up prism in front of the left eye then the deviation is described as either right hyperphoria or left hypophoria in the amount equal to the neutralizing prism before the left eye.

questions.question: Which of the following extraocular muscles of the right and left eye are responsible for levodepression of the eyes?
options: Right inferior oblique, left superior rectus
Right superior oblique, left inferior rectus
Right inferior rectus, left superior oblique
Right superior rectus, left inferior oblique
Right superior oblique, left superior rectus
Right superior rectus, left superior oblique
answers: Right superior oblique, left inferior rectus
questions.explanation: Levodepression is the movement of each eye into down and left gaze. This position of gaze is considered one of the six cardinal positions, in which a single muscle of each eye is responsible for moving the eye into that particular direction. In the case of levodepression, the right eye moves down and nasally by the action of the right superior oblique, while the left eye moves down and temporally, due to contraction of the left inferior rectus muscle.

questions.question: Which of the following extraocular muscles is considered the synergistic pairing to the left superior oblique?
questions.explanation: Synergistic extraocular muscles pairs are those muscles of the same eye which, when contracted, act to move the eye in the same direction. In this question, one of the actions of the left superior oblique is to depress the left eye. Additionally, in the left eye, the left inferior rectus also acts to depress the eye. Therefore, the muscle that acts synergistically with the left superior oblique is the left inferior rectus.

questions.question: Which of the following muscles pairs are considered yoke muscles?
options: Right superior oblique, right superior rectus
Right superior oblique, left superior rectus
Right superior oblique, left inferior rectus
Right superior oblique, right inferior rectus
Right superior oblique, left superior oblique
answers: Right superior oblique, left inferior rectus
questions.explanation: Yoke muscle pairs consist of a single muscle in each eye that works together to produce conjugate ocular movements. For the above question, the right superior oblique acts to move the right eye into left downgaze when contracted. The muscle of the left eye that contracts to move the left eye in the same direction is the left inferior rectus. These two muscles comprise a yoke muscle pair (also known as contralateral synergists).

questions.question: Fick's axes are often used to describe the eye's rotation. In this system, which of the following correctly describes the X-axis?
options: Runs from the anterior pole to the posterior pole
Runs from the anterior pole to the inferior pole
questions.explanation:
In this system, Fick's axes intersect at the center of rotation of the eye and can be described as follows: the X-axis is the transverse or horizontal axis and runs from nasal to temporal. The Y-axis is the sagittal axis and runs from the anterior pole to the posterior pole. The Z-axis is the vertical axis and runs from superior to inferior. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 p 160

questions.question: Which of the following laws describes the concept of reciprocal innervation, in which increased innervation to an extraocular muscle is accompanied by an equal amount of decreased innervation to its antagonist?
questions.explanation: Sherrington's law refers to the reciprocal decreased innervation that occurs in an antagonist muscle when the agonist receives increased innervation. For example, when the lateral rectus muscle contracts to move an eye laterally, the medial rectus muscle will automatically relax. It is important to note that Sherrington's law applies for both versions and vergences.

questions.question: A 15-year old white female complaining of intermittent blurry near-to-distance vision presents with the following clinical findings: Uncorrected VA: OD: 20/30 OS: 20/30, MEM: -0.50 OD, OS, NRA: +1.00 Wet Subjective: -0.50 OD, OS 20/20. What is the MOST appropriate prescription for this patient?
options: Spectacle Prescription: OD: -0.50 DS OS: -0.50 DS +2.50 add
Spectacle Prescription: OD: -0.50 DS OS: -0.50 DS
Spectacle Prescription: OD: -0.50 DS OS: -0.50 DS +1.00 add
Spectacle Prescription: OD: -0.25 DS OS: -0.25 DS +1.00 add
Spectacle Prescription: OD: plano DS OS: plano DS +2.50 add
answers: Spectacle Prescription: OD: -0.50 DS OS: -0.50 DS +1.00 add
questions.explanation:
This patient presents with accommodative spasm. Her lead of accommodation found on MEM and her NRA are the most pertinent clinical findings. Additionally, symptoms of intermittent near to distance vision hints at accommodative dysfunction. The patient also fits the patient population most correlated with accommodative spasm, i.e. young teenage females. The patient's entering visual acuities correlate with her wet subjective findings and so should be fully corrected in her glasses to optimize her distance vision. A +1.00 add is needed to keep her focusing system relaxed with near activities, and as such, should be included in her spectacle prescription. There is no preference or advantage to having a lined bifocal or a progressive additional lens. 

Spectacle Prescription: OD: -0.50 DS OS: -0.50 DS. This answer is incorrect since an add is needed to help keep the focusing system relaxed. 

Spectacle Prescription: Over-the-counter +1.00 DS OU. This answer is incorrect because OTC Reading glasses would be insufficient, since the patient also presents with blurry distance vision and myopia, even upon cycloplegic examination. 

Spectacle Prescription: OD: plano DS OS: plano DS +2.50 add 
This prescription is not valid as the patient needs myopic correction for distance, as seen with wet subjective findings. The +2.50 add is too high, as her NRA is +1.00. Anything higher than a +1.00 will cause blur at both distance and near. 

Spectacle Prescription: OD: -0.50 DS OS: -0.50 DS +2.50 add 
The prescription is adequate for distance visual demand, but the +2.50 is too strong and will cause blur up-close. Her NRA is only +1.00, as anything higher will cause near blur. 

Spectacle Prescription OD: -0.25 DS OS: -0.25 DS +1.00 add 
The patient should be fully corrected in the distance to optimize visual acuity. -0.50 DS in both eyes is not due to accommodative spasm, as the patient still presented with -0.50 even upon cycloplegic exam.
PowerPage
Accomodative Dysfunctions

questions.question: Which of the following types of aberration have been shown to play a major role in how the eye detects defocus and responds with the normal reflex accommodative response?
questions.explanation:
Studies have shown that longitudinal chromatic aberration (LCA) plays a very important role in how the eyes detect defocus, resulting in an accommodative response. There is a significant amount of LCA present in the human eye; this occurs due to the fact that the refractive index of any medium (other than a vacuum) varies with wavelength. Therefore, shorter wavelengths (blues) will bend more as they pass through a lens, while longer wavelengths (reds) bend less. This leads to a variation in the image location, also known as LCA. If the LCA is removed by using monochromatic light or by optically neutralizing the LCA, it has been proven that a significant disruption occurs in the normal reflex accommodative response. 

Adaptive Optics for Vision Science: Principles, Practices, Design, and Applications. Porter, et. al. 2006. Wiley-Interscience. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye 11th Edition. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. 2011. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: You are able to accurately screen for a heterophoria by performing a cover test on your 4 year-old patient. To properly complete a binocular vision evaluation on this patient, which of the following tests does NOT need to be performed?
options: Determining the near point of convergence
questions.explanation: Hirschberg testing and cover testing are both utilized to denote the presence of an ocular deviation; therefore, Hirschberg testing does not need to be performed on this patient.

questions.question: A 47-year old man sustained orbital trauma and now presents with complaints of retro-orbital pain, impaired ability to move the eye, a droopy eyelid, and diplopia. These signs are most consistent with damage to which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
The superior orbital fissure is a cleft between the lesser and greater wings of the sphenoid. Structures traveling through the superior orbital fissure include the oculomotor nerve (CN III), trochlear nerve (CN IV), abducens nerve (CN VI), lacrimal nerve, frontal nerve, nasociliary nerve, and the ophthalmic vein (superior and inferior divisions). These structures can be damaged when there is orbital trauma causing fractures through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary sinus. This leads to superficial orbital fissure syndrome (also known as Rochon-Duvigneaud's syndrome). Signs include paralysis of extraocular muscles, diplopia, ptosis, exophthalmia and decreased sensation of the upper eyelid and forehead. Vision loss or blindness implies a more serious injury involving the orbital apex (orbital apex syndrome). 

Tolusa-Hunt syndrome (THS) is an inflammatory condition within the cavernous sinus or superior orbital fissure causing damage to the structures in those regions. Signs are usually acute and unilateral at onset in adults and the most common presenting signs are pain and ophthalmoparesis. 

The internal auditory (or acoustic) meatus is a canal in the petrous portion of the temporal bone through which the facial (CN VII) and vestibulocochlear nerves (CN VIII) and the labyrinthine artery travel. Damage to these structures can result in deafness and facial muscle paralysis. Acoustic neuromas will commonly expand the internal auditory meatus and damage these structures. Other signs may include tinnitus or vertigo. 

The stylomastoid foramen is the termination of the facial canal between the styloid and mastoid processes of the temporal bone. The facial nerve and stylomastoid artery travel through this area. Damage to this area can result in facial drooping and paralysis. Bell's palsy (idiopathic facial nerve paralysis) is an inflammatory condition that may lead to swelling of the facial nerve in this region. 

The superficial temporal artery is a major artery arising from the bifurcation of the external carotid artery. The artery begins within the parotid salivary gland and passes over the zygomatic process of the temporal bone. It is often affected in cases of giant cell arteritis (which is also known as temporal arteritis for this reason). This condition is a vasculitis of the medium and large arteries of the head and is not necessarily restricted to the temporal artery. Temporal arteritis is seen predominantly in older patients and is characterized by fever, headache, sensitivity on the scalp, jaw pain, reduced visual acuity or vision loss, diplopia, and acute tinnitus. Due to potentially rapid progressive vision loss, this disease is a medical emergency. Treatment usually consists of high-dose corticosteroids.

questions.question: In order for a patient to look up (supraduction) in the primary position of gaze, which extraocular muscles are used?
questions.explanation:
The superior rectus turns the eye up while adducting and medially rotating. The inferior oblique turns the eye up while abducting and laterally rotating. To look straight up, both muscles are used simultaneously. 

The functions of all the extraocular muscles on the globe are as follows: 
Lateral rectus- abducts the eye (laterally) 
Medial rectus- adducts the eye (medially) 
Superior rectus- supraducts, adducts, and medially rotates the eye (intorsion) 
Inferior rectus- infraducts, adducts, and laterally rotates the eye (extorsion) 
Superior oblique- medially rotates (intorsion), infraducts and abducts the eye 
Inferior oblique- laterally rotates (extorsion), supraducts and abducts the eye

questions.question: Which of the following is the only extraocular muscle that does not originate from the apex of the orbit?
questions.explanation:
In contrast to the other extraocular muscles (EOMs), the inferior oblique is the only EOM that does not originate from the apex of the orbit. Instead, the inferior oblique muscle arises from the maxillary bone in the medial wall of the orbit. From here, it courses posteriorly and inferiorly to the inferior rectus muscle and inserts into the sclera at a location on the lateral aspect of the globe medial to the tendon of the lateral rectus and posterior to the equator. 

Neuroanatomy of the Oculomotor System. Buttner-Ennever, J.A. 2006. Elsevier.

questions.question: Which of the following extraocular muscles has its insertion point FURTHEST from the limbus?
questions.explanation: The spiral of Tillaux is an imaginary line that joins the insertion points of the four recti muscles. As their insertions get further away from the limbus, a spiral pattern is created, starting with the medial rectus. The insertion point for the medial rectus is the closest to the limbus (5.3mm), followed by the inferior rectus (6.8mm), lateral rectus (6.9mm), and finally the superior rectus, which inserts the furthest from the limbus (7.9mm).

questions.question: After performing refraction, you then proceed to measure relative accommodation on your 45-year old patient. With the tentative add in place (in which your patient can clearly read RS 20) your findings are as follows: Negative relative accommodation (NRA): +3.00 D, positive relative accommodation (PRA):-0.50 D. What is the most likely explanation for these findings?
options: The tentative add requires more power
The tentative add requires less power
questions.explanation:
Negative relative accommodation (NRA) and positive relative accommodation (PRA) should be fairly balanced, and they should not be greater than the overall amplitude of accommodation. The PRA is commonly high in young adults as they possess good accommodative skills. In presbyopes the range of relative accommodation is much more limited (due to the fact that accommodative ability is diminished). The above findings suggest that the patient has been over-minussed in the distance and therefore the NRA and PRA are imbalanced. Because the patient is over-minussed he or she will tend to require more plus powered lenses to compensate for the diminished ability to stimulate accommodation which will manifest as an imbalanced range of relative accommodation, with the NRA being asymmetrically higher. 

Based upon the above findings, the add power should not be adjusted as the patient is capable of reading RS 20 with a tentative add in place. One should always try to prescribe the least amount of power that achieves good near vision. Otherwise, the greater the near power, the closer the focal point and most people prefer to maintain a good range of clarity at near without having to hold objects too close to them. Once the distance prescription is re-evaluated, in this instance, one would also have to re-evaluate the tentative add which would likely decrease due to compensation for originally over-minussing the distance prescription.

questions.question: Accommodation is primarily controlled by which system?
questions.explanation:
Accommodation is innervated by the parasympathetic system. During accommodation, the parasympathetic system causes contraction of the ciliary muscles which decreases the tension on the zonules causing the lens to become more spherically shaped thereby increasing its dioptric power. Another theory suggests that ciliary body contraction increases the mass in the vitreous which causes the vitreous to push the lens forward. 

The sympathetic nervous system is primarily responsible for bodily functions in the presence of heightened awareness, danger or excitement and it prepares the body for fight-or-flight. 

The parasympathetic system is generally in charge of basic housekeeping tasks when the body is at rest. This system essentially tells the body to slow down. 

The somatic division of the peripheral nervous system is responsible for motor function and serves to convey information to and from skeletal muscles, tendons and skin. This division works closely with the autonomic system which relays signals to visceral organs such as the heart and gut. 

The lymphatic system plays a large role in the immune system.

questions.question: When determining the near point of convergence, which of the following sentences is TRUE?
options: The maximal point of divergence is recorded in centimeters as the 'break point'
If diplopia is not reported by the patient, the test should be repeated until the patient reports blurring of the target
As the target is moved closer, diplopia is typically reported prior to blurring of the target
As the object is moved closer, the accommodative system maintains the target clarity while the convergence system preserves fusion of the object
answers: As the object is moved closer, the accommodative system maintains the target clarity while the convergence system preserves fusion of the object
questions.explanation: The near point of convergence (NPC) is the point in which the patient's eyes are maximally converged. The NPC is determined by presenting the patient with an appropriate accommodative target at near and with the patient's near correction in place, the patient is asked to keep the target clear and single. The target is then brought closer to the patient until either the patient reports that the image of the object appears double or the clinician notes that one of the patient's eyes turns out. This point is measured and recorded from the spectacle plane in centimeters. While performing the NPC, the convergence system maintains fusion of the target and accommodation sustains clarity. Some patients may report blurring of the target (near point of accommodation) prior to experiencing diplopia, but rarely do patients report blurring of the target after experiencing diplopia. The majority of clinicians record 'TTN' or 'to the nose' for patients who do not report diplopia or do not exhibit a break in fusion.

questions.question: As a stimulus for accommodation increases, which of the following statements is TRUE in regards to the measured accommodative response?
options: The measured accommodative response is typically the same as the magnitude of the stimulus
The measured accommodative response is typically greater than the magnitude of the stimulus
The measured accommodative response is typically less than the magnitude of the stimulus
answers: The measured accommodative response is typically less than the magnitude of the stimulus
questions.explanation:
As a stimulus for accommodation increases (an object is brought closer to the eyes), studies have shown that the objectively measured response to accommodation is actually less than the overall magnitude of the stimulus. This is known as a lag of accommodation. This type of study can be done by placing negative trial lenses with increasing power in front of the eyes (stimulating accommodation), while measuring the accommodative response with a refractometer. As the stimulus is increased and plotted, the linear response will have a slope of less than 1 due to the observed lag of accommodation. Eventually, there comes a point in which the maximum accommodative response amplitude is reached. It is also important to note that there is typically an initial small lead in accommodation (the response is greater than the stimulus) for low magnitudes of accommodative stimuli. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye 11th Edition. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. 2011. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: Which of the following methodologies for quantifying a heterophoria includes the utilization of a Maddox rod?
questions.explanation:
The modified Thorington technique is performed by placing the test card at 40 cm. A Maddox rod is then introduced over the right eye or left eye with its axis oriented horizontally. The eye with the Maddox rod is occluded while a penlight is directed through the hole in the center of the card; the patient should report seeing a light and some letters and numbers. It is important that these targets should remain clear throughout the entire test. Next, un-occlude the eye with the Maddox rod; the patient should now see a red vertical streak (assuming the Maddox rod is over the right eye) that is superimposed upon the Thorington card. Direct the patient's gaze towards the spot of light and ask the patient to note which letters or numbers the horizontal streak is closest to. Flash the pen light on and off each time, asking the patient to inform you where the streak is located. Continue flashing the penlight until two consistent responses are obtained. If the patient has an exo deviation, s/he will report seeing a vertical streak to the left of the spot of light (Maddox rod over the right eye). If the Maddox rod is over the left eye, the streak will be seen to the right of the spot of light. Each optotype represents a one-prism diopter result. 

The Von Graefe method utilizes prism to produce dissociation between the eyes. The Mohindra method is a technique utilized by some clinicians when performing retinoscopy. Mohindra retinoscopy purportedly achieves results similar to cycloplegic retinoscopy without the use of pharmaceuticals. Randot stereoacuity is a measure of third-degree fusion and does not require the use of a Maddox rod. The Hess-Lancaster test uses red-green glasses to evaluate the position of each eye in the nine primary positions of gaze and is used to document/detect ocular paresis.

questions.question: A patient with an AC/A ratio of 9/1 is prescribed a reading add of -1.00 D. Which of the following clinical results would be expected?
options: The near phoria would be expected to become more esophoric or less exophoric
The negative relative accommodation would be expected to decrease by roughly 1.00 D
The monocular estimation method retinoscopy values would decrease in positive power or would increase in minus power
The amplitude of accommodation would increase by roughly 1.00 D
answers: The near phoria would be expected to become more esophoric or less exophoric
questions.explanation:
A patient who has an AC/A ratio of 9/1 and is prescribed an add of -1.00 D would be expected to have the following clinical findings: the amplitude of accommodation would decrease by roughly 1.00 D, the near phoria would become more esophoric or less exophoric by 9.00 prism diopters, the monocular estimation method retinoscopy value would increase in plus power, the negative relative accommodation findings would increase by about 1.00 D, and the positive relative accommodation values would decrease by approximately 1.00 D. 

Clinical Management of Binocular Vision: Heterophoric, Accommodative, and Eye Movement Disorders 4th edition. Scheiman, M. & Wick, B. Lippincott, Williams & Wilkins, 2014.

questions.question: A 12 year-old patient is seen at your office complaining of distance blur. Cover test reveals 4 prism diopters of exophoria at near. Subjective refraction reveals -2.25 DS OU. The patient returns 4 weeks later and reports that her vision is clear at distance with the glasses, but when she reads her eyes become fatigued and she reports frontal headaches, all of which she did not experience prior to getting her glasses. What is the MOST likely etiology of her headaches while reading?
options: The optical center of her glasses was measured too low
The pantoscopic tilt is incorrect and is inducing unwanted astigmatism
Resultant esophoria at near induced by her glasses
Her glasses are too tight and are putting pressure on her temples
answers: Resultant esophoria at near induced by her glasses
questions.explanation:
Patients with myopia who are newly corrected may display esophoria at near when wearing their spectacle correction. Reading through minus-powered lenses causes an increase in the accommodative response as well as the vergence system, resulting in less exophoria or more esophoria at near. If enough esophoria is induced, symptoms of asthenopia can occur. For patients with mild amounts of myopia, the removal of their glasses while performing near, visually oriented tasks will typically eliminate ocular discomfort. Other options include prescribing a bifocal or a progressive addition lens (PAL). Research has demonstrated that myopic patients who possess esophoria at near may benefit from a bifocal or PAL, which may serve to slow down the rate of progression of myopia. 

Primary Care Optometry 5th edition. Grosvenor, T. Butterworth-Heinemann, 2007, page 252.

questions.question: A patient is seen at your office reporting horizontal diplopia that is worse towards the end of the day. Unilateral cover testing reveals no movement of either eye. Which of the following can correctly be concluded from the above findings?
options: The patient does not likely possess a heterotropia
The patient does not likely possess a heterophoria
Further testing is required prior to reaching a conclusion regarding the presence of an ocular deviation
The patient does not likely possess a heterotropia or a heterophoria
answers: The patient does not likely possess a heterotropia
questions.explanation:
The unilateral cover test (UCT) is useful in diagnosing a heterotropia. If a person does not suffer from a heterotropia, then no movement would be observed on the UCT. A heterophoria would present only on the alternating cover test (ACT). 

Ophthalmology: Investigation and Examination Techniques. James, B & Benjamin, L. Elsevier Limited, 2007, page 109.

questions.question: Using the Von Graefe method to determine the amount of phoria present at near on your patient, she reports that the targets are lined up vertically with 8 base in prism before the right eye. What conclusion can you deduce from the above results?
options: The patient has an esophoria of 8 prism diopters
The patient has a hyperphoria of 8 prism diopters
The patient has an exophoria of 8 prism diopters
The patient has a hypophoria of 8 prism diopters
answers: The patient has an exophoria of 8 prism diopters
questions.explanation: When performing the Von Graefe method, a 6 base up prism is placed before the left eye (dissociating prism) and a 12 base in prism (biasing prism) is placed before the right eye. A single letter or target is projected at far (or near). The patient should initially perceive two targets, with one being up and to the right and the other down and to the left (if the upper one is to the left, more base in prism needs to be added as the initial phoria is greater than 12 prism diopters). The 12 base in prism is then slowly reduced (either via intermittent occlusion or no occlusion) until the patient reports that the two targets are directly above one another lined up vertically. If there is base in prism before the right eye, the deviation is categorized as exo by the amount of prism before the right eye. If there is base out prism in front of the right eye, the deviation is eso equal to the amount of neutralizing prism before the right eye.

questions.question: Cover testing of your patient through their best correction reveals 6 prism diopters of esophoria at distance. While performing Von Graefe testing at distance, with 6 base-up prism in front of the left eye and 14 base-in prism over the right eye, the patient reports only seeing one target. When each eye is covered individually, the patient reports seeing the target, but with both eyes together does not report seeing two targets. What is the MOST likely explanation for the patient's lack of diplopia?
options: The patient is suppressing an eye
The phoropter is not aligned properly
The patient's refractive error is affecting the results of the test
The biasing prism in the phoropter has neutralized the patient's heterophoria
answers: The patient is suppressing an eye
questions.explanation: The most likely explanation for the patient's lack of diplopia on Von Graefe testing is suppression of an eye. One can infer both that the phoropter is aligned properly and the patient's prescription is not a factor, since the patient can see an image with each eye individually but does not report diplopia with both eyes together. One can also deduce that the prism in the phoropter has not neutralized the patient's phoria, given that the cover test revealed 6 prism diopters of esophoria and, all else being equal, the horizontal biasing prism in the phoropter is more likely to neutralize 14 prism diopters of exophoria.

questions.question: Your 12 year-old female patient reports to you that she just noticed that when she focuses on a distant object, things in front of that object appear double. Which of the following explains this type of visual perception?
options: The patient must have a large phoria, which is causing the images to appear double
The patient has poor vergence ranges, leading to difficulty fusing images
The patient is experiencing diplopia due to parallax
Objects that appear double lie outside of Panum's fusional area
answers: Objects that appear double lie outside of Panum's fusional area
questions.explanation:
The patient in the above question is experiencing normal physiologic diplopia. There is an imaginary plane that exists in external space called the horopter, which represents all points that stimulate corresponding retinal elements. Any object that lands along the horopter will be fused and seen as a single image and in the same plane as the point of fixation. In addition to the horopter, there is a zone that lies both in front of and behind the horopter whereby objects stimulate slightly non-corresponding retinal points; this is known as retinal disparity. Objects within this area are also observed as single images; however, the disparity information is used to produce a binocular perception of depth, or stereopsis. Physiological diplopia is based on this idea; therefore, objects that lie outside of Panum's fusional area will be perceived as double. However, many patients will exhibit physiological suppression and are unaware of this phenomenon. 

In summary, objects along the horopter are seen singly and in the same plane; objects within Panum's fusional area are seen singly and stereoscopically; and objects that are outside of Panum's fusional area will appear double.

questions.question: While performing the alternate cover test, the patient's eyes consistently display outward movement, or rotation in the temporal direction. Which of the following can CORRECTLY be concluded from this clinical finding?
options: The patient possesses a heterophoria and a heterotropia, but they are not equal in magnitude
The patient is very likely to display eccentric fixation
The patient possesses both a heterophoria and a heterotropia, and both are equal in magnitude
The patient possesses an ocular deviation, but it cannot be classified as a tropia or a phoria without further testing
answers: The patient possesses an ocular deviation, but it cannot be classified as a tropia or a phoria without further testing
questions.explanation: The alternate cover test (ACT) will result in eye movement regardless of whether the ocular deviation is heterophoric or heterotropic in nature and cannot be used to differentiate a phoria from a tropia. The unilateral cover test (UCT) is the only test of the two that will correctly ascertain the presence or absence of a tropia. The ACT is helpful in quantifying the magnitude of the deviation. In order to correctly identify the type and the magnitude of the deviation, both the UCT and the ACT need to be performed. The ACT and the UCT are not used to test for eccentric fixation.

questions.question: Grave's disease can cause spontaneous diplopia. Which of the following extraocular muscles is the most commonly affected in a patient afflicted with Grave's disease?
questions.explanation: Grave's disease is an auto-immune condition caused by hyperthyroidism (overproduction of thyroid hormones). The eye muscles may become thicker and shorter due to an infiltration of lymphocytes, which limits the ability of the muscles to contract, eventually resulting in fibrosis of the muscle. Restriction of the extraocular muscle (EOM) causes a perceived palsy of the opposing EOM. The eye muscles most frequently affected are the inferior rectus, medial rectus, and the superior rectus, with the inferior rectus being by far the most commonly involved.

questions.question: Which extraocular rectus muscle has its insertion site CLOSEST to the limbus?
questions.explanation:
The medial rectus inserts into the sclera roughly 5.3 mm from the limbus, followed by the inferior rectus, which inserts 6.8 mm from the limbus. The lateral rectus inserts 6.9 mm from the limbus, and the superior rectus has the furthest insertion point at 7.9 mm from the limbus. Remember MILS (Medial rectus, Inferior rectus, Lateral rectus, Superior rectus). If one draws a line connecting the insertion points of the muscles, an imaginary spiral is created called the spiral of Tillaux. 

Reference: Chen, W. Oculoplastic Surgery: the Essentials (2001) page 330.

questions.question: While performing the alternate cover test at near on a patient with esophoria, you ask the patient to note any target movement. Which of the following responses is this patient MOST likely to report?
options: The target does not appear to move
The target appears to move in the opposite direction of the occluder movement
The target appears to move downwards
The target appears to move in the same direction of the occluder movement
The target appears to move upwards
answers: The target appears to move in the opposite direction of the occluder movement
questions.explanation:
If a phoria is too small in magnitude to be observed while performing the alternate cover test, the clinician can ask the patient to fixate on the target and report any movement seen. Patients with esophoria will report that the target appears to become displaced in the opposite direction of the occluder movement. For example, when the occluder moves from the patient's right eye to the left eye, the patient will note that the fixation target appeared to move from left to right or 'against jump'. A patient with exophoria will report that the target is displaced in the same direction as the movement of the occluder or 'with jump'. 

Primary Care Optometry 5th edition. Grosvenor, T. Butterworth-Heinemann, 2007, page 119.

questions.question: While performing the unilateral cover test, the right eye assumes an exo position when covered. If the right eye were to maintain an exo position when the occluder is removed where would the target's image fall on the retina in relation to the fovea?
options: The target's image would be nasal to the fovea
The target's image would be inferior to the fovea
The target's image would be temporal to the fovea
The target's image would be superior to the fovea
answers: The target's image would be temporal to the fovea
questions.explanation: An exo position places the fovea of the right eye nasal to the image projected from the object of regard. This is due to the outward rotation of the eye which rotates the fovea nasally relative to the object. This places the target's image temporal to the fovea.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered an example of the highest level of fusion?
options: Visual acuity via a Snellen chart
questions.explanation:
There are 3 degrees of fusion, with third-degree fusion being the highest level. Stereopsis is an example of third-degree fusion. The red lens test and the Worth-4-Dot are both examples of second-degree fusion. 

Third-degree fusion is the ability to fuse two identical images that are separated by space, creating the perception of depth. The images must be placed at points that cause retinal disparity in order for the perception of depth to occur. 

Second-degree fusion is the ability to superimpose like objects (not necessarily identical objects), with the end result being the perception of a single object that is a composition of the two separate images. 

First-degree fusion is defined as the ability to superimpose two dissimilar objects such that the two objects are perceived to occupy the same space and appear as a combination of the two objects.

questions.question: The Worth-4-dot test is an example of which type of fusion?
questions.explanation:
The Worth-4-dot test is administered to examine second-degree fusion which is the ability to superimpose like objects (not necessarily identical objects) with the end result being the perception of a single object that is a composition of the two separate images. In this test, one eye is presented with a red dot and the fellow eye is presented with 2 green dots. Both eyes view a white dot. If fusion is present, the patient will report having a binocular percept of 4 dots. 

First-degree fusion is the ability to superimpose two dissimilar objects-for example a circle and a square, such that the two objects are perceived to occupy the same space and appear as an amalgamation of the two objects. 

Third-degree fusion is described as the ability to fuse two identical images that are separated by space resulting in the perception of depth. 3-D movies are an example of this type of fusion. The images must be placed at points that cause retinal disparity in order for the perception of depth to ensue. 

Fourth-degree fusion does not exist.

questions.question: Stereopsis is considered an example of which degree of fusion?
questions.explanation:
Third-degree fusion is described as the ability to fuse two identical images that are separated by space, resulting in the perception of depth. 3-D movies are an example of this type of fusion. The images must be placed at points that cause retinal disparity in order for the perception of depth to ensue. 

Second-degree fusion is the ability to superimpose like objects (not necessarily identical objects), with the end result being the perception of a single object that is a composition of the two separate images. The Worth-4-Dot and the red lens test are examples of second-degree fusion. 

First-degree fusion is the ability to superimpose two dissimilar objects (for example, a bird and a cage) such that the two objects are perceived to occupy the same space and appear as an amalgamation of the two objects. 

Fourth-degree fusion does not exist.

questions.question: What is the MAIN purpose of performing binocular balance testing during subjective refraction?
options: To confirm the presence of a tropia
To ensure ocular alignment of the eyes
To ensure equal accommodative states between the eyes
To attempt to balance the refractive errors between the eyes
The ensure equal visual acuity between the eyes
answers: To ensure equal accommodative states between the eyes
questions.explanation:
Binocular balance testing is performed to ensure that the accommodative state of each eye is equal to the other. Theoretically, because this test is performed at a distance that attempts to simulate optical infinity, accommodation should be at rest. Although it is ideal if the visual acuities are equal between the eyes (certain binocular balance tests cannot be performed unless the eyes possess equal acuities), the main function of balance testing is to confirm equal accommodation between the eyes. The presence of a tropia and ocular alignment are typically determined via cover testing or by other methodologies. Many patients do not possess symmetrical refractive errors between the eyes and, therefore, attempting to achieve equality of the refractive errors can be detrimental to the visual acuity and comfort afforded by the prescription. Binocular balance testing is important to certify binocular comfort and efficiency. 

Primary Care Optometry 5th edition. Grosvenor, T. Butterworth-Heinemann, 2007, page 215-216.

questions.question: Which type of vergence is NOT considered reflexive?
questions.explanation: Tonic vergence is caused by baseline innervation. This type of vergence is generally maintained when all other vergence stimuli are absent. Proximal vergence is driven by near objects. The response increases as the distance from the object decreases. Accommodative response results from target defocus. Fusional involuntary vergence is provoked by retinal disparity. Voluntary convergence, as the name implies, is voluntarily regulated and denotes the ability to converge one?s eye in the absence of a target.

questions.question: Which of the following visual functions is present and continues to develop in a newborn infant?
questions.explanation:
Horizontal saccadic eye movements first emerge at birth and continue to develop until roughly 24 months. Vertical saccades require a longer time to mature and emerge at around 2 months of age and continue to develop until about 24 months. Pursuits may be seen as early as 2 months but are more commonly evident at 4 months of age. Stereopsis is absent at birth and does not become apparent until 3-5 months of age (some sources quote 4-6 months), reaching adult levels at 5-7 years of age. 

References: Optometric Clinical Practice Guideline Pediatric Eye and Vision Examination, Reference Guide for Clinicians. American Optometric Association, 2002, page 10. 
Visual Perception: A Clinical Orientation, 2nd edition. Schwartz, S. Appleton & Lange, 1999, page 373.
PowerPage
Ocular Motility Evaluation

questions.question: Which of the following methods for measuring a heterophoria is classified PRIMARILY as dissociating?
questions.explanation:
Dissociating methods cause diplopia with prism thereby enabling the clinician to quantify a phoria. The Von Graefe method is considered dissociating. This technique is performed by placing a 4 base-up dissociating prism before the left eye and a base-in prism (biasing prism) before the right eye. A single letter or target is projected at far (or near). The patient should initially perceive two targets, with one being up and to the right and the other down and to the left. The 4 base-up prism is then slowly reduced (either via intermittent occlusion or no occlusion) until the patient reports that the two targets are directly beside one another and lined up horizontally. When the targets are aligned horizontally, the amount of prism before the left eye is recorded. If there is base-up prism in front of the left eye, then the deviation is described as either right hyperphoria or left hypophoria in the amount equal to the neutralizing prism before the left eye. 

Distortion methods blur one or both retinal images such that the reflex for binocular fusion is eliminated. The Modified Thorington method utilizes a Maddox rod to create distortion. The Hirschberg test is uses the position of the corneal reflexes relative to the center of the pupil to determine the presence or absence of a heterotropia. Temporal displacement of the corneal reflex suggests esotropia, while nasal displacement infers exotropia. The Bruckner reflex test is used to denote an asymmetry between the brightness of the retinal reflexes that may be caused by strabismus, anisometropia, anisocoria, or certain pathologies such as a large retinal detachment or retinoblastoma. In the event of strabismus, the deviated eye will appear brighter because more light is reflected from the retinal periphery.

questions.question: A 22 year-old male presents with a history of a right orbital medial wall fracture and restriction in right gaze on extraocular muscle testing. Which of the following additional tests is MOST useful in determining whether the limitation is secondary to muscle entrapment or muscle paralysis?
questions.explanation: Forced duction testing is an in-office procedure that is used in differentiating between muscle weakness and restrictive causes of limitations in extraocular muscle movements. This test is typically performed when a patient is anesthetized using topical eye drops. The patient is then instructed to look as far as possible in the direction of the muscle that is suspected of underacting such that maximum innervation is recruited to that muscle. The examiner will then use forceps in order to grasp the conjunctiva as close to the area of the limbus as possible, opposite the side of gaze restriction. If the forceps can then rotate the globe further than where the patient can move it on his own, some degree of muscle paresis is likely. However, if the globe cannot be rotated farther, restriction or entrapment of the muscle is probable. For example, if the patient has a deficit in superior gaze, the insertion of the inferior rectus muscle should be topically anesthetized. The patient's gaze should then be directed upwards and the inferior rectus muscle should be grasped with forceps. Further superior rotation of the eye should then be attempted. Resistance is considered a positive forced duction test, while effortless rotation is deemed a negative forced duction test.

questions.question: How much damage to the kidney occurs before signs and symptoms develop?
What is the dosing for doxy as an anti-inflammatory?
questions.explanation: This is a garbage question. There are a ton of options for low dose doxy now too (Oracea (40mg), Periostat (20mg).

questions.question: What is the deal with allergies to cephalosporins? (pick 2)
options: 1-10% that if allergic to azythromycin, you're allergic to cephalosporins
1-10% that if allergic to amoxicillin, you're allergic to 1st gen cephalosporins
Recent research says that the cross-allergy may be as high as 90%
Recent research says that the cross-allergy may be as low as 1%
answers: 1-10% that if allergic to amoxicillin, you're allergic to 1st gen cephalosporins
Recent research says that the cross-allergy may be as low as 1%
questions.explanation: Historically it was though that 10% of pts allergic to penicillins are allergic to cephalosporins but new reseach suggests that it's more likely ~1%. Also there is minimal issues with later gen cephs (2nd and 3rd generation cephs have minimal cross-reactivity).

questions.question: What percent of anaphylaxis treatments require a second dose of epinephrine?
questions.explanation: Shots are Intramusclar (IM) and usually delivered to the mid-anterolateral thigh. It can be repeated after 5-15 minutes if it wasn't effective enough.

questions.question: How many hormones are secreted by the anterior and posterior pituitary lobes respectively?
questions.explanation: The anterior lobe secretes prolactin, growth hormone, ACTH, TSH and others for a total of 7. The posterior lobe secretes only 2.

questions.question: What pregnancy category are tetracyclines?
questions.explanation:
3 drugs in tetracycline class (1. tetracycline, 2. doxycycline, 3.minocycline) are pregnancy category D.
Lightheadedness, dizziness, vertigo, tinnitus.
Photosensitivity (DO NOT GO IN SUN WHEN TAKING TETRACYCLINES), pseudotumor cerebri, inhibition of BONE GROWTH/TOOTH DISCOLORATION, potentiation of coumadin effects (making it cause MORE anti-coagulation), antagonistic to penicillins.

questions.question: Select the right option regarding what causes anaphylaxis.
options: IgG reactions require an initial exposure to an allergen
IgE reactions require an initial exposure to an allergen
answers: IgE reactions require an initial exposure to an allergen
questions.explanation: True anaphylaxis is IgE mediated and requires a prior exposure to the allergin (even though pts don't usually remember the first exposure). IgE receptors are then fabricated and held on Mast Cells and Basophils which cause a release of inflammatory mediates (cytokines and histamine). Ultimately the inflammatory reaction induces contraction of bronchial smooth muscle which narrows airways, vasodilation (decreases blood pressure) and increased leakage from BVs.

questions.question: What is the leading cause of carotid artery stenosis?
questions.explanation:
Atherosclerosis, which is chronic inflammation of the large BVs (including carotid) reduces the flow of blood and can result in plaque build up/stenosis of the carotids. 
Carotid dopplers are used to diagnose this issue and it's especially important to order when a hollenhorst plaque is detected since most likely the carotid is the origin site of the plauque.

questions.question: Select the true statement about biphasic anaphylaxis
options: Biphasic anaphylaxis is a recurrence of anaphylaxis within 1 week after the initial reaction.
Biphasic anaphylaxis is a recurrence of anaphylaxis within 1-3 days after the initial reaction.
It happens in ~20% of anaphylaxis cases
It happens in ~50% of anaphylaxis cases
answers: Biphasic anaphylaxis is a recurrence of anaphylaxis within 1-3 days after the initial reaction.
It happens in ~20% of anaphylaxis cases

questions.question: What is the visual field defect from pituitary tumors?
What class/generation is Levaquin?
questions.explanation:
Levafloxacin is a 3rd gen Fluoroquinolone
1. One Dick = Nalidixic Acid
2. CO2 = Ciprofloxaxin, Ofloxacin

questions.question: What is the retinal complication associated with plaquenil use? Also what is the # risk factor for developing plaquenil toxicity?
questions.explanation:
Total cumulative dose is the most important factor for predicting likelihood of plaquenil toxicity. A late finding of ocular changes is bulls eye retinopathy. Other findings include; whorl keratopathy, 10-2 visual field defects, and disruption to the photoreceptor integrity line paracentrally on OCT. 
**At 1000g (1 kilo) the risk of toxicity increases 1%.

questions.question: Selecting the true statements about Cushing's syndrome
options: Cushing's is caused by inefficient cortisol/prednisone in the body.
Cushing's is caused by excess cortisol/prednisone in the body from any source
Cushings can be caused by a steroid secreting tumor.
'Buffalo hump' and 'Moon face' are some of the signs of cushing's
answers: Cushing's is caused by excess cortisol/prednisone in the body from any source
Cushings can be caused by a steroid secreting tumor.
'Buffalo hump' and 'Moon face' are some of the signs of cushing's
questions.explanation:
•  Cushing’s syndrome is excess cortisol/prednisone (steroids) in the body from 
any etiology
• The most common cause of Cushing’s Syndrome is excess exogenous steroids 
(prednisone) which means it is physician induced. 
• Cushing’s syndrome symptoms include HTN, weight gain, “moon” face, 
“buffalo hump”, hyperglycemia (DM), osteoporosis, increased risk of 
infection, glaucoma, and cataracts.
• Treatment involves discontinuing the prednisone, or surgery if the Cushing’s 
Syndrome is caused by a tumor.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of whorl keratopathy?
questions.explanation: Almost ALL patients using amiodarone develop whorl keratopathy!! Another SE is NAION but it is rare.

questions.question: What is the definition of hyperthyroidism?
options: Elevated thyroid hormones in the blood (T3/T4)
Elevated thyroid hormones in the blood (T3/T2)
Elevated thyroid hormones in the urine (T3/T2)
answers: Elevated thyroid hormones in the blood (T3/T4)

questions.question: What is the most common cause of kidney disease/failure?
questions.explanation: Diabetes is the most common cause of kidney failure.

questions.question: What is Atherosclerosis and what is the biggest risk factor?
options: Expansion of the peripheral blood vessels in response to elevated BP.
Expansion of the largest blood vessels in response to elevated BP.
Inflammation in large blood vessels due to high cholesterol
Inflammation of peripheral blood vessels due to high cholesterol
answers: Inflammation in large blood vessels due to high cholesterol
questions.explanation:
Atherosclerosis is the chronic inflammation of medium to large blood vessels (including the coronary and carotids).
The biggest risk factor is high cholesterol. But it's also from HTN, smoking, DM. 

Atherosclerosis leads to vessel narrowing which can cause pain (angina), MI, stokes, and embolisms.

questions.question: What ocular finding is tamsulosin associated with. What receptor does it work on?
questions.explanation: Flomax (tamsulosin) is used for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and is used to help men with difficulty urinating. All cataract surgeons should be aware of tamsulosin use.

questions.question: What is pseudo-anaphylaxis?
options: Mast cell degranulation without prior exposure to allergen
answers: Mast cell degranulation without prior exposure to allergen
questions.explanation: Pseudo-anaphylaxis reactions are identical to real anaphylaxis but are not carried out by IgE reaction pathway like anaphylaxis is. Therefore, they DO NOT require a prior exposure to an allergen.

questions.question: Which is true about cephalosporins.
options: Increased gram - coverage every later generation
Decreased gram + coverage every later generation
Decreased gram - coverage every later generation
answers: Increased gram - coverage every later generation
Decreased gram + coverage every later generation
questions.explanation: Just think 'later generations become more negative and less positive'.

questions.question: What is a more likely side effect for Augmentin/Clavulin? (pick 2)
questions.explanation: The main SE of any penicillin is allergy (hypersensitivity), but also headaches, dizziness, and GI upset (diarrhea is VERY common and directly related to dose).

questions.question: Which cholesterol does simvastatin work to decrease? Also, what is the main side effects of statins (pick 2).
questions.explanation:
Cholesterol is created from the Acetyl-CoA –|HMG-CoA-Reductase|-- Mevalonate  Isoprenoids  Cholesterol.
STATINS (simvastatin, atorvoastatin) inhibit HMG-CoA-Reductase from creating LDLs
The problem is that statins reduce the liver’s function and causes a break down of muscles.

questions.question: What is the most common pituitart tumor?
What is the main side effect of ACE-inhibitors?
questions.explanation:
Ace-inhibitors (end with '-pril') 
Juxtaglomerular cells release RENIN when it discovers a drop in BP. RENIN goes to the liver and converts Angiotensin into Angiotensin 1 which floats over to the lungs (where ACE is) and it convert AG1 to AG2. AG2 enacts a physiologic change that results in: INCREASED BP, (increased thirst --^water intake), (constricts BVs --^pressure), (stims outer layer of adrenal cortex (glomerlaris) to secrete ALDOSTERONE (which acts on distal tubules of kidneys to reabsorb Na into blood -- increased osmosis into BVs).

questions.question: Select the following true statement about pituitary tumors.

The pituitary directly affects the eyes and can cause bitemporal hemianopsias.
answers: Most pituitary tumors are benign with the most common pituitary tumors being the prolactin-secreting adenomas.
questions.explanation:
Most pituitary tumors are benign. The most common pituitary tumors are 
prolactin-secreting adenomas*** Nothing the pituitary secretes directly 
affects the eyes. Ocular manifestations of pituitary tumors result from the 
mass effect. Headache & bitemporal hemianopsia visual field defect is classic 
for pituitary tumors**

questions.question: What is the benefit of using angiotensin 2 inhibitors over ACE inhibitors?
options: No dry cough since it stops AG2 before it works on the lungs
No dry cough since it doesn't mess with ACE within the lungs
answers: No dry cough since it doesn't mess with ACE within the lungs
questions.explanation:
AG2 inhibition is less affective on the lungs since that’s where ACE is and ACE-inhibitors work.
ACE inhibitors are better for kidney protection (which is why diabetics use it too since its stops Na retention ion the distal tubules via less ALDOSTERONE)

questions.question: What category is the drug of choice for chlamydia?
questions.explanation:
Azythromycin (1g) is the DOC for chlamydia. It is effective against gram + and - and belongs to the MACROLIDE class of Abs

Macrolides have a long half life (68 hours). Since they stick around for a while they can be dosed daily. Ex: Z-Pac = 6x250mg pills. 2 are taken on the first day and then once daily for the next 3 days.

questions.question: What is the category for the drug of choice for preseptal cellulitis?
questions.explanation:
Keflex = cephalexin is a first gen cephalosporin so it has high gram + coverage and is the DOC for preseptals

Remember for cephalosporins; Just think 'later generations become more negative and less positive'.

questions.question: What is the category for the drug of choice for gonorrhea?
questions.explanation:
Rocephin = cephtriazone is the Drug of choice for gonorrhea infections (a gram - bacteria), also treatsmycobacterium Tuberculosis (TB) (as long as it's not a MDR TB (multi-drug resistant)
Remember for cephalosporins; Just think 'later generations become more negative and less positive'.

questions.question: What is the DOC for preseptal cellulitis in a child?
questions.explanation:
This is a tricky question. But the answer is 2nd or 3rd gen cephs because they have more gram - coverage and kids are more likely to have H. Influenza (gram -) infections.
One way to think about it is -- kids are more likely to have a diverse group of bacteria causing their infection -- middle generation cephs are half gram +/half gram -.

Ex: Ceftin = cephurozime which is a 2nd gen ceph.

questions.question: What is the scariest side effect of doxycycline?
questions.explanation: Main side effects: GI irritation, photosensitivity/more likely to sunburn, idiopathic intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri), vestibular toxicity (mainly with minocycline), they can increase the effects of anticoagulants and therefore interfere with blood clotting.

questions.question: Which of the following options is false regarding the treatment of hyperthyroidism?
options: Propylthuouracil (PTU) is a medical therapy that doesn't have a lot of long term success.
Thyroidectomy has a high success rate but a high amount of patients become hypothyroid and have to be hospitalized for the procedure.
A single dose of radioactive iodine has a moderate success rate but may require multiple doses to achieve normalised thyroid levels.
answers: Thyroidectomy has a high success rate but a high amount of patients become hypothyroid and have to be hospitalized for the procedure.
A single dose of radioactive iodine has a moderate success rate but may require multiple doses to achieve normalised thyroid levels.
questions.explanation: Treatment options include: 1. Medical therapy – propylthiouracil (PTU) – hospitalization/surgery are avoided, not a lot of long-term success. 2. Surgical therapy - subtotal thyroidectomy – rapid cure of hyperthyroidism, high success rate with few patients become hypothyroid, patients must be hospitalized/have surgery. 3. Radioactive iodine – single dose – cure rate approaches 100%, no hospitalization/surgery; disadvantage is that a lot of patients end up hypothyroid (but that is easily managed).

questions.question: What is the weird side effect of fluoroquinolones?
questions.explanation:
Main SE of FQs is the same as other ABs (GI upset = #1, HA, dizziness, phototoxicity, liver problems) But it also causes tendonitis/tendon rupture which is why it's not commonly given to young people <18 since they can have issues with that.
IT CAN ALSO CAUSE RETINAL DETACHMENTS?!?!

questions.question: Select the true statement(s) about the thyroid gland.
options: Synthesizes and releases triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4). T3 & T4 decrease the metabolic rate.
By far the most common cause is Grave’s Disease which is an autoimmune disease where autoantibodies constantly are inhibiting the thyroid receptors
Symptoms of hyperthyroidism include decreased metabolism (weight gain), nervousness, tremor, tachycardia, heat intolerance, hypermotility of the gut, and staring gaze with lid retraction.
The most common cause of hypothyroidism is radioactive iodine therapy
answers: The most common cause of hypothyroidism is radioactive iodine therapy
questions.explanation:
• Synthesizes and releases triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4). T3 & T4 
increase the metabolic rate.
• Hyperthyroidism = thyrotoxicosis = elevated levels of thyroid hormone in 
the blood.
 **By far the most common cause is Grave’s Disease which is an 
autoimmune disease where autoantibodies constantly are stimulating the 
thyroid receptors
• Symptoms of hyperthyroidism include increased metabolism (weight loss), 
nervousness, tremor, tachycardia, heat intolerance, hypermotility of the gut, 
and staring gaze with lid retraction.
• Hypothyroidism = reduced levels of thyroid hormones, more common 
than hyperthyroidism. Most common cause is radioactive iodine therapy.
Symptoms include weight gain, fatigue, cold intolerance, decreased bowel 
motility, bradycardia, generalized apathy & mental sluggishness (mimics 
depression). Treatment: L-thyroxine (oral pill).

questions.question: What is the definition of hypertension?
questions.explanation:
HTN = when BP > 140/90 at multiple visits
Normal BP = less than 120/80
Pre-HTN = 120-139/80-90
Malignant HTN = >220/>120

questions.question: Select the right options that describe type 1 DM
options: T1DM is where the auto-immune system creates resistance in peripheral cells within the body
T1DM is where the auto-immune system destroys the beta cells in the pancreas.
answers: T1DM is where the auto-immune system destroys the beta cells in the pancreas.

questions.question: Which is true of ACE inhibitors?
options: They are first line therapy (along with diuretics)
They are second line therapy (after diuretics)
First choice for treating HTN in diabetics.
answers: First choice for treating HTN in diabetics.
questions.explanation: ACE-inhibitors are very kidney protective (notice how indirectly stopping ACE results in reduced ALDOSTERONE which means less salt is reabsorbed in the distal tubules of the kidney. Less salt = less kidney stones).

questions.question: Select the correct answer for GOOD cholesterol levels.
questions.explanation:
Total Cholesterol levels: <200 (over 240 is too high)
LDL <100 (over 160 is too high)
HDL >60 (lower than 40 is bad)

questions.question: Select the right answer for what constitutes BAD cholesterol levels
questions.explanation:
Total Cholesterol levels: <200 (over 240 is too high)
LDL <100 (over 160 is too high)
HDL >60 (lower than 40 is bad)

questions.question: What generic drugs combine create 'Bactrim'?
questions.explanation:
Sulfamethoxazole is a sulfonomide (which is a class of drugs that inhibits folate synthesis). 
Trimethoprim belongs to its own class 'trimethoprim' and is also a folate synthesis inhibitor.
Combining these two is synergistic and is even effective against MRSA. Due to that, when a pt gets a preseptal cellulitis while in the hospital, bactrim should be considered.
» Bactrim 80/400 (80 mg trimethoprim/400 mg sulfamethoxazole)
» Bactrim DS (double strength) 160/800 (160 mg trimethoprim/800 
mg sulfamethoxazole w. recommended dose BID X 1 week)

questions.question: Ignoring cost as a factor. Which antiviral is the better option?
questions.explanation:
Valtrex (valcyclovir) is the prodrug of Zovirax (acyclovir) and makes it 25-80% more bioavailable which means significantly less dosing is required. 
ACYCLOVIR: Simplex (400mg 5x/day (2g) for 7-10 days) Zoster (800mg 5x/day (4g) for 7-10 days)
VALCYCLOVIR Simplex (500mg 3x/day (1.5g) for 7-10days) ZOSTER (1000mg 3x/day (3g) for 7-10 days)
FAMCYCLOVIR Simplex (250mg 3x/day (0.75g) for 7-10days) ZOSTER (500mg 3x/day (1.5g) for 7-10 days)

Less dosing is more convenient but Fam and Val also have less incidence of post-herpetic neuralgia. There is a 72 hour window for AVs to be used to decrease odds of PHN...

questions.question: Tor F Doxycycline should be taken with dairy to avoid GI upset
questions.explanation: The main side effect of Tetracyclines (including DOXY) is GI irritation* (take Doxy with non-dairy food, avoid taking with acidic beverages, take at least 1 hour before bed)*

questions.question: Tor F Doxycycline should be avoided for pregnant and young pts
questions.explanation: Tetracycline inhibits bone formation and are thus category D. Do not use in pts younger than 8 due to teeth discolouration.

questions.question: True or False. Epinephrine is the primary treatment for anaphylaxis and has no contraindication to its use.
questions.explanation: Epinephrine causes sympathetic system to engage. ^broncho dilation, ^peripheral BV constriction (^BP and decreases leakage), ^HR, decreased histamine (and other inflammatory mediator) secretion.

questions.question: A young strabismic child presents at your office. Using visuoscopy you ask the patient to fixate the center of the target with their right eye (the left eye is occluded). The foveal reflex is positioned three hash marks to the LEFT of the center circle of the target. This finding suggests which type of fixation? (assume each hash mark is equal to 1 prism diopter)
options: The patient does not possess any eccentric fixation
questions.explanation:
Visuoscopy is an excellent technique to evaluate for eccentric fixation. This is performed by using the cross-hair target of your direct ophthalmoscope and projecting it onto the macula of the unoccluded eye. The patient is asked to fixate on the center of the target. No eccentric fixation is present if the foveal reflex aligns with the center of the cross-hairs. If the foveal reflex is to the left of the center (for the right eye), then the patient has nasal eccentric fixation. If the foveal reflex is located to the right of the target center, the patient possesses temporal eccentric fixation. The opposite holds true for the left eye (if the foveal reflex is to the right of the target center, the patient has nasal eccentric fixation). If the foveal reflex is located above the target, then the patient has inferior eccentric fixation, whereas a foveal reflex below the target is classified as superior eccentric fixation. 
In order to calculate the amount of eccentric fixation, you will have to know that from the center of the circle on the visuoscopy target to the edge of the circle is one prism diopter, and then each hash mark away from the center circle is an additional prism diopter. Therefore, the above patient has a total of 4 prism diopters of eccentric fixation (1 to the edge of the circle, and 3 for each additional hash mark).

questions.question: Which of the following prescriptions, if left uncorrected during the critical period, will lead to meridional amblyopia, in which vertical lines will appear clearer and horizontal lines appear blurry?
questions.explanation: All of the above prescriptions are likely to lead to meridional amblyopia except for +0.50-1.25x180. This prescription is quite low and will not result in amblyopia if left uncorrected during the critical period. Meridional amblyopia is caused when lines of a certain orientation are in focus to a greater degree than lines of another orientation. For example, the above prescription of -0.25-4.25x178 will cause lines in the vertical meridian to be in focus (remember that the power is 90 degrees away from the axis), while lines that are horizontal will appear blurry. This person may have difficulty with optotypes containing horizontal components like the letter E. Meridional amblyopia can only result if the astigmatism is great enough and is present during the critical period.

questions.question: What is the MOST likely predicted visual acuity of a patient with 2 prism diopters of temporal eccentric fixation?
questions.explanation:
An equation that can be used to determine the predicted amount of visual acuity loss that can be attributed to eccentric fixation: 

MAR = EF + 1 

MAR = minimum angle of resolution (the reciprocal of the Snellen fraction) 
EF = eccentric fixation in prism diopters 

In the above question, the fixation disparity has been measured as 2 prism diopters, and plugging this into the equation gives an expected of MAR = 2 + 1 or 3 (60/20). The reciprocal in terms of Snellen fraction can then be converted to 20/60. Therefore, in a patient with 2 prism diopters of eccentric fixation, the visual acuity is likely to be about 20/60. If the visual acuity is significantly worse than this, one should seek further evaluation into an additional pathologic cause of visual acuity loss. 

Clinical Strabismus Management: Principles and Surgical Techniques. Rosenbaum, A.L., Santiago, A.P. 1999. W.B. Saunders Company. Philadelphia, PA.

questions.question: When performing a unilateral cover test on your patient, you note the following: upon covering the right eye, the left eye moves in 1/10 times. Upon covering the left eye, the right eye moves in 4/10 times. The alternating cover test measures 25 prism diopters base-in. What is your diagnosis based on these findings?
options: 25 prism diopter intermittent alternating esotropia; right eye preferred
25 prism diopter intermittent alternating esotropia; left eye preferred
25 prism diopter intermittent alternating exotropia; right eye preferred
25 prism diopter intermittent alternating exotropia; left eye preferred
answers: 25 prism diopter intermittent alternating exotropia; left eye preferred
questions.explanation: The unilateral cover test will tell you the eye (or eyes) affected, the direction, and the frequency of the ocular deviation. In this case, the eyes lose fixation 5/10 times, which shows that the frequency is intermittent (it would be constant if at least 1 eye moved 10/10 times). Since each eye moves at least once when the other is covered, the deviation is considered to be alternating. The uncovered eye is noted to move 'in' on unilateral cover test, meaning that the deviation is an exotropia (if the eye moves 'out' it is an esotropia). Since the right eye loses fixation more than the left eye (4/10 vs. 1/10), the left eye is considered to be the preferred eye. Also, the alternating cover test will tell you the full amount of the deviation, which is 25 prism diopters in this case.

questions.question: Which of the following types of refractive error would have the greatest tendency to lead to amblyopia?
options: A three-year old boy with an uncorrected refractive error of OD: +1.50 DS and OS: -2.00 DS
A four-year old girl with an uncorrected refractive error of OD: +1.00-1.50 x 180 and OS: +1.50-1.25 x 180
A five-year old girl with an uncorrected refractive error of OD: -3.25 DS and OS: -0.75 DS
A four-year old boy with an uncorrected refractive error of OD: +6.00 DS and OS: +1.50 DS
answers: A four-year old boy with an uncorrected refractive error of OD: +6.00 DS and OS: +1.50 DS
questions.explanation:
A prescription in which there is a big refractive difference between the eyes, especially if both eyes are hyperopic, is most likely to cause amblyopia. Consider the prescription of OD: +6.00 DS and OS: +1.50 DS. The left eye will be able to accommodate 1.50 diopters to obtain a clear distance image and, because accommodation is bilateral and equal, the right eye will still be 4.50 diopters out of focus. This defocus will cause the left eye to dominate the cortical neurons, causing a decreased amount of binocular neurons and leading to poor stereopsis and amblyopia of the right eye. 

A prescription of OD: -3.25 DS and OS:-0.75 DS will not lead to amblyopia because even though the right eye is blurry in the distance, at 30 cm its image will be clear and in focus. This also applies to the prescription of OD: +1.50 DS and OS:-2.00 DS. Although both patients will have good monocular corrected acuities, they will most likely possess poor stereopsis due to a decreased amount of binocular neurons because the eyes are never in focus at the same distance. 

It is important to note that in order for amblyopia to occur, ametropia must be present during the critical period.

questions.question: The mother of a 6 year-old female reports that her daughter's right eye seems to turn out occasionally. A unilateral cover test performed at near reveals a tropia that is neutralized with 4 prism diopters base-in in upgaze, 10 prism diopters base-in in primary gaze, and 16 prism diopters base-in in downgaze. Which of the following patterns describes the ocular alignment of this patient?
questions.explanation:
An A-pattern exotropia is an incomitant ocular deviation in which there exists a significant difference in the magnitude of an exotropia when measured in up-gaze and down-gaze (typically greater than 10 prism diopters). The ocular deviation is less apparent in up-gaze and becomes more evident as the patient positions his or her eyes downward. It is for this reason that this type of deviation most commonly causes difficulty with reading. These patients will often adopt a chin-down compensatory head position in an attempt to attain fusion. 

A- and V-pattern ocular deviations occur as a result of abnormal relative contributions of the oblique and vertical rectus muscles, resulting in an imbalance of their horizontal components in up and down-gaze. For example, in the case of A-pattern deviations, there is either a primary superior oblique overaction, inferior oblique underaction with superior oblique overaction, or inferior rectus underaction, which causes the horizontal exo deviation to become larger in downgaze as compared to upgaze (or the eso deviation to become less apparent in downgaze).

questions.question: While performing the alternating cover test (ACT), the patient's right eye moves outwards when the occluder is moved from the right eye to the left eye, and the patient's left eye moves outwards when the occluder is moved from the left eye to the right eye. Which of the following statements is true regarding the above results?
options: Base-out prism is required to neutralize the ocular deviation thereby displacing the retinal image nasally
Base-in prism will effectively neutralize the deviation and will result in a displacement of the retinal image nasally
Base-out prism is required to neutralize the ocular deviation thereby displacing the retinal image temporally
Base-in prism will neutralize the deviation by displacing the retinal image temporally
answers: Base-out prism is required to neutralize the ocular deviation thereby displacing the retinal image temporally
questions.explanation:
While performing the alternate cover test, eye movement will occur in the opposite direction of the deviation. For example, a patient with an eso deviation will manifest outward movement of the eyes (nasal to temporal) as in the above patient. Esophoria is neutralized with base-out prism. When an object is viewed through a prism, its perceived image will become displaced towards the apex of the prism; however, the retinal image will be displaced towards the base of the prism. Therefore, base-out prism will shift the retinal image temporally. In order to place the resultant image onto the fovea, the eye will move in the direction of the apex of the prism. 

Handbook of Pediatric Strabismus and Amblyopia. Wright, K., Spiegel, & Thompson, L. Springer, 2006 page 91.

questions.question: Which of the following methodologies can be used to test for anomalous correspondence?
questions.explanation:
Anomalous correspondence can be measured via the Bagolini striated lens test, the Hering-Bielschowsky afterimage test, the major amblyoscope, and Haidinger's brushes used in conjunction with the Brock Givner afterimage test. 

Binocular versions and the Bruckner test are useful for determining the presence of an ocular deviation. 

Interferometry is helpful in measuring a patient's potential acuity, especially for an amblyope.

questions.question: What is the name of the sensory perception that results in the simultaneous appreciation of two dissimilar superimposed images caused by stimulation of corresponding retinal points by different objects?
questions.explanation:
At the onset of strabismus, there are two sensory perceptions that arise based on the normal projection of stimulated retinal points. These are known as confusion and pathological diplopia. In order to appreciate these, the patient must possess the ability to perceive images from both eyes simultaneously. 

Confusion refers to the simultaneous perception of two dissimilar images that are superimposed upon one another. This occurs in cases of strabismus in which the fovea of the fixating eye is stimulated by the image of the target of regard, while the corresponding retinal point in the non-fixating eye (usually the fovea also) is stimulated by the image of a different object. This results in simultaneous superimposition of two different objects. 

Pathological diplopia is the simultaneous appreciation of two images of the same object in two different positions. This occurs in cases of strabismus in which the fovea of the fixating eye is stimulated by the image of a certain object, while that same object falls on a different (non-corresponding) retinal point other than the fovea in the non-fixating eye. This causes the same object to appear in two different locations.
