In patients with esotropia, the diplopia is considered homonymous (non-crossed), while exotropes experience heteronymous diplopia (crossed).

questions.question: A very concerned mother brings in her 3-month old Asian child into your office reporting that his right eye appears to be turned in. Acuities and cover test are unable to be attained as the patient is uncooperative. Hirschberg reveals a light reflex that is displaced nasally by 5 degrees in both eyes and Kappa measures 0 for both the right and left eye. Ocular motilities are normal and the infant does not react when either eye is transiently occluded. Cycloplegic retinoscopy reveals OD: +2.50-1.00 x 180 and OS: +2.25-0.75 x 176. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Because the Hirschberg reflexes are symmetrical and within normal limits and the cycloplegic findings are normal one can assume prominent epicanthal folds are causing the appearance of strabismus. This finding is quite common in patients of Asian origin as well as some Caucasian infants. Because the bridge is slightly flatter and the nasal epicanthal dermis tissue is prominent, the medial canthus can be covered. To confirm this diagnosis, gently pinch the skin of the bridge for gross observation and comparison of the eyes and measure Kappa and Hirschberg. All of these findings should be normal. Be sure to praise the parent for being astute because strabismus is best treated if caught early. If you are in doubt bring the patient back in a month or so and re-measure or refer to a pediatric optometrist or ophthalmologist. 

Reference: Wright, K., Spiegel, P. and Thompson, L. Handbook of Pediatric Strabismus and Amblyopia, 2006, pp. 144-147.

questions.question: A 5-year old Asian female presents with best corrected visual acuities of OD: 20/100 and OS: 20/20. Her parents report a history of patching OS on and off for 1 year, but report that the patient has been very non-compliant with traditional patching. However, the patient has been very good about wearing her glasses. Wet retinoscopy reveals OD: -9.50-2.00x180 and OS: pl-0.25x180 with unremarkable ocular health findings. What is the best form of treatment for this patient?
options: Contact lens prescription: OD: -8.50-1.25x180 OS: no correction and Cyclopentolate 1% ophthalmic solution: 1gtt OS qam q3days; near activities are highly recommended 2-3 hrs/day
Spectacle prescription: OD: -9.50-2.00x180 and OS: pl-0.25x180 and Cyclopentolate 1% ophthalmic solution: 1gtt OS qam q3days; near activities are highly recommended 2-3 hrs/day
Contact lens prescription only: OD: -8.50-1.25x180 and OS: no correction
Contact lens prescription: OD: -9.50-2.00x180 and OS: no correction and Cyclopentolate 1% ophthalmic solution: 1gtt OS qam q3days; near activities are highly recommended 2-3 hrs/day
Spectacle prescription: OD:-9.50-2.00x180 and OS: pl-0.25x180 and patch OS 2-3 hrs/day with distance activities only
answers: Contact lens prescription: OD: -8.50-1.25x180 OS: no correction and Cyclopentolate 1% ophthalmic solution: 1gtt OS qam q3days; near activities are highly recommended 2-3 hrs/day
questions.explanation: Although the patient is quite young, a contact lens should be prescribed for this patient due to her high anisometropia. Instead of continuing with traditional patching for this patient (due to non-compliance), contact lenses along with Cyclopentolate drops were recommended. ATS I studies reveal that cycloplegic treatment is just as effective as traditional patching, with better compliance than using atropine. Due to her high degree of ametropia, it is important to remember to take into account vertex distance.

questions.question: A 14-year old female post-traumatic brain injury patient presents with limited ADDuction of the right eye in left gaze, along with a constant right hypertropia of 5 prism diopters. In left gaze, the left eye presents with a horizontal jerk nystagmus. Pupils are equal, round and reactive to light with no ptosis of either lid. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Internuclear ophthalmoplegia occurs when there is a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). This results in difficulty with ADDuction of the affected eye ipsilateral to the affected MLF region, with a horizontal jerk nystagmus in the ABDucting eye. 

A bilateral Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia would present with an upbeat nystagmus in upgaze and would present with limited ADDuction in both eyes. 

Cranial Nerve III palsies present with a blown pupil of the affected eye, along with a hypotropia and exotropia. A partial Cranial Nerve III palsy may present with a lid ptosis only with no other associated findings. 

Cranial Nerve IV palsy would present with a hypertropia of the affected eye with limited movement in downward gaze of the affected eye.

questions.question: A patient presenting with a history of a right lateral rectus palsy will MOST likely have a compensatory abnormal head posture in which of the following directions?
questions.explanation: In cases where there is purely a horizontal deviation of the eye (lateral or medial rectus palsy), patients will typically develop a compensatory abnormal face turn to reduce diplopia. For example, a patient with a right lateral rectus palsy will experience diplopia in right gaze. In order to reduce this, the patient can turn his or her face to the right, which deviates the eyes to the left and away from the field of gaze in which muscle weakness and diplopia are present.

questions.question: A patient presenting with a history of a left superior oblique palsy will MOST likely have a compensatory abnormal head posture in which of the following directions?
questions.explanation: In order to compensate for diplopia due to torsional or vertical misalignment of the eyes, patients will often adopt an abnormal head posture in which the head is tilted to either side. For example, in the case of left superior oblique weakness, the left eye will be elevated relative to the right eye. Patients will then develop a head tilt toward the right side (or towards the hypotropic eye). This compensatory position will reduce the vertical separation between the diplopic images, allowing for fusion to be regained.

questions.question: Which of the following tests would be the most appropriate to conduct if a patient presented with the following symptoms: unexplained asthenopia, presence of head tilt, and tilt of targets on other tests when dissociated?
questions.explanation:
Head tilt and tilt of targets would indicate a cyclotorsion. The double Maddox rod would be the most appropriate test to conduct in order to indicate direction and angle size of the torsion. A head tilt can also be attributed to non-concomitancy; hence other tests that could aid in diagnosis include version testing, forced-duction, alternate cover test, Park's 3-step, and Hess-Lancaster. 

Visuoscopy is used to diagnose monocular fixation. 

Accommodative Facility Test is used to test accommodative dysfunction. 

Although the Bruckner Test is used to detect an ocular deviation, it will not help explain a head tilt. 

The Hirschberg Test is also used to detect an ocular deviation, but will not explain a head tilt. This test will provide an estimated amount of ocular deviation, but does not detect any cyclotorsion.

questions.question: You ask your patient to place a red lens in front of their right eye and proceed to perform the red lens test. Your patient reports seeing two images with the red image being perceived to the left of the white light. What type of deviation corresponds with the above findings?
questions.explanation: As the red lens is placed over the right eye, your patient reports that his right eye sees a red light and the left eye sees a white light. In this case, the red light is perceived to the left of the white light demonstrating crossed diplopia. Crossed diplopia is characteristic of an exo deviation. The easiest way to remember this is that a cross makes an 'x', and 'exo' contains an 'x' so the 'x's always go together.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following are TRUE in regards to central and peripheral suppression? (Select 2)
options: In peripheral suppression, the image from the peripheral retina of the deviating eye is suppressed to avoid confusion
In central suppression, the image from the fovea of the deviating eye is suppressed to avoid diplopia
In peripheral suppression, the image from the peripheral retina of the deviating eye is suppressed to avoid diplopia
In central suppression, the image from the fovea of the deviating eye is suppressed to avoid confusion
answers: In peripheral suppression, the image from the peripheral retina of the deviating eye is suppressed to avoid diplopia
In central suppression, the image from the fovea of the deviating eye is suppressed to avoid confusion
questions.explanation:
Confusion refers to the simultaneous perception of two dissimilar images that are superimposed upon one another. In order to avoid confusion, the image from the fovea of the deviating eye is suppressed. 

Pathological diplopia is the simultaneous appreciation of two images of the same object in two different positions. In order to avoid diplopia, the image from the peripheral retina of the deviating eye is suppressed.

questions.question: Which of the following tests would prove helpful in diagnosing a V-pattern exotropia?
questions.explanation:
Non-concomitancy describes an ocular deviation that is unequal in different fields of gaze with either eye fixating, such as a V-pattern exotropia. Hess-Lancaster allows the examiner to quantify differences in the angle of deviation with either eye fixating, allowing one to diagnose a V-pattern exotropia vs. an A-pattern exotropia, etc. Other tests that can help diagnose non-concomitancy include version testing, forced-duction, alternate cover test, Park's 3-step, red lens, and the Maddox rod test. 

The 4 Base Out test is used to test ocular deviation, but does not quantify deviation in different fields of gaze. 

Interferometry is used to assess a patient's visual acuity potential. It can be used with amblyopic patients or patients with media-obstructing pathology. 

Visuoscopy is used to test for monocular fixation. 

The Worth 4-Dot test is used to check for suppression and type of ocular deviation, but does not quantify deviation. 

Monocular Estimate Method Retinoscopy (MEM) is used to help diagnose accommodative dysfunction disorders.

questions.question: The unilateral cover test reveals the following results: cover right eye, left eye turns in: cover left eye, no movement of right eye: cover right eye, no movement of left eye. How would you classify these results?
questions.explanation:
Movement of the uncovered eye on the unilateral cover test indicates that eye was not directed at the target of regard. In this instance, movement of the left eye was noted on the first attempt at covering the right eye but the left eye remained stationary when the test was repeated. Any movement seen on the unilateral cover test is diagnosed as a tropia of the eye that moved. Since the left eye did not move each time the right eye is covered, it is described as an intermittent movement. Since the left eye rotated inward, this is described as a left exotropia. 
The presence of a phoria is tested for by administration of the alternating cover test. Phorias cannot be subdivided as intermittent or constant.

questions.question: A concerned father reports that one of his 12-month-old infant's eyes does not appear straight. You decide to perform the Hirschberg test to evaluate for strabismus. The corneal reflex of the right eye is centered, while the left reflex is displaced 0.5 mm superiorly relative to the center of the pupil. Angle Kappa (Lambda) is zero for each eye. What is the correct deviation and magnitude of the observed strabismus?
questions.explanation: The Hirshberg test is performed at a distance of 50 cm. A penlight or transilluminator is held just below the doctor's preferred eye and the doctor then sits in front of the patient and directs the beam towards the patient's nose while the patient is instructed to fixate on the light. The position of the corneal reflexes relative to the center of the pupil is assessed in each eye. Superior displacement of the corneal reflex suggests hypotropia, while inferior displacement infers hypertropia. Each millimeter of displacement of the reflex from the center of the pupil equates to roughly 22 prism diopters of deviation.

questions.question: Which of the following methods of checking visual acuity would be the most appropriate and most precise when following an amblyopic patient?
questions.explanation: The Bailey-Lovie Chart provides a more PRECISE way of following visual acuity improvement with amblyopic patients. Using LogMAR, you are able to award extra points for extra letters guessed on the chart (-0.02 for each letter guessed correctly). All of the other charts are noted in Snellen units. The Feinbloom chart is a good method to use for low vision patients, but again is in Snellen notation.

questions.question: A 12-year old white female presents with an intermittent, alternating exotropia of 15 prism diopters at distance and near. Uncorrected visual acuity is 20/20 OD, OS. Wet retinoscopy reveals +0.50 DS OD, OS. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
options: No prescription at this time; consult OMD for strabismus surgery
Prescribe -1.00 spectacles for full-time use with gross convergence exercises; no surgery required at this time
Prescribe +0.50 OD, OS spectacles for full-time use with gross convergence exercises; consult an ophthalmologist (OMD) for strabismus surgery
No spectacle prescription or surgery required at this time. Suggest vision therapy, i.e., gross convergence exercises 5 min/day
No prescription at this time; gross convergence exercises daily; consult OMD for strabismus surgery
Plano lenses OU with 20 prism diopter of horizontal prism for full-time use; consult OMD for surgery
answers: No spectacle prescription or surgery required at this time. Suggest vision therapy, i.e., gross convergence exercises 5 min/day
questions.explanation: A strabismus is present with this patient but does not require surgery or correction at this time because the patient does not have a monocular strabismus and the magnitude of the angle of deviation is <20 prism diopters. Additionally, the patient's visual acuity is 20/20 without correction, so no spectacle correction is required at this time. If the patient had a prescription of -0.50 with decreased acuities, one would consider prescribing spectacles. Gross convergence exercises are recommended for improvement in gross convergence activities and control.

questions.question: A 2 year-old female is referred to your office for the evaluation of a possible eye turn. Upon examination you determine that she has a 15-prism diopter right esotropia. Dry retinoscopy reveals +2.00DS OD, and +1.50DS OS, while wet retinoscopy reveals +5.00DS OD, and +4.50DS OS. Which of the following refractive corrections is MOST appropriate to prescribe?
questions.explanation: There are some general rules that optometrists typically utilize in order to determine the amount of refractive correction to prescribe for children. In cases of hypermetropia, young children presenting with up to 4D of hyperopia, good acuities, and no complaints, spectacle correction is not necessary. With degrees of hyperopia greater than 4D, or complaints of near vision, a general rule of thumb is to prescribe about 2/3 of the full cycloplegic refraction. In patients where an esotropia exists (as in the patient in this question), the full cycloplegic refraction should always be prescribed (if hyperopic), as this may help reduce the angle of the deviation by decreasing the amount of accommodation that must be employed.

questions.question: A 4-year old white male was correctly diagnosed with a 4+ congenital nuclear cataract in the right eye. Wet retinoscopy after surgical removal of the cataract revealed the following prescription: OD: +18.00 DS Visual Acuity: 20/200 OS: +0.75 DS Visual Acuity: 20/20. He was also found to have an intermittent, right esotropia of 15 prism diopters, with a 20% occurrence rate. What would be the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
options: OD: +9.00DS contact lens; patching of the OS 6hrs/day 7days/wk
Spectacle correction OD: +18.00DS, OS: +0.75; patching of the OS 6hrs/day 7days/wk
OD: +18.00 DS, OS: plano spectacle prescription; patching of the OD 6 hrs/day 7days/wk
OD: +23.50 contact lens, OS: no correction; patching of the OS, 6hours/day, 7 days/wk
OD: +18.00 DS contact lens, OS: no correction; patching of OD 6hrs/day 7 days/wk
answers: OD: +23.50 contact lens, OS: no correction; patching of the OS, 6hours/day, 7 days/wk
questions.explanation:
A contact lens with part-time patching of the left eye would be the best treatment option for this patient. The high anisometropia between the two eyes secondary to the cataract removal and ensuing aphakia would benefit most with a contact lens versus a spectacle correction. Using a contact lens will minimize the image size difference between the two eyes. With such a high prescription, it is important to account for vertex distance to ensure optimal correction. Fc= Fs/1-dFs where Fc= the dioptric power at the corneal plane, Fs= the dioptric power at the spectacle plane, and d is the vertex distance in meters. In general, the vertex distance of the phoropter from the corneal plane is 13 mm unless otherwise specified. Solving for Fc: Fc= +18.00/1-(0.013)(+18.00), Fc = +18.00/1-(0.234), Fc= +18.00/0.766, Fc= +23.49, rounding to the nearest 0.25 is +23.50. 

Patching is an important treatment with this patient, as he is still young. Optimal age for improvement from patching is between the ages of 2-7 for amblyopia. One must patch the good eye, to stimulate the eye with the worse visual acuity. Near activities such as video games, reading, coloring, homework or the computer are recommended in order to stimulate accommodation in the weaker eye. Although ATS studies cite that part-time patching is just as effective, full-time patching is recommended to increase compliance. 

Answer: Spectacle correction OD: +18.00DS OS: +0.75; Patching of the OS 6hrs/day 7days/wk. This is not the optimal treatment, as image size difference between the eyes is too great. Additionally, lens thickness in a spectacle prescription would hinder optimal vision. 

Answer: OD: +18.00 DS Contact Lens OS: no correction; Patching of OD 6hrs/day 7 days/wk. One should recommend patching of the OS not the OD, as the OD has amblyopia, not the OS. 

Answer: OD: +9.00DS Contact Lens; Patching of the OS 6hrs/day 7days/wk. One should prescribe full plus to optimize visual acuity especially since the patient presents with an intermittent esotropia. 

Answer: OD: +18.00 DS OS: plano Spectacle prescription; Patching of the OD 6 hrs/day 7days/wk. A spectacle prescription has too much of an image size difference between the eyes. Additionally, one should patch the OS and not the OD, as the OD is the eye with amblyopia.

questions.question: Which of the following actions will result in the erroneous finding of a heterotropia while performing the unilateral cover test?
options: Having the patient focus too hard on the target causing over-accommodation
Use of an improper accommodative target
Using a colored fixation target as opposed to a black and white target
questions.explanation:
The unilateral cover test is useful for detecting the presence of a heterotropia. However, the test is not meant to be overtly dissociating and therefore, if the occluder is left too long over an eye, an underlying phoria may become expressed and mistaken for a tropia. 

If an appropriate accommodative target is not used, this may potentially result in under-diagnosis of a heterotropia due to a failure to control the patient's accommodation. As long as the target controls accommodation, the color will not affect the outcome of the test. 

Pediatric Ophthalmology and Strabismus 2nd ed. Wright K. & Spiegel, P. Springer, 2003, page 194.

questions.question: A mother reports that her 2-year-old child's right eye does not appear straight. You decide to perform the Hirschberg test to evaluate for strabismus. The corneal reflex of the right eye is displaced 0.5 mm temporally while the left reflex is centered. Angle Kappa (Lambda) is zero for each eye. What is the correct deviation and magnitude of the observed strabismus?
questions.explanation: The Hirshberg test is performed at a distance of 50 cm. A penlight or transilluminator is held just below the doctor's preferred eye and the doctor then sits in front of the patient and directs the beam towards the patient's nose while the patient is instructed to fixate on the light. The position of the corneal reflexes relative to the center of the pupil is assessed in each eye. Temporal displacement of the corneal reflex suggests esotropia, while nasal displacement infers exotropia. Each millimeter of displacement of the reflex from the center of the pupil equates to roughly 22 prism diopters of deviation.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following examination findings indicate the presence of a bilateral fourth nerve palsy? (Select 2)
options: Right hypertropia in left gaze, left hypertropia in right gaze
Greater than 10 degrees of cyclodeviation on double Maddox rod test
Right hypertropia in right gaze, left hypertropia in left gaze
Less than 10 degrees of cyclodeviation on double Maddox rod test
answers: Right hypertropia in left gaze, left hypertropia in right gaze
Greater than 10 degrees of cyclodeviation on double Maddox rod test
questions.explanation:
Bilateral involvement in cases of a fourth nerve palsy should be suspected until further examination proves otherwise. The following tests and results can be utilized to differentiate between unilateral and bilateral palsies: 
- Extraocular muscle evaluation will reveal a right hypertropia in left gaze (due to right inferior oblique overaction), and left hypertropia in right gaze (due to left inferior oblique overaction) in cases of bilateral involvement 
- On double Maddox rod testing, the amount of rotation of one Maddox rod (indicating the amount of cyclodeviation) will be less than 10 degrees in unilateral cases and greater than 10 degrees (sometimes even greater than 20) in bilateral cases 
- A cover test performed in different positions of gaze will reveal a 'V' pattern esotropia in bilateral fourth nerve palsies

questions.question: A 37-year female patient complains of diplopia worse at distance than at near. You immediately note that her right eye is mildly esotropic in primary gaze and that she turns her chin toward her right to look at you. You suspect that she is compensating for an inability to ABduct the right eye. Which extraocular muscle is most likely effected in this patient?
questions.explanation: The lateral rectus is responsible for ABduction of the eye. In this case, paresis of the right lateral rectus has made the patient unable to ABduct the right eye adequately to maintain fusion, and she is compensating to minimize her diplopia by turning her head to the right.

questions.question: A patient presents with a right hypertropia that worsens when he looks to the right and when he tilts his head to the right. Which of the following muscles is MOST likely affected?
questions.explanation: Using the Parks three-step method, one can easily isolate the affected muscle. Draw out the muscles and circle appropriately. Remember that for Parks three-step, a right hypertropia entails a circling of the right IR and right SO and the left IO and left SR. Because the hypertropia is worse in right gaze, circle the right SR and the right IR and the left IO and the left SO. Lastly, because his hypertropia is worse when he tilts his head to the right, circle the right SR and the right SO, as well as the left IO and the left IR. The only muscle that has been circled three times is the left inferior oblique.

questions.question: While performing visuoscopy of the LEFT eye, your patient's foveal reflex is located 3 hash marks below and 2 hash marks to the right of the center of the target. These results suggests which type of eccentric fixation? (assume each hash mark is equal to 1 prism diopter)
questions.explanation: Visuoscopy is an excellent technique to evaluate for eccentric fixation. This method is performed by using the cross-hair target of your direct ophthalmoscope and projecting it onto the macula of the unoccluded eye. The patient is asked to fixate on the center of the target. No eccentric fixation is present if the foveal reflex aligns with the center of the cross-hairs. If the foveal reflex is to the left of the center (for the right eye), then the patient has nasal eccentric fixation. If the foveal reflex is located to the right of the target center, the patient possesses temporal eccentric fixation. The opposite holds true for the left eye (if the foveal reflex is to the right of the target center, the patient has nasal eccentric fixation). If the foveal reflex is located above the target, then the patient has inferior eccentric fixation, whereas a foveal reflex below the target is classified as superior eccentric fixation.

questions.question: While performing the Worth-4-dot test (red lens placed over right eye) your patient reports seeing 3 green circles. Based upon these findings what is the correct extrapolation?
options: The glasses were placed backwards on the patient
questions.explanation: In the Worth-4-dot test, the red lens is generally placed in front of the right eye. Four dots are then projected onto the screen. The two horizontal circles are green, the top circle is white and the bottom circle is red (in most cases). The right eye alone views the bottom and the top circle as red and pink/red, respectively. The left eye views three green circles. Combined both eyes view four circles, two green, one lower that appears red and the upper one appears red/green. Viewing three green circles to the right of two red circles indicates crossed diplopia. Three green circles viewed to the left of two red circles denote uncrossed diplopia. The perception of three green circles alone is indicative of right eye suppression. If the patient reports two red circles suppression of the left eye is indicated.

questions.question: Which of the following methods can be used to test for the presence of eccentric fixation?
questions.explanation: Angle Kappa (Lambda), visuoscopy, Haidinger's Brush, and the Brock-Givner afterimage transfer tests are all methods of investigating for the presence of monocular fixation. The Hirschberg test allows for the determination of the direction, magnitude, and frequency of the ocular deviation. The Bruckner test may be used to detect small angle deviations, media opacities, anisometropia, and tumors. Binocular versions allows for the determination of the comitancy of the deviation.

questions.question: You are performing a Haidinger's brush test on the right eye of your young amblyopic patient and he reports to you that he visualizes the center of the brush pattern to be 5 degrees to the left of to the fixation target. Which of the following BEST describes the result of this test?
options: The patient has nasal eccentric fixation
The patient has anomalous retinal correspondence
The patient has temporal fixation disparity
The patient has temporal eccentric fixation
The patient has nasal fixation disparity
answers: The patient has nasal eccentric fixation
questions.explanation:
Eccentric fixation refers to an anomalous condition in which some retinal point other than the fovea is used for fixation. Eccentric fixation can occur under both binocular and monocular conditions, but it is best diagnosed with the normally fixating eye occluded. When present, eccentric fixation is observed in the strabismic or amblyopic eye. In a patient with esotropia, the abnormal fixation point is typically located in the nasal retina; with exotropia, the fixation point is located in the temporal retina. Additionally, there can also be a vertical component to eccentric fixation. 

There are several different tests that can be utilized to aid in the diagnosis of eccentric fixation, including the Haidinger's brush test. During this test, the normally fixating eye is occluded while the patient views a blank surface through a rotating polarizer. The patient will then see a small rotating figure eight or bow-tie pattern that represents where the fovea projects in object space. The patient is asked to fixate on a reference dot on the display pattern and report where the brush pattern is located with respect to this point. If the patient states that the brush is placed nasal to the fixation point (as in the above question), this indicates that he or she is using an eccentric fixation point that is nasal to the fovea; the opposite is true if the patient states that the brush is rotating temporal to the reference point. 

Anomalous retinal correspondence is a binocular condition in which there is an abnormal sensory adaptation that results in the fovea of the normal eye being paired with a non-foveal retinal point of the deviating eye. 

Fixation disparity is also a binocular condition in which there is a very small misalignment of the eyes that does not result in a breakdown of single binocular vision. 

Primary Care Optometry (5th edition). Grosvenor, T.P. 2007. Butterworth Heinemann Elsevier. St. Louis, MO.

questions.question: Which of the following tests for stereopsis does not require the use of polarizing glasses?
questions.explanation: The Random dot E, the Titmus stereo test, and the Randot stereo test all require the use of polarizing glasses to achieve stereopsis. The Lang stereo test is administered without the use of polarizing glasses, which is helpful with anxious or non-cooperative children. The test plate uses a random dot stereogram pattern to test for bifixation. The card is held at 40 cm and the child is asked to find a star, a car, and a cat (for Lang I) which all represent different levels of stereopsis (600', 550', and 1200', respectively).

questions.question: You perform a Worth 4-dot test on your 10 year-old patient who is wearing a green lens in front of the right eye and red lens in front of the left. She reports to you that she sees 3 green lights only. What can you conclude from these results?
options: There is suppression of the left eye
There is suppression of the right eye
The patient is amblyopic in the left eye
The patient is amblyopic in the right eye
answers: There is suppression of the left eye
questions.explanation:
Worth 4-dot testing is typically implemented using a red lens over the right eye and a green lens over the left eye. This filters out all colors except red for the right and all colors except green for the left eye. The patient is then asked to view a box or flashlight with 4 lights; one red, two green, and one white. However, in this question, the patient is viewing the flashlight with the green lens over the right eye and the red lens over the left eye. 

Results can be interpreted as follows: 
- If all 4 lights are observed, the patient has binocular single vision 
- If the patient is strabismic but still sees 4 lights, the patient has harmonious anomalous retinal correspondence 
- If 2 red lights are seen, the patient is suppressing the right eye 
- If 3 green lights are seen, the patient is suppressing the left eye 
- If the patient sees 3 green lights and 2 red lights, diplopia is present (indicating strabismus) 

It is important to note that patients may be strabismic AND have suppression simultaneously, but this conclusion cannot be made by the Worth 4-dot test alone. A cover test and determination of either the presence or absence of strabismus should be made before testing for the best interpretation of results. In this question, the results of the cover test are not provided; therefore, one can only conclude that suppression is present.

questions.question: Which of the following types of retinal correspondence occurs in a patient whose objective angle of strabismus is equal to the angle of anomaly?
options: Type I paradoxical anomalous retinal correspondence
Type II paradoxical anomalous retinal correspondence
questions.explanation:
Patients with strabismus will typically either experience diplopia or suppress the image from the deviating eye in order to reduce confusion and double vision. In some cases, patients with strabismus can undergo a sensory adaptation in order to be able to fuse images from each eye. This subtle binocular anomaly is known as anomalous retinal correspondence and has shown to be present in up to half of strabismus cases. In normal retinal correspondence, the two foveae are corresponding retinal points, both having the same occulocentric visual direction. In patients with anomalous retinal correspondence, the fovea of the non-deviating (or better-seeing eye) is matched with another a non-foveal point of the retina of the deviating eye. This occurs only during binocular fixation and reflects a reorganization of the visual direction in the strabismic eye in order to allow for binocular fusion. 

There are several different types of anomalous retinal correspondence based on the measurements of three different angles: the objective angle of strabismus, the subjective angle of strabismus, and the angle of anomaly. 

° Harmonious anomalous retinal correspondence 
- Sensory adaptation completely compensates for the angle of strabismus; therefore, there is no subjective angle of strabismus 
- The objective angle of strabismus is equal to the angle of anomaly 

° Unharmonious anomalous retinal correspondence 
- Usually, the subjective angle of strabismus is smaller than the objective angle of strabismus 
- Angle of anomaly is location somewhere between the fovea and point zero (retinal projection of straight ahead direction) 

° Paradoxical anomalous retinal correspondence 
- Unexpected sensory adaptations that typically occur following strabismus surgery 
- Paradoxical Type I: The angle of anomaly is greater than the objective angle of strabismus, and the objective and subjective angles of strabismus are in opposite directions (eso vs. exo) 
- Paradoxical Type II: The subjective angle of strabismus is greater than the objective angle of strabismus (but in the same direction) and the angle of anomaly is smaller than the subjective angle of strabismus

questions.question: Which of the following actions will result in UNDER-estimation of the angle of deviation while performing the alternate cover test?
options: Using an accommodative target of 20/25 in a patient who is correctable to 20/20 vision
Having the patient wear their distance glasses while performing the cover test at a simulated distance of 6 m
Placing the fixation target slightly below the patient's eye level
Stacking prisms in the same orientation while attempting to neutralize the ocular deviation
answers: Stacking prisms in the same orientation while attempting to neutralize the ocular deviation
questions.explanation:
When attempting to neutralize the patient's deviation using prism, the stacking of prisms oriented in the same manner will result in the underestimation of the deviation. Stacking of prisms that are oriented in different directions is acceptable (i.e. base-out and base-up). When performing the alternate cover test, it is important to use an appropriate accommodative target as well as having the patient wear their habitual spectacles. Failure to control for accommodation may result in improper measurement of the magnitude of the ocular deviation. When performing the cover test at near, it is often recommended to hold the target slightly below the patient's eye level. 

Pediatric Ophthalmology and Strabismus 2nd ed. Wright K. & Spiegel, P. Springer, 2003, page 195.

questions.question: Which of the following tests relies on the birefringence pattern of the macula in order to evaluate an anomaly associated with strabismus and amblyopia?
questions.explanation:
A Haidinger's brush is an entopic phenomenon that is seen as a yellowish horizontal bow-tie shaped figure with fuzzy edges (hence the name 'brush') that can be observed in the center of the visual field against a blue sky while facing away from the sun. Clinically, this phenomenon is artificially created by having a patient look at a diffusely illuminated blank surface through a rotating polarizer. The patient will then see a small rotating bow-tie pattern. This rotating object represents where the fovea projects in object space. It is most commonly accepted that this phenomenon is caused by the birefringence pattern of the radially oriented fibers of Henle's layer around the fovea. Haidinger's brushes are very helpful in the diagnosis of eccentric fixation. 

Primary Care Optometry (5th edition). Grosvenor, T.P. 2007. Butterworth Heinemann Elsevier. St. Louis, MO.

questions.question:
An 8-year old Hispanic male comes in with the following habitual prescription: +0.75-0.75 x 180 OU. His entering visual acuity with correction was 20/40 OD, OS, OU at both distance and near. After cycloplegic examination, you find the following on wet retinoscopy: 
OD: +4.00-2.75 x 180 20/25 (Distance) 
OS: +4.50-2.75 x 180 20/25 (Distance) 
Which of the following would be the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
options:
OD: +3.50-2.75x180 
OS: +3.50-2.75x180 
Return for follow-up appointment in 4-6 weeks

Spectacle prescription: 
OD: +3.25-2.75 x 180 
OS: +3.75-2.75 x 180 
Return for a follow-up appointment in 4-6 weeks

Spectacle prescription 
OD: +4.00-1.00 x 180 
OS: +4.00-1.00 x 180 
Return for follow up appointment in 4-6 weeks

OD: +0.75-2.75 x 180
OS: +0.75-2.75 x 180 
Return for follow-up appointment in 1 year
Continue with current habitual prescription; alternate patching therapy 3hrs/day 5 days/week. Return for follow-up appointment in 4-6 weeks.
answers:
Spectacle prescription: 
OD: +3.25-2.75 x 180 
OS: +3.75-2.75 x 180 
Return for a follow-up appointment in 4-6 weeks
questions.explanation: In this case, poor entering visual acuities were attributed to refractive amblyopia in both eyes. The patient was not wearing his full potential prescription. When deciding on the spectacle prescription, one should keep in mind that the prescription should have full cylinder and no less than half of the hyperopic prescription. For full visual acuity potential, the retinal images should be equal and balanced, hence keeping the +0.50 DS difference between the two eyes. It is important to follow up on these types of prescription changes in case the patient presents with more hyperopia after adapting to his/her new spectacle prescription. Part-time patching is not warranted at this initial visit as his visual acuity may improve drastically by correcting his refractive error alone, and his refractive error is relatively equal in both eyes.

questions.question: You have appropriately diagnosed a 42-year old black male complaining of acute, binocular horizontal diplopia with an ischemic Cranial Nerve VI palsy OD. He presented with the following clinical findings:
options: Habitual Prescription: OD: -2.50 DS OS: -2.50 DS +1.00 add
Unilateral Cover Test: 40 prism diopter constant right esotropia
Versions: -4 restriction in right gaze of the right eye
Diplopia resolves with 30 prism diopter Base Out over the right eye.
What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
5 prism diopter Fresnel prism over the right eye only; refer to the ER for systemic work up
Occlusion patch over the spectacles of the left eye for full time wear; monitor for changes in 4-6 weeks; refer to primary care physician for systemic work up
No treatment at this time; monitor for changes in 4-6 weeks; refer to primary care physician for systemic work up
Spectacle lenses: OD:-2.50 DS OS: -2.50 DS Add: +1.00 with 15 BO ground in prism OD, OS; refer to emergency room for systemic work up
Place a patch over the right eye of his current habitual prescription; refer to ER for immediate systemic work up
Refer to ophthalmology for strabismus surgery of the right eye
answers: Place a patch over the right eye of his current habitual prescription; refer to ER for immediate systemic work up
questions.explanation:
Placing a patch over the right eye of his current spectacle prescription along with an immediate ER referral is the most appropriate treatment because the Cranial Nerve VI palsy is acute and ischemic. Grinding prism into the glasses would prove useless, as an ischemic cranial nerve palsy is expected to resolve with time with appropriate systemic treatment. Additionally, 30 diopters of prism is too large to grind into a pair of habitual spectacle lenses. Though the deviation of the esotropia is high, surgery is not warranted at this time because it is caused by ischemia and may completely resolve with time. 

The ER is warranted in this case, as a primary care physician consult would be more appropriate if the patient's systemic blood pressure and fasting blood sugar were not extremely high. The patient's blood pressure is considered a hypertensive emergency.

questions.question:
You wish to assess the comitancy of your patient's deviation via the alternate cover test in all nine diagnostic fields of gaze. The results are as noted below from your point of view: 

What is the correct diagnosis given these findings?
options: A non-comitant deviation due to an underacting left lateral rectus
A non-comitant deviation due to an underacting right medial rectus
A comitant deviation due to an overacting left lateral rectus
A comitant deviation due to an overacting right medial rectus
answers: A non-comitant deviation due to an underacting left lateral rectus
questions.explanation: When assessing comitancy, the deviation should be roughly equivalent in all fields of gaze. The primary deviation is assessed when the non-paretic eye is fixating in primary gaze and the deviation is neutralized with prism. The secondary deviation is measured when the paretic eye is fixating and the deviation is neutralized in straight-ahead gaze. The deviation will be greater when the deviated eye is fixating. The deviation will also be greater towards the side of the affected muscle.

questions.question: Patching the right eye of a seven year old cat, rendering it monocular for a year, will have what effect on binocular cells in the striate cortex?
options: A rapid increase in monocular cells of the deprived eye
A rapid increase in monocular cells of the non-deprived eye
questions.explanation: Once a cat (or a human) has matured beyond its critical period, monocular deprivation will have virtually no effect on cortical cells. If an eye is sutured or patched during the critical period, many or all of the cells in the cortex will become monocular and react to stimuli presented to the non-deprived eye. For a cat, the critical period is the first three months of life; for a human, the first two years are the most sensitive, and the critical period is over by 7-9 years.

questions.question: Which of the following patients would most likely possess good stereopsis?
options: A six-year old with a constant right 30 prism diopter esotropia
A five-year old with constant alternating esotropia
A four-year old with OD: -2.50 DS and OS: -2.25 DS
A three-year old boy with an uncorrected refractive error of OD: +1.50 DS and OS: -2.00 DS
A five-year old girl with an uncorrected refractive error of OD: -3.25 DS and OS: -0.75 DS
answers: A four-year old with OD: -2.50 DS and OS: -2.25 DS
questions.explanation:
A prescription of myopia that is relatively low to moderate and equal between the eyes will not cause a reduction in stereopsis because even without correction, this person will have good near acuities, and the eyes will be in focus at the same distance. 

A person who has constant alternating esotropia will not possess amblyopia because each eye is used to focus an image, just not at the same time. Because the eyes are not used simultaneously, there will be little to no stereopsis. 

Strabismus results in the perception of two images that are not fusible by the brain, causing diplopia. In order to eliminate double vision, the brain will suppress an eye (usually the deviated eye). This suppression leads to amblyopia and poor stereopsis. 

A prescription of OD:-3.25 DS and OS:-0.75 DS will not lead to amblyopia because even though the right eye is blurry in the distance, at 30 cm its image will be clear and in focus. This also applies to the prescription of OD: +1.50 DS and OS: -2.00 DS. Although both patients will have good monocular corrected acuities, they will most likely possess poor stereopsis due to a decreased amount of binocular neurons because the eyes are never in focus at the same distance.

questions.question: A virtual image is located 30.00 cm from a +12.00 D crown glass (n=1.52) lens in air. Which of the following equations can be used to determine the location of the object?
questions.explanation: One can solve the above problem using the equation L'=L+P where L'=the image vergence (n'/l' in meters) L=the object vergence (n/l in meters) and P=the power of the refracting surface. Substituting the above values into the equation yields: (1/-0.30)= (1/l) +12.00, solving for l, -3.33= (1/l)+12.00, -3.33-12.00=(1/l), -15.33=(1/l), l=1/-15.33, l=-0.0652 or -6.52cm. The index of refraction used for the equation is 1.00 as the lens is in air, and both the object and the image are located in air.

questions.question: A real image is located 25.00 cm from a +15.00 D polycarbonate (n=1.586) lens in air. Which of the following equations can be used to determine the location of the object?
questions.explanation: One can solve the above problem using the equation L'=L+P where L'=the image vergence (n'/l' in meters), L=the object vergence (n/l in meters), and P=the power of the refracting surface. Substituting the above values into the equation yields: (1/0.25)= (1/l) +15.00 solving for l, 4= (1/l)+15.00, 4-15.00= (1/l), -11.00= (1/l), l= 1/-11.00, l= -0.091 or -9.1 cm. The index of refraction used for the equation is 1.00 as the lens is in air, and both the object and the image are located in air.

questions.question: According to ANSI standards, what is the tolerance for error in cylinder power for spectacle prescriptions possessing cylinder powers of 2.00 diopters or less?
questions.explanation:
ANSI standards for cylinder power tolerances vary depending on the strength of the cylinder power 
- For cylinder powers of 2.00 D or less, the error tolerance is +/- 0.13 D 
- Cylinder powers ranging from 2.25 through 4.50 D have an error tolerance of +/- 0.15 D 
- Any cylinder power above 4.50 D has an error tolerance that is 4% of the cylinder power
PowerPage
ANSI Standards

questions.question: What is the sphero-cylinder equivalent (in minus cylinder format) of a 0.50 D Jackson crossed-cylinder when the axis of the minus cylinder is located at 180 degrees?
questions.explanation:
The Jackson crossed-cylinder is a lens comprised of two cylindrical lenses of equal power. One cylindrical lens is positive and is situated on one side of the lens; the other is negative and is positioned on the other side of the lens; their axes are located perpendicularly to each other. Typically, the location of the minus axis is identified with a red dot, and the plus cylinder axis location is marked by a black or white dot. The sphero-cylinder equivalent of a 0.50 D Jackson crossed-cylinder with its minus axis located at 180 degrees is +0.50 -1.00 x 180. Placing the individual components on an optical cross can sometimes help in the determination of the sphero-cylinder form and would appear as described for a 0.50 D Jackson crossed-cylinder lens with its minus axis located at 180 degrees: 

Reference: Clinical Optics and Refraction. A Guide for Optometrist, Contact Lens Opticians and Dispensing Opticians. Evans, B., Franklin, A. & Harvey, W. Bailliere, Tindall and Elsevier, 2007, page 112.

questions.question: Using a lens bar, an eye with -1.00 -1.00 x 180 of ametropia would require which of the following two lenses to achieve a neutral reflex in all meridians during retinoscopy (assume a working distance of 67.0 cm)?
options: +0.50 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented vertically and -0.50 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented horizontally
-0.50 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented vertically and +0.50 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented horizontally
-2.00 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented vertically and -1.00 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented horizontally
-1.00 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented vertically and -2.00 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented horizontally
answers: +0.50 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented vertically and -0.50 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented horizontally
questions.explanation: Principal meridians are located 90 degrees apart. When performing retinoscopy, in order to neutralize the 180-degree axis the retinoscope streak is oriented vertically and is swept from side to side. In order to neutralize the 090-degree axis, the retinoscope streak is oriented horizontally and is swept up and down. A working distance of 67.0 cm corresponds to 1.50 D (1/0.67 m = 1.50 D). 1.50 D must be added to both values to achieve the gross findings in each meridian. Therefore, in the above example, when scoping the 180 degree meridian, the streak is oriented vertically at a working distance of 67.0 cm to neutralize a -1.00 D refractive error in this meridian; it would require a +0.50 D lens in place. To neutralize the 090-degree meridian, with the streak oriented horizontally, a -0.50 lens must be placed in front of the eye.

questions.question: Using a lens bar, an eye with +1.50 -0.50 x 090 of ametropia would require which of the following two lenses to achieve a neutral reflex in all meridians during retinoscopy (assume a working distance of 50.0cm)?
options: +1.50 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented vertically and +1.00 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented horizontally
+3.50 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented vertically and +3.00 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented horizontally
+3.00 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented vertically and +3.50 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented horizontally
+1.00 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented vertically and +1.50 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented horizontally
answers: +3.00 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented vertically and +3.50 D with the streak of the retinoscope oriented horizontally
questions.explanation: Principal meridians are located 90 degrees apart. When performing retinoscopy, to neutralize the 180-degree axis, the retinoscope streak is oriented vertically and is swept from side to side. In order to neutralize the 090-degree axis, the retinoscope streak is oriented horizontally and is swept up and down. A working distance of 50.0cm corresponds to 2.00 D (1/0.50m = 2.00 D). 2.00 D must be added to both values to achieve the gross findings in each meridian. Therefore, in the above example, when scoping the 90-degree meridian, the streak is oriented horizontally at a working distance of 50.0cm to neutralize a +1.50 D refractive error in this meridian; it would require a +3.50 D lens in place. To neutralize the 180-degree meridian, the streak of the retinoscope is oriented vertically and a +3.00 D lens must be placed in front of the eye.

questions.question: A single spherical surface (r= -6cm) separates glass from air. What is the position of the first focal point (F)?
questions.explanation:
The L + D = L' equation should be used in the above question because it is asking about a single refracting surface. The definition of the first focal point states that it is the unique point in which the final pencil of rays is parallel to the system (infinity). This would mean that x' in this equation should be set to infinity, and anything divided by infinity is 0; therefore, we can set L' equal to 0. 

This reduces the equation to L + D = 0 
n= 1.52, x= unknown (distance to F), n'= 1.0, and r= -0.06m (6cm) 
1.52/x + (1.0-1.52)/-0.06 = 0 
1.52/x = -8.67 
x= -17.53 cm 

Note- This equation can also be switched around and simplified to: 
f = -n/D f= distance to first focal point (F) 
f' = +n/D f'= distance to second focal point (F) 
If D is not explicitly given you'll still need to use D= (n'-n)/r

questions.question: After performing your distance refraction, the phoropter reads -1.75-1.25 x 075 in the right eye. You then proceed to calculate the near prescription. The patient reports that they can read RS 20 when the phoropter reads +0.50-1.25 x 075 OD. What is the power of the reading addition?
questions.explanation: In order to determine the reading add, calculate the difference between the near endpoint in the phoropter and the distance endpoint in the phoropter which in this case is +2.25 D.

questions.question: In order to determine the most appropriate reading add for your presbyopic patient you decide to balance relative accommodation. With a +1.00 D tentative reading add in place, the NRA measures +1.50 and the PRA measures -0.50. Given the above results what should the final add be?
questions.explanation: In order to determine the reading add by balancing the relative accommodation, one must first determine what number needs to be added to the PRA and subtracted from the NRA to equalize the two. In the above example that number is 0.50 D. Taking away 0.50 D from the NRA yields +1.00D and adding it to the PRA gives -1.00 D. Therefore in order to balance both the NRA and the PRA one must increase the reading add by 0.50 D giving a final add of +1.50 D.

questions.question: You wish to confirm a patient's glasses prescription for the right eye of +2.00-1.00 x 180 via hand neutralization. Which of the following combination of lenses would correctly neutralize her prescription? (in minus cylinder format)
options: +2.00 DS lens oriented at 180 degrees (with break motion)/+1.00 DS lens oriented at 090 degrees (against break motion)
-1.00 DS lens oriented at 180 degrees (with break motion)/-2.00 DS lens oriented at 090 degrees (against break motion)
+1.00 DS lens oriented at 180 degrees (with break motion)/-2.00 DS lens oriented at 090 degrees (against break motion)
-1.00 DS lens oriented at 180 degrees (with break motion)/+2.00 DS lens oriented at 090 degrees (against break motion)
-2.00 DS lens oriented at 180 degrees (with break motion)/-1.00 DS lens oriented at 090 degrees (against break motion)
+2.00 DS lens oriented at 180 degrees (with break motion)/-1.00 DS lens oriented at 090 degrees (against break motion)
answers: -2.00 DS lens oriented at 180 degrees (with break motion)/-1.00 DS lens oriented at 090 degrees (against break motion)
questions.explanation:
When hand neutralizing a lens, one must first determine if the lens is spherical or possesses astigmatism. While holding up the lens and looking through it at some type of cross hair grid or vertical line, rotate the lens and observe whether or not the line viewed through the glass appears to 'break' relative to the line that is not viewed through the lenses. If a break is observed, the lens has astigmatism. The location on the lens where the line appears to 'break' in the same direction of the rotation (with break) is the minus cylinder axis. The other principal meridian of the lens is located 90 degrees away and should exhibit 'against break' motion. 

Neutralize each meridian separately and place the answers on an optical cross. It is imperative to change the signs of the powers, as the true power of the unknown lens will be opposite those of the neutralizing lenses. The minus cylinder axis should be the meridian with the least minus power (or most plus power). The power of the lens can then be written in minus cylinder form. The axis can be determined by placing the lens against a protractor, with the temporal and the nasal aspect of the frame aligned with the 180 and zero marks for the left eye, with the temples facing towards you (the 180 should always be located to the left for each eye and gradually decrease to zero while moving to the right). The location on the lens with the meridian that displayed 'with break' will be the minus cylinder axis.

questions.question: A thick lens system has a center thickness of 1cm, index of 1.50, plane front surface, and back surface power of +20 diopters. What is the equivalent power of the lens?
questions.explanation:
De = D1 + D2 - (t/n) x D1D2 
De = equivalent power, D1 = front surface power, D2 = back surface power 
t = thickness of lens system, n = index between the 2 surfaces 

In the above question, t = 1cm (0.01 m), n=1.5, D1 = 0 and D2 = +20 

De = 0 + 20 -(0.01/1.5) x (0 x 20) 
De = 0 + 20 - 0 
De = +20 diopters 

The equivalent power of this thick lens system is +20 diopters, which is also equivalent to the back vertex power and back surface power of the lens. Therefore, to get the most accurate reading of this lens, it should be placed in a lensometer with the back surface against the stop in order to measure the back surface power.

questions.question: A convex mirror in water (n=1.33) has a radius of curvature of 12 cm. What is the dioptric power of the mirror?
questions.explanation:
A concave mirror converges light and therefore acts like a convex lens, hence concave mirrors have positive dioptric values whereas convex mirrors diverge light and possess negative dioptric powers. 

The equation used to determine the power of a mirror is P=-2n/r, where P= the power of the mirror in diopters, n= the index of refraction of the surrounding medium, and r= the radius of curvature of the mirror in meters. P=2(1.33)/-0.12=-22.17 D. Remember, a convex mirror will have a positive radius of curvature and a concave mirror will have a negative radius of curvature.

questions.question: What is the power of a concave mirror (in diopters) located in air with a radius of curvature of 20 cm?
questions.explanation: A concave mirror converges light and therefore acts like a convex lens hence concave mirrors have positive dioptric values whereas convex mirrors diverge light and possess negative dioptric powers. The equation used to determine the power of a mirror is P=-2n/r where P= the power of the mirror in diopters, n= the index of refraction of the surrounding medium, and r= the radius of curvature of the mirror in meters. Unless otherwise stated, always assume that the index of refraction of air is 1.0. Input the values from the above question: P= -2(1)/-0.2=+10.00 D.

questions.question: A myope with 3.00 D of ametropia will have a far point located at which distance (in meters)?
questions.explanation: The far point of a myopic eye is located by calculating the reciprocal of the ametropia. The answer will be in meters. 1/3=0.33 meters. Therefore, an object placed at 33 cm will be in focus for a person who has 3.00 D of myopia. Anything past 33 cm will be observed with decreased clarity with the intensity of blur increasing as one progresses further from the far point.

questions.question: What is the equivalent logMAR acuity of 20/60?
questions.explanation: The logMAR acuity is determined by taking the log of the reciprocal of the decimal acuity. For the above Snellen fraction 20/60, the decimal acuity is found by dividing the numerator by the denominator. 20/60 = 0.333. Now take the log of the reciprocal which gives us log (1/0.333) = 0.478 or 0.48.

questions.question: Which of the following spectacle prescriptions can be classified as simple hyperopic astigmatism?
questions.explanation:
Refractive astigmatism is classified by the relationship of the two focal lines that are produced by the refractive components of the eye with respect to the retina (when accommodation is relaxed). The different clinical types of astigmatism are described below. 

Simple astigmatism: When accommodation is relaxed, one focal line is located at the retina; the other is located either in front of or behind the retina 
- If the second focal line is in front of the retina, this is simple myopic astigmatism (one principle meridian is plano, the other is myopic) 
- If the second focal line is located behind the retina, this is simple hyperopic astigmatism (one principle meridian is plano, the other is hyperopic) 

Compound astigmatism: When accommodation is relaxed, both focal lines are located either in front of or behind the retina 
- If both are located in front of the retina, this is considered compound myopic astigmatism (both principle meridians are myopic) 
- If both are located behind the retina, this is classified as compound hyperopic astigmatism (both principle meridians are hyperopic) 

Mixed astigmatism: With relaxed accommodation, one focal line will be located in front of the retina and one line will be located behind the retina (one principle meridian is myopic, the other is hyperopic). 

In order to determine where the focal points are located for a given spectacle correction, place the values on an optical cross. Plus values indicate that the focal line is behind the retina, minus values indicate focal points in front of the retina, and a value of plano indicates a focal line that is located on the retina. 

In the above question, the spectacle prescription of +2.75 -2.75 x 180, when placed on an optical cross, will have one principle meridian that is hyperopic and one that is plano. This corresponds to the definition of simple hyperopic astigmatism. 

Primary Care Optometry (5th edition). Grosvenor, T.P. 2007. Butterworth Heinemann Elsevier. St. Louis, MO.

questions.question: Using Javal's rule, what is the predicted magnitude of refractive astigmatism for the given keratometry readings? 44.50 D at 90 degrees and 43.50 D at 180 degrees.
questions.explanation:
Another formula that you may want to commit to memory is Javal's rule. Javal's rule is used to predict the magnitude of refractive astigmatism based upon keratometry readings. The formula is refractive astigmatism = (1.25 x the difference in keratometry readings) +/- 0.50 D. If the astigmatism is with-the-rule, 0.50 D is subtracted, if the astigmatism is against-the-rule, 0.50 D is added to the results. If the astigmatism is oblique, 0.50 D is dropped from the equation. 

Grosvenor et al (1988) later proposed that dropping the 1.25 factor from the equation results in more accurate calculations and modified the formula to: refractive astigmatism = the difference in keratometry readings +/- 0.50 D (added or subtracted based upon if the astigmatism is with or against-the-rule). Oblique astigmatism simply is thought to be equal to the oblique corneal toricity. 

For our example above, the astigmatism is considered with the rule therefore 1.25 x 1 = 1.25. 1.25-0.5 = 0.75 D.

questions.question: A window in water is located 2 meters to the left of a light source (the index of refraction for water is 1.33). What is the reduced vergence for the pencil of rays falling at the surface of the window (the index of refraction for the window is 1.54)?
questions.explanation: The formula for reduced vergence (L) is L=n/x where n= the index of refraction and x is equal to the distance of the surface from the source (in meters). Remember measurements are to be taken from the surface to the point of convergence. Surfaces located to the right of the convergence point result in negative vergences. Surfaces located to the left yield positive vergences. For the above example, the index of refraction of the window does not matter, since the question addresses the light falling at its surface and not the light penetrating the window. The answer is determined as follows: 1.33/2=0.665 D or 0.67 D.

questions.question: A small pond containing a liquid with an unknown index measures 3.2 meters deep. A coin at the bottom of the pond appears to be located 2.8 meters away when viewed from directly above by an observer in air. What is the index of the liquid in the small pond?
questions.explanation: For angles smaller than 15 degrees Snell's law reduces to sin i=i' and can therefore be represented as x/n= x'/n' where x= the object distance, x'= the image distance, n= the index of the medium in which the object resides, and n'= is the index of the medium in which the observer lies. For the above example, 3.2/n=2.8/1.0 solve for n, n=1.14.

questions.question: While performing binocular indirect ophthalmoscopy (BIO), in order to completely fill a +20 D condensing lens with the image of a patient's fundus, how far should the lens be held from the patient's corneal plane (assume emmetropia of both the patient and the examiner)?
questions.explanation: In order to fill the lens with an image of the fundus, it must be held at its focal point, which is 5 cm. The focal point of the lens is determined by taking the reciprocal of its dioptric power, in this case 1/20=0.05 meters, or 5 cm. Failure to hold the lens at this distance from the patient's eye will not degrade the image quality, but rather the proportion of the lens that is occupied by the image of the fundus.

questions.question: A ray of light traveling through air reaches the surface of a plane glass plate with an angle of incidence of 30 degrees. The light ray continues through the glass plate and reaches water on the opposite side. Which of the following equations can be used to calculate the angle of the light ray as it exits the glass and enters the water?
questions.explanation:
Use Snell's law equation for this problem. 
n sin i = n' sin i' 
n= index of refraction of where incident rays travel from 
n'= next media encountered (n''= third media encountered, etc.) 
i= angle of incidence at 1st surface (i2 would be angle of incidence at 2nd surface) 
i'= angle of refraction at first surface (i2' would be angle of refraction at 2nd surface) 

In this case there are 3 different media, but the final ray will have the same direction it would have without the glass plate in the middle. In other words, the initial angle of incidence is related to the final angle by Snell's law no matter what media is in between. 

With that in mind, we can ignore the glass plate. 
1.0 sin 30 = 1.33 sin i' 
i' = 22.08 degrees

questions.question: A ray of light traveling in air strikes a flat transparent surface (n= 1.53) at an angle of 47 degrees from the normal. Which of the following equations can be used to determine the angle of refraction?
questions.explanation: Snell's law of refraction states that when light travels through a material that possesses an index of refraction greater than 1.0, the light rays change direction and become bent (or refracted). Snell's law is depicted as the following: n sin i= n' sin i' where n= the index of refraction of the first medium, i= the angle of incidence, n'= the index of the second medium, and i'= the angle of the refracted ray. All angles are measured with respect to the normal which lies perpendicular to the interface between the different media. For the above example 1.00 (sin 47)= 1.53 sin i', solving for i'= 28.55 degrees.

questions.question: A presbyopic patient having 1.00 D of hyperopia wears +2.50 D single vision lenses for reading. If the patient's near point of accommodation while wearing these lenses is measured to be 25 cm using the push-up method, then what is the patient's actual amplitude of accommodation?
questions.explanation: Since +1.00 D of the reading lens power is correcting the patient's 1.00 D of hyperopia, the actual reading add provided is then +2.50 - 1.00 D or +1.50 D. Through this add, the measured amplitude of accommodation would be increased by 1.50 D over the actual amplitude. Since the near point of accommodation with the lenses in place is measured to be 25 cm (4.00 D equivalent), the patient's actual amplitude of accommodation is then equal to 4.00 - 1.50 or 2.50 D.

questions.question: What is the equivalent decimal acuity of 20/40?
questions.explanation: To determine the decimal equivalent simply divide the numerator of the Snellen fraction by the denominator. For the above case, 20/40 = 0.5

questions.question: You are looking through a microscope and focus on a mark that is on the bottom of an empty dish. You then fill the dish with a liquid to a depth of 0.5cm. In order for the mark to stay in focus, you have to raise the microscope a distance of 0.22cm. What is the index of the liquid in the dish?
questions.explanation:
This question is asking for you to calculate the index using the equation for lift. If you are looking through the microscope without the medium over the object and then place the medium over the object, use the lift equation to answer the question. On the other hand, if you are looking through the microscope with the medium in place, you are viewing the image, and the question is asking you to use the reduced thickness equation. 
lift = (x - x') = t(1-1/n) (when the other medium is air) 
x-x' is the distance from the object to the image (or how much you have to move the microscope; in this case it is 0.22cm). 
t is the thickness of the medium, which is 0.5cm. 
0.22cm = 0.50cm (1-1/n) 
n= 1.785 

Remember that lift only depends on the thickness and index of the material.

questions.question: The pupil of an eye has a diameter of 7mm and is 3.5mm behind the anterior cornea. If the radius of curvature of the cornea is 7.5mm, what is the lateral magnification of the image of the pupil?
questions.explanation:
The equation for lateral magnification can be written as follows: 
m= h'/h (height of image/height of object) = (n/x)/(n'/x') or (nx')/(n'x) = L/L' 
The stem of the question gives us h= 7mm, x=-3.5mm, r=-7.5mm (x and r are both negative because the pupil is a real object, and the cornea is a convex surface). We also know that n=1.33 and n'= 1.0; in order to solve the equation, we first need to solve for x'. 

Use equation L+D= L' which can also be written as n/x + (n'-n)/r = n'/x' 
1.33/-0.0035 + (1.0-1.33)/-0.0075 = 1.0/x now solve for x: 
-380 + 44 = 1/x 
x= -2.98mm 

We can now use the lateral magnification equation m= (nx'/n'x) 
m= (1.33 x -2.98)/(1.0 x -3.5) 
m= 1.13

questions.question: What is the size of the 20/20 distance optotype for Snellen acuity used clinically ?
questions.explanation: The height of the Snellen 20/20 optotype that subtends an angle of 5 minutes of arc at twenty feet is 8.73 mm. All other target heights will be multiples of this number.

questions.question: A ray of light travels through a water-glass interface (n= 1.33 and 1.58 respectively) and is refracted at an angle of 42 degrees from the normal. Which of the following equations can be used to solve for the angle of the incident ray from the normal?
questions.explanation: Snell's law of refraction states that when light travels through a material that possesses an index of refraction greater than 1.0, the light rays change direction and become bent (or refracted). Snell's law is depicted as the following: n sin i= n' sin i' where n= the index of refraction of the first medium, i= the angle of incidence, n'= the index of the second medium, and i'= the angle of the refracted ray. All angles are measured with respect to the normal, which lies perpendicular to the interface between the different media. For the above example, 1.33 (sin i)= 1.58 (sin 42) solving for i= 52.65 degrees.

questions.question: A ray of light traveling in water (n=1.33) strikes a flat, transparent surface (n= 1.59) at an angle of 32 degrees from the normal. Which of the following equations can be used to determine the angle of refraction?
questions.explanation: Snell's law of refraction states that when light travels through a material that possesses an index of refraction greater than 1.0, the light rays change direction and become bent (or refracted). Snell's law is depicted as the following: n sin i= n' sin i' where n= the index of refraction of the first medium, i= the angle of incidence, n'= the index of the second medium, and i' = the angle of the refracted ray. All angles are measured with respect to the normal, which lies perpendicular to the interface between the different media. For the above example, 1.33(sin 32)=1.59 sin i', solving for i'= 26.31 degrees. It is important to commit the index of refraction of water to memory; it is 1.33.

questions.question: You are looking through a microscope and focus on a mark on the lower surface of a glass plate that is 2.5mm thick. To focus on a mark on the top surface of the glass, you have to move the microscope up a distance of 1.5mm. What is the index of refraction of the glass?
questions.explanation:
This question is asking you to calculate the index of refraction using the equation for reduced thickness. If you are already looking through the microscope with the glass (or other medium) in place, you are viewing the image and the question requires that you use the reduced thickness equation. 
reduced thickness = x' = t /n 
x' is the distance from the object to the image which is 1.5mm 
t= thickness of the medium which is 2.5mm 
1.5 = 2.5/n 
n= 1.67

questions.question: A ray of light is deviated by a crown glass prism with a power of 10.0 pd. Which of the following formulas will CORRECTLY determine the distance from the prism required for the ray of light to be deviated 6.0 cm?
questions.explanation: Using the equation P=(100)(x/d), where P= power of the prism (in prism diopters, pd), x=the total distance that a ray of light is deviated and d=the total distance from the prism to the location where the deviation is measured, we can determine the distance required to deviate a ray of light 6.0 cm. For the above question, 10.0 pd= (100)(6.0 cm/d cm), solving for d yields 60 cm or 0.6 m.

questions.question: Unpolarized light is incident onto a 1/4-wave plate. What is the total amount of transmitted light?
questions.explanation: An ideal wave plate does not absorb any light and therefore the total transmittance of light will be 100% or T=100. Wave plates serve to change phase relations between components of a ray of light. 1/4-wave plates cause the O-ray and the E-ray (components of a ray of light) to undergo a phase shift so that they differ by one quarter of a cycle or pi/2 radians. Quarter-wave plates are important for producing circularly polarized light.

questions.question: You are at an aquarium looking at a fish swimming in the tank. The fish appears to be 15 inches from the window. What is the actual distance from the window?
questions.explanation:
For this equation, you will need to use the small-angle form of Snell's law. 
object vergence (L) = n/x 
image vergence (L') = n'/x' 
For a plane surface L=L' or n/x = n'/x' 
n= 1.33, x= actual (object) distance, n'= 1.0, x'= 15 inches (image distance) 
1.33/x = 1.0/(-)15 
x= (-)19.95 

Remember that the (-) just means that the object rays are divergent; therefore, the object is real.

questions.question: A concave mirror, located in water, has a radius of curvature of 13.0 cm. What is the power of the mirror (rounded to the nearest 0.25 D)?
questions.explanation:
A concave mirror converges light and therefore acts like a convex lens; hence, concave mirrors possess positive dioptric powers. 

The equation used to determine the power of a mirror is P=-2n/r, where P= the power of the mirror in diopters, n= the index of refraction of the surrounding medium, and r= the radius of curvature of the mirror in meters. P=-2(1.33)/-0.13= 20.46 D, or 20.50 D rounded to the nearest diopter. Remember, a concave mirror will have a negative radius of curvature; a convex mirror will have a positive radius of curvature. The index of refraction of water is 1.33.

questions.question: A convex mirror, located in air, has a radius of curvature of 6.0 cm. What is the power of the mirror (in diopters)?
questions.explanation:
A convex mirror diverges light and therefore acts like a concave lens; hence, convex mirrors possess negative dioptric powers. 

The equation used to determine the power of a mirror is P=-2n/r, where P= the power of the mirror in diopters, n= the index of refraction of the surrounding medium, and r= the radius of curvature of the mirror in meters. P=-2(1.0)/0.06= -33.33 D. Remember, a convex mirror will have a positive radius of curvature, and a concave mirror will have a negative radius of curvature.

questions.question: A concave mirror, located in water, has a dioptric power of +15.25 D. What is the radius of curvature of the mirror (in centimeters)?
questions.explanation: The equation used to determine the power of a mirror is P=-2n/r, where P= the power of the mirror in diopters, n= the index of refraction of the surrounding medium, and r= the radius of curvature of the mirror in meters. Manipulating the formula to solve for the radius of curvature yields +15.25 D=-2(1.33)/r = -0.1744 or -17.44 cm. Remember, a concave mirror will have a negative radius of curvature, and a convex mirror will have a positive radius of curvature. The index of refraction of water is 1.33.

questions.question: An eye with 2.00 D of myopia will have a far point located at which distance (in meters)?
options: 0.5 M in front of the eye
2.0 M in front of the eye
answers: 0.5 M in front of the eye
questions.explanation: The far point of a myopic eye is located by calculating the reciprocal of the ametropia. The answer will be in meters. In our case, 1/2 = 0.5 meters. The far point of a myopic eye is always located in front of the eye. Therefore an object placed at 50 cm will be in focus for a person who has 2.00 D of myopia. Anything past 50 cm will be observed with decreased clarity with the intensity of blur increasing as one progresses further from the far point.

questions.question: If a clinician performs retinoscopy at a working distance of 80 cm, what value should be subtracted from the gross spherical findings?
questions.explanation: The amount of power that should be subtracted from the examiner's gross retinoscopy findings is determined by the reciprocal (in meters) of the clinician's working distance. For the above example, the clinician has a working distance of 80 cm, which yields a dioptric equivalent of 1.25 D (1/0.80 m = 1.25 D). This value should be subtracted from the gross spherical retinoscopy findings to determine the net retinoscopy value.

questions.question: An axial length that is 1.0 mm greater than average will correspond to roughly what degree of refractive error?
questions.explanation: Typically, a 0.33 mm increase in axial length equates to approximately 1.00 D of myopia. Therefore an axial length that is 1.0 mm longer than what is deemed as a typical axial length corresponds to roughly 3.00 D of myopia.

questions.question: A 6-foot tall man wishes to buy a plane mirror in which he can visualize his whole length at the same time. How tall must the mirror measure in order for the above to occur?
questions.explanation: In order for a person to see their entire reflection, a plane mirror must be half as tall as the person. This holds true regardless of the position of the person. For the above example, 6/2= 3 feet.

questions.question: You are standing at the edge of a pool looking down and notice that the floor of the pool has an eyeball painted on it. If you know that the pool is 2 meters deep, what is the apparent depth of the eyeball when viewed from above?
questions.explanation:
