In this question (when placed on an optical cross), the meridian of highest absolute power is axis 135 in which the power should be -15.50 D. This should then be compared to the prescription that was sent from the lab, which is -15.25 (at axis 132). The difference between these two powers is 0.25. ANSI standards read that for sphere powers above 6.50 D, the tolerance is +/- 2% of the power. Therefore, this prescription falls within ANSI standards because the difference is 0.25 and 0.31 is allowed (2% of 15.50 is 0.31). 
ANSI standards for error tolerance in cylinder power is +/- 0.15 D for cylinder powers of 2.25 to 4.50 D (the above prescription meets ANSI standards as there is no difference between what was ordered and what was measured for cylinder power).
PowerPage
ANSI Standards

questions.question: You are verifying a pair of spectacles that arrived from your fabrication lab to make sure that they fall within ANSI standards. If a prescription reads -5.25 -0.67 x 166 by lensometry, and -5.00 -0.75 x 170 was ordered, is this prescription acceptable according to ANSI?
options: No, this Rx fails ANSI standards due to the difference in sphere power
No, this Rx fails ANSI standards due to the difference in cylinder axis
No, this Rx fails ANSI standards due to the difference in cylinder power
Yes, this Rx falls within ANSI standards
answers: No, this Rx fails ANSI standards due to the difference in sphere power
questions.explanation:
According to ANSI standards regarding error tolerances for spectacle lenses, the above prescription is considered to fall outside of standards due to the difference in the sphere power of the measured and ordered lens prescriptions. 
When determining the error tolerances for the sphere power of spectacle lenses, one must first find the meridian of the highest absolute power. In this question (when placed on an optical cross), the meridian of highest absolute power is axis 080 in which the power should be -5.75 D. This should then be compared to the prescription that was sent from the lab, which is -5.92 (at axis 076). The difference between these two powers is 0.17. 
ANSI standards read that for sphere powers equal to or less than +/- 6.50 D, the tolerance is +/- 0.13 D. Therefore, this prescription fails ANSI standards because the difference is -0.17 D. 
For powers greater than -6.50, the standard is +/- 2% of the sphere power in the meridian of highest absolute power. 
ANSI standards for error tolerance in cylinder power is +/- 0.13 D for cylinder powers of 2.00 D or less (this prescription just passes on cylinder power). 
Additionally, the ANSI standard for cylinder axis with cylinder power of 0.75 D is a variation of up to 5 degrees (this prescription also passes on cylinder axis).
PowerPage
ANSI Standards

questions.question: What is a clinical term for symptoms including, eye strain, eye fatigue, headaches, pain in/around the eyes and photophobia?
questions.explanation: Asthenopia is the clinical term used to encompass the above symptoms. Ametropia refers to the condition of an uncorrected refractive error but not the symptoms. Ocular discomfort is a symptom. Malingering refers to a situation in which a patient pretends (for whatever reason) that they cannot see clearly when there is no evidence of organic pathology.

questions.question: A 16-year old female patient walks into your office complaining of decreased distance vision. She has never worn glasses. Her uncorrected monocular acuities are OD: 20/30 and OS: 20/50. Based solely on her uncorrected acuities, what would MOST likely be her refractive error?
questions.explanation:
Eggers and Smith both conducted studies to determine a correlation between the amount of ametropia and the amount of corresponding visual degradation. They roughly concluded that, on average, one can assume 0.37 D of ametropia per line of acuity lost. 

References; Eggers, H Estimation of Uncorrected Visual Acuity in Malingerers. Arch Ophthal, 1945; 33(1) pages 23-27. 
Smith, G. Relation between Spherical Refractive Error and Visual Acuity. Optom Vis Sci, 1991; 68(8) pages 591-598.

questions.question: The mother of your 3 year-old patient refuses the use of any pharmaceutical drops on her child and therefore will not allow cycloplegic retinoscopy. Which of the following procedures may be performed in an attempt to achieve the MOST accurate results?
options: Dissociate the eyes with prism and perform retinoscopy
questions.explanation:
Research has demonstrated that, if performed correctly, Mohindra retinoscopy may yield accurate results that are similar to retinoscopy with cycloplegia. Therefore, when there is a contraindication for the use of cycloplegic drops or in the event that a parent is resistant to the use of pharmaceuticals, this technique may yield results that are similar to wet retinoscopy values. However, Mohindra retinoscopy assumes that tonic accommodation contributes 0.75D when, in actuality, tonic accommodation may measure between 0 to 4D. With the Mohindra method of retinoscopy, some patients may be under-plussed. In the event of poor patient attention, high refractive error or fluctuating responses, a cycloplegic refraction may be warranted. 

Off-axis retinoscopy or dissociating the eyes with prism does not yield accurate results. Auto-refraction in children, particularly due to poor attention, is not typically deemed reliable. 

Optometry: Science, Techniques and Clinical Management 2nd edition. Rosenfield, M & Logan, N. Butterworth, Heinemann, Elsevier, 2009, page 451.

questions.question: Where will the far points be located for a person with compound myopia?
options: One will be located at infinity, the other will be a finite distance in front of the eye
One will be in front of the eye, the other will be behind the eye
Both will be a finite distance in front of the eye
Both will be located behind the eye
answers: Both will be a finite distance in front of the eye
questions.explanation: For a compound myope, both far points will be located in front of the eye but at a finite distance (that is neither point will be at optical infinity). The far point of a myopic eye is always located in front of the eye.

questions.question: A positive plastic spherical surface (1.50) in air has a secondary focal length of 28.52 cm. Which of the following equations would correctly solve for the power of the plastic surface?
questions.explanation: In order to solve for the refractive power of the spherical surface in diopters one must multiply the reciprocal of the secondary focal length (in meters) by the index of refraction of the secondary medium yielding P=n'/f'. For the above problem, the correct solution would be P=1.50/0.2852 m, P= +5.259 (because the surface is positive) or +5.25 D.

questions.question: A ray of light is deviated 5.50 cm by a prism made of crown glass located 7.0m away. Which of the following equations will CORRECTLY determine the total prism power?
questions.explanation: Prism power is found by using the equation P=(100)(x/d), where P= power of the prism (in prism diopters, pd), x=the total distance that a ray of light is deviated, and d=the total distance from the prism to where the deviation is measured. For the above question, P= (100)(5.50 cm/700 cm)=0.786 pd. Key: both the distances must be in either meters or centimeters. If the units of the distances are not the same then 100 must be dropped from the formula. For example, P=5.50 cm/7.0 m=0.786 pd.

questions.question: Light rays with angles of incidence and refraction that are sufficiently small so that the small-angle form of Snell's law holds at every surface are known as which of the following?
questions.explanation: By definition, paraxial rays through an optical system are those rays with angles of incidence and refraction sufficiently small that the small-angle form of Snell's law holds at every surface. These angles are usually about 15 degrees or less.

questions.question: +1.50 -1.50 x 090 is required to neutralize a reflex in retinoscopy with a working distance of 50 cm. What is the resulting NET retinoscopy finding?
questions.explanation: A working distance of 50 cm creates a divergent wave of 2.00 D that is neutralized by retinoscopy in addition to the patient's refractive error. Therefore, 2.00 D must be subtracted from the spherical portion of the findings. To determine how much to subtract from the gross findings, one must first calculate the reciprocal of the working distance in meters. In our case, 1/0.5 = 2. Therefore +1.50 (the spherical gross findings) -2.00 = -0.50 -1.50 x 090. Remember NET is the final result, this is found after the working distance has been accounted for by subtracting the working distance from the spherical portion of the findings.

questions.question: Which of the following situations will result in the creation of a real, magnified image?
options: Placing an object between the center of the curvature of a concave mirror and its corresponding focal point
Placing an object at the center of curvature of a concave mirror
Placing an object between a concave mirror and its corresponding focal point
Placing an object beyond the center of curvature of a concave mirror
answers: Placing an object between the center of the curvature of a concave mirror and its corresponding focal point
questions.explanation: Concave mirrors, also known as converging mirrors, act like a plus lens and converge light. When an object is located between the focal point of the mirror and the center of curvature, the resulting image will be real and will appear inverted and magnified. An object that is located beyond the center of curvature (and the focal length of the mirror) will result in the formation of an image that is real, inverted and minified. An object that is located between the mirror and its focal point will result in an image that is virtual and appears upright and magnified. An object that is located at the center of curvature of a convex mirror will form an image that is real, the same size as the object, and inverted.

questions.question: Which of the following spectacle prescriptions can be classified as compound hyperopic astigmatism?
questions.explanation:
Refractive astigmatism is classified by the relationship of the two focal lines that are produced by the refractive components of the eye with respect to the retina (when accommodation is relaxed). The different clinical types of astigmatism are described below. 

Simple astigmatism: When accommodation is relaxed, one focal line is located at the retina; the other is located either in front of or behind the retina 
- If the second focal line is in front of the retina, this is simple myopic astigmatism (one principle meridian is plano, the other is myopic) 
- If the second focal line is located behind the retina, this is simple hyperopic astigmatism (one principle meridian is plano, the other is hyperopic) 

Compound astigmatism: When accommodation is relaxed, both focal lines are located either in front of or behind the retina 
- If both are located in front of the retina, this is considered compound myopic astigmatism (both principle meridians are myopic) 
- If both are located behind the retina, this is classified as compound hyperopic astigmatism (both principle meridians are hyperopic) 

Mixed astigmatism: With relaxed accommodation, one focal line will be located in front of the retina and one line will be located behind the retina (one principle meridian is myopic, the other is hyperopic). 

In order to determine where the focal points are located for a given spectacle correction, place the values on an optical cross. Plus values indicate that the focal line is behind the retina, minus values indicate focal points in front of the retina, and a value of plano indicates a focal line that is located on the retina. 

In the above question, the spectacle prescription of +2.00 -0.50 x 120 will have hyperopic principle meridians (+2.00 and +1.50) when placed on an optical cross. This corresponds to the definition of compound hyperopic astigmatism. 

Primary Care Optometry (5th edition). Grosvenor, T.P. 2007. Butterworth Heinemann Elsevier. St. Louis, MO.

questions.question: With respect to thick lenses, all refraction is assumed to take place at which of the following points?
questions.explanation:
Light rays may undergo bending within an optical system in which the outcome may appear very difficult to predict in terms of imaging properties; however, it has been shown that a system may be reduced to refraction occurring only at the principal planes (P and P'). 

Cardinal points are composed of the principal points, nodal points, and focal points of a symmetrical optical system, and may be used to deduce all optical properties of the system no matter how many optical elements it contains.

questions.question: When performing retinoscopy, there is often a range over which neutrality is achieved. Which of the following will MOST likely INCREASE the resultant range of neutrality?
options: Pushing the retinoscope sleeve down so that the light emerges divergently
Increased pupil size of the patient
answers: Increased pupil size of the patient
questions.explanation:
When performing retinoscopy, the goal is to achieve a neutral reflex. Occasionally, several neutral points are experienced. Many authors agree that the mid-point of neutrality serves as the best end-point. Ultimately, the goal is not to over-minus the patient. A large pupil results in increased spherical aberration, which may also lead to confusing retinoscopy findings, as the center of the pupil may display with-motion while the peripheral portion of the pupil may exhibit against-motion. In the case of a large pupil, it is important to focus on the reflex at the center of the pupil to increase the accuracy of your results. The range of neutrality may also be increased in patients with larger pupils due to the creation of anomalous with-motion due to spherical aberration. 

Optom Vis Sci. 2004 Sep;81(9):663-72.

questions.question: A crown glass spherical surface (n= 1.52) has a power of -12.00 D. Which of the following equations will correctly solve for the radius of curvature?
questions.explanation: Using the equation P=(n'-n)/r where P= the power of the refracting surface, n'= the refractive index of the surface, n= the refractive index of the surrounding medium and r= the radius of curvature of the surface in meters. Solving for r and using the above values, the equation becomes r=(1.52-1.00)/-12.00= -0.043 m or -4.3 cm.

questions.question: Which of the following types of aberrations is primarily responsible for the appearance of a rainbow that occurs either during or after a rain?
questions.explanation:
Chromatic aberration is a type of distortion in which a lens is unable to focus all wavelengths of light to the same convergence point. It occurs because the refractive index of any medium (other than a vacuum) varies with wavelength. Therefore, shorter wavelengths (blues) will bend more as they pass through a lens, while longer wavelengths (reds) bend less. This leads to a variation in the image location (longitudinal chromatic aberration) and image size (lateral chromatic aberration). 

A rainbow is produced by billions of tiny droplets of water vapor hovering in the air either during or after rain. Each water droplet acts as a very small yet powerful round refracting lens. As described above, these 'lenses' will bend each wavelength of light differently as a result of chromatic aberration. Billions of these water droplets refracting light in this manner will create the appearance of a rainbow.

questions.question: The change in direction of a light ray that occurs when it travels from one media through another is known as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
In general, upon entering a material of which the index is different than the material the light ray is exiting, the ray will change its direction. This is called refraction. Refraction occurs because of the speed change that light undergoes when it changes mediums. 

The angle of refraction is the angle that a refracted light ray makes with the normal to an interface separating different media. Keep in mind that when a ray is directed along the normal, it will pass straight through the medium undeviated (it will slow down but will not bend). If the light travels from a lower to higher index, the ray will bend towards the normal, and away from the normal if traveling from higher to lower index. 

The law of refraction states that the incident, normal, and refracted rays all lie in the same plane. The angles of refraction are related by Snell's law (n sin i = n' sin i'). Snell's law does not distinguish between incident and refracted rays; therefore, the path is reversible (it doesn't matter which direction light is coming from).

questions.question: Your net retinoscopy results yield -1.25 -0.75 x 080 for the right eye. Which of the following is the correct sequence of your clinical refraction of the right eye if the net retinoscopy findings are left in place?
options: Refinement of cylinder power-> refinement of cylinder axis-> refinement of sphere power
Refinement of cylinder power-> sphere power refinement-> refinement of cylinder axis
Sphere power refinement-> refinement of cylinder power-> refinement of cylinder axis
Refinement of cylinder axis-> refinement of cylinder power-> sphere power refinement
Sphere power refinement-> refinement of cylinder axis-> refinement of cylinder power
answers: Sphere power refinement-> refinement of cylinder axis-> refinement of cylinder power
questions.explanation: After retinoscopy is performed, the left eye should be occluded to allow for prescription refinement via subjective refraction. The first step is to fog and then unfog the right eye in 0.25 D steps to achieve the spherical lens that affords the best visual acuity. The Jackson crossed-cylinder is then placed before the eye, commencing with cylinder axis refinement. The majority of clinicians agree that if 0.75 D or more of astigmatism is present, the clinician should begin with cylinder axis refinement proceeded by cylinder power refinement. It is important to verify cylinder axis prior to cylinder power because an off-axis refraction can lead to erroneous results. Once the axis of the astigmatism is determined, the clinician should then confirm the amount of cylinder power.

questions.question: According to Knapp's law, anisometropia caused by an uneven axial length between the eyes is best corrected by which of the following methods?
questions.explanation: According to Knapp's law, anisometropia caused by unequal axial lengths is best corrected by glasses, whereas anisometropia caused by dissimilar corneal curvatures is best corrected by contact lenses. Knapp suggested that if anisometropia induced by dissimilar corneal curvatures were to be corrected by glasses, the resulting aniseikonia would be difficult for the patient to handle, as they would be unable to fuse the images due to size difference. However, this law fails to consider other important factors, such as cortical processing and stretching of the retina, among others.

questions.question: Myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism refractive errors are known as which of the following types of aberrations?
questions.explanation:
Lower order aberrations: can be corrected by glasses, contact lenses, or refractive surgery 
- Zero order aberrations: a constant (characterized by axial symmetry and a flat wavefront 
- First order aberrations: lineal aberrations (correspond to tilting around a horizontal or a vertical axis and describe a tilt or prismatic error) 
- Second order aberrations: defocus (myopia and hyperopia) and astigmatism 

Higher order aberrations: cannot be corrected for by spherocylindrical lenses 
- Third order aberrations: coma (horizontal and vertical) and trefoil (triangular astigmatism with base along the x or y axis) 
- Fourth order aberrations: spherical aberration, tetrafoil, and secondary astigmatism (oblique/irregular astigmatism) 
- Fifth through tenth order aberrations: only important with extremely dilated pupils

questions.question: A concerned mother wants to know if her 10-year-old child has amblyopia. Her uncorrected visual acuities are 20/40 OU. Her ocular health assessment is unremarkable, as is the unilateral cover test. You decide to pinhole the child and she reads 20/20 OD, OS. What can you conclude from this finding?
options: She likely has some form of deprivation amblyopia
She probably suffers from anisometropic amblyopia
The decreased acuity is likely due to a refractive error
The decreased visual acuity is attributable to strabismic amblyopia
answers: The decreased acuity is likely due to a refractive error
questions.explanation: If a patient is capable of seeing 20/20 with a pinhole, then decreased acuity attributable to an uncorrected refractive error must be ruled out. Amblyopia will not improve with a pinhole. Anisometropic amblyopia may develop in eyes that have as little as a 1.00 D refractive error difference. Typically, the greater the difference in refractive errors between the eyes, the greater the degree of amblyopia. Strabismic amblyopia occurs in the presence of a constant unilateral eye turn that is present before the critical period (prior to ages 6-8). Deprivation amblyopia is caused by an actual physical barrier that impedes clear vision, such as a cataract or a complete ptosis that is present prior to the critical period.

questions.question: Manifest refraction performed on your 55 year-old female patient reveals a spectacle correction of +2.75 -3.50 x 110 for her right eye. Which of the following BEST describes her type of refractive astigmatism?
questions.explanation:
Refractive astigmatism is classified by the relationship of the two focal lines that are produced by the refractive components of the eye with respect to the retina (when accommodation is relaxed). The different clinical types of astigmatism are described below. 

Simple astigmatism: When accommodation is relaxed, one focal line is located at the retina; the other is located either in front of or behind the retina 
- If the second focal line is in front of the retina, this is simple myopic astigmatism (one principle meridian is plano, the other is myopic) 
- If the second focal line is located behind the retina, this is simple hyperopic astigmatism (one principle meridian is plano, the other is hyperopic) 

Compound astigmatism: When accommodation is relaxed, both focal lines are located either in front of or behind the retina 
- If both are located in front of the retina, this is considered compound myopic astigmatism (both principle meridians are myopic) 
- If both are located behind the retina, this is classified as compound hyperopic astigmatism (both principle meridians are hyperopic) 

Mixed astigmatism: With relaxed accommodation, one focal line will be located in front of the retina and one line will be located behind the retina (one principle meridian is myopic, the other is hyperopic). 

In order to determine where the focal points are located for a given spectacle correction, place the values on an optical cross. Plus values indicate that the focal line is behind the retina, minus values indicate focal points in front of the retina, and a value of plano indicates a focal line that is located on the retina. 

In the above question, the spectacle prescription of +2.75 -3.50 x 110, when placed on an optical cross, will have one principle meridian that is hyperopic (+2.75) and one that is myopic (-0.75). This corresponds to the definition of mixed astigmatism. 

Primary Care Optometry (5th edition). Grosvenor, T.P. 2007. Butterworth Heinemann Elsevier. St. Louis, MO.

questions.question: Which of the following charts will allow for the measurement of a patient's contrast sensitivity?
questions.explanation:
Patients may report blurring of vision even though acuity may be measured to be 20/20 or 20/25. In these instances, one should consider performing a visual acuity test with low contrast, such as the Bailey-Lovie low contrast acuity chart or the Pelli-Robson test, to assess for a deficit in contrast sensitivity. The Pelli-Robson chart consists of optotypes that are the same size but decrease in contrast sensitivity (see image 1). 

The Feinbloom, Snellen, and Jaeger charts, although all different, possess optotypes that do not vary in contrast. The Jaeger chart is used for assessment of near visual acuity.

questions.question: The type of aberration that occurs as a result of the variation in magnification across the entrance pupil from off-axis point sources is know as which of the following?
questions.explanation: Coma is a type of aberration that occurs when an off-axis point source of light (object) is imaged. The rays that pass through the outer margins of the lens focus at different distances from the optical axis as compared to rays that pass through the center of the lens. This results in a series of ring-shaped images (known as comatic circles) from bundles of parallel rays that pass through the lens at equal distances from the axis. Each comatic circle produced by the optical system is of different magnification and distance from the optical axis, and when combined, results in a V-shaped or comet-like flare.

questions.question: A mirror is an example of a specular surface. Which of the following statements regarding mirrors is TRUE?
options: The angle of reflectance is the angle created between the normal and the incident ray
The angle of incidence is the angle created between the surface of the mirror and the incident ray
The angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection
answers: The angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection
questions.explanation:
The law of specular reflection states that the angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection. The angle of incidence is the angle made between the incident ray and the normal. The angle of reflectance is measured as the angle created between the reflected ray and the normal. The normal is always located perpendicular to the surface (in this case, the mirror), which is a right angle and measures 90 degrees. 

A perfectly diffusing surface is one that appears the same brightness when viewed from any angle. Perfectly diffusing surfaces do not appear shiny or glossy. These surfaces tend to reflect light evenly in every direction. A blackboard is an example of a perfectly diffusing surface.

questions.question: If a real object located at optical infinity results in the formation of an image that is focused on the retinal surface of an emmetropic, reduced eye (n=1.33, radius of curvature= 5.55 mm), which of the following can be calculated?
options: The axial length of the reduced eye
The size of the exit pupil
The thickness of the retinal surface
answers: The axial length of the reduced eye
questions.explanation: Initially, one can determine the power of the refracting surface of the reduced eye by using the equation P=(n'-n)/r where P= the power of the refracting surface, n'= the refractive index of the surface, n= the refractive index of the surrounding medium, and r= the radius of curvature of the surface in meters. Using the known values given in the problem, one can calculate the value of P, P=(1.33-1.0)/0.00555= +59.46 D; rounding up to the nearest whole diopter yields +60.00 D. The value of P is then inserted into the equation L'=L+P where L'=the image vergence (n'/l' in meters), L=the object vergence (n/l in meters), and P=the power of the refracting surface. The value of the object vergence (L) is 0 because the object rays are parallel. Therefore, solving for L'=60.00 +0, (n'/l')=60.00 D, 1.33/l'=60, l'=0.02216 or 22.2 mm.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the far-point vergence relationship of the eye is true?
options: The clarity of an object located at the far point of the eye is dependent only upon the pupil size of the eye
The longer the axial length of the eye, the greater the vergence required at the corneal plane for an object to be clearly imaged on the retina
An eye with a longer axial length will possess a far point located further from the corneal plane than an eye with a shorter axial length
An object located at the far point of the eye will require more accommodation to achieve a clear retinal image than an object that is located closer to the eye
answers: The longer the axial length of the eye, the greater the vergence required at the corneal plane for an object to be clearly imaged on the retina
questions.explanation:
The far-point vergence relationship can be expressed as the equation A= F(fp) + P (eye), where A= 1.33/a, a= the axial length of the eye, F(fp)= the far point vergence, and P= the power of the reduced eye (+60.00 D). An eye with an increased axial length will require an increased vergence in order for an object to be focused in the retinal plane. An eye with an increased axial length will also have a decreased far point. For example, with an eye with a power of +60.00 D has an axial length of 26.00 mm, what power of corrective lens when placed at the corneal plane will result in a clear retinal image? Using the above equation: 1.33/0.026= F(fp)+ 60.00 D, solving for F(fp)= -8.85 D; therefore this eye has -8.85 D of myopia and will require a vergence of -8.85 D to produce a clear retinal image; this can be achieved by placing a -8.85 D corrective lens at the corneal plane. The far point of the eye can be located by solving for the reciprocal of the vergence; 1/8.85= 0.113 or 11.3 cm. The greater the axial length, the closer the far point of the eye. An uncorrected highly myopic patient will have to hold an object closer to their eye to achieve a clear retinal image than an uncorrected, mildly myopic patient. 

An object that is placed closer than the far point of the eye will require more accommodation to achieve a clear retinal image than an object that is placed further than the far point.

questions.question: In order for emmetropization to occur, which of the following changes must occur as a child grows?
options: The cornea and lens must both lose refractive power as the axial length increases
The cornea and lens must both gain refractive power as the axial length increases
The cornea must gain refractive power and the lens must lose refractive power as the axial length increases
The cornea must lose refractive power and the lens must gain refractive power as the axial length increases
answers: The cornea and lens must both lose refractive power as the axial length increases
questions.explanation:
The axial length of the human eye at birth is typically around 17mm; this measurement increases roughly 25% by the time a child reaches adolescence. As the eye grows in length, the optical power of the eye's refracting system must concurrently weaken in a tightly coordinated fashion in order to keep a clear image focused on the retina. Therefore, the optical components of the eye, which include they cornea and crystalline lens, must both lose refractive power in order to compensate for the growth of the eye that occurs as children mature. At birth, the power of the cornea is typically about 48 diopters; the refractive power of the crystalline lens is close to 45 diopters. Typically, the cornea will lose about 4-5 diopters of power, while the crystalline lens will lose about 20 diopters of power as the axial length increases to an average of 24mm. This developmental process is known as emmetropization. If the process does not occur in this precise manner, myopia or hyperopia will develop. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye 11th Edition. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. 2011. Saunders Elsevier. 

Optical and Structural Development of the Crystalline Lens in Childhood. Mutti, D.O. et al. IOVS, January 1998, Vol 39, No. 1. 

The Wisdom of the Eye. Miller, D.M. 2000. Academic Press. San Diego, CA.

questions.question: In retinoscopy, against motion would be observed in which of the following scenarios?
options: The far point is located between the retinoscope and the patient's eye
The far point is located behind the retinoscope
The far point is located at the retinoscope aperture
The far point is located behind the patient's eye
answers: The far point is located between the retinoscope and the patient's eye
questions.explanation:
Against motion is observed when the far point of the patient's eye is located between the retinoscope and the patient's eye. Remember against motion indicates the presence of myopia. Light rays reflected from the retina of a myopic eye will emerge convergently because the far point of the eye is in front of the cornea. For a myope, the far point will be located in front of the eye but at a finite distance (that is it will not be located at optical infinity). The far point of a myopic eye is always located in front of the eye. 

Conversely, with motion (accounting for working distance) results when the far point of the eye is positioned behind the retinoscope and therefore signals a hyperope. 

Neutral motion (accounting for working distance) occurs when the far point of the eye is located at the viewing aperture of the retinoscope and indicates emmetropia.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT TRUE in regards to the characteristics of wave motion?
options: The frequency of a wave slows when light travels from air into a denser medium
The speed of light (or c) is a universal constant that is independent of the observer or the source
For a wave of a given velocity (e.g. light), frequency and wavelength are inversely related
The amount of energy of light is proportional to frequency, and inversely related to wavelength
answers: The frequency of a wave slows when light travels from air into a denser medium
questions.explanation: The frequency of light is invariant across media; therefore, frequency remains constant when light travels from one medium to another. On the other hand, wavelength and velocity are dependent on the medium.

questions.question: During the subjective refraction of an absolute presbyope, if the acuity chart is closer than the standard twenty feet how will the resultant glasses prescription be affected?
options: The glasses will have too much plus power or too little minus power.
The glasses will have too little plus power or too much minus power
The glasses will display too much induced astigmatism
The glasses will not be affected
answers: The glasses will have too much plus power or too little minus power.
questions.explanation: If the acuity chart is closer than 20 feet (either reflected, simulated or actual distance) then the patient will report needing more plus power or less minus power than required to see clearly at optical infinity.

questions.question: You are in geometrical optics lab and experimenting with pinhole cameras. You and your lab partner found all of the following rules to be true EXCEPT:
options: The image formed from a pinhole camera is in focus at any distance that the screen is moved
The image formed from a pinhole camera is in focus at any distance that the object is moved
The image formed by a pinhole camera is inverted
The image formed from a pinhole camera is brighter when the object is moved closer to the screen
answers: The image formed from a pinhole camera is brighter when the object is moved closer to the screen
questions.explanation: The image brightness stays constant as the object distance is changed and the image distance is unchanged.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the properties of the entrance pupil of an optical system?
options: The image of the aperture stop through all following lenses
The image of the aperture stop through all preceding lenses
The image of the field stop through all following lenses
The image of the field stop through all preceding lenses
answers: The image of the aperture stop through all preceding lenses
questions.explanation:
The definition of the entrance pupil of an optical system is the image of the aperture stop through all preceding lenses. In other words, it is the aperture stop placed into object space. In situations where no lenses precede the aperture stop, the aperture stop is also the entrance pupil. 

The exit pupil of an optical system can be defined as the image of the aperture stop through all following lenses. Again, if no lenses follow the aperture stop, the aperture stop is also the exit pupil.

questions.question: The aperture stop of an optical system is defined as which of the following?
options: The image of the entrance pupil through all of the lenses that follow it
The lens that most limits the size of an incoming beam of light in an optical system
The image of the exit pupil through all of the preceding lenses in an optical system
Any clear circular opening located on the axis of an optical system
answers: The lens that most limits the size of an incoming beam of light in an optical system
questions.explanation: The lens that most limits the size of an incoming beam of light in an optical system is called the aperture stop. Any clear circular opening located on the axis of an optical system is known as a stop. The image of the aperture stop through all of the preceding lenses in an optical system is called the entrance pupil. If there are no lenses that precede the aperture stop, then the aperture stop also becomes the entrance pupil. The image of the aperture stop through all of the lenses that follow it is known as the exit pupil. If there are not any lenses following the aperture stop (AS), then the AS also becomes the exit pupil.

questions.question: The exit window of an optical system can be described by which of the following statements?
options: The image of the field stop through all preceding lenses
The image of the aperture stop through all following lenses
The image of the aperture stop through all preceding lenses
The image of the field stop through all following lenses
answers: The image of the field stop through all following lenses
questions.explanation:
The exit window is the image of the field stop through all following lenses. Contrastingly, the entrance window can be defined as the image of the field stop through all preceding lenses. 

The entrance and exit pupils of an optical system are determined by imaging the aperture stop through the preceding and following lenses.

questions.question: In order for a corrective lens to focus an object that is located at optical infinity onto the retina of a myopic eye, which of the following must be coincident with the far point of the eye?
options: The point on the lens where the index of refractive is greatest
The thickest portion of the lens
The secondary focal point of the corrective lens
The primary focal point of the corrective lens
answers: The secondary focal point of the corrective lens
questions.explanation: Corrective lenses for myopia (minus-powered lenses) diverge light rays so that the resultant image is focused onto the retinal surface rather than in front of it. In order for an object located infinitely from a myopic eye to be in focus on the retinal surface, the secondary focal point of the corrective lens must coincide with the far point of the eye. An image that is located at the far point of the eye will be imaged at the retinal plane.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the definition of irregular astigmatism?
options: The principal meridians of the cornea are not perpendicular to each other
The axis of astigmatism is located along the 90 degree meridian
The principal meridians of the cornea are located 90 degrees apart
The axis of astigmatism is located along an oblique axis
answers: The principal meridians of the cornea are not perpendicular to each other
questions.explanation:
Astigmatism can be classified as either being regular or irregular. Regular astigmatism occurs in individuals in which the principal meridians of the cornea are located 90 degrees apart. That is, the area of the cornea with the flattest curvature (the axis) is oriented perpendicular to the meridian of the steepest curvature. 

In certain ocular conditions such as keratoconus, corneal scarring, or post-surgical corneas, the steep and flat meridians may not be oriented 90 degrees apart. This type of corneal curvature can be considered irregular astigmatism. In these cases, the refractive error is typically not well corrected with spectacles, in comparison to correction with gas-permeable contact lenses.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding the radius of curvature of a plane mirror?
options: The radius of curvature is infinite
The radius of curvature is twice the index of refraction of the mirror
The radius of curvature is located twice as far as the focal point of the mirror
The radius of curvature is half of the index of refraction of the mirror
answers: The radius of curvature is infinite
questions.explanation: A plane mirror does not possess any power and therefore will not diverge or converge incident light. Because a plane mirror is flat, its radius of curvature is infinite. All resultant images formed by a plane mirror will be virtual, erect, located the same distance from the mirror as the object, and will be neither magnified nor minified and will appear laterally reversed.

questions.question: While performing retinoscopy, how does the resultant reflex change as your approach neutral motion?
options: The reflex appears to move more slowly
The reflex becomes brighter and appears narrower
The reflex becomes brighter and broader
The reflex becomes dimmer and broader
answers: The reflex becomes brighter and broader
questions.explanation:
When performing retinoscopy, as one nears neutrality, the reflex becomes wider/broader, brighter and appears to move more quickly. 

The Retinoscopy Book: An Introduction Manual for Eye Care Professionals 5th ed. Corboy, R. SLACK inc., 2003, pages 30-33.

questions.question: While performing retinoscopy at a distance of 50cm, you achieve neutral motion. To verify your findings, you move the sleeve of the retinoscope as far up as possible. How will the resulting reflex be altered?
options: The observed reflex will appear significantly dimmer
questions.explanation: While performing retinoscopy and achieving neutrality, many clinicians will verify their findings by pushing the sleeve of the retinoscope to the up position. If a neutral point has been reached, this motion should be maintained regardless of whether the sleeve is in the up or down position. If with- or against-motion is observed then neutrality was not obtained initially.

questions.question: While performing streak retinoscopy, you observe with-motion of the reflex with the sleeve in the down position. With the same lenses in place, you decide to move the sleeve of the instrument to the fully up position. How will the resulting reflex be altered?
options: The resulting reflex will appear to move more slowly
The reflex will appear significantly dimmer
The reflex will be conjugate with infinity
The reflex will now appear to move against-motion
answers: The reflex will now appear to move against-motion
questions.explanation: When the sleeve is pushed down as far as the instrument will allow, the emerging light from the retinoscope is divergent, as the mirror is in a plano position. Moving the sleeve all the way to the top of the instrument causes emerging light to be convergent because the mirror of the retinoscope is in a concave position. This will reverse the direction of the reflex; therefore, if with-motion was observed with the sleeve down, against-motion will be observed with the sleeve pushed up.

questions.question: While practicing ray-tracing, you find which of the following to be TRUE in regards to object and image relationships?
options: The set of all points or rays associated with the light incident on an optical system is called image space
For a real object, incident (object) rays are convergent
An object does not need to be located in object space; it only must be associated with incident light
For a virtual image, emergent (image) rays are convergent
answers: An object does not need to be located in object space; it only must be associated with incident light
questions.explanation:
The following is true of object and image relationships (assuming that object space is to the right of the optical system and image space is to the left for simplicity): 
- Real Object: Incident (object) rays are divergent; it exists to the left of the optical surface or system; there are physically real objects and optically real objects. 
- Virtual Object: Incident (object) rays are convergent on the surface; it exists to the right of the surface (where the incident rays would come to a point). 
- Real Image: Emergent (image) rays are convergent; it exists to the right of a clear optical surface or system (for a mirror, it is to the left). There are physically and optically real images as well. 
- Virtual Image: Emergent (image) rays are divergent; virtual images would have originated on the left for a clear optical surface (right of the reflecting surface for a mirror image). 
- Object Space: Set of all points or rays associated with the light incident on an optical system; object does not need to be located in object space. 
- Image space: Set of all points or rays associated with light leaving the optical system; image does not need to be located in image space.

questions.question: In refraction, the use of polarized targets in which the target for each eye is polarized at different angles such that each eye sees a different target simultaneously is used in which technique?
questions.explanation: The vectograph technique is a type of binocular refraction in which each eye views a different target simultaneously through the use of polarized lenses (polarized at different angles for each eye). This technique requires a special polarized slide. This allows for monocular testing without occlusion of the fellow eye. Some disadvantages of this method include decreased contrast of the targets potentially leading to poor end results. Another disadvantage is that strong eye dominance may lead to eye suppression rendering this method more challenging.

questions.question: A cornea that displays toricity is said to have with-the-rule astigmatism if it possesses which of the following keratometry readings?
options: The vertical meridian is flatter than the other principal meridian
The horizontal meridian has a shorter radius of curvature
The vertical meridian is steeper than the other principal meridian
The horizontal meridian is steeper than the other principal meridian
answers: The vertical meridian is steeper than the other principal meridian
questions.explanation: With-the-rule astigmatism occurs when the vertical meridian is steeper than the other principal meridian; that is, the horizontal meridian is flatter and corresponds with the axis of the astigmatism. In this case, the vertical meridian would have a shorter radius of curvature indicating that it possesses a greater dioptric power than the horizontal meridian. If the steeper meridian lies between 60 and 120 degrees, the cornea is said to have with-the-rule astigmatism. If the steeper meridian lies between 150 and 30 degrees, the cornea displays against-the-rule astigmatism. Anything outside of these meridians is considered oblique astigmatism.

questions.question: A lens with a single refracting surface has negative power and a virtual object that lies between the vertex of the lens and its first focal point. What are the characteristics of the image that the system creates?
options: There is not enough information to determine these characteristics of the image
Virtual, upright, and smaller than the object
Virtual, upright, and larger than the object
Real, upright, and smaller than the object
Real, upright, and larger than the object
answers: Real, upright, and larger than the object
questions.explanation:
Keep these rules in mind when ray-tracing: 
-F is that unique object point that produces a final parallel pencil 
-F' is that unique image point produced by an incident parallel pencil 
-V is the intersection of the optical axis with a surface, which is also called the vertex of the surface 
-C is the center of curvature of a lens, which is the location where any ray perpendicular to the surface will pass through undeviated 
-The surface vertex (V) and the center of curvature (C) are symmetrically positioned between the focal points. (FC = VF' or FV=CF')

questions.question: Which of the following actions will aid in enhancing the accuracy of your results when performing retinoscopy on a patient with keratoconus?
options: Tilt the phoropter towards the clinician, advertently occluding one eye to minimize glare
Decrease the brightness of the retinoscope to maximize pupil mydriasis
Focus primarily on the reflex seen at the center of the pupil
Move the streak more quickly across the pupil to minimize distortion of the reflex
answers: Focus primarily on the reflex seen at the center of the pupil
questions.explanation:
Performing retinoscopy on a patient with an irregular cornea, such as in keratoconus, can be difficult and usually results in a reflex called 'scissor-motion' in which the reflex appears to separate or converge together. Regardless of the etiology, when challenged with an aberrated reflex, the majority of clinicians recommend focusing on the reflex seen at the center of the pupil. Many practitioners also attempt to achieve a maximal reflex by utilizing a bright light, resulting in pupil constriction and an optimization of the area of the most 'normal' reflex. 

Optics, Retinoscopy, and Refractometry 2nd edition. Lens, A. SLACK inc, 2006, page 37. 
Optometry: Science, Techniques and Clinical Management 2nd edition. Rosenfield, M. & Logan, N. Butterworth, Heinemann & Elsevier, 2009, page 194.

questions.question: During retinoscopy why is the contralateral eye not occluded?
questions.explanation: In order to achieve good retinoscopy results, both eyes must remain open and fogging (adding lenses causing the projected letters to be perceived as blurry but still readable) of the contralateral eye helps to control accommodation. Controlling accommodation is especially important with hyperopes who possess very good accommodative skills.

questions.question: If atoms and molecules of light contain electrons with the same frequency as that of the medium in which they enter, the medium will __________ the energy of the light wave and convert it to __________ energy.
questions.explanation:
When atoms and molecules of light contain electrons with the same frequency as that of the medium in which they enter, the medium will absorb the energy and convert it to thermal (heat) energy. The light will not be able to continue to pass as light itself. 

If frequencies of light waves do not match the frequency of the particles in a medium (or object), upon interaction, the electrons will vibrate for a brief period of time and then the energy is re-emitted as a light wave. 
If the medium is transparent, the light is transmitted. 
If the medium is opaque, the light is reflected.

questions.question: Placing a septum between the patient and visual acuity chart so that central fusion of the eyes is eliminated but peripheral fusion is maintained is known as which method?
questions.explanation: The Turville method is a type of binocular refraction where neither eye is occluded. In this technique a septum is placed between the eye chart and the patient creating a situation where each eye sees a separate portion of the chart. Therefore each eye cannot see the target of the other eye. In such an instance, central fusion is suppressed but peripheral fusion is maintained. Each eye can be isolated without occlusion by directing the patient's gaze to the appropriate side of the test chart. This method works well for most individuals but may pose a problem for those who may suppress an eye, people with strabismus or those with high phorias or amblyopia.

questions.question: Which type of light scattering is responsible for the reddish-orange colors that are often observed during sunsets?
questions.explanation: Scattering of light occurs when the medium through which light or other electromagnetic radiation travels is not homogenous. In the case of Rayleigh scattering, the particles that scatter the light are smaller than the wavelength of the light passing through. The particles may be individual atoms or molecules of a solid, liquid, or most commonly, a gas. The appearance of the blue sky during the day and the reddish hue of the sunset are due to Rayleigh scattering of light.

questions.question: A real object placed between the first focal point and a plus lens will produce which type of image?
questions.explanation: A real image placed between F (first focal point) and a plus lens will produce a virtual, upright, and enlarged image. This type of system is the basis for all single-lens magnifiers.

questions.question: Your patient is interested in refractive surgery and tells you that he heard an advertisement about 'wavefront-guided' LASIK on the radio. He has never heard of the term 'wavefront' and asks you to explain it to him. Which of the following statements regarding wavefronts would be INCORRECT?
options: Wavefronts have a larger dioptric value the closer they are to the light source
The radius of curvature of a wavefront is larger the closer it is to the light source
Wavefronts become flatter (less curved) the further they are from the light source
answers: The radius of curvature of a wavefront is larger the closer it is to the light source
questions.explanation:
Vergence is a quantitative measure of the degree of convergence or divergence of light at a particular position (reference point). Diverging wavefronts have negative vergence, while converging wavefronts have positive vergence. 

The closer the reference point is to the source of light, the more steeply curved the wavefronts will be. Therefore, they will have a smaller radius of curvature than wavefronts at a reference point further away (not larger). These closer wavefronts will also have a larger dioptric power (Vergence in diopters = 1/radius of curvature of wavefront). 

The further the reference point is to the source of light, the flatter the wavefronts will be; they will have a larger radius of curvature and a lower dioptric value.

questions.question: Light reflected from the retina of a myopic eye will have light rays emerging in which fashion?
questions.explanation: Light rays reflected from the retina of a myopic eye will emerge convergently because the far point of the eye is in front of the cornea. An emmetropic eye will have light rays emerging in a parallel fashion as the far point is set at optical infinity whereas a hyperopic eye's light rays will emerge divergently due to the fact that the far point of the eye is projected behind the eye.

questions.question: Most Caucasian infants tend to display which type of astigmatism?
questions.explanation: Most Caucasian infants possess between 0.25 to 2.00 D of against-the-rule astigmatism. Infants of Chinese descent have a tendency to display with-the-rule astigmatism. Most studies demonstrate that the astigmatism tends to decrease until around five or six years of age. It is generally accepted that low levels of astigmatism in the age group below five or six should be monitored for emmetropization rather than corrected unless severe symptoms of asthenopia are present.

questions.question: While performing streak retinoscopy on a 6 year-old patient at a working distance of 50cm, you observe with-motion with no lenses in place. Which of the following refractive errors can you deduce that this patient is MOST likely to possess?
options: You cannot conclude the type of refractive error based upon the above findings
answers: You cannot conclude the type of refractive error based upon the above findings
questions.explanation: With motion can be observed in hyperopia, myopia and astigmatism; therefore, until the reflex is neutralized with retinoscopy and the working distance is accounted for, one cannot accurately deduce the type of refractive error without any lenses in place. For example, performing retinoscopy at a working distance of 50cm on a 1.00 D myope with no lenses in place will initially display with-motion of the reflex. Neutralization of the reflex will require the addition of +1.00 D (gross retinoscopy). To determine the net refractive error, the working distance must be subtracted from the gross retinoscopy findings. Because the working distance is 50cm, 2.00 D must be subtracted (reciprocal of the working distance) from the above gross findings of +1.00 D, yielding a net of -1.00 D.

questions.question: A barium glass surface with an index of refraction of 1.60 sits in air. Which of the following equations may be used to calculate the vergence of the light rays (in diopters) that converge to form a real image located 30 cm to the right of the surface?
questions.explanation: The vergence is calculated using the formula L'=n'/l' where L= the image vergence, n'= the index of the medium in which the light rays form an image, and l'= the distance between the refracting surface and the image. Because the image is located within the second medium (barium glass) and not in air, the index of refraction that should be used in the equation is 1.60 and not 1.00 (index of air). The correct equation is L'=1.60/0.30= +5.33 D. It is important to convert the distance from centimeters into meters. Because the rays of light forming the image are converging, the resulting vergence is positive.

questions.question: A ray of light falling on a plane mirror has an angle of incidence of 70 degrees. What is the angle created between the reflected ray and the mirror?
questions.explanation: The law of specular reflection states that the angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection. The angle of incidence is measured from the angle made between the incident ray and the normal. The angle of reflectance is measured from the angle made between the reflected ray and the normal. Therefore, in the above example, if the angle of incidence is 70 degrees so is the angle of reflectance. The normal is always located perpendicular to the surface (in this case, the mirror), which is a right angle and measures 90 degrees. If the angle of reflectance measures 70 degrees, the angle made between the angle of reflectance and the mirror must be equal to 90-70, which is 20 degrees.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following factors are known to contribute to the development/progression of myopia? (Select 3)
options: Greater than 0.50 D of hyperopia observed in school-age children
Prolonged near activities on a consistent basis
answers: Prolonged near activities on a consistent basis
questions.explanation: Risk factors that are thought to contribute to the development or progression of myopia include prolonged periods of near work on a consistent basis and a family history of myopia, especially if both parents are myopic. Studies have demonstrated the prevalence of myopia at 33-60% in children whose parents are both myopic, whereas the prevalence decreases to 23-40% in children with one parent who is myopic. Children who are emmetropic or have less than 0.50 D of hyperopia when they are school age are also at greater risk for developing myopia. Children with against-the-rule astigmatism are also thought to have a higher likelihood of becoming myopic. High axial length to corneal radius ratios, steep corneal curvatures, near point esophoria, and poor accommodative skills all also are thought to contribute to myopia development or progression. Lastly, anything that interferes with obtaining a clear retinal image during infancy (such as a corneal opacity or a vitreous hemorrhage) will likely cause myopia.

questions.question: You decide to perform the Schirmer 1 test (without anesthetic) on a 23 year-old patient with symptoms of dry eye. After a period of 5 minutes, which of the following values indicates the threshold whereby any measurement below this is considered abnormal?
questions.explanation:
When the Schirmer test is performed properly, patients with normal tear production will have a total amount of tear secretion that wets at least 10mm of the filter paper after a period of 5 minutes in the eye. 

Before placing the Schirmer strip in the eye, the eye should be gently dried of any excess tears using a cotton-tipped applicator at the inferior conjunctival fornices on both sides. The filter paper should be folded 5mm from one end and placed in the lower conjunctival sac near the junction of the middle and outer third of the lower eyelid. Care should be taken not to touch the strip to the cornea or eyelashes upon insertion. After 5 minutes, the filter paper should be removed and the amount of paper that is moist is measured from the fold.

questions.question: Tear volume in a normal, healthy, young adult measures approximately between which of the following values?
questions.explanation: Tear volume has been measured by several methods to be approximately 6-7 microliters in normal individuals, with lesser values occurring in conditions of aqueous tear deficiency. This has implications for drug delivery, since the normal ophthalmic drop volume varies between 25 and 50 microliters, effectively overwhelming the native tear value upon instillation.

questions.question: You decide to perform lacrimal dilation and irrigation on a patient with a suspected blockage of the lacrimal drainage system. Which of the following BEST describes the average length of the vertical and horizontal canaliculi, respectively?
questions.explanation: The canaliculi pass vertically from the opening of the puncta for a length of 2mm before turning medially and coursing another 8mm where the superior and inferior divisions come together at the common canaliculus. This is important to know when performing lacrimal dilation and irrigation so that the cannula is positioned to follow this anatomical characteristic.

questions.question: What is the average period of time an eyelash of an adult continues to grow?
questions.explanation:
Eyelashes grow at a fairly slow rate. A single eyelash grows on average for two months and then falls out after a period of roughly three to five months. 

Eyelashes tend to grow faster and have a quicker turnover rate in children.

questions.question: What is the approximate average refractive power of the crystalline lens at birth?
questions.explanation:
The refractive power of the human crystalline lens average 45 diopters in infancy. As the axial length of the eye increases as a child grows, the crystalline lens, in a coordinated effort, will lose about 20 diopters of power by the age of 6. This process is part of emmetropization, in which the refractive power of the cornea also decreases to maintain a clear image on the retina as the eye becomes lengthened. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye 11th Edition. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. 2011. Saunders Elsevier. 

Optical and Structural Development of the Crystalline Lens in Childhood. Mutti, D.O. et al. IOVS, January 1998, Vol 39, No. 1. 

The Wisdom of the Eye. Miller, D.M. 2000. Academic Press. San Diego, CA.

questions.question: On average, how many eyelashes are located on the upper eye lid?
questions.explanation: In general, the upper eyelid contains two to three irregularly spaced rows of eyelashes totaling between 100-150 (sometimes more) individual eyelashes. On average, the lower lid contains 50 to 75 eyelashes.

questions.question: Tear thickness in a normal, healthy, young adult measures approximately how thick?
questions.explanation: There has been a significant range of normal human tear thicknesses reported in research literature since the early 1990s, but the most consistent value suggested by several groups using non-invasive methods is about 3.0 micrometers. The value of approximately 40 micrometers was put forth by Prydal and co-workers in 1992 (IOVS 33:2006-2011) but has not been confirmed by other investigators or alternative methods.

questions.question: You are evaluating the function of the levator muscle in a patient with a suspected myogenic ptosis. A measurement less than what value would be considered abnormal?
questions.explanation:
Measuring levator function (upper eyelid excursion) is a very helpful test in aiding in the diagnosis of a ptosis and identifying the underlying etiology. The measurement is achieved by having the patient look down while placing a thumb firmly against the brow to negate the action of the frontalis muscle. The patient is then instructed to look up as far as possible, and the amount of excursion is measured with a ruler. 
- Average levator function is about 15mm 
- A value of 12mm or above is considered 'good' 
- 'Fair' levator function is 5-11mm 
- 4mm or less is considered 'poor' 
- Typically anything below 12mm is considered abnormal

questions.question: When focused on an object located at optical infinity, assuming no refractive error, what is the dioptric power typically exhibited by the crystalline lens?
questions.explanation: The human eye possesses a total refractive power of roughly 60 diopters. Of the total 60 D, the dioptric power of the cornea contributes approximately 40 D. The crystalline lens, when focused on a distant target, displays nearly 20 D of power. The power of the crystalline lens increases during accommodation when a person brings a near target into focus.

questions.question: Oral acyclovir is most effective for patients presenting with eyelid findings associated with herpes zoster if administered within which of the following periods following the onset of the disease?
questions.explanation: Oral acyclovir is the mainstay of therapy for patients diagnosed with herpes zoster ophthalmicus. This systemic treatment is maximally beneficial if it is initiated within 72 hours from the onset of the disease (usually the appearance of eyelid lesions). The use of oral acyclovir typically results in quick resolution of skin vesicles, decreases the amount of pain the patient experiences, and reduces the duration of viral shedding and appearance of new lesions. Acyclovir has also been shown to significantly reduce the incidence of ocular findings such as episcleritis, keratitis, and iritis. The recommended dosage is 800mg orally 5 times per day for 7-10 days.

questions.question: What is the average diameter of the iris?
questions.explanation: The average diameter of the iris is 12 mm. The iris originates from, or is an extension of, the anterior portion of the pars plicata. This transition junction is termed the root of the iris and is the thinnest portion of the iris measuring just 0.5 mm thick.

questions.question: Which of the following individuals is MOST likely to possess large pupils?
options: A 7 year-old Asian, hyperopic male with brown eyes
A 12 year-old Caucasian, myopic female with blue eyes
A 68 year-old Caucasian, hyperopic female with hazel eyes
A 57 year-old African-American, myopic male with brown eyes
answers: A 12 year-old Caucasian, myopic female with blue eyes
questions.explanation:
Patients who are near-sighted, young or possess lighter-colored irides typically exhibit larger pupils than patients who are hyperopic, older, or have darker-colored irides. Pupil size typically diminishes with age. 


Reference: 
The Ophthalmic Assistant: A Text for Allied and Associated Ophthalmic Personnel. Stein H., Stein R. & Freeman M. Elsevier, 2012

questions.question: Which of the following conditions would be categorized as causing amblyopia due to deprivation?
options: A child born with a monocular 2 mm ptosis
A three-year with a constant right 30 prism diopter esotropia
A child born with a large congenital cataract in one eye only
A five-year old with an uncorrected prescription of OD: +7.00 D 20/400 OS: +0.50 20/20
answers: A child born with a large congenital cataract in one eye only
questions.explanation:
Form deprivation amblyopia results when a clear and focused retinal image is blocked to one eye during the critical period. This can occur by a complete congenital cataract in one eye, a large ptosis that covers most or all of the pupil or by some other element that occludes the eye. The lack of visual information to the retina causes the other eye (non-occluded eye) to become dominant and thusly have stronger and a greater number of synaptic connections to the brain. Amblyopia causes a disproportionate amount of cortical neurons to respond preferentially to the non-deprived eye. The occlusion must occur during the critical period, and the earlier the occlusion is detected and removed, the better the prognosis. A small ptosis (i.e. 2 mm) would not be expected to cause amblyopia because the pupil would not be occluded. An unequal prescription such as the one in the above question would cause anisometropic amblyopia in which one eye would receive a clear image while the other would receive a blurry image. The brain would favor the clear retinal image, resulting in a strong dominance of cortical neurons for the least ametropic eye. Strabismus results in the perception of two images that are not fusible by the brain, causing diplopia. In order to eliminate double vision, the eye will suppress an eye (usually the deviated eye). This suppression leads to amblyopia.
PowerPage
Congenital Lens Anomalies

questions.question: Which type of common congenital cataract rarely affects vision and appears as blue dots of varying shapes and sizes dispersed throughout the lens?
questions.explanation:
A cerulean cataract is also known as a 'blue dot' cataract and generally is seen in the lenticular periphery, although it can be scattered throughout the lens. This type of congenital cataract is fairly common but rarely affects visual acuity. 

A Mittendorf's dot is on the posterior aspect of the lens and serves as a remnant of the hyaloid system that had previously been attached to the lens. 

During the third month of development, mesenchymal cells migrate between the lens epithelium and the corneal epithelium to form a transitory network of blood vessels anterior to the lens. This is the pupillary membrane. At 6 months of development, the central blood vessels atrophy and the peripheral vessels increase their contribution to the lesser circle of the iris. By 8.5 months of development, the central vessels fragment and disappear, although they can sometimes persist and appear as web-like projections attached to the iris surface. 

A lamellar cataract, also known as a zonular cataract, is attributable to a fleeting exposure to some type of cataract-inducing event or substance. The cataract is limited to one or several layers of the lens, allowing the practitioner to determine during which time frame of the developmental period the exposure occurred. The fetal nucleus is commonly involved. This type of cataract can have an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern but is not always congenital in origin. 

Reference: Wilson, E., Trivedi, R., and Pandey, S. Pediatric Cataract Surgery: Techniques, Complications and Management (2005) pp 9-11.
PowerPage
Congenital Lens Anomalies

questions.question: Which of the following types of intraocular lens implants is NOT recommended for a patient who suffers from glaucoma with notable field loss?
questions.explanation: Premium multifocal intraocular lenses are great options for many patients, particularly those who wish to have freedom from glasses. However, due to the diffractive optics of multifocal lenses, contrast sensitivity may be reduced. Patients with normal vision typically do not experience a decrease in contrast sensitivity; however, patients with macular disease or those with glaucoma and associated field loss may suffer a significant loss of contrast sensitivity. Monofocal, toric, aspheric and accommodating intraocular lenses do not typically degrade vision and may serve as better options for glaucoma patients with visual field defects.

questions.question: Many skin anomalies may mimic malignant lesions. Which of the following skin conditions has the HIGHEST risk of becoming malignant?
questions.explanation:
Actinic keratosis is a precursor to squamous cell carcinoma and appears as scaly, dry skin that does not heal. People with skin that is of lighter pigmentation along with excessive exposure to ultraviolet light tend to be most at risk for development of this condition. 

Papillomas may take on various forms and may be viral or non-viral in origin. They can commonly be found on the eyelids or surrounding orbital skin. Viral warts tend to grow at an accelerated rate while non-viral papillomas are fairly slow to grow. Papillomas can mimic neoplastic growths so be sure to rule this out while watching carefully for color change, ulceration, lash loss, bleeding, and vascularization. 

Cutaneous horns or tags are also benign and are likely a form of papilloma but appear to involve more keratin. Treatment is similar to that of a papilloma. 

Seborrhoeic keratosis is more commonly seen in middle-aged and elderly persons. This benign, epidermal growth is quite superficial and does not extend into the dermis. It appears like a brown plaque that has been stuck onto someone's skin. The borders are very distinct and there may be some elevation. The lesions may be removed if the patient is concerned about cosmesis.

questions.question: You correctly diagnose your 31 year-old female patient with acute unilateral anterior uveitis. When should laboratory testing typically be initiated in otherwise healthy patients presenting with this condition?
options: Laboratory testing is not indicated in acute cases of uveitis
questions.explanation:
When the patient presents with an anterior uveitis that has an initial presentation, occurs unilaterally, and the patient is otherwise healthy with no other systemic symptoms, no further laboratory testing is usually indicated. On the other hand, patients with recurrent, chronic, or bilateral presentations, or patients that have other symptoms possibly indicating the presence of an associated systemic condition, should undergo a thorough work-up to determine the underlying etiology. Typically, in conjunction with the patient's primary care provider, laboratory testing should be initiated in a patient where anterior uveitis recurs after cessation of treatment (2nd episode). In these cases, there is a much higher risk of being associated with a systemic disease, as compared to a patient with a single episode of intraocular inflammation. 

When indicated, minimal lab testing should include the following: 
- Complete blood cell count (CBC) 
- Urinalysis 
- Lyme titers 
- HLA-B27 test (spondylarthropathies) 
- Antinuclear antibody (ANA) test (juvenile arthritis) 
- Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) test (sarcoidosis) 
- Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test (syphilis) 
- Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) test (syphilis)

questions.question: Which 4 of the following proteins are found in the tear film? (Select 4)
questions.explanation:
The major proteins found in tears include: albumin, lysozymes, lactoferrin, IgA, IgG, secretory component, glycoproteins, antiproteinases, tissue plasminogen activator and the epidermal growth factor. 

Albumin's role in tears is not yet fully understood. It is purported to help regulate tear osmolarity and aid in regulating the flow of fluid. 

Lysozymes and lactoferrin are responsible for bacteriostatic activity. Lysozymes are hydrolytic and lactoferrin chelates iron which is needed for bacterial function. 

IgA and secretory component are useful for destroying bacteria. 

Glycoproteins are needed for proper mucous function. Antiproteinase concentration increases in the presence of infection and may serve to inhibit hydrolytic enzymes produced by bacteria. Tissue plasminogen activator is required to activate plasmin which is necessary for wound healing, as is the epidermal growth factor. 

Creatine is produced by the liver and kidneys as an energy source used primarily by muscle cells. 

Serotonin is a neurotransmitter. Altered levels of this neurotransmitter have been associated with depression among other ailments. 

Glutathione is a powerful antioxidant. Low levels of this tripeptide have been linked with cataract formation.

questions.question: You are examining a patient who reports a previous history of Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome. You immediately notice that his eyelashes appear whitened. What is the name of this finding?
questions.explanation:
The term poliosis refers to the decrease or absence of melanin in the hair of the eyelashes, eyebrows, or head. It is a common occurrence in patients diagnosed with Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada (V-K-H) syndrome but can also be hereditary in healthy individuals. 

Vitiligo is a condition that causes depigmentation of parts of the skin, also commonly found in those with V-K-H syndrome. 

Madarosis refers to the loss or absence of eyelashes (and in some cases, the eyebrows), and can either be congenital in nature or as a result of certain infections. 

Distichiasis is an ocular condition that is characterized by the abnormal growth of lashes from the orifices of the meibomian glands, most commonly of the lower eyelids. 

Alopecia is a condition in which there is significant hair loss in various areas of the body, usually the scalp. This is another feature that is common in V-K-H syndrome.

questions.question: A patient presents to your office reporting mild ocular pain and sectoral injection. Slit-lamp exam confirms your suspicion of episcleritis. The patient reports that he has a history of increased intraocular pressure with steroid-use. The patient wishes to be prescribed a steroid. Given the patient's ocular history, which of the following types of medications would be the BEST choice in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
If a topical steroid is indicated in a patient who has a history of steroid-induced ocular hypertension, glaucoma, or is under the age of 10, it is often sufficient to prescribe an ester-based steroid (such as loteprednol) to control the signs and symptoms of an inflammatory reaction. Ester-based corticosteroids tend to cause less pressure elevation for a given amount of anti-inflammatory effect in comparison to ketone-based steroids (dexamethasone and prednisolone). 

http://www.revoptom.com/content/s/89/c/15591/

questions.question: Which cells are responsible for growth of the fetal lens after the development of the embryonic nucleus?
questions.explanation: The anterior lens epithelium will differentiate into secondary lens fibers which form the fetal nucleus. The posterior lens epithelium differentiates into primary lens cells and is responsible for the embryonic lens nucleus. This occurs at approximately 2 months. Erect and inverted Y sutures visualized via slit lamp examination mark the boundaries of the fetal nucleus.

questions.question: The non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body is continuous anteriorly with what layer of the iris?
questions.explanation: The non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body is continuous anteriorly with the posterior pigmented epithelium of the iris and continuous posteriorly with the neurosensory retina. The non-pigmented epithelium is the most internal layer of the ciliary body and comes into contact with the aqueous humor.
