questions.explanation: Compression of the cornea while measuring the axial length will artificially shorten the eye's length. A decreased axial length will alter the values that are used to calculate the required intraocular lens (IOL) power causing an IOL with a higher plus dioptric power to be implanted. The outcome will result in a greater magnitude of post-operative myopia than expected.

questions.question: Which of the following is MOST likely to occur as a complication of a Neodymium YAG (Yttrium aluminum garnet) laser capsulotomy?
questions.explanation:
Although YAG laser capsulotomy is a relatively safe procedure, it is not without associated risks. Pitting or damage to the IOL may occur, the intraocular pressure may increase (in less than 3% of cases), cystoid macular edema may develop (in less than 1% of cases), a retinal detachment can ensue (2.8 % of cases), anterior chamber inflammation may develop, endophthalmitis may transpire (less than 1% of cases), neovascularization of the iris in patients with diabetes may occur (less than 1% of cases), or the IOL may subluxate or dislocate. 

Many authors agree that the amount of energy applied to the eye and the presence of predisposing factors (such as a history of a retinal detachment) can increase the risk of complications that may be experienced with YAG laser capsulotomy.

questions.question: In general, how is the intraocular pressure (IOP) affected in a patient with an anterior uveitis?
options: More information is required to answer the question
questions.explanation: Typically, a patient with an anterior uveitis will display a decreased IOP due to the fact that the ciliary body decreases its production of aqueous. However, in the event that the trabecular meshwork becomes blocked by the cells and flare therefore hindering aqueous outflow, one would expect to observe an increase in IOP.

questions.question: Purkinje images are caused by reflections of objects on the cornea and lens. Which of the four images moves forward with accommodation?
questions.explanation:
There are four Purkinje images. The first image is caused by reflection from the anterior corneal surface and is the brightest of the images. The first image is roughly the same size as the object. The second Purkinje image is formed by the posterior surface of the cornea and almost coincides with the first Purkinje image. The third Purkinje image is the largest and is caused by reflection off of the anterior plane of the crystalline lens. The fourth Purkinje image is the smallest and is inverted, formed by reflection off of the posterior surface of the lens. 

During the process of accommodation the anterior surface of the lens moves forward. The image that is reflected off of this surface is Purkinje III. Purkinje image III will be seen to move forward during accommodation.

questions.question: You wish to evaluate your patient's overall tear production. Which of the following tests assesses the volume of reflex AND basal tear secretions?
questions.explanation: The Schirmer I test is performed without anesthetic and therefore measures both the basal and reflex tear secretions. This test is conducted by placing a small strip of paper in the temporal region of the inferior cul-de-sac of the eye. The room illumination is dimmed and the patient is asked to blink normally. After five minutes, the length of the paper that is moist is measured. If greater than 10 mm of the paper is wet, the tear production is considered normal. The Schirmer II test is performed in conjunction with anesthetic, and therefore measures the basal tear production. Prior to the test, anesthetic is instilled into the eye. After one minute, the tears and excess anesthetic are removed from the inferior cul-de-sac. The test is then performed in the same fashion as the Schirmer I test. If greater than 5 mm of the paper is wet, the tear production is normal. Alternatively, the basal levels of tear secretion can be investigated by placing a specially coated thread (phenol red thread test) at the outer canthi of each eye for 15 seconds. The amount of thread that turns bright red (due to wetting of the phenol red dye) should measure greater than 10 mm for a normal result. The Jones I test evaluates the integrity of the tear drainage system. Sodium fluorescein is placed into the patient's eyes, and after five minutes the patient is asked to blow their nose. The tissue is evaluated for dye or, alternatively, a cotton-tipped applicator may be placed under the inferior turbinate and evaluated for the presence of dye. If dye is not observed, then there may be a blockage of the drainage system.

questions.question: Which area of the trabecular meshwork offers the greatest resistance to outflow?
questions.explanation: The uveal meshwork possesses the largest pore size and it is the first area of the trabecular meshwork through which the aqueous drains. The corneoscleral meshwork is the thickest portion of the trabecular meshwork and has pore sizes that are slightly smaller than those of the uveal meshwork. The juxtacanalicular layer is quite thin, around 10-20 microns, and does not contain pores but rather a layer of endothelial cells that form vacuoles that allow for drainage of aqueous into the canals of Schlemm. The canals of Schlemm are not considered a part of the trabecular meshwork.

questions.question: Dacryocystitis refers to inflammation or infection of which of the following structures of the eye?
questions.explanation:
Dacryocystitis refers to inflammation of the lacrimal sac, commonly caused by nasolacrimal duct obstruction or infection. Symptoms of dacryocystitis typically involve pain, redness, and swelling over the medial canthal aspect of the lower eyelid where the lacrimal sac resides. Additionally, patients will also commonly complain of watery eyes or of mucous that may extrude from the punctum upon digital pressure. The mainstay of treatment for cases of dacryocystitis includes oral antibiotics; however, in some patients surgical treatment may be necessary. 

Remember that inflammation of the lacrimal gland, located at the temporal aspect of the upper lid, is known as dacryoadenitis.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct pathway for the drainage of tears through the nasolacrimal drainage system?
options: Lacrimal sac, lacrimal punctum, lacrimal canaliculus, ampulla, nasolacrimal duct, valve of Hasner
Nasolacrimal duct, lacrimal sac, valve of Hasner, lacrimal canaliculus, ampulla, lacrimal punctum
Lacrimal punctum, lacrimal canaliculus, ampulla, valve of Hasner, nasolacrimal duct, lacrimal sac
Lacrimal punctum, lacrimal canaliculus, ampulla, lacrimal sac, nasolacrimal duct, valve of Hasner
answers: Lacrimal punctum, lacrimal canaliculus, ampulla, lacrimal sac, nasolacrimal duct, valve of Hasner
questions.explanation:
The lacrimal punctum is a small aperture located in the lacrimal papilla, the slight elevation at the junction of the lacrimal and ciliary portions of the eyelid margin. Initially, the tear film drains through this aperture. The lacrimal punctum leads into the lacrimal canaliculus, the tube connecting the punctum to the lacrimal sac. The ampulla is a slight dilation in the initial portion of the lacrimal canaliculus. The canaliculi from the upper and lower lids run horizontally along the lid margin, connecting into a common canaliculus that then enters the lateral aspect of the lacrimal sac located in the anterior portion of the medial orbital wall. The lacrimal sac empties into the nasolacrimal duct in the maxillary bone. The valve of Hasner is located at the terminus of the nasolacrimal duct in the inferior nasal meatus. The Valve of Hasner is a fold of mucosal tissue that ensures that fluid flows anterograde out of the duct. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 153-154

questions.question: Which 2 of the following changes of the crystalline lens occur during accommodation? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
During accommodation, the following changes of the crystalline lens occur in order to allow for an increase in the optical power of the eye to focus on near objects: 
- The ciliary muscle contracts, releasing resting zonular tension around the equator of the crystalline lens 
- The diameter of the lens decreases 
- The thickness of the lens increases 
- The anterior surface of the lens moves anteriorly, while the posterior surface of the lens does not change position 
- This causes the anterior and posterior surfaces of the lens to be more curved 
- The thickness of the lens nucleus increases, without a change in the thickness of the cortex 
- The increase in curvature of the anterior and posterior lens surfaces results in a subsequent increase in the optical power of the lens, allowing the eye to focus on near objects

questions.question: In what order do the lens structures develop embryologically?
options: Lens pit, lens vesicle, lens plate (placode), lens capsule, embryonic lens nucleus
Lens plate (placode), lens capsule, lens vesicle, embryonic lens nucleus, lens pit
Lens vesicle, lens pit, lens plate (placode), embryonic lens nucleus, lens capsule
Lens plate (placode), lens vesicle, lens pit, lens capsule, embryonic lens nucleus
Lens plate (placode), lens pit, lens vesicle, embryonic lens nucleus, lens capsule
answers: Lens plate (placode), lens pit, lens vesicle, embryonic lens nucleus, lens capsule
questions.explanation:
The lens plate (placode) forms from surface ectoderm adjacent to the optic vesicle, beginning around day 27 of development. The outer surface of the lens plate invaginates to form a lens pit which continues until it forms the lens vesicle. The lens vesicle which separates from the surface ectoderm around day 33; it is a single layer of cells forming a hollow sphere. After the lens vesicle is formed, posterior epithelial cells become the primary lens fibers and form the embryonic lens nucleus at the center of the developing lens. The anterior cells stay in place at this time, and the equatorial cells divide and elongate to form secondary lens fibers around the embryonic nucleus. The lens capsule is apparent at about 5 weeks; it originates from the basement membrane of the surface ectoderm and from secretions of the lens epithelium. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 107-109

questions.question: Slit-lamp examination of your 13 year-old patient with a history of Down syndrome reveals the presence of whitish, pale lesions at the peripheral iris stroma in both eyes. What is the name of this finding?
questions.explanation:
Brushfield spots are small whitish or greyish lesions that are typically found circumferentially around the peripheral region of the iris. They represent focal areas of stromal hyperplasia that are surrounded by areas of relative hypoplasia. Brushfield spots are more commonly observed in patients with lightly pigmented irides. This finding can be observed in some normal individuals but has a strong association in patients with Down syndrome. 

Lisch nodules are small hyper-pigmented lesions that are observed in almost all cases of neurofibromatosis-1. Mammilations are also associated with neurofibromatosis (as well as congenital ocular melanocytosis, Axenfeld-Rieger anomaly, and Peters anomaly) and present as tiny conical or vitelliform lesions that either partially or completely cover the anterior surface of the iris. 

Koeppe and Busacca nodules are iris lesions that are associated with granulomatous uveitis; however, their placement differs from one another. Koeppe nodules are observed at the iris pupillary border, in contrast to Busacca nodules, which are found in the mid-iris stroma.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the blood flow to and away from the ciliary processes?
options: Long posterior and short ciliary arteries-> arteriole-> many ciliary processes-> venule-> vortex vein-> ophthalmic vein
Long posterior and short ciliary arteries-> arteriole-> ciliary process-> venule-> vortex vein-> ophthalmic vein
Long posterior and short ciliary arteries-> arteriole-> many ciliary processes-> venule-> ophthalmic vein-> vortex vein
Long posterior and short ciliary arteries-> arteriole ->ciliary process-> venule-> ophthalmic vein->vortex vein
answers: Long posterior and short ciliary arteries-> arteriole-> ciliary process-> venule-> vortex vein-> ophthalmic vein
questions.explanation: The key piece of information to note is that one arteriole supplies a single ciliary process rather than many, due to the fact that the secretion of aqueous is a rather important function of the ciliary body and is best regulated via a 1:1 ratio.

questions.question: The lens changes significantly as we age. One of these changes is the formation of vacuoles. What causes this?
options: Loss of lenticular capsule elasticity causing decreased accommodation
Decreased function of the sodium/potassium pump causing decreased protein synthesis
The separation of water from proteins causing agglutination of proteins and pooling of water
Glutathione loss with age causing cross linking between proteins
answers: The separation of water from proteins causing agglutination of proteins and pooling of water
questions.explanation:
Crystalline proteins are normally water-soluble. With age, they begin to clump together altering the amount of water that they are capable of binding to. The water begins to pool together creating vacuoles. The pooling of water causes light scattering because the index of refraction differs between that of the lens proteins and the water aggregations. 

Glutathione loss and decreased function of the ion pump do indeed contribute to cataract formation, but the direct cause of vacuoles is pooling of water. 

Loss of capsular elasticity leads to presbyopia.

questions.question: Patients with which type of refractive error are MOST likely to experience a decrease in intraocular pressure (IOP) following cataract surgery?
questions.explanation: Patients with moderate to high amounts of hyperopia typically have a shortened axial length of the eye. In these cases, the volume and depth of the anterior chamber is reduced as well as compared to normal eyes (or eyes with myopic refractive errors). This decreased anterior chamber depth puts these patients at higher risk for increased intraocular pressure due to narrow angles that may eventually result in an angle closure attack. Additionally, as a cataract progresses with age, the crystalline lens tends to grow, further shallowing the anterior chamber. Cataract surgery in this population usually results in a deepening of the anterior chamber (usually decreasing the IOP) and also reduces the chances of a future angle closure. It is important to note that this effect may not occur in all cases of moderate to high hyperopia, but this group is the most likely to experience a change in IOP following cataract extraction.

questions.question: Dry eyes can cause blurred vision, stinging and foreign body sensation. How do the tears seen in people with dry eyes compare to those with normal eyes?
questions.explanation: The tear film in people with dry eyes displays a higher pH than that of normal eyes. The change in pH is attributable to the fact that the osmolarity of the tears increases, thus increasing the pH. Many drug companies have taken advantage of this knowledge and applied it in their manufacture of artificial tears. Alcon, the company that invented Systane, ultilizes a component called Hydroxypropyl-guar (HP-Guar) which is a gel-forming matrix. Upon instillation of Systane into the eye, the liquid transforms into a gel. The difference in pH between the tear film and the artificial tears leads to an alteration in the cross-linking between HP-Guar and borate (another ingredient in the artificial tears), causing the creation of a gel-like layer that allows for increased ocular contact time. Studies show that the tear lysozyme content is decreased in people who suffer from dry eyes.

questions.question: Your 43 year-old male patient reports a gradual decrease in vision over the past year that tends to worsen when reading or in bright lighting conditions. Slit-lamp examination reveals a granular, plaque-like cataract that appears black on retroillumination. What is the MOST likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Posterior subcapsular cataracts occur just in front of the posterior capsule and typically present as a granulated or vacuolated opacity that can be best viewed with an obliquely oriented parallel-piped light beam on slit-lamp biomicroscopy. On retroillumination, this type of cataract appears as a black plaque located deep within the lens (it has the same appearance on retinoscopy). Patients presenting with this type of cataract commonly complain of decreased vision, even in mild cases, due to the location of the opacities occurring at the nodal point of the eye. Near vision and vision under bright light conditions are typically the most affected due to miosis that occurs in these situations. Posterior subcapsular cataracts have a strong association with long-term use of systemic or topical corticosteroids. 

Cortical cataracts typically present as wedge-shaped or radial spoke-like opacities that can occur in the anterior, posterior, or equatorial cortex of the crystalline lens. These patients more commonly complain of problems with glare due to the scattering of light from these opacities. 

A nuclear sclerotic cataract is characterized by an early yellowing of the crystalline lens nucleus due to the deposition of urochrome pigment and eventually appears brownish in color in later stages. It is best viewed with an oblique light beam on slit-lamp evaluation as compared to retroillumination. 

A mature cataract is a completely opacified crystalline lens that commonly appears white in color.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following bones make up the floor of the orbit? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
The orbital floor consists of three bones: the palatine, maxillary, and zygomatic bones. It is the floor of the orbit that is most susceptible to orbital blow out fractures due to the relative weakness of the posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone. 

Orbital roof bones: lesser wing of sphenoid, orbital plate of the frontal 
Lateral wall bones: greater wing of sphenoid, zygomatic 
Medial wall bones: maxillary, lacrimal, ethmoid, sphenoid

questions.question: Which of the following systemic medications has been associated with the development of blue-grey perilimbal discoloration of the sclera?
questions.explanation:
Prolonged administration of high doses of minocycline has been shown to cause a blue-grey pigmentary discoloration in certain sun-exposed areas of the body. This includes the skin, perilimbal area of the sclera (usually denser in the interpalpebral area), and nail beds. It is believed that this pigmentation may be due to the photosensitizing properties of the drug. 

Diseases of the Eye and Skin: A Color Atlas. Ostler, H.B., Maibach, H.I., Hoke, A.W., Schwab, I.R. 2004. Lipincott Williams & Wilkins. Philadelphia, PA.

questions.question: In addition to the meibomian glands which other accessory glands secrete oil?
questions.explanation:
The glands of Zeiss and Moll are accessory oil glands located on the lid margins adjacent to the base of the lash follicles. The lipid layer of the tear film is superficial and as such it is exposed to the environment protecting the aqueous layer from evaporation. 

The glands of Wolfring and Krause are located deep in the fornix of the eyelids and serve to secrete a portion of the aqueous layer of the tear film.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following BEST describe the definition as well as the normal value for the margin-reflex distance 1 (MRD1), which is commonly utilized in the evaluation of a ptosis? (Select 2)
options: MRD1 is the distance between the upper eyelid margin and the corneal reflection of a penlight that the patient is viewing directly
The average MRD1 measurement is about 4-4.5mm
The average MRD1 measurement is about 2-2.5mm
MRD1 is the distance between the lower eyelid margin and the corneal reflection of a penlight that the patient is directly viewing
The average MRD1 measurement is about 6-6.5mm
answers: MRD1 is the distance between the upper eyelid margin and the corneal reflection of a penlight that the patient is viewing directly
The average MRD1 measurement is about 4-4.5mm
questions.explanation: The margin reflex distance 1 (MRD1) is the vertical distance between the corneal reflex produced by a penlight that the patient is viewing directly and the upper eyelid margin. MRD2 is the distance from the corneal reflex to the lower eyelid margin. The average MRD1 measurement is about 4-4.5mm, and the average MRD2 measurement is about 6-6.5mm. These measurements are helpful in evaluating potential eyelid ptosis or retraction.

questions.question: Deficiency of vitamin A can lead to a decrease in the number of goblet cells in the conjunctiva. This can decrease production of which of the following?
options: Mucous portion of the tear film
Lipid portion of the tear film
Aqueous portion of the tear film
Apocrine portion of the tear film
answers: Mucous portion of the tear film
questions.explanation: Goblet cells produce the mucous portion of the tear film. Dry eye disorders characterized by a decrease in goblet cell numbers are sometimes treated with vitamin A supplementation. The aqueous portion of the tear film is produced by lacrimal glands. The lipid portion of the tear film is produced by meibomian glands. There is no apocrine portion of the tear film; however, the glands of Moll, also known as ciliary glands, are modified apocrine sweat glands found next to the base of the eyelashes.

questions.question: Ptosis can be caused by dysfunction or damage to which of the following muscles?
questions.explanation:
Ptosis is a condition in which the upper eyelid sags. It can be caused by dysfunction of either the superior palpebral levator or the superior tarsal muscle (muscle of Muller). Because the levator is the major muscle responsible for raising the upper eyelid, ptosis from levator damage is often more severe then ptosis from dysfunction of the muscle of Muller. 

The muscle of Horner (also known as the pars lacrimalis) is part of the palpebral portion of the orbicularis oculi. The fibers for the muscle of Horner come from the lacrimal crest and encircle the lacrimal canaliculi. This assists the flow of tears into the nasolacrimal drainage system when the orbicularis oculi contracts to close the eye. The muscle of Riolan (also known as the pars ciliaris) is another section of the palpebral portion of the orbicularis oculi; it lies near the lid margin to maintain the margins next to the globe. The orbicularis oculi is the major muscle responsible for closing the eyelids. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 140-143

questions.question: Contraction of the orbicularis oculi to close the eye aids in movement of tears through the lacrimal canaliculi and nasolacrimal drainage system via the action of which section of the muscle?
options: Orbital portion of the orbicularis oculi
questions.explanation:
The muscle of Horner (also known as the pars lacrimalis) is part of the palpebral portion of the orbicularis oculi. The fibers for the muscle of Horner come from the lacrimal crest and encircle the lacrimal canaliculi. This assists the flow of tears into the nasolacrimal drainage system when the orbicularis oculi contracts to close the eye. The muscle of Riolan (also known as the pars ciliaris) is another section of the palpebral portion of the orbicularis oculi; it lies near the lid margin to maintain the margins next to the globe. The orbital portion of the orbicularis oculi is mainly responsible for forced closure of the eyelids. The muscle of Mueller (also known as the superior tarsal muscle) is a sympathetic smooth muscle that acts to widen the palpebral fissure. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 140-143

questions.question: Which of the following systemic diseases is MOST commonly associated with the presence of a positive Cogan's lid twitch sign?
questions.explanation:
Cogan's lid twitch sign is characterized by an overshoot of the upper eyelid on a vertical saccade from down-gaze to the primary position (when the patient first looks downward for a short period of time). The upper eyelid will also often twitch in a nystagmoid fashion or slowly droop back to a ptotic primary position. It is thought that this sign is a result of a transient improvement in lid strength after a short rest of the levator when in downgaze, followed by a drop in the lid in primary position as the levator begins to fatigue again. Cogan's lid twitch is most commonly associated with myasthenia gravis.
PowerPage
Myasthenia Gravis

questions.question: The presence of small, iridescent, fleck-like opacities scattered throughout the crystalline lens (also known as 'Christmas tree cataracts') are associated with which of the following systemic diseases?
questions.explanation:
- Myotonic dystrophy: associated with multi-colored opacities known as 'Christmas tree' cataracts (close to 90% of patients develop these cataracts) 
- Atopic dermatitis: associated with shield-like, dense anterior subcapsular plaques 
- Neurofibromatosis: associated with posterior subcapsular or posterior cortical cataracts 
- Wilson's disease: associated with green 'sunflower' cataracts 
- Down's syndrome: low association with Cerulean or 'blue-dot' cataracts
PowerPage
Cataracts in Systemic Disease

questions.question: Which of the following types of scleritis presents without ocular inflammation, has a low risk for perforation, and does not typically result in pain or decreased visual acuity?
questions.explanation:
Scleromalacia perforans is a type of necrotizing scleritis that typically presents without vascular congestion or pain. Clinical observations commonly include yellow-colored necrotic plaques that occur near the limbus without inflammation and very slow progression of scleral thinning that eventually exposes the underlying uveal tissue. Patients commonly complain of a mild non-specific irritation but no pain. Visual acuity is also not usually affected in these patients. Scleromalacia perforans typically affects elderly women with a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis. By the time patients are correctly diagnosed with this condition, treatment is usually not needed or is ineffective. Even though the name contains the word 'perforans,' the risk of perforation is extremely rare, as the integrity of the globe is usually well maintained.
PowerPage
Scleritis

questions.question: Which 3 of the following clinical observations will aid in the confirmation of a diagnosis of nodular episcleritis? (Select 3)
options: Nodule is usually tender to touch
Associated congested blood vessels do not blanch with phenylephrine
Nodule cannot be moved over the underlying sclera
Nodule is not usually tender to touch
Associated congested blood vessels blanch with phenylephrine
Nodule can be moved over the underlying sclera
answers: Nodule is not usually tender to touch
Associated congested blood vessels blanch with phenylephrine
Nodule can be moved over the underlying sclera
questions.explanation:
Several features of the presentation of nodular episcleritis can be utilized to aid in differentiating this condition from conjunctival lesions (such as a phlyctenule) and a nodule associated with scleritis. Typically, in nodular episcleritis, there is an area of localized inflammation that forms a round or oval nodule that is commonly 2-6mm in size. Any associated episcleral blood vessel congestion is usually minimal and will blanch, along with the conjunctival vessels, with the instillation of phenylephrine drops. Scleral blood vessels will not blanch; therefore, if congestion is still present, the inflammation is affecting the sclera. Additionally, nodules related to episcleritis are not usually tender to touch, as they are in cases of nodular scleritis. Also, light mechanical pressure in the region of the nodule can help localize the lesion, as the conjunctival tissue will freely move over the nodule, and the nodule will freely move over the sclera in patients with nodular episcleritis. Conjunctival lesions will move with the conjunctival tissue when pressure is applied, while a nodule associated with scleritis is completely immobile.
PowerPage
Scleritis

questions.question: You notice a palpable flat elevation of the skin on the left upper lid of your 73 year-old male patient that is about 2.5cm in diameter. What is the proper dermatological term for this type of lesion?
questions.explanation:
- Plaque: a palpable but flat lesion of the skin that is greater than 0.5cm in diameter. Plaques may have well-defined, or ill-defined borders. 
- Macule: a localized area of color change without any associated infiltration or elevation (the surface is smooth). The lesion may be pigmented (as in a freckle), hypopigmentation (vitiligo), or erythematous (in a capillary hemangioma). The area of change is typically less than 1.5cm in diameter. 
- Papule: small palpable lesions in which there is a solid elevation of the skin. These lesions are usually less than 0.5cm in diameter, may be flat-topped or dome-shaped, and may be a single lesion or present as multiple lesions. 
- Vesicle: a small fluid-filled lesion that is typically less than 0.5cm in diameter. There may be a single lesion or multiple lesions. 
- Nodule: a solid area of elevated skin; a papule that is enlarged in three dimensions (height, width, and length).

questions.question: Which of the following types of congenital cataracts are characteristic of galactosemia?
questions.explanation:
Central oil droplet opacities are a type of congenital cataract that is associated with galactosemia, a genetic metabolic disorder that affects the body's ability to metabolize galactose properly. 

Blue dot (Cerulean) opacities are congenital cataracts and are not usually associated with systemic disease but are thought to be due to autosomal dominant mutations in several genes. 

Christmas tree cataracts are not considered a congenital type of cataract; they are a rare variant of senile cataracts that have a strong association with myotonic dystrophy. 

Sunflower cataracts are also not considered congenital cataracts and are due to the abnormal deposition of copper in patients suffering from Wilson's disease.
PowerPage
Cataracts in Systemic Disease

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the blood flow through the scleral tissue?
options: Only the posterior ciliary arteries run through the scleral tissue
The sclera is considered avascular; it contains no capillary beds
Both the anterior and posterior ciliary arteries pass through the scleral tissue
Only the anterior ciliary arteries run through the scleral tissue
answers: The sclera is considered avascular; it contains no capillary beds
questions.explanation:
The sclera is considered an avascular tissue due to the fact that it does not contain any capillary beds. The sclera is a very low metabolically active tissue, and it obtains sufficient nutrition through the overlying episcleral and underlying choroidal blood supplies. In contrast, the episclera obtains a rich supply of blood from both the anterior ciliary arteries and posterior ciliary arteries, which form a superficial vascular plexus and deep vascular plexus within its tissue. An episode of episcleritis is characterized by vasculitis of the superficial vascular plexus and edema of the episclera, while scleritis involves vasculitis of the deep episcleral vascular plexus and edema of the scleral tissue. Episcleritis occurs in the absence of scleritis; however, scleritis typically occurs in conjunction with episcleritis (but can also be isolated). 

Clinical Ocular Pharmacology. Bartlett, J.D., Jaanus, S. D.
PowerPage
Scleritis

questions.question: At which location of the eye is the sclera THICKEST?
questions.explanation: The thickness of the scleral tissue of the human eye varies from 1.0mm at the posterior pole to 0.3mm just behind the insertion sites for the rectus muscles.

questions.question: The anterior portion of the ciliary body which contains the ciliary processes is known as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The pars plicata is the anterior portion of the ciliary body which contains the ciliary processes. The ciliary processes extend into the posterior chamber and have valleys between them known as the valleys of Kuhnt. The pars plana is the flatter region of the ciliary body and extends from posterior to the pars plicata to the ora serrata which is the transition from ciliary body to choroid. The ora serrata has a serrated pattern of dentate processes which are elongations of retinal tissue into the pars plana. The supraciliaris is the outermost layer of the ciliary body adjacent to the sclera containing loose connective tissue arranged in bands that allow the ciliary body to slide against the sclera. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 p 37

questions.question: A 72 year-old Caucasian male has developed lower lid ectropion as a result of a surgical complication that occurred after the removal of a basal cell carcinoma. This type of ectropion can be classified as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ectropion that is caused by contraction of scar tissue following injury (burns or lacerations) or surgery to the eyelid is known as cicatricial ectropion. 

Involutional ectropion is the most common cause of ectropion and is caused by stretching and laxity of the medial and lateral canthal ligaments and by retractor dehiscence. It is associated with aging and is most often seen in individuals over the age of 60. 

Paralytic ectropion occurs as a result of the inability of a paralytic orbicularis muscle to oppose the force of gravity. 

A mechanical type of ectropion occurs when a large lesion forms on the eyelid, which pulls the eyelid away from the eye. 

Congenital ectropion of the eyelid can occur as well, but it is very rare and will be present at birth due to some defect of eyelid formation.

questions.question: What is the correct sequence of aqueous flow beginning from its point of origin?
options: Pars plicata-> posterior chamber-> trabecular meshwork-> anterior chamber-> pupil
Posterior chamber-> pars plicata-> pupil-> trabecular meshwork -> anterior chamber
Pupil-> anterior chamber-> pars plicata-> posterior chamber-> trabecular meshwork
Pars plicata-> posterior chamber-> pupil-> anterior chamber-> trabecular meshwork
answers: Pars plicata-> posterior chamber-> pupil-> anterior chamber-> trabecular meshwork
questions.explanation: The ciliary processes of the pars plicata produce the aqueous humor. The aqueous then flows into the posterior chamber where it flows across the anterior surface of the lens, through the pupil and into the anterior chamber. Once in the anterior chamber it drains through the trabecular meshwork.

questions.question: You are evaluating your 56 year-old female patient and notice a small area of localized hyperpigmentation of the skin on her right upper lid that does not have any associated infiltration or elevation. What is the proper dermatological term for this type of lesion?
questions.explanation:
- Macule: a localized area of color change without any associated infiltration or elevation (the surface is smooth). The lesion may be pigmented (as in a freckle), hypopigmentation (vitiligo), or erythematous (in a capillary hemangioma). The area of change is typically less than 1.5cm in diameter. 
- Papule: small palpable lesions in which there is a solid elevation of the skin. These lesions are usually less than 0.5cm in diameter, may be flat-topped or dome-shaped, and may be a single lesion or present as multiple lesions. 
- Vesicle: a small fluid-filled lesion that is typically less than 0.5cm in diameter. There may be a single lesion or multiple lesions. 
- Plaque: a palpable but flat lesion of the skin that is greater than 0.5cm in diameter. Plaques may have well-defined or ill-defined borders. 
- Nodule: a solid area of elevated skin; a papule that is enlarged in three dimensions (height, width, and length).

questions.question: Dissection of the eye reveals that the ciliary body is actually triangular in shape. The apex of this triangle points in which direction and is continuous with which structure?
options: Points anteriorly: continuous with ora serrata
Points posteriorly ; continuous with scleral spur
questions.explanation: The ciliary body is a band roughly 6mm wide and runs circumferentially internal to the sclera and posterior to the limbus. This structure is triangular in shape whose apex points posteriorly and is continuous with the choroid.

questions.question: An 81 year-old female patient presents with a chief complaint of blurred vision and glare at night. Slit-lamp examination reveals fibrosis on the posterior surface of her intraocular lens. What is her diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most common late complication (of uncomplicated cataract surgery) is visually significant posterior capsular opacification. This finding commonly causes complaints of decreased vision, impaired contrast sensitivity, glare, and in some cases, monocular diplopia. Elschnig pearls are a typical finding that appear as vacuolated clusters on the back surface of the lens implant. They are a result of migration and proliferation of residual equatorial lens epithelial cells along the posterior capsule. In addition to Elschnig pearls, capsular fibrosis is another common finding of posterior capsular opacification that is due to fibrous metaplasia of epithelial cells. It is less common than Elschnig pearls but usually appears earlier. 

Posterior subcapsular cataracts and posterior polar cataracts only occur in the natural crystalline lens. 

Anterior capsular contraction is a post-operative complication that typically occurs several weeks after cataract surgery. Contraction and fibrosis of the anterior capsule can continue to progress and affect visual acuity; this progression may require a laser capsulotomy.

questions.question: Granular-appearing crystalline lens opacities that form due to posterior migration and swelling of lens epithelial cells are known as which of the following types of cataracts?
questions.explanation:
Posterior subcapsular cataracts (PSCs) are lens opacities that form in front of the posterior lens capsule, typically presenting with a granular appearance on retroillumination during slit-lamp examination. PSCs develop as a result of abnormal migration of lens epithelial cells that form a cluster of swollen cells at the posterior region of the lens. Light scatter from these types of opacities is particularly disabling because the scatter tends to be located near the optical axis. 

Textbook of Ophthalmology (6th edition). 2012. Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye. (11th edition). 2011. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.F.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: Which of the following types of cataracts is the MOST detrimental to visual acuity?
questions.explanation: Posterior subcapsular cataracts (PSC) are the result of cellular migration from the equator to the posterior pole and tend to affect visual acuity to a greater degree than other types of cataracts due to the fact that they are closest to the posterior nodal point of the eye and are located on or near the visual axis. Patients with PSCs will complain of decreased acuity in bright light and to a lesser degree in low light. This asymmetrical disruption of visual acuity in varying light levels stems from changes in pupil size. In bright light the pupils constrict, creating a small aperture that is covered over by the opacification. In low lighting conditions, the pupils dilate allowing for greater lens exposure most of which is not opacified (or at least to a lesser degree) resulting in improved vision.

questions.question: Long-term use of corticosteroids can lead to the formation of which of the following types of cataract?
questions.explanation: The possible formation of posterior subcapsular cataracts (PSC) is a common concern in patients undergoing long-term treatment with corticosteroid therapy. PSCs have been associated with the use of systemic, topical, ophthalmic, topical dermatologic, nasal aerosol, and inhalation type steroids. This relationship is likely dose-dependent, and the usual time from beginning steroid treatment to the onset of lens changes is 1 year (with a dosage of 10 mg/day of prednisone) but has been observed in as short as 2 months with as little as 5 mg/day. Patients with PSC formation may complain of an increase in light sensitivity, photophobia, glare, or difficulty reading. If visual acuity is notably decreased, surgical removal of the lens may be warranted.

questions.question: The medial portion of the eyelid lymphatics drains into which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
The medial 1/3 of the upper eyelid and the medial 2/3 of the lower lid lymphatics drain into the submandibular node located just under the jaw-line. The lateral 2/3 of the upper lid and the lateral 1/3 of the lower lid lymphatics drain into the pre-auricular lymph node located directly in front of the ear. Therefore, it is very important to evaluate these two nodes separately, especially when a condition of viral etiology is suspected. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye (Eleventh edition). Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.F.E., Ver Hoove, J., Wu, S.M. 2011. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: An infection of the subcutaneous tissue anterior to the orbital septum is known as which of the following ocular conditions?
questions.explanation:
Preseptal cellulitis is defined as an infection of the soft subcutaneous tissue anterior to the orbital septum. If an infection occurs anywhere in the orbit posterior to this septum, it is known as orbital cellulitis. 

An internal hordeolum is a localized infection of the meibomian glands, while an external hordeolum is described as an acute infection with abscess formation of the glands of Zeiss and Moll. A pyogenic granuloma is a proliferative fibrovascular response to prior inflammation, surgery, or trauma.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following ocular conditions are MOST likely to lead to the development of a Vossius ring? (Select 2)
questions.explanation: A Vossius ring refers to an annular ring of iris pigment that can be seen on the anterior capsule of the crystalline lens. A Vossius ring may be observed following blunt ocular trauma, in which the pupillary edge of the iris is forced against the anterior lens capsule; a concurrent traumatic cataract is also typically found in these cases. A Vossius ring may also occur secondary to posterior synechiae that have formed between the pupillary border and crystalline lens and then broken by mydriasis.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following muscles of the face are responsible for closure of the eyelids? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
The major protractor of the eyelid, responsible for the closure of the lids, is the orbicularis oculi muscle. It is innervated by the facial nerve and can be divided into three portions: preseptal, orbital, and pretarsal. Spontaneous blinking is a result of the action of the pretarsal and preseptal regions, while stimulation of the orbital portion results in forced eyelid closure. 

Corrugators are also considered protractors of the eyelids. They also act to draw the eyebrow downward and medially, causing wrinkles of the forehead. It is for this reason that this muscle is also known as the 'frowning' muscle. 

The procerus also aids in the closure of the eyelids. Additionally, it helps pull the skin between the eyebrows downward and contributes to the expression of anger. 

The frontalis and levator palpebrae superioris muscles are responsible for retraction of the eyelids. 

Ocular Surface Disease: Conjunctiva and Tear Film: Expert Consult. Holland, E.J., Mannis, M.J., Lee, B. 2013. Elsevier Saunders.

questions.question: Preseptal cellulitis can lead to orbital cellulitis if it is not treated appropriately. Which of the following findings is more commonly seen with ORBITAL cellulitis?
questions.explanation:
Preseptal cellulitis is an infection that is limited to structures that lay anterior to the orbital septum and is most commonly caused by sinusitis. This condition may also arise from a dental infection, internal hordeola or trauma. Common pathogens include Haemophilus influenzae (especially in children) and Staphylococcus and Streptococcus (more likely in adults). Findings of preseptal cellulitis include a unilateral painful, swollen eyelid with potentially mild chemosis. EOMs, visual acuity, pupillary reaction, and fundus findings should be normal. Treatment consists of oral antibiotics and close follow-up to ensure resolution. 

Orbital cellulitis is a very serious infection that has a risk of mortality due to its ability to extend into the meninges and cavernous sinus. Patients with orbital cellulitis will typically feel very ill. Clinical findings may include proptosis, an afferent pupillary defect, diplopia, pain on eye movement, papilledema, decreased visual acuity, reduced color vision, eyelid edema, external ophthalmoplegia, and an increased white blood cell count. Treatment is immediate hospitalization and antibiotic treatment.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the etiology of the presence of anterior chamber flare in a patient with iritis?
options: Protein in the anterior chamber due to breakdown of the blood-retinal barrier
Cells in the anterior chamber due to breakdown of the blood-retinal barrier
Protein in the anterior chamber due to breakdown of the blood-aqueous barrier
Cells in the anterior chamber due to breakdown of the blood-aqueous barrier
answers: Protein in the anterior chamber due to breakdown of the blood-aqueous barrier
questions.explanation:
Flare in the anterior chamber refers to presence of an increased amount of protein in the aqueous fluid, and is often seen in association with cells. Aqueous cells and flare occur secondary to the breakdown of the blood-aqueous barrier as a result of trauma, infection, inflammation due to uveitis, scleritis, keratitis, or ocular surgery. 

Cells and flare in the anterior chamber may be difficult to appreciate in mild cases and are best observed when viewed what a short, narrow slit-lamp beam, directed at an oblique angle through the pupil. All room lights should be completely turned off and the observer allowed time to dark-adapt. Cells will appear as small white particles floating in the anterior chamber, while flare makes the aqueous fluid appear hazy or cloudy (like smoke in a dark room).

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the drainage pathway of tears?
options: Puncta-> caniculi-> nasolacrimal duct-> lacrimal sac-> inferior meatus
Puncta-> lacrimal sac-> nasolacrimal duct-> caniculi-> inferior meatus
Puncta-> caniculi-> lacrimal sac-> nasolacrimal duct-> inferior meatus
Puncta-> lacrimal sac-> caniculi-> nasolacrimal duct-> inferior meatus
answers: Puncta-> caniculi-> lacrimal sac-> nasolacrimal duct-> inferior meatus
questions.explanation: The tears drain into the puncta and travel through the caniculi to the lacrimal sac; they then drain into the nasolacrimal duct and finally into the inferior meatus.

questions.question: What is the proper term for a congenital absence of the punctal opening/orifice?
questions.explanation: The congenital absence of a punctal opening is termed punctal atresia. The word 'atresia' refers to the absence of a bodily opening that should normally be present. Punctal stenosis is a narrowing of the puncta, which usually occurs secondarily to usage of pharmacological agents. Dacryocystitis refers to an inflammation of the lacrimal sac (generally secondary to an infection). Canaliculitis is caused by inflammation of the canaliculus (usually as a result of infection).

questions.question: An 81-year old female reports that her eye has been watering more frequently over the past month; you decide to administer the primary Jones dye test (Jones I). After 5 minutes, the application of a cotton-tipped applicator to the inferior turbinate reveals the presence of dye in the area. Taking this into consideration, what is the MOST likely cause of the patient's epiphora complaint?
options: Dysfunction of the valve of Hasner
questions.explanation:
The primary Jones dye test can be utilized to determine the patency of the nasolacrimal system. 1-2 drops of fluorescein are instilled into the inferior fornix of the eyes while the patient is in an upright position and blinking her eyes normally. After a period of 5 to 10 minutes, a cotton-tipped applicator is used to swab the undersurface of the inferior turbinate on each side of the nasal passage. 

When the primary Jones dye test is positive (dye is recovered from the inferior turbinate of the nose), practitioners may conclude that the system is patent and that no significant blockage of the nasolacrimal drainage structure is likely. However, minor stenosis or physiologic dysfunctions cannot be completely ruled out. Patients who have a positive result on the Jones I test are more likely to experience symptoms of epiphora that are secondary to primary oversecretion of tears, rather than a dysfunction in lacrimal drainage (as in the above question). 

When the primary Jones dye test is negative, the probability of an obstruction or dysfunction in lacrimal drainage is much greater; however, this test alone is not sufficient to document this conclusion. The secondary Jones dye test is then necessary to determine the severity and location of the obstruction.

questions.question: During case history, your patient reveals that he is concerned about a lesion on his left lower eyelid. He states that it grew very rapidly at first, then has remained static for the past 2 months. Upon examination you notice that the lesion has a keratin-filled crater centrally. Which of the following is the MOST likely diagnosis of the patient's chief complaint?
questions.explanation:
Keratoacanthoma is a rapidly growing tumor that typically occurs in patients with fair skin and a history of chronic sun exposure. It may have a similar appearance to that of a squamous cell carcinoma; however, the following stages and characteristics may aid in correctly diagnosing this type of lesion: 
- Very rapidly growing lesion, typically pink in color initially and often found on the lower eyelid 
- The lesion usually stops growing and remains stable in size for a period of 2-3 months 
- After this time, the lesion starts to involute spontaneously (this phenomenon is very helpful in diagnosing keratoacanthoma) 
- During this period of involution, the central part of the lesion becomes hyperkeratotic, and a keratin-filled crater commonly develops 
- Involution may take up to a year and a residual scar in the area of the lesion typically occurs after involution is complete 

Actinic keratosis is a slow-growing lesion that typically occurs on the forehead and back of hands (rarely on the eyelids). It presents as a hyperkeratotic plaque, with a scaly surface, and distinct borders. This condition is a precursor to squamous cell carcinoma. 

A pyogenic granuloma is a rapidly growing vascular lesion that tends to be painful and commonly bleeds with minor trauma. It is usually preceded by a history surgery, trauma, or infection. 

Chalazia form as a result of retained sebaceous secretions from the meibomian glands (or other sebaceous glands). A chalazion presents as a non-tender, roundish nodule at the region of the tarsal plate. 

Squamous cell papillomas can have variable appearances, such as a flesh-colored pedunculated lesion, a broad-based raspberry-like lesion, or a cutaneous horn-like presentation.

questions.question: Numerous reports have suggested that increased tear film osmolarity is a key consequence in dry eye. Although osmolarity is not easily measured in the clinical setting, tear osmolarity increases in most dry eye sub-types due to which of the following processes?
options: Reactive oxygen species are increased in the tears of most dry eye sub-types; this increases osmolarity
Patients with dry eye tend to blink less than normals, leading to increased evaporation
Loss of tear stability induces an increased evaporation rate, leading to increased osmolarity
Decreased capillary exchange leads to ionic bonding
In aqueous tear deficiency, the lacrimal gland produces more ionic species
The lipid layer is altered in most dry eye states, leading to ion pairing
answers: Loss of tear stability induces an increased evaporation rate, leading to increased osmolarity
questions.explanation: Tear instability leads to greater evaporation and higher osmolarity through a mechanism of concentration of the remaining tears, since only the aqueous tear portion evaporates rather than the ionic species. Several studies have indicated that normal tear osmolarity is less than or equal to 300 Osm/L, with values exceeding 308 Osm/L indicating increased osmolarity. As a single measure, tear osmolarity has recently been found to correlate the best (r squared 0.55) to dry eye severity of several clinical tests in a large, multi-center study (Sullivan et al., IOVS 51:6125-6130, 2010).

questions.question: Patients suffering from an episode of acute anterior uveitis typically initially present with decreased intraocular pressure. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for this finding?
options: Reduced active secretion of aqueous by the ciliary epithelium
Increased aqueous outflow through the uveoscleral route
Reduced passive secretion of aqueous by ultrafiltration and diffusion
Increased aqueous outflow through the trabecular meshwork route
answers: Reduced active secretion of aqueous by the ciliary epithelium
questions.explanation:
In acute phases of anterior uveitis, intraocular pressure is initially decreased secondary to a reduction of active aqueous production by the ciliary epithelium. This finding is due to the ciliary body essentially 'shutting down' in response to inflammation. In later stages or in more severe cases of intraocular inflammation, IOP can be elevated due to blockage of the trabecular meshwork by inflammatory cells. 

In cases of herpetic uveitis and Posner-Schlossman syndrome, intraocular pressure can actually be elevated, but these conditions occur with much less frequency than acute anterior uveitis.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following measurements are MOST important in calculating the intraocular lens power that will result in the desired refractive error following cataract surgery? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
In order to calculate the necessary power of the intraocular lens implant to be utilized during cataract surgery, there are critical measurements that must be made prior to the procedure. This ensures that the patient's outcome will most closely match the desired post-operative refractive values. These measurements include corneal keratometry as well as the antero-posterior dimension of the eye (axial length). These values are most important due to the fact that the overall power of the eye is essentially dependent on corneal curvature and the lens, with the location of the retina as the image plane. 

Other measurements are often made with newer technological advances to better calculate the power of the intraocular lens. These include the anterior chamber depth and corneal white-to-white diameter.

questions.question: Your 63-year-old patient with bilateral 3+ nuclear sclerosis of the lenses does not wish to undergo cataract surgery at this time. His ocular health exam is otherwise unremarkable. He wants to know what is the GREATEST risk of delaying cataract surgery for a few years?
options: Retinal damage causing decreased visual acuity
Hardening of the lenticular nucleus potentially increasing the difficulty of cataract extraction
Bilateral amblyopia secondary to a sustained blurring of the retinal image
Nerve damage attributable to limited retinal illumination
answers: Hardening of the lenticular nucleus potentially increasing the difficulty of cataract extraction
questions.explanation: The desire to delay cataract surgery is a common occurrence. Ultimately, if the patient is asymptomatic, visual acuity remains fairly good, and their activities of daily living are not affected, the patient may choose to postpone surgery. The potential complications of delaying surgery must be discussed with the patient before reaching a decision. A 'soft' cataract is easier to remove than a 'hard' cataract. The longer a cataract is left in the eye, the harder the lens will become, making it more difficult to break apart and separate from the posterior capsular bag. Additionally, a younger patient will heal faster and more readily than a person who is of advanced age. A cataract does not cause damage to retinal structures or the optic nerve, nor can it cause amblyopia in this patient, as he is no longer considered to be in the critical period of development.

questions.question: Upon examining your patient, you notice that her eyelids do not close completely during blinking. What is the name of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Incomplete closure of the eyelids is known as lagophthalmos. Complete closure of the lids is imperative in maintaining a proper tear film and promoting an adequately moist environment for the corneal surface. Additionally, the resurfacing of tears during blinking flushes away possible irritants, bacteria, and foreign bodies. If this process is impaired by incomplete closure of the lids, the eye can suffer from drying, infections, and ulceration. 

Some patients may experience this condition at night while sleeping; this is known as nocturnal lagophthalmos. Typically, when lids are closed during sleep, Bell's phenomenon occurs (eyes roll back), which protects the surface of the cornea; however, if Bell's phenomenon is poor, these patients may also experience symptoms of exposure keratopathy.

questions.question: An elderly patient is seen at your office for a follow-up visit. She was diagnosed with iritis 1 week ago and is currently being managed with Pred Forte® topical eye drops every 2 hours. She reports no change in her symptomology and is still very photophobic, and her eye still bothers her. Slit lamp evaluation reveals no change in her clinical signs. Which of the following conditions may be the underlying cause of a non-responsive iritis?
questions.explanation:
Patients, especially the elderly, may exhibit a non-responsive iritis, which is caused by an intraocular tumor, leukemia, metastatic cancer, or non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Therefore, if a patient is being treated for iritis and the condition is not responding to conventional topical therapeutic treatment, further evaluation is warranted. 

Patients with iritis, also known as anterior uveitis, typically will report photophobia, excessive lacrimation, pain, and diminished visual acuity. This condition is caused by either inflammation of the iris or of both the iris and the anterior portion of the ciliary body (iridocyclitis). Clinical signs include: keratic precipitates (which are variable in size and distribution, depending upon the etiology of the iritis) deposited on the corneal endothelium, cells and flare (protein that has leaked from iris vessels into the anterior chamber), sluggish and slightly constricted pupils caused by swelling of the uveal tract, irregular pupil margins (if posterior synechiae are present), and in the event of granulomatous inflammation, iris nodules. An acute episode of anterior uveitis or chronic uveitis may cause the formation of posterior synechiae. Cells may also be present in the vitreal chamber; however, the number of cells in the anterior chamber should exceed the number seen in the vitreous cavity. Treatment of iritis includes a cycloplegic agent to help prevent formation or promote breakdown of synechiae. A cycloplegic also aids in pain management by controlling pupil size and avoiding unnecessary movement of the iris muscles, which can be very painful with this inflammatory condition. UV protection (tinted lenses) is also helpful in management of the associated photophobia. A topical steroid is prescribed to reduce the inflammatory response. It is very important to slowly taper the use of the steroid; otherwise there is a risk of rebound inflammation. 

Although rheumatoid arthritis, Behcet's syndrome, and tuberculosis can lead to the development of an iritis, this associated iritis can typically be managed via traditional methods such as topical steroid and cycloplegic drops. 

Review of Optometry. Vol 3 Number 38, July 8, 2013.

questions.question: Visible vessel dilation seen in episcleritis (or deeper involvement known as scleritis) may produce discomfort and is associated with which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation: There is a well-established association between scleritis and rheumatoid arthritis. A patient with rheumatoid disease may present with a painful red eye and complaints of a deep aching feeling. Behcet's syndrome and ankylosing spondylitis are both associated with iritis or uveitis but generally do not affect the episclera or sclera. Scleroderma is a disease that may be recognized by loss of the ability to smile and the presence of linear wrinkles around the lips, but it does not produce inflammatory changes in the eye.

questions.question: A 43-year old woman is seen at your office concerned about the fact that she constantly seems to have styes on her eyelids and her eyes are continually red and irritated. Biomicroscopy reveals meibomitis and blepharitis along with lid telangiectasia and a TBUT of 4 seconds for each eye. She also reports that her cheeks, nose, forehead and chin are easily flushed, especially when exposed to heat or cool temperatures. Given the above findings, what is your tentative diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Rosacea is a condition that causes excessive blushing of the face, with or without ocular involvement. Rhinophyma (a large, bulbous, red nose) is common in rosacea. Patients will often complain of facial flushing that is exacerbated with extreme temperature exposure, exertion, or the ingestion of hot beverages. This condition is seen two times more frequently in women. Ocular implications commonly include blepharitis, meibomitis, telangiectasia, dry eye syndrome, and occasional corneal involvement such as superficial punctate keratitis, pannus, and neovascularization. Treatment of facial rosacea includes oral tetracycline, topical metronidazole and retinoid compounds. Ocular rosacea is best treated by managing concomitant lid diseases along with artificial tears. While a hordeola and dry eye syndrome do occur in rosacea, these should not be your primary diagnoses. Remember to look at the overall broad picture and not just the pair of eyeballs. 

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disorder that has the capability of affecting many areas of the body. A common finding of SLE is called the malar (or butterfly) rash that is seen in roughly half of the individuals affected by this disorder. This rash generally occurs on the cheeks and over the nose bridge and worsens with ultraviolet light exposure. Concurrent eye conditions with SLE are primarily secondary to complications from the medications used to manage the condition such as oral corticosteroids and anti-malarials.

questions.question: Your patient with a history of thyrotoxicosis presents with retraction of the upper eyelids, whereby the sclera is visible above the superior cornea in primary gaze. This 'staring' appearance is known as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
- Dalrymple sign: Lid retraction in primary gaze 
- Kocher sign: Rotation of the globe lags behind the movement of the upper eyelid on upward gaze 
- Von Graefe's sign: Upper eyelid lag on down-gaze 
- Stellwag's sign: Infrequent or incomplete blinking 
- Boston's sign: Spasmodic lower of the upper eyelid on downgaze 
- Rosenbach's sign: Tremor of the eyelids when closed

questions.question: Proteins from which of the following structures have the least turnover?
questions.explanation:
Lens proteins have the lowest turnover rate of all proteins in the body. Most lens cells are incapable of synthesizing new proteins so generally most lens proteins must last for an entire lifetime. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 p 88

questions.question: Which of the following regions of the sclera is the weakest and most likely to cup outward when there is increased intraocular pressure (i.e. glaucoma)?
questions.explanation:
The lamina cribrosa is the posterior scleral foramen through which the optic nerve passes. It is a sieve-like structure with interwoven collagen fibrils forming canals allowing optic nerve fibers to pass. It is the weakest area of the outer connective tissue tunic which is why cupping out or ectasia may be seen as a sign of increased intraocular pressure. The scleral spur is a region of circularly oriented collagen bundles which serves as the origin of the longitudinal ciliary muscle fibers. The limbus is the band located at the junction of the cornea and sclera. Here, there is a transition from squamous corneal epithelium to columnar conjunctival epithelium, as well as a transition from the very regular corneal stroma to the irregular scleral stroma, and the termination of Bowman's layer, Descemet's membrane and the corneal endothelium. The palisades of Vogt are radial projections of the limbal epithelium that extend into the cornea; it is an area where corneal epithelial stem cells reside. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 23-26

questions.question: What is the MOST frequently encountered type of anterior scleritis?
questions.explanation:
Scleritis is an inflammation of the sclera that generally occurs secondarily to a systemic condition, usually of collagen vascular origin. Diffuse scleritis has a gradual onset and presents as a boring pain which may radiate to other structures such as the jaw and forehead. Patients will present with distension of the scleral vascular pattern, causing a deep pinkish hue of the sclera. Nodular scleritis appears similar to diffuse scleritis, but the areas of inflammation are localized to painful, raised nodules. Scleromalacia perforans is the least common form and is almost always seen in association with rheumatoid arthritis. Patients with scleromalacia perforans generally do not experience pain or inflammation. Necrotizing scleritis is the most severe form and has a higher mortality rate than the other types due to the fact that it usually stems from autoimmune diseases. 

References: Schwartz, G. Around the eye in 365 days (2009) page 314. 

Pavan-Langston, D. Manual of Ocular Diagnosis and Therapy, 6th edition (2008) pp 133-136.
PowerPage
Scleritis

questions.question: Which 4 of the following are functions of the eyelids? (Select 4)
options: Primary refractive component of the eye
questions.explanation: The tarsals serve many functions. The eyelids protect against damage from foreign objects (as do the eyelashes). Eyelids also help to maintain a moist environment for the cornea enabling a regular surface and better optics. In addition to reducing visual stimuli (we can only process so much at one time), eyelids aid in corneal metabolism. Blinking helps to redistribute tears, allowing for diffusion of oxygen into the cornea and removing wastes, like carbon dioxide. The palpebrae are NOT the primary refractive component of the eyes; this role is assigned to the cornea, nor do they secrete lysozymes. Lysozymes are found in the tear film and help to protect the eye as they possess antibacterial properties.

questions.question: Which of the following types of entropion is NOT considered a good surgical candidate?
questions.explanation:
Spastic entropion results from over stimulation of the palpebral segment of the orbicularis and is generally caused by blepharospasm due to inflammation, irritation, or injury. This type of entropion cannot be repaired via surgery. It does, however, respond well to Botox injections. 

Congenital entropion generally arises from a malformation of the tarsal plate and is well managed with surgery. 

Atonic, involutional, and senile entropion are synonymous and are caused by an increased lid laxity and a decreased tonus of the lid (usually the lower lid). This type of entropion is seen in the elderly and responds very well to surgery.

questions.question: The arterial supply of the anterior segment of the eye originates from which 2 of the following sources? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
The arterial blood supply to the anterior segment of the eye comes from the anterior ciliary arteries (ACAs), as well as the terminal branches of the long posterior ciliary arteries (LPCAs). 

The LPCAs arise from branches of the ophthalmic artery. They pierce the posterior aspect of the sclera and run anteriorly along either side of the eye, between the sclera and the choroid. The ACAs are derived from branches of the ophthalmic artery and run anteriorly with the extraocular muscles. They pierce the sclera near the area of the cornea. The LPCAs and ACAs together form two sagittal arterial circles and two coronal arterial circles, called the episcleral arterial circle superficially and the greater circle of the iris deeply. The physiology of the arterial flow in this region ensures that the anterior segment of the eye is always supplied with an adequate supply of blood. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye. (11th edition). 2011. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.F.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: Which muscle group of the ciliary muscle originates at the ciliary tendon and inserts into the suprachoroid forming muscle stars?
questions.explanation: All of the three muscle groups, the longitudinal, radial and circular originate from the ciliary tendon but only the longitudinal muscle terminates at the suprachoroid. The radial muscles terminate onto the ciliary processes. Lastly, the circular muscles also insert onto the ciliary processes but they terminate onto the anterior ends of the processes. Skeletal muscle is not found in the ciliary muscle.

questions.question: The ciliary muscle of the ciliary body is composed of which type of muscle?
questions.explanation: The ciliary muscle is composed of smooth muscle and is controlled by the autonomic nervous system. Smooth muscle cells are long and spindle-shaped containing only one nucleus per cell. Skeletal muscle cells (sometimes known as striated muscle) are long cells that are multi-nucleated. Columnar muscle does not exist.

questions.question: Which of the following skin conditions is considered to be benign and has the LOWEST risk of malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Keratoacanthoma appears very much like squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in that it tends to progress rapidly and appears to ulcerate. This condition typically occurs in middle-aged and elderly patients of Caucasian descent on areas of the skin that are exposed. The lesion appears elevated, and eventually the center will produce a scab-like plug of keratin. The margins surrounding the plug will be rolled. At some point the keratin plug will fall out, resulting in the formation of a pit, and the lesion will regress. Most patients and clinicians do not like to wait this condition out due to its similarities to SCC. 

Actinic keratosis is a pre-cursor to squamous cell carcinoma and appears as scaly, dry skin that does not heal. People with skin that is of lighter pigmentation along with excessive exposure to ultraviolet light tend to be most at risk for development of this condition. 

Squamous cell carcinoma (SSC) is thankfully one of the rarest malignancies but due to its ability to metastasize can be quite dangerous. This malignancy has the ability to progress rapidly and has a high affinity for people who spend a lot of time in the sun, especially those who are light-skinned. The only way to definitively diagnose SCC is to refer for a biopsy and ensuring the use of Mohs technique. This strategy takes more time but ensures that the lesion is removed. Essentially, Mohs procedure calls for removal of tissue and biopsy of the surrounding borders. If the borders prove to be malignant then more tissue is removed and biopsied. This continues until the borders prove to be free of any carcinoma. 

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common malignant lid lesion and mercifully tends to be very slow-growing. BCC generally appears as a waxy, translucent nodule. Eventually the nodule will ulcerate. Patients may bring these to your attention and tell you that they have 'had it for years and it just does not seem to heal'. Whenever you hear this it is best to send out for biopsy via Mohs technique. BCC very rarely metastasizes.

questions.question: Your 67 year-old Asian female patient returns to your office for the third time in the past year with a bump in the same location on her left upper eyelid. You had previously diagnosed her with a chalazion; however, due to its recurrent nature, you send her out for a tissue biopsy. Which of the following eyelid lesion are you MOST concerned about?
questions.explanation:
Sebaceous cell carcinoma of the eyelid often masquerades as a recurrent chalazion; therefore, it is very important to send patients out for tissue biopsies in cases of recurrent lesions. It is also for this reason that sebaceous cell carcinomas are one of the most dangerous eyelid tumors because correct diagnosis tends to be delayed until the tumor has metastasized. 

This type of tumor is more common in Asian populations as compared to other races. In most cases, female patients outnumber males, and the mean age at diagnosis is in the mid-60s. Sebaceous cell carcinoma also tends to show a predilection for the upper eyelid (unlike basal cell carcinoma). It typically presents as a focal mass (pseudochalazion), but can also appear as a multi-centric tumor, or a diffuse lesion. It also does not usually ulcerate, as do basal and squamous cell carcinomatous lesions.

questions.question: A 34 year-old patient presents to your office with a chief complaint of redness and irritation of his eyelids and his eyelashes occasionally sticking together. Upon biomicroscopy, you notice hyperemic and greasy eyelid margins, and soft scales scattered along the eyelid margins and eyelashes. What is the MOST likely diagnosis of this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Seborrheic blepharitis 
- Soft scales are present and located along the eyelid margin and eyelashes 
- Anterior lid margins appear greasy and hyperemic 
- Eyelashes commonly stick together 

Staphylococcal blepharitis 
- Scales and crusts are typically harder and are mainly located around the base of the eyelashes (collarettes) 
- Eyelid changes usually occur in conjunction with chronic staph blepharitis, such as scarring and notching, madarosis, trichiasis, and poliosis 
- Conjunctival hyperemia, papillary conjunctivitis, stye formation, marginal keratitis, phlyctenulosis, tear film instability, and dry eye are also commonly associated with staphylococcus blepharitis 

Angular blepharitis 
- Involves the lateral portion of the eyelid 
- Signs include scaly, red, and macerated skin, with occasional associated papillary and follicular conjunctivitis 

Meibomian gland dysfunction 
- Capping of meibomian gland orifices with hyperemia and telangiectasia of the eyelid margin 
- Tear film is usually oily and froth is commonly observed on the eyelid margin 
- Pressure on the lid margin will usually result in turbid secretions, and in some cases inspissation is so severe that expression of glands is impossible 

Bacterial conjunctivitis commonly presents with symptoms of debris on the lashes and eyelashes sticking together; however, signs of mucous and conjunctival hyperemia are usually present.

questions.question: Impetigo is a superficial skin infection that can be caused by which 2 of the following pathogens? (Select 2)
questions.explanation: Impetigo is one of the most common skin infections occurring in children. It is a contagious condition that is caused by one of two bacteria: either Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. Impetigo presents as erythematous macules, which develop into painful blisters or sores on the face, neck, hands, and diaper area. Treatment is typically with topical and/or oral antibiotics.

questions.question: Reflexive blinking is caused primarily by which of the following actions?
options: Stimulation of Mueller's muscle and inhibition of the levator palpebrae superioris
Inhibition of Mueller's muscle and stimulation of the levator palpebrae superioris
Inhibition of the orbicularis and stimulation of the levator palpebrae superioris
Stimulation of the orbicularis and inhibition of the levator palpebrae superioris
answers: Stimulation of the orbicularis and inhibition of the levator palpebrae superioris
questions.explanation: Reflexive blinking has many etiologies all of which result in stimulation of different pathways, but all of the pathways have one common outcome:closure of the eyelids via stimulation of the orbicularis and inhibition of the levator palpebrae superioris.

questions.question: Weakness of which of the following extraocular muscles is MOST commonly associated with a simple congenital eyelid ptosis?
questions.explanation: Weakness of the superior rectus muscle is the most common ocular motility abnormality associated with a simple congenital ptosis. This is due to the close embryological association of the levator and the superior rectus; these two muscles develop from the same myotome. Keep in mind that extraocular muscle surgery must be performed prior to ptosis correction due to the associated lid position changes that will occur once the eye position is adjusted.

questions.question: Age-related cortical cataracts are MOST commonly initially found in which quadrant of the crystalline lens?
questions.explanation:
Cortical cataracts of the crystalline lens occur as a result of opacification of the mature fiber cells that lie close to the surface of the lens. They typically begin as small opacities of the lens periphery that may eventually spread around the circumference of the lens as age increases. These opacities can also extend centrally as well, potentially impinging on the visual axis and interfering with vision. Early stages of cortical cataracts most often occur in the inferior half of the lens periphery, with a predilection for the inferior-nasal quadrant specifically. Cortical lens opacities are best viewed with retroillumination through a dilated pupil on slit-lamp biomicroscopy. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye. (11th edition). 2011. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.F.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: Iris colobomas form due to incomplete closure of the choroidal fissure. This usually results in a keyhole-shaped defect in which region of the iris?
questions.explanation:
An iris coloboma is an inferonasal, keyhole-shaped defect. The remainder of the iris is normal. Atypical colobomas may develop at sites other than the inferonasal area.
