Ref: Trachimowicz, R. Review of Embryology and its Relation to Ocular Disease in the Pediatric Population. Optometry and Vision Science. 71:3 pp 154-163
PowerPage
Iris Coloboma

questions.question: A 56 year-old male patient reports that his vision constantly fluctuates with his current glasses prescription. Case history reveals poorly controlled diabetes mellitus with large variations in blood glucose levels. Which of the following diabetic related ocular changes is MOST likely responsible for his chief complaint?
options: Swelling of the cornea, leading to changes in refractive error
Edema of the retina, leading to a decrease in visual acuity
Elevated glucose levels, leading to cloudiness of the vitreous
Swelling of the crystalline lens, leading to changes in its refractive index
answers: Swelling of the crystalline lens, leading to changes in its refractive index
questions.explanation: In addition to causing cataracts, patients with diabetes mellitus can experience changes in the crystalline lens, which results in an alteration of its refractive index as well as its amplitude of accommodation. Elevated blood glucose levels cause an increase in the concentration of glucose present in the aqueous humor, which can then diffuse into the crystalline lens. In the lens, glucose is metabolized to sorbitol (by aldose reductase), which subsequently accumulates within the lens. This leads to an influx of water into the lens from an osmotic imbalance, causing overhydration of the lens substance, which alters the refractive index of the crystalline lens. Therefore, with patients in whom there is a continuous large fluctuation in blood glucose levels, the lens also constantly changes in response to glycemic level changes, resulting in a variation in the refractive error. Patients will complain that the glasses Rx seems to be incorrect or that their vision constantly changes; this is most commonly due to these lens changes. Most doctors defer prescribing glasses until the patient can maintain a more consistent glycemic value.

questions.question: Which of the following terms correctly describes an elongated eyelid resulting in lateral poor globe apposition and causing a local area of exposure?
questions.explanation:
Euryblepharon is the result of an enlarged horizontal palpebral fissure that causes partial lateral ectropion or poor lateral apposition of the eyelid to the globe. This finding may occur in conjunction with strabismus, a double row of meibomian glands, or telecanthus. Severe cases of euryblepharon may result in exposure keratopathy. 

Symblepharon is a partial or complete adhesion between the palpebral conjunctiva of the eyelid (usually the lower lid) to the bulbar conjunctiva of the globe. 

Ankyloblepharon refers to partial adhesion of the eyelids to each other or complete fusion occurring secondary to injury, infection (Trachoma), or tarsorrhaphy. Ankyloblepharon causes a reduction of the palpebral aperture. This condition can also be congenital, in which case the condition is known as ankyloblepharon filiforme adenatum. 

Blepharophimosis describes a condition in which the lateral and medial canthi are fused together, resulting in a narrowing of the palpebral fissure. This condition typically occurs in conjunction with telecanthus (enlarged distance between the two orbits) and epicanthus inversus (prominent nasal semilunar fold). 

Reference: 
Arch Ophthalmol. 2004;122(7):1075-1077. doi:10.1001/archopht.122.7.1075. 
http://archopht.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=416398

questions.question: While several tests such as tear stability and ocular surface staining are global tests diagnostic for the presence of dry eye, what is a specific test that can differentiate aqueous tear deficiency from meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD)?
options: Tear clearance, which is normal in MGD
A detailed dry eye questionnaire to allow for score-based symptomology
Meibomian gland atrophy/dropout as measured by meiboscopy
The Schirmer I test, which is considered abnormal if the strip wetting is less than 10 mm in 5 minutes without anesthesia
Conjunctival staining by lissamine green, which is worse in MGD
answers: The Schirmer I test, which is considered abnormal if the strip wetting is less than 10 mm in 5 minutes without anesthesia
questions.explanation: Whether aqueous tear production is normal or not can be determined using the cotton thread tear test or the Schirmer I test without anesthesia. The Schirmer I without anesthesia essentially becomes a stress test since it is so irritating; if the patient cannot produce aqueous tears under irritating conditions, the main lacrimal gland is probably compromised. Conversely, meibomian gland dropout can be observed in both aqueous tear deficiency and MGD, possibly due to inflammatory processes on the ocular surface.

questions.question: The presence of foam at the canthus is thought to be pathognomonic for blepharitis. What is the direct etiology of the foam?
options: Tear film debris such as sloughed epithelial cellular material that is increased in dry eye
Bacterial lipases resulting from low-grade infection within the meibomian glands
Increased lysozymes react with free radicals to produce a froth-like material
Mucin balls form from increased ocular surface shear forces exerted by the eyelids in dry eye
A detergent effect from altered meibomian gland lipids
answers: A detergent effect from altered meibomian gland lipids
questions.explanation: The foam is considered to be caused by an alteration in the chemical composition of the meibomian lipids through a process termed saponification. Upon contact of these abnormal lipids with the calcium located in the tear film, a frothy tear film develops. Foam at the canthi is mentioned as a key diagnostic sign of MGD in most literature on the topic.

questions.question: An outward outpouching (eversion) of the eyelid margin such that the lid margin comes away from the globe is known as which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
Ectropion means an eversion of the eyelid margin. When the lid margin is no longer in contact with the globe, this can lead to poor tear drainage and overflow (epiphora). Ectropion most commonly occurs due to loss of muscle tone with aging. Entropion is an inversion of the lid margin that can place the eyelashes in contact with the globe and lead to abrasion. Entropion can occur from spasm of the orbicularis oculi muscle or from scarring of the eyelid. Both entropion and ectropion occur more commonly in the lower eyelid than the upper eyelid. Telecanthus is a term that describes increased distance between the eyelids at the medial canthus. Epicanthus is a synonym for the orbital fold or Mongolian fold of the eyelid. Madarosis is a term that describes loss of the eyelashes (ciliary madarosis) or the eyebrows (superciliary madarosis). 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 137-143

questions.question: Biomicroscopic examination reveals neovascular changes on the iris surface, which is a finding known as Rubeosis iridis. Which of the following 3 conditions are associated with this finding? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: Though a vascular disease, temporal arteritis does not cause ischemia to the iris and therefore it does not result in neovascularization. Diabetes, in association with retinopathy, is the most common cause. Rubeosis iridis also occurs as a result of central retinal venous thrombosis and has been reported with chronic retinal detachments as well. The most devastating ocular consequence is contracture of the vessels, causing acute angle closure glaucoma.

questions.question: Which layer of the iris primarily determines the perceived color of the iris?
questions.explanation: The anterior limiting layer is primarily responsible for perceived iris color. A thin anterior limiting layer contains less pigment and thus will appear blue or green because the stroma absorbs longer wavelengths and the shorter wavelengths will be reflected. A thicker layer will result in greater pigmentation leading to less absorption of longer wavelengths subsequently causing the perception of a brown iris.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following sentences are TRUE regarding the crystalline lens? (Select 2)
options: The clarity of the crystalline lens is attributable to high molecular weight aggregates that are not water-soluble
Increased levels of glutathione have been linked with cataract formation
The development of cataracts is attributable to the formation of disulfide bonds secondary to oxidative damage
The crystalline lens is formed of amino acids joined by peptide bonds arranged in multiple anti-parallel beta sheets
answers: The development of cataracts is attributable to the formation of disulfide bonds secondary to oxidative damage
The crystalline lens is formed of amino acids joined by peptide bonds arranged in multiple anti-parallel beta sheets
questions.explanation:
The crystalline lens is composed of proteins arranged in anti-parallel beta sheets. Crystallin protein is highly water-soluble and is the primary protein located within the lens. Crystallin is important in lens clarity. Oxidative damage, such as that from UV light, causes the formation of sulfide bonds between methionine groups and cysteine side chains (both of these amino acids contain sulfur). The sulfide bonds cause high molecular weight aggregates that precipitate as they lose their water solubility. The precipitates are opaque, causing reduced lens clarity. Glutathione is a powerful reductant produced by the body. It is implicated in the protection against oxidative damage by free radicals. Glutathione breaks the disulfide bonds, restoring proper protein configuration.
PowerPage
Crystalline Lens

questions.question: Which structure of the eye is isolated from the immune system and as such can be classified as antigenic?
questions.explanation: The only structure of the eye that is isolated from the immune system is the lens. This is due to the fact that the lens is completely avascular and derives all of its nutritional needs from the aqueous humor. Because the lens is contained within a capsule, the body is never exposed to its protein contents and therefore if the proteins do become exposed, such as in a hypermature cataract or a dropped nucleus during cataract surgery, the body surmounts an immune reaction because it will not recognize the proteins.

questions.question: Upon dissection, the trabecular meshwork appears like a triangle whose apex points towards which structure?
questions.explanation: The trabecular meshwork is triangular in shape with the base of the triangle abutting the scleral spur. The apex of the trabecular meshwork points towards the cornea, and its anterior surface points towards the ciliary body. This is in opposition to the ciliary body whose apex points posteriorly towards the ora serrata.

questions.question: The trabecular meshwork can be divided into three components. What is the correct order of these components from most internal to most external?
options: The corneoscleral meshwork, juxtacanalicular tissue, and the uveal meshwork
The juxtacanalicular tissue, corneoscleral meshwork, and the uveal meshwork
The uveal meshwork, corneoscleral meshwork, and the juxtacanalicular tissue
The corneoscleral meshwork, uveal meshwork, and the juxtacanalicular tissue
The uveal meshwork, juxtacanalicular tissue, and the corneoscleral meshwork
answers: The uveal meshwork, corneoscleral meshwork, and the juxtacanalicular tissue
questions.explanation: The trabecular meshwork is important for aqueous drainage. The correct exit route of aqueous from most internal to the most external structure is the uveal meshwork, the corneoscleral meshwork followed by the juxtacanalicular tissue. A blockage at any of these locations will cause in increase in intraocular pressure which can lead to glaucoma.

questions.question: Which of the following ocular structures absorbs the most amount of UV C, ensuring minimal retinal exposure?
questions.explanation: The cornea absorbs the majority of UV C when the eye is exposed to this very short wavelength of light. Because UV C is a short wavelength, it is also very high energy and therefore prolonged exposure can lead to solar keratitis. The crystalline lens absorbs the majority of UV A and UV B, protecting the retina from potential UV damage. However, over time, the lens may become impaired and result in the formation of a cataract. For the above reasons, it is essential to always recommend good UV protection for your patients. It is also noteworthy that although longer wavelengths tend be less damaging, over exposure to near-infrared wavelengths can result in a 'glass blower's cataract'.

questions.question: Which of the following features is present in the crystalline lens in order to offset the occurrence of spherical aberration that would otherwise naturally appear in this refracting element?
options: The curvature of the crystalline lens is steeper in the periphery as compared to the curvature of the lens in its center
A larger pupil size reduces spherical aberration inherent in the crystalline lens
The radius of curvature of the anterior surface of the crystalline lens is shorter than the radius of curvature of the posterior surface
The crystalline lens has a lower index of refraction near its edge as compared the index of refraction at its center
answers: The crystalline lens has a lower index of refraction near its edge as compared the index of refraction at its center
questions.explanation: Spherical aberration occurs when parallel light rays that are incident on an optical refracting element towards the edge of the lens are bent more than those light rays that travel through the system closer to the center of the lens. This creates a smeared focal point because the peripheral light rays focus at a point in front of the main image. There are a few ways in which the human eye tries to offset this type of aberration. With respect to the cornea, this surface is an aspherical optical element, in which the periphery of the cornea is flatter than the center of the cornea, thereby weakening the focusing power of the peripheral cornea in an attempt to reduce the amount of spherical aberration present. The crystalline lens is also vulnerable to spherical aberration; however, this refracting component has taken a different approach to control the aberration. Instead of relying on just the varying the curvature of its surface, the lens also varies its index of refraction. The index of refraction of the edge of the lens is lower (and therefore less powerful) than the index of refraction at its center. This is the lens's way of attempting to self-correct spherical aberration inherent within itself. A smaller pupil size is another way that the eye acts to reduce the spherical aberration intrinsic in the crystalline lens.

questions.question: Ultimately the majority of aqueous is drained away from the eye by which structure?
questions.explanation:
Essentially, the aqueous humor travels through the trabecular meshwork into Schlemm's canal. From there, it drains through efferent collector channels which may anastomose to form the deep scleral plexus eventually draining to the episcleral venous plexus or it may drain from the collector channels directly into the episcleral venous plexus. 

Another possible aqueous drainage pathway is uveoscleral outflow. This conduit does not actually possess any identifiable channels or vessels. Instead, aqueous seeps through the ciliary body and its surrounding tissues like the sclera, eventually draining into the choroidal vessels and as some studies indicate also the lymphatic system.

questions.question: Berger's space is created by an interval between which two structures?
options: The equator of the lens and the ciliary body
The anterior face of the lens and the posterior surface of the iris
The posterior surface of the cornea and the anterior face of the iris
The posterior face of the lens and the anterior vitreous
answers: The posterior face of the lens and the anterior vitreous
questions.explanation:
Berger's space is created by the separation between the posterior face of the lens and the anterior face of the vitreous. 

The space between the equator of the lens and the ciliary body is known as the circumlental space.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following occur during accommodation? (Select 2)
options: The equatorial circumference of the lens decreases
The depth of the anterior chamber increases
The posterior surface of the lens changes position
answers: The equatorial circumference of the lens decreases
questions.explanation: During the process of accommodation, the anterior surface of the lens moves forward while the posterior surface remains stationary. This forward movement decreases the anterior chamber depth. The change in anterior depth causes a change in the outflow resistance, resulting in a transitory decrease in intraocular pressure. Lastly, because the lens becomes more spherical, the equatorial circumference of the lens decreases.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the autonomic innervation of the iris muscles?
options: The iris sphincter is innervated sympathetically and the iris dilator is innervated parasympathetically
The iris sphincter and iris dilator are both innervated parasympathetically
The iris sphincter and iris dilator are both innervated sympathetically
The iris sphincter is innervated parasympathetically and the iris dilator is innervated sympathetically
answers: The iris sphincter is innervated parasympathetically and the iris dilator is innervated sympathetically
questions.explanation:
Stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system results in pupil dilation and the parasympathetic nervous system pupil constriction. Accordingly, the sphincter muscle (which constricts the pupil) is innervated by the parasympathetic nervous system and the dilator muscle (which dilates the pupil) is innervated by the sympathetic nervous system. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 p 44

questions.question: Contraction of the ciliary muscle leads to which of the following?
options: The lens becomes more oblong and loses refractive power, bringing near objects into focus
The lens becomes more spherical and increases refractive power, bringing near objects into focus
The lens becomes more spherical and increases refractive power, bringing distant objects into focus
The lens becomes more oblong and increases refractive power, bringing near objects into focus
The lens becomes more oblong and loses refractive power, bringing distant objects into focus
answers: The lens becomes more spherical and increases refractive power, bringing near objects into focus
questions.explanation:
Contraction of the ciliary muscle decreases the diameter of the ring formed by the ciliary body. This releases tension on zonule fibers and allows the lens capsule to become more spherical. The anterior surface curve increases and the lens becomes thicker. This increases refractive power (a.k.a. accommodation) and brings near objects into focus on the retina. Another school of thought believes that ciliary body contraction causes an increase in the vitreal mass which causes the vitreous to push the lens forward allowing for clearer near acuity. When the ciliary muscle relaxes, the eye is considered at rest for distant vision. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 p 44-45

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the lens epithelium?
options: The lens epithelium is composed of a single layer of cuboidal epithelium located beneath the anterior lens capsule
The lens epithelium is composed of a double layer of squamous epithelium located beneath the anterior lens capsule
The lens epithelium is composed of a single layer of cuboidal epithelium located beneath the anterior and posterior lens capsule
The lens epithelium is composed of a single layer of squamous epithelium located beneath the posterior lens capsule
The lens epithelium is composed of a double layer of squamous epithelium located beneath the anterior and posterior lens capsule
answers: The lens epithelium is composed of a single layer of cuboidal epithelium located beneath the anterior lens capsule
questions.explanation:
The lens epithelium is only found beneath the anterior lens capsule. It consists of a single layer of cuboidal epithelium; each cell contains a nucleus, mitochondria, ribosomes, Golgi bodies, polysomes, and endoplasmic reticula. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 81-83

questions.question: The human lens grows throughout life. Which portion of the lens is responsible for this continued growth?
questions.explanation:
The anterior epithelium is responsible for all lens growth. This layer is a single cell thick and is located beneath the capsule of the anterior portion of the lens. The anterior epithelium is divided into three different zones based upon mitotic activity and metabolic needs: central, intermediate and equatorial. The cells in the central portion of the lens are cuboidal in shape and possess a slow mitotic rate. Moving towards the equator, the cells begin to elongate and increase their mitotic activity. The cells at the equatorial zone have the highest mitotic rate and are the most elongated. As the cells move inferiorly, they begin to lose their nuclei while they elongate and become lens fibers. The lens fibers are produced all throughout life, with the older fibers being pushed towards the center of the lens. 

The lens capsule is essentially a clear bag that contains the lens. The capsule is produced by the anterior epithelium and the superficial fiber cells of the posterior lens. 

The lens nucleus is divided into several sections. The center of the lens is known as the embryonic nucleus and can be seen as a sutureless round ball of lens fibers. This is surrounded by the fetal nucleus which is demarcated by two Y sutures, one of which is inverted posteriorly. The outermost layer is comprised of the adult nucleus which grows throughout life. The adult nucleus is surrounded by the cortex.

questions.question: Which cranial nerves are responsible for opening and closing the eye?
options: The oculomotor nerve (CN III) opens the eye and the facial nerve (CN VII) closes the eye
The facial nerve (CN VII) opens the eye and the trigeminal nerve (CN V) closes the eye
The trigeminal nerve (CN V) opens the eye and the facial nerve (CN VII) closes the eye
The oculomotor nerve (CN III) opens the eye and the trigeminal nerve (CN V) closes the eye
answers: The oculomotor nerve (CN III) opens the eye and the facial nerve (CN VII) closes the eye
questions.explanation:
All of the cranial nerves listed have names and numbers correctly matched. The oculomotor nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris (which opens the eye), along with Mueller's muscle (which is controlled by the sympathetic nervous system). The facial nerve innervates the muscles of facial expression including the orbicularis oculi, which closes the eye. The trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the eyelids and cornea. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 137-143

questions.question: Where is the thickest portion of the iris?
questions.explanation: The anterior surface of the iris is divided into two main zones; the central pupillary and the peripheral ciliary zones. The central pupillary zone is located just next to the pupillary ruff. The collarette lays adjacent to the central pupillary zone and serves as a junction between the central pupillary zone and the peripheral ciliary zone. The collarette typically has a distinctive zigzag appearance to its edges. The collarette is roughly 0.6 mm thick. The iris ruff surrounds the pupil edge and appears as a dark, scalloped border. The pupillary ruff is the visible portion of the posterior pigmented epithelium.

questions.question: When evaluating a nevus of the eyelid, which of the following characteristics is indicative of stability (i.e., benign)?
options: The presence of inactive hair follicles within the lesion
Uniformity of color within the lesion
answers: Uniformity of color within the lesion
questions.explanation: When evaluating a suspicious nevus of the skin surrounding the eye, it is important to remember your 'ABCDEs'. A=asymmetry, B=borders, C=color, D=diameter, E=evolution. A benign nevus tends to be symmetrical such that one can almost fold it in half and the sides would be evenly matched. The borders of a benign nevus are typically regular and distinct. The uniformity of the color should be assessed, rather than the actual level of pigmentation; evenness of pigmentation indicates stability. In general, the diameter of a benign nevus does not exceed 6 mm; although this is obviously not true all of the time, some small nevi may be malignant, and some large nevi (i.e., greater than 6 mm) can be benign. Lastly, most benign nevi tend to be rather flat (as opposed to elevated) with no change or evolution over time. Generally, hair growing out of the lesion is a positive sign, as this indicates that the hair follicle is intact. A cancerous lesion tends to kill the follicle; in this case, hair will no longer sprout. Remember, nevi should be stable and not change in shape, color, or size. ANY change in the nevus warrants a biopsy. Photo documentation is key when following a nevus or with any suspicious lesion.

questions.question: A common cause of epiphora in infants is caused by a small membrane that covers over which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
It is common for mothers of young infants to note that one eye (or both eyes) of her infant constantly tears in conjunction with the presence of mucopurulent discharge. This epiphora results from a blockage of the nasolacrimal passageway caused by a membrane covering the valve of Hasner. The majority of blockages will self-resolve without intervention (80-90% of infants) within the first 12 months of life. Treatment may include massage of the nasolacrimal sac several times a day in an effort to rupture the membrane. 

Reference: Chern, K. and Wright K., Review Questions in Ophthalmology: A Question and Answer Book (2005) pp 241

questions.question: Dacryoadenitis refers to an inflammation or infection of which of the following ocular structures?
questions.explanation: Dacryoadenitis describes inflammation of the lacrimal gland, generally due to infection. The swelling is categorized as either chronic or acute. Acute presentations appear more commonly as a unilateral swelling of the upper eyelid, along with pain, excessive lacrimation, probable ipsilateral lymphadenopathy, and potential proptosis. If the condition is bilateral it is likely due to a systemic infection. Chronic dacryoadenitis is generally bilateral and presents with hard masses that are palpable at the location of the lacrimal gland. This form is often painless and caused by inflammatory diseases such as Grave's, Sjogren's, or sarcoidosis. The chronic type warrants further investigation in order to rule out a lacrimal gland tumor.

questions.question: The lymphatic system serves many important roles in the human body. The lateral portion of the eyelid lymphatics drain into which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
The lateral 2/3 of the upper lid and the lateral 1/3 of the lower lid lymphatics drain into the pre-auricular lymph node located directly in front of the ear. The medial 1/3 of the upper eye lid and the medial 2/3 of the lower lid lymphatics drain into the submandibular node located just under the jaw-line. Therefore, it is very important to evaluate these two nodes separately, especially when a condition of viral etiology is suspected.
PowerPage
Lymphatic System

questions.question: The blood-aqueous barrier is formed by tight junctions between which cells of the ciliary body?
questions.explanation: The cells of the non-pigmented epithelium have many different attachment sites to each other to ensure that proteins and other macromolecules do not enter. The side walls of the cells are connected via desmosomes. The superior portion of the cell's lateral wall towards the apex are firmly joined by a connection termed zona occludens. The non-pigmented epithelial cells and the epithelial cells are attached to each other by desmosomes and puncta adherens to ensure that the layers are not easily separated.

questions.question: The ligaments that suspend the lens (zonules) are embryonically derived from what structure?
questions.explanation: The zonules are attached to the posterior and anterior surfaces of the lens and connect to the pars plana of the ciliary body. The primary vitreous develops from weeks 3 through 9. The secondary vitreous then begins to form and condenses the primary vitreous forming Cloquet's canal. Developmentally, the tertiary vitreous is secreted last; the zonules are comprised of condensed tertiary vitreous.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the sensory innervation of the eyelids?
options: The upper and lower eyelid both receive their sensory innervation from branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V)
The upper eyelid receives sensory innervation from branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), and the lower eyelid receives sensory innervation from branches of the facial nerve (CN VII)
The upper eyelid receives sensory innervation from branches of the oculomotor nerve (CN III), and the lower eyelid receives sensory innervation from branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V)
The upper and lower eyelid both receive their sensory innervation from branches of the facial nerve (CN VII)
The upper eyelid receives sensory innervation from branches of the oculomotor nerve (CN III), and the lower eyelid receives sensory innervation from branches of the facial nerve (CN VII)
answers: The upper and lower eyelid both receive their sensory innervation from branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V)
questions.explanation:
All sensory innervation of the eyelid comes from branches of the trigeminal nerve. The upper eyelid is supplied by the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve; specifically the supraorbital, supratrochlear, infratrochlear, and lacrimal nerves. The lower eyelid is supplied by the ophthalmic and maxillary branches of the trigeminal nerve; specifically the infratrochlear (ophthalmic branch) and the infraorbital nerves (maxillary branch). 

The facial nerve supplies motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression, including the orbicularis oculi. The oculomotor nerve supplies motor innervation to several of the extraocular muscles and to the superior palpebral levator. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 147-148

questions.question: The superior palpebral sulcus delineates which structures?
options: The upper eyelid and the eyebrow
The tarsal portion of the upper eyelid and the orbital portion of the upper eyelid
The lower eyelid and the cheek
The lacrimal portion of the lower eyelid and the ciliary portion of the lower eyelid
The lacrimal portion of the upper eyelid and the ciliary portion of the upper eyelid
answers: The tarsal portion of the upper eyelid and the orbital portion of the upper eyelid
questions.explanation:
The superior palpebral sulcus is a furrow that separates the tarsal and orbital portions of the upper eyelid. The tarsal portion lies closest to the lid margin and rests on the globe. The tarsal portion contains the tarsal plate and is composed of thin skin and connective tissue. The orbital portion of the eyelid extends to the level of the eyebrow. The lower eyelid has the inferior palpebral sulcus which separates the lower lid into a tarsal and orbital portion but it is not as distinct as the superior palpebral sulcus. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 138-139

questions.question: You are measuring the palpebral fissure height in a patient reporting drooping of his upper eyelid. Which of the following BEST describes the normal positioning of the upper and lower eyelids in comparison to the limbus?
options: The upper lid normally rests about 1mm lower than the upper limbus, and the lower lid rests about 2mm above the lower limbus
The upper lid normally rests about 2mm lower than the upper limbus, and the lower lid rests about 1mm above the lower limbus
The upper lid normally rests about 1mm lower than the upper limbus, and the lower lid rests about 2mm lower than the lower limbus
The upper lid normally rests about 2mm lower than the upper limbus, and the lower lid rests about 1mm lower than the lower limbus
answers: The upper lid normally rests about 2mm lower than the upper limbus, and the lower lid rests about 1mm above the lower limbus
questions.explanation:
The palpebral fissure height is a measurement of the distance between the upper and lower eyelid margins when the patient is looking in primary gaze. This particular measurement is typically less in males (7-10mm) as compared to females (8-12mm). The normal positioning of the upper and lower eyelids are as follows: the upper eyelid usually rests about 2mm below the superior limbus, while the lower eyelid position is typically 1mm above the lower limbus. A unilateral ptosis can be quantified by comparing these measurements to the contralateral eye. A ptosis up to 2mm may be graded as mild; a 3mm ptosis is considered moderate; a ptosis of 4mm or more is deemed severe. 

Another important measurement in evaluating a ptosis is the marginal-reflex distance (MRD). The MRD can be defined as the distance between the upper eyelid margin and the resultant corneal reflection caused by directing a patient's gaze at a penlight held by the examiner. This measurement is normally 4-4.5mm.

questions.question: Which of the following statements MOST accurately applies to the sclera?
options: The weakest locations of the anterior sclera are the just behind the rectus muscle insertion points
Due to its collagen composition, the sclera is thicker than the cornea
The sclera is stronger than the cornea and therefore capable of resisting great pressures
The collagen that comprises the sclera is the most ordered of all the eye structures
answers: The weakest locations of the anterior sclera are the just behind the rectus muscle insertion points
questions.explanation: The collagen fibrils of the sclera are not as organized as those found in the cornea; this explains why the cornea is transparent and the sclera is not. The cornea is stronger than the sclera. The weakest anterior locations of the sclera are the just behind the rectus insertion junctions. The sclera is thinner than the cornea.

questions.question: Your patient reports constant epiphora of the right eye. You wish to determine if there is a blockage of her tear drainage system. You perform lacrimal irrigation. During the procedure, the plunger of the cannula is depressed with great difficulty, and the fluid is regurgitated through the puncta that you are irrigating. What is the CORRECT interpretation of these findings?
options: There is a blockage that is distal to the common caniculus
There is an obstruction of the lacrimal duct of the opposite eye
The passageway is clear; there is no obstruction at this time
There is a blockage that is proximal to the common caniculus
answers: There is a blockage that is proximal to the common caniculus
questions.explanation: Lacrimal irrigation is performed when an obstruction of the tear drainage system is suspected. Dilation of the puncta generally precedes irrigation. Once the puncta is anesthetized and dilated, a cannula is inserted and saline is injected. If the patient reports that they taste saline, or if they cough because of the fluid in their throat, the drainage system is considered open. If the saline is released by the opposite puncta, then there is a blockage located distally to the common caniculus. If the plunger cannot be depressed, or the fluid is expressed by the same puncta that is being irrigated, then the obstruction is proximal to the common caniculus.

questions.question: A 53-year old male complains of pain, irritation, watering, and foreign body sensation of the left eye. Upon slit lamp examination, you notice several eyelashes emanating from the meibomian glands that are turned inward toward the globe. What is this condition known as?
questions.explanation:
Distichiasis is a condition of the eyelids in which eyelashes originating from a position posterior to the normal row of lashes grow inward toward the eye. Typically, these lashes emanate from the meibomian gland orifices and may consist of an entire extra row of cilia, or may be focal with only a few abnormal lashes. Distichiasis may be congenital or can be acquired secondary to chronic eyelid inflammatory conditions, surgery, or when an eyelid tumor is present. There is no evidence of entropion in these cases. 

Trichiasis occurs when eyelashes originating from a normal position grow inward toward the globe. Again, there is no entropion of the eyelid margin. This condition can occur after eyelid trauma, surgery, chronic blepharoconjunctivitis, cicatricial pemphigoid, trachoma, or may also be idiopathic. 

Madarosis is a loss of lashes, usually due to either a congenital condition or as a result of an infectious condition. Trichotillomania occurs secondary to a compulsive urge to pull out one's own hair and/or eyelashes.

questions.question: The sphincter muscle of the iris is innervated by which nerve fibers?
questions.explanation:
The sphincter muscle of the iris is innervated by parasympathetic nerve fibers. The sphincter muscle is composed of smooth muscle and when it contracts, it serves to decrease pupil size, or constrict the pupil. 

The dilator muscle of the iris is innervated by sympathetic input. 

The superior oblique controls eye movement (specifically cranial nerve IV-the trochlear nerve). 

The trigeminal nerve has three facets one of which supplies sensory innervation from the cornea and conjunctiva. 

Pupillary nerve fibers do not exist.

questions.question: You correctly diagnose your 22 year-old female patient with contact dermatitis of her right periorbital skin. This allergic reaction is mediated by which of the following types of hypersensitivity responses?
questions.explanation:
Contact dermatitis is an inflammatory response that typically occurs following exposure to metals, cosmetics, medications, or preservatives. During the initial contact with an allergen, the individual is sensitized and develops an immune response if exposure occurs again. This type of reaction is characteristic of a delayed type IV hypersensitivity response and is mediated by T lymphocytes. 

Type I reactions are IgE-mediated reactions that result in an immediate response occurring within minutes of exposure. This type of reaction is seen in allergic disease. Type II reactions are antibody-dependent cytotoxic reactions that are mediated by IgM/IgG and complement. Type III reactions are due to immune complex formation. Immune complex diseases include systemic lupus erythematosus, Arthus reactions, and serum sickness.

questions.question: The bulk of aqueous humor is formed by which mechanism?
questions.explanation:
The ciliary processes of the pars plicata produce the aqueous humor. It is created by three different methods which are as described below. 

Active transport produces the majority of aqueous humor. It requires the use of sodium, chloride and bicarbonate ions that serve to create an osmotic gradient between the interdigitations of the non-pigmented epithelial cells of the ciliary body. This creates a higher concentration of solutes inside the cells near their tight junctions which diminishes towards the posterior chamber, pulling water into the posterior chamber. 

Ultrafiltration accounts for a small amount of aqueous produced. Fluid is pushed out of the ciliary processes via capillary hydrostatic forces (blood pressure). 

Diffusion is responsible for producing a very small amount of aqueous. Particles in fluid flow down their concentration gradient moving from an area of high concentration to an area of low particle concentration.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the movement of the eyelids and globe on closure during a REGULAR blink?
options: Upper and lower lids close lateral to medial direction, globe moves posteriorly
Upper and lower lids close medial to lateral direction, globe moves forward
Upper and lower lids close lateral to medial direction, globe moves forward
Upper and lower lids close medial to lateral direction, globe moves posteriorly
answers: Upper and lower lids close lateral to medial direction, globe moves posteriorly
questions.explanation:
During the closure portion of a blink, the eyelids close in a zipper-like fashion beginning laterally to medially. This pushes the tears into the caniculi. The globe itself is pushed further back into the orbit (most likely for defensive purposes). Upon opening, the lids open in a medial to lateral direction. 

Facts about blinking: 
The eyes close twice as fast as they open. 
The normal blink rate at rest is 12-15 times a minute. The blink rate increases with excitement and decreases during periods of increased concentration such as computer work and reading.

questions.question: A patient presents to your office reporting recent blunt trauma to the eye. Biomicroscopy reveals a hyphema of the right eye. Which of the following procedures should be avoided in this patient?
options: Use of sodium fluorescein to evaluate the integrity of the corneal surface
questions.explanation:
A hyphema is defined as blood in the anterior chamber, which typically pools inferiorly. When a patient presents with an acute hyphema, gonioscopy is contraindicated as it may increase the likelihood of re-bleeding and should be performed 2-4 weeks after the initial trauma, allowing time for the blood to clear from the anterior chamber. Evaluation of a hyphema should include observation of the anterior chamber to assess for potential damage to the cornea or iris. Intraocular pressure will likely be elevated. It is also important to ensure that the globe is not compromised and that orbital fractures are absent. Gonioscopy should be performed several weeks later to evaluate the angle for possible recession. 

Gonioscopy: A Text and Atlas. Dada, T., Sharma, R. & Sobti, A. Jaypee, 2013, page 8.

questions.question: Xerophthalmia is a dry eye condition associated with a deficiency of which of the following vitamins?
questions.explanation:
Severe ocular dryness that is a result of vitamin A deficiency is known as xerophthalmia. Patients with this condition typically present with conjunctival xerosis (extreme dryness and keratinization), Bitot's spots (foamy, white accumulations of sloughed cells), and corneal involvement that can eventually lead to ulceration. In advanced cases, blindness occurs due to necrosis of the cornea. 

Xerophthalmia is one of the most common causes of preventable blindness in children throughout the world. This condition is considered endemic in certain areas of Asia, Latin America, Africa, and the Middle East.

questions.question: A father brings his 6-year old boy to your office for evaluation of his frequent blinking that began two weeks ago. Uncorrected acuities are 20/20 OU, and biomicroscopy is unremarkable. What is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Blepharoclonus is commonly seen in children 5-10 years of age, and frequently no cause can be determined. The condition presents as either increased blink rate (the most common form) or increased duration of lid closure. It is important to rule out any possible external cause such as irritation to a portion of the anterior segment, especially that of the cornea. The condition is self-limiting, but sometimes artificial tears can help alleviate the frequency. Blepharoclonus can also be seen in patients suffering from brainstem lesions due to trauma or stroke; it is also seen with patients suffering from multiple sclerosis and Parkinson's disease. As a precaution, some practitioners recommend a neurological consult. 

Lid myokymia presents as intermittent, unilateral lid twitching; this can stem from a myriad of causes, such as fatigue, stress, anemia, increased levels of caffeine, alcohol or tobacco ingestion, and dry eyes, to name a few. This condition is generally self-limiting and will resolve, especially if the stimulus is removed. 

Ankyloblepharon can be congenital or can occur secondary to pathology. This condition causes the margins of the upper and lower lid to adhere to one another (generally at the lateral canthus). 

Vitiligo: Think of Michael Jackson: This condition presents as patchy depigmentation of the skin and sometimes depigmentation of the eyelashes and hair as well.

questions.question: When examining a patient, a pinpoint spot of the posterior surface of the lens known as Mittendorf's dot is seen. What is this a remnant of?
options: Glial tissue of the optic nerve
questions.explanation:
Mittendorf's dot is a remnant of the hyaloid artery and appears as a black dot on the posterior surface of the lens. Pupillary membrane remnants would be present in front of the lens and are a complex of fibers. Glial tissue of the optic nerve head is a remnant that is known as Bergmeister's papilla. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 110

questions.question: A patient presents in your office for an annual exam. On biomicroscopy, you note a dense ring of pigment on the anterior portion of the lens. The patient reports being punched in that eye six years ago. What is the proper term for this ring of pigment?
questions.explanation:
A Vossius ring occurs due to trauma which causes the posterior surface of the iris to rub against the anterior portion of the lens. Remnants of melanocytes from the pupillary border remain adherent to the lens, causing a ring of pigment. A Vossius ring does not require treatment unless it immensely interferes with vision (which is rare). Because it is an opacity on the lens it is considered a cataract. 

Epicapsular stars are congenital and appear as small pigment deposits on the anterior portion of the lens. This is a benign finding that rarely interferes with vision. 

Persistent pupillary membrane is the result of a failure of fetal tissue to atrophy. In the womb, blood is supplied to the lens via a grouping of blood vessels that generally regress and atrophy by birth. Occasionally they do not fully disintegrate leading to cobweb-like strands generally attached to the iris. Rarely does this condition affect vision. 

Crocodile shagreen is a benign corneal finding commonly seen in the elderly. Crocodile shagreen appears in the peripheral cornea as polygonal white opacities.

questions.question: The Y sutures of the lens are located in which of the following zones?
questions.explanation:
The regions of the lens can be described by zones of discontinuity. From anterior to posterior, these zones are: 

Anterior capsular zone - consists of the anterior lens capsule 
Anterior subcapsular zone - consists of lens epithelium and outermost cortical fibers 
Anterior zone of disjunction - consists of segments of cortical fibers formed after sexual maturation 
Anterior zone of the adult nucleus - consists of the secondary fibers formed after birth but before sexual maturation 
Anterior zone of the fetal nucleus - consists of secondary fibers formed before birth 
Zone of the embryonic nucleus - consists of primary lens fibers formed during the first 2 months of embryonic development 
Posterior zone of the fetal nucleus - consists of secondary fibers formed before birth 
Posterior zone of the adult nucleus - consists of the secondary fibers formed after birth but before sexual maturation 
Posterior subcapsular zone - consists of lens epithelium and outermost cortical fibers 
Posterior capsular zone - consists of the posterior lens capsule 

The upright Y suture is located in the anterior zone of the fetal nucleus; the inverted Y suture is located in the posterior zone of the fetal nucleus.

questions.question: When a chromophore absorbs a photon of light, which of the following changes occurs?
questions.explanation:
In the human visual cycle, light is converted into electrical signals in rod and cone photoreceptors in order for vision to occur. This process begins when opsins, which contain the 11-cis-retinal chromophore, absorb a photon of light. Once struck by a photon, 11-cis-retinal undergoes photoisomerization to the all-trans state (all-trans-retinal). This change leads to signal transduction cascades that eventually result in the closure of a cyclic GMP-gated cation channel and subsequent hyperpolarization of the photoreceptor cell. 

After this occurs, all-trans-retinal is reduced to all-trans-retinol. It then travels back to the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) where it is esterfied and then converted to 11-cis-retinol. It is finally oxidized to 11-cis-retinal before traveling back to the photoreceptor outer segment and attaching to an opsin, forming a new, functional visual pigment that is ready for photoisomerization again.

questions.question: What is the net overall moles of ATP produced by the electron transport chain (i.e. not including glycolysis)?
questions.explanation: The electron transport chain yields a total of 34 moles of ATP. Glycolysis produces a total of 2 moles of ATP. The overall net of cellular respiration is 36 moles of ATP.

questions.question: According to the Bohr Effect, which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: A higher pH favors release of oxygen from hemoglobin into the tissues
A higher pH favors release of oxygen from the tissues to hemoglobin
A lower pH favors oxygen release from hemoglobin into the tissues
A lower pH favors oxygen release from the tissues to hemoglobin
answers: A lower pH favors oxygen release from hemoglobin into the tissues
questions.explanation:
The Bohr Effect describes the effect of pH on the capability of hemoglobin to bind oxygen. A lower pH (drives the reaction to the right) favors the release of oxygen from hemoglobin into the tissues. Please reference Equation 1. 

During exercise, muscles produce lactic acid and carbon dioxide which decreases the pH of blood (increases hydrogen ion concentration). The change in pH signals hemoglobin to release more oxygen to the tissues that are now oxygen-deprived. Higher pH levels will shift the reaction to the left and cause less oxygen to be delivered to tissues.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following are classified as catecholamines? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: All catecholamines are derived from tyrosine which is converted to its respective neurotransmitter (either norepinephrine, epinephrine, or dopamine). Catecholamines are sympathomimetic 'fight-or-flight' hormones released by the adrenal glands in response to stress. Acetylcholine utilizes choline as its building block. It is a parasympathomimetic hormone and therefore is not classified as a catecholamine. Serotonin is derived from tryptophan and is also not considered a catecholamine. Cortisol is a steroid hormone and is not a neurotransmitter.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding acids is TRUE?
options: Ionization of a strong acid results in a high pKa value
Weak acids completely ionize in a solution
questions.explanation:
Acids are regarded as proton donors, and bases are considered proton acceptors. In solution, strong acids will completely ionize while weak acids will partially ionize. 

The amount of ionization of a weak base is dependent upon the Ka value (also known as the acid dissociation constant). Ka = [H][A-]/[HA]. A higher Ka value results in a greater amount of ionized acid, which is inversely related to pKa. pKa = -logKa. A higher Ka (or a lower pKa) indicates a stronger acid. 

pH is a measure of the concentration of hydrogen ions in solution. A higher pH corresponds to a more basic solution. pH= -log[H+].

questions.question: Which of the following tissue cells are insulin-independent?
options: Cells that line the walls of blood vessels
questions.explanation:
Insulin is a hormone secreted by the beta cells of the pancreas in response to elevated blood glucose. The target sites for insulin are the liver, adipose tissue, and muscle cells where the hormone stimulates anabolic pathways. In muscle cells, there is an increase in the uptake of glucose. 

In the liver, glucokinase and glycogen synthase are activated; this results in an increase in the uptake of glucose and an increase in the synthesis of glycogen respectively. The enzyme acetyl-CoA carboxylase is also activated, causing a rise in fatty acid synthesis. Conversely, glycogen phosphorylase is inhibited, producing a decrease in the breakdown of glycogen. 

Lipoprotein lipase enzymes are activated in adipose tissue triggering an increase in the synthesis of triglycerides. 

Red blood cells, brain cells, lens fiber cells, and kidney cells do not require insulin for proper functioning and therefore do not possess insulin receptors. Glucose entry into these cells is not regulated by insulin but rather the concentration difference of glucose levels on the inside versus the outside of the cell. Muscle cells and adipose cells require insulin receptors which mediate the transportation of glucose into the cells. Insulin-independent cells are therefore more susceptible to damage in diabetes cases as the glucose intake into these tissues is not as regulated as those that possess insulin receptors.

questions.question: Which histamine receptor plays a primary role in ocular allergies?
questions.explanation: H1 receptors are the primary histamine receptors found in the eye. The allergic response is initiated when an antigen (animal dander, pollen, etc.) binds to the IgE receptor and causes mast cell degranulation leading to the release of histamines, prostaglandins, tryptase, and heparin (the last two being inflammatory mediators). Histamine then binds to the H1 receptors located on nerves (leads to itching) and blood vessels (causes chemosis and erythema).

questions.question: Pepsinogen and fibrinogen are examples of which type of protein?
questions.explanation:
Pepsinogen and fibrinogen are categorized as zymogens. Zymogens, also called proenzymes, are synthesized as inactive proteins that later become activated via some type of transformation, for example, cleavage of a portion of the protein resulting in a functional enzyme. The enzymes cannot be reverted back to their inactive forms. Blood-clotting factors and digestive enzymes are common examples of zymogens. The zymogen pepsinogen is secreted from chief cells in the stomach and is converted to its active form, pepsin, via exposure to hydrochloric acid. The enzyme pepsin aids in the digestion of proteins. 

Allosteric enzymes are regulatory proteins that are controlled via modulators. The modulators activate or inhibit the enzyme function by binding to a location on the enzyme that is not the active site. 

Isoenzymes are enzymes that are molecularly different but catalyze the same reaction. Isozymes have different amino acid sequences than other enzymes, but both used for the same reaction. 

Sphingolipids are important for central nervous system (CNS) function. They are generally incorporated into CNS membranes.

questions.question: Which of the following types of hormones alters the activity of a cell by directly entering the nucleus of the target cells and turning on or off certain genes?
questions.explanation:
Hormones that are derived from the parent molecule cholesterol are classified as steroid hormones and are lipid-soluble. These hormones include testosterone, estrogens, progesterone, aldosterone, and cortisol. Due to the fact that these hormones are lipid-soluble, they are capable of diffusing through the plasma membrane of the target cell; also, they can bind to a receptor on the membrane. Once inside the cell, these hormones bind to a receptor in the cytoplasm or on the membrane of the nucleus; this complex then moves into the nucleus to alter protein synthesis, turning genes off or on. 

Amine hormones (norepinephrine and epinephrine) and peptide hormones (ADH, oxytocin and TRH) are non-steroidal because they are derived from amino acids and are therefore water-soluble. These hormones bind to receptors on the membrane of the target cell, and, in the majority of instances, alter the cell's function by activating a second messenger system such as cyclic AMP.

questions.question: Peptides are created through the formation of a bond between which two different groups of amino acids?
options: Hydroxyl group and R side chain
questions.explanation:
A peptide bond is formed between the amino group of one amino acid and the carboxyl group of another. Multiple amino acids bonded together in this manner form a peptide (polymers of amino acids). A peptide consisting of two amino acids is termed a dipeptide; one that is comprised of three amino acids is called a tripeptide and so forth. Peptides possess an 'N' terminal end and a 'C' terminal end. Aspartame is a man-made peptide that contains aspartate and phenylalanine with an added methyl ester group, which is responsible for the sweet taste. 

Glutathione is an important tripeptide made up of glutamate-cysteine-glutamate. This tripeptide contains an abnormal peptide bond. Glutathione is produced by our tissues and acts as a strong reductant that prevents the oxidative damage caused by free radicals.
PowerPage
Proteins & Amino Acids

questions.question: The basic structure of all amino acids contains which 3 of the following molecules? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
The basic structure of amino acids is as depicted in the image. 

H3N+ is the amine group; COO- is the carboxyl group (which is acidic); R refers to the side chain, which differs from and is specific to each amino acid. The R side chain determines the properties of the amino acid (for instance, polarity). 

Phenylalanine (PHE), tyrosine (TYR) and tryptophan (TRP) have aromatic benzene rings; histidine (HIS) also possesses an aromatic ring, however, it is categorized as an imidazole ring. Only three of the twenty amino acids contain a benzyl group.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following are normally located in the cytoplasm of a eukaryotic cell? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
Plasmids are defined as circular, double-stranded DNA molecules that are located extrachromosomally (not in the chromosome) of prokaryotic cells. Plasmids are usually not required for normal growth and functioning of bacteria but are generally comprised of genes that allow for a selective advantage. For example, genes that code for resistance to an antibiotic like tetracycline would be carried in a plasmid. 

Arachidonic acid is stored in cellular membranes and is utilized in various chemical pathways.

questions.question: Free radicals can cause severe damage to tissue. Which of the following electrolytes can function as an antioxidant in the aqueous?
questions.explanation: The aqueous humor contains many electrolytes including Na+, K+ , Cl-, HCO3-, glucose, lactate, amino acids, and ascorbate. Ascorbate is found in high concentrations in the aqueous (20x greater when compared to the concentration found in plasma). Ascorbate can serve as an antioxidant to eradicate free radicals reducing potential damage from ultraviolet light. Interesting note: the aqueous humor and tears of uncontrolled diabetics display higher levels of glucose than those of non-diabetics.

questions.question: Which metabolic pathways occur in the brain for the derivation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)?
questions.explanation: Glycolysis and the TCA cycle occur in cells located in the brain (as well as cells located in other organs of the body). Beta oxidation (breakdown of fatty acids) can occur in cells located in the muscles, liver and adipose tissue. Gluconeogenesis (the creation of glucose) takes place in liver cells. Proteolysis (the breakdown of proteins) occurs primarily in muscle cells.

questions.question: What is the result of the process of DNA annealing?
options: Breaking hydrogen bonds, resulting in two single strands of nucleic acid
The formation of a double helix
The addition of a 5' cap to the nucleotide sequence
The addition of nucleotides causing a shift in the reading frame
answers: The formation of a double helix
questions.explanation: Annealing refers to the process by which two strands of nucleotides that are complementary join together, forming a double helix. Denaturation describes the procedure in which double-stranded DNA is heated, causing breakage of hydrogen bonds between complementary base pairs. The double helix unwinds and becomes two single strands. The addition of a nucleotide(s) is considered a mutation and usually results in nonsense proteins. A 5' cap is usually added to a nucleotide sequence in preparation for RNA processing.

questions.question: Which of the following acts as a second messenger in the retina and is involved in the phototransduction cascade?
questions.explanation: Signal transduction in the retina occurs as follows: Light-> activates rhodopsin-> activates G protein (in rod outer segment disc called transducin)-> transducin-> activates phosphodiesterase, which lowers cGMP levels. Decreased levels of cGMP causes sodium and calcium channels to close, resulting in hyperpolarization of the membrane. Because the membrane is now hyperpolarized, the current flow to bipolar and ganglion cells becomes interrupted; this signals the brain and results in the perception of light.

questions.question: Which of the following is a precursor to steroid hormones such as testosterone?
questions.explanation:
Progesterone, aldosterone, testosterone, estradiol and cortisol are all derived from cholesterol. Cholesterol has a unique configuration comprised of four joined cycloalkane rings. Because these hormones are fat-soluble, they readily pass through cell membranes. They diffuse into the blood and are generally bound to carrier proteins, which transport the hormones to their designated target site where they may further undergo processing or transformation. 

Sphingolipids are important in cell membranes, especially those located in the central nervous system, such as myelin sheath. Sphingolipids contain sphingosine as a backbone and are then further classified depending on which molecules are attached to that backbone, such as ceremides, gangliosides, sphingomyelin, etc. 

Phospholipids contain a polar and non-polar end, thus making them amphoteric. This property allows for the formation of bilayers (polar ends aligned together and pointed outwards) resulting in the lipid bilayer commonly seen in cell membranes. Phospholipids are generally comprised of a phosphate group, a choline group (polar), and two fatty acid chains (non-polar) attached to glycerol, which serves as the backbone.

Triglycerides are comprised of three fatty acid chains attached to a glycerol backbone. Triglycerides are important in long-term energy storage for use by cells.

questions.question: All of the amino acids that are found naturally in proteins are of which configuration?
questions.explanation:
Enantiomers are mirror images of each other but cannot be superimposed, regardless of orientation. For biochemical compounds, the notation of L or D is placed before the name of the agent, as it is important to distinguish between the L and D configurations. All of the amino acids used in the formation of biological proteins are of the 'L' configuration. 
Below is an example of alanine in its two different configurations.

questions.question: Which of the following occurs as a result of insulin release?
options: Decreased fatty acid synthesis in the liver
Decreased uptake of glucose by the liver
Increased glucose uptake in muscle cells
Increased breakdown of glycogen in the liver
Decreased triglyceride synthesis in adipose tissue
answers: Increased glucose uptake in muscle cells
questions.explanation:
Insulin is released by the pancreas in response to elevated glucose levels. The target sites for insulin are the liver, adipose tissue, and muscle cells where it stimulates anabolic pathways. In muscle cells, there is an increase in the uptake of glucose. 

In the liver, glucokinase and glycogen synthase are activated, which results in an increase in the uptake of glucose and an increase in the synthesis of glycogen respectively. The enzyme acetyl CoA carboxylase is also activated, causing a rise in fatty acid synthesis. Conversely, glycogen phosphorylase is inhibited, producing a decrease in the breakdown of glycogen. 

Lipoprotein lipase enzymes are activated in adipose tissue, triggering an increase in the synthesis of triglycerides.

questions.question: How does the addition of a competitive inhibitor change the Lineweaver-Burk plot of an enzyme?
questions.explanation:
Inhibitors are agents that bind to an enzyme and thereby slow the reaction rate. Competitive inhibitors compete with the substrate for the active site of the enzyme. Once the inhibitor is bound, the enzyme cannot bind to the substrate, leading to decreased product formation. Competitive inhibitors can also bind to another site on the enzyme that causes a conformational change to the enzyme, disabling its ability to bind its substrate (allosteric inhibition). Competitive inhibitors cannot bind to the allosteric site once a substrate is bound. However, increasing the concentration of the substrate will allow it to out-compete the inhibitor, thus allowing for proper saturation of the enzyme. 

A non-competitive inhibitor binds to a location on the enzyme that is not the actual active site but still causes the enzyme to become inactive. The substrate is still capable of binding to the enzyme, but there is no product created since the enzyme has been rendered inactive. 

The addition of a competitive inhibitor does not alter the y-intercept value but does lead to an increase in the slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot. Competitive inhibitors cause an increase in the Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) but do not alter the maximum velocity (Vmax) of the reaction. Therefore, the y-intercept remains unchanged but the slope increases; and the x-intercept is also altered. 

Non-competitive inhibitors result in a decreased Vmax but no change to the Km value; this changes the y-intercept and increases the slope but leaves the x-intercept unaltered.

questions.question: Which enzyme catalyzes the addition of nucleotide units during DNA replication?
questions.explanation:
DNA polymerase (there are several) is responsible for the addition of nucleotides during DNA replication. Polymerase joins the new base to an old base via a phosphodiester bond elongating the strand from the 5' end to the 3' end. Polymerases are very accurate and proofread the new strand. If a base is incorrect, the enzyme will remove it. 

Helicases and topoisomerases are responsible for unwinding the helix and separating the strands to expose the template for replication, resulting in a replication fork. 

Primase adds the RNA primer that is necessary to initiate the replication sequence. Without a primer, replication cannot occur. After replication is complete the RNA primers are excised by exonucleases, and DNA polymerase I adds DNA to the now vacated spots. All gaps are filled in via DNA ligase resulting in the formation of two identical DNA strands.

questions.question: What is the first step in protein synthesis?
questions.explanation: Protein synthesis begins with transcription of messenger RNA from DNA. The mature messenger RNA is then transported into the cytoplasm where it will serve as a template for protein synthesis (translation).

questions.question: Which enzyme is involved in the rate-limiting step of glycolysis?
questions.explanation:
Glycolysis is the metabolic pathway responsible for the breakdown of glucose. The net result of glycolysis is 2 pyruvate molecules, 2 ATP, 2H+ and 2 NADH (although technically, it produces 4 ATP, but 2 ATP are used in the breakdown of glucose). Glycolysis is a complex pathway that involves many enzymes and the input of energy in the form of ATP. The initial steps of glycolysis are as follows: 

glucose (+ATP) --> glucose-6-phosphate<--> fructose-6-phosphate (+ ATP) --> fructose 1,6-biphosphate. 

The conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose 1,6-biphosphate is catalyzed by the enzyme phosphofructokinase and is irreversible. This is also the rate-limiting step as well as a main controlling point in glycolysis. The majority of the reactions in glycolysis are reversible, which is important for gluconeogenesis (the creation of glucose). Phosphofructokinase (PFK) is inhibited by high levels of ATP. Therefore when ATP is present in higher concentrations, glycolysis is suppressed. During these occasions, glucose is stored as glycogen in the liver.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding enzymes is FALSE?
options: Enzymes increase the level of energy of activation needed for a reaction
Enzymes serve to increase reaction rates
Enzymes are highly specific for their substrates
Enzymes function best in the presence of mild pH and temperature
answers: Enzymes increase the level of energy of activation needed for a reaction
questions.explanation: Enzymes are proteins that serve as catalysts for many reactions. They are very specific in the substrates or reactants that they bind. Due to the fact that enzymes are proteins, they are susceptible to denaturation if there is a large change in either the pH or temperature of their environment. Either of these changes will lead to a decrease in productivity of the enzyme or a complete loss of function. Enzymes serve to reduce the amount of energy that is needed in order for the reaction to occur. By lowering the energy of activation, the rate of the reaction can proceed much more rapidly.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding amino acids?
options: Essential amino acids are synthesized via glycolysis and the Krebs cycle
14 amino acids cannot be synthesized by mammals
There are a total of 24 amino acids
In mammals, 10 amino acids must be supplemented via diet
answers: In mammals, 10 amino acids must be supplemented via diet
questions.explanation:
There are a total of 20 amino acids typically found and used in human peptides and proteins. Ten of these are considered absolutely essential because humans do not possess the ability to synthesize them, and they are necessary for normal functioning. The essential amino acids must be supplied via ingestion from external sources. Non-essential amino acids can be fabricated from carbohydrate sources via the tricarboxylic acid cycle, glycolysis and pentose phosphate shunt, or their intermediates. 

The non-essential amino acids include: alanine, asparagine, aspartate, cysteine, glutamate, glutamine, glycine, proline, serine, and tyrosine. Essential amino acids are: arginine, isoleucine, leucine, lysine, methionine, phenylalanine, threonine, tryptophan, valine, and histidine. Although the list varies between what is deemed essential and what is non-essential, it is rather a moot point since all of the amino acids are required by our system.

questions.question: An increased rate of molecular movement down its respective concentration gradient via help from carrier proteins refers to which type of transportation?
questions.explanation: Facilitated diffusion is described as the net movement of molecules down its concentration gradient whose rate of diffusion is increased via the use of carrier proteins. Passive diffusion refers to the movement of molecules through a plasma membrane from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration without the use of carrier molecules. Active transport implies the movement of material against its respective concentration gradient. This type of transport requires energy and enlists the use of specific carrier proteins. Lastly, group translocation is defined as the chemical modification of a molecule while it is being transported into a cell; for example, sugars are often phosphorylated during transportation.

questions.question: A 42-year old male is found to have a gray-white ring around the cornea. What blood test do you recommend the patient obtain?
questions.explanation:
The white or grey ring is a deposition of lipid material and has been referred to in the past as arcus senilis. It is common in African-Americans, and its prevalence increases with age. In a young male with higher gender-based risk, the association with elevated cholesterol makes the test mandatory so that statin treatment can be instituted as early as possible. Arcus cornealis and arcus juvenilia (that is, discoloration around the cornea in younger people) are independently associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, probably reflective of the deposition of lipid material in the blood vessels as it has been demonstrated in the cornea.
PowerPage
Cholesterol

questions.question: Gluconeogenesis occurs primarily in what organ of the body?
questions.explanation:
Gluconeogenesis occurs predominantly in the liver cells. Gluconeogenesis is the process by which glucose is synthesized from non-carbohydrate sources such as lactate, glucogenic amino acids, or glycerol. It is important to note that fatty acids CANNOT be used in the formation of glucose. Gluconeogenesis requires the expenditure of ATP and GTP. This process is essentially the reverse of glycolysis except that the three irreversible steps undergone in glycolysis must be by-passed. The fact that glycolysis cannot be directly and easily reversed is important for proper regulation of glucose levels. 

In glycolysis, the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose 1,6-biphosphate is catalyzed by the enzyme phosphofructokinase and is irreversible. In gluconeogenesis, the reversal of this process and the creation of fructose-6-phosphate from fructose 1,6-biphosphate requires the enzyme fructose 1,6,biphosphatase. Also, in glycolysis, glucose is transformed to glucose 6-phosphate (G-6-P) via the enzyme hexokinase. Conversely, in gluconeogenesis, G-6-P is converted back to glucose by the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. Another important distinction is the enzyme pyruvate kinase of glycolysis is replaced with the enzyme phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) carboxykinase, which is used to convert oxaloacetate into phosphoenolpyruvate in gluconeogenesis.

questions.question: Which of the following amino acids is NOT chiral? (Chiral refers to the property of a molecule whose mirror image is NON-superimposable and therefore asymmetric).
questions.explanation:
Glycine (figure 1) is the only amino acid that is not chiral. Chirality refers to asymmetry. An amino acid is declared as chiral if its central (alpha) carbon is surrounded by four different groups. 

Notice how glycine contains two hydrogen groups around its central carbon. Because it contains two groups that are the same, glycine is achiral. All of the other 19 amino acids are chiral.

questions.question: Which organelle in a eukaryotic cell is responsible for lipid biosynthesis?
questions.explanation:
The smooth endoplasmic reticulum is important for the synthesis of lipids. It is also involved in storing calcium ions which are necessary for muscle cell function. 

The Golgi apparatus (or Golgi complex) functions to modify newly-synthesized proteins as well as to package and sort macromolecules in preparation for secretion from or for use within the cell. 

Mitochondria are extremely important for cell function as they are the site of cellular respiration. 

Lysosomes are necessary for the destruction of cellular debris and old cells. These organelles contain enzymes used to degrade protein (proteases), lipids (lipases), and nucleic acids (nucleases). 

The rough endoplasmic reticulum is the site of protein synthesis.

questions.question: D-glucose is an example of which type of carbohydrate?
questions.explanation:
Monosaccharides are the simplest form of sugar and are the building blocks of more complex carbohydrates like starch and cellulose. Monosaccharides are generally colorless, crystalline solids that are water-soluble. Some common examples include glucose, galactose, ribose, and fructose. All of the carbon atoms that contain hydroxyl as a group (excluding the first and last carbons) are chiral. The chirality of the carbon atoms allows for multiple stereoisomers (same chemical formula, but the atoms are positioned differently in space).
PowerPage
Carbohydrates

questions.question: Familial hypercholesterolemia is the result of a defect to what structure?
questions.explanation: Familial hypercholesterolemia is the result of elevated blood levels of cholesterol. Normally, cholesterol is carried to cells via low-density lipoproteins. Target cells possess receptors for LDL; once LDL is bound, the receptors initiate endocytosis, bringing cholesterol into the cell for digestion by lysozymes. The receptors are then recycled. People who suffer from familial hypercholesterolemia possess defective LDL receptors; as such, cholesterol is unable to enter the cell, leading to increased blood levels of cholesterol.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the bicarbonate buffering system found in our blood is TRUE?
options: Hypoventilation increases the concentration of carbon dioxide, lowering the pH of the blood
Hyperventilation decreases the concentration of carbon dioxide, resulting in an increase in the production of hydrogen ions
Hypoventilation decreases the concentration of carbon dioxide, resulting in an increase in the pH of blood
Hyperventilation increases the concentration of carbon dioxide, causing the blood to become more acidic
answers: Hypoventilation increases the concentration of carbon dioxide, lowering the pH of the blood
questions.explanation:
A buffer is an agent that serves to maintain the desired pH of its respective system. Buffers are comprised of a weak base and a weak acid. Bicarbonate is used by our body to resist drastic changes in pH. Hypoventilation causes the blood to become more acidic (lower pH) by causing an increase in the production of hydrogen ions due to an increase in the concentration of carbon dioxide in the lungs and blood. 
Hyperventilation results in an increase in the pH of blood (more basic) due to a decrease in the concentration of carbon dioxide, which results in a decrease in hydrogen ion production.

questions.question: Fatty acid synthesis is activated during which of the following situations?
options: Increased levels of citrate, decreased levels of glucagon and insulin
Decreased levels of citrate, increased levels of glucagon and insulin
Decreased levels of citrate and glucagon, increased levels of insulin
Decreased levels citrate and insulin, increased levels of glucagon
Increased levels of citrate and insulin, decreased levels of glucagon
Increased levels of citrate and glucagon, decreased levels of insulin
answers: Increased levels of citrate and insulin, decreased levels of glucagon
questions.explanation:
Fatty acid synthesis is stimulated by insulin and inhibited by glucagon and epinephrine. The formation of fatty acids is catalyzed via the enzyme acetyl CoA reductase, which is activated by citrate.
