Acetyl CoA reductase is allosterically inhibited by palmitoyl-CoA. Fatty acid synthesis occurs in the cytosol and requires the use of ATP and NADPH, as this is a complex anabolic process. 

A brief overview and important points of the pathway are as follows: Essentially, acetyl CoA combines with oxaloacetate (OAA) in the mitochondria to form citrate, which is then shuttled out into the cytosol by the citrate shuttle. Once in the cytosol, citrate is broken down again into its constituents, OAA and acetyl CoA. OAA is converted back into pyruvate to re-gain entry into the mitochondria. Acetyl CoA is converted to malonyl-CoA via acetyl CoA carboxylase (rate-limiting step and uses biotin as a cofactor). Malonyl CoA and the acyl carrier protein undergo several reactions to create fatty acid.

questions.question: Which of the following STIMULATES the synthesis of cholesterol?
options: Increased levels of statin drugs (i.e. Lipitor)
questions.explanation: Cholesterol is synthesized in the liver from acetyl-CoA, which is mediated by the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, and requires the use of NADPH. Cholesterol synthesis is stimulated via insulin. Elevated levels of intracellular cholesterol, glucagon, and statin drugs inhibit the formation of cholesterol. Cholesterol is a precursor for progesterone, aldosterone, cortisol, estradiol, and testosterone.

questions.question: Regarding Michaelis-Menten (M-M) kinetics of enzymes and their substrates, which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: Increasing the concentration of substrate will increase the reaction rate indefinitely
Increased concentration of substrate increases the rate of reaction in a linear fashion
The maximal rate of reaction is achieved when the enzyme is saturated
The formation rate of a product is dependent solely upon the amount of enzyme present
answers: The maximal rate of reaction is achieved when the enzyme is saturated
questions.explanation:
The Michaelis-Menten equation is as follows: 
v = Vm[S] 
-------- 
Km + [S] 
Where v=the rate of reaction, Vm=the enzyme's maximum rate, [S]=the concentration of substrate, Km=the Michaelis-Menten constant; each enzyme possesses its own specific Km. 

The reaction rate depends on the concentration of the substrate as well as the enzyme. The rate of the reaction will reach its maximal velocity when the enzyme becomes saturated, at which point the addition of substrate will not alter the reaction rate as there are no more available enzymes. Plotting the saturation curve for an enzyme demonstrates that as the amount of substrate increases, the reaction rate also increases in an almost linear fashion; however, as the enzyme reaches its saturation point, the curve will flatten out and the reaction rate will cease to increase. 

Remember; Km=[S]when v=1/2 Vm!

questions.question: What is the most common cause of nonsense mutations?
questions.explanation:
Nonsense mutations are a type of point mutation in which a single nucleotide is substituted for another that leads to a stop codon. For example, CAG is altered to UAG. CAG codes for the amino acid lysine, but UAG is a stop codon, causing premature completion of a protein. 

Insertion or deletion is when one base (or several) is added or deleted, causing a disruption of protein function. 

Frame shifts result from insertion or deletion of nucleotides, leading to an improper reading of the nucleotide sequence.

questions.question: Dietary triglycerides are metabolized primarily by which organ of the body?
questions.explanation: Fat is digested primary in the intestine. It enters the intestine from the stomach, where it becomes emulsified by bile salts and hydrolyzed by lipases released from the pancreas. These end products are then absorbed by enterocytes that line the walls of the intestine. Once in the enterocytes, triglycerides are then rebuilt and packaged along with cholesterol and protein to form chylomicrons. The chylomicrons are able to enter the lymph system, where they are absorbed into the blood stream and transported to the liver or adipose tissue. Triglycerides cannot directly diffuse through the cell membranes of the liver or adipose tissue; they must first be broken down into fatty acids and glycerol. This process is made possible by lipoprotein lipases located on the walls of blood vessels. The fatty acids and glycerol are then absorbed by the liver for energy or taken up by adipose tissue and re-synthesized into triglycerides for storage purposes.

questions.question: Why is ultraviolet light (UV) considered mutagenic?
options: It causes the formation of thymine dimers
It leads to the creation of base analogs that resemble bases, causing faulty base pairing
It leads to back mutations and reversions
It causes incorporation of acridine dyes, leading to frameshift mutations
answers: It causes the formation of thymine dimers
questions.explanation:
The formation of thymine dimers disrupts proper DNA replication. UV light causes covalent bonds to form between adjacent thymine bases which then inhibit polymerases and DNA replication. The offending nucleotides can be excised by the body but, if they are left, dimers can causes melanomas in humans. 

Acridine used to be a main component in hair dye. This chemical would become incorporated via intercalation into DNA and lead to frameshift mutations secondary to insertion of nucleotides. A base analog is a chemical that resembles a nucleotide and may become incorporated into DNA, which leads to faulty base pairing. Back mutation or reversion describes a scenario in which a point mutation leads to the restoration of a wild-type phenotype or the original nucleotide sequence.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding type I diabetes?
options: It is caused by defective insulin-producing cells
It is caused by defective insulin receptors
Cells of the body do not respond to insulin
It is also known as adult-onset diabetes
answers: It is caused by defective insulin-producing cells
questions.explanation:
Type I diabetes (proper term), juvenile onset diabetes or also called insulin-dependent diabetes is essentially a systemic condition caused by faulty beta insulin-producing cells of the pancreas. Due to the lack of insulin or smaller concentration of insulin produced, the body is incapable of regulating blood glucose, causing some tissues to receive too much glucose while insulin-dependent tissues do not receive enough. Type I diabetes is treated with insulin injections. 

Type II diabetes (adult-onset, non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus) is caused by insulin resistance. Either the insulin cells are defective or the cells fail to use insulin appropriately resulting in elevated blood glucose levels. Type II is often manageable via diet and exercise or medication or both.

questions.question: Which of the following regarding deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is FALSE?
options: It is helical in shape with a hydrophobic core
It is composed of polymers of nucleotides linked via phosphodiester bonds
Complementary base pairs include AU and GC
answers: Complementary base pairs include AU and GC
questions.explanation: Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) contains genetic information necessary for proper function and development of living organisms. It consists of polymers of nucleotides which are linked via phosphodiester bonds. DNA is double-stranded and contains the complementary base AT and CG, which are linked in an antiparallel fashion. GC bonds are stronger than AT bonds as they contain more hydrogen bonds (3 vs. 2 respectively). Therefore, DNA with a higher CG content is considered more stable. The DNA strands are wound in a right-handed tightly coiled helix. The nucleobases are centered towards the core, causing the center of the helix to be hydrophobic.

questions.question: An amphipathic molecule will react in what manner when exposed to water?
questions.explanation: Amphipathic molecules, such as phosphatidylcholine, contain both polar and non-polar components. Because water is polar, it will dissolve other polar compounds (like dissolves like). Upon exposure to water, the hydrophilic polar elements of the amphipathic molecule will begin to align and point outwards towards the water, eventually forming small spheres called micelles. The inner portion of the micelle is comprised of the non-polar elements which are hydrophobic. Micelle formation increases the entropy of water molecules; therefore, the water molecules are less ordered; this is a more favorable outcome. If the solvent is non-polar, then an inverse micelle will form, with the hydrophobic portions pointing outwards. Entropy is a measure of disorder; higher entropy entails less order. Lipid bilayers are formed based on the principals of micelle formation.

questions.question: Why is the formation of ketone bodies detrimental to the body?
options: Ketone bodies become favorably metabolized over glucose
Ketone bodies disrupt the function of fatty acid synthesis
Ketone bodies are acidic and lower the pH of blood
Ketone bodies become incorporated into nucleic acids
answers: Ketone bodies are acidic and lower the pH of blood
questions.explanation: Ketoacidosis can occur during periods of starvation, low carbohydrate levels, when there is excessive breakdown of fats, or in uncontrolled diabetes. Carbohydrate catabolism is always favored over the formation of ketone bodies. When there is an excessive amount of acetyl-CoA present, ketone bodies are formed (for instance, acetone). When the body is starving, the brain uses ketones as a fuel source to maintain regulatory functions. The ketone bodies are acidic and can lower the pH of blood. Warning signs include: vomiting, flushed skin, difficulty breathing, and confusion. A key sign to watch and/or smell for is fruity breath or breath that smells like nail polish remover. Ketoacidosis can lead to a diabetic coma or death. People with Type I diabetes are more susceptible to ketoacidosis than those suffering from Type II.

questions.question: Which of the following occurs to an element that has undergone oxidation?
questions.explanation:
In oxidation/reduction reactions, the chemical species that undergoes oxidation loses electrons and becomes positively charged, or stated differently, its oxidation state increases. Conversely, those species that become reduced will gain electrons and become negatively charged. Mnemonic = OIL RIG. Oxidation Is Loss of electrons, Reduction Is Gain of electrons. Because electrons are negatively charged, if the species gains electrons it will also become more negatively charged and reduced. 
For example: 2Ag+ (aq) + 2e- = 2 Ag (s) 
Silver becomes reduced with the addition of electrons and loses its positive charge. 

In true terms, oxidation and reduction refer to an increase or decrease in the oxidation number, respectively. Not all redox reactions result in the transfer of electrons.

questions.question: How are the end products of triglyceride metabolism transported from the intestine to the liver?
options: Via exocytosis into the lymph system
Excreted directly into the blood stream
questions.explanation: Fat is digested primarily in the intestine. It enters the intestine from the stomach, where it becomes emulsified by bile salts and hydrolyzed by lipases released from the pancreas. These end products are then absorbed by enterocytes that line the walls of the intestine. Once inside, the enterocytes, triglycerides are then rebuilt and packaged along with cholesterol and protein to form chylomicrons. The chylomicrons are able to enter the lymph system, where they are absorbed into the blood stream and transported to the liver or adipose tissue. Triglycerides cannot directly diffuse through the cell membranes of the liver or adipose tissue; they must first be broken down into fatty acids and glycerol. This process is made possible by the presence of lipoprotein lipases on the walls of blood vessels. The fatty acids and glycerol are then absorbed by the liver to be used for energy or taken up by adipose tissue, where they are re-synthesized into triglycerides for storage purposes.

questions.question: Glycolysis occurs at which location within a eukaryotic cell?
questions.explanation:
Glycolysis is an important metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose into pyruvate. Then, pyruvate can either be converted anaerobically into lactate or undergo oxidative phosphorylation yielding 36 moles of ATP. Glycolysis occurs in the cytosol of a cell. 

To help remember the above, think of this little rhyme: glycol occurs in the cytosol. 

Ref: Guyton and Hall, Textbook of Medical Physiology 10th ed. (2000) page 775-778.

questions.question: Hyaluronic acid is an example of which type of carbohydrate?
questions.explanation: Hyaluronic acid is located in between the collagen fibers of the vitreous humor. It is composed of repeating units of two sugars (glucuronic acid and N-acetyl glucosamine in this case). Conversely, homopolysaccharides such as starch, cellulose, and glycogen are made up of repeating units of only one sugar (glucose in the aforementioned cases). Disaccharides are comprised of two monosaccharides joined by a glycolytic bond. Examples of common disaccharides are maltose, lactose, and sucrose. Sucrose is also known as table sugar and is created by bonding glucose and fructose.

questions.question: What acts as the terminal electron acceptor in the electron transport chain?
questions.explanation:
The electron transport chain transfers electrons to various proteins within the mitochondria. As the electrons are transferred, energy is released that is used to pump protons (H+) out of the membrane to create a pH gradient; this serves to drive adenosine triphosphate (ATP) synthesis. Coenzyme Q, also known as ubiquinone, transfers electrons from complex I to complex III as well as from complex II to complex III. Cytochrome C serves as an electron carrier between complex III and complex IV. Complex IV then delivers the electron to oxygen, which acts as the terminal electron acceptor. NADH and FADH2 are the initial electron donors that pass the electrons into complex I and complex II respectively; the electron transport chain and oxidative phosphorylation thus ensues.
PowerPage
Solute Transfer

questions.question: A series of biochemical events that leads to a process of programmed cell death is known as which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
Apoptosis and necrosis are two different methods of cell death. Apoptosis refers to the process of programmed cell death; necrosis refers to premature death of living cells and tissue. There are several characteristic features that help differentiate between apoptosis and necrosis, summarized below. 
- Apoptosis typically involves a natural process of cell death, while necrosis is caused by factors external to the cell (such as infection, trauma, or toxins) 
- Apoptosis is usually regarded as beneficial to the tissue, while necrosis is detrimental to the tissue 
- Apoptosis can prevent tumor formation due to a balance between cell death rate and mitosis rate 
- Necrosis results in inflammation of surrounding tissues, which can become chronic 

Autolysis refers to the destruction of a cell by means of its own enzymes. It is also commonly known as self-digestion. 

Phagocytosis is the process by which a cell engulfs a particle forming an internal vesicle known as a phagosome. 

Acute Neuronal Injury: The Role of Excitotoxic Programmed Cell Death Mechanisms. Fujikana, D.G. 2010. Springer. New York, NY.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following occur in RNA processing after transcription has transpired? (Select 3)
options: Neutrons are added to the 5' tail
Complete RNA processing results in mature messenger RNA
answers: Complete RNA processing results in mature messenger RNA
questions.explanation: Once transcription has occurred, the primary transcript may undergo further processing, resulting in functional RNA. In order for processing to occur, a 5' methylated cap must first be added to the primary transcript which helps to serve as a recognition marker during the synthesis of proteins. A 3' polyadenylate tail is then added, which helps to keep the RNA from becoming degraded. Lastly, introns are spliced out of the nucleotide sequence, while exons remain in the mature RNA; the exons are shuttled into the cytoplasm and utilized in translation.

questions.question: Which enzyme is responsible for catalyzing the reaction of peptide bond formation during the elongation phase of protein synthesis?
questions.explanation:
Peptidyl transferase is the enzyme responsible for the formation of a peptide bond between amino acids in the P site of the ribosome and the A site during the elongation phase. 

Upon the formation of a thymine dimer caused by exposure to UV light, nuclease removes several nucleotides, including the offending ones and the bases adjacent to them. DNA polymerase I is then responsible for the replacement of correct base pairs. Lastly, DNA ligase then seals the nicks or gaps caused by the nuclease.

questions.question: What is the proper sequence of enzymes used to correct damage done to DNA by ultraviolet (UV) light?
options: Nuclease, DNA polymerase I, DNA ligase
DNA ligase, Nuclease, DNA polymerase I
DNA polymerase I, Nuclease, DNA ligase
DNA polymerase I, DNA ligase, Nuclease
Nuclease, DNA ligase, DNA polymerase I
DNA ligase, DNA polymerase I, Nuclease
answers: Nuclease, DNA polymerase I, DNA ligase
questions.explanation: Upon the formation of a thymine dimer caused by exposure to UV light, the nuclease removes several nucleotides, including the offending ones and the bases adjacent to them. DNA polymerase I is then responsible for the replacement of correct base pairs. Lastly, DNA ligase then seals the nicks or gaps caused by the nuclease.

questions.question: The electron transport chain occurs at which location of a eukaryotic cell?
questions.explanation:
The electron transport chain (ETC) and the Krebs cycle occur in the mitochondria. The Krebs cycle (TCA/citric acid cycle) takes place in the matrix of the mitochondrion. ETC occurs in the mitochondrial inner membrane. Glycolysis and gluconeogenesis occur in the cytosol of eukaryotic cells.
PowerPage
Tricarboxylic Acid Cycle

questions.question: The tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle occurs at which location within the eukaryotic cell?
questions.explanation: The TCA cycle, also known as the Krebs or the citric acid cycle, is an important part of a complex metabolic pathway that is used for the breakdown of carbohydrates, proteins, and lipids to create energy that is required by aerobic cells. Pyruvate is transformed into acetyl-CoA via the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase. Acetyl CoA joins with oxaloacetate (OAA) to create citrate, which then enters the TCA cycle and goes through a series of chemical transformations with help from multiple enzymes used to catalyze the reactions. For every acetyl-CoA group that is metabolized, 2 CO2 molecules are created along with 3 NADH coenzymes and FADH2. NADH and FADH2 are then used by the electron transport chain (ETC). The final product of the TCA cycle is oxaloacetate; this OAA then feeds back into the cycle to combine with acetyl-CoA.

questions.question: The binding of insulin to its receptor directly activates which of the following enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Tyrosine kinase is attached to the insulin receptor on the inside of the cell. Once the insulin is bound to the receptor, tyrosine kinase becomes activated. This reaction results in phosphorylation of the glucose transport protein which then relocates to the cellular membrane, where it facilitates the import of glucose. 

Adenylyl cyclase is an enzyme important for cellular communication and is found in the adenylyl cyclase pathway (also known as the cAMP-dependent pathway) which causes a signaling cascade initiated via a G protein-coupled receptor. 

Hexokinase catalyzes the first step of glycolysis by converting glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. 

Pepsin is an enzyme that is released by the stomach to aid with the digestion of proteins.

questions.question: Premature death of living cells and tissue that is caused by factors external to the cell or tissue is known as which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
Apoptosis and necrosis are two different methods of cell death. Apoptosis refers to the process of programmed cell death; necrosis refers to premature death of living cells and tissue. There are several characteristic features that help differentiate between apoptosis and necrosis, summarized below. 
- Apoptosis typically involves a natural process of cell death, while necrosis is caused by factors external to the cell (such as infection, trauma, or toxins) 
- Apoptosis is usually regarded as beneficial to the tissue, while necrosis is detrimental to the tissue 
- Apoptosis can prevent tumor formation due to a balance between cell death rate and mitosis rate 
- Necrosis results in inflammation of surrounding tissues, which can become chronic 

Autolysis refers to the destruction of a cell by means of its own enzymes. It is also commonly known as self-digestion. 

Phagocytosis is the process by which a cell engulfs a particle, forming an internal vesicle known as a phagosome. 

Acute Neuronal Injury: The Role of Excitotoxic Programmed Cell Death Mechanisms. Fujikana, D.G. 2010. Springer. New York, NY.

questions.question: Coenzyme Q, vitamins A, D, E, and K, and cholesterol are all derived from which of the following lipids?
questions.explanation:
Coenzyme Q, all steroids, cholesterol, and vitamins A, D, E, and K are derived from isoprenes or terpenes. These agents contain or at some point originated from precursors that were comprised of isoprene units. Isoprene units have the chemical formula C5H8. 

Sphingolipids are important in cell membranes, especially those located in the central nervous system such as myelin sheath. Shingolipids contain shingosine as a backbone and are then further classified depending upon which molecules are attached to that backbone, such are ceremides, gangliosides, sphingomyelin, etc. 

Phospholipids contain a polar and non-polar end, thus making them amphoteric. This property allows for the formation of bilayers (polar ends aligned together and pointed outwards) resulting in the lipid bilayer commonly seen in cell membranes. Phospholipids are generally comprised of a phosphate group, a choline group (polar), and two fatty acid chains (non-polar) attached to glycerol, which serves as the backbone.

Triglycerides are comprised of three fatty acid chains attached to a glycerol backbone. Triglycerides are important in long-term energy storage for use by cells.
PowerPage
Lipids

questions.question: The formation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) is driven by which force in oxidative phosphorylation?
options: Proton force caused by a pH gradient
The net movement of water (osmosis) through the mitochondrial membrane
The breakdown of cytochrome c, which yields high energy reactants
answers: Proton force caused by a pH gradient
questions.explanation: Oxidative phosphorylation is the synthesis of adenosine triphosphate (ATP), by essentially by the creation a pH gradient across the mitochondrial membrane. This is achieved via the transfer of electrons through redox reactions and protein complexes. The transfer of electrons from electron donors to electron acceptors releases energy that is then used to pump protons (H+) from the matrix of the mitochondrion into the intermembrane space (this process is called chemiosmosis). The difference in pH created across the membrane causes the protons to flow back into the mitochondrial matrix down its respective concentration gradient through a pore in the enzyme ATP synthase. This proton flow provides the energy necessary for ATP synthase to phosphorylate ADP and form ATP.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following are classified as nucleobases? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
Pyrimidine, cytosine, thymine, uracil, guanine, purine, and adenine are all classified as nucleobases. Nucleobases are composed of purine or pyrimidine ring structures and are found in the formation of nucleic acids. Cytosine, adenine and guanine are used in the synthesis of both DNA and RNA. Thymine is found only in DNA formation, and uracil is specific for RNA. 

Cytidine and deoxyguanosine are considered nucleosides, which are composed of a nucleobase joined with a sugar (ribose or deoxyribose). Adenosine monophosphate is a nucleotide, a nucleoside linked with one or multiple phosphates. A nucleotide is composed of a nucleobase, a sugar (ribose or deoxyribose), and a phosphate. Important nucleotides include adenosine triphosphate (ATP), nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+), coenzyme A, and cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP).

questions.question: Alpha helices and beta sheets are considered which level of protein structure?
questions.explanation:
Alpha helices and beta sheets are categorized as secondary structures. 

Primary structures are the initial sequences of amino acids that will eventually code for the final structure of the protein. Primary structures are held together via peptide bonds. 

Secondary structures are formed by folding chains of amino acids into a helix or sheet. The helices are coiled so that the R side chains face away from the center of the helix. The beta sheets can be folded in a parallel pattern, where all of the N terminals are located at the same end of the sheet, or in an anti-parallel pattern, where the N and C terminals alternate at the ends of the sheet. Secondary structures are stabilized by hydrogen bonds between the peptide bond groups. 

Tertiary structure refers to the final overall three-dimensional shape of the protein. Bonding between the side chains causes folding and twisting of the protein. There are four types of bonding that occur at this level; hydrogen bonds, hydrophobic interactions between non-polar side groups (weak), disulfide bonds (strong, covalent) and salt bridges (also called electrostatic attraction). Electrostatic forces deals with the overall charge of the side groups. A positively charged group will be attracted to a negatively charged group. Disulfide bonds form when the sulfhydryl groups of cysteine become oxidized. 

Quaternary proteins can be classified as either globular or fibrous. Quaternary proteins are oligomeric, meaning that they are created through the bonding of several peptide units. Globular proteins (for example hemoglobin) are generally compact, water-soluble and ball-shaped. Most globular proteins are enzymes. Fibrous proteins tend to be elongated, strong, and not water-soluble. Fibrous proteins (for example collagen) tend to serve a structural role.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following are considered types of mutations? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: Recombination refers to a process in which genetic elements from two different genomes are combined together into one unit. A point mutation results from the change of a single base. Point mutations can lead to missense mutations, silent mutations, and nonsense mutations. Missense mutations are caused by the alteration of a single nucleotide, resulting in a codon that now codes for a different amino acid. Silent mutations occur when a single base is changed but the actual codon still codes for the same amino acid. For instance, ACC is altered to CGG both codons code for arginine. Nonsense mutations are the result of a changed nucleotide that leads to a stop codon. For example, CAG is altered to UAG. CAG codes for the amino acid lysine, but UAG is a stop codon, causing premature completion of a protein. Deletion or insertion of a single or multiple bases usually results in frame-shift mutations and may lead to a complete loss of ability to produce necessary proteins.

questions.question: Hemoglobin is an example of which type of protein?
questions.explanation:
Proteins are created via polymers of amino acids which are linked together by peptide bonds. Proteins vary in their structure and function. 

Transport proteins are created to bind specific molecules and transfer them to their designated destinations. Hemoglobin is designed to carry oxygen. 

Contractile proteins (collagen, for example) are important in maintaining structural support. 

Regulatory proteins serve to manage physiological processes such as controlling blood sugar via insulin and glucagon. 

Enzymes are proteins that alter the rate of a reaction. An example of a biological enzyme is DNA helicase which serves to uncoil DNA.

questions.question: In order to undergo oxidation, how are fatty acids transported into the mitochondria?
options: Simple diffusion through the cellular membrane
questions.explanation: Triglycerides are an important energy source. Fat is stored in adipose tissue where it gets converted into fatty acyl-CoAs by glucagon and epinephrine when energy levels become depleted. When there is a demand for energy, the fatty acids in adipose tissue diffuse out of the cell and join with blood albumin to be transported to peripheral tissues. The fatty acids diffuse into muscle or liver cells, where they become activated to fatty acyl-CoAs and are transported via the carnitine shuttle from the cytoplasm into the mitochondria. Once in the mitochondria, the fatty acyl-CoAs undergo multiple rounds of beta oxidation; each cycle removes two carbons from the fatty acyl-CoAs. Each rotation of beta oxidation produces one mole of FADH2, one NADH and one acetyl-CoA. Each acetyl-CoA then enters the TCA cycle to undergo further oxidation to produce 3 NADH, 1 FADH2 (which are then used by electron transport chain) and one mole of ATP. The breakdown of fatty acids yields a greater amount of energy than the oxidation of carbohydrates.

questions.question: What is the function of lipoproteins?
questions.explanation: Lipoproteins are agents that are comprised of lipid and protein and are found in the blood. Lipoproteins serve to transport lipids. They are generally classified according to their densities, which are related to the amount of protein and lipid present. Chylomicrons are the largest lipoproteins and are used in the transportation of dietary triglycerides from the intestine to target tissues (e.g. adipose or liver). Very low density lipoproteins (VLDL) shuttle lipids (mostly triglycerides) from the liver to other tissues. Low density lipoproteins (LDL) are used to move cholesterol to various cells. Elevated levels of LDLs are associated with heart disease. Lastly, high density lipoproteins (HDL) are the smallest and also contain the most amount of protein. HDLs function to transport cholesterol from peripheral tissues to the liver to be broken down and excreted in bile. Elevated HDL levels are associated with 'good cholesterol'.

questions.question: What is an important function of the pentose phosphate shunt?
options: Creation of oxaloacetate (OAA) to be used in the Krebs cycle
questions.explanation:
The pentose phosphate shunt has two phases. One of the phases is oxidative in nature and is not reversible. The primary function of this phase is the production of NADPH and the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate (shunted from glycolysis) to ribulose-5-phosphate and carbon dioxide. Ribulose-5-phosphate is used in the synthesis of nucleic acids and nucleotides. The oxidative phase is controlled by the enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G-6-P DH). G-6-P DH is inhibited by elevated levels of NADPH. If this enzyme functions improperly, a deficiency of NADPH will result. NADPH is important for the proper performance of glutathione. Glutathione is a very powerful peptide produced by the body to protect the system from oxidative damage. Accumulation of oxidative damage can be mutagenic. 

The second phase of the pentose phosphate shunt is non-oxidative and reversible. The main purpose of this phase is to shuffle carbons back into the glycolysis pathway by breaking down ribulose-5-phosphate. The two important enzymes to remember in this phase are transketolase and transaldolase. 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase is used for the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, which is then fed into the tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA cycle). The synthesis of pyruvate dehydrogenase is not controlled via the pentose phosphate shunt. 

Ref: Guyton and Hall, Textbook of Medical Physiology 10th ed. (2000) page 775-776.

questions.question: What are the target sites of glucagon?
questions.explanation:
During times of depressed blood glucose levels, glucagon is released by the pancreas. Glucagon then travels to the liver and adipose tissue where it stimulates catabolic pathways. In the liver, glucagon causes the activation of glycogen phosphorylase, causing the breakdown of glycogen. The enzyme fructose-1,6-biphosphatase is also stimulated, which triggers gluconeogenesis. Lastly, glycogen synthase and phosphofructokinase are inhibited, resulting in decreased glycogen synthesis and inhibition of glycolysis, respectively. 

Glucagon also increases the activity of lipase causing hydrolysis of triglycerides in adipose tissue creating free fatty acids which are released into the blood stream and delivered to liver and muscle cells in order to be further broken down for the acquisition of energy.

questions.question: For a given reaction, an overall change in free energy that is negative is indicative of what?
options: The reaction favors the formation of reactants
The overall reaction is not spontaneous
At equilibrium the concentration of products will be lower than the concentration of reactants
This means that the reaction is exergonic
answers: This means that the reaction is exergonic
questions.explanation: A reaction that has a negative change in free energy (delta G) is considered exergonic. The energy of the reactants is greater than the energy of the end products; therefore, the formation of products leads to a release of energy. This type of reaction is spontaneous and favors the formation of products. Because the synthesis of products is favorable, at equilibrium the concentration of products would be greater than the amount of reactants. A reaction with a positive change in free energy is non-spontaneous and endergonic (requires energy); the concentration of the reactants is greater than that of the product at equilibrium.

questions.question: Which of the following characteristics is shared with both RNA and DNA?
options: They both contain the same sugar (ribose) as a backbone
They both contain bases A, C and G
answers: They both contain bases A, C and G
questions.explanation:
Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) contains genetic information necessary for proper function and development of living organisms. It consists of polymers of nucleotides which are linked via phosphodiester bonds. DNA is double-stranded and contains the complementary base AT and CG which are linked in an antiparallel fashion. GC bonds are stronger than AT bonds as they contain more hydrogen bonds (3 vs. 2, respectively). The DNA strands are wound in a right-handed tightly coiled helix. The nucleobases are centered towards the core, causing the center of the helix to be hydrophobic. The DNA backbone is composed of repeating patterns of a sugar (2-deoxyribose which is a 5-carbon sugar) and phosphate groups. 

RNA is single stranded and has a backbone made up repeating units of a ribose sugar and a phosphate group. RNA is not helical but can take on many different secondary structure configurations such as hairpins and loops. RNA contains the base pairs adenine, uracil, cytosine and guanine, whereas DNA utilizes thymine in lieu of uracil.

questions.question: In order to maintain an electrochemical potential across a membrane, what must occur?
options: Three Na+ ions are pumped out of the cell for every two K+ ions pumped into the cell
Two Na+ ions are pumped out of the cell for every three K+ ions pumped into the cell
Two Na+ ions are pumped into the cell for every three K+ ions pumped out of the cell
Three Na+ ions are pumped into the cell for every two K+ ions pumped out of the cell
answers: Three Na+ ions are pumped out of the cell for every two K+ ions pumped into the cell
questions.explanation: Cells maintain an electrochemical gradient so they remain capable of normal regulatory functions. This gradient also allows for the ability of some cells to undergo action potentials. Ion pumps are used to sustain the voltage difference between the outside and inside of the cell. The pump hydrolyzes adenosine triphosphate (ATP) as the energy source used to power the active pumping of three sodium ions out of the cell for every two potassium ions pumped into the cell.

questions.question: Which of the following lipids is involved in inflammation?
questions.explanation:
Eicosanoids are derivatives of arachidonic acid. Examples of eicosanoids include leukotrienes, prostaglandins, and thromboxanes. 

Progesterone, aldosterone, testosterone, estradiol and cortisol are all derived from cholesterol. Cholesterol has a unique configuration comprised of four joined cycloalkane rings. Because these hormones are fat-soluble, they readily pass through cell membranes. They diffuse into the blood and are generally bound to carrier proteins that transport the hormones to their designated target site, where they may further undergo further processing or transformation. 

Triglycerides are comprised of three fatty acid chains attached to a glycerol backbone. Triglycerides are important in long-term energy storage for use by cells. 

Coenzyme Q, all steroids, cholesterol, and vitamins A, D, E, and K are derived from isoprenes or terpenes. These agents contain or at some point originated from precursors that were comprised of isoprene units. Isoprene units have the chemical formula C5H8.
PowerPage
Lipids

questions.question: What is the initiation codon for all proteins?
questions.explanation:
AUG (methionine) is the universal initiation codon for protein synthesis in eukaryotes (ATG for DNA). Stop codons are UAA, UAG, and UGA (for RNA) which terminate protein synthesis. Protein synthesis begins with transcription of messenger RNA from DNA. The mature messenger RNA is then transported into the cytoplasm where the codon AUG signals for the initiation of protein synthesis. The initiation complex is formed via ribosomal subunits, tRNA (transfer RNA), mRNA (messenger RNA), initiation factors and GTP (for energy). The 80s (70s for prokaryotes) ribosomal subunit contains a P site (peptidyl) and an A site (acceptor). The transfer RNA that is bound to methionine (AUG) binds to the P site; and a second tRNA with the proper anticodon sequence and associated amino acid binds to the A site. The amino acids carried by the initial two tRNAs are then bound together via peptidyl transferase and elongation factors. The ribosome then advances three base pairs (one codon) and releases the first tRNA. The P site is now occupied by the second tRNA, which has vacated the A site. The tRNA that contains the appropriate anticodon that matches the codon of the mRNA will then bind to the A site along with its respective amino acid. The new amino acid will bind to the first two amino acids, creating a polypeptide chain. This sequence continues until a stop codon is encountered by the ribosome on the mRNA. At this point releasing factors and ATP causes dissociation of the ribosomal complex and the protein and mRNA are released. The mRNA is decoded from the 5' end to the 3' end. Proteins are synthesized from the N terminal to the C terminal. While it elongates, the amino acids of the polypeptide chain interact, causing folding /looping of the growing protein. 


A great illustration of this is seen at: http://highered.mcgraw-hill.com/olcweb/cgi/pluginpop.cgi?it=swf::535::535::/sites/dl/free/0072437316/120077/micro06.swf::Protein%20Synthesis

questions.question: Which of the following amino acid substitutions occur in the beta subunits of hemoglobin in individuals carrying the sickle cell trait?
options: Valine is substituted for glutamic acid
Glutamic acid is substituted for valine
Arginine is substituted for glutamic acid
answers: Valine is substituted for glutamic acid
questions.explanation:
Patients affected by sickle-cell anemia characteristically have elongated and curved (like a sickle) red blood cells instead of the normal round disc shape seen in healthy patients. Additionally, these individuals have low red blood cell counts due to the fact that the abnormally shaped red blood cells are more fragile than normal cells. The sickle shape can also lead to restriction of blood flow within capillaries, decreasing the amount of oxygen the individual's cells are able to receive. 

The underlying cause of sickle-cell anemia has been traced to a small structural difference in the beta subunits of hemoglobin that occurs in individuals possessing the sickle cell trait. The amino acid valine is substituted for the glutamic acid that is normally in this position. Valine and glutamic acid are very different from each other and cause a significant variation in structure of the red blood cell. The side chain in glutamic acid is ionic, while in valine it is nonpolar. This causes an additional nonpolar region to 'stick out' from the hemoglobin molecule in sickle cells. When hemoglobin is in its deoxygenated state (whether associated with normal or sickle cells), there is a nonpolar cavity formed in another region of the molecule that will attach nicely to the nonpolar region formed by valine in sickle cells. This leads to sickle-cell hemoglobin proteins linking together and forming long chains that can restrict blood flow within capillaries. There are other cases where amino acid substitutions occur within hemoglobin, but they do not result in such severe consequences as this single abnormality. 

Chemisty & Chemical Reactivity. Volume 1 (7th edition). J. Kotz, P. Treichel, J. Townsend. 2009. Thomson Higher Education. Belmont, CA.

questions.question: Use the Henderson-Hasselbach equation to solve the following problem.
options: Calculate the pH of a buffered solution containing 0.2M of sodium benzoate and 0.25M of benzoic acid. Benzoic acid has a pKa of 4.2.
questions.explanation: Henderson-Hasselbach (HH) equation is pH=pKa + log [A-]/[HA]. Plug in the above numbers pH=4.2 +log (0.2)/(0.25) = 4.10. This is a fairly simple equation to memorize; since it is a rather important one, it is advisable to take a few seconds to commit it to memory.

questions.question: Given the Lineweaver-Burk equation below, which component denotes the y intercept when plotted as a graph?
questions.explanation:
The Lineweaver-Burk equation and plot are commonly used to illustrate the kinetic data of an enzyme. 

1/v = (Km/Vm)(1/[S]) + 1/Vm 

Remember the basic formula of a straight line equation y=mx+b. y=the y axis, m=slope, b=the y intercept. 

The linear equation can be applied to the Lineweaver Burk equation. 
1/v=the y axis, Km/Vm= the slope and 1/Vm =the y intercept.

questions.question:
Use the Michaelis-Menten equation to solve the following problem. 
Study hard + ATP (coffee?) = good NBEO results + ADP +Pi 
For the above reaction given, the Km and Vm values of the following five enzymes, which enzyme possesses the fastest reaction rate? The substrate (study hard) concentration is 0.03mM (Assume unlimited ATP supply)
questions.explanation:
The lower the Km value, the higher the affinity for an enzyme to bind to its respective substrate, resulting in a faster reaction rate. The opposite holds true for a higher Km value. 

Of the above enzymes, number 1 possesses the lowest Km value. However, to be certain we should solve for v (reaction rate) by applying the Michaelis-Menten equation.

questions.question: What basic tissue type is responsible for generating apocrine cells?
questions.explanation: Many epithelial cells end up becoming glandular. Glands can be classified by the mechanism in which they secrete. Apocrine cells secrete a portion of their cytoplasm into the secretion. Merocrine glands secrete material without losing any cellular components. Glands can also be classified according to the manner in which they secrete. For example, exocrine glands will secrete their material directly into a duct, while endocrine glands secrete directly into the blood stream.

questions.question: Which of the following values BEST describes the average stromal swelling pressure (SP) of the cornea?
questions.explanation:
When placed in water or an aqueous solution, the corneal stroma will swell, with expansion of the tissue primarily occurring perpendicular to the surface. This stromal swelling is caused by electrostatic repulsive forces between the fixed negative (or anionic) charges associated with corneal stromal glycosaminoglycan (GAG) side-chains present in the tissue. These forces induce an expansive force termed the swelling pressure (SP) of the corneal stroma. Acting against this force is the cohesive and tensile stiffness (elasticity) of the cornea. Due to these corneal properties, the normal swelling pressure is typically around +55 mmHg. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye. (11th edition). 2011. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.F.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. Saunders Elsevier. 

Corneal Surgery: Theory, Technique and Tissue (4th edition). Brightbull, F.S. 2009. Mosby Elsevier.

questions.question: The average cornea possesses approximately how much refractive power?
questions.explanation: The cornea is the major refractive surface of the eye and possesses roughly +43 diopters of power.

questions.question: You are measuring the keratometry values of your keratoconic patient using a manual keratometer. The drum readings do not go high enough to measure the corneal curvatures so you place a +2.25 trial lens to the keratometer to extend the range. Approximately how much do you need to add to the drum reading to obtain the true keratometry values?
questions.explanation:
When measuring the keratometry values utilizing a manual keratometer there are certain circumstances in which the reading may be out of the range of the drum values. In these cases, one will need to add a trial lens to keratometer in order to extend the ranges (lenses are added to the patient's side of the keratometer). Cases in which the curvature is steeper than the drum reading, plus trial lenses are required, and when the reading is flatter than the drum reading, minus trial lenses are necessary. 
In patients with steeper curvatures, typically a +1.25 trial lens is tried first. If a measurement can be found with this lens, one will need to add about 8-9D to the drum reading in order to obtain the true value. A +1.25 lens will extend the range from about 52D to 60 or 61D. 
If keratometry values are even steeper (in the 60-68D range), a +2.25 trial lens can be utilized to extend the drum range even more. In these cases, about 16D is added to the drum reading to reach the true keratometry value. This is the case in the above patient. 
If the curvature is flatter than can be measured with the manual keratometer, a minus lens can be added to extend the range in the opposite direction. Typically a -1.00 trial lens will encompass a keratometry reading from about 32-38D. If a -1.00 lens is added, one will need to subtract 6D from the drum reading.

questions.question: Which of the following values BEST describes the average imbibition pressure (IP) of the corneal stroma?
questions.explanation:
The imbibition pressure of the corneal stroma is due to the anionic (negatively charged) repulsive forces of the glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), which causes the tissue to expand and suck fluid into the cornea. In vitro, the imbibition pressure (IP) and the stromal swelling pressure (SP) are equivalent. However, in vivo, the IP is lower than the SP because the hydrostatic pressure induced by the intraocular pressure must be accounted for. Therefore, the average imbibition pressure of the corneal stroma is approximately -40 mmHg. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye. (11th edition). 2011. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.F.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. Saunders Elsevier. 

Corneal Surgery: Theory, Technique and Tissue (4th edition). Brightbull, F.S. 2009. Mosby Elsevier.

questions.question: Which of the following values most closely corresponds to the average eccentricity of the human cornea?
questions.explanation:
Eccentricity is the measurement of the asphericity of a curved surface. In the case of the human cornea, it indicates the way in which the cornea changes from a more curved central portion to a flatter periphery (also known as a prolate shape). Normal corneal eccentricity values (e values) range between +0.50 and +0.60 in humans. A higher corneal eccentricity value indicates that the cornea flattens more rapidly in the periphery; a lower eccentricity measurement would occur in a patient whose cornea flattened more slowly in the periphery. 

Another way to think of eccentricity is that the 'e' value designates that amount by which the cornea deviates from a perfect sphere (which has an eccentricity value of 0). A parabola has an eccentricity value of 1; a prolate ellipse (as in the normal cornea) will have an eccentricity between 0.1 and 0.9 depending on how fast the peripheral flattening occurs. Lastly, an oblate ellipsoid (as in some post myopic refractive surgical corneas) will have an eccentricity value of between -0.1 and -0.9, depending on how fast the curvature steepens in the periphery.

questions.question: Which of the following values MOST closely corresponds to the average refractive index of the human cornea (round to the nearest .01)?
questions.explanation:
The refractive index of the cornea varies for each corneal layer. Studies have indicated that the refractive index of the epithelium, anterior stroma, and posterior stroma are 1.401, 1.380, and 1.373 respectively. Because the stroma comprises the majority of the thickness of the cornea, the average of the indices of refraction between the anterior and posterior surface of the stroma are typically used to determine the overall mean value of the refractive index of the entire cornea. This value is 1.3765 (or rounded to 1.38 in this case). 

Wavefront Optics for Vision Correction. Dai. G. 2008. Society of Photo-Optical Instrumentation Engineers. Bellingham, WA. 

Refractive Index of the Human Corneal Epithelium and Stroma. Patel, S., Marchall, J., Fitzke, F.W. J Refract Surg. 1995 Mar-Apr;11(2): 100-5.

questions.question: What is the mean horizontal and vertical diameter of the human cornea, respectively (when viewed ANTERIORLY)?
questions.explanation: The human cornea has an elliptical configuration in which the mean horizontal diameter is 11.7mm and the mean vertical diameter is 10.6mm, when viewed anteriorly. Contrastingly, when viewed posteriorly, the cornea is actually circular, with mean horizontal and vertical diameters of 11.7mm. This discrepancy is due to the anterior extension of the opaque sclera superiorly and inferiorly.

questions.question: What is the mean horizontal and vertical diameter of the human cornea, respectively (when viewed POSTERIORLY)?
questions.explanation: The human cornea has an elliptical configuration in which the mean horizontal diameter is 11.7mm and the mean vertical diameter is 10.6mm, when viewed anteriorly. Contrastingly, when viewed posteriorly, the cornea is actually circular, with mean horizontal and vertical diameters of 11.7mm. This discrepancy is due to the anterior extension of the opaque sclera superiorly and inferiorly.

questions.question: According to the FDA, what is the minimum post-treatment residual thickness requirement of the corneal bed for LASIK patients?
questions.explanation: Laser vision correction removes tissue from the cornea; however, at some point the structure of the cornea is adversely affected by having too little tissue remaining. While there have not been any studies that point to a specific depth at which most corneas become at risk, the FDA has set a minimum limit of 250 microns of thickness for the corneal bed in order to minimize the risk of ectasia. To calculate that thickness, a doctor takes the thinnest corneal pachymetry measurement and subtracts the thickness of the proposed corneal flap as well as the thickness of the ablation. The thickness of the ablation increases with increased refractive error and increased higher order aberrations; therefore, greater refractive errors require the ablation of more tissue.

questions.question: The cornea absorbs which of the following amounts of incident UV-A, UV-B, and UV-C light, respectively?
questions.explanation:
The cornea is a major filter for UV light that is incident on the eye. 
- 100% of incident UV-C light (100-280nm) is absorbed by the cornea 
- About 90% of incident UV-B light (280-315nm) is absorbed by the cornea 
- Approximately 60% of incident UV-A light (315-400nm) is absorbed by the cornea 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye. (11th edition). 2011. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.F.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: In cases of epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (EKC), subepithelial infiltrates (SEIs) typically appear within how many days after the onset of the disease?
options: SEIs are not associated with EKC
questions.explanation:
Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis typically runs a common clinical course that begins with characteristic signs and symptoms following an 8-10 day incubation period. Initially, patients will usually complain of eyelid edema, pain, photophobia, and lacrimation. Early conjunctival clinical signs include a mixed papillary and follicular response, hyperemia, chemosis, and subconjunctival hemorrhages that typically last for 7-21 days. In more severe cases, the development of a conjunctival membrane or pseudomembrane is possible. 

Corneal involvement in patients with EKC is variable, but most patients develop diffuse, fine, superficial keratitis within the first week of the onset of the disease. After about 6-13 days, focal punctate epithelial lesions that appear elevated and stain with sodium fluorescein often occur, and by day 14, subepithelial opacities develop under these focal lesions in about 20% of patients. These subepithelial infiltrates may affect vision and can persist for months to years but typically will eventually resolve without scarring or neovascularization.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the average horizontal visible iris diameter (HVID) and vertical visible iris diameter (VVID), respectively?
questions.explanation: Measurements of the horizontal visible iris diameter (HVID) and vertical visible iris diameter (VVID) average about 11.7mm and 10.6mm, respectively. Women typically have about 0.1mm smaller diameters than males, and infants measure about 0.6mm less than the adult-like values.

questions.question: Loss of corneal clarity (also known as corneal decompensation) typically begins to occur once the central endothelial cell density reaches which of the following values?
questions.explanation:
The central corneal endothelial density at birth is typically in the range of 5000 cells/mm2. Unlike some other mammals, humans do not have the ability to regenerate the corneal endothelial cell monolayer after injury or disease; a decline in the central corneal endothelial cell density with age has been well-documented. In early life, there is a faster decrease in endothelial cell density, in which it declines to approximately 3500 cells/mm2 by the age of 5, and to 3000 cells/mm2 by age 14-20. Thereafter, there is a much slower decline in which the cell density decreases at a fairly constant rate of about 0.3 to 0.6% each year. This results in an endothelial cell density of about 2500 cells/mm2 in late adulthood. Even with a steady decline in endothelial cells, the cornea is able to maintain transparency due to the migration, expansion, and thinning of the surviving endothelial cells to cover a larger area (also known as polymegathism and pleomorphism). It is because of these morphological cellular changes that corneal decompensation does not usually occur unless the endothelial cell density reaches a level of 500 cells/mm2, or a 90% decrease from birth. In healthy individuals, there appears to be plenty of reserve remaining after the average human lifespan. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye. (11th edition). 2011. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.F.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: Which of the following values BEST describes the normal cellular density of the corneal endothelium?
questions.explanation: The normal value of the cellular density of the corneal endothelium is 3,000 cells/mm2. A cell density count on specular microscopy that is below 1,000 cells/mm2 is associated with a much higher risk for corneal endothelial decompensation.

questions.question: Which of the following keratometry values is representative of irregular astigmatism?
questions.explanation:
Astigmatism can be classified as either being regular or irregular. Regular astigmatism occurs in individuals in which the principal meridians of the cornea are located 90 degrees apart. That is, the area of the cornea with the flattest curvature (the axis) is oriented perpendicular to the meridian of the steepest curvature. 

In certain ocular conditions such as keratoconus, corneal scarring, or post-surgical corneas, the steep and flat meridians may not be oriented 90 degrees apart. This type of corneal curvature can be considered irregular astigmatism. In these cases, the refractive error is typically not well corrected with spectacles as compared to correction with gas-permeable contact lenses.

questions.question: Given the following keratometry readings, which of the following corneas displays against-the-rule astigmatism?
options: 45.00 D at axis 170 and 43.00 D at axis 80
43.00 D at axis 45 and 41.00 D at axis 135
46.50 D at axis 90 and 44.25 D at axis 180
47.00 D at axis 70 and 43.25 D at axis 160
answers: 45.00 D at axis 170 and 43.00 D at axis 80
questions.explanation: A cornea with against-the-rule astigmatism will display a steeper meridian in the horizontal or near horizontal location. Of the above options, only one fulfills this description.

questions.question: While performing keratometry on your patient, you notice that the reflected corneal mires appear elliptical with the long axis located vertically. Which of the following keratometry values is this patient MOST likely to possess?
options: This is the expected result and the patient does not have astigmatism
questions.explanation: The patient's cornea is steeper horizontally and therefore minimizes the image in this meridian, creating an ellipse with its axis located vertically. Because the flatter meridian is vertical, this patient is most likely to exhibit against-the-rule astigmatism in which the flat meridian of the cornea is located at 90 degrees +/- 30 degrees.

questions.question: What is the approximate average refractive power of the human cornea at birth?
questions.explanation: At the time of birth, the approximate average refractive power of the human cornea is 48 diopters. As emmetropization occurs, the cornea will typically lose about 4 diopters of refractive power by the time a child reaches the age of 2.

questions.question: You are measuring the curvature of your keratoconic patient's cornea using a manual keratometer. You are experiencing difficulty measuring the steep keratometry value as the drum reading does not go high enough. You extend the range by adding a +1.25 trial lens and are able to obtain a reading of 50.50D. Which of the following MOST closely represents the true keratometry value in his steep meridian?
questions.explanation:
When measuring the keratometry values utilizing a manual keratometer there are certain circumstances in which the reading may be out of the range of the drum values. In these cases, one will need to add a trial lens to the keratometer in order to extend the ranges (lenses are added to the patient's side of the keratometer). Cases in which the curvature is steeper than the drum reading, plus trial lenses are required, and when the reading is flatter than the drum reading, minus trial lenses are necessary. 
In patients with steeper curvatures, typically a +1.25 trial lens is tried first. If a measurement can be found with this lens one will need to add about 8-9D to the drum reading in order to obtain the true value. A +1.25 lens will extend the range from about 52D to 60 or 61D. In the case of the above patient, adding about 8.5D will result in a true value of 59.00D. 
If keratometry values are even steeper (in the 60-68D range), a +2.25 trial lens can be utilized to extend the drum range even more. In these cases, about 16D is added to the drum reading to reach the true keratometry value. 
If the curvature is flatter than can be measured with the manual keratometer, a minus lens can be added to extend the range in the opposite direction. Typically a -1.00 trial lens will encompass a keratometry reading from about 32-38D. If a -1.00 lens is added, one will need to subtract 6D from the drum reading.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the average central radius of curvature of the anterior and posterior cornea, respectively?
questions.explanation: The average central radius of curvature for the anterior surface of the cornea is 7.8mm, while the posterior radius of curvature averages 6.5mm. This means that the anterior corneal curvature is flatter than the posterior curvature. In addition to this difference between the two corneal surfaces, the anterior cornea tends to flatten more at the periphery as compared to the posterior surface.

questions.question: Which of the following patients is at the GREATEST risk for developing dry eye after laser assisted in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK)?
options: A 54-year old male with a prescription of -4.00 OU who is taking Zoloft®
A 54-year old female with a prescription of +2.50 OU who is taking Zoloft®
A 25-year old male with a prescription of -2.50 OU who is not taking any medicine
A 54-year old female with a prescription of -2.50 OU who is taking Aspirin
answers: A 54-year old female with a prescription of +2.50 OU who is taking Zoloft®
questions.explanation: Dry eye is the most common side effect from LASIK. Corneal nerves are severed during the procedure, decreasing the neural feedback to the lacrimal gland. Those most at risk are females, patients over fifty years of age, hyperopes, higher refractive errors, Asians and patients on medicines that cause dryness.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions warrants the use of a bandage contact lens?
questions.explanation:
Bandage contact lenses can be used in situations where the corneal surface requires protection from mechanical forces (such as trichiasis or entropion) or from eyelid movement over the exposed area; the bandage contact lenses can be used to promote healing and pain relief (i.e., from a corneal abrasion) and to improve vision while maintaining binocularity. In general, it is best to choose a silicone hydrogel for extended wear purposes that fits a little more steeply to reduce lens movement and mechanical friction (do not seal off the cornea-- some movement is required). 

A dellen is a paralimbal thinning of corneal tissue adjacent to elevated tissue. In general, a dellen can develop beside a pinguecula, pterygium, chemosis or scar tissue secondary to trauma or surgery. This condition arises from uneven tear film distribution, causing desiccation and thinning. If present for a long period of time, scar tissue may develop. 

Corneal arcus is commonly seen in the elderly as a bilateral yellow/white ring that encircles the cornea while maintaining a clear zone between itself and the limbus. The ring occurs due to lipid leakage from limbal blood vessels. Treatment is not generally required as vision is not affected. However, if the patient is under 50 years of age, consider systemic hyperlipidemia and refer for blood work. If the patient is under 40 years of age and presents with arcus, refer for a serum cholesterol measurement. Lastly, if the arcus is unilateral, consider carotid occlusion on the side that DOES NOT display corneal arcus. 

A limbal girdle of Vogt is located in the interpalpebral zone at the 3 and 9 o'clock positions of the cornea and comes in two types. The less common form leaves a clear zone between itself and the limbus and appears as a white/yellow band that remains in the peripheral cornea and is considered to be an early form of band keratopathy. The second form is contiguous with the conjunctiva and may be mistaken for a pinguecula, because there is no clear zone between itself and the limbus. The white-yellow band occurs as a result of collagen breakdown in Bowman's layer. No treatment is necessary.
PowerPage
Corneal Epithelial Wound Healing

questions.question: Which of the following patients is MOST at risk for developing epithelial ingrowth?
options: A patient undergoing LASIK monocularly with a history of having LASIK performed on the contralateral eye 2 years prior
A patient with dry eyes who is undergoing the procedure for the first time
A patient undergoing an enhancement five years after an initial LASIK procedure
A highly myopic patient undergoing LASIK for the first time
answers: A patient undergoing an enhancement five years after an initial LASIK procedure
questions.explanation: Epithelial ingrowth tends to develop several days to weeks post-LASIK and initially presents along the flap edge interface. This condition is caused by the proliferation of surface epithelial cells into the corneal flap interface. Ingrowth is more commonly encountered after enhancement surgeries, particularly if more than two years have passed since the original surgery date. Risk factors for ingrowth are increased for patients who are slightly older, those with epithelial basement membrane dystrophy, those with a history of recurrent corneal erosions, those who frequently rub their eyes, diabetic patients, and those with blepharospasm.

questions.question: What is the best way to determine if a patient's corneal thickness is adequate for LASIK?
options: Ablation, plus the flap thickness, minus the total pachymetry, should be at least 250 microns
Ablation, plus the flap thickness, minus the total pachymetry, should be at least 200 microns
Total Pachymetry, minus the flap thickness, minus the ablation depth, should be at least 250 microns
Total Pachymetry, minus the flap thickness, minus the ablation depth, should be at least 175 microns
answers: Total Pachymetry, minus the flap thickness, minus the ablation depth, should be at least 250 microns
questions.explanation: Laser vision correction removes tissue from the cornea however at some point the structure of the cornea is adversely affected by having too little tissue remaining. While there have not been any studies that point to a specific depth at which most corneas become at risk, the FDA has set a minimum limit of 250 microns of thickness for the corneal bed. To calculate that thickness, a doctor takes the thinnest corneal pachymetry measurement and subtracts the thickness of the proposed corneal flap as well as the thickness of the ablation. The thickness of the ablation increases with increased refractive error and increased higher order aberrations therefore greater refractive errors require the ablation of more tissue.

questions.question: You are performing manual keratometry on your post-LASIK patient and realize that his corneal curvature is so flat that it falls outside of the range of the keratometer. Which of the following trial lenses would extend the range in the proper direction, and what adjustment do you need to make to the reading to obtain the true value?
options: Add a +1.00 lens and subtract 9D from the drum reading
Add a -1.00 lens and subtract 6D from the drum reading
Add a +1.00 lens and add 9D from the drum reading
Add a -1.00 lens and subtract 9D from the drum reading
Add a -1.00 lens and add 6D to the drum reading
Add a +1.00 lens and subtract 6D from the drum reading
answers: Add a -1.00 lens and subtract 6D from the drum reading
questions.explanation:
When measuring the keratometry values utilizing a manual keratometer, there are certain circumstances in which the reading may be out of the range of the drum values. In these cases, one will need to add a trial lens to keratometer in order to extend the ranges (lenses are added to the patient's side of the keratometer). Cases in which the curvature is steeper than the drum reading, plus trial lenses are required, and when the reading is flatter than the drum reading, minus trial lenses are necessary. 
In the case of steeper curvatures, typically a +1.25 trial lens is tried first. If a measurement can be found with this lens, one will need to add about 8-9D to the drum reading in order to obtain the true value. A +1.25 lens will extend the range from about 52D to 60 or 61D. 
If keratometry values are even steeper (in the 60-68D range), a +2.25 trial lens can be utilized to extend the drum range even more. In these cases, about 16D is added to the drum reading to reach the true keratometry value. 
If the curvature is flatter than can be measured with the manual keratometer, a minus lens can be added to extend the range in the opposite direction. Typically a -1.00 trial lens will encompass a keratometry reading from about 32-38D. If a -1.00 lens is added, one will need to subtract 6D from the drum reading. This is the case for the above patient.

questions.question: If your laser assisted in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK) patient is not seeing 20/40 or better on day 1, which of the following is the MOST appropriate action?
options: Adjust the steroid to manipulate the prescription
Start to counsel them about having an enhancement
Perform retinoscopy and evaluate for any dry eye
answers: Perform retinoscopy and evaluate for any dry eye
questions.explanation: The most common reason for reduced uncorrected visual acuity on the one-day post operative visit is dry eye. The goblet cells may be damaged during the procedure and there may also be mechanical damage to the corneal epithelium. Central corneal staining is often seen at the one-day post operative visit. Also, a patient may have over- or under-responded to the treatment. It is best to determine the refractive error of a patient by performing retinoscopy, because this test allows the clinician to also determine if straie or irregular astigmatism could be causing the decrease in vision. Visual acuity can vary greatly during the first week after surgery, so a final determination of the patient's vision cannot be made and glasses are premature at this time.

questions.question: Which type of refractive surgery utilizes radiofrequency energy?
questions.explanation:
Conductive keratoplasty is a type of refractive surgery that is used in the treatment of low amounts of hyperopia (+0.75 to +3.00 D with less than 0.75 D of astigmatism). A thin probe is inserted into the peripheral cornea at specified intervals which delivers radiofrequency energy, causing a shrinking of the surrounding collagen. The circular ring of altered collagen results in a steepening of the central cornea and thus a decrease in hyperopia. The results of CK are temporary and generally do not last more than a few years. The surgery can be repeated. 

Laser thermal keratoplasty (LTK) is also a surgery that is targeted towards presbyopes with low amounts of hyperopia and astigmatism. This procedure utilizes a holmium laser to cause shrinkage of the peripheral corneal collagen, resulting in corneal steepening. Again, LTK is temporary and will generally revert in roughly two to three years. 

Photo-refractive keratectomy (PRK) requires the use of an excimer laser to ablate the corneal epithelium and then refine the underlying tissue. PRK has been used for thin corneas and can eliminate up to roughly 7.00 D of myopia. There are varying levels of discomfort associated with this procedure, and it entails a visual recovery period of two to three weeks. During this time the cornea re-epithelializes. PRK usually requires the use of a bandage contact lens during the immediate recovery period. 

Radial Keratotomy was quite a popular procedure prior to LASIK. This surgery was used to eliminate low amounts of myopia and astigmatism by flattening the cornea via the creation of radial incisions. A hand-held scalpel was used to generate 4-8 cuts (or more). Unfortunately, the results were variable due to lack of precision and reproducibility of incision depth and unpredictable healing effects. RK also requires a long recovery time and can be quite uncomfortable. 

LASIK also utilizes a laser to alter the corneal topography. Past LASIK procedures utilized a microkeratome to cut a flap and expose the underlying corneal stroma for sculpting. It is now more common for the flap to be created by a laser, which provides greater precision and reproducibility of incision depth. Reportedly, LASIK can be used to correct up to 12.00 D of myopia, 6.00 D of astigmatism and 6.00 D of hyperopia. LASIK is currently the refractive procedure of choice due to its good results, increased reliability, quick recovery time and decreased level of discomfort when compared to other refractive surgeries.

questions.question: A 42-year old construction worker presents to you with a history of getting plaster in his right eye. He complains of pain, foreign body sensation, and photophobia. His acuity is reduced in that eye to 20/50 with a normal pupillary response. What type of chemical trauma did the worker experience, and what would be your first therapeutic intervention?
options: Alkali burn and lavage eye with balanced saline solution for 30 minutes
Thermal burn and lavage eye with balanced saline solution for 30 minutes
Acid burn and lavage eye with balanced saline solution for 30 minutes
Ultraviolet (UV) burn and lavage eye with balanced saline solution for 30 minutes
answers: Alkali burn and lavage eye with balanced saline solution for 30 minutes
questions.explanation:
Lime, particularly in the form of plaster, is the most commonly encountered alkali injury. Fortunately, it tends to cause a less severe burn than other types of alkali burns. 

The rapidity with which pH abnormalities of the ocular surface are neutralized has a significant impact on the subsequent clinical course. Irrigation for a minimum of 30 minutes and checking pH of tears for evidence of neutrality is recommended. 

The explanations for the alternative answers are as follows: 

Acid burn and Lavage eye with balanced saline solution for 30 minutes; 
plaster contains lime, which is alkali and not acid. 

Thermal burn and lavage eye with balanced saline solution for 30 minutes; 
there is no mention of heat (cigarette or matches) during the injury to the eye. 

Ultraviolet (UV) burn and lavage eye with balanced saline solution for 30 minutes; UV burns usually are associated with delayed response after exposure to UV light. 


References: 
1. McCulley JP, Chemical Injuries. Smolin G, Thoft RA eds. The Cornea: scientific foundation and clinical practice, 2nd ed. 1987: 527-542 
2. Herr RD, White GL, Clinical comparison of ocular irrigation fluids following chemical injury, Am J of Emerg Med 1991: 9:228-231

questions.question: While awake, what is the major source of oxygen used by the cornea?
questions.explanation: Tears absorb oxygen from the air which then diffuses into the cornea. Oxygen is required by the endothelium and the epithelium because they are metabolically active. A small amount of oxygen is also supplied by the limbal blood vessels and by diffusion from the aqueous. However, due to the large amount of oxygen required by the cornea, most of the oxygen during periods of wakefulness is derived from the tears. For this reason, it is important that contact lens patients be fitted with lenses that offer high oxygen permeability.

questions.question: The stem cells of the corneal epithelium originate from which location on the eye?
questions.explanation: The epithelial stem cells are located within the palisades of Vogt. These white, linear structures traverse radially around the cornea and are more prominent inferiorly than superiorly. They are clearly evident right on the edge of the limbus and extend to blend invisibly with the cornea. The palisades serve as housing for blood vessels, nerves, connective tissue and lymphatics. Most importantly, the palisades have been proven to contain stem cells that can be stimulated for renewal of aging/damaged epithelial cells. Axenfeld loops are generally seen in the sclera as sometimes raised areas of pigment. These loops are formed by nerves that initially course one way and then turn back on themselves. Goblet cells secrete the mucous layer of the tear film and are found primarily in the conjunctiva.

questions.question: A 24-year old female patient is seen at your office and reports that her eyes have been red for a few days. Biomicroscopy reveals bilateral diffuse superficial punctate keratitis (SPK) that stains with sodium fluorescein with no mucopurulent discharge. Based ONLY upon the corneal staining pattern, what is the MOST likely origin of her condition?
questions.explanation:
Diffuse SPK likely signals either a viral origin or a toxic reaction to solution or topical ophthalmic drops. 

A bacterial etiology will cause staining of the inferior third of the cornea. 

Interpalpebral corneal staining is usually caused by lagophthalmos or environmental desiccation. 

A foreign body will either leave small punctate staining or tracks (especially if it is trapped under a contact lens).

questions.question: A patient walks into your office with a mild corneal abrasion, what is the correct healing sequence?
options: Basal cells at the wound margin flatten and spread-> attachment of cells via fibronectin and laminin-> mitosis of cells surrounding wound area-> hemidesmosome formation between basal cells
Hemidesmosome formation between basal cells-> basal cells at the wound margin flatten and spread-> mitosis of cells surrounding wound area-> attachment of cells via fibronectin and laminin
Basal cells at the wound margin flatten and spread-> mitosis of cells surrounding wound area-> attachment of cells via fibronectin and laminin-> hemidesmosome formation between basal cells
Mitosis of cells surrounding wound area-> attachment of cells via fibronectin and laminin-> hemidesmosome formation between basal cells-> basal cells at the wound margin flatten and spread
answers: Basal cells at the wound margin flatten and spread-> mitosis of cells surrounding wound area-> attachment of cells via fibronectin and laminin-> hemidesmosome formation between basal cells
questions.explanation:
Following minor corneal injuries, the main concern is for the cornea to seal off the wound and form tight junctions as quickly as possible to prevent edema and infection. The first phase following an abrasion is the sloughing off of superficial cells at the wound margin. This is followed by a flattening of basal cells surrounding the wound which then move into the damaged area via filpodia (extensions that allow for amoeboid-type motion). Mitosis rates increase surrounding the injury site to replace those cells that have migrated. The basal cells then secrete fibronectin and laminin to achieve transitory cellular attachment until the formation of hemidesmosomes. Once a basal cell comes in contact with another basal cell, a hemidesmosome forms signaling for a decrease in mitosis.
PowerPage
Corneal Epithelial Wound Healing
