Flexure of a gas-permeable contact lens will result in an increase in over-refraction cylinder in the opposite meridian of the corneal toricity
Toric peripheral curves result in an oval optic zone and spherical peripheral curves result in a circular optic zone
Polishing or adding power to a front surface toric contact lens is an easy, in-office modification
answers: Optics of bitoric contact lenses are usually not as crisp as those of the base curve toric design
SPE bitoric contact lenses act optically like a spherical lens
questions.explanation:
The following statements are true in regards to gas-permeable contact lenses: 

SPE bitoric contact lenses act optically like a spherical lens 
- When prescribed, SPE bitoric lenses will not have any effect on the over-refraction cylinder, and lens rotation on the eye will not alter vision or the refractive error measured; therefore, they are typically used in patients with high amounts of corneal cylinder and low amounts of residual astigmatism (when a spherical diagnostic lens is placed on the eye) 

Optics of bitoric contact lenses are usually not as crisp as those of the base curve toric design 
- In cases where a CPE bitoric lens is considered, it is important to first rule out the possibility of a base curve toric lens 
- These lenses tend to be cheaper, have better optics, and in-office modification and polishing are possible 

Polishing or adding power to a base curve toric contact lens is an easy, in-office modification due to the spherical front surface of the lens 

Toric peripheral curves result in a circular optic zone, and spherical peripheral curves result in an oval optic zone 
- With spherical peripheral curves, the meridian with the flatter base curve will have the larger optic zone diameter 
- Toric peripheral curves typically allow for better lens stabilization 

Flexure of a gas-permeable contact lens will result in an increase in over-refraction cylinder in the same meridian of the corneal toricity 
- If a gas-permeable lens flexes or warps on an against-the-rule cornea there will be an increase in against-the-rule cylinder in the over-refraction 
- On a with-the-rule cornea, lens flexure will lead to an increase in with-the-rule cylinder, which may be beneficial in cases where a decrease in against-the-rule cylinder is desired

questions.question: The Dk value of a contact lens refers to which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
The Dk value of a contact lens (hard or soft) is the industry standard for the measurement of the oxygen permeability of a particular lens. A higher Dk value corresponds to a greater amount of oxygen permeability of a material. The 'D' in Dk represents diffusion; the k represents solubility. When the thickness of a lens is taken into consideration, one can calculate the oxygen transmissibility, which is represented by Dk/t. 

Manual of Contact Len Prescribing and Fitting (3rd edition). Hom, M.M., Bruce, A.S. 2006. Butterworth Heinemann Elsevier. St. Louis, MO.

questions.question: A 53-year old female soft contact lens patient is seen at your office reporting symptoms of dry eyes while wearing her contact lenses. Her current medications include anti-hypertensive pills and blood thinners. Which of the following dry eye treatments should NOT be recommended to her?
questions.explanation: In general, all of the above choices would be acceptable options; this is especially true because the patient is taking medications to help regulate her blood pressure (these medications can have the side effect of dry eye symptoms). Patients taking blood thinners should check with their primary care doctor before beginning an omega III regimen. Omega III fish oil can cause an increase in blood clotting time, which can be dangerous when used in combination with blood thinners.

questions.question: At the initial dispensing visit your gas-permeable (GP) contact lens patient achieves visual acuity of 20/15 through both her manifest refraction and contact lens over-refraction. At a follow-up visit one year later, the patient's visual acuity is 20/30 with her spectacle blur (manifest) refraction and 20/15 with the contact lens over-refraction. What is the most likely cause for the reduced visual acuity obtained through the spectacle blur refraction?
options: Corneal distortion secondary to GP contact lens wear
answers: Corneal distortion secondary to GP contact lens wear
questions.explanation: If a patient achieves visual acuities of 20/15 through both her spectacle prescription and GP contact lenses, neither the 'internal' portion of the eye nor the cornea are decreasing the patient's vision. If the patient's VAs are 20/40 through both her spectacle prescription and GP contact lenses, the reduction in vision is caused by an internal condition such as macular degeneration or a cataract. The decreased acuity may also be due to an external factor such as corneal scarring. If the patient's VAs are 20/40 through her spectacle prescription and 20/15 through her GP contact lenses, the patient probably has an irregular corneal surface such as keratoconus. If the patient's VA's through her spectacle prescription is 20/15 and 20/40 through her GP lenses, the reduction in contact lens VA is probably caused by a dirty or distorted GP contact lens.

questions.question: What is the most effective 'procedure' for removing lipid deposits from an existing soft contact lens?
options: Switch to hydrogen peroxide-based care system
questions.explanation:
Rubbing with a cleaner or multi-purpose solution containing a surfactant will remove lipid deposits that are not bound to the lens surface. Lipids tend to readily deposit on today's silicone hydrogel lenses. 

Thimerosal, a mercurial antibacterial effective against Gram-positive bacteria, was a component of some soft lens care solutions from the 1970's and 1980's. There were many reports of cytotoxicity to the corneal epithelium, leading to Type IV hypersensitivity and patient discomfort. 

Enzyme treatment utilizing papain- or pancreatin-based products attacks denatured tear proteins accumulated on the lens surface or in the lens matrix. Heat-based care systems tended to denature proteins onto the lens surface. 

Most current hydrogen peroxide-based lens care systems do not contain a rubbing component to the procedure. Rubbing is instrumental in removing lipid deposition. 

Alternatively, if the deposits are numerous, one can replace the lens with a brand new one.

questions.question: Which of the following ophthalmic instruments is MOST commonly used to evaluate the edge profile of a rigid gas-permeable contact lens?
questions.explanation:
A shadowscope is an instrument commonly used with rigid gas-permeable contact lenses in order to inspect several aspects of the lens. It provides about 20x magnification and projects the contact lens on a glass screen with a reticule for measurements. Shadowscopes are often used for evaluating the contour and thickness of the edge of the contact lens. It is also commonly utilized to measure the overall diameter of the lens, as well as the width of the intermediate and peripheral curves. The shadowscope is also useful in showing any scratches, cracks, or nicks in the edge of the lenses. 
- A radiuscope is used to measure the base curve of a rigid gas-permeable contact lens 
- A V-channel gauge aids in measuring the overall diameter of the contact lens 
- A 7x comparator is a handheld measuring magnifier that is useful for measuring the overall diameter, optic zone diameter, and peripheral curve diameter, as well as overall inspection of the lens for scratches, etc. 
- A lensometer is used to measure the power of the contact lens

questions.question: When analyzing a rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lens, you measure base curves of 7.30 (46.25) and 7.54 (44.75) with a radiuscope, and -3.75 and -6.00 on lensometry. What type of toric gas-permeable contact lens design do you have?
questions.explanation:
The first measurement that should be made when analyzing RGP contact lenses is lensometry. Lenses should be placed concave side down on the aperture stop, and the power and axis wheels should be rotated until mires are clear and lined up. If cylinder is present, powers should be recorded in both major meridians (record gross amounts). After lensometry, lenses should be analyzed using the radiuscope. Again, once the sharpest focus of mires is found, both base curves should be measured and recorded. Base curves should be converted from millimeters to diopters. The steep meridian is recorded over the flat meridian, and the most plus meridian goes with the flat meridian. 

For the above patient, the measurements are as follows: 
46.25 -6.00 
44.75 -3.75 
The next step is to determine the values of the difference in base curves and the difference in contact lens power. For this patient, the difference in base curves is 1.50D and the difference in contact lens power is 2.25D. 
- If the difference in base curve is multiplied by 3/2 and that value is equivalent to the contact lens power then you have a Toric Base Curve lens (with spherical front surface) 
o For this patient (3/2) x (1.50) = 2.25 and difference in CL power = 2.25 
o 2.25 = 2.25 therefore, this is a Toric Base Curve lens design 
o Note that 'equivalent' is defined as less than or equal to 0.50D 
- If the difference in base curve is equal to the difference in contact lens power then you have a spherical power effect (SPE) bitoric lens design 
- If the difference in base curve is not equivalent to the difference in CL power, and 3/2 x the difference in base curve is also not equal to the difference in CL power then you have a cylinder power effect (CPE) bitoric lens

questions.question: Which of the following rigid gas-permeable (RGP) lens designs is MOST appropriate for a patient presenting with corneal toricity of 0.50D at axis 090, and 1.75D of residual cylinder axis 090 on over-refraction (when a spherical RGP diagnostic lens is placed on the eye)?
questions.explanation:
The following chart represents guidelines for lens selection when prescribing rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lenses. This will aid in determining which type of RGP lens is best for your patient, depending on the patient's corneal toricity and residual over-refraction cylinder values (when a spherical GP diagnostic lens is placed on the eye). 

The above patient presents with a minimal amount of corneal toricity, so a lens with a toric back surface is not required. A spherical contact lens; however, will not provide adequate vision, as there is significant residual cylinder (lenticular) on over-refraction. In these cases, a Front Surface Toric (F1 toric) lens is most appropriate as the base curve will be spherical, and the front surface will be toric to account for the residual cylinder.

questions.question: Which of the following rigid gas-permeable (RGP) lens designs is MOST appropriate for a patient presenting with corneal toricity of 2.00D at axis 160, and 0.50D of residual cylinder on over-refraction (when a spherical RGP diagnostic lens is placed on the eye)?
questions.explanation:
The following chart represents guidelines for lens selection when prescribing rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lenses. This will aid in determining which type of RGP lens is best for your patient, depending on the patient's corneal toricity and residual over-refraction cylinder values (when a spherical GP diagnostic lens is placed on the eye). 
For the above patient, a spherical RGP contact lens is the most appropriate lens choice. After placing a spherical diagnostic RGP lens on the patient's eye, the over-refraction is only 0.50D. Any over-refraction less than or equal to 0.75D will typically provide excellent vision, and a toric lens design is not needed.

questions.question: You are designing a rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lens for your patient who presents with keratometry reading of 46.50 x 43.00 @ 090, and manifest refraction of -1.50 -6.00 x 090. With a spherical RGP diagnostic lens placed on the eye, the over-refraction is -0.50 -3.50 x 090. Which of the following RGP lens designs is MOST appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The following chart represents guidelines for lens selection when prescribing rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lenses. This will aid in determining which type of RGP lens is best for your patient, depending on the patient's corneal toricity and residual over-refraction cylinder values (when a spherical GP diagnostic lens is placed on the eye). 

The above patient presents with 3.50D of corneal toricity and 3.50D of residual cylinder on over-refraction. Cases in which corneal toricity and residual cylinder are both high would benefit from a cylinder power effect (CPE) bitoric RGP contact lens.

questions.question: When analyzing a gas-permeable lens, you measure base curves of 7.58 and 7.84 with a radiuscope, and -1.00 and -2.50 on lensometry. What type of toric gas permeable contact lens design do you have?
questions.explanation:
In order to determine which design of toric gas-permeable contact lens you have once the lens has been analyzed, the difference in base curve (BC) values and contact lens power (CLP) readings must be calculated first. 

BC1 = 7.58 = 337.5/7.58 = 44.50 
BC2 = 7.84 = 337.5/7.84 = 43.00 
Change in BC = 1.50 D 

CLP1 = -1.00 
CLP2 = -2.50 
Change in CLP = 1.50 D 

The differences in base curves and contact lens powers for the above gas-permeable contact lens are equal (both 1.50 D), indicating that the design of the lens is a spherical power effect (SPE) bitoric type. 

If the change in BC does not equal the change in CLP, the lens type may either be a base curve toric or cylinder power effect (CPE) bitoric. 

Clinical Contact Lens Practice. Bennet, E.S., Weissman, B.A. (2005). Philadelphia, PA. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins 

Manual of Contact Lens Fitting and Prescribing (3rd ed.). Hom, M.M., Bruce, A.S. (2006). St. Louis, MO. Butterworth Heinemann Elsevier

questions.question: You are designing a rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lens for your patient who presents with keratometry reading of 43.75 x 40.50 @ 100, and manifest refraction of +1.00 -4.50 x 100. With a spherical RGP diagnostic lens placed on the eye, the over-refraction is -0.50 -1.50 x 100. Which of the following RGP lens designs is MOST appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The following chart represents guidelines for lens selection when prescribing rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lenses. This will aid in determining which type of RGP lens is best for your patient depending on the patient's corneal toricity and residual over-refraction cylinder values (when a spherical GP diagnostic lens is placed on the eye). 

The above patient presents with 3.25D of corneal toricity and 1.50D of residual cylinder on over-refraction. Both corneal and residual cylinders are the same axis, and the over-refraction cylinder amount is about 1/2 of the amount of the corneal toricity. In cases such as this, a Toric Base Curve lens is most appropriate and can be calculated to compensate for the residual cylinder.

questions.question: Which of the following alterations will help to loosen a tightly-fitting gas-permeable lens?
options: Steepen the base curve of the lens
Reduce the size of the optic zone
Reduce the width of the peripheral curve system
answers: Reduce the size of the optic zone
questions.explanation: There are a multitude of alterations that can be made when a lens is fitting too tightly, many of which can be done in-office if a modification unit is available. If a gas-permeable lens is fit too tightly, the most commonly altered parameter is flattening of the base curve. One can also decrease the optic zone, decrease the overall diameter (OAD), widen the peripheral curve system, or flatten the peripheral curve system. In order to modify a lens that is fitting too loosely, simply reverse all of the above: steepen the base curve, increase the OAD, increase the optic zone, steepen the peripheral curve system, and narrow the width of the peripheral curves.

questions.question: Your spherical gas-permeable contact lens patient returns for a dispense appointment once the contact lens you ordered arrives from the lab. You place the lens on the eye and observe a tight fit in which there is minimal movement of the lens. Which of the following changes could be ordered from the lab to allow for better alignment?
options: Reduce the width of the peripheral curves
questions.explanation:
Lens modifications that may be made in order to loosen a tight-fitting lens include: 
- Reduce the overall diameter 
- Reduce the optic zone width 
- Flatten the base curve 
- Flatten the peripheral curves 
- Widen the peripheral curves 
- Increase the blend between the peripheral curve 

All of these procedures can be done with in-office modification except for flattening of the base curve; however, in cases of prism ballasted front-surface toric lenses, reducing the overall diameter in-office will significantly reduce the amount of ballast present and may cause excess lens rotation 

In order to tighten a loose lens, the opposite changes in lens parameters stated above will allow for this adjustment.

questions.question: Your 23 year-old rigid gas-permeable contact lens wearer returns to your office for a contact lens follow-up after wearing his new lenses for about 2 weeks. During slit-lamp evaluation you notice several circular, well-demarcated indentations of the central cornea that pool with fluorescein. What is the name of this finding?
questions.explanation:
Dimple veiling is a finding that occurs almost exclusively in rigid gas-permeable contact lens wearers (but can occur with scleral lenses due to mucin ball formation). Several circular, well-demarcated indentations are found in the cornea, either central or peripheral, that pool with fluorescein (they do not stain, as they do not represent breaks in the corneal epithelium). Dimple veiling is caused by a sub-optimal fitting relationship of a rigid gas-permeable contact lens in which tiny air bubbles that become trapped beneath the contact lens and are then mechanically compressed by the lens, indenting the cornea. Patients are typically asymptomatic; however, if sufficient in number, the dimples may interfere with vision, producing glare, hazy vision, and/or a loss of contrast sensitivity. 

Dimple veiling is transient and will resolve within a few hours if the contact lens is removed from the cornea. Longer-term treatment involves modification of the fitting relationship of the contact lens, such as flattening the base curve, decreasing the optical zone diameter, blending the junction between the base curve and peripheral curve, or steepening the peripheral curves to allow for better tear exchange beneath the lens. 

Dimple veiling has also been shown to occur in a few cases of soft contact lens wear. In these cases, mucin balls composed of mucus, lipids, and proteins can build up on the contact lens and create a similar corneal finding.

questions.question: Long-term wear of a superior positioning 'lid attachment' gas-permeable (GP) fitting relationship will typically result in which one of the following corneal topography patterns?
questions.explanation: Lid attached GP lenses are often prescribed with a flat or apical touch fitting relationship. Because the GP lens positions superiorly, this will tend to result in a physical flattening of the superior cornea and a steepening of the inferior cornea. The topography map will be similar in appearance to keratoconus. To verify that the topography is due to the GP fit as opposed to keratoconus, lens deprivation or refitting with a more center lens position will slowly change the topography to a more normal image. Also, keratoconus patients often have clinical corneal signs of striae, Fleisher's ring, and/or corneal scarring, indicative of keratoconus.

questions.question: When analyzing the fit of a gas-permeable contact lens, you observe pooling of sodium fluorescein under the center of the lens along with minimal peripheral clearance. In order to fix this problem, what parameters of the lens should be adjusted?
options: The base curve should be flattened
The contact lens material should be changed
The center thickness should be decreased
The contact lens power should be adjusted
The base curve should be steepened
answers: The base curve should be flattened
questions.explanation: The above lens was fit with excess apical clearance. Increased levels of clearance can interfere with corneal metabolism. In order to solve this problem, one must flatten the base curve of the lens. A flatter base curve will bring the contact lens closer to the apex of the cornea and also flatten out the peripheral curves in order to ensure adequate peripheral clearance.

questions.question: The presence of dimple veiling in a rigid gas-permeable contact lens wearer is MOST often due to which of the following?
options: The formation of microcysts due to epithelial corneal edema
Spherical particles of mucous, lipids, and proteins that are present under the lens and press on the cornea
Inflammation due to decreased availability of oxygen to the cornea
Air bubbles trapped beneath the lens due to poor tear exchange
answers: Air bubbles trapped beneath the lens due to poor tear exchange
questions.explanation:
The presence of dimple veiling in a patient wearing rigid gas-permeable contact lenses occurs secondary to tiny air bubbles that become trapped beneath the lens. These air bubbles are then mechanically compressed by the contact lens, causing indentations in the anterior surface of the cornea. 

Soft contact lens wearers may also show signs of dimple veiling; however, this finding in these patients is due to spherical particles consisting of mucous, lipids, and proteins, that build-up on the contacts and press on the cornea. Dimple veiling from mucin balls can also occur in RGP wearers, but it is much less likely than dimple veiling caused by air bubble formation.

questions.question: Which of the following will occur if you increase the water content of a soft hydrogel contact lens?
options: The patient will report an increase in dry eye symptoms
The tendency of lens deposits will decrease
answers: The patient will report an increase in dry eye symptoms
questions.explanation:
As the water content of a soft hydrogel contact lens increases, generally the durability of the lens will decrease, the permeability of the lens will increase as will deposit formation and dry eye symptoms. 
This is also mostly try for silicone-hydrogel lenses, except for the fact that with these lenses, as water content increases, the permeability of the lens tends to decrease.

questions.question: Your patient undergoes pre-testing and reports that she was wearing her +5.00 D soft contact lenses while non-contact tonometry (NCT) was performed. How would you expect this finding to alter the test results?
options: The measured intraocular pressure will remain unaffected
The measured intraocular pressure will be falsely elevated
The measured intraocular pressure will be falsely lowered
NCT should never be performed over soft contact lenses
answers: The measured intraocular pressure will be falsely elevated
questions.explanation:
Studies have demonstrated that NCT performed over soft contact lenses generally does not affect the results unless the power of the lens is greater than +3.00 D due to increased center thickness (and therefore increased rigidity). Lenses greater than +3.00 D cause a falsely elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) when NCT is performed over the contact lenses. Research has also purported that when NCT is performed over minus-powered soft contact lenses (greater than -6.00 D), the IOP tends to be underestimated, with a direct relationship between increasing degree of myopia and increased underestimated values. 

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16303525 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19593202

questions.question: Soft lenses are ideal for sports because they tend to dislodge less than gas-permeable lenses. Which of the following occurs when a soft lens dehydrates?
options: The contact lens power becomes more plus
questions.explanation: When a soft contact lens dehydrates, the contact lens power increases in minus, the overall diameter and the thickness decrease while the index of refraction increases. Clinically, it is important to monitor the base curve because as a contact lens dehydrates, its base curve steepens, especially in people with dry eyes. When a contact lens steepens, it can tighten up and can seal off the cornea, causing edema as well as eye infections. In contrast, when a soft contact lens is hydrated, its base curve flattens, the overall diameter and the thickness increase, the contact lens power increases in plus, and the index of refraction decreases.

questions.question: Increasing silicone content and decreasing water content will have what effect on the oxygen transmissibility of soft contact lenses?
options: The oxygen transmissibility will not be affected
questions.explanation: Increasing silicone content and decreasing water content will increase overall oxygen permeability and transmissibility; this combination might also increase the propensity for lipid deposition and may increase the modulus of the material. Silicone hydrogel materials tend to have an inverse relationship between Dk and water content.

questions.question: While fitting a patient with a gas-permeable lens, you notice that there is a lot of fluorescein pooling under the lens and decide to change the base curve from 45.00 D to 44.25 D. Based on these new parameters, how should you adjust the prescription?
options: The prescription should be increased by +0.75 D
More information is required to answer this question
The prescription should be decreased by -1.25 D
The prescription should be increased by +1.25 D
The prescription should be decreased by -0.75 D
answers: The prescription should be increased by +0.75 D
questions.explanation: A good rule of thumb to follow is that of SAM FAP (Steep Add Minus, Flat Add Plus). When altering a base curve, one must also adjust the prescription due to changes in the tear film. Flattening the base curve of a lens induces a minus tear film; therefore, to offset this power change one must add plus power to the prescription. On the other hand, steepening of the base curve induces a plus tear film and therefore must be compensated for by adding minus to the prescription.

questions.question: The prescription of a gas-permeable lens is generally found on which location of the lens?
questions.explanation: The optic zone is the central portion of the lens and, as the name implies, aligns with the pupil and neutralizes the patient's refractive error.

questions.question: For a gas-permeable lens, what happens to the following parameters as the oxygen permeability of the lens is increased (Dk)?
options: The wettability increases, the durability decreases, the lens flexes/warps more easily, the ability of the lens to resist scratches increases
The wettability increases, the durability increases, the lens flexes/warps less easily, the ability of the lens to resist scratches decreases
The wettability decreases, the durability decreases, the lens flexes/warps more easily, the ability of the lens to resist scratches decreases
The wettability decreases, the durability increases, the lens flexes/warps less easily, the ability of the lens to resist scratches increases
answers: The wettability decreases, the durability decreases, the lens flexes/warps more easily, the ability of the lens to resist scratches decreases
questions.explanation: As one increases the Dk of a gas-permeable lens, the amount of oxygen that is able to reach the cornea increases; however, the wettability of the lens decreases. This hurdle can be overcome by adding fluorine, which helps to increase the wettability and increase deposit resistance. As the Dk increases, the lens also becomes less durable and can become prone to scratching, flexure, and warping.

questions.question: When analyzing a gas-permeable lens, you measure base curves of 7.58 and 7.84 with a radiuscope, and -1.00 and -2.50 on lensometry. What type of toric gas-permeable contact lens design do you have?
questions.explanation:
In order to determine which design of toric gas-permeable contact lens you have once the lens has been analyzed, the difference in base curve (BC) values and contact lens power (CLP) readings must be calculated first. 

BC1 = 7.58 = 337.5/7.58 = 44.50 
BC2 = 7.84 = 337.5/7.84 = 43.00
Change in BC = 1.50 D 

CLP1 = -1.00 
CLP2 = -2.50 
Change in CLP = 1.50 D 

The differences in base curves and contact lens powers for the above gas-permeable contact lens are equal (both 1.50 D), indicating that the design of the lens is a spherical power effect (SPE) bitoric type. 

If the change in BC does not equal the change in CLP, the lens type may either be a base curve toric or cylinder power effect (CPE) bitoric. The way to tell these two apart is that if 3/2 change in BC = change in CLP, then it may be considered a base curve toric.

questions.question: If your patient has been wearing rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lenses for 20 years, how long before he undergoes refractive surgery should he discontinue wear of his contact lenses?
options: Time is not the issue when refraction and keratometry are stable
answers: Time is not the issue when refraction and keratometry are stable
questions.explanation: The amount of time that a patient needs to be out of their contact lenses prior to refractive surgery varies from patient to patient and surgeon to surgeon. In regards to rigid gas-permeable contact lenses, a good starting point is to let the patient know that on average, they will need to discontinue their contact lenses for about 1 month per decade of RGP contact lens wear. So, for the above patient, one could estimate that it may take about 8 weeks for the cornea to stabilize. However, time is not really the issue here. What is important is that the refraction, keratometry, and topography values are all stable prior to undergoing surgery. For some people this can take much less or much more time than expected.

questions.question: When analyzing a rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lens, you measure base curves of 7.71 (43.75) and 8.44 (40.00) with a radiuscope, and -4.25 and +2.50 with lensometry. What type of toric gas-permeable contact lens design do you have?
questions.explanation:
The first measurement that should be made when analyzing RGP contact lenses is lensometry. Lenses should be placed concave side down on the aperture stop and the power and axis wheels should be rotated until mires are clear and lined up. If cylinder is present, powers should be recorded in both major meridians (record gross amounts). After lensometry, lenses should be analyzed using the radiuscope. Again, once the sharpest focus of mires is found, both base curves should be measured and recorded. Base curves should be converted from millimeters to diopters. The steep meridian is recorded over the flat meridian, and the most plus meridian goes with the flat meridian. 
For the above patient, the measurements are as follows: 
43.75 -4.25 
40.00 +2.50 
The next step is to determine the values of the difference in base curves and the difference in contact lens power. For this patient, the difference in base curves is 3.75D and the difference in contact lens power is 6.75D. 
- If the difference in base curve is multiplied by 3/2 and that value is equivalent to the contact lens power then you have a Toric Base Curve lens (with spherical front surface) 
o For this patient (3/2) x (3.75) = 5.62 and difference in CL power = 6.75 
o 5.62 is not equivalent to 6.75 (This lens is not a toric base curve design) 
o Note that 'equivalent' is defined as less than or equal to 0.50D 
- If the difference in base curve is equal to the difference in contact lens power then you have a spherical power effect (SPE) bitoric lens design 
o For the above patient difference in base curve is 3.75D and difference in CL power is 6.75D 
o 3.75 is not equivalent to 6.75 (This lens is not an SPE bitoric design) 
o Again, note that 'equivalent' is defined as less than or equal to 0.50D 
- If the difference in base curve is not equivalent to the difference in CL power, and 3/2 x the difference in base curve is also not equal to the difference in CL power then you have a cylinder power effect (CPE) bitoric lens 
o This lens follows these rules; therefore, it can be considered a CPE bitoric lens design

questions.question: You are designing a rigid gas permeable (RGP) contact lens for your patient who presents with keratometry reading of 44.25 x 41.00 @ 180, and manifest refraction of -2.50 -3.00 x 180. With a spherical RGP diagnostic lens placed on the eye, the over-refraction is +0.50 -0.25 x 180. Which of the following RGP lens designs is MOST appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The following chart represents guidelines for lens selection when prescribing rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lenses. This will aid in determining which type of RGP lens is best for your patient, depending on the patient's corneal toricity and residual over-refraction cylinder values (when a spherical GP diagnostic lens is placed on the eye). 

The above patient presents with 3.25 diopters of corneal cylinder, which is typically above the threshold for a spherical RGP contact lens. Although a spherical lens would provide a low cylinder over-refraction (as shown when a diagnostic lens is placed on the eye), the fit of a spherical lens on a cornea with over 2.50 D of toricity would not be ideal. Because the above patient has high amounts of corneal astigmatism and a very low amount of cylinder on over-refraction, a spherical power effect (SPE) bitoric lens would be the most appropriate option. An SPE bitoric lens will improve the fit of the contact lens with a toric surface but will not change the cylinder amount on over-refraction. 

The spherical power effect lens has a toric curve on the front surface of the contact lens to compensate for the astigmatic power induced by the toric back surface of the lens. Since the lens has a spherical power effect, the patient does not see any changes in vision with blinking if the lens rotates on the eye.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the proper method of measuring the contact lens 'lag' on your soft contact lens-wearing patient?
options: With the patient looking in primary gaze, have them blink and measure the amount of contact lens movement that occurs during the blink
With the patient looking in primary gaze; measure the amount of movement of the contact lens occurs when it is gently pushed up with manipulation of the lid
Have the patient move from primary gaze to superior gaze; measure the amount the soft contact lens drops
Have the patient move from primary gaze to lateral gaze; measure the amount the soft contact lens moves relative to the cornea
Have the patient look in primary gaze without blinking; measure the amount of inferior decentration of the soft contact lens
answers: Have the patient move from primary gaze to lateral gaze; measure the amount the soft contact lens moves relative to the cornea
questions.explanation:
The following describes the proper procedure for measuring certain aspects of the fitting relationship of soft contact lenses: 
- Lag: Have the patient move from primary gaze to lateral gaze; measure the amount the soft contact lens moves relative to the cornea 
- Sag: Have the patient move from primary gaze to superior gaze; measure the amount the soft contact lens drops 
- Centration: Have the patient look in primary gaze without blinking; measure the amount of decentration (if present) of the soft contact lens; this may be in any direction 
- Movement on Blink: With the patient looking in primary gaze, have them blink and measure the amount of contact lens movement that occurs during the blink 
- Push-up test: With the patient looking in primary gaze; measure the amount of movement of the contact lens occurs when it is gently pushed up with manipulation of the lid
PowerPage
Soft Contact Lens Evaluation

questions.question: Your 46 year-old female patient wishes to wear soft contact lenses as monovision. He currently wears distance contact lenses in both eyes, is left eye dominant, and requires a +1.50 add power. Based on the following data, which of the following contact lenses would you prescribe for each eye?
options: Current distance CL Rx: OD: +1.25 OS: +1.00
questions.explanation:
Because the above patient is left eye dominant, his left eye would be considered the distance eye and the right eye would be used for near vision. 
The patient is currently wearing distance Rx in both eyes, and distance over-refraction is +0.25 in the right eye; therefore we would first determine the proper distance Rx, which would be +1.25 +0.25 = +1.50. Then, in order to determine the near Rx for this eye, we would simply add the near requirement to the proper distance Rx; +1.50 +1.50 = +3.00. 
For the left eye, the patient is also wearing distance Rx, and the distance over-refraction has a plano equivalent sphere; therefore we would continue with the same contact lens Rx in this eye for distance; +1.00.

questions.question: Your 54 year-old female patient wishes to wear soft contact lenses as monovision. She currently wears distance contact lenses in both eyes, is right eye dominant, and requires a +2.00 add power. Based on the following data, which of the following contact lenses would you prescribe for each eye?
options: Current distance CL Rx: OD: -2.50 OS: -1.00
Distance over-refraction: OD: plano OS: +0.25 -0.50 x 180
questions.explanation:
Because the above patient is right eye dominant, her right eye would be considered the distance eye and the left eye would be used for near vision. 
The patient is currently wearing distance Rx in both eyes, and distance over-refraction is plano in the right eye; therefore we would keep the right contact lens prescription the same in this eye (-2.50). 
For the left eye, the patient is also wearing distance Rx, and the distance over-refraction has a plano equivalent sphere. In order to determine the near Rx for this eye, we would simply add the near requirement to her current distance Rx; -1.00 +2.00 = +1.00.

questions.question:
Your 28 year-old female patient wears rigid gas-permeable contact lenses. The following parameters are for her right eye: 
Keratometry: 44.50 @ 090 x 43.50 @ 180 
Base curve of RGP: 43.25D (apical alignment with 1.00D of with-the-rule toricity) 
Which 2 of the following would you expect to occur to the apical relationship if you suspect that her contact lens is warped by 0.50D? (Select 2)
options: The apical relationship will become apical clearance
The apical relationship will become apical touch
The amount of with-the-rule toricity will remain the same
The amount of with-the-rule toricity will decrease
The apical relationship will remain the same
The amount of with-the-rule toricity will increase
answers: The amount of with-the-rule toricity will decrease
The apical relationship will remain the same
questions.explanation:
When a rigid gas-permeable contact lens warps, the apical relationship will not change. If a lens is apical alignment and the lens warps by any amount, the average base curve will remain the same; therefore, the apical relationship will continue to be apical alignment. On the other hand, the amount of toricity present when analyzing the fitting relationship will change; the toricity will decrease by the amount of warpage. 

In the above example, if the RGP lens warped by 0.50D, the apical relationship will remain the same (apical alignment), and the amount of toricity will decrease by the amount of warpage (from 1.00D to 0.50D).

questions.question:
Your 19 year-old patient wears rigid gas-permeable contact lenses with the following base curve and power, respectively: 
OD: 42.25 / +3.00DS and OS: 43.50 / +2.50DS 
She reports that after she put her contacts on this morning, her vision was blurred at distance especially in the right eye. You suspect that she may have accidentally switched the lenses. If this were the case, what would you expect the over-refraction to be for each eye? (Assuming that the over-refraction is plano with the proper lenses and fit is apical alignment OD, OS)
questions.explanation:
OD: 42.25 / +3.00DS OS: 43.50 / +2.50DS 
With these lenses, fit is apical alignment and over-refraction is plano. 

OD: 43.50 / +2.50DS (switched)
This lens will create apical clearance by 1.25DS; this would add +1.25D created by the positive tear meniscus. 
-1.25D would then be manifested in the OR to offset the plus power created. 

The switched lens is +0.50D undercorrected in power and will require +0.50D in the OR to offset this. 

Expected OR: -0.75DS

OS: 42.25 / +3.00DS (switched) 
This lens will create apical touch by 1.25DS; this would add -1.25D created by the negative tear meniscus. 
+1.25D would then be manifested in the OR to offset the minus power created. 

The switched lens is +0.50 overcorrected in power and will require -0.50D in the OR to offset this. 

Expected OR: +0.75DS

questions.question:
Your 26 year-old patient wears rigid gas-permeable contact lenses with the following base curve and power, respectively: 
OD: 44.37 / -1.00DS and OS: 44.00 / -1.50DS 
He reports that after he put his contacts on this morning, his vision was blurred at distance, especially out of the left eye. You suspect that he may have accidentally switched the lenses. If this were the case, what would you expect the over-refraction (OR) to be for each eye? (Assuming that the over-refraction is plano with the proper lenses and fit is apical alignment OD, OS)
questions.explanation:
OD: 44.37 / -1.00DS OS: 44.00 / -1.50DS 
With these lenses, fit is apical alignment and over-refraction is plano. 

OD: 44.00 / -1.50DS (switched).
This lens will create apical touch by 0.37DS; this would add -0.37D created by the negative tear meniscus. 
+0.37D would be manifested in the OR to offset the minus power created. 

The switched lens is -0.50D overcorrected in power and will require +0.50D in the OR to offset this. 

Expected OR: +0.87DS

OS: 44.37 / -1.00DS (switched). 
This lens will create apical clearance by 0.37DS; this would add +0.37D created by the positive tear meniscus. 
-0.37D would be manifested in the OR to offset to plus power created. 

The switched lens is -0.50D undercorrected in power and will require -0.50D in the OR to offset this. 

Expected OR: -0.87DS

questions.question: The Dk/t value of a contact lens refers to which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
The Dk/t value of a contact lens (hard or soft) refers to the oxygen transmissibility of a particular contact lens. Oxygen transmissibility is therefore directly proportional to the oxygen permeability of a material (Dk) and inversely proportional to the average thickness of a lens material (t). In most cases of published Dk/t values, contact lens companies will use a standard -3.00D contact lens prescription to calculate this value. 

Manual of Contact Len Prescribing and Fitting (3rd edition). Hom, M.M., Bruce, A.S. 2006. Butterworth Heinemann Elsevier. St. Louis, MO.

questions.question:
The following gas-permeable contact lenses provide your patient with an alignment fitting relationship and a plano DS over-refraction OU: 
OD: 43.25 D base curve / -2.87 D power 
OS: 42.87 D base curve / -2.00 D power 
If the patient inserts the above lenses into the wrong eyes (right lens inserted into left eye and left lens inserted into right eye), what over-refraction would you predict?
questions.explanation:
Solution by inspection of data 

Before lens switch: 

OD: 43.25 / -2.87 gave alignment fit and plano DS OR 
OS: 42.87 / -2.00 gave alignment fit and plano DS OR 

Lenses switched: 
OR changes by 
OD: new lens (42.87) flatter by 0.37D (SAM-FAP) +0.37 DS 
new lens (-2.00) more plus power by 0.87D -0.87 DS 
Resultant OR = -0.50 DS 

OS: new lens (43.25) steeper by 0.37D (SAM-FAP) -0.37 DS 
new lens (-2.87) more minus power by 0.87D +0.87 DS 
(P)OR = +0.50 DS 

SAM-FAP (Steep Add Minus, Flat Add Plus)

questions.question:
You obtain the following data during your GP contact lens evaluation: 
OD Diagnostic CL: 43.37 / -2.87
OD Distance OR: -0.50-0.25 X 90 
OD Fluorescein Pattern: Alignment
OS Diagnostic CL: 42.87 / -3.25 
OS DIstance OR: -0.75 DS 
OS Fluorescein Pattern: Flat by 0.37 D 
It is decided that monovision is the best option for this 51-year old patient who requires a +1.75 D add. Testing reveals that the right eye is dominant. You prescribe the rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lenses to fit alignment on both eyes. What contact lens powers would you order?
questions.explanation:
The right eye's trial lens fitting relationship is already alignment, so you would add the equivalent sphere of the OR (-0.62 D) to the power of the trial lens (-2.87). This results in a power of -3.50 D. Since the right eye is dominant and will be correcting distance vision and the fitting relationship of the trial lens is alignment, you do not need to further adjust the lens power. 

For the left eye, adding the trial lens power (-3.25 D) to the OR (-0.75DS) results in a power of -4.00 D. You would order this power if you were prescribing a 42.87 D base curve for distance viewing. However, you desire to prescribe a 43.25 D base curve to achieve an alignment fitting relationship. To compensate for the steeper base curve, you will need to adjust the power by -0.37 D, resulting in a distance correcting power of -4.37 D (SAM-FAP). To prescribe a near monovision lens for the left (non-dominant) eye, you add the add power (+1.75 D) to the -4.37 D value. The final contact lens power for the left eye will be -2.62 D.

questions.question: At approximately what age does the globe reach its adult size?
questions.explanation:
The globe reaches its adult size by about 3 years of age while the orbit does not reach its adult size until around 16 years of age. 

Recent research demonstrates that the globe may continue to grow until puberty. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 118

questions.question: In a developing toddler, resolution acuity (as determined by forced-choice looking) normally reaches adult levels by what age?
questions.explanation:
A one-month old infant possesses roughly 20/600 acuity as measured via the forced-choice preferential looking test. Normal 20/20 Snellen acuity is not generally reached until roughly 3-5 years of age due to retinal immaturity, particularly the cone receptors. On the other hand, visual evoked potentials (VEPs) have demonstrated that adult levels are actually reached by 6 to 8 months. 

Reference: Schwartz, S. Visual Perception: A Clinical Orientation 2nd edition 1999 pp. 369-373
PowerPage
Visual Systems Development Norms

questions.question: The onset of stereopsis generally occurs at which age?
questions.explanation:
Stereopsis rapidly develops in infants and is present by 3-5 months of age. 

References: 
Advances in Pediatrics, Dutta, AK, Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers (2007) page 1045. 

Visual Development, Diagnosis, and the Treatment of the Pediatric Patient, Duckman, R. Lippincott, Williams and Wilkins (2006) page 132.

questions.question: A one-year old child is able to discern 6 cycles/degree via the forced-choice preferential looking test. What is the correlating Snellen acuity?
questions.explanation:
The forced-choice preferential looking test enlists gratings instead of optotypes and does not require the patient to respond verbally, making it ideal for those that are physically unable to orally participate. The examiner displays two stimuli, one is a grey pattern; the other is a grating. Both stimuli possess equal average luminance profiles. Infants prefer looking at gratings rather than a homogenous background, so the infant's eyes will gravitate towards the grating so long as they can resolve it. The examiner views the child's eyes while observing through a peephole. The examiner is not privy as to which side contains the grating and therefore must guess using the preferred gaze of the infant. This is repeated again with the same grating (mixing up the side of placement so that the examiner does not know where the grating is located). The results are then plotted to determine the infant's grating acuity. 

To determine the Snellen acuity, simply divide 600 by 6. The result will be the Snellen denominator. 600/6=100, therefore 20/100 is the Snellen fraction of the infant.

questions.question: At what age does the retinal vasculature reach the nasal and temporal periphery, respectively?
options: 8 months of gestation, 1 month after birth
answers: 8 months of gestation, 1 month after birth
questions.explanation: The retina is a very unique tissue because it does not contain any blood vessels until the fourth month of gestation. At this time, arteries and veins begin to emanate from the hyaloid vessels at the optic disc and grow towards the peripheral retina. These blood vessels eventually reach the nasal periphery after 8 months gestation, but do not reach the temporal periphery until about 1 month after birth.

questions.question: At what age does stereopsis reach adult-like levels?
questions.explanation:
Although stereopsis is present at 3 to 5 months of age, it does not actually reach adult-like levels until 5-7 years of age. 

References: Moseley, M and Fielder, A. Amblyopia: A Multidisciplinary Approach (2002) page 106. 

Advances in Pediatrics, Dutta, AK, Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers (2007) page 1045.
PowerPage
Visual Systems Development Norms

questions.question: Which 3 of the following retinal cells develop from the inner neuroblastic layer of the developing neural retina? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
The inner neuroblastic layer becomes the ganglion cells, amacrine cells, and Muller cells. The outer neuroblastic layer becomes the bipolar cells, horizontal cells, and photoreceptor cells. Note that in the developed retina, the nerve fiber layer and ganglion cell layer are composed of only cells from the inner neuroblastic layer (ganglion cells). The inner plexiform layer, inner nuclear layer, and outer plexiform layer of the developed retina consist of cells from both developmental layers (amacrine cells, Muller cells, bipolar cells, and horizontal cells). The outer nuclear layer and photoreceptor layer are composed only of cells from the outer neuroblastic layer (photoreceptors). 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 p 112

questions.question: In the second gestational month, the eyelids develop from folds of surface ectoderm filled with mesenchyme that grow toward each other over the developing cornea. The eyelids meet and fuse around week 10 of development. When do the eyelids separate?
questions.explanation:
Fusion of the eyelids early in gestation protects the eye from amniotic fluid and may play an important role in preventing keratinization of the cornea and conjunctiva. Between months 5 and 6, the desmosomes that held the lids together break down and allow separation. Lipid secretions from the meibomian glands may play a role in the separation. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 118

questions.question: During ocular development, the neural tube forms and the ectoderm can be divided into the neural ectoderm (which lines the neural tube) and the surface ectoderm (which is around the tube). The neural crest develops from a fold of ectoderm between the neural ectoderm and surface ectoderm. Which of the following 3 structures arise from the surface ectoderm? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
The surface ectoderm gives rise to the lens, corneal epithelium, conjunctival epithelium, lacrimal gland, epithelium of the eyelids, meibomian glands, and epithelial lining of the nasolacrimal system. The neural ectoderm gives rise to the retinal pigment epithelium, neural retinal fibers of the optic nerve, neuroglia, ciliary body epithelium, and the iris epithelium (including both the iris sphincter and dilator). The neural crest gives rise to the corneal stroma, corneal endothelium including Descemet's membrane, most of the sclera, trabecular structures and uveal pigment cells. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 103-104

questions.question: During embryonic development, what is the name of the artery that supplies nutrients to the lens and later dissolves to form the canal of Cloquet?
questions.explanation: The hyaloid artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery and is important for delivering nutrients to the lens and structures behind the lens during development. The artery disintegrates before birth leaving a canal in the primary vitreous called Cloquet's canal. Remnants of this artery are often perceived as 'floaters'.

questions.question: Retinoblastoma is considered the most common primary intraocular tumor in children. During the development of which eye structure is the tumor likely to arise?
questions.explanation: This malignancy arises during the development of the retina as a result of mutation in the Rb tumor-suppressor gene.

questions.question: During ocular development, the neural tube forms and the ectoderm can be divided into the neural ectoderm (which lines the neural tube) and the surface ectoderm (which is around the tube). The neural crest develops from a fold of ectoderm between the neural ectoderm and surface ectoderm. Which of the 3 following structures are derived from neural crest cells? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
The neural crest gives rise to the corneal stroma, corneal endothelium including Descemet's membrane, most of the sclera, trabecular structures and uveal pigment cells. The surface ectoderm gives rise to the lens, corneal epithelium, conjunctival epithelium, lacrimal gland, epithelium of the eyelids, meibomian glands and epithelial lining of the nasolacrimal system. The neural ectoderm gives rise to the retinal pigment epithelium, neural retinal fibers of the optic nerve, neuroglia, ciliary body epithelium, and the iris epithelium (including the iris sphincter and dilator). 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 103-104

questions.question: Which of the primary germ layers of embryonic development take part in the development of ocular structures?
questions.explanation:
The three primary germ layers are the endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm. Of these layers, only the ectoderm and mesoderm are involved in ocular development. The endoderm is involved in development of the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory tract, endocrine organs, urinary bladder, and auditory epithelium. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 103

questions.question: Which cells are the last to develop within the neural retina?
questions.explanation: Ganglion cells are the first to develop within the neural retina. This is followed by horizontal cells, cones, amacrine cells, bipolar cells, rods, and finally Mueller cells. Interestingly, the macular area begins differentiation first but is the last to develop completely.

questions.question: During fetal development, which quadrant of the peripheral retina is the last to become fully vascularized?
questions.explanation: The retina is a unique tissue due to the fact that it is avascular until about the fourth month of gestation. At this time, arteries and veins begin to emanate from the hyaloid vessels at the optic disc and grow towards the peripheral retina. These blood vessels ultimately first reach the nasal periphery after 8 months gestation. The last area to become vascularized is the temporal retina, which occurs about 1 month after birth. The incompletely developed retinal vascular system at birth is what causes a premature infant to be particularly susceptible to oxygen damage, which can lead to the development of retinopathy of prematurity.

questions.question: How does the contrast sensitivity function of an infant change as the infant matures from 1-month old to 1-year old?
options: It shifts up and to the left
It shifts down and to the left
It shifts down and to the right
It shifts up and to the right
answers: It shifts up and to the right
questions.explanation: The contrast sensitivity function of an infant shifts up and to the right as the infant grows. This makes sense intuitively because as the resolution acuity progressively improves, the high spatial frequency cut-off of the infant will also increase, inducing a right shift of the curve. The peak of the curve reaches adult levels (4 cycles per degree) by roughly six months of age.

questions.question: The developing embryo is comprised of several major layers. Which of these layers is a major contributor to the development of the neurological structure of the eye?
questions.explanation:
The ectoderm is comprised of surface and neural ectoderm and plays a major role in ocular development. It is also responsible for the development of the brain, spinal cord, and other structures such as skin and hair. The mesoderm is responsible for the development of the notochord, muscles, dermis, connective tissue, and circulatory system. 

It is important to note that the mesoderm does contribute to the development of the eye by way of supplying the ocular muscles and necessary connective tissue; but it is not the major contributor to the neural structures of the eye. 

The endoderm is involved in the development of glands, digestive tract, and respiratory tract. This layer has no contribution to the development of the eye. 

Basiderm is a term meant to distract and is not one of the major layers of the developing embryo.

questions.question: Which of the following congenital anomalies occurs if the optic vesicle fails to reach the surface ectoderm due to interference with closure of the neural tube?
questions.explanation:
Anophthalmos is when no eye forms. It can occur if the optic vesicle either fails to form as an outgrowth of the wall of the diencephalon or if the optic vesicle does not reach the surface ectoderm due to interference with closure of the neural tube during expansion of the optic vesicle. 

Microphthalmia is when a normal but smaller eye develops; it occurs when the optic vesicle contacts a smaller than normal area of the surface ectoderm. 

Congenital glaucoma likely has a complex pathogenesis but is associated with a poorly differentiated, thickened trabecular meshwork. 

A keratolenticular stalk is a persistent stalk connecting the lens to the cornea and occurs when the lens vesicle fails to detach from the surface ectoderm. A keratolenticular stalk is characteristically seen in Peter's anomaly. 

Iris coloboma involves the pigment epithelium and stroma giving rise to a keyhole pupil; it results from incomplete closure of the choroidal fissure. 


Ref: Trachimowicz, R. Review of Embryology and its Relation to Ocular Disease in the Pediatric Population. Optometry and Vision Science. 71:3 pp 154-163

questions.question: During embryonic development, the region known as the telencephalon eventually develops into which of the following structures of the brain?
questions.explanation:
In early embryonic development, the brain is divided into three primary portions: the prosencephalon (forebrain), mesencephalon (midbrain), and rhombencephalon (hindbrain). As development proceeds, these three major vesicles will begin to differentiate and separate into 5 main vesicles. The prosencephalon will separate into the telencephalon and diencephalon. The telencephalon eventually becomes the cerebrum (cerebral cortex, white matter, and basal ganglia), while the diencephalon forms four distinct components including the thalamus, subthalamus, hypothalamus, and epithalamus. 

The mesencephalon is also known as the midbrain and is located below the cerebral cortex and above the hindbrain; it does not separate any further. 

The rhombencephalon is the third vesicle of the brain in early developmental stages and ultimately becomes divided into the myelencephalon and metencephalon. The myelencephalon forms the medulla oblongata, while the metencephalon forms the pons and cerebellum. 

Neuroscience: Exploring the Brain (3rd edition). Bear, M.F., Connors, B.W., Paradiso, M.A. 2007. Lippincott Williams and Wilkins. Baltimore, MD. 

Essential Developmental Biology (2nd edition). Slack, J.M.W. 2006. Blackwell Publishing. Malden, MA.

questions.question: During embryonic development, the optic vesicle forms as an extension of which of the following regions of the brain?
questions.explanation:
In early embryonic development, the brain is divided into three primary portions; the prosencephalon (forebrain), mesencephalon (midbrain), and rhombencephalon (hindbrain). As development proceeds, these three major vesicles will begin to differentiate and separate into 5 main vesicles. The prosencephalon will separate into the telencephalon and diencephalon. The telencephalon eventually becomes the cerebrum (cerebral cortex, white matter, and basal ganglia), while the diencephalon forms four distinct components including the thalamus, subthalamus, hypothalamus, and epithalamus. It is from the diencephalon that the optic vesicles form, eventually invaginating to form the optic cup and the optic stalk, which will later become the retina and optic nerve. 

The mesencephalon is also known as the midbrain, which is located below the cerebral cortex and above the hindbrain. 

The rhombencephalon is the third vesicle of the brain in early developmental stages, and ultimately becomes divided into the myelencephalon and metencephalon. The myelencephalon forms the medulla oblongata, while the metencephalon forms the pons and cerebellum. 

Neuroscience: Exploring the Brain (3rd edition). Bear, M.F., Connors, B.W., Paradiso, M.A. 2007. Lippincott Williams and Wilkins. Baltimore, MD. 

Essential Developmental Biology (2nd edition). Slack, J.M.W. 2006. Blackwell Publishing. Malden, MA.

questions.question: During ocular development, the pupillary membrane consists of which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
During the third month of development, mesenchymal cells migrate between the lens epithelium and the corneal epithelium to form a transitory network of blood vessels anterior to the lens. This is the pupillary membrane. At 6 months of development, the central blood vessels atrophy and the peripheral vessels contribute to the lesser circle of the iris. By 8.5 months of development, the central vessels fragment and disappear, although they can sometimes persist and appear as web-like projections attached to the iris surface. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 114-116

questions.question: From which of the following germ cell layers is the crystalline lens derived from?
questions.explanation:
Unlike the rest of the human eye, which is mostly derived from the neural ectoderm, the crystalline lens is formed from surface ectoderm. 

The first stage of lens differentiation begins at the 4mm embryonic stage, in which the lens plate (placode) forms from surface ectoderm adjacent to the optic vesicle (formed from neural ectoderm), beginning around day 27 of development. At this stage, the lens placode is a single monolayer of columnar cells. As development progresses, the outer surface of the lens plate deepens and invaginates to form a lens pit, which continues to invaginate until it forms the lens vesicle. By the 10mm stage, the lens vesicle completely separates from the surface ectoderm (around day 33) and forms a hollow sphere consisting of a single layer of cells. After the lens vesicle is formed, posterior epithelial cells become the primary lens fibers and form the embryonic lens nucleus at the center of the developing lens. The anterior cells stay in place at this time, and the equatorial cells divide and elongate to form secondary lens fibers around the embryonic nucleus. The lens capsule is apparent at about 5 weeks; it originates from the basement membrane of the surface ectoderm and from secretions of the lens epithelium.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly lists the progressive development of ocular structures in order from earliest to latest?
options: Ocular pits, ocular stalk, ocular vesicles, optic cup, optic fissure
Ocular vesicles, ocular pits, ocular stalk, optic cup, optic fissure
Ocular pits, ocular vesicles, ocular stalk, optic fissure, optic cup
Ocular vesicles, ocular stalk, ocular pits, optic fissure, optic cup
Ocular stalk, ocular pits, ocular vesicles, optic cup, optic fissure
answers: Ocular pits, ocular vesicles, ocular stalk, optic fissure, optic cup
questions.explanation:
The neural tube forms from ectoderm along the dorsal aspect of the embryo around day 22. The optic pits are indentations that form along the neural tube near the forebrain region. Around day 25, the optic pits form sac-shaped extensions that gradually separate from it; these are known as optic vesicles. As an optic vesicle invaginates, the optic stalk is formed from the tissue joining the optic vesicle to the neural tube. The retinal disc is formed by thickening and flattening of the optic vesicle. The optic vesicle and stalk invaginate inward, forming the optic fissure (also known as the embryonic fissure, choroidal fissure, or fetal fissure). The edges of the optic fissure grow toward each other and start to fuse at about 5 weeks into development, closing at 7 weeks and forming the two-layered optic cup. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 103-107

questions.question: Development of the eye is coordinated by the neural ectoderm and mesoderm. The embryonic fetal fissure is the last structure to close to allow for the development of what?
questions.explanation: The embryonic fetal fissure allows passage of the mesenchyme so that the hyaloid artery plexus can form. Eventually the hyaloid plexus within the vitreous cavity will regress; however, it persists as the central retinal artery posteriorly. If the embryonic fetal fissure fails to close, a coloboma will result. Inferior colobomas are the most common.

questions.question: Retinal colobomas result from an incomplete closure of which of these developing structures?
questions.explanation:
Incomplete closure of the optic fissure alters development of the optic cup and can lead to development of a coloboma of the retina, ciliary body, or iris. Retinal colobomas result in large blind spots, usually in the upper visual field. Many children with retinal colobomas prefer to be upside-down and to scoot or 'bottom-shuffle' to best utilize their available visual field. 

Neural tube defects generally are defects of the brain and spinal cord such as spina bifida and anencephaly. Optic pits are very early developmental structures, forming around day 25 as evaginations in the area of the forebrain. The lens placode is the precursor to the lens. The transient layer of Chievitz appears between the inner and outer neuroblastic layers of the developing retina. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 107

questions.question: During embryonic growth, which of the following portions of the developing central nervous system eventually becomes the pons and cerebellum?
questions.explanation:
In early embryonic development, the brain is divided into three primary portions: the prosencephalon (forebrain), mesencephalon (midbrain), and rhombencephalon (hindbrain). As development proceeds, these three major vesicles will begin to differentiate and separate into 5 main vesicles. The prosencephalon will separate into the telencephalon and diencephalon. The telencephalon eventually becomes the cerebrum (cerebral cortex, white matter, and basal ganglia), while the diencephalon forms four distinct components including the thalamus, subthalamus, hypothalamus, and epithalamus. The mesencephalon is also known as the midbrain, and is located below the cerebral cortex and above the hindbrain. It does not separate any further. The rhombencephalon is the third vesicle of the brain in early developmental stages and ultimately becomes divided into the myelencephalon and metencephalon. The myelencephalon forms the medulla oblongata, while the metencephalon forms the pons and cerebellum. 

Neuroscience: Exploring the Brain (3rd edition). Bear, M.F., Connors, B.W., Paradiso, M.A. 2007. Lippincott Williams and Wilkins. Baltimore, MD. 

Essential Developmental Biology (2nd edition). Slack, J.M.W. 2006. Blackwell Publishing. Malden, MA.

questions.question: During gestation, when does the secondary vitreous begin to develop?
questions.explanation: The primary vitreous develops at around the third week of gestation. It is formed by mesoderm. The secondary vitreous begins to develop during the ninth embryonic week and later becomes the mature vitreous. The secondary vitreous stems from primary vitreal cells and retinal glial cells and therefore originates from neuroectoderm. The secondary vitreous expands to fill the globe while compacting the primary vitreous in the center of the globe.

questions.question: How does the optokinetic response in a young infant compare to that of an adult?
options: The optokinetic response in adults is asymmetrical with the nasal to temporal direction being superior
There is marked asymmetry monocularly, with the response being better in the temporal to nasal direction
The optokinetic response in young infants is the same as that of adults
The optokinetic response cannot be measured until the age of three
answers: There is marked asymmetry monocularly, with the response being better in the temporal to nasal direction
questions.explanation:
The optokinetic response can be observed in very young infants with marked asymmetry monocularly, with the temporal to nasal direction being superior. The response becomes symmetrical at roughly 4-6 months of age, although the asymmetry does persist into adulthood with the temporal to nasal direction being minutely better. 

Reference: Ansons, A and Davis, H. Diagnosis and Management of Ocular Motility Disorders 3rd edition (2001) page 102.

questions.question: Which two layers of the iris are derived from mesoderm?
options: The stroma and the posterior pigmented epithelium
The posterior pigmented epithelium and the anterior limiting layer
The stroma and the anterior epithelium
The anterior limiting layer and the stroma
The epithelium and the posterior pigmented epithelium
answers: The anterior limiting layer and the stroma
questions.explanation:
The iris can be classified into four layers. The most external is the anterior limiting layer, followed by the stroma, the anterior epithelium and the posterior pigmented epithelium which is the most internal layer. The first two layers are derived from mesoderm. 

The anterior limiting layer contains numerous melanocytes and fibroblasts. Interestingly, this layer is not present over Fuch's crypts. The anterior limiting layer is not uniform and varies in density across the entirety of the iris. There is some debate as to whether or not this layer exists and therefore can be simply classified as stroma. 

The stroma is the thickest layer of the iris and is comprised mostly of collagen. The stroma houses many structures including; blood vessels, pigmented cells, nerves and the sphincter muscle. 

The epithelial layers are derived from neuroectoderm.

questions.question: When attempting to determine whether or not an elderly patient has the capability to drive an automobile, which of the following tests is the BEST measure of their risk assessment?
questions.explanation: Ball et al, 1993 have determined that assessing the useful field of vision is a good indicator used to predict the potential risk of an elderly patient causing a car accident or getting into a car crash. The useful field of view assesses the elderly patient's ability to divide their attention between images that are foveally fixated and those that are seen simultaneously by the peripheral retina. Basically this test determines the extent of a person's visual attention to stimuli residing in the visual field. Obviously, individuals with a small useful field of vision are more likely to be implicated in a car accident. Although visual acuity and even visual fields are important tests to conduct, they do not explain why elderly patients are more frequently involved in auto accidents, nor can they be used as predictive values to assess accident related risk.

questions.question: You wish to perform a visual field on a patient with advanced glaucoma using a Humphrey Field Analyzer. Which of the following visual field programs will BEST allow for monitoring of changes to or progression of visual field loss?
questions.explanation:
A patient with advanced glaucoma should be monitored using a threshold 10-2 test which tests 68 test points, 2 degrees apart in a central 10 degree area. Patients with advanced glaucoma possess a central island of vision, and therefore it is important to monitor for change within this region. A 40 point screener, 30-2 or 24-2 threshold visual field presents too many test points that lay outside of the patient's area of useable vision and therefore do not provide useful information. A 30-2 field tests 76 points, 6 degrees apart within a central 30 degree radius. A 24-2 field presents a total of 54 points within a central 24 degree region (except nasally where it extends out to 30 degrees). When treating patients with advanced glaucoma, the objective is to save the central acuity. If the glaucoma is not adequately controlled, progression will cause a splitting of fixation due to inward advancement of the superior nasal field defect followed by inferior field loss due to encroachment of the nasal defect. 

References: 
Shared Care Glaucoma, A Clinical Text for Ophthalmic Allied Professionals. Alwitry, A. Blackwell Publishing, 2008, page 144. 
Pearls of Glaucoma Management. Giaconi, J. et al. Springer, 2010, page 124.

questions.question: A patient reports a history of past trauma to the orbit. You perform gonioscopy and notice areas of angle recession. What degree of damage is typically observed before the onset of glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
Angle recession is typically caused by orbital trauma, resulting in a tear between the longitudinal and circular muscles of the ciliary body. This broadening of the ciliary body band can lead to glaucoma secondary to damage to the trabecular meshwork, particularly if the damage exceeds more than 270 degrees. 

Reference: 
Gonioscopy: A Text and Atlas. Dada, T., Sharma, R &Sobti, A. Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers, 2013, page 75.
PowerPage
Gonioscopy

questions.question: Your patient recently had argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT) performed to help decrease her intraocular pressure (IOP). At which time interval would you expect the best IOP-reducing response to occur?
questions.explanation:
Argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT) treatment typically takes about 4-6 weeks for best response. If intraocular pressure (IOP) reduction is significant at this time, gradual withdrawal of topical medications may be attempted. 
If IOP is still inadequate, the other 180 degrees of trabecular meshwork can be treated (if not having been done at the initial visit); alternately, filtration surgery should be considered (further ALT treatment is unlikely to be beneficial).

questions.question: Fluctuations in intraocular pressure are normal within a certain range. What is the average diurnal variation of intraocular pressure for a person who does not suffer from glaucoma?
questions.explanation: The average intraocular pressure (IOP) is around 15 mmHg (+/- 2.57). Pressures for most people (those who do not suffer from glaucoma) fall within 10.5-20.5 mmHg. IOP can fluctuate between 3-6 mmHg on a daily basis resulting most likely resulting from a change in aqueous production rather than aqueous drainage. This may be related to nocturnal hypotension. A fluctuation of greater than 10mmHg is usually indicative of glaucoma.

questions.question: A patient with narrow angles at risk for angle-closure is accidently dilated with 1% tropicamide by a staff member at your office. After the instillation of drops, what time period is the patient MOST likely to experience angle-closure?
questions.explanation: Patients with occludable angles who are dilated are most at risk for angle-closure 90 minutes after the instillation of mydriatic drops when the pupil beings to recover from dilation and reaches a mid-dilated position.

questions.question: Which perimetric target/technique given below tests the magno cellular pathway of the retina?
options: A blue target on a yellow background utilized in short wavelength automated perimetry (SWAP)
A white target on a white background such as that used in standard automated perimetry
Counterphase flickering targets found in frequency doubling technology
answers: Counterphase flickering targets found in frequency doubling technology
questions.explanation: When a stimulus is presented to the retina, it stimulates the photoreceptors, and the information is transmitted to the brain by either magno, parvo, or konio cellular pathway. A white stimulus on a white background will not isolate any particular pathway, and all mechanisms will be stimulated. A blue stimulus on a yellow background suppresses the mid-range and long-range cones and selectively stimulates the blue/yellow opponent pathway or konio cellular pathway. A flickering target like that of frequency doubling technology readily isolates the magno cells, as they are the most sensitive to flicker.

questions.question: What does angle recession of the eye refer to?
options: A detachment between the iris root and the ciliary body
A detachment between the ciliary body and the scleral spur
A tear between the longitudinal and circular muscle layers of the ciliary body
A tear between the posterior aspect of the zonules and the lenticular equator
answers: A tear between the longitudinal and circular muscle layers of the ciliary body
questions.explanation: Iridodialysis involves a detachment between the iris root and the ciliary body. Cyclodialysis cleft involves a detachment between the ciliary body and the scleral spur.

questions.question: Instillation of too much fluorescein when attempting Goldmann applanation tonometry will result in what type of erroneous result?
options: A measured intraocular pressure that is higher than the true intraocular pressure
A measured intraocular pressure that is lower than the true intraocular pressure
answers: A measured intraocular pressure that is higher than the true intraocular pressure
questions.explanation:
There are many potential sources of error when performing Goldmann applanation tonometry. If the mires created by the prisms in the tonometer are not aligned properly, the resulting IOP measurement will not be accurate. This also applies if too little or too much fluorescein is instilled. Too little fluorescein causes thin mires and an underestimation of the IOP reading. Too much fluorescein results in large mires and a falsely elevated measurement. If the mires are misaligned inferiorly (that is, the majority of the mires are located below the prism line) then the slit lamp needs to be lowered to center the mire images.
