If the mires are misaligned superiorly then the slit lamp needs to be raised to center the mires. 

A corneal abrasion may occur if the slit lamp is moved excessively or if too much force is placed by the tonometer head against the cornea.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of functional glaucoma progression?
options: A superior arcuate visual field defect
Superior notching of the rim tissue observed with a direct ophthalmoscope
A Drance hemorrhage observed at the disc margin
Thinning of the inferior nerve fiber layer as indicated by optical coherence tomography (OCT)
answers: A superior arcuate visual field defect
questions.explanation:
Functional progression occurs when the natural performance of the element in question has been altered. Functional glaucoma progression is measured via visual field testing. Any defects/changes observed on visual field testing should be re-tested to ensure that the defect/change is repeatable. Many times, observed misses will not occur upon re-testing. Many clinicians believe that it is important to perform many visual field tests during the first year of diagnosis to establish a proper baseline as well as to allow for the determination of the rate of progression. Although there is no current agreed up value that indicates if a patient displays a fast rate of progression, many clinicians consider a change of 1.5 decibels or greater per year to be a fast rate of progression. Newer software allows for easier detection of progression by comparing visual field results across time and extrapolating a graph of the visual field index. A steeper slope indicates a faster rate of progression. A Drance hemorrhage, superior notching of the rim tissue, and an abnormal OCT scan are considered structural signs of glaucoma progression. 

Review of Optometry. September 2013. East Coast Optometric Glaucoma Symposium, page 6.

questions.question: When performing Goldmann applanation tonometry, why is it important to control for patient accommodation?
options: Accommodation increases the size of the mires
Accommodation neutralizes the effects of the tonometer prism
Accommodation can falsely decrease intraocular pressure
Accommodation changes the contractile properties of the cornea, offsetting the mechanical forces of the tonometer tip
answers: Accommodation can falsely decrease intraocular pressure
questions.explanation: Accommodation can cause a rapid decrease in intraocular pressure, and therefore it is important to direct your patient's fixation towards a distant object in order to maximize the reliability of your results.

questions.question: Which of the following ocular conditions is MOST commonly associated with the presence of an optic disc hemorrhage?
questions.explanation: Optic disc hemorrhages occurring at the margin of the optic nerve are most commonly associated with normal tension glaucoma. These hemorrhages appear at the edge of the optic disc and typically extend onto the nerve fiber layer (called Drance hemorrhages). Additionally, they are most often found at the infero-temporal quadrant of the optic nerve head. It is thought that patients who exhibit progressive optic neuropathy with intraocular pressures (IOPs) consistently within the normal range are likely to have some form of vascular insufficiency or low systemic blood pressure which can lead to a decrease in the ocular perfusion pressure. It is for this reason that optic disc hemorrhages are more commonly observed in individuals exhibiting normal IOPs. When an optic disc hemorrhage is present, it is common to eventually manifest a visual field defect in the region corresponding to the location of the previous hemorrhage (often several months later).

questions.question: Upon examination of your 63 year-old female glaucoma suspect, you notice what appears to be an area of peripapillary atrophy surrounding the optic nerve of her left eye. Which 2 of the following statements are TRUE in regards to chorioretinal atrophy in this region? (Select 2)
options: Atrophy in the beta zone occurs more frequently and is typically larger in patients with glaucoma
The alpha zone borders the disc margin and is surrounded by the beta zone
Atrophy in the alpha zone occurs more frequently and is typically larger in patients with glaucoma
The beta zone borders the disc margin and is surrounded by the alpha zone
answers: Atrophy in the beta zone occurs more frequently and is typically larger in patients with glaucoma
The beta zone borders the disc margin and is surrounded by the alpha zone
questions.explanation:
Chorioretinal atrophy surrounding the optic nerve (also known as peripapillary atrophy) can be divided into two separate zones. The beta zone directly borders the margin of the optic disc, while the alpha zone is the outer region that concentrically surrounds the beta zone. 

Chorioretinal atrophy that occurs in the beta zone will present with increased visibility of the sclera and large choroidal blood vessels, in contrast to the appearance of alpha zone atrophy, which displays an irregular variation of both hyper and hypopigmentation of the retinal pigmented epithelium. 

Typically, when comparing peripapillary atrophy characteristics in normal and glaucomatous patients, the alpha zone is usually larger in patients with glaucoma; however, its frequency is similar in both groups. Conversely, both the size and frequency of beta zone atrophy is greater in patients with glaucoma, and the changes appear to be more pronounced in more severely affected eyes.

questions.question: At birth, the eyeball is not completely developed and continues to grow. At what age does the size of the optic nerve head reach 95% of its adult size?
questions.explanation: Although the optic nerve head is not fully developed at birth, the nerve reaches 95% of its adult size rather quickly, before the age of 1. However, at this age it remains not fully developed, particularly the lamina cribrosa.

questions.question: Which of the following glaucoma combination medications is currently NOT in production?
questions.explanation: Currently, a combination glaucoma medication consisting of a prostaglandin and a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor does not exist. The two medications possess vastly different dosing schedules. Prostaglandins are used once a day, while carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are typically prescribed up to three times daily.

questions.question: A patient presents with a cup-to-disc ratio of 0.65 with potential notching superiorly of the right eye. You wish to perform optical coherence tomography (OCT) imaging. Which of the following procedures should NOT be performed prior to obtaining OCT imaging on this patient?
options: Evaluation of the fundus with a 90 D lens
questions.explanation: In order to achieve maximal imaging results, it is recommended that the corneal surface remain as pristine as possible. A compromised corneal epithelium can lead to poor scan quality and therefore to potentially erroneous results. Should applanation tonometry need to be performed, it is best to complete this procedure after imaging has been completed.

questions.question: Which of the following types of visual field defects occurs EARLIEST in patients exhibiting glaucomatous optic nerve damage?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic defects in glaucoma consist of damage to the optic nerve head, resulting in a retinal nerve fiber bundle defect. The configuration of nerve fibers served by the damaged bundle will correspond to a specific defect in the visual field. The earliest visual field changes that may suggest glaucomatous damage commonly consist of an increased variability of responses in an area that will eventually develop a defect. 

When a glaucomatous visual field defect does occur, it tends to initially present as a paracentral scotoma. Paracentral scotomas are typically small and relatively steep depressions that are most commonly observed just supero-nasal to the fovea. Approximately 70% of all early glaucomatous field defects can be characterized as a paracentral scotoma. This type of defect is due to damage of the papillomacular bundle, which will respect the horizontal midline. 

It is important to remember that a single visual field test cannot definitively prove that a visual field defect exists. For this reason, interpretation of visual fields should not be performed in isolation but rather in conjunction with other clinical findings (IOP, appearance of optic nerve, RNFL). According to Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, there is a set of minimal criteria for determining glaucomatous damage (also known as Anderson's criteria), summarized below: 

1. Glaucoma hemifield test that is 'outside normal limits' on at least 2 consecutive occasions. 
2. A cluster of 3 or more non-edge points in a location typical for glaucoma, all of which are depressed on pattern standard deviation (PSD) at a P < 5% level and one of which is depressed at a P <1% level, on 2 consecutive occasions. 
3. Corrected pattern standard deviation (CPSD) that occurs in less than 5% of normal individuals on two consecutive fields.

questions.question: Haab's striae are clinical signs typically associated with congenital glaucoma that indicate ruptures of which of the following layers of the cornea?
questions.explanation:
Haab's striae are caused by horizontal breaks or ruptures in Descemet's membrane. These striae may be single or multiple and are usually associated with congenital glaucoma and buphthalmos. It is important to distinguish these from the vertically oriented breaks in Descemet's membrane that are associated with trauma from forceps delivery during birth. 

Eagle, R.C. (2011). Eye Pathology: An Atlas and Text (2nd ed.). Philadelphia, PA: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs decrease intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral outflow?
questions.explanation:
Glaucoma medications lower intraocular pressure by either decreasing aqueous production or by increasing aqueous outflow. There are three classes of drugs for which the mechanism of action is increasing aqueous outflow: cholinergic agonists, prostaglandin analogs, and alpha-2 agonists. Cholinergic agonists, such as pilocarpine, work by increasing trabecular outflow, whereas prostaglandin analogs and alpha-2 agonists work by increasing uveoscleral outflow. The other classes of glaucoma medications, such as beta-blockers and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, work by decreasing aqueous production. 

It is important to note that alpha-2 agonists, such as Brimonidine (Alphagan®) and Apraclonidine (Iopidine®), have dual mechanisms of action. This class of medication decreases intraocular pressure by both increasing uveoscleral outflow and decreasing aqueous production.

questions.question: Which of the following terms is commonly used to describe abnormal enlargement of an infant's eye secondary to elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), usually in the first two years of life?
questions.explanation:
Corneal enlargement or opacification (or both) often signal glaucoma in the infant; both may progress rapidly over the first two years of life if the IOP remains elevated. 

Exophthalmos is a term that is used more commonly for overall globe position from intraorbital lesions or inflammation. 

Keratoconus is a term used to describe an ectatic condition of the cornea in young adult hood; it is usually found in the inferior third of the cornea. 

Lentiglobus is a term used to describe ectasia of the human intraocular lens (specifically, the posterior capsule) causing a posterior bulging of the lenticular cortex; this is commonly associated with internal astigmatism. 


Reference: 
1.Kiskis, AA Corneal diameter and axial length in congenital glaucoma Can J Ophthalmology 1985; 20(3):93-97

questions.question: Which of the following side effects is MOST likely to be FIRST observed after the initiation of topical prostaglandin therapy used in the management of glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
Potential side effects associated with prostaglandin use include increased lash length, increased iris and periorbital tissue pigmentation, and periorbital fat cell atrophy. Signs of prostaglandin-associated periorbitopathy include increased inferior scleral show, ptosis of the upper lid, dermatochalasis involution, slight enophthalmos, atrophy of periorbital fat cells, and a deepening of the superior lid sulcus. However, the most common initial side effect is conjunctival hyperemia. This side effect can be bothersome to many patients, and therefore it is important for the primary eye care provider to determine which prostaglandin analog is best suited for the patient. Studies have demonstrated that latanoprost may be associated with the least amount of conjunctival hyperemia. Conjunctival hyperemia is purportedly mediated by nitric-oxide causing vasodilation of the conjunctival vasculature. Typically, the level of hyperemia decreases with increased time and continued use of the medication. 

Reference: 
A randomized, controlled comparison of macroscopic conjunctival hyperemia in patients treated with bimatoprost 0.01% or vehicle who were previously controlled on latanoprost. Clin Ophthalmol. 2010; 4: 1433?1440.

questions.question: A 32-year old myopic male is seen at your office. Biomicroscopy reveals a vertical line of pigment deposited on his posterior endothelium along with an iris transillumination defect. You correctly diagnose him with pigmentary dispersion syndrome. What is the name for the deposited pigment on his cornea?
questions.explanation:
Pigmentary dispersion syndrome generally occurs in young, myopic males with deep anterior chambers. This condition is caused by a disruption of the posterior iris pigment epithelium, causing this layer to rub against the ciliary zonules and release pigment into the anterior chamber and its associated structures. The aqueous in the anterior chamber displays convection currents. Warming inferiorly, aqueous rises and migrates forward towards the posterior surface of the endothelium, carrying pigment granules with it, then falls as it cools, causing the pigment to deposit vertically in a linear-fashion on the endothelium. Monitor these patients for blockage of the trabecular meshwork, causing a rise in intraocular pressure (IOP) and potential glaucomatous damage to the optic nerve. Physical exertion as well as mydriasis may exacerbate pigment release; therefore, when dilating (especially with phenylephrine), you must be sure to measure post-dilated IOPs. 

Siderosis appears as a brown/yellow iron deposit in the epithelium and/or stroma of the cornea secondary to a metal foreign body. 

Fleischer's ring occurs in keratoconus. This ring appears as brown/yellow iron pigmentation around the base of the ectasia. 

Cornea farinata appear as small white specks located in the interpalpebral zone of the posterior stroma. This condition is generally bilateral and does not require treatment. 

Corneal arcus appears as a white/yellow circular band of cholesterol that deposits in the stromal periphery, leaving a clear zone adjacent to the limbus. It is important to refer patients with corneal arcus who are unaware of their cholesterol levels for evaluation of their serum cholesterol.

questions.question: It has long been hypothesized that the ocular blood flow may in part play a role in mechanisms surrounding primary open angle glaucoma (POAG). When evaluating the contribution of perfusion pressure, a decrease in diastolic perfusion pressure causes the prevalence of primary open angle glaucoma to change in which manner?
questions.explanation: Perfusion pressure dictates how the blood reaches the end organs. There are two components to perfusion pressure: systolic and diastolic. If the perfusion pressure is low, blood flow to the capillaries is compromised. This holds true for either component of perfusion pressure. Thus, there is an increase in the prevalence of primary open angle glaucoma with a decrease in diastolic perfusion pressure.

questions.question: How is the temporal modulation transfer function expected to change in a person with early glaucoma not yet manifesting any defects on visual field testing?
options: Decreased sensitivity to low and moderate frequencies
Decreased sensitivity to moderate and high temporal frequencies
Decreased sensitivity to moderate frequencies only
Decreased sensitivity to low temporal frequencies only
answers: Decreased sensitivity to moderate and high temporal frequencies
questions.explanation: Early glaucomatous damage can be difficult to detect because intraocular pressure and visual fields can be normal. Recent studies demonstrate that the magno cells may be damaged early on in glaucoma. The magno cells are a part of the 'where' pathway and therefore display excellent temporal resolution. Due to this factor, there is evidence that clearly reveals a correlation between an altered temporal modulation transfer function and early glaucoma, with a marked decrease noted for the moderate and high temporal frequencies, even though the respective visual field is free of defects.

questions.question: A patient presents with an acute angle closure attack. You are about to initiate topical and oral medical treatment in order to quickly reduce the intraocular pressure. Which of the following would be a contraindication to the use of oral acetazolamide?
questions.explanation:
Acetazolamide (or Diamox®) is a sulfa-based medication and should not be ingested or administered to a patient with a past history of a severe sulfonamide allergy. Some studies have shown that patients exhibiting a mild reaction to sulfa-based antimicrobial medications may be able to tolerate acetazolamide without risk, but a lesser dose test dose should be administered. This is not practical in the case of an acute angle closure, as the intraocular pressure must be reduced very quickly. In the event of a sulfa allergy, a non sulfa-containing diuretic should be utilized to err on the side of caution.
PowerPage
Oral Glaucoma Medications

questions.question: Which of the following processes contributes the MOST to aqueous humor production?
questions.explanation:
Three physiological processes contribute to the formation of aqueous humor: diffusion, ultrafiltration, and secretion. Diffusion and ultrafiltration form the filtrate in the stroma from which aqueous is derived via active secretion across the ciliary processes. Under normal conditions, active secretion accounts for 80-90% of total aqueous humor formation. 

Reference: Morrison, J. and Pollack, I. Glaucoma: Science and Practice (2003) pp 24-35.

questions.question: Your patient's visual field printout reveals many scattered misses and multiple false positive errors and fixation losses. Based upon this information, what actions should be taken?
options: Evaluate the fundus for organic causes of the visual field loss
Refer for an MRI scan to rule out a brain mass or lesion
questions.explanation: If there is no pattern to the field loss and the reliability indices reveal many errors or fixation losses, it is best to re-test the field to verify if the defects are repeatable. There are many factors that can result in a poor visual field result, such as: decreased patient attention, fatigue, lack of comprehension, or wrong/no visual correction in place, to name a few. If the pattern loss is specific and repeatable, then it is important to look for retinal pathology that correlates with the associated field loss, and take the appropriate actions (i.e. treat, monitor, or refer) at that time.

questions.question: Frequency doubling technology (FDT) has been thought to be an advantageous screening tool for early detection of visual field loss associated with glaucomatous damage. Which of the following statements BEST describes the basis for this concept?
options: FDT targets the small bistratified retinal ganglion cells, which are thought to be damaged in early glaucoma
FDT targets the large bistratified retinal ganglion cells, which are thought to be damaged in early glaucoma
FDT targets the parvocellular pathway, which is thought to be preferentially damaged in the early glaucoma process
FDT targets the magnocellular pathway, which is thought to be preferentially damaged in the early glaucoma process
answers: FDT targets the magnocellular pathway, which is thought to be preferentially damaged in the early glaucoma process
questions.explanation:
Frequency doubling technology (FDT) perimetry utilizes a low spatial frequency sinusoidal grating combined with a high temporal frequency counterphase flicker to produce a stimulus target. The FDT has been shown to specifically activate the magnocellular ganglion cells in order to see this type of stimulus. This is of great importance due to the fact that the magnocellular pathway is thought to be preferentially damaged in the early glaucoma process. 

Recent studies have shown that the FDT demonstrates 85% sensitivity and 90% specificity for detecting early glaucomatous visual field loss, and 95% sensitivity and 95% specificity for detecting visual field loss in patients with moderate glaucomatous damage. Furthermore, this degree of effectiveness in early detection has allowed the FDT to reveal the presence of abnormalities in the visual field before they could be detected by standard automated perimetry. 

It is also believed that short-wave automated perimetry (SWAP) is able to detect early glaucomatous functional loss by isolating the small bistratified ganglion cells that have also been thought to be damaged early in the glaucoma process.

questions.question: What factors can influence the efficacy of the Heijl-Krakau blind spot monitoring in perimetry?
questions.explanation: Heijl-Krakau blind spot monitoring is utilized in perimetry to check for patient fixation. During the administration of visual fields, the stimulus is presented in the visual space at the location of patient's blind spot. Because this area of the eye does not possess receptors, it will not be able to perceive the light, and therefore the patient will not respond. However, if the patient undergoing perimetry either tilts their head, or if the fellow eye is not patched appropriately, this may influence the efficacy of the monitoring technique. This may result in decreased reliability of the test, as the patient will be able to respond from the seeing region around the optic disc of the ipsilateral eye or stimulation of the inappropriately patched contralateral eye.

questions.question: A patient with a very dense central corneal scar of his right eye requires his intraocular pressure (IOP) measured. Which of the following instruments will yield the MOST accurate reading of his IOP?
questions.explanation:
Conditions that can alter central corneal elasticity, such as corneal edema or scarring, may decrease the accuracy of IOP measurement. For these situations it is best to use a McKay-Marg or Tonopen tonometer, which were constructed to better measure corneas with abnormal rigidity. The design of the instrument was created such that the forces of corneal rigidity and surface tension are decreased substantially. 

The ocular response analyzer and the pneumotonometer offer advanced technology over the Tonopen and purport more accurate intraocular pressure measurement. 

Reference: Lang, G. Ophthalmology: A Pocket Textbook Atlas 2nd edition (2007) pages 248-249.

questions.question: Which of the following is MOST likely considered as an increased risk factor for the rapid progression of visual field defects in a patient with normal tension glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
The Collaborative Normal-Tension Glaucoma Study determined that female gender, a history of migraine headaches and patients with disc hemorrhages are at a greater risk for rapid progression of damage caused by normal tension glaucoma. Currently under further investigation is the relationship between cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure and intraocular pressure (IOP). Other potential associations with normal tension glaucoma include systemic hypotension, decreased optic nerve perfusion pressure, increased IOP, and systemic peripheral vasospasm (Raynaud's phenomenon). 

Reference: 
http://www.revoptom.com/content/c/41903/

questions.question: According to the Van Herick technique of angle estimation, which angle grade is considered MOST narrow and potentially capable of closure?
questions.explanation:
The Van Herick method of angle estimation, although not infallible, is a good way of assessing the probability of angle closure with dilation. The temporal angle of a patient is evaluated by having the patient look straight ahead, placing the oculars of the slit lamp in the straight ahead position and shifting the lighthouse temporally so that an angle of 60 degrees is created. The beam is then narrowed to an optic section and placed at the temporal limbus. The width of the anterior chamber space at the angle is then compared to the width of the corneal optic section. The procedure is repeated and the illumination source is placed nasally to assess the grade of the nasal angle. If the angle space is equal to 1/2 or greater than the corneal optic section, the angle is not considered occludable and is given a grade of 4. A grade three displays an angle space that is less than 1/2 but greater than 1/4 of the width of the corneal optic section, and is considered safe to dilate. A grade two has an angle space that is roughly equal to 1/4 the width of the corneal optic section, and may be dilated but with caution. A grade 1 has an angle space of less than 1/4 the width of the corneal optic section, and requires gonioscopy to ensure that the patient is safe to dilate. 

Reference: Casser, L., Fingeret, M., Woodcome, T. Atlas of Primary Eye Care Procedures, 2nd edition 1997, pp. 28-29.

questions.question: You wish to determine if a patient is safe to dilate via gonioscopy. Using the Becker-Shaffer angle grading system, which grade signifies an angle with no visible structures?
questions.explanation: According to the Becker-Shaffer grading system, the ability to safely dilate a patient is determined by which ocular structure is visible most posteriorly. The anatomy of the angle of the anterior chamber is comprised of several structures. The most posterior of the structures is the ciliary body, followed by the scleral spur, trabecular meshwork, and lastly Schwalbe's line, which is the most anterior. A grade of 4 is assigned if the ciliary body is visible, and is considered safe for dilation. When the scleral spur is the most posterior structure visible, the angle is graded as a 3 and is safe to dilate. When 1/2 to 1/3 of the trabecular meshwork is visible, the angle is classified as a 2 and is somewhat risky to dilate. When only the most anterior portion or only Schwalbe's line is viewed, the angle is graded as a 1 and is considered to be at high risk for angle occlusion. If no structures are seen, then the angle is classified as 0 and the angle is closed.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is MOST frequently seen in association with normal tension glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
Normal tension glaucoma (NTG) is characterized by normal or low intraocular pressure readings. Normal tension glaucoma has a higher predilection in Asians (notably persons of Japanese descent). This condition differs slightly from primary open angle glaucoma in that there appears to be an association with Raynaud's phenomenon (peripheral vasospasm). Patients with this condition also possess a propensity for disc hemorrhages. Visual field defects in NTG have a slight tendency to be located more paracentrally rather than peripherally. Patients with NTG also display peripapillary atrophy that differs from that of patients with primary open angle glaucoma. 

http://www.aao.org/publications/eyenet/200702/pearls.cfm

questions.question: Which refractive condition is associated with an increased in risk for angle-closure?
questions.explanation: Various anatomical predisposing factors pose an increased risk for an episode of angle-closure. The two greatest factors are the depth of the anterior chamber and the morphology of the iris insertion. On average, individuals who possess emmetropic, myopic, or purely astigmatic refractive errors have deeper anterior chamber depths when compared to individuals with hypermetropia. Eyes with smaller anterior chamber depths are more predisposed to a greater degree to incur irido-corneal contact and hence carry an increased possibility of angle-closure attack.

questions.question: You decide to prescribe a beta-blocker for your patient diagnosed with primary open angle glaucoma. Taking into consideration the mechanism of action of this medication, what time of day is a beta-blocker MOST effective in lowering intraocular pressure?
options: In the middle of the night
Right before the patient goes to bed
questions.explanation: Beta-blockers serve to decrease aqueous production. Aqueous production is measurably reduced at night when a patient is laying down and therefore beta-blockers are least effective at this time. Research has demonstrated that beta-blockers prove to be most effective in the morning.

questions.question: A mother brings in her 12 month-old son, reporting that he frequently rubs his eyes and that they constantly appear to be tearing. Further investigation with a 20 D lens and a transilluminator reveals enlarged, cloudy corneas and horizontal striae. Fundus exam reveals an excavated optic nerve. Given the exam findings, what is the MOST likely condition observed in the young infant?
options: Incomplete dehiscence of the valve of Hasner
questions.explanation:
Primary congenital glaucoma is the most commonly encountered form of infantile glaucoma. This condition is seen more frequently in males, and the majority of cases are sporadic in origin with no inheritance pattern. 75% of cases occur bilaterally and typically present before the child's first birthday. The condition is caused by an abnormality of the angle (either a flat iris insertion or a concave iris insertion) and is rarely linked with any systemic disorders. Characteristically, the patient's caregiver will note a triad of symptoms: photophobia, epiphora, and blepharospasm. Occasionally, the parents will note that the child's corneas appear cloudy due to corneal edema. Clinical findings include a unilateral or bilaterally enlarged globes and corneas (greater than 12mm), horizontal tears in Descemet's membrane (Haab's striae), a myopic refractive error, elevated IOPs, corneal edema, hypoplasia of the iris stroma, and cupping of the optic nerve. If the condition persists, the globe and its associated structures will stretch due to consistently elevated IOP, resulting in buphthalmos. 

Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy usually affects males in their 20s and typically presents as a unilateral, painless loss of vision. 

It is common for mothers of young infants to note that one eye (or both eyes) of her infant constantly tears in conjunction with the presence of mucopurulent discharge. This epiphora results from a blockage of the nasolacrimal passageway, caused by a membrane covering the valve of Hasner. The majority of blockages will self-resolve without intervention (80-90% of infants) within the first 12 months of life. 

Dacryocystitis refers to inflammation of the lacrimal sac, commonly caused by nasolacrimal duct obstruction or infection. Symptoms of dacryocystitis typically involve pain, redness, and swelling over the medial canthal aspect of the lower eyelid where the lacrimal sac resides., Commonly, patients will also complain of watery eyes or mucous that may extrude from the punctum upon digital pressure.

questions.question: Which of the following appears to be a risk factor for the development of pseudoexfoliation glaucoma?
options: Warm weather with minimal sun exposure
questions.explanation:
Pseudoexfoliation/exfoliative glaucoma appears as white, flaky material that deposits along the pupillary margin, the anterior surface of the lens and other structures of the anterior chamber. The material is composed of extracellular matrix produced by ocular tissue along with other components of the body (such as the skin) and is therefore considered a systemic condition. Pseudoexfoliation is usually unilateral and is frequently seen in the elderly with a concurrent cataract. Transillumination defects, if present, are limited to the iris sphincter region. The pseudoexfoliative material can accumulate in the trabecular meshwork, causing an increase in IOP, leading to glaucoma. Studies have demonstrated that this condition is linked with high systemic levels of homocysteine. There is also evidence that high levels of coffee drinking (but not other caffeinated beverages) may increase the risk of developing exfoliative glaucoma. Roughly 99% of patients with this condition also possess the lysyl oxidase-like 1 (LOXL 1) gene; however, around 75% of the population without exfoliative glaucoma also has the LOXL 1 gene. It is therefore theorized that the gene is likely triggered by something environmental in nature. Research has demonstrated that living in the northern latitude along with high UV exposure and cooler temperatures may increase the chances of LOXL 1 gene activation. 

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22918628

questions.question: You decide to perform a threshold visual field on a patient who is a glaucoma suspect. A good visual field analyzer possesses which of the following qualities?
questions.explanation: Ideally, a good visual field analyzer possesses high specificity as well as sensitivity. High specificity denotes that the test is able to accurately detect patients who possess the condition in regard. A high sensitivity allows for an increased probability of excluding patients who are not afflicted with a given condition.

questions.question: What is the MOST COMMON location of a laser peripheral iridotomy?
questions.explanation: The superior iris is usually the selected quadrant to place the laser treatment so that the opening may be covered by the upper eyelid (should also be as peripheral as possible to minimize potential damage to the crystalline lens).

questions.question: As we age, what is expected to happen to intraocular pressure?
questions.explanation: As we age, studies have shown that intraocular pressure increases. There are a myriad of factors that may contribute to this increase in pressure. Some would attest that the trabecular meshwork becomes clogged, or that the channels narrow with age. However, regardless of the etiology, it is of vital importance to evaluate intraocular pressure and to monitor for changes in the structure of the optic nerve.

questions.question: Goldmann applanation tonometry is calibrated for a central corneal thickness of roughly 520 micrometers. How will a cornea measuring 600 micrometers thick affect the intraocular pressure (IOP) measurements, and how should the IOP reading be compensated?
options: IOP will be falsely low; the measured IOP should be adjusted down
IOP will be falsely elevated; the measured IOP should be adjusted up
IOP will be falsely elevated; the measured IOP should be adjusted down
IOP will be falsely low; the measured IOP should be adjusted up
answers: IOP will be falsely elevated; the measured IOP should be adjusted down
questions.explanation:
A thicker than average cornea will cause a falsely elevated IOP measurement due to greater than normal corneal rigidity requiring more pressure to achieve proper indentation with the tonometer. Therefore, the resultant IOP should be adjusted down. The magnitude of the adjustment depends on how much the central corneal thickness deviates from the calibrated thickness of 520 micrometers. 

Reference: Gupta, D. Glaucoma Diagnosis and Management (2005) pp. 66-68.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true regarding the conventional outflow route of the aqueous humor?
options: It is the major component of outflow facility of the aqueous humor
Aqueous exits via the iris root, uveal meshwork and the anterior face of ciliary muscle
It is also called the trabecular route
answers: Aqueous exits via the iris root, uveal meshwork and the anterior face of ciliary muscle
questions.explanation: The non-conventional outflow route of the aqueous humor passes through the iris root, uveal meshwork, and the anterior face of the ciliary muscle. The conventional outflow is also called the trabecular route and, although there is a debate as to how much the trabecular route contributes to the outflow facility, it is agreed that this route is the major component of outflow facility of aqueous humor. Both the conventional and unconventional outflow facilities decline with increasing age.

questions.question: While performing Goldmann applanation tonometry, the mires are lined up properly horizontally; however, the lower semi-circle is much larger and almost complete, while the upper one is small. If no adjustment is made, how will this alignment affect the reading of the intraocular pressure (IOP)?
options: It is not possible to determine how the reading will be affected
The reading will be falsely high
The reading will be falsely low
The reading will not be affected
answers: The reading will be falsely high
questions.explanation: If the mires are not equal in size during Goldmann applanation tonometry, the resultant IOP reading will be falsely elevated.

questions.question: Which population given below has the highest prevalence of angle-closure glaucoma?
questions.explanation: Angle-closure glaucoma is a multifactorial disease with various anatomical pre-disposing factors in certain individuals, mainly the depth of the anterior chamber and the morphology of the iris insertion. For reasons that remain unclear at this time, epidemiologically it is found that the Chinese have the highest prevalence of primary angle-closure glaucoma, about three times greater than Caucasians, African-Americans, and Japanese. Both Caucasians and African-Americans have much deeper anterior chamber depths than the Chinese; however, the anterior chamber depth is relatively similar between the Chinese and Japanese.

questions.question: When performing argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT), which of the following BEST describes the anatomical location in which the aiming beam should be focused?
options: Junction of pigmented and non-pigmented trabecular meshwork
answers: Junction of pigmented and non-pigmented trabecular meshwork
questions.explanation:
The following describes the proper procedure for performing argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT): 
- Instillation of topical anesthetic and topical hypotensive agent (usually alpha-agonist) is the initial step 
- A gonioscopy lens is placed on the eye with the semi-circular lens at 12 o'clock in order to view the inferior angle (usually the easiest area to see) 
- The pigmented portion of the trabecular meshwork is identified 
- The aiming beam should be focused at the junction of the pigmented (filtering trabecular meshwork) and non-pigmented (non-filtering) trabecular meshwork

questions.question: Which of the following laser treatments is thought to increase aqueous outflow by the clearing of trabecular meshwork debris through cell division and migration of macrophages induced by the laser, in addition to opening of untreated trabecular spaces by tightening of treated trabecular meshwork?
questions.explanation:
Mechanism of action argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT): 
- ALT involves the application of isolated laser burns to the trabecular meshwork in order to increase the outflow of aqueous, subsequently lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) 
- It is thought that increased outflow occurs as a result of the following: 
- Opening of adjacent untreated trabecular spaces by tightening of the treated trabecular meshwork 
- The clearing of trabecular meshwork debris by cell division and migration of macrophages induced by the laser treatment 

Mechanism of Action SLT: 
- Selectively targets pigmented trabecular meshwork cells, while sparing the non-pigmented (non-filtering) cells 
- The absorption of radiant energy by the melanin-containing cells leads to rupture of melanosomes and cellular destruction (photolysis) 
- The ruptured cells release metalloproteases and other proteolytic enzymes, triggering an inflammatory response mediated by macrophages and other phagocytic cells 
- Phagocytic action in and around the trabecular meshwork typically results in increased aqueous outflow and reduction in intraocular pressure

questions.question: Which of the following 3 activities is associated with a decrease in intraocular pressure? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: Exercise, general anesthesia, alcohol consumption, and marijuana use cause a temporary decrease in intraocular pressure (IOP). Transitioning from sitting to a lying down position, blinking, coughing, blepharospasm and tobacco usage may cause an increase in IOP.

questions.question: At what time period of the day would the aqueous humor production be least?
questions.explanation: The precise role and receptors specificity of adrenergic mechanisms in regulating the rate of aqueous humor formation are unclear. Studies using fluorophotometry have shown that beta adrenergic antagonists unequivocally decrease aqueous humor formation, particularly aqueous humor production during sleeping hours, during which production is decreased by up to 50%. This decrease is due to the B-arrestin/cAMP cascade regulation from the beta-adrenergic receptors. This does not mean that the intraocular pressure necessarily decreases at night; in fact, nocturnal intraocular pressure spikes have recently been reported; these may have a role in causing progressive glaucomatous damage.

questions.question: A 35-year old male is seen at your office for his first eye exam ever and reports no ocular concerns. Gross observation reveals a large nevus of Ota of his right eye. What type of ocular condition does this finding put your patient at risk for?
questions.explanation: A nevus of Ota (also called oculodermal melanosis or oculodermal melanocytosis) is a congenital condition in which there is increased pigmentation of the periorbital skin as well as the uveal tract, generally unilaterally. This condition appears as purple/gray patches of melanocyte distribution and is usually seen in African-Americans and Asians but rarely in Caucasians. If a nevus of Ota is observed in a Caucasian, monitor carefully for malignancy. Due to the fact that this disorder is caused by increased levels of pigmentation, these cells can impede the flow of aqueous through the trabecular meshwork, potentially resulting in glaucoma.

questions.question: Which 3 signs are typically associated with pigment dispersion glaucoma? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: The anterior chamber in patients with pigment dispersion glaucoma is usually very deep with wide open angles. The reason for deep anterior chambers is the presence of a backward bowing of the peripheral iris (this leads to an increase in lens/iris contact). Patients with pigment dispersion glaucoma tend to be male and myopic.

questions.question: Which of the following sentences is CORRECTLY related to the pathogenesis of glaucoma?
options: Nitric oxide is beneficial at low concentrations because of vasodilation but is neurotoxic at higher concentrations
Blood flow disruption is visible as a decrease in blood flow through the major arteries of the eye
Optic nerve crush performed experimentally perfectly simulates the glaucomatous pathogenesis observed in humans
Increases in intraocular pressure do not cause a change to target derived growth factors of the eye
answers: Nitric oxide is beneficial at low concentrations because of vasodilation but is neurotoxic at higher concentrations
questions.explanation: Increased intraocular pressure (IOP) is associated with a decrease in both brain derived and target derived growth factors of the eye. Optic nerve crush is a popular model used in experimental models of glaucoma, however, it does not completely simulate the pathogenesis of human glaucoma. Unlike human glaucoma, the death of ganglion cells is rapid when the optic nerve is crushed. There is a blood flow dysregulation that is known to occur in patients with glaucoma, and there is also a decrease in the number of superficial capillaries, however larger arteries and arterial flow remain intact. Nitric oxide secreted by endothelial cells helps in auto-regulation and increases the blood flow in the retina by metabolic processes, but it is toxic in larger amounts and disrupts the mitochondrial and DNA functions.

questions.question: You wish to evaluate the intraocular pressure (IOP) of a patient with keratoconus. Which of the following instruments is the BEST option to perform IOP measurement of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Of the devices listed, DCT is least affected by decreased corneal thickness and therefore offers the most accurate assessment of intraocular pressure, particularly when utilized in individuals who have undergone refractive surgery (such as LASIK) or who have thinner corneas (keratoconic patients, for example). In patients with keratoconus, corneal hysteresis and resistance are also important elements to consider as they both may compromise the accuracy of IOP measurements if they are not accounted for. DCT purportedly performs IOP assessment independently of corneal thickness and rigidity, thus enabling for more precise IOP results. 

References: 

http://www.aao.org/publications/eyenet/200505/glaucoma.cfm 

Clinical Glaucoma Care: The Essentials. Samples, J. & Schacknow, P. Springer, 2014, page 8. 

http://commons.pacificu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1011&context=coofac

questions.question: During the administration of visual field testing, which of the following would result in an elevated number of false negatives?
options: The patient fell asleep during the test
answers: The patient fell asleep during the test
questions.explanation:
False negatives during Humphrey perimetry testing are detected by presenting a stimulus that is brighter than the previously determined threshold value in a certain location. If the patient fails to respond to the stimulus, a false negative is recorded. False negatives may occur due to lack of attention (the patient fell asleep). 

False positives occur when the patient responds without an accompanying light stimulus. A 'trigger-happy' patient would demonstrate a high amount of false positives. 

Nuclear sclerosis of the lens may cause generalized depression of the visual field. Refractive errors should not interfere with the administration of the test, as patients should have their visual corrections accounted for.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT considered a risk factor for the conversion of ocular hypertension to primary open angle glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
The following factors represent an increased risk for the development of primary open angle glaucoma (POAG) in patients with ocular hypertension: 
- Older age: POAG is more often associated with older-aged patients. 
- Enlarged vertical cup-to-disc ratio: Naturally, the horizontal cup-to-disc ratio is larger than the vertical cup-to-disc ratio (inferior and superior nerve tissue is usually thicker than the nasal and temporal tissue); however, when the vertical cup-to-disc ratio is enlarged, the area of visible disc surrounding the cup does not follow the ISNT rule, typically representing early glaucomatous damage. 
- Thin central corneal thickness: Eyes with a thinner central corneal thickness will give a false low reading on tonometry; therefore, the true eye pressure may be significantly higher than measured with the Goldmann tonometer. 
- Peripapillary atrophy: Peripapillary changes can be observed in over 50% of patients with ocular hypertension that convert to POAG. 

Additional risk factors for the conversion of ocular hypertension to POAG include elevated intraocular pressure, family history of glaucoma, and high myopia. High hyperopia is not considered a risk factor for POAG, but is a significant factor for the development of angle closure glaucoma.

questions.question: Which of the following exam findings is MOST likely attributable to glaucomatous damage?
options: Cupping of the rim tissue of the optic nerve
answers: Cupping of the rim tissue of the optic nerve
questions.explanation:
There are many pathologies and anomalies that may cause defects of the nerve fiber layer, visual field defects or pallor of the optic nerve; these findings are not specific to glaucoma. Cupping of the optic disc is HIGHLY indicative of glaucomatous damage. 

Reference: 
Glaucoma Identification and Co-management. Edgar, D. & Rudnicka, A. Butterworth, Heinemann & Elsevier, 2007, page 122.

questions.question: Which of the following is the MOST common early pattern of a glaucomatous visual field defect?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic defects in glaucoma consist of damage to the optic nerve head, resulting in a retinal nerve fiber bundle defect. The configuration of nerve fibers served by the damaged bundle will correspond to a specific defect in the visual field. The earliest visual field changes that may suggest glaucomatous damage commonly consist of an increased variability of responses in an area that will eventually develop a defect. 

When a glaucomatous visual field defect does occur, it tends to initially present as a paracentral scotoma. Paracentral scotomas are typically small and relatively steep depressions that are most commonly observed just supero-nasal to the fovea. Approximately 70% of all early glaucomatous field defects can be characterized as a paracentral scotoma. This type of defect is due to damage of the papillomacular bundle which will respect the horizontal midline. 

It is important to remember that a single visual field test cannot definitively prove that a visual field defect exists. For this reason, interpretation of visual fields should not be performed in isolation, but rather in conjunction with other clinical findings (IOP, appearance of optic nerve, RNFL). According to Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, there is a set of minimal criteria for determining glaucomatous damage (also known as Anderson's criteria), which is summarized below: 

1. Glaucoma hemifield test that is 'outside normal limits' on at least 2 consecutive occasions. 
2. A cluster of 3 or more non-edge points in a location typical for glaucoma, all of which are depressed on pattern standard deviation (PSD) at a P < 5% level and one of which is depressed at a P <1% level, on 2 consecutive occasions. 
3. Corrected pattern standard deviation (CPSD) that occurs in less than 5% of normal individuals on two consecutive fields.

questions.question: What is the name of the type of secondary glaucoma that occurs in association with a hypermature cataract, whereby high molecular weight lens proteins that have leaked from the crystalline lens cause an obstruction of the trabecular meshwork?
questions.explanation:
Phacolytic glaucoma occurs as a result of high molecular weight proteins that have leaked into the anterior chamber through an intact lens capsule from a hypermature cataractous crystalline lens. These proteins cause obstruction of the trabecular meshwork, which can cause a significant elevation in intraocular pressure and eventual damage to the optic nerve if not treated efficiently and effectively. 

Phacomorphic glaucoma is considered an acute secondary angle closure type of glaucoma in which the antero-posterior growth of the crystalline lens (that occurs naturally with age), along with natural anterior movement of the lens, leads to an increase in iridolenticular contact. These morphological changes can cause subsequent pupillary block and iris bombe, leading to significantly elevated intraocular pressure and eventual severe damage to the optic nerve. 

Posner-Schlossman syndrome (also known as glaucomatocyclitic crisis) is characterized by recurrent acute attacks of anterior uveitis, which is accompanied by elevated intraocular pressure (presumed to be due to acute trabeculitis). 

Phacoanaphylactic uveitis is an autoimmune reaction that occurs secondary to proteins that have leaked from a lens with a ruptured capsule.

questions.question: What is the name of the type of acute secondary angle-closure glaucoma that can occur as a result of anterior-posterior growth of the crystalline lens with age?
questions.explanation:
Phacomorphic glaucoma is considered an acute secondary angle closure type of glaucoma in which the antero-posterior growth of the crystalline lens (which occurs naturally with age), along with natural anterior movement of the lens, leads to an increase in iridolenticular contact. These morphological changes can cause subsequent pupillary block and iris bombe, leading to significantly elevated intraocular pressure and eventual severe damage to the optic nerve. 

Phacolytic glaucoma occurs as a result of high molecular weight proteins that have leaked into the anterior chamber through an intact lens capsule from a hypermature cataractous crystalline lens. These proteins cause obstruction of the trabecular meshwork, which can cause a significant elevation in intraocular pressure and eventual damage to the optic nerve if not treated efficiently and effectively. 

Posner-Schlossman syndrome (also known as glaucomatocyclitic crisis) is characterized by recurrent acute attacks of anterior uveitis, which is accompanied by elevated intraocular pressure (presumed to be due to acute trabeculitis). 

Phacoanaphylactic uveitis is an autoimmune reaction that occurs secondary to proteins that have leaked from a lens with a ruptured capsule.

questions.question: A 22-year old male presents in your office for his annual exam. Biomicroscopy reveals bilateral Krukenberg spindles and iris transillumination defects. Given the above findings, what is the correct diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Pigmentary dispersion syndrome generally occurs in young, myopic males with deep anterior chambers. This condition is caused by a disruption of the posterior iris pigment epithelium, causing this layer to rub against the ciliary zonules and release pigment into the anterior chamber and its associated structures. The aqueous in the anterior chamber displays convection currents. Warming inferiorly, aqueous rises and migrates forward towards the posterior surface of the endothelium, carrying pigment granules with it, then falls as it cools, causing the pigment to deposit vertically in a linear-fashion on the endothelium. Monitor these patients for blockage of the trabecular meshwork causing a rise in intraocular pressure (IOP) and potential glaucomatous damage to the optic nerve. Physical exertion as well as mydriasis may exacerbate pigment release; therefore, when dilating (especially with phenylephrine), you must be sure to measure post-dilated IOPs. 

Salzmann's nodular degeneration appears as blue/white hyaline plaque deposits between the epithelium and Bowman's membrane, generally around the pupillary area of the cornea. This condition stems from other pathologies, primarily old phlyctenula. Treatment is generally not required unless vision is affected. 

Posner-Schlossman syndrome causes an acute IOP spike, usually unilaterally and lasting for hours to weeks with recurrent episodes. Patients are often young and report decreased vision due to corneal edema, mild pain, and ocular redness. This syndrome is also known as glaucomatocyclitic crisis. Biomicroscopy will often reveal ciliary flush, a sluggish or dilated pupil, a mild anterior chamber reaction, potentially with keratic precipitates, corneal edema, open angles and normal optic nerves. IOP readings will normally range from 40-60 mmHg. The etiology is still uncertain; some have postulated that it may be of viral origin. Treatment includes (unless contraindicated) topical steroid drops, beta-blockers, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. 

Pseudoexfoliation appears as white, flaky material that deposits along the pupillary margin, the anterior surface of the lens and other structures of the anterior chamber. This condition is usually unilateral and is seen in the elderly with a concurrent cataract. Transillumination defects, if present, are limited to the iris sphincter region. The pseudoexfoliative material can accumulate in the trabecular meshwork, causing an increase in IOP leading to glaucoma.

questions.question: The size of the Goldmann applanation tonometer is chosen based upon the principle that which two forces will cancel each other out and result in an accurate reading of intraocular pressure?
options: Pressure exerted on the cornea by the aqueous and corneal elasticity
Surface tension of tear film and the force applied externally by the Goldmann tonometer
Surface tension of tear film and corneal elasticity
Force applied externally by the Goldmann tonometer and corneal elasticity
answers: Surface tension of tear film and corneal elasticity
questions.explanation: The area of the cornea to be applanated during measurement of intraocular pressure is chosen specifically to minimize potential error sources such as the surface tension of the tear film and corneal elasticity. If the probe is a certain size (specifically if it has a diameter of 3.06 mm), then theoretically the force from the surface tension of the tear film should cancel the spring force of the cornea. This leaves us with an intraocular pressure reading of within a close proximity (1-2 mm) of the actual IOP.

questions.question: Patients with which of the following ocular conditions are LEAST likely to benefit from a YAG peripheral iridotomy treatment?
options: Narrow angles that are considered occludable
Secondary angle closure glaucoma with pupillary block
questions.explanation:
Plateau iris syndrome is caused by an anteriorly positioned ciliary body, which results in displacement of the peripheral iris forward. The plateau configuration causes narrowing of the angle and can lead to mechanical obstruction of the trabecular meshwork, even though the anterior chamber will appear deep on slit lamp examination. Although an element of pupillary block is usually present in these cases, patients with plateau iris configuration will still show an occludable angle on gonioscopy, even in the presence of a patent peripheral iridotomy. 
Treatment of plateau iris commonly involves performing argon laser peripheral iridoplasty (ALPI), in which peripheral iris burns cause the iris to shrink and pull away from the angle. This laser treatment is much more effective than a laser peripheral iridotomy in preventing or managing angle closure glaucoma.

questions.question: When performing automated perimetry, when one fixates at a particular point, after about 20 seconds or so, a stimulus away from the fixation point will fade away and disappear. What is the name of this phenomenon?
questions.explanation: The Troxler effect is noted when individuals stare at a central fixation point and the peripheral targets disappear. This is observed regularly by patients when performing perimetry. This phenomenon is particularly evident when observing low contrast dull targets. Raynaud's phenomenon refers to an abnormal response of peripheral vasculature when an individual moves from a hot to a cold environment. This condition is caused by restriction of blood flow to the extremities, such as the fingers and toes, causing numbness or an excessively cool sensation when exposed to decreased temperatures or stress. The Riddoch phenomenon refers to the fact that a stimulus is only observed when it is in motion, and cannot be detected by the observer when it is static. The Riddoch phenomenon may be reported by individuals who suffer from an occipital lobe lesion, optic nerve damage, or chiasmal damage. The Stiles Crawford effect I refers to the fact that photoreceptors are more sensitive to light rays from the center of the pupil than to light rays entering from the periphery.

questions.question: A patient who suffers from intermittent angle-closure attacks is MOST likely to experience relief during which of the following activities?
options: Walking into a dark movie theater
questions.explanation: Intermittent angle-closure attacks are most likely to resolve spontaneously when a patient is laying down to sleep due to pupil constriction. Situations that cause pupil mydriasis (such as dimly-illuminated environments) can cause or exacerbate angle-closure. Acute-angle closure glaucoma is typically a unilateral phenomenon and is frequently attributable to pupillary block or plateau iris syndrome. Patients with this condition will often present with blurred vision, corneal edema, and ocular pain along with conjunctival injection, a frontal headache, a fixed and dilated pupil, a shallow anterior chamber, nausea and vomiting, and an elevated intraocular pressure.

questions.question: The semicircles created by the prism of the Goldmann tonometer probe and sodium fluorescein are most successfully viewed with the help of which of the following filters?
options: A filter will not enhance the resultant image
questions.explanation:
A cobalt blue filter is used in conjunction with sodium fluorescein to enhance the resultant image of the semicircles created by the tonometer prism, in order to maximize intraocular pressure measurement. The blue light emitted by the cobalt blue filter excites the sodium fluorescein, which causes it to glow a bright green color. 

Reference: Korb, Donald. The Tear Film: Structure, Function and Clinical Examination (2002). Page 67.

questions.question: Recent studies have demonstrated the implication of which type of cell damage in the early stages of glaucoma?
questions.explanation: With their larger diameter, magno cells may be at risk and can be damaged before smaller neurons such as parvo cells. Recent data suggests that if we can detect damage to magno cells earlier, we may be able to greatly limit damage caused by glaucoma. Due to the ability of magno cells to respond to high temporal frequencies as well as the fact that the cells respond nonlinearly, the integrity of this pathway is able to be tested via a technique that is based upon frequency doubling. Research has demonstrated deficient frequency doubling in people displaying early stages of primary open angle glaucoma.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the most ANTERIOR structure of the anterior chamber angle?
questions.explanation:
Starting with the iris and moving anteriorly, the anterior chamber angle structures are as follows: 
Ciliary body --> scleral spur --> posterior trabecular meshwork --> anterior trabecular meshwork --> Schwalbe's line 

When evaluating the anterior chamber angle using gonioscopy, it is best to orient oneself by beginning with the iris structure and following it out to the ciliary body. The ciliary body will vary in color, depending on the pigmentation of the iris, but is typically darker than the iris itself. Moving anteriorly, the next observable structure is the scleral spur, which will be bright white in color because it is a projection of the white sclera. This is a great landmark when assessing the angle because it does not vary much from person to person. Adjacent to the scleral spur is the trabecular meshwork. This can be greyish or pinkish in color (not as bright as the scleral spur). If there is pigment in the trabecular meshwork, one will be able to differentiate between the posterior and anterior trabecular meshwork; the posterior will be more pigmented than the anterior trabecular meshwork. The most anterior identifiable structure in the angle is Schwalbe's line, which is the termination of Descemet's membrane. It is a white ridge (which may be difficult to observe in some patients) that may occasionally have pigment lying on surface of the ridge. The area anterior to Schwalbe's line represents reflections from the surface of the cornea.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the most POSTERIOR structure of the anterior chamber angle?
questions.explanation:
Starting with the iris and moving anteriorly, the anterior chamber angle structures are as follows: 
Ciliary body --> scleral spur --> posterior trabecular meshwork --> anterior trabecular meshwork --> Schwalbe's line 

When evaluating the anterior chamber angle using gonioscopy, it is best to orient oneself by beginning with the iris structure and following it out to the ciliary body. The ciliary body will vary in color, depending on the pigmentation of the iris, but is typically darker than the iris itself. Moving anteriorly, the next observable structure is the scleral spur, which will be bright white in color because it is a projection of the white sclera. This is a great landmark when assessing the angle because it does not vary much from person to person. Adjacent to the scleral spur is the trabecular meshwork. This can be greyish or pinkish in color (not as bright as the scleral spur). If there is pigment in the trabecular meshwork, one will be able to differentiate between the posterior and anterior trabecular meshwork; the posterior will be more pigmented than the anterior trabecular meshwork. The most anterior identifiable structure in the angle is Schwalbe's line, which is the termination of Descemet's membrane. It is a white ridge (which may be difficult to observe in some patients) that may occasionally have pigment lying on surface of the ridge. The area anterior to Schwalbe's line represents reflections from the surface of the cornea.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a cilio-destructive procedure?
questions.explanation:
Cilio-destructive procedures include cyclophotoablation (laser) or cyclocryoablation (freezing). These processes involve intentional damage to the ciliary processes, which decreases their production of aqueous. These are typically reserved as last resort procedures as they can lead to chronic hypotony as well as inflammation. The majority of clinicians will perform these procedures if the glaucoma is end-stage or complex such as in cases of neovascular glaucoma. However, given recent research and advancements in technological techniques, some surgeons are reconsidering their use of this procedure and are performing it on patients with less advanced glaucoma rather than reserving it as a last resort option. 

A trabeculoplasty is a glaucoma surgical procedure in which a laser beam is utilized to apply burns to areas of the trabecular meshwork with the goal of increasing fluid outflow and decreasing intraocular pressure. There are two types of laser trabeculoplasty procedures that are commonly used: argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT) and selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT). SLT is newer technology than ALT and uses a Nd:YAG laser to specifically target melanocytes within the trabeculum. This provides an effective option for treatment with less thermal damage than ALT. Additionally, unlike ALT, SLT does not affect the overall structure of the trabecular meshwork, allowing for retreatment with SLT if necessary. 

Tube-shunt implantation and trabeculectomy are classified as filtering procedures. Both are considered by the majority of clinicians as the gold standard of incisional procedures for glaucoma. These techniques are typically reserved for patients with moderate to advanced glaucoma who possess good central vision and do not respond adequately to topical therapeutic intervention. 

Color Atlas and Synopsis of Clinical Ophthalmology. Wills Eye Institute. Glaucoma, 2nd edition, Rhee, D. Lipincott, Williams and Wilkins, 2012, page 402.

questions.question: Differences in the depth of the anterior chamber can be observed in patients presenting with varying forms of secondary glaucoma. What is the classic anterior chamber depth appearance in patients with primary angle closure, pigmentary glaucoma, and plateau iris syndrome, respectively?
questions.explanation:
Patients with primary angle closure are anatomically predisposed to an elevation in intraocular pressure that is secondary to the obstruction of aqueous outflow. This blockage of aqueous drainage is caused by occlusion of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris. Classic ocular signs in these patients include short axial length, shallow anterior chamber, and narrow anterior chamber angles. 

Patients with pigmentary glaucoma have characteristically deep anterior chambers that result in the mechanical rubbing of the iris against the crystalline lens zonules, leading to the liberation of fine pigment granules into the anterior chamber. 

Plateau iris syndrome presents in the same way as an angle closure, with elevated intraocular pressures secondary to a blockage of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris; however, the anterior chamber depth is normal, and the iris plane is flat, rather than bowed.

questions.question: Which of the following topical glaucoma combination medications does NOT contain a beta-blocker?
questions.explanation: Simbrinza® is a combination of brinzolamide (a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor) and brimonidine (alpha-2 adrenergic agonist). Cosopt® consists of timolol (beta-blocker) and dorzolamide (carbonic anhydrase inhibitor). Combigan® is comprised of timolol (beta-blocker) and brimonidine (alpha-2 adrenergic agonist). Because Simbrinza® does not contain a beta-blocker, it is a good option for patients who require several medications to manage their glaucoma but also possess contraindications to the use of beta-blockers.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following visual signs indicate a successful laser burn has been placed when performing argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT)? (Select 2)
options: Slight blanching of the trabecular meshwork
Slight darkening of the trabecular meshwork
answers: Slight blanching of the trabecular meshwork
questions.explanation: When performing argon laser trabeculoplasty, the aiming beam should be focused at the junction of the pigmented and non-pigmented trabecular meshwork. Initial laser settings are typically a 50 micron spot size, 0.1 second duration, and 700mW power. Burns are then created with a desired endpoint, resulting in slight blanching of the trabecular meshwork or small bubble formation.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE in regards to selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) for the treatment of glaucoma?
options: SLT can be repeated in the same region if either SLT or ALT (argon laser trabeculoplasty) has been previously attempted
SLT requires a more precise placement of the laser beam and is therefore considered harder to perform
SLT targets the non-pigmented trabecular meshwork
SLT causes more structural damage to the trabecular meshwork tissue than ALT (argon laser trabeculoplasty)
answers: SLT can be repeated in the same region if either SLT or ALT (argon laser trabeculoplasty) has been previously attempted
questions.explanation:
- Selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) may be performed on patients who were unsuccessful with ALT or previous SLT 
- SLT selectively targets pigmented trabecular meshwork cells, while sparing the non-pigmented (non-filtering) cells 
- ALT causes more structural damage to the trabecular meshwork as it increases outflow by the opening of adjacent untreated trabecular spaces through the tightening of the treated trabecular meshwork 
- In SLT, the aiming beam is larger and centered over the trabecular meshwork and straddles the entire structure; because precise placement of the laser beam is not necessary as it is in ALT, SLT is considered technically easier to perform

questions.question: Which enzyme given below is, in part, responsible for the production of aqueous humor?
questions.explanation: Two enzymes are abundantly present in the non-pigmented part of the ciliary epithelium; sodium potassium ATPase and carbonic anhydrase. Both of these enzymes contribute to the production of aqueous humor. Sodium transport is the primary step in the production of aqueous humor because its transport sets up an osmotic gradient, and water follows the sodium ions. Evidence for the importance of this enzyme stems from the fact that when the enzyme sodium potassium ATPase is blocked by chemicals, like ouabain, the production of aqueous humor decreases significantly.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following statements are TRUE in regards to laser settings during argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT) and selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) treatments? (Select 3)
options: Spot size is larger with argon laser trabeculoplasty
Pulse duration is longer with argon laser trabeculoplasty
An Nd:YAG laser is used in selective laser trabeculoplasty
An Nd:YAG laser is used in argon laser trabeculoplasty
Pulse duration is longer with selective laser trabeculoplasty
Spot size is larger with selective laser trabeculoplasty
answers: Pulse duration is longer with argon laser trabeculoplasty
An Nd:YAG laser is used in selective laser trabeculoplasty
Spot size is larger with selective laser trabeculoplasty
questions.explanation:
In ALT, the argon laser is typically set at a 50 micron spot size, 0.1-second duration, and approximately 700mW of power (the power setting can vary between 300-1000 mW, depending on response). 
In SLT, the laser is a 532nm, Q-switched, frequency-doubled, Nd:YAG laser. The laser settings are fixed except for the power. Spot size is approximately 400-microns with a pulse duration is 0.3 ns. The initial energy setting is typically 0.8 mJ (in more heavily pigmented angles, the initial power can usually start off lower at 0.3-0.6 mJ).

questions.question: Which of the following locations of the optic nerve head is MOST likely to exhibit a Drance hemorrhage?
questions.explanation: Optic disc hemorrhages occurring at the margin of the optic nerve are most commonly associated with normal tension glaucoma. These hemorrhages appear at the edge of the optic disc and typically extend onto the nerve fiber layer (called Drance hemorrhages). Additionally, they are most often found at the infero-temporal quadrant of the optic nerve head. It is thought that patients who exhibit progressive optic neuropathy with intraocular pressures (IOPs) consistently within the normal range are likely to have some form of vascular insufficiency or low systemic blood pressure, which can lead to a decrease in ocular perfusion pressure. It is for this reason that optic disc hemorrhages are more commonly observed in individuals exhibiting normal IOPs. When an optic disc hemorrhage is present, it is common to eventually manifest a visual field defect in the region corresponding to the location of the previous hemorrhage (often several months later).

questions.question: Passive secretion of aqueous humor by the processes of ultrafiltration and diffusion is dependent upon which 3 of the following factors? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: In addition to active secretion of aqueous humor by the non-pigmented ciliary epithelial cells, aqueous humor is also produced by the passive processes of ultrafiltration and diffusion. These passive processes are dependent upon certain conditions, such as the level of capillary hydrostatic pressure, the oncotic pressure, and the level of the intraocular pressure. Fluid movement into the posterior chamber is favored by the hydrostatic pressure difference between the capillary pressure and the intraocular pressure. On the other hand, the oncotic pressure of the plasma and aqueous humor resists the movement of fluid into the posterior chamber. Passive secretion is thought to only play a minor role in the production of aqueous humor under normal conditions, as most of the formation of aqueous occurs as a result of active secretion.

questions.question: When assessing the anterior chamber angle, what is an advantage to using a Goldmann 3 mirror as opposed to a four mirror gonioscopy lens?
options: The 3 mirror allows for greater patient comfort
The 3 mirror does not require the use of a cushioning agent
The 3 mirror lens does not need to be rotated on the eye
questions.explanation:
A four mirror is a very convenient tool used to assess the anterior chamber angle. This lens affords a faster exam, does not require a cushioning agent, and allows for greater patient comfort, as is it smaller and does not require rotation on the eye. The 3 mirror, however, offers greater and clearer optics.
PowerPage
Gonioscopy

questions.question: Which of the following sentences regarding the aqueous humor is NOT true?
options: The aqueous humor is a source of antioxidants for the corneal endothelium and the lens
The aqueous humor helps to maintain the shape of the globe and also serves as a shock absorber
The aqueous humor carries oxygen via hemoglobin to the ocular structures
The aqueous humor is a carefully controlled filtrate of the blood
answers: The aqueous humor carries oxygen via hemoglobin to the ocular structures
questions.explanation:
Aqueous humor is a carefully controlled filtrate of the blood that supplies nourishment to both the cornea and crystalline lens. It has a high turnover rate, as it is produced and removed continuously from the eye. If either the production of aqueous humor stops or there is a sudden pathological leaking of fluid, the globe becomes soft and loses its shape. Aqueous humor functions as a shock absorber and provides nutrition including glucose and oxygen to both the lens and cornea. 

The aqueous humor is an excellent source of antioxidants, particularly ascorbate, which may in part help in the removal of free radicals and thus the prevention of cataract formation. However, it does not supply oxygen via hemoglobin. Healthy eyes are devoid of both red blood cells and hemoglobin due to the blood aqueous-barrier; this serves to maintain excellent light transmissibility.

questions.question: A patient is seen at your office and reports a history of LASIK. Her previous prescription was -7.50 DS OD and -6.75-1.00 x 130 OS. How is this likely to affect the measurement of her intraocular pressure (IOP) with Goldmann applanation tonometry?
options: The measured IOP values will be overestimated
The measured IOP values will be accurate
The measured IOP values will be underestimated
answers: The measured IOP values will be underestimated
questions.explanation:
The IOP readings via Goldmann applanation tonometry of post-LASIK patients is typically lower than expected. Goldmann applanation tonometry is affected by corneal hysteresis. Myopic LASIK results in a thinning of the central cornea, since this is an ablative process. Research has demonstrated that one can expect a 0.3-0.4 mmHg decrease in IOP for every diopter of refractive error correction via LASIK. 

LASIK (Laser in Situ Keratomileusis): Fundamentals, Surgical Techniques, and Complications. Azar, D. & Koch, D. Marcel Dekker, 2013, page 380.

questions.question: While assessing the printout of an optical coherence tomography (OCT) scan you notice that the vessels of the right retina appear broken. What is the MOST likely reason for this finding?
options: The patient lost fixation while undergoing imaging
The patient likely has vessel attenuation caused by uncontrolled hypertension
The patient suffers from a ptosis of the right upper eyelid
The patient blinked excessively during scan acquisition
answers: The patient lost fixation while undergoing imaging
