questions.explanation: Eye movements or loss of fixation by the patient while undergoing an OCT scan may be seen as a 'broken' or disjointed blood vessel. Typically, the newer OCT software is able to adjust for small fixation losses without compromising the quality of the scan; however, sometimes it may be necessary to repeat acquisition of the scan. Excessive blinking may lead to an inability to obtain adequate scans of the retina and will appear as black bands on the printout. If the patient suffers from a ptosis, again this area of the scan will be devoid of information and will appear black.

questions.question: When performing a visual field, which of the following information MUST be accurately input into the instrument?
options: The patient's age or date or birth
answers: The patient's age or date or birth
questions.explanation: In order to achieve reliable results when administering a visual field, it is important that the patient's age is correctly input into the instrument. The results of the patient's visual field are compared to normative data of individuals of the same age range. If the age of the patient is incorrect, the interpretation of the visual field may also be erroneous. The test center location, the patient's gender and ethnicity do not directly affect the outcome of visual field performance.

questions.question: A patient with a cataract undergoes a visual field test. Which of the following areas on the visual field print-out is likely to reveal generalized depression?
questions.explanation:
Ptosis and cataracts will most likely present on this area of the printout (see figure 1A). 

The pattern deviation plot gives a more accurate rendering of whether or not a true defect exists by removing excess 'noise' such as that seen with a cataract. By removing the effects of generalized depression, it is easier to determine the size, shape and depth of a visual field defect (see figure 1B). 

The VFI relates information pertaining to the overall amount of field loss. The VFI ranges from 100% (normal) to 0% (a blind eye). This index is purported to be less affected by cataracts than the other indices. The VFI can be used to monitor progression when compared to previous visual field results. 

The glaucoma hemifield test compares test points above the horizontal midline to those below the midline. Any asymmetry is considered suspect and appropriate action should be taken (see figure 1C). 

Cataracts, if they are advanced enough, may cause a generalized depression of the visual field because they will act like a filter and will also scatter light. 

http://www.revoptom.com/content/c/39563/

questions.question: One of the conclusions of The Ocular Hypertension Treatment Study (OHTS) showed that 9.5% of untreated ocular hypertensives developed glaucomatous optic nerve head or visual field damage over the first 5 years of follow-up. What did the study conclude about those who were treated to at least a 20% decrease in intraocular pressure during that same follow-up period?
options: The same amount of treated and untreated ocular hypertensives developed glaucomatous damage
Only 2.4 % of treated ocular hypertensives developed glaucomatous damage
None of the treated ocular hypertensives developed glaucomatous damage
Only 4.4% of treated ocular hypertensives developed glaucomatous damage
answers: Only 4.4% of treated ocular hypertensives developed glaucomatous damage
questions.explanation: The OHTS study's untreated (observation) group showed a 9.5% rate of development of glaucomatous optic nerve head or visual field damage over the first 5 years (about 2% per year over the first 5 years of follow-up). Those in the treated group with at least a 20% decrease in IOP showed only a 4.4% rate of glaucomatous damage over the same 5 years. Therefore; treatment of ocular hypertensives may cut the transition to glaucoma by close to 50%.

questions.question: The mires are of unequal sizes, with the top semicircle being larger than the lower one while performing Goldmann applanation tonometry. What adjustment must be made in order to ensure an accurate intraocular pressure measurement?
options: The tonometer probe must be moved to the right
The tonometer probe must be raised up
The tonometer probe must be moved to the left
The tonometer probe must be lowered
answers: The tonometer probe must be raised up
questions.explanation: When the mires are unequal in size, one must reposition the probe towards the larger mire until the semicircles are of equal size, otherwise the resultant intraocular pressure measurement will be falsely elevated.

questions.question: When performing Van Herick angle estimation of your patient's temporal limbus with the slit lamp, how will placing the lighthouse temporally 40 degrees from the oculars affect the evaluation of the angle estimation?
options: The width of the angle not be affected
The width of the angle will be underestimated
The angle width can only be assessed via direct ophthalmoscopy
The width of the angle will be overestimated
answers: The width of the angle will be underestimated
questions.explanation:
The Van Herick method of angle estimation, although not infallible, is a good way of assessing the probability of angle closure with dilation. The temporal angle of a patient is evaluated by having the patient look straight ahead, placing the oculars of the slit lamp in the straight ahead position and shifting the lighthouse temporally so that an angle of 60 degrees is created. The beam is then narrowed to an optic section and placed at the temporal limbus. The width of the anterior chamber space at the angle is then compared to the width of the corneal optic section. The procedure is repeated and the illumination source is placed nasally to assess the grade of the nasal angle. If the angle space is equal to 1/2 or greater than the corneal optic section, the angle is not considered occludable and is given a grade of 4. A grade 3 displays an angle space that is less than 1/2 but greater than 1/4 of the width of the corneal optic section, and is considered safe to dilate. A grade 2 has an angle space that is roughly equal to 1/4 the width of the corneal optic section, and may be dilated but with caution. A grade 1 has an angle space of less than 1/4 the width of the corneal optic section, and requires gonioscopy to ensure that the patient is safe to dilate. 

Placing the lighthouse so that an angle significantly greater than 60 degrees is created will cause an overestimation of the angle, while an angle much less than 60 degrees will cause underestimation of the angle. 

Reference: Casser, L., Fingeret, M., Woodcome, T. Atlas of Primary Eye Care Procedures, 2nd edition 1997, pp. 28-29.

questions.question: Which of the following glaucoma medications has the FASTEST PEAK onset of action?
questions.explanation:
Timolol maleate blocks both beta1 and beta2 adrenergic receptors and serves to decrease intraocular pressure. The effects of timolol ophthalmic solution may be observed as early as one half hour after drop instillation, reaching peak efficiency at one- to two-hours post-instillation. 

Brimonidine tartrate is an alpha-2 adrenergic receptor agonist causing increased uveoscleral outflow and decreased aqueous production. Topical ocular administration results in peak IOP reduction levels two hours after instillation. 

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog and decreases intraocular pressure (IOP) by increasing uveoscleral outflow. Its effects reach peak effectiveness roughly two hours after use. 

Bimatoprost is also a prostaglandin analog and causes IOP reduction via increasing both uveoscleral and trabecular meshwork outflow. Its effects can be observed four hours after instillation, reaching peak effectiveness at eight to twelve hours after instillation. 

References: 
https://www.apotex.com/us/en/products/downloads/bio/timo_opso_be.pdf. 
http://www.alphaganp.com/alphganp.pdf. 
http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2012/020597s044lbl.pdf. 
http://www.allergan.com/assets/pdf/lumigan_pi.pdf.

questions.question: Which of the following glaucoma medications is the LEAST effective at stabilizing a spike in the intraocular pressure (IOP) that transpires at night?
questions.explanation:
Studies have demonstrated that aqueous production decreases at night due to decreased adrenergic stimulation. Due to the fact that Timoptic? largely functions by reducing aqueous production by decreasing the concentration of cyclic andenosine monophosphate (cAMP) in the ciliary epithelium, this medication is not as effective at stabilizing a nocturnal spike in IOP. However, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors remain effective at decreasing aqueous production nocturnally because the carbonic anhydrase component of the system that controls aqueous production at night remains active. Interference or inhibition of this component of the system will therefore lead to decreased IOP. Although Alphagan-P? also serves to decrease aqueous production, studies have shown that it does remain effective at night (likely due to its role in increasing uveoscleral outflow). Prostaglandin analogs such as Lumingan? maintain good control of IOP both diurnally and nocturnally and significantly decrease the risk of an IOP spike. 

References: 
http://www.revoptom.com/content/c/27571/ 
Pearls in Glaucoma Therapy. Tanuj, D., Parul, I. & Spaeth, G. Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishing, 2011, page 124. 
Diagnosis and Management of Glaucoma. Ramakrishana, R. et al. Jaypee-Highlights Medical Publishers, 2013, pages 479-489.

questions.question: Which of the following surgical glaucoma treatments involves the application of laser burns to the trabeculum in order to enhance aqueous outflow and subsequently lower intraocular pressure?
questions.explanation:
A trabeculoplasty is a glaucoma surgical procedure in which a laser beam is utilized to apply burns to areas of the trabecular meshwork with the goal of increasing fluid outflow and decreasing intraocular pressure. There are two types of laser trabeculoplasty procedures that are commonly used: argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT) and selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT). SLT is newer technology than ALT and uses a Nd:YAG laser to specifically target melanocytes within the trabeculum. This provides an effective option for treatment with less thermal damage than ALT. Additionally, unlike ALT, SLT does not affect the overall structure of the trabecular meshwork, allowing for retreatment with SLT if necessary. 

A trabeculectomy is glaucoma procedure that involves creating a fistula between the angle of the anterior chamber and sub-Tenon's space. This allows for a secondary route for drainage of the aqueous, which is allowed to flow directly from the anterior chamber into a 'drainage bleb,' bypassing the trabeculum. 

Trabeculotomy surgery is traditionally performed in cases of congenital glaucoma and involves surgically dissecting the trabeculum to create a more direct opening for aqueous to flow into Schlemm's canal. The anterior chamber angle is accessed via the external surface of the eye; therefore, the need for a clear cornea is unnecessary. 

An iridotomy involves creating an opening in the tissue of the iris (usually with a YAG laser). An iridectomy involves the intraocular removal of iris tissue (usually from the far periphery).

questions.question: The scleral spur is the most posterior structure visible in all four quadrants using your Goldmann 3- mirror while performing gonioscopy. Is this patient considered safe to dilate?
options: Yes, the patient is absolutely safe to dilate
No, the patient should undergo a laser peripheral iridotomy prior to dilation
Yes, but the patient should be dilated with caution
No, the patient will never be able to undergo dilation even with a peripheral laser iridotomy
answers: Yes, the patient is absolutely safe to dilate
questions.explanation:
According to the Becker-Shaffer grading system, the ability to safely dilate a patient is determined by which ocular structure is visible most posteriorly. The anatomy of the angle of the anterior chamber is comprised of several structures. The most posterior of the structures is the ciliary body, followed by the scleral spur, trabecular meshwork, and lastly Schwalbe's line, which is the most anterior. A grade of 4 is assigned if the ciliary body is visible, and is considered safe for dilation. When the scleral spur is the most posterior structure visible the angle is graded as a 3 and is safe to dilate. When 1/2 to 1/3 of the trabecular meshwork is visible, the angle is classified as a 2 and is somewhat risky to dilate. When only the most anterior portion or only Schwalbe's line is viewed, the angle is graded as a 1 and is considered to be at high risk for angle occlusion. If no structures are seen, then the angle is classified as 0 and the angle is closed.
PowerPage
Gonioscopy

questions.question: Which of the following prostaglandin analog glaucoma medications has a dosing regimen of twice a day?
questions.explanation:
Rescula®, although a prostaglandin, is structurally different and functionally unique when compared to the other prostaglandins. Rescula® is prescribed twice daily and serves to increase the trabecular outflow. Zioptan® , Travatan® and Xalatan® enhance uveoscleral outflow. Lumigan® increases both uveoscleral and trabecular outflow. The prostaglandin analogs (except Rescula®) are prescribed for use once a day. 

http://www.travatanz.com/ 
http://www.lumigan.com/ 
http://www.rescula.com/ 
http://www.merck.com/product/usa/pi_circulars/z/zioptan/zioptan.html 
http://www.xalatan.com/content/prescribing-information.aspx

questions.category: Lens / Cataract / IOL / Pre and Post-operative Care | General
questions.question: Posterior capsular opacification is a common occurrence after cataract surgery. A patient with which of the following conditions should NOT undergo a Neodymium YAG (Yttrium aluminum garnet) laser capsulotomy?
options: Mild glaucoma controlled with topical medications
Active iritis with 2+ cells/flare in the anterior chamber
1+ superficial punctate keratitis (SPK) secondary to dry eyes
answers: Active iritis with 2+ cells/flare in the anterior chamber
questions.explanation:
Patients with active inflammation of the anterior chamber should not undergo YAG capsulotomy. Because a YAG capsulotomy creates a potential conduit between the anterior and posterior pole, any inflammation present in the anterior chamber may increase the chances of posterior pole inflammation. If the patient presents with an active anterior chamber inflammation, the procedure should be delayed until the inflammation has subsided. 

Patients with SPK secondary to dry eyes or a large choroidal nevus can undergo YAG capsulotomy, as can those with controlled glaucoma. Although intraocular pressure (IOP) spikes are a potential side effect of a YAG capsulotomy, patients are monitored closely after the procedure to ensure that if an IOP spike occurs it is addressed immediately.

questions.category: Lens / Cataract / IOL / Pre and Post-operative Care | General
questions.question: Which of the following procedures may be eliminated when performing a refraction on a patient who is bilaterally pseudophakic?
options: The establishment of monocular best-corrected acuities
questions.explanation:
The ultimate purpose of performing a binocular balance test is to ensure that the eyes achieve an equal accommodative state. It therefore follows that patients who are monocular, pseudophakic, or over the age of 60 do not require binocular balance testing. 

All patients, even those who are pseudophakic, require the determination of best-corrected monocular and binocular visual acuities. Cover testing is also important in this population, as decompensation of vergence ranges may occur, causing asthenopia with reading or near viewing tasks. Cover testing will allow for the detection of large phorias or the development of previously undocumented tropias, which may require further investigation. 

Clinical Procedures in Primary Eye Care, 4th edition. Elliott, D. Elsevier, 2013, page 94.

questions.category: Lens / Cataract / IOL / Pre and Post-operative Care | General
questions.question: Which of the four Purkinje images is inverted?
questions.explanation: There are four Purkinje images. The first image is caused by reflection from the anterior corneal surface and is the brightest of the images. The first image is roughly the same size as the object. The second Purkinje image is formed by the posterior surface of the cornea and almost coincides with the first Purkinje image. The third Purkinje image is the largest and is caused by reflection off of the anterior plane of the crystalline lens. The fourth Purkinje image is the smallest and is inverted, formed by reflection off of the posterior surface of the lens.

questions.category: Lens / Cataract / IOL / Pre and Post-operative Care | General
questions.question: What is the MOST common type of intraocular lens implant utilized to replace the crystalline lens after cataract surgery?
questions.explanation:
A posterior chamber intraocular lens implant (PCIOL) is the lens preferred by surgeons because it helps to better simulate natural vision due to lens placement, and poses the least risk of complications. Most surgeons will attempt to place the PCIOL in front of the posterior capsule, which ideally is left intact post-surgery. Anterior chamber lens implants are generally used if the posterior capsule breaks or there is some other reason that a PCIOL cannot be used. Iris-fixed are rarely used anymore. A characteristic finding with these lenses is that this implant induces a square pupil. If you encounter an iris-fixed intraocular lens implant, you CANNOT dilate this patient because you may cause dislocation of the lens.
PowerPage
Crystalline Lens

questions.question: You are working with an 80-year old patient who has wet macular degeneration. His visual acuity is measured at 8/200 in the right eye and 8/400 in the left eye through his habitual spectacle prescription. When performing a trial frame refraction, what spherical lenses do you start with for the right eye?
questions.explanation: OD 8/200 = 20/500 Just noticeable difference is 5.00D; trial lenses would span the 5 D interval and be +/- 2.50 D.

questions.question: An 82-year-old patient presents with age-related macular degeneration. The visual acuity obtained on the ETDRS chart, with best correction, is 2/40 in the right and the left eye. The starting bracketing lenses (i.e., the lens that the patient is theoretically most sensitive to or just noticeable difference), following retinoscopy and used by a low vision clinician in the subjective evaluation would be which of the following?
questions.explanation: Low vision clinicians traditionally refine the refraction in a trial frame. The bracketing lenses used in refining the refraction are dependent upon the findings of the incoming visual acuity. The bracketing lenses used, for example, with a visual acuity of 4/40 (which is equivalent to 20/200) is a + and -1.00. This is determined by dividing the denominator by 2. 200/2 = +/-1.00. The bracketing lenses for a visual acuity of 1/40 (20/800) would be +/-4.00. The power of the bracketing lenses therefore increases with decreasing visual acuity.

questions.question: According to Kestenbaum's rule, what add power would be needed for your low vision patient to read 1M-sized print at near if her distance visual acuity is measured to be 20/200?
questions.explanation:
Kestenbaum's rule is a method that is often utilized in determining the approximate near add power necessary to read standard newspaper print (1M) in a low vision patient with significantly reduced visual acuity. It is meant to be used as an estimate or starting point, and then can be refined based on how the patient responds to the magnification. 

In order to arrive at a near add power, the reciprocal of the patient's distance visual acuity is calculated. 
For example, in the above patient, her distance visual acuity was measured to be 20/200. The reciprocal of this is 200/20, or 10. Therefore, a +10.00 D lens is the starting add power needed to read 1M font, according to Kestenbaum's rule.

questions.question: Your 73 year-old low vision patient reports to you that he would like to be able to read the scoreboard at his grandson's baseball games, which you determine to be equivalent to an acuity of 20/100. If his distance acuity is measured to be 20/400, what magnification is needed in a telescope in order to see this?
questions.explanation:
In order to determine the magnification needed for a patient to be able to see a particular object, one requires the measurement of the patient's entering acuity and the acuity of the goal they desire to see. 
For example, the above patient's entering visual acuity is 20/400, and his goal acuity is 20/100. Once these two values are known, the entering acuity is then divided by the goal acuity, with the result being the needed angular magnification. Again, for the above patient: 400/100 = 4. Therefore, he would require a telescope with at least 4x magnification to see the scoreboard.

questions.question: Your patient wishes to see street signs and bus signs better with the aid of a hand-held telescope. The side of the telescope is marked 6x18. What is the diameter of the exit pupil?
questions.explanation:
The exit pupil diameter is calculated by dividing the size of the objective lens (18 mm) by the the magnification (6) ; 18/6=3 

If the student switched the two measurements 6/18, they would have arrived at 0.33 as the answer. If the student multiplied rather than divided, 10.8 mm would have been the conclusion; (6x18) = 108.

questions.question: What is the equivalent of a Reduced Snellen 20/50 optotype in metric notation (assuming a working distance of 40 cm)?
questions.explanation:
To convert from Reduced Snellen to metric notation one must divide the denominator by 50. In the above example 50/50 = 1M. 

To convert from Reduced Snellen to Printer's point, divide the denominator by 6. To convert from Printer's point to metric, divide by 8. To convert from Metric notation to Reduced Snellen, multiply by 50; this will give you the denominator of Reduced Snellen. 

A good rule of thumb is 1M = RS 20/50 = 8 point. 

Here is the conversion triangle:

questions.question: A patient is using a stand magnifier of +16D with a +2.00 add. If the distance separating the two lenses is 25 cm what is the equivalent power of this combination?
questions.explanation:
De= D1+D2 -tD1D2 where De=equivalent power;D1=power of magnifier;D2=power add;t=separation in meters between the lenses 
De = (16+2) - 0.25(16)(2) De= 18-8 = 10D 

18D- incorrect answer -would come up with this if added the stand magnifier power to the power of the add 
22D -incorrect answer - would come up with this if added 16D for stand mag 2D for add and 4D for equivalent of 25cm. 
26D - if added the 18 +8 in the De equation instead of subtracting

questions.question: Your patient's best corrected acuity measured 10/160. What magnification would be required to read 0.8M text?
questions.explanation:
10/160 = 20/320 Goal is 0.8M = Reduced Snellen 40 320/40 =8x 

If the student did not convert the acuity to the 20ft notation and used 160/40, they would have arrived at 4x as the answer. 6.4x would have been the conclusion if 50 had been used instead of 40; 0.8M = Reduced Snellen 40, not RS 50. If the 10 foot equivalent was used, also mistaking 0.8M for Reduced Sellen 50 instead of 40, 3.2x would have been found as the answer; 160/50 = 3.2x.

questions.question: A 2.5x Galilean telescope has a -25D ocular lens. When focused for infinity, what is the length of the telescope?
questions.explanation:
M = -Doc/Dobj where Doc=power ocular; Dobj= power objective; t= separation of lenses 
2.5= - (-)25/Dobj 
Dobj= 10D 
t= f'obj + f'oc 
f'obj=1/10D = 0.10 m 
f'oc = 1/-25D = 0.04 m 

t=0.10 + -0.04 = 0.06 m or 6 cm 

10 cm - incorrect- would come up with this answer if only took in account the focal length of the objective lens. 
4 cm - incorrect- would come up with this answer if only took in account the focal length of the ocular lens. 
14 cm - incorrect - would come up with this answer if thought equation was t= f'obj + f'oc

questions.question: You have a telescope upon which the markings are unreadable. You wish to determine the magnification of the telescope. The objective lens measures 16 mm and the ocular lens measures 6 mm. You are able to accurately measure the exit pupil to be 4 mm. What is the magnification of the telescope?
questions.explanation:
The formula for telescopic magnification = objective lens diameter/exit pupil diameter 

In the above example, telescopic magnification = 16 mm/4 mm = 4x magnification

questions.question: You determine that your low vision patient will require +10.00 high-powered reading glasses for near work. Which of the following types of prism should be added into the spectacles in an effort to maintain binocularity?
questions.explanation:
Low vision patients typically require a higher add power for near work than patients with normal vision in order to allow for enough relative distance magnification to read print such as the newspaper. In cases in which high-powered plus lenses are needed, these patients will also require the addition of base-in prism to aid in convergence at such close reading distances to maintain binocularity. A general rule-of-thumb for high-powered reading glasses is that the amount of base-in prism added to the spectacle Rx should be 2 prism diopters greater than the dioptric amount of the optical correction in each eye. For example, in the above question, the patient will need +10.00 readers; +10.00 + 2.00 = 12.00 prism diopters of base-in prism. 

Clinical Guide to Comprehensive Ophthalmology. Lee, D.A., Higginbotham, E.J. 1999. Thieme. New York, NY.

questions.question: Your trial frame refraction yields a distance prescription of -1.00 DS in both eyes of your 78-year old low vision patient. Using a +4.00 DS OU near prescription only with a CCTV set to 16x magnification, what is the equivalent power?
questions.explanation:
De= (Mrd)(Dadd), where De= equivalent Power and Mrd= Magnification of relative distance. De= 16x5= 80 D 

The add is +5.00, not +4.00, to account for uncorrected myopia. If the additional +1.00 D (due to uncorrected myopia) was not accounted for, 64 D would have been concluded. 21 D would have been concluded if the student simply added 16 and 5. If a 40 cm working distance had been assumed, 32 D would have been selected; (16/2.5)x5= 32.

questions.question: In order to determine if your non-aphakic low vision patient is legally blind based only on visual fields, you must use which of the following tests?
questions.explanation:
Section 2.03A of Social Security Act states you must use a light projected stimulus test, Goldmann III4e or equivalent. You can also use Humphrey automated static threshold perimetry with 30-2 or 24-2 and size III target and 31.5 apostilbs (10 cd/m2) background illumination, targets must be no more than 6 degrees apart horizontally or vertically. The Humphrey brand of perimeter is not required, but if another brand is used, it must have: 
- Optical projection of stimulus (no LEDs, no FDT) 
- Normative database and statistical analysis package 
- Demonstrated clinical validity reported in 3 or more independent peer-reviewed papers 
- Screening tests, such as confrontation, tangent screen; automated screening tests are expressly prohibited

questions.question: Which patient would be considered legally blind?
options: A myopic patient with acuities of 20/400 OD and OS uncorrected
A wet macular degeneration patient with best central acuities of 10/120 OD and 10/200 OS
A retinitis pigmentosa patient who has 20/20 central vision in each eye and a 30 degree in diameter visual field
A patient with Best's disease with best corrected central acuities measure OD 10/80 and OS 10/100
A patient with a total retinal detachment of the right eye, no light perception and a best corrected central acuity of 8/60 due to wet macular degeneration
answers: A wet macular degeneration patient with best central acuities of 10/120 OD and 10/200 OS
questions.explanation: Legal blindness must take into account central best corrected visual acuity, with the better eye 20/200 or worse. If the central acuity is normal such as in the RP patient then the field would be the restricting qualification, which, at 30 degrees, does not qualify.

questions.question: Your advanced glaucoma patient brings in a broken telescope that he would like to replace. Looking at the telescope, how can you tell that it is a Keplerian design?
options: By the weight of the telescope
It has a virtual exit pupil
By the amount of magnification of the telescope
It has a real exit pupil
By the length of the telescope
answers: It has a real exit pupil
questions.explanation: Keplerian telescopes always have a real exit pupil; it is located outside the telescope beyond the eye piece. Galilean telescopes have a virtual exit pupil that is located within the system. In general, Keplerian telescopes are heavier and longer than Galilean designs but the type of scope cannot be determined based only on that information.

questions.question: The denial of vision loss in patients with blindness is known as which of the following phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Patients with cortical blindness can often be unaware of their visual deficit. This denial of blindness is known as Anton's syndrome, or visual anosognosia. In these cases, patients will act as if their vision is unaffected. They tend to run into walls, bump into objects, and walk around without the precautions that a blind person would take. When confronted about their vision loss and behavior, patients will make excuses such as 'the lighting is poor' or 'these glasses must be an old prescription.' This syndrome mostly occurs in patients with blindness due to occipital lobe disease, but it may also occur subsequent to cataracts, retinopathies, and optic nerve disease. The explanation of the mechanism and anatomy responsible for Anton's syndrome is widely unknown and unclear. Typically, after several weeks or months, patients eventually become aware of their visual deficits. 

Blindsight is the opposite of visual anosognosia. These patients have some visual function but are unaware of it and deny its existence. They lack awareness of visual stimuli, but respond to it. 

Charles Bonnet syndrome occurs in patients with severe vision loss who experience hallucinatory images. These patients are completely aware the objects that they are seeing are not real, and there is no history of mental disorder.

questions.question: A patient presents with chronic open angle glaucoma. The contrast sensitivity function (CSF) on the MARS CSF chart is profoundly reduced in the right eye. Reduced CSF would manifest itself in all of listed options EXCEPT for which of the following?
options: Driving at night, in rain or in foggy conditions
In reading instructions on a medicine container
Reading a menu in a dimly lit restaurant
questions.explanation: Reduced contrast sensitivity makes the world appear hazy or washed out. Older adults who have poorer levels of contrast may have difficulty in judging distances and are more likely to experience a fall than those with better contrast sensitivity in areas of poor lighting. Patients with reduced contrast sensitivity have problems as well with reading low-contrast text such as that on medicine bottles or store receipts. Discomfort glare occurs when the overall illumination is too bright (e.g. when the midday sun is reflected from sand or snow).

questions.question: The visual acuity of a 77 year-old female patient with age-related macular degeneration is 2/16 in the right eye on the ETDRS chart. Why is this chart useful in monitoring the response to treatment with anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)?
options: Each line is 1.0 log units larger than the previous line
A three-line decrease represents a factor of a two time decrease in the size of the letters
The Snellen construction of the chart enables the examiner to quickly note that a two-line increment represents a factor of a two time increase in the size of the letters
Each line has 5 Sloan letters throughout the chart with equal spacing and is 1.26 times larger than the line below it; each line is .1 log units larger than the line below it when moving up the chart
answers: Each line has 5 Sloan letters throughout the chart with equal spacing and is 1.26 times larger than the line below it; each line is .1 log units larger than the line below it when moving up the chart
questions.explanation:
The ETDRS chart is a logarithmic eye chart modeled after the Bailey-Lovie chart. It is the primary standardized eye chart used in evaluating the visual acuity of low vision patients. The ETDRS charts are logMAR (log of the minimum angle of resolution) in design and are constructed with 10 Sloan sans serif letters. Each line is 1.26 times larger than the line below, and the construction of each line is such that the difficulty is theoretically equivalent on every line. 

The construction of the ETDRS chart is made to eliminate the inherent errors in the measurement of visual acuity found in the traditional non-standardized Snellen test charts. The Snellen test charts have variations in legibility of different letters as well as differences in the spacing between the lines of letters and between adjacent letters on single lines. The ETDRS logarithmic chart is constructed in such a way that each line of letters is 0.1 log units (about 1.26 times) larger than the previous line. This is a geometric progression.

questions.question: Illumination is one of the most important considerations to discuss in the case disposition for a visually impaired patient. A patient with chronic open angle glaucoma moves a 60 watt bulb on a flexible mounted arm from three feet to one foot from the page. The illumination on the page will appear to have been increased by how much?
options: Increased by 3 times the original brightness
Increased by 9 times the original brightness
Decreased by 1/3 of the original brightness
Decreased by 1/9 of the original brightness
answers: Increased by 9 times the original brightness
questions.explanation: It has been said that prescribed optical devices without consideration of the appropriate lighting will often doom the patient to failure. Unfortunately, there are no good tests to determine the exact type of lighting. Generally, different light levels are tried during the examination (as well as during the training session) with the patient using an adjustable light. The distance from the page is very important because of the inverse-square law of illumination: the intensity varies inversely as the square of the distance from the page. If the light is moved from 1 foot to 3 feet from the page, a bulb will be needed that is approximately nine times as bright to keep the same illumination on the page. (It should be noted that technically, this relationship is only true for a point source of light.) Clinically, however, it gives a good approximation of the change in brightness (illumination) seen on the page when the distance of the light is changed. The illumination in the above example would therefore increase by 9X when the bulb is moved towards the page.

questions.question: Which of the following pathologies is MOST likely to result in a generalized depression of the visual field?
options: Tilted discs of the optic nerve
questions.explanation:
Cataracts, if they are advanced enough, may cause a generalized depression of the visual field because they will act like a filter and they will also scatter light. Macular scarring is likely to result in a central scotoma, depending upon the extent of the scarring, but the peripheral portion of the field should remain unaffected. A patient who has tilted discs will have an optic nerve that exits the eye superiorly and may be accompanied by situs inversus, fundus ectasia, myopia, and superior temporal visual field defects. Drusen of the optic nerve head may present with vertical elongation of the blind spot, and occasionally peripheral constriction of the visual field or arcuate defects, making it sometimes difficult to discern from glaucomatous damage. Other causes of generalized depression include but are not limited to: fatigue, small pupils, advanced age, and media opacities. 

References: Susanna, R. and Medeiros, F. The Optic Nerve in Glaucoma 2nd edition, 2006 pages 131-132. 

Alwitry, A. and Vernon S. Shared Care Glaucoma, 2008 pages 110-112.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding the objective lens of a telescope?
options: It is the lens furthest from the eye, it is always positive in power, it limits the amount of light entering the telescope
It is the lens closest to the eye, it is negative in power for Galilean systems, and it limits the amount of light entering the eye
It is the lens closest to the eye, it is positive in power for a Keplerian system, and it limits the amount of light entering the eye
It is the lens furthest from the eye, it is always negative in power, and it limits the amount of light entering the telescope
It is the lens furthest from the eye, it is negative in power for Galilean systems, and it limits the amount of light entering the telescope
answers: It is the lens furthest from the eye, it is always positive in power, it limits the amount of light entering the telescope
questions.explanation:
The objective lens (or system of lenses) is the lens closest to the object being viewed or furthest from the eye. Because of its orientation, it limits the amount of light entering the telescope. The objective lens (or system of lenses) is always positive for all telescopes. 

The ocular lens is the lens closest to the eye. This lens (or system of lenses) is positive in power in Keplerian designs and negative in power in Galilean designs. The absolute value of the power of the ocular lens is always greater than that of the objective lens.

questions.question: One of your tech-savvy low vision patients wishes to use a CCTV for reading. The CCTV operates on what principle of magnification?
questions.explanation:
CCTVs work on the principle of relative size magnification (or projection). It operates by enlarging the text without lenses in front of the patient or the patient moving closer to the device. When the print is enlarged electronically in this matter, the image of the print subtends a larger area on the retina and thus a larger size. 

An example of relative distance magnification would be if you were holding a newspaper at 40 cm and you moved it closer to 20 cm. The print now appears 2 times as large relative to the 40 cm distance. 

Rated magnification is often used by manufacturers of some hand magnifiers and stand magnifiers using a 25 cm reference distance.

questions.question: Congenital cataracts can be caused by a viral infection of the mother with rubella virus (German measles) during development of the primary lens fibers. At which time period in embryonic development can infection cause congenital cataracts?
questions.explanation:
The developing lens is susceptible to rubella virus when the lens fibers are forming, which occurs around weeks 4-7 of gestation. Earlier infection will occur prior to lens fiber development, and the lens is resistant to later infection because the virus is unable to penetrate the lens capsule. 

The fetus is most susceptible to lenticular damage during the first trimester. Contraction of the rubella virus will cause the greatest amount of damage during this time period. Congenital cataracts are usually detectable at birth but may be seen later because the virus can persist in the lens. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 109

questions.question: What type of organism is responsible for the development of syphilis infections?
questions.explanation:
The causative organism of syphilis is a spirochete known as Treponema pallidum. Spirochetes have a unique structure that is responsible for their motility. This distinctive configuration consists of a central protoplasmic cylinder, bound by a plasma membrane, cell wall, and an outer sheath composed of glycosaminoglycans. Between the cell wall and outer sheath are multiple periplasmic flagella. These flagella span the entire length of the cell and are anchored at both ends. It is believed that the flagella rotate and cause the organism to propel forward in a corkscrew-like manner. Spirochetes can easily move through viscous solutions with little impediment, which explains their ability to easily penetrate and invade host tissue. 

Gonorrhea, chlamydia, and tuberculosis are all infections caused by bacteria. The causative organism of HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) is a lentivirus; toxoplasmosis is caused by a parasite, and toxocariasis is caused by a nematode.

questions.question: Antibiotic resistance that is rapidly spread within a population of bacteria is due to what mechanism?
questions.explanation: Conjugation occurs between a donor (possesses a conjugative plasmid) and recipient bacteria. The donor bacterium initiates contact with the recipient via a sex pilus, allowing for cell-to-cell contact and transfer of DNA. The plasmids often contain genes that encode for toxin production, virulence factors, and antibiotic resistance. Genetic transformation is achieved by very few strains of bacteria and may only occur during certain phases of growth; therefore, rapid antibiotic resistance is not feasible. Budding and binary fission are means of reproduction but are not directly responsible for antibacterial resistance. Genes must have been transferred that code for resistance prior to budding and binary fission in order for the progeny to contain genes that allow for drug resistance.

questions.question: Which of the following microorganisms is associated with peptic ulcer formation?
questions.explanation: H. pylori is a helix-shaped gram-negative microaerophillic organism that colonizes in cells that secrete the mucosal lining of the stomach. These bacteria protect themselves from stomach acid by secreting urease, which, through a series of reactions, helps to neutralize the lower pH levels. H. pylori causes chronic gastritis, which in turn can lead to ulcer formation if pepsin and stomach acid levels increase to the point that the protective mucosal lining is broken down. C. tetani is associated with the contraction of tetanus. V. cholerae causes cholera, resulting in abdominal cramps, diarrhea, fever, and vomiting.

questions.question: A positive catalase test indicates that a bacteria is capable of breaking down which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Catalase is an enzyme commonly found in organisms that are exposed to oxygen. Catalase breaks down hydrogen peroxide into oxygen and water. The catalase test is performed by applying a drop of hydrogen peroxide to a microscope slide. A colony of bacteria is then exposed to the hydrogen peroxide via an applicator stick. The presence of bubbles or froth yields a positive catalase test. Staphylococci and Micrococci are catalase-positive organisms. Campylobacter and Escherichia coli are catalase-negative organisms. 

Ref: Brock, Madigan et al. Biology of Microorganisms 9th edition (2000) pg 160-161

questions.question: What term describes the phenomenon in which a bacterium directs its movement TOWARD a chemical in its environment?
questions.explanation:
Many bacteria possess flagella, or thread-like appendages, which allow for movement. Certain chemicals attract bacteria (chemoattractants), while others repel them (chemorepellents). Chemotaxis refers to the response of the bacteria to either chemoattractants or chemorepellents. In the absence of either of the aforementioned chemicals, bacteria will move in random patterns. Some bacteria possess genes and proteins which allow for the sensing of concentration gradients in their environment. In the presence of a chemoattractant, bacteria will have longer runs in the appropriate direction. 

Apoptosis is defined as programmed cell death. 

Phagocytosis refers to the engulfment of a particle (for example, bacteria) by a phagocyte (for example, a macrophage). 

Transposition refers to the rare phenomenon in which genes move from one place on the genome to another position.

questions.question: The pox virus is an example of which type of basic virus structure?
questions.explanation: Viruses are highly variable in their sizes and shapes. There are essentially five (or four if you consider 'enveloped' a class of its own) general classifications of structures: naked helical, enveloped helical, naked icosahedral, enveloped icosahedral and complex. Helically-shaped virions appear like a tightly-coiled ribbon that can form a rod or can resemble a telephone cord. An example of one such virus is the tobacco mosaic virus. Icosahedral appears as a polyhedron, with 20 equilateral triangular faces and 12 vertices. Each point of the different triangles is joined together, forming a capsomere, which can either be 5- or 6- sided. The adenovirus is an example of an icosahedral structure. Complex viruses appear neither icosahedral nor helical and tend to comprise tails or complex outer walls. Viruses are further classified based upon the nucleic acid genome. Viruses contain DNA or RNA that may be single-stranded or double-stranded, linear or circular, segmented or not. Classification also depends on whether or not the viral RNA can function as messenger RNA.

questions.question: Which organism is responsible for Lyme disease?
questions.explanation: Borrelia burgdorferi is a Gram-negative spirochete that is transmitted via mice and deer ticks. A person or child affected by Lyme disease may experience fatigue, headaches, and fevers. A definitive diagnostic sign is a red rash with a bull's eye appearance around the site of infection called erythema migrans occurring three to thirty days post-bite. Yersinia pestis is a gram-negative rod responsible for causing the plague. Legionella pneumophila is a Gram-negative bacterium and is the culprit that causes Legionnaire's disease. This bacterium takes up residence in the lungs and causes high fevers, headaches, and severe bronchopneumonia among other problems. Corynebacterium diphtheriae is a Gram-positive rod normally found in very overcrowded living conditions. This pathogen can lead to kidney, cardiac, and nervous tissue destruction.

questions.question: Which organism is responsible for Rocky Mountain spotted fever?
questions.explanation:
Rickettsia is a Gram-negative obligate intracellular bacterium. Rickettsia is found on ticks, fleas, and lice and can cause many diseases in humans including typhus, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and rickettsial pox. Rocky Mountain spotted fever is caused by tick bites. Symptoms include chills, fever, rash, headache, nausea, vomiting, muscle pain, and confusion. The prognosis is good with treatment. Rarely, complications can lead to hearing loss, paralysis, brain damage, lung failure, kidney failure, nerve damage, and death. Treatment includes careful removal of the tick along with tetracycline or doxycycline. 

Mycoplasma is a genus of bacteria that lack a cell wall and are capable of causing atypical pneumonia. Corynebacterium is associated with diphtheria. Cryptococcus neoformans is a type of fungus that causes cryptococcosis which is an infection that involves the central nervous system and the lungs.

questions.question: Athlete's foot and jock itch are examples of which type of human infection?
questions.explanation: Human fungal infections can be categorized based upon the site of invasion and the degree of infection. Cutaneous infections are limited to deeper layers of the skin, hair and nails. Examples of offending pathogens are epidermophyton and microsporum, which can lead to tinea, ring worm, jock itch, and athlete's foot. Cutaneous infections are usually treated with topical ointments (for instance, Monistat-Derm® (miconazole)). Superficial infections do not extend deeper than the outermost layers of the skin, hair, and nails and are often seen in tropical regions. A common superficial infection is that caused by Tinea versicolor, which results in the appearance of spots on the back, chest, arms and legs. Superficial infections are commonly resolved through the use of cleansing agents. Subcutaneous infections involve deep tissue and result from the introduction of fungi through a piercing wound. These types of infections tend to be chronic in nature and can prove to be difficult to treat. An example of a subcutaneous infection is Sporotrichosis which is caused by Sporothrix schenckii. Remedies include amphotericin B, 5-fluorocytosine, or surgical excision. Systemic infections generally originate in the lungs due to inhalation of spores of dimorphic fungi. Common examples are histoplasmosis and valley fever (coccidioides). Opportunistic fungal infections are seen in individuals who are immunocompromised. These types of infections tend to be very serious and can be fatal. Examples of opportunistic infections include aspergillosis, candidiasis (thrush), and Pneumocystis pneumonia.

questions.question: Which of the following regarding zone of inhibition is TRUE?
options: Denotes the sensitivity of an organism to an antibiotic
The larger the zone of inhibition, the greater the degree of resistance displayed by the organism
Allows one to quantify the number of plaque-forming units (PFU)
Allows for the determination of which type of media promotes the proliferation of a specific bacteria
answers: Denotes the sensitivity of an organism to an antibiotic
questions.explanation: An agar plate is inoculated with an isolated bacterium. Disks that are permeated with different antibiotics are placed in separate places on the agar plate. After the incubation period is over, the amount of bacteria that have grown on the plate is assessed. A clear ring surrounding a disk indicates that the bacteria are sensitive to this particular antibiotic and were unable to grow in its presence. A larger ring indicates a greater sensitivity to the antibiotic. The lack of a clear zone denotes that the bacteria are resistant to the antibiotic; therefore treatment of the bacteria with this particular antibiotic would be ineffective. PFU allows for the functional determination of the number of virus particles capable of cell damage. For this test, host cells are infected with a virus. The combination is plated on agar, and the number of plaques that form are counted. Plaques are localized areas of cell damage or cell lysis. Each plaque is thought to represent a single virion.

questions.question: Gram stains are used to differentiate between gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. Why do gram-positive bacteria stain purple with crystal violet?
options: Due to the presence of high amounts of peptidoglycan contained within the cellular wall
Gram-negative bacterial cell walls contain lipopolysaccharides, which repel crystal violet
Gram-positive bacteria cell walls contain teichoic acid
The large periplasmic spaces in the cellular wall allow for greater absorption of crystal violet
answers: Due to the presence of high amounts of peptidoglycan contained within the cellular wall
questions.explanation: Crystal violet binds to peptidoglycan. The greater the percentage of peptidoglycan contained within the cellular wall, the greater the intensity of staining. Gram-positive cell walls are comprised of a larger amount of peptidoglycan (50-90%) than gram-negative cell walls (roughly 10%).

questions.question: Which of the following mechanisms is NOT employed by viruses as a means of host penetration?
options: Entry of the virus via fusion with the host cell's plasma membrane
Passive diffusion via osmosis into the host cell
Direct injection of the virus' DNA into the host
Endocytosis of the virus into the host cell
answers: Passive diffusion via osmosis into the host cell
questions.explanation:
Osmosis refers to the net movement of water through a semi-permeable membrane down its respective concentration gradient. There are many ways in which a virus can infect a host cell. A non-enveloped virus can directly inject their DNA into host cells. Viruses with envelopes can fuse the host cell, leading to the incorporation of the envelope into the plasma membrane of the host, which then leaves the DNA free to transfer into the host cell. Viruses may also enter the host cell via endocytosis. After the process of endocytosis is complete, the virus sheds its envelope and releases its DNA into the host cell.
PowerPage
Osmosis

questions.question: How do eukaryotic ribosomes differ from those of prokaryotic ribosomes?
options: Eukaryotic ribosomes are utilized in the formation of plasmids
Eukaryotic ribosomes are not contained within the cytoplasm
Eukaryotic ribosomes consist of 40S and 60S subunits
answers: Eukaryotic ribosomes consist of 40S and 60S subunits
questions.explanation:
Eukaryotic ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S) subunit, while prokaryotic cells are comprised of 30S and 50S subunits. Both eukaryotic and prokaryotic ribosomes are located in the cytoplasm and are the sites of protein synthesis. Eukaryotic cells do not contain plasmids and therefore are not used to create them. Peptidoglycan is a major component found in the cell walls of bacteria. Peptidoglycan is a target site for many antibiotics, which serve to disrupt cell wall synthesis, thereby compromising the offending bacteria.
PowerPage
Prokaryotic & Eukaryotic Cells

questions.question: Which 3 of the following are utilized by bacteria as a means of protection from desiccation? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
Pili are small hair-like appendages found on some bacteria that play a role in attaching bacteria to each other or to various surfaces. 

Flagella are projections of the cell that provide locomotive capabilities as well as occasionally serving to detect temperature or chemical gradients. 

Slime layers, capsules, and glycocalyces are generally composed of polysaccharides. The composition and complexity of glycocalyces varies from bacteria to bacteria. The presence of a glycocalyx generally infers an ability of the bacteria to cause infection. A very condensed glycocalyx that is tightly bound to the cell wall is termed a capsule. A loosely-adhering glycocalyx is called a slime layer. Both serve to defend the cell from desiccation as well as to protect it from phagocytosis.

questions.question: Eukaryotic cells create new genomes through genetic exchange via which mechanism?
questions.explanation:
Eukaryotic cells create new genomes via sexual reproduction. Prokaryotic cells use transformation, transduction, and conjugation as methods of creating new genomes. Transformation occurs when a cell uptakes naked DNA material secreted from live bacteria or released from dead bacteria. Transduction is the transfer of DNA from one bacterium to another via a virus. The process begins with a virus destroying a host cell (bacterium 1) and incorporating some of its genes into the viral genome. The virus then replicates, and some of the progeny contain the original host DNA from bacterium 1. The progeny then infect another bacterium (bacterium 2), injecting some of the original host DNA (from bacterium 1), along with viral DNA, into bacterium 2. Conjugation occurs between a donor (possessing a conjugative plasmid) and recipient bacteria. The donor bacterium initiates contact with the recipient via a sex pilus, allowing for cell-to-cell contact and transfer of DNA. The plasmids often contain genes that encode for toxin production, virulence factors, and antibiotic resistance.
PowerPage
Prokaryotic & Eukaryotic Cells

questions.question: What type of agar is commonly used to culture fungi?
questions.explanation:
Sabouraud's agar is useful for culturing fungi. Culturing and sensitivity testing are important diagnostic tools used to determine the offending pathogen and help to select the appropriate medication for treatment. Sabouraud's agar is unique in that it possesses a low pH that causes the inhibition of most bacterial growth, allowing for better isolation of the fungus. Hay infusion agar is frequently utilized to culture slime moulds. 

Cetrimide agar is designed to isolate Gram-negative bacteria. 

Blood agar plates are useful for the detection of pathogenic organisms via the presence of hemolytic activity (the ability of organisms to lyse or destroy red blood cells). Blood agar plates are not a selective medium, as many different types of organisms are capable of growth on this type of agar. 

Thayer-Martin agar is a type of chocolate agar used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

questions.question: Which classification of microorganism can synthesize its own food from inorganic sources?
questions.explanation: Autotrophs, such as plants and algae, are capable of synthesizing food from inorganic sources using light energy (photosynthesis) or chemical energy (chemosynthesis). This process requires a great expenditure of energy. Heterotrophs, such as animals and fungi, cannot fix carbon dioxide as their sole carbon source; these organisms must obtain carbon from organic sources (most commonly other organisms). A prototroph is defined as an organism that is capable of synthesizing its own amino acids, vitamins, and other nutrients from inorganic compounds. Auxotrophs are a class of microorganism that, due to mutation, lack or have lost the ability to synthesize a component necessary for their growth and therefore must obtain it from their environment.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the ability of an organism to establish a focal point of infection?
questions.explanation: Infectivity refers to the ability of an organism to initiate a site of infection. Invasiveness describes the capability of an organism to spread to adjacent sites of the body. Pathogenicity denotes the ability of an organism to cause sickness or disease. Virulence describes the degree of pathogenicity.

questions.question: Lactoferrin, which is present in saliva, is an example of what type of host defense?
questions.explanation: Saliva is a type of general, non-specific chemical barrier to pathogens. Saliva contains lysozymes, peroxidase, lactoferrin, and myeloperoxidase. Lactoferrin binds iron, which is needed for bacterial growth. Therefore, by decreasing levels of available iron, saliva is designed to promote a healthy environment. Skin and mucous membranes are examples of non-specific physical barriers to pathogens. A fever is an example of a biological barrier. An increase in temperature can both hinder growth of pathogens and inactivate certain toxins. Fevers also lead to a greater immune system response. Innate immunity refers to cellular-mediated responses and humoral components involving leukocytes and the complement pathway.

questions.question: Which of the following genus of organisms is responsible for tuberculosis and leprosy?
questions.explanation: Mycobacterium is an aerobic, Gram-positive (although this is somewhat debatable) genus that includes several pathogenic species. Mycobacteria are extremely difficult to treat due to the nature of their cell walls which are truly neither Gram-negative nor Gram-positive (although they are classified as Gram-positive because they are acid-fast). M. tuberculosis is responsible for causing tuberculosis. M. leprae is the culprit that causes Hansen's disease (also termed Leprosy). A species of Borrelia can cause Lyme disease. Salmonella has been known to cause food poisoning. Contraction of Klebsiella can lead to the development of pneumonia.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms is LEAST LIKELY to cause food poisoning?
questions.explanation: Klebsiella is a Gram-negative rod-shaped bacterium that can cause pneumonia, especially in immunocompromised individuals. Infections caused by this organism may approach high mortality rates (about 50%), even with treatment. All of the other mentioned microorganisms are common culprits of food poisoning. The most common symptoms of food poisoning are nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, all of which serve to eliminate bacteria and contaminated food from the system.

questions.question: Sorting and processing of proteins and lipids prior to transportation occurs in which structure of a eukaryotic cell?
questions.explanation: The role of the Golgi apparatus is to serve as a final check point for proteins and lipids prior to transport to either intracellular or extracellular destinations. Lysozymes are responsible for digestion of nutrients, old cell parts, or foreign particles within the cell. Chromosomes are highly organized structures of coiled DNA and protein. Ribosomes play a major role in the synthesis of proteins.

questions.question: The lowest concentration of an antimicrobial drug that prevents further visible growth of an organism is known as which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) is the lowest concentration of a drug that visibly inhibits the further growth of a particular organism. It is determined by inoculating a series of tubes or plates with known antimicrobial concentrations. After a standard period of incubation, the concentration of the antimicrobial that inhibits growth of the organism is known as the MIC. 

The minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC) is the minimum concentration of a drug that actually kills the organism rather than just inhibiting further growth.

questions.question: Which of the following infections is considered parasitic in nature?
questions.explanation:
Scabies is a skin condition that is caused by parasitic mites that burrow under the skin and cause itching, rashes, and blisters. The condition is spread via close contact with infected people or infected linens or towels. Patients typically report that the severity of the itching worsens at night. Scabies is treated via the application of prescribed topical cream or lotion or via oral medication. Although scabies will self-resolve, it is best to seek treatment immediately if the condition is suspected in order to minimize its chances of spreading. 

Molluscum contagiosum is a cutaneous viral infection that results in small red or skin-colored bumps. Lesions can be removed, or a topical ointment can be prescribed to decrease healing time. The condition, if left untreated, will self-resolve. 

Impetigo is bacterial in nature (caused by staphylococcus) and results in cutaneous blisters of various sizes. The lesions are frequently limited to the arms, legs, and face. 

Tinea, also known ringworm, is a fungal infection of the skin. The lesions associated with this condition appear circular with clear centers. Athlete's foot is a type of ringworm. 

References: 
http://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/tc/scabies-treatment-overview 
http://medicalcenter.osu.edu/patientcare/healthcare_services/skin_conditions/skin_infections/viral_infections_skin/molluscum_contagiosum/Pages/index.aspx

questions.question: Toxoplasma gondii is classified as which type of parasite?
questions.explanation: Toxoplasma is a protozoan parasite. Protozoa are microscopic, single-celled, mobile organisms. Protozoa are classified into three phyla: Sarcomastigophora, apicomplexa and ciliophora. Helminths are worm-like multi-cellular parasites. Helminths are further categorized into nematodes (roundworms), cestodes (tapeworms), and trematodes (flukes). Schistosomes are a type of trematode.

questions.question: Viruses with this characteristic are significantly more resistant to environmental degradation; in other words, they survive longer in the environment.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is non-enveloped viruses. Non-enveloped viruses are typically very resistant to environmental degradation and therefore survive longer in the environment and are harder to disinfect than enveloped viruses, such as the influenza virus. Whether a virus is a DNA or RNA virus has no effect on its environmental durability.

questions.question: Which of the following classifications refers to an organism that can survive in an environment with or without oxygen?
questions.explanation:
Facultative anaerobes are capable of using oxygen as a life source but can also thrive using anaerobic respiration. When culturing this type of bacteria in a test tube of liquid media, one would observe the bacteria dispersed throughout the entire tube but with greatest concentration at the top, as aerobic respiration yields a more favorable energy result. 

Obligate aerobes require oxygen to survive. Test tube culturing would display bacteria gathering at the top of the tube where the oxygen levels are greatest. 

Microaerophiles are capable of utilizing oxygen, but only at lower concentrations. A test tube culture of microaerophillic bacteria would result in the greatest concentration of bacteria towards the upper portion of the test tube, but not at the very top. 

Strict anaerobes cannot tolerate oxygen and rely on anaerobic respiration to survive. A test tube culture of strict anaerobes would display the greatest concentration of bacteria towards the bottom of the tube where the least amount of oxygen is present. 

Aerotolerant organisms are capable of growing in the presence of oxygen but do not actually utilize it for respiration. One would observe these bacteria evenly distributed throughout a test tube liquid culture.

questions.question: Blood agar is a suitable culture media for most bacterial and fungal samples except Neisseria, Haemophilus, and Moraxella species. If one of these organisms is suspected, which of the following media should be utilized for culturing purposes?
questions.explanation:
Chocolate agar is a variant of the blood agar plate that contains red blood cells that have been slowly heated to a temperature in which the blood cells are lysed (80 degrees Celsius). The agar is named after the color of the plate, and does not actually contain any form of chocolate. This type of agar is specifically used for growing fastidious organisms such as Neisseria, Haemophilus, and Moraxella species that do not grow well on conventional blood agar plates. 

Chocolate agar with the addition of bacitracin becomes selective for Haemophilus, while another variant of chocolate agar, known as Thayer-Martin agar, contains an assortment of different antibiotics that results in selection of Neisseria species. 

Sabouraud's agar and malt extract agar are fungal media. Knop agar is a type of moss media, and phenethyl alcohol agar selects for staphylococcal species while inhibiting Gram-negative bacilli.

questions.question: The immune system will produce antibodies in response to a pathogen. What portion of the bacterial cell causes an immune reaction and is responsible for the creation of antibodies by the host?
questions.explanation: The outer portion of a gram-negative cellular envelope contains chains of lipopolysaccharides. These chains consist of lipid A, a core polysaccharide, and an O side chain. Lipid A is an endotoxin (which is a misnomer, as this component is actually located outside of the cell, but it produces the same results as an endotoxin) that causes symptoms associated with infections. The O side chain is also called an O antigen, which is specific to certain bacteria. The immune system will host a reaction to this antigen and produce antibodies in response in order to prohibit future infections. Some bacteria are capable of changing their O side chains to avoid detection by the immune system. Porin proteins are embedded within the matrix of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria that allow for passage of nutrients needed by the cell. Peptidoglycan is a polymer that is located in the cellular walls of both Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria but is seen to a much greater extent in the Gram-positive bacteria.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT present in the cellular envelope of a Gram-negative bacteria?
questions.explanation: Cell walls define the shape of the cell and serve as protection for the bacteria. Gram-negative cells have complex cellular envelopes comprised of only a thin layer of peptidoglycan sandwiched between an outer and inner membrane. The outer membrane contains porin proteins, within its matrix which allow for the passage of molecules (i.e., nutrients) into the cell. The outer membrane also includes lipopolysaccharides, which consist of an O side chain (antigen), a core polysaccharide, and lipid A (endotoxin). In contrast, the composition of a Gram-positive cell wall is relatively simple: it contains a thick layer of peptidoglycan, teichoic, and lipoteichoic acids. Gram-positive cells have only one plasma membrane.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE of a eukaryotic cell?
options: Does not contain a true nucleus
questions.explanation: Eukaryotic cells are complex cells surrounded by a plasma membrane, which serves as the outer boundary of the cell. Eukaryotic cells possess membrane-bound organelles and contain a nucleus that is encapsulated by a nuclear envelope. Prokaryotic cells are classified as simple, single-celled organisms that do not possess a true nucleus; instead, these cells have a nucleoid region of structures that consist of RNA, DNA and protein. Prokaryotic cells multiply through binary fission.

questions.question: The human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is an example of which type of virus?
questions.explanation: Retroviruses are capable of using their virion RNA as a template for reverse transcriptase to create DNA, which is then used in the production of more virus particles through a series of complex processes. Prions are virus-like particles that contain little to no nucleic acids. Examples of negative single-stranded RNA viruses are the paramyxoviruses that cause the mumps and measles. An example of a double-stranded RNA virus is the rotavirus, which causes infantile diarrhea.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms is used as a treatment for blepharospasm?
questions.explanation: C. botulinum can be used to treat blepharospasm and hemifacial spasm. This type of bacteria produces a toxin that blocks nerve impulses to the muscles, causing paralysis or semi-paralysis. By controlling the amount and site of injection, it is possible to decrease or eliminate muscle spasms. The effect is transient, lasting an average of three to four months. Side effects include blurred vision, ptosis and diplopia, none of which are permanent. C. botulinum is also used for cosmetic purposes as Botox injections. The toxin is injected intramuscularly to reduce the signs of aging by eliminating fine lines on the skin.

questions.question: A patient presents with acutely progressive keratitis. A scraping is performed, and the material is stained with a Gram stain. The causative agent is a bacterial coccus that stains violet on the Gram stain. Which of the following agents could this be?
questions.explanation: This is a description of a Gram-positive round bacteria. Staphylococcus is the only choice that fits this description. It is also the most common cause of many ocular infections. Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis are the most common species. Pseudomonas is a Gram-negative bacterium, and mycobacterium is a Gram-resistant rod that stains best with an acid-fast stain. Acanthamoeba is a protozoan and is not a bacteria.

questions.question: Which organism can be contracted in a newborn via an infected mother and was previously treated prophylactically with silver nitrate?
questions.explanation: Chlamydia trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae are both organisms that can lead to neonatal eye infections. Passage of a newborn through an infected birth canal results in contraction of the organism. Most countries currently treat the newborn with eye ointments or drops containing erythromycin or some type or antibacterial. Silver nitrate is now rarely used as it can lead to toxic conjunctivitis.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms can penetrate an INTACT cornea?
questions.explanation:
There is currently much debate in the literature regarding Pseudomonas because it was previously believed that Pseudomonas aeruginosa was capable of penetrating an intact cornea by secreting proteolytic enzymes that could break down the corneal barrier. However, current research suggests that this line of thinking no longer holds true. At present, it is believed that N. gonorrhoeae, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Listeria species, and Haemophilus species are capable of infecting an intact cornea. Treatment commonly involves topical antibiotic ophthalmic drops. 

Staphylococcus aureus, S. Epidermis, and Salmonella cannot penetrate an intact epithelium. 

References: 
Clinical Applications of the Limulus Amoebocyte Lysate Test. Prior, R. CRC Press, 1990 page 122. 
Clinical Infectious Disease.Schlossberg, D. Cambridge Medicine, 2008, page 87 
Cornea and External Eye Disease. Reinhard, T. et al. Springer, 2008, page 22. 
Haemophilus: Advances in Research and Treatment: 2011 Edition: Scholarly Paper. 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2715680/

questions.question: Which organism is the MOST frequent cause of contact lens-associated keratitis?
questions.explanation: All of the genii of bacteria mentioned have been associated with contact lens-associated keratitis but the prevailing microorganism is P. aeruoginosa. These bacteria have been isolated from soft contact lenses, lens cases, and solutions. Treatment against these bacteria must be sought quickly as P. aeruginosa produce enzymes that can easily liquefy the cornea in 1-2 days time.

questions.question: In adults, which organism is the most common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in warmer climates?
questions.explanation:
Haemophilus influenza is the predominant cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in adults in warmer climates, while Streptococcus pneumonia is the most common cause in adults in cooler climates. Acute conjunctivitis is characterized by mucopurulent discharge that is worse in the morning. It usually begins unilaterally and spreads to the other eye. Under normal circumstances the most common isolate in adults is S. aureus while in children under five years old, the common culprit is H. influenza. 

Ref:Hoang-Xuan, T., Baudouin C., Creuzot-Garcher, C. Inflammatory Diseases of the Conjunctiva, 1998 pg 112.

questions.question: What is the causative organism of angular blepharitis?
questions.explanation:
Angular blepharitis is a localized inflammation usually of the outer canthus. The offending organisms include M. lacunata and Staphylococcus. Angular blepharitis can be bilateral or unilateral and is most commonly seen in young adults who inhabit warmer climates. Primary signs and symptoms include redness, itching, scaling of the skin, and mild discomfort. Discharge may or may not be present. 

Treatment includes lid hygiene, and if the case is severe, topical antibacterials such as erythromycin or bacitracin. Oral tetracyclines or erythromycin can be prescribed if the angular blepharitis proves to be resistant. 

Reference: Holland, E. Cornea second edition, volume 1. 2005, page 494

questions.question: Traveler's diarrhea, also known as Montezuma's revenge, is most commonly caused by which organism?
questions.explanation: Traveler's diarrhea (TD) is usually linked to ingestion of contaminated water or food which results in loose stools, abdominal cramping, and nausea. The most frequent cause of TD is enterotoxigenic E. coli. Treatment is not usually required, as most cases are self-limiting; however, it is important to maintain hydration and prevent loss of electrolytes. The best prevention is to avoid questionable sources of food and water.

questions.question: Which organism is associated with the development of toxic shock syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Toxic shock syndrome is a potentially lethal infection caused by S. aureus. The infection is caused by the use of super-absorbent tampons which decreases the need for frequent replacement. The environment and the tampon contribute to a great breeding ground for this pathogen. 

C. trachomatis is a sexually transmitted disease (STD) characterized by burning sensation during urination, penile or vaginal discharge, and, if left untreated, may cause infertility. People affected with chlamydia may also be completely asymptomatic. Gonorrhea is also an STD. Symptoms include those seen with chlamydia as well as fever, sore throat, increased urinary frequency, and other symptoms. If left untreated, long-term complications of gonorrhea include infertility, long-term joint pain, meningitis, and heart valve infection. People infected with gonorrhea must be reported to the centers for disease control and prevention (CDC). 

T. gondii is commonly associated with improper handling of raw meat or cat fecal matter from an animal that has ingested infected meat; however, it rarely leads to illness in healthy individuals. For this reason, it is important that pregnant mothers do not handle feline fecal matter so as not to potentially harm the unborn fetus, as toxoplasmosis can result in blindness if enough retinal damage occurs. Immunocompromised persons may suffer from encephalitis and chorioretinitis, among other problems.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is considered a fungal infection?
questions.explanation:
Candidiasis is a fungal infection. A number of species of the genus Candida are part of the normal flora that live on the skin and mucous membranes of humans without causing an associated infection. If something alters the body's immune system (such as a medication or illness) or results in an environment where the fungus can flourish, candidiasis symptoms may occur. A fungal infection of the throat or mouth caused by candida is called thrush. Candidiasis is treated by oral or topical anti-fungal medications. 

Patients with psoriasis possess patches of red, inflamed plaques of dermal tissue with overlying white, dry scales whose severity waxes and wanes and is caused by overly rapid replication of skin cells. 

Actinic keratosis is a precursor to squamous cell carcinoma and appears as scaly, dry skin that does not heal. People with skin of lighter pigmentation along with those with excessive exposure to ultraviolet light tend to be most at risk for development of this condition. 

Tularemia is an infection caused by the bacteria Francisella tularensis. Individuals may become infected via exposure with an infected animal (such as a rodent or rabbit), being bitten by a tick or deer fly, drinking contaminated water, or by exposure in the laboratory. Symptoms may include fever, an ulcer at the entry site of the organism, swollen lymph nodes, conjunctival injection, or swelling of the tissues of the throat (depending on how and where the organism entered the body). 

References: 
http://www.cdc.gov/fungal/candidiasis/ 
http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/

questions.question: When performing the swinging flashlight test to examine your patient's pupils, you observe a potential mild relative afferent pupillary defect (APD). Which of the following will help to enhance the detection of the APD?
options: Increase the overhead lighting by 5 lumens
Change the light source to a MacBeth lamp
Increase the brightness of the test light
