questions.question: Which of the following equations may be used to determine the location of the secondary focal point of a +5.00 polycarbonate (n=1.586) thin lens that is located in air?
questions.explanation:
A thick lens has two refracting surfaces. The refractive power of the first surface is determined by using the equation P=(n-n')/r. The power of the second refractive surface is calculated via use of the equation P=(n'-n)/r. For a thin lens, in most circumstances, it can be assumed that all refraction occurs at a single surface despite the fact that the lens possesses two surfaces. In the case of a thin lens, the thickness is presumed to be negligible the majority of the time (as in this question). 
To correctly solve for the location of the secondary focal point, one must use the equation P=n'/f'. Inputting the values from the above question yields: +5.00= 1.00/f'. 
Solving for f' yields= 1.00/+5.00

questions.question: An object located in air (n=1.00) measures 2.5 cm in height and is 12.0 cm in front of a -12.00 polycarbonate (n=1.586) surface. Which of the following will correctly calculate the location of the secondary focal point?
questions.explanation: To correctly solve for the location of the secondary focal point, one must use the equation P=n'/f'. Inputting the values from the above question yields: -12.00= 1.586/f'. Solving for f' yields= -0.132 or 13.2 cm. Because the answer is negative, the secondary focal point will be located to the left of the diverging surface.

questions.question: Hutchinson's sign associated with herpes zoster is an indication of reactivation of which of the following cranial nerves?
options: Lacrimal branch of the trigeminal nerve
Nasociliary branch of the trigeminal nerve
Frontal branch of the trigeminal nerve
answers: Nasociliary branch of the trigeminal nerve
questions.explanation: A vesicular eruption on the tip of the nose in patients with herpes zoster indicates the reactivation of herpes involving the nasocilary branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. This sign may provide an early predictive factor of impending eye involvement (herpes zoster ophthalmicus).

questions.question: You are fitting a 6 year-old with a progressive addition lens (PALs) due to a binocular vision condition. Which of the following adjustments to the fitting height is MOST appropriate to ensure that he will actually look through the add power when doing near tasks?
options: Fitting height should be about 2mm higher than normal
No adjustment needs to be made
Fitting height should be about 4mm higher than normal
Fitting height should be about 4mm lower than normal
Fitting height should be about 2mm lower than normal
answers: Fitting height should be about 4mm higher than normal
questions.explanation:
If PALs are indicated for a child it is recommended that the lenses be fit about 4mm higher than normal to guarantee that the child will actually look through the near add power when performing near tasks. If the fitting height is not compensated for, children will often just move their head position rather than take advantage of the reading area located in the lower portion of the lens.
PowerPage
Measuring Multifocal Heights

questions.question: Which 2 of the following are TRUE in regards to the ANSI standard tolerances for the cylinder axis of ophthalmic lenses? (Select 2)
options: For cylinder powers of 1.00, 1.25, and 1.50 D, the axis tolerance is 3 degrees
For cylinder powers of 0.25 D, the axis may deviate up to 14 degrees
A cylinder power of 0.50 D may allow an axis variation of up to 10 degrees
0.75 D of cylinder power may have a deviation of axis up to 7 degrees
Cylinder powers of 1.75 or above are only allowed an axis deviation of 1 degree
answers: For cylinder powers of 1.00, 1.25, and 1.50 D, the axis tolerance is 3 degrees
For cylinder powers of 0.25 D, the axis may deviate up to 14 degrees
questions.explanation:
The following represents the ANSI standards tolerance values for cylinder axis: 
- For cylinder powers of 0.25 D, the axis may deviate up to 14 degrees 
- A cylinder power of 0.50 D may allow an axis variation of up to 7 degrees 
- 0.75 D of cylinder power may have a deviation of axis up to 5 degrees 
- For cylinder powers of 1.00, 1.25, and 1.50 D, the axis tolerance is 3 degrees 
- Cylinder powers of 1.75 or above are only allowed an axis deviation of 2 degrees

questions.question: You are trying to obtain some frame measurements for a patient and can't find your ruler. You see some markings on the inside of the frame that reads ''55 □ 19 145.' What do these measurements represent, respectively?
options: Frame PD (pupillary distance), 'B' measurement, and temple length
Frame PD (pupillary distance), DBL (distance between lenses), and temple length
'B' measurement, DBL (distance between lenses), and temple length
'A' measurement, DBL (distance between lenses), and temple length
answers: 'A' measurement, DBL (distance between lenses), and temple length
questions.explanation:
If you are trying to obtain some quick measurements of a frame, most frames are marked with the eye size, DBL, and temple length. When a marking with □ is seen, it means that the measurements are determined using the boxing system. For example a marking on a frame that reads: '55 □ 19 145' indicates that the 'A' measurement is 55mm, DBL is 19mm, and the temple length is 145mm. On most frames these markings are found imprinted on the inner side of the temples in plastic frames and inside of the bridge on metal frames (but they may be present at other locations).
PowerPage
Boxing System

questions.question: Which of the following properties is a DISADVANTAGE to having glass lenses in an ophthalmic frame?
options: Glass does not block UV light
Glass has a high specific gravity
Glass possesses a low index of refraction
answers: Glass has a high specific gravity
questions.explanation: Although it can be heavy due to its high specific gravity and is prone to chipping and shattering, glass does have several advantages over other ophthalmic materials. Glass has a high index of refraction, allowing for a thinner lens. Glass also possesses a high Abbe number, resulting in less chromatic aberration. Additionally, glass blocks some UV light and is very resistant to scratching.

questions.question: Your patient wants the lightest lenses available. Based on specific gravity alone, which of the following materials would be the best recommendation?
questions.explanation: Specific gravity is the ratio of the weight of a specific substance to the weight of water of the same volume. For example, a cubic foot of glass weighs 158.6 pounds while water weighs 62.5 pounds per cubic foot. Thus, the specific gravity for glass is 2.54g/cubic cm. Trivex material has one of the lowest specific gravity values of current lens materials, measured at 1.11g/cubic cm.

questions.question: Which of the following ocular diagnostic pharmaceutical agents is MOST commonly used to aid in the diagnosis of an Adie's tonic pupil?
questions.explanation:
A patient presenting with an Adie's tonic pupil will exhibit anisocoria in which the affected pupil is dilated and possibly irregular in shape and reacts poorly to a light stimulus. Later, the pupil will eventually become miotic over time. This presentation is thought to be caused by a lesion in the ciliary ganglion or short ciliary nerves, with aberrant regeneration of the ciliary muscle fibers to the iris sphincter. This subsequently leads to a tonic pupil with associated denervation hypersensitivity. 

Diagnostic pharmacologic testing to confirm an Adie's tonic pupil relies on this concept of denervation hypersensitivity. A normal pupil will not constrict to a weak (0.125%) concentration of pilocarpine; however, the abnormal pupil will. This is a quick and easy in-office test that clinicians can use in order to verify a suspected diagnosis of an Adie's pupil.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are TRUE in regards to frame adjustments on a patient's face? (Select 2)
options: If the right lens is too close to the face, bring the right temple in
If the right lens is too low, bend the left temple down
If the right lens is too far from the face, bring the left temple out
If the right lens is too high, bend the right temple up
answers: If the right lens is too close to the face, bring the right temple in
If the right lens is too high, bend the right temple up
questions.explanation:
If the temple spread of a pair of spectacles is uneven, or one side of the patient's head is somewhat wider than the other, it is possible that one lens will be closer to the face than the other. For example, if the right lens is too far from the patient's face, this could be due to the fact that either the right temple is not spread far enough, making that side fit too tightly, or that the left temple is too loose. The opposite is true if the right lens were to be sitting too close to the face. 
A simple rule of thumb for frame adjustment is: 
-If the right lens is in -> move the right temple in (or left temple out) 
-If the left lens is in -> move the left temple in (or right temple out) 
-If the right lens is out -> move the right temple out (or left temple in) 
-If the left lens is out -> move the left temple out (or right temple in) 

If the frame is not straight on the face, it could be because of incomplete standard alignment, or because one ear of the patient is positioned slightly higher than the other. The solution is the same regardless of the cause of the misalignment: 
-If the right lens is up -> bend the right temple up (or left temple down) 
-If the left lens is up -> bend the left temple up (or right temple down) 
-If the right lens is down -> bend the right temple down (or left temple up) 
-If the left lens is down -> bend the left temple down (or right temple up)

questions.question: Which of the following formulas can be used to directly determine the lateral magnification produced by an optical system?
options: Image size/radius of curvature of refracting lens
questions.explanation: The lateral magnification of an image produced by an optical system can be calculated by dividing the image size by the object size or, alternatively, by dividing the object vergence by the image vergence.

questions.question: Your -10.00 D patient wishes to have the thinnest edges possible for his glasses. Which of the following actions will result in a reduced edge thickness?
options: Increasing the minimum blank size of the lens
Increasing the center thickness of the lens
Decreasing the refractive index of the lens
questions.explanation: For a myope, the goal is to reduce the overall edge thickness. Decreased edge thickness can be achieved by decreasing the eyesize, increasing the refractive index of the lens, or by minimizing the center thickness.

questions.question: A patient walks into your office complaining of blurry vision through his glasses. He recently sat on them and tried to bend them back into shape. His original prescription was -2.00 OU. The bent glasses now have too much face wrap. Given the new shape of the glasses, how has the prescription changed?
options: Induced cylinder power with a horizontal axis and a decrease in minus power
Induced cylinder power with a vertical axis and a decrease in minus power
Induced cylinder power with a vertical axis and an increase in minus power
Induced cylinder power with a horizontal axis and an increase in minus power
answers: Induced cylinder power with a vertical axis and an increase in minus power
questions.explanation: Increasing the pantoscopic tilt or face form will cause an increase in the sphere power. Bending the frame so that the optical center no longer passes through the center of rotation of the eye will also induce astigmatism. The induced astigmatism will have the same axis as the axis of rotation, therefore increasing the face wrap will induce astigmatism with an axis of 90 degrees. Increasing the pantoscopic tilt will induce astigmatism with an axis of 180 degrees. The power of the induced astigmatism will have the same sign as the sphere. Therefore, if a -10.00-3.00 x090 Crown glass lens has a 15-degree face-form tilt, the new prescription would be: -10.29-3.95x090.

questions.question: Your optician is trying to insert lenses into a frame made of polycarbonate and therefore cannot use heat. Which of the following techniques offers the easiest method of lens insertion?
options: Insert the temporal edge of the lens first, followed by the nasal aspect from the back of the frame
Insert the nasal edge first, followed by the temporal edge of the lens from the back of the frame
Insert the nasal edge first, followed by the temporal edge of the lens from the front of the frame
Insert the temporal edge of the lens first, followed by the nasal aspect from the front of the frame
answers: Insert the temporal edge of the lens first, followed by the nasal aspect from the front of the frame
questions.explanation: Although there are many ways of inserting ophthalmic lenses into a frame, the most commonly used method is to insert the temporal aspect of the lens first followed by snapping the nasal edge into place from the front of the frame. Most frame materials can be heated, which allows for ease of insertion, but this must be done with caution. Most opticians and clinicians prefer to use a hot air warmer rather than glass beads or sand, allowing for better control of heat distribution and minimizing frame and lens damage. If using sand or glass beads, it is best to use a lower heat setting. Some opticians add baby powder to glass beads to help keep the beads from sticking to the frame, which may cause small bubble-like indentations. When using heat, it is best to remove the temples, thereby decreasing the chances of dislodging or twisting the hinge. Remember that dark-colored frames tend to heat more quickly than light-colored ones. Frames fabricated from polyamide, copolyamide, carbon fiber, carbon fiber graphite or polycarbonate should not be heated.

questions.question: The optic nerve can be divided into four segments, beginning with the optic disc and extending to the optic chiasm. Which of the following terms BEST describes the subdivision of the optic nerve that courses from the globe to the optic foramen?
questions.explanation:
The optic nerve can be divided into four segments as it courses from the eye to the optic chiasm. These include the intraocular segment, intraorbital portion, intracanalicular portion, and intracranial region. 

The intraocular segment represents the axons of the photoreceptors as they exit the eye. This is the shortest segment of the nerve, typically measuring 1mm deep and 1.5mm in vertical diameter, and is known as the optic disc or optic nerve head. 

The intraorbital portion of the optic nerve corresponds to the segment that extends from the globe to the optic foramen at the orbital apex. It is about 25 to 30mm in length, and its diameter is significantly larger (3-4mm) due to the addition of the myelin sheaths surrounding the nerve fibers. At the region of the orbital apex, the nerve is surrounded by tough fibrous tissue known as the annulus of Zinn (in which the rectus muscles originate). 

The intracanalicular region of the optic nerve is the segment that traverses the optic canal. It measures about 6mm in length and is fixed to the canal due to fusion of the dura mater with the periosteum. 

The intracranial segment varies in length (averages about 10mm) and is the portion that extends to join the optic chiasm. Fibers that course posteriorly from the optic chiasm are then referred to as the optic tract.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE in regards to the location of the physiologic blind spot on visual field testing?
options: It is located about 15 degrees temporal to fixation and slightly above the horizontal plane
It is located about 15 degrees temporal to fixation and slightly below the horizontal plane
It is located about 15 degrees nasal to fixation and slightly below the horizontal plane
It is located about 15 degrees nasal to fixation and slightly above the horizontal plane
answers: It is located about 15 degrees temporal to fixation and slightly below the horizontal plane
questions.explanation:
The physiologic blind spot is a scotoma that can be plotted on a visual field test, which corresponds to the location of the optic nerve head. Because the optic nerve head does not contain any rods or cones, it is blind to all visual information processing. The physiological blind spot is located approximately 15 degrees temporal to fixation and just below the horizontal midline. Anatomically, the optic disc lies nasal to the macula (and just above), but when projected into the visual field, it is located in the opposite direction. The blind spot is elliptical in shape and average 7.5 degrees vertically and 5.5 degrees horizontally, extending about 2 degrees above and 5 degrees below the horizontal midline.

DeJong's The Neurologic Examination (Seventh edition). Campbell, W. W. 2013. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. Philadelphia, PA.

questions.question: In order to maintain the same power of a lens, how must the radius of curvature be adjusted if the index of refraction of the lens is increased?
questions.explanation: In order to prove that the radius of curvature must increase, use the equation for a single surface power and input any numbers into it. For example, if a lens in air had a power of +4.00 D and an index of refraction of 1.60, it would have a radius of curvature of F = n'-n/r Solve for r: 4.00 = 1.6-1/r; 4.00 = 0.6/r; r = 0.6/4.00 r = 0.15 meters or 15 cm. Therefore, if the index of refraction was to increase to 1.7 and we desired the same power of +4.00 D, the new radius of curvature would have to increase to 17.5 cm. 4.00 = 1.7-1.0/r Solve for r; 4 = 0.7/r; r = 0.7/4; r = 0.175 meters or 17.5 cm.

questions.question: Which 2 of these sentences about the lamina cribrosa pores of a healthy optic nerve head are TRUE? (Select 2)
options: Lamina cribrosa pores are larger superiorly and inferiorly when compared to nasally and temporally
Lamina cribrosa pores are present only along the outer rim tissue
The number of pores of the lamina cribrosa increases with glaucomatous damage
Lamina cribrosa pores are round in healthy eyes
answers: Lamina cribrosa pores are larger superiorly and inferiorly when compared to nasally and temporally
Lamina cribrosa pores are round in healthy eyes
questions.explanation:
When evaluating the morphology of the lamina cribrosa, we find that there are pores in all quadrants of the lamina cribrosa of the optic nerve. The pores are round in healthy eyes whereas they are stretched and oval in cases with open angle glaucoma. The pores are also larger superiorly and inferiorly, when compared to nasal and temporal regions, to allow for the passage of large numbers of retinal nerve fiber layer axons. 

Reference: Jonas, JB., Mardin CY et al. Morphology of the Human Lamina Cribrosa Surface, Invest Opthal Vis Sci 1991, Feb 32(2): 401-5.

questions.question: Which of the following equations can be used to determine the optical density for a neutral density filter that transmits 20 percent of incident light?
questions.explanation:
Neutral density filters are advantageous because they offer minimal or no distortion of colors and possess flat transmission curves; in other words, they transmit all wavelengths equally. The optical density of a neutral density filter can be calculated using the following equation: 
OD=log(1/T), where OD= optical density and T=transmission fraction of the filter 
For the above problem: OD= log (1/0.2)=0.699

questions.question: Your patient complains of her eyelashes touching the back surface of her right spectacle lens. You notice that the lens vertex distance is closer to her right eye compared to that of the left lens. Select the most appropriate frame adjustment to solve the complaint.
options: Increase the temple spread by bringing the right temple out
Reduce the temple spread by bringing in the right temple
answers: Reduce the temple spread by bringing in the right temple
questions.explanation: The right lens is closer to the eye and the vertex distance needs to be increased. Bringing in the right temple increases the force on the frame's right side. This increased force rotates the frame on the nose outwardly, increasing the right lens vertex distance.

questions.question: A Keplerian telescope possesses an eyepiece with a corresponding power of +20.00 D and a +5.00 D objective lens. Which of the following will CORRECTLY solve for the resulting angular magnification of the telescope?
questions.explanation: Using the formula M= -Doc/Dobj, where Doc= dioptric power of the oculars and Dobj= dioptric power of the objective lens one can solve for the angular magnification provided by the telescope. Solving for M= -(+20.00)/(+5.00)= -4.0 x.

questions.question: A Galilean telescope possesses an eyepiece with a corresponding power of -23.00 D and a +8.00 D objective lens. Which of the following will CORRECTLY solve for the resulting angular magnification of the telescope?
questions.explanation: Using the formula M= -Doc/Dobj, where Doc= dioptric power of the oculars and Dobj= dioptric power of the objective lens, one can solve for the angular magnification provided by the telescope. Solving for M= -(-23.00)/(+8.00)= 2.875 or 2.88x.

questions.question: The retinal nerve fiber axons follow a characteristic path in the retina towards the optic nerve head. The arcuate fibers of the retina occupy which part of the optic nerve?
options: Nasal and superior temporal regions of the optic nerve
Nasal and temporal regions of the optic nerve
Superior and inferior temporal regions of the optic nerve
Only the temporal regions of the optic nerve
answers: Superior and inferior temporal regions of the optic nerve
questions.explanation: The arcuate fibers, also known as Bjerrum's fibers, travel both in the superior and inferior aspects of the hemi-retina towards the optic disc, occupying the superior and inferior temporal regions of the optic nerve head. From here, the fibers pass through the lamina cribrosa.

questions.question: The office staff wants to know if Mrs. Jones' glasses are acceptable to dispense. The glasses are off axis by 3 degrees in the left lens. The right lens is within ANSI standards. The Rx is +1.50-1.75 x 087 OS. Does the left lens meet ANSI standards?
questions.explanation: ANSI standards state that for a cylinder power of 1.75D the axis tolerance is +/- 2 degrees. The left lens in this example does not pass since the axis is off by 3 degrees.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following ocular elements pass through the optic foramen before reaching the eye? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
The optic foramen is a small hole that is found within the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone at the apex of the orbit. This foramen allows for the passage of the optic nerve (cranial nerve II) and the ophthalmic artery. 

Remember that the superior orbital fissure is an opening that is created between the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bone and is located lateral to the optic foramen. Here, the four cranial nerves (CN III to CN VI) controlling movements of the eye and eyelid pass through. Additionally, the inferior orbital fissure is another opening at the apex of the orbit that is formed between the maxillary, zygomatic, and greater wing of the sphenoid bone; the inferior orbital fissure allows for the transmission of the maxillary branch of cranial nerve V. 

Textbook of Radiographic Positioning and Related Anatomy (8th edition). Bontrager, K.L., Lampignano, J.P. 2014. Elsevier Mosby. St. Louis, MO.

questions.question: Which 4 of the following nerves pass through the cavernous sinus and enter the orbital apex through the superior orbital fissure? (Select 4)
options: Ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve
Maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve
answers: Ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve
questions.explanation:
-The cavernous sinus is a large collection of thin-walled veins that create a cavity within the human head bordered by the temporal bone of the skull and the sphenoid bone, lateral to the sella turcica 
-The cavernous sinus receives blood via the superior and inferior ophthalmic veins and the superficial cortical veins 
-It is drained by 2 channels, the superior and inferior petrosal sinuses, and into the jugular vein via the sigmoid sinus 
-Each cavernous sinus (one for each hemisphere of the brain) contains the internal carotid artery along with the following cranial nerves: 
-Oculomotor nerve (CN III) 
-Trochlear nerve (CN IV) 
-Ophthalmic nerve; the V1 branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) 
-Maxillary nerve; the V2 division of CN V 
-The above nerves run from superior to inferior within the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus 
-Abducens nerve (CN VI) 
-This nerve runs through the middle of the sinus alongside the internal carotid artery 
-CN III, CN IV, CN VI, and CN V1 pass through the cavernous sinus and enter the orbital apex via the superior orbital fissure 
-CN V2 travels through the lower portion of the sinus and exits through the foramen rotundum 
-The optic nerve lies just outside and superior to the cavernous sinus on each side and enters the orbital apex via the optic canal 
-Lesions involving the cavernous sinus typically result in the dysfunction of several nerves due to their close proximity

questions.question: Which of the following retinal conditions is the MOST common complication associated with the presence of an optic disc pit?
questions.explanation:
An optic pit is a round- or oval-shaped pit that is typically observed at the temporal aspect of the optic disc but can also present centrally in some cases. The optic nerve itself is typically larger than normal, and the pit can be of variable size. Visual acuity remains normal in these patients, as long as there are no associated complications. 

About 45% of patients with a non-central optic disc pit will develop a serous macular detachment during their lifetime (average age is 30 years). The subretinal fluid that leads to the detachment of the outer retinal layers is thought to be derived from the vitreous. There may be associated subretinal deposits present surrounding the macula in these cases, and the appearance may initially be mistaken for central serous retinopathy (CSR). Therefore, it is important to examine the optic disc carefully in patients that present with signs and symptoms of suspected CSR or other causes of macular edema.

questions.question: Testing of the pupillary reflexes is a quick way to check the integrity of both the afferent and efferent pathways. Which of the following conditions may result in a left afferent pupillary defect (APD)?
options: Optic neuritis of the left eye
A large lesion of the left optic tract
Early macular degeneration in both eyes
Extensive macular scarring of the right eye
answers: Optic neuritis of the left eye
questions.explanation:
An afferent pupillary defect may be caused by any pathology that causes unilateral or asymmetrical damage to ganglion cell axons. If the disease is similar in both eyes, one cannot have an APD because the pupil responses will be affected equally between the eyes. Small amounts of damage to the optic nerve will yield a larger APD, while large amounts of retinal damage result in the generation of a small APD. A lesion in the left optic tract will cause an APD of the right eye (because 55% of nerve fibers cross over, therefore one would expect a contralateral APD).
PowerPage
The Pupillary Pathway

questions.question: Which of the following frame materials requires HIGH heat for lens insertion and frame adjustments?
questions.explanation:
The steps utilized in inserting a lens into a frame during fabrication and adjusting the frame are standard for most plastic frames; however, the major variant is whether or not heat is used during the process (and how much). Some frame materials do not use heat at all when inserting lenses (this is called 'cold snapping') and some materials require high amounts of heat so that the material easily bends with only mild pressure. 
Optyl is a frame material that requires high amounts of heat. Heat is typically applied to the frame until it can bend under it's own weight and then lenses can be snapped into the frame, or adjustments to the frame can be made as necessary. Optyl material can safely be heated to temperatures of up to 200 degrees Celsius. 
Most other materials utilize only minimal amounts of heat if lenses cannot be 'cold snapped' (cellulose acetate, cellulose proprionate, and carbon fiber). Polycarbonate and polyamide materials should not be heated at all for the lens insertion process as this may lead to lens warpage; therefore, edged lenses must be fabricated exactly to size.

questions.question: Disruption of sympathetic innervation to which of the following structures is responsible for the ptosis seen in Horner's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Horner's syndrome results from a disruption of the sympathetic innervation to the eye due to a lesion or mass located either post-ganglionically or pre-ganglionically. The classic triad of signs seen in a patient suffering from Horner's syndrome is miosis, a small ptosis and anhidrosis (lack of sweat) on one side of the head or body depending of the location of the lesion. Be sure to test for miosis in dim illumination as it is more evident under this lighting condition. 

Muller's muscle is under sympathetic innervation and is responsible for 2-4 mm of eyelid elevation. 

The frontalis muscle is controlled by cranial nerve VII and is only active in extreme upward gaze. 

The levator palpebra superioris in under control of cranial nerve III and is the primary muscle used to open the eye. 

Orbicularis oculi is innervated by cranial nerve VII and is responsible for eyelid closure.

questions.question: A patient views an object through his left spectacle lens 3.0 mm temporally to the optical center of his -4.25 D lens. Which of the following will correctly determine the resulting amount of prism power at this location of the lens?
questions.explanation:
For this problem, Prentice's rule is used in order to determine the total prismatic effect. Prentice's rule is expressed as P=(d)(F) where P=prismatic power of the lens, F=the power of the lens in diopters, and d= the distance between the patient's line of sight and the optical center of the lens in centimeters. Prism can be induced when a patient is looking above/below or lateral to the optical centers of a spectacle lens. For the above problem, Prism=(0.3)(4.25 D)= 1.2575 D, or 1.25 D base out prism. 

When dealing with vertical prismatic effects, if the induced prism values over each eye have the same base direction, the prism values are subtracted. If prism values have opposite base directions, then the prism values are added. 

The base direction is dependent on whether the lens is a plus- or minus-powered prescription. Since a plus-powered lens has a greater center thickness, looking above the optical center will induce base down (BD) prism, and looking below the optical center will induce base up prism (BU). A way to visualize this is to picture two prisms stacked together base to base, creating a thick center. Looking temporally from the optical center will create base in (BI) prism while nasal displacement will result in base out (BO) prism. The opposite is true for a minus-powered lens, since the thickness of the lens is greatest at the edge. Looking above the optical center of a minus lens induces BU prism, and looking below the optical center induces BD prism. A minus-powered lens can be visualized as two prisms stacked apex to apex, creating a thin center and thick edge. Looking nasally from the optical center through a minus-powered lens will create base in (BI) prism while temporal displacement will result in base out (BO) prism.

questions.question: Which of the following equations may be used to determine the refractive power of the back surface of a thick lens in air?
questions.explanation: A thick lens has two refracting surfaces. The refractive power of the second surface is determined by using the equation P=(n-n')/r. The power of the first refractive surface is calculated via use of the equation P=(n'-n)/r. For a thin lens, in most circumstances it can be assumed that all refraction occurs at a single surface despite the fact that the lens possesses two surfaces. In the case of a thin lens, the thickness is presumed to be negligible the majority of the time.

questions.question: Transpose the following Rx: +2.00 - 2.00 x 045 to plus cylinder format
questions.explanation:
The rules for transposition are as follows: 
1. Add the sphere and cylinder powers together, keeping in mind the signs of each power. 
2. Change the original cylinder power to the opposite sign. 
3. If the original axis is 90 degrees or less, add 090 degrees to determine the new axis. If the original axis is greater than 090 degrees, subtract 090 degrees to determine the new axis.
PowerPage
Lensometry and Transposition

questions.question: Which of the following clear lens materials inherently blocks the MOST amount of ultraviolet-A (UV-A) light?
questions.explanation: Polycarbonate blocks 100% of UV-B and most of UV-A light (some studies state that it blocks all UV-A) and therefore does not require the addition of a UV protective coat. CR-39 blocks 100% of UV-B light but only some of UV-A light. Glass transmits both UV-A and UV-B light to a much greater degree than CR-39 or polycarbonate. Remember to prescribe a UV coating to patients who insist on tinting glass or CR-39 lenses because many patients associate a tint with adequate UV protection.

questions.question: A patient with neurosyphilis causing an Argyll Robertson pupil would be expected to display which of the following results on pupil testing?
options: Positive pupillary response to near target testing, positive pupillary response to light
Positive pupillary response to near target testing, absent or decreased pupillary response to light
Absent or minimal pupillary response to near target testing, positive pupillary response to light
Absent or minimal pupillary response to near target testing, absent or decreased pupillary response to light
answers: Positive pupillary response to near target testing, absent or decreased pupillary response to light
questions.explanation:
Bilateral Argyll Robertson pupils are a highly specific sign found in patients with neurosyphilis. In these cases, patients typically present with small pupils that do not respond well to light but will exhibit significant constriction when fixation on a near object occurs. This is usually bilateral but may be asymmetrical. This particular finding is also known as 'light-near dissociation.' Argyll Robertson pupil is generally limited to observation in patients with tertiary syphilis; therefore if a patient presents in your office with this finding and does not report a history of syphilis or any other clinical conditions, it is important to refer them for further evaluation and treatment. 

Around the Eye in 365 days. Schwartz, G. SLACK, 2009, page 43.

questions.question: A 52 year-old female presents in your office with a concern that her right pupil appears significantly larger than her left. Upon instillation of 10% cocaine, her right pupil dilates but her left pupil does not. You bring her back the next day and instill 1% hydroxyamphetamine in both eyes, and both pupils dilate. What is the BEST diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
In patients with a suspected damage to the oculosympathetic pathway (Horner's syndrome), cocaine will confirm the diagnosis, while hydroxyamphetamine will differentiate a pre-ganglionic from a post-ganglionic lesion. A summary of pharmacologic testing in Horner's is summarized below. 

10% Cocaine 
- The normal pupil will dilate but the abnormal pupil will not 
- The rationale for this is that in a normal pupil, norepinephrine is released from the post-ganglionic sympathetic nerve endings and is eventually re-absorbed, terminating the nerve impulse 
- Cocaine inhibits the re-uptake of norepinephrine, allowing it to accumulate in the synapse and causing dilation of the pupil 
- In Horner's syndrome, the abnormal eye will not produce any norepinephrine in the first place, so cocaine has no effect on the pupil size 

1% Hydroxyamphetamine 
- In a pre-ganglionic lesion, both pupils dilate 
- In a post-ganglionic lesion, the abnormal pupil will not dilate 
- The rationale for this is that hydroxyamphetamine will stimulate the release of norepinephrine from the post-ganglionic neurons 
- If there is damage to a pre-ganglionic neuron (leaving the post-ganglionic intact), norepinephrine will be released and dilation will occur 
- If there is damage to the post-ganglionic neuron, hydroxyamphetamine will have no effect on this neuron, no norepinephrine will be released, and the pupil will not dilate

questions.question: A patient is seen at your office complaining that her right eye is physiologically higher than her left eye. She would like to know if glasses would help improve the cosmesis of her predicament. You know that prism will shift the image of an object. How would you orient a prism to help her appearance?
options: Prescribe base out prism over the left eye
Prescribe base up prism over the right eye
Prescribe base down prism over the left eye
Prescribe base in prism over the left eye
answers: Prescribe base up prism over the right eye
questions.explanation: A prism will bend light towards its base, but the image will be shifted towards the apex of the prism. Therefore, by prescribing base up prism over her right eye, its image will be shifted down towards the apex of the prism. Another way of remembering this is to think of the prism as an arrow that will point in the direction of the deviation (i.e., exotropia is neutralized with base in prism, the eye points outwards, the apex of the prism also points out). Prescribing prism for cosmetic purposes may not always be an option as significant vertical prism may induce diplopia or visual discomfort.

questions.question: A patient with 4.50 D of hyperopia wishes to purchase glasses. Which of the following can be performed to minimize the amount of spherical aberration experienced by the patient when he is looking through his glasses?
options: Prescribing a plano-convex lens with the convex side of the lens placed inwards (the convex side should be the F2 surface)
Maintain a single and uniform radius of curvature throughout the lens
Prescribe a biconvex lens and ensure that the smallest blank size is utilized placing the bevel towards the front of the lens
Ensure that the prescribed lens is steeper towards the center and flatter peripherally
answers: Ensure that the prescribed lens is steeper towards the center and flatter peripherally
questions.explanation: Spherical aberration occurs when parallel light rays incident on the cornea and lens that are located further away from the visual axis are bent to a greater degree than axial rays, resulting in an image that comes to a point focus in front of the retinal plane. Spherical lenses (both plus- and minus-powered) result in positive spherical aberration; thus rays of light that are located towards the lens periphery (nonparaxial) are bent more than those that intersect the center of the lens (paraxial rays). Spherical aberration can be minimized by prescribing an aspheric lens for higher powered prescriptions. Aspheric lenses have multiple radii of curvature. A plus powered aspheric lens has a radius of curvature that increases towards the periphery of the lens (the periphery of the lens is flatter than the center). Studies have shown that plano-convex lenses produce smaller amounts of spherical aberration. For hyperopes, a plano-convex lens should be placed with its convex side as the F1 to decrease spherical aberration. Spherical aberration can also be minimized by decreasing the size of the aperture/pupil. Biconvex lenses should not be prescribed as this lens results in more spherical aberration than a plano-convex lens.

questions.question: What is the relationship between the Abbe number and chromatic aberration?
questions.explanation: The Abbe number is the reciprocal of the dispersion of a spectacle lens. As the dispersion increases, a patient might experience seeing a rainbow of color as they view in the lens periphery. This is known as chromatic aberration. Crown glass has a high Abbe number of 59 and thus a low chromatic aberration.

questions.question: Light falls onto an air-water interface. Assuming normal incidence, which of the following equations would allow you to solve for the percentage of light that is reflected? (index of water is 1.33)
questions.explanation: Fresnel's law of reflectance states that some amount of light is reflected at each surface, which then decreases the amount of transmitted light. The equation is as follows: R = (n2-n1)2/(n2+n1)2 , where R= reflectance (assuming normal incidence), n2= the index of the second medium, and n1= the index of the first medium. Solve for R= (1.33-1.0)2/(1.33+1.0)2, R= (0.1089)/(5.43)=0.020 or 2%. This finding is important for ophthalmic lenses, especially those of higher index which reflect more light. Makers of optical devices can minimize reflectance by adding anti-reflective coatings.

questions.question: A chiasmal lesion or mass, such as a pituitary tumor, generally causes what type of visual field defect?
questions.explanation: The center of the chiasm contains axons of decussating ganglion cells that originate from the nasal retinas, which process temporal visual field information. The lateral portion of the chiasm is comprised of the axons of the temporal aspect of the retinas, which do not cross over. Lesions most commonly occur in the central portion of the chiasm and not the lateral aspects. Any central chiasmal mass or lesion will cause a bitemporal visual field defect that respects the vertical midline.

questions.question: Which of the bifocal lens designs below will create the largest amount of image jump?
questions.explanation: Image jump is the phenomenon where the patient's eyes are passing from the distance prescription and are now viewing just below the top of the bifocal segment. The eyes are not quite at the near optical center (OC), therefore prism is induced. The farther away the near OC is from the top of the segment, the larger the amount of image jump. The round 28 bifocal has its optical center 14 mm below the top of the segment (the optical center for a round segment is located at its center, which is half of its diameter). The flat top 28 and flat top 35 bifocal optical centers are located 5 mm below the segment line. The Executive OC is on the segment line, so no image jump is created.

questions.question: Which of the following heating methods is BEST for adjusting frames fabricated from nylon?
questions.explanation: The preferred method utilized for heating nylon frames is hot water. Nylon frames cannot be heated uniformly enough through other methods as hot forced air and salt pans do not penetrate the material enough, leaving the outer layers hot and the deeper portions too cool to stretch or bend. Hot water tends to penetrate the nylon material best. When adjusting a nylon frame, it is best to hold the frame into its desired position as it cools. If the frame is released before it cools, it tends to resume its initial conformation. The addition of cold running water can help speed the process along.

questions.question: Which of the following muscles would NOT be affected by a lesion to the facial nerve (CN VII)?
questions.explanation:
The oculomotor nerve (CNIII) innervates the superior palpebral levator which opens the eye. The facial nerve innervates the muscles of facial expression including the orbicularis oculi which closes the eye, the frontalis which raises the eyebrow, and the corrugator supercilii which moves the eyebrow medially. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 pp 137-148

questions.question: In order to ensure proper measurements for a pair of progressive spectacles, which of the following should be completed during the fitting process?
options: Drawing a line for the fitting height at the lower eyelid margin
Use of the standard progressive lens cut-out chart to verify that frame depth is adequate
Pre-adjustment of the frame on the patient's face
answers: Pre-adjustment of the frame on the patient's face
questions.explanation:
The standard method for taking progressive lens fitting measurements is as follows (according to Brooks and Borish). 
•Measure distance PDs monocularly (not binocularly) 
°Recommended method is to use a pupillometer (most accurate) 
•Fit and fully adjust the desired frame on the patient's face 
°Pantoscopic tilt, frame height, vertex distance, face-form wrap, and nose-pad alignment 
°If the frame is not pre-adjusted, fitting height measurements may be incorrect 
•Ensure that the clear demo lenses are in place in the desired frame 
°If lenses are not present, or are darkly tinted, place clear (transparent) tape across the eyewire of the empty frame 
•Dispenser should be positioned with his or her eyes at the level of the patient's eyes 
°The patient should look at the bridge of the fitter's nose 
°Draw a horizontal line on the lens or tape through the center of the pupil for each eye (not the lower eyelid margin as for bifocals) 
•Place the frame on the specific manufacturer's centration chart (there is no standard progressive lens cut-out chart) 
°Line up the bridge so that it is centered on the diagonally converging central alignment pattern 
°Line up the marked horizontal fitting lines so that they are aligned with the horizontal axis of the chart 
°Mark the previously measured PD for each eye as a vertical line that crosses the horizontal fitting line 
•The fitting height of the lenses should then be measured as the vertical distance between the fitting cross and the level of the inside bevel of the lower eyewire of the frame 
•Move the frame over to the lens picture portion of the centration chart so that the cross on the lens matches with the cross on the chart 
°Verify that the add power circle fits within the boundaries of the frame 
°Verify that one of the large overall circles completely encloses the frame's lens shape
PowerPage
Measuring Multifocal Heights

questions.question: A lens clock has many uses. Which 4 of the following items can be measured via a lens clock? (Select 4)
options: The add power of a multifocal ophthalmic lens
The index of refraction of a spectacle lens
The base curve of a gas-permeable lens
The thickness of an anti-reflective coating
The base curve of an ophthalmic lens
The center thickness of a gas-permeable lens
Potential warpage of an ophthalmic lens
answers: The add power of a multifocal ophthalmic lens
The base curve of an ophthalmic lens
The center thickness of a gas-permeable lens
Potential warpage of an ophthalmic lens
questions.explanation: Lens clocks are useful instruments that can be used to calculate the base curve of an ophthalmic spectacle lens, determine the add power of a multifocal lens, test for potential lens warpage, determine the amount of slab-off prism on an ophthalmic lens, calculate the thickness of a gas-permeable lens as well as determine the nominal (or approximate) power of an ophthalmic lens.

questions.question: When measuring the overall temple length of a pair of eyeglasses, where does the anterior end of the measurement begin?
options: The anterior end of the temple
The anterior surface of the frame
The center of the hinge screw
The posterior surface of the frame
answers: The center of the hinge screw
questions.explanation: The overall temple length is measured by taking the distance from the center of the hinge screw to the posterior end of the temple (measured along the center of the temple). In plastic or metal frames, this is typically measured by adding the length to the bend of the temple to the length of the drop (bend to posterior end).

questions.question: Where is the base curve of a modern spectacle lens typically located?
options: The base curve is located on the same side as the cylinder power
The base curve is located on the front lens surface
The base curve is located on the opposite side of where the bifocal segment is located
The base curve is located on the back side of a modern lens
answers: The base curve is located on the front lens surface
questions.explanation:
Base curves are located on the front or non-ocular side of a modern spectacle lens (minus cylinder form). Older lenses had the base curve on the back of the lens, with the cylinder power on the front side (plus cylinder form). The advantage to the minus cylinder lens form is that the cylinder is closer to the eye, minimizing marginal astigmatism when one views away from the optical center. 

Modern bifocal lenses have the bifocal on the front of the lens; thus, the base curve is on the same side as the bifocal but on the opposite side of the cylinder power.

questions.question: What portion of the progressive lens should be used to verify the distance prescription when the lenses arrive from the lab?
options: The center of the fitting cross
The center of the distance arc
answers: The center of the distance arc
questions.explanation:
When a progressive lens prescription is returned from the lab, it typically contains the removable markings that can be used for prescription verification and fitting purposes. 

Distance reference point (DRP) 
-Located at the center of the distance arc 
-Indicates the recommended position of the lens through which the distance 
prescription should be measured with a lensometer 

Fitting cross 
-Used to verify the fitting height 
-Should be centered on the patient's pupil 
-2 horizontal dashes to the right and left of the fitting cross help to determine 
whether the lens is level or tilted 

PRP (prism reference point) 
-Used to verify the prism power 
-This is the same as the MRP (major reference point) 

Near reference point (NRP) 
-Located at the center of the circle in the lower part of the lens 
-Used to verify the near add power
PowerPage
Lensometry Multifocals

questions.question: A myopic patient wears a contact lens with a power of -7.00 D. She wishes to purchase a pair of glasses. How must her prescription be altered so that her spectacle lenses provide a clear retinal image?
options: The center thickness of the lens must be increased to compensate for a change in vertex distance
The minus power of the spectacle lenses must be decreased
The optical center of the lens must be decreased so that it coincides with the lower edge of her pupil
The minus power of the spectacle lenses must be increased
answers: The minus power of the spectacle lenses must be increased
questions.explanation: When a minus powered lens (greater than 4.00 D) is moved from the corneal to the spectacle plane, the power needs to be adjusted by adding more minus to ensure a clear retinal image. Logically, the far point of the eye must correspond with the secondary focal point of the lens to achieve a clear retinal image. The far point of a myopic eye is an unchanging fixed distance from the eye. Spectacles are further from the eye but closer to the far point of the eye (by the vertex distance of the spectacle) and therefore a higher power will achieve a reduced focal length, which makes sense, as the lens is physically closer to the far point of the eye. Contact lenses sit closer to the eye and further from the actual far point of the eye and therefore require less minus power at the corneal plane. Therefore, to ensure that the far point of the eye coincides with the secondary focal point of the lens, the power of the contact lens must be decreased for a myopic eye when going from the spectacle to the corneal plane.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for an image created by a plane mirror?
options: The image is located closer to the mirror than the object
The image is the same size as the original object
answers: The image is the same size as the original object
questions.explanation: Images created by a plane mirror are virtual, reversed, laterally inverted and upright, appear the same size as the object and appear to be located as far from the mirror as the object is situated in front of the mirror.

questions.question: Which of the following statements holds true for a thin lens that is located in ANY homogenous medium?
options: The index of refraction of the lens increases as the index of refraction of the surrounding medium increases
The location of the primary focal point from the lens is half the distance of the secondary focal point from the lens
The primary and secondary focal points are equidistant from the lens
The location of the primary focal point from the lens is twice that of the distance of the secondary focal point from the lens
answers: The primary and secondary focal points are equidistant from the lens
questions.explanation:
A thin lens, when located in any medium (as long as it is homogenous), will have primary and secondary focal lengths situated equidistant from the lens; that is, their absolute values will be equivalent because the surrounding medium is the same. 

The index of refraction of a lens will not change even if the index of refraction of the surrounding medium is altered. The index of refraction of the lens is an inherent property of the lens material and will not change even if the curvature of the lens is altered. However, if the shape of the lens is changed, the power of the lens will also be changed.

questions.question: A hyperopic patient increases the vertex distance of his glasses from 14.0 mm to 19.00 mm. How does this alter the effectivity of his spectacle lenses?
options: Lens effectivity applies only to contact lenses
questions.explanation: The effective power of a plus-powered lens increases as the lens is moved further from the eye (increased vertex distance) and decreases as the lens is moved closer to the eye. The effective power of a minus-powered lens increases as the vertex distance decreases (moves closer to the eye) and decreases with increased vertex distance (further away from the eye).

questions.question: Which of the following characteristics of concave-meniscus lenses is TRUE?
options: The lens has an overall negative power
The lens is thicker in the center than at its edge
Both the front surface and back surfaces of the lens are concave
Both the front surface and back surfaces of the lens are negative in power
answers: The lens has an overall negative power
questions.explanation:
A concave-meniscus lens has a surface that is concave (negative power) and a surface that is convex (plus power). With this type of lens, the power of the concave surface is greater than the convex, leading to a negative overall power. If the convex surface had a greater power, this would be considered a convex-meniscus lens. 

Concave-meniscus lenses also have thicker edges compared to their center thickness (convex-meniscus lenses are thicker in the center).

questions.question: According to the American National Standards Institute (ANSI), what marking must be seen on the frame in order for it to qualify as a safety frame?
options: The letter 'V' permanently etched onto the lens
The letter 'S' etched onto the front of the frame and both temples
A 'plus' mark (+) etched onto the periphery of the lens
'Z87-2' and the manufacturer's mark on the front of the frame and on both temples
answers: 'Z87-2' and the manufacturer's mark on the front of the frame and on both temples
questions.explanation: Frames that have successfully met the requirements for high-impact and high mass-velocity tests are marked with Z87-2. Lenses that have passed the high-impact test will have a '+' mark (along with the manufacturer's trademark) permanently etched onto the lens. The letter 'V' symbolizes that the safety lens is photochromic. The letter 'S' denotes that the lens is designated for a special purpose, such as a didymium lens commonly worn by glass-blowers.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the 'B' measurement of a spectacle lens in an eyeglasses frame?
options: The longest length of the lens in any direction
The longest vertical length of the lens
Distance between the two geometric centers of the lenses
Twice the distance from the geometric center of the lens to the lens apex furthest from this point
The longest horizontal length of the lens
answers: The longest vertical length of the lens
questions.explanation:
Boxing system measurements: 
- 'A' Measurement: The horizontal length of the lens (or box enclosing the lens); it is also known as the 'eye size' when referring to the frame, and the 'lens size' when referring to the spectacle lens 
- 'B' Measurement: The vertical length of the lens (or box enclosing the lens); the 'A' and 'B' measurements are independent of the lens shape 
- 'C' Measurement: The width of the lens itself along the horizontal midline; this can vary significantly from the lens 'A' measurement and is rarely used 
- Effective Diameter (ED): This dimension is found by doubling the distance from the geometric center of the lens to the apex of the lens bevel that sits farthest from the center; this measurement is helpful in determining the minimum lens blank size 
- Distance Between Lenses (DBL): The distance between the two boxes when both lenses are boxed in the frame; this can be determined on the frame by measuring the distance between the grooves in the nasal eyewires at the narrowest point

questions.question: The positive spherical aberration of the eye is typically MOST offset by which natural property of the eye?
options: The natural unaccommodated state of the eye
questions.explanation: Spherical aberration (SA) occurs when parallel light rays incident on the cornea and lens that are located further away from the visual axis are bent to a greater degree than axial rays, resulting in an image that comes to a point focus in front of the retinal plane. Because the cornea is steepest centrally and flattens towards the periphery, this asphericity offsets some of the positive spherical aberration experienced by the eye. A larger pupil results in more spherical aberration. Accommodation decreases the amount of spherical aberration, while an unaccommodated eye generally possesses increased positive spherical aberration; this explains why SA tends to increase with age as we lose our ability to accommodate.

questions.question: If a thick lens with a positive front and back surface increases in thickness, what effect will this have on the net equivalent power of the optical system?
options: The net equivalent power will become less positive
The change in net equivalent power cannot be determined without knowing the index of the material
The net equivalent power will become more positive
The net equivalent power will remain unchanged
answers: The net equivalent power will become less positive
questions.explanation:
If both of the surface powers of a thick less are either negative or positive, increasing the separation between the surfaces will cause the net equivalent power of the optical system to become more negative (or less positive). 

The effective power equation is below: 
De = D1 + D2 - (t/n) x D1D2

questions.question: The power of a thin lens in air can be found by using which of the following equations?
options: The radius of curvature subtracted by the primary focal length
The reciprocal of the radius of curvature of the lens in meters
The reciprocal of the secondary focal length in meters
The square of the sagittal height of the lens divided by the chord length
answers: The reciprocal of the secondary focal length in meters
questions.explanation: The power of a thin lens in air can be determined using the formula P= n/f' where n=the index of refraction of the surrounding medium, which in the above case is air (1.00) and f'=the secondary focal length.

questions.question: An object in air is located 40 cm to the left of a +4.25 D spherical CR39 plastic surface (n=1.498). In order to solve for the distance of the resultant image from the apex of the surface, which of the following must be calculated FIRST?
options: The index of the surrounding medium
The object location from the refracting surface
The image vergence at the refracting surface
The object vergence at the refracting surface
answers: The object vergence at the refracting surface
questions.explanation: In order to solve for the distance of the image from the refracting surface, the object vergence must be calculated. In the above problem, this is solved as follows: L=n/l where L= the object vergence, n=the index of the medium containing the object, and l=the distance of the light rays from the object to the refracting surface in meters. L= 1.0/-0.4= -2.5. The paraxial relationship deems that the vergence of light rays forming an image is the combination of incident vergence and the power of the refracting surface. One can now determine that the vergence of the incident light on a +4.25D plastic surface is -2.50. Adding the two values together yields the power of the image vergence L'=L+P where L= the object vergence and P= the power of the refracting surface, which in this case is -2.50 +4.25 = +1.75 D. Because the light rays forming the image are converging, the image is real. The location of the image is calculated using the formula L'=n'/l' where L= the image vergence, n'= the index of the medium in which the light rays form an image, and l'= the distance between the refracting surface and the image. We have already determined that L'= +1.75 D and n'= 1.498. Solving for l', +1.75=1.498/l', l'= 0.856 or 85.6 cm to the right of the refracting surface.

questions.question: You prescribe a patient 4 base down prism in the right eye. The patient wishes to order bifocal lenses. How should the segment height be adjusted to compensate for the prism?
options: The segment height of the left eye should be raised
The segment height of the right eye should be lowered
The segment height does not need to be altered
The segment height of the right eye should be raised
answers: The segment height of the right eye should be raised
questions.explanation:
Because the prism will shift the image towards the apex, the patient's eye will be looking slightly up at the image. In order to ensure that the pupils view through the segments at the same time, one must raise the bifocal height of the right eye. Make sure that you inform the patient that their seg heights will be unequal so there are no surprises when they pick up their glasses! A good rule of thumb to follow is that the segment height must be altered by 0.3 mm for every diopter of vertical prism added to one eye only (if the prism is distributed fairly equally between the eyes, then there is no need to adjust the bifocal height). Remember that for base down prism you must raise the seg height and for base up prism you must lower the seg height.
PowerPage
Measuring Multifocal Heights

questions.question: Which of the following terms describes the vertical measurement taken from the top of the reading segment on a bifocal to the deepest part of the frame or lens?
questions.explanation: The segment height is measured as the distance between the top of the segment to the deepest portion of the frame (this measurement is frame dependent). The segment depth is measured as the longest vertical distance from the top of the seg to the bottom of the seg. The seg width is determined by measuring the widest horizontal portion of the seg. The segment fusion is fictional.

questions.question: Instructing a patient to wrinkle their forehead assesses the integrity of which of the following?
options: The sensory aspect of cranial nerve VII
The motor aspect of cranial nerve VII
The motor aspect of cranial nerve VIII
The sensory aspect of cranial nerve VIII
answers: The motor aspect of cranial nerve VII
questions.explanation: The motor aspect of cranial nerve VII (facial) can be evaluated by asking a patient to wrinkle their forehead, tightly shut their eyes, smile, and whistle. Any asymmetry or inability suggests damage or inflammation to cranial nerve VII. The sensory function of cranial nerve VII may be investigated by blindfolding the patient and presenting substances that are sweet, salty, sour, and bitter to each side of the tongue, and asking the patient to identify the substance as sweet, salty, sour, or bitter.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following are TRUE in regards to ANSI standards for progressive addition lenses (PALs) and single vision or bifocal lenses? (Select 2)
options: The tolerance for cylinder axis is higher for PALs as compared to single vision or bifocal lenses
The tolerance for sphere power is higher for PALs as compared to single vision or bifocal lenses
The tolerance for cylinder power is higher for PALs as compared to single vision or bifocal lenses
The tolerance for add power is higher for PALs as compared to bifocal lenses
answers: The tolerance for sphere power is higher for PALs as compared to single vision or bifocal lenses
The tolerance for cylinder power is higher for PALs as compared to single vision or bifocal lenses
questions.explanation:
General tolerances for single vision (SV) and multifocal lenses (MF; these include bifocals and trifocals) are slightly different than progressive addition lenses (PALs), according to ANSI standards. 

Sphere power 
-SV/MF: For powers up to +/- 6.50, tolerance is +/- 0.13D 
-PALs: For powers up to +/- 8.00, tolerance is +/- 0.16D 
-Powers higher than this have a tolerance of +/-2% for both SV/MF and PALs 

Cylinder power 
-Tolerances are higher for PALs at all cylinder power ranges 

Cylinder axis 
-Tolerance ranges are the same for SV/MF and PALs 

Add power 
-Tolerance ranges are the same for SV/MF and PALs 

Others 
-Unmounted prism, vertical prism imbalance, and horizontal prism imbalance tolerances are the same for SV/MF and PALs 
-Vertical segment height (fitting point height) and vertical segment difference (fitting point difference) tolerances are the same for MF and PALs 
-Horizontal segment location (fitting point location) tolerance is less for PALs than MF (1.0 mm vs. 2.5 mm)
PowerPage
Measuring Multifocal Heights

questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE in regards to changes in retinal ganglion cell axons that occur with age?
options: There are approximately 5,000 axons lost per year of life
There are approximately 10,000 axons lost per year of life
Loss of axons does not typically occur with age
There are approximately 1,000 axons lost per year of life
answers: There are approximately 5,000 axons lost per year of life
questions.explanation: Normal human aging results in the gradual loss of retinal ganglion cells at an approximate rate of 5,000 axons per year of life. Additionally, it has been shown that there is a smaller degree of loss of the macular retinal ganglion cells as compared to the retinal ganglion cells situated in the periphery. In cases of certain ocular diseases, such as optic neuropathy, the rate of ganglion cell loss per year is much more rapid.

questions.question: Which cranial nerve is the ONLY nerve to emerge from the dorsal aspect of the brain?
questions.explanation:
The fourth cranial nerve (trochlear nerve) has several important characteristics that can aid in diagnosis and localization of lesions involving this nerve. These include the following: 
- The 4th nerve is a very slender nerve that runs a very long course as it leaves its nucleus and travels to the eye 
- The 4th nerve is a crossed nerve; it innervates the contralateral superior oblique muscle 
- The 4th nerve is the only cranial nerve to exit the brain from the dorsal side

questions.question: Horizontally polarized light is incident on a polarizer with an absorption axis that is rotated 25 degrees from the horizontal. Which of the following equations will solve for the percentage of light that will be transmitted?
questions.explanation: An ideal polarizing sheet is composed of dichroic material that will transmit 100% of light parallel to its transmission axis and will absorb 100% of incident light perpendicular to this axis. The transmittance of light that is oriented at a certain angle from the polarizing axis will follow Malus' law, which is Tpol=cos2 theta, where Tpol= the amount of transmitted light after it has passed through the polarizer, and theta= the angle between the incident light and the transmission axis. For the question above, the absorption axis is tilted 25 from the horizontal and its transmission axis is perpendicular to that, so the angle between the incident light and the transmission axis is 65 degrees or 90-25 degrees. Tpol=cos2(65 degrees)=0.178 or 18%. When answering these types of questions, ensure that the answer makes sense. In the above case, the absorption axis is close to the original orientation of the incident polarized light and therefore one should expect a low transmission percentage.

questions.question: Vertically polarized light is incident on a polarizer with an absorption axis that is rotated 15 degrees from the vertical. Which of the following equations will solve for the percentage of light that will be transmitted?
questions.explanation:
An ideal polarizing sheet is composed of dichroic material that will transmit 100% of light parallel to its transmission axis and will absorb 100% of incident light perpendicular to this axis. The transmittance of light that is oriented at a certain angle from the polarizing axis will follow Malus' law which is Tpol=cos2(theta), where Tpol= the amount of transmitted light after it has passed through the polarizer and theta= the angle between the incident light and the transmission axis. In the question above, the absorption axis is tilted 15 degrees from the vertical and its transmission axis is perpendicular to that, so the angle between the incident light and the transmission axis is 75 degrees or 90-15 degrees. Tpol=cos2(75 degrees)=0.0669 or 6.7%. When answering these types of questions, be sure that the answer makes sense. In the above case, the absorption axis is close to the original orientation of the incident polarized light and therefore one should expect a low transmission percentage.
PowerPage
Important Formulas

questions.question: Which of the following pathological events is LEAST likely to result in an aberrant regeneration of cranial nerve III (oculomotor)?
questions.explanation: Aberrant regeneration of cranial nerve (CN) III can occur secondary to an acute oculomotor palsy caused by a tumor, an aneurysm or trauma, or alternatively it may originate from a congenital CN III palsy. Aberrant regeneration can occur any time there are multiple structures innervated by a common point of origin. When the fibers regenerate, they end up innervating a different muscle than the one for which the fibers were originally destined (nerve fiber misdirection). Common signs of CN III aberrant regeneration include: miosis of the pupil with downgaze, upgaze or adduction, pseudo von Graefe sign (lid retraction with downgaze), or lid retraction with adduction as well as adduction that occurs with up- or downgaze.

questions.question: Which of the following systemic conditions is MOST commonly associated with the occurrence of optic neuritis?
questions.explanation: Optic neuritis is a term used to describe swelling and inflammation of the optic nerve along any of its segments. When associated with a swollen optic disc, this condition is known as papillitis, and when the optic nerve head appears normal, the term retrobulbar optic neuritis is utilized. The etiology of optic neuritis is presumed to be demyelination of the optic nerve, most commonly associated with multiple sclerosis (MS); however, it can be an acute idiopathic disease. Studies on optic neuritis have also shown that patients in whom optic neuritis occurs as an isolated phenomenon have a higher risk of developing multiple sclerosis in the future. Therefore, there is a strong association with the occurrence of optic neuritis in patients diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, and for those in which MS is not present, there is a high chance they will eventually develop the disease.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions are NOT associated with a lesion involving the third nerve fasciculus?
questions.explanation:
The third nerve fasciculus is composed of efferent fibers that pass from the nuclear complex, through the red nucleus and medial region of the cerebral peduncle. These fibers then emerge from the midbrain and traverse into the interpeduncular space. The most common causes of fascicular lesions are vascular disease, primary tumors, metastasis, and demyelination. There are several syndromes that may occur, depending on the location of the lesion, along the course of the fascicular fibers. These include Benedikt syndrome, Weber syndrome, Nothnagel syndrome, and Claude syndrome. Wall-eyed bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia (WEBINO) occurs as a result of a lesion involving the paired medial rectus subnuclei of the third nerve. 

Benedikt syndrome involves the fasciculus as the fibers pass through the red nucleus. Patients will develop an ipsilateral third nerve palsy with contralateral extrapyramidal signs (such as hemitremor). 

Weber syndrome involves the fascicular fibers as they pass through the cerebral peduncle. Signs include ipsilateral third nerve palsy with contralateral hemiparesis. 

Nothnagel syndrome involves the superior cerebral peduncle and the fasciculus. It is characterized by ipsilateral third nerve palsy as well as cerebellar ataxia. 

Claude syndrome is a combination of both Benedikt and Nothnagel syndromes.

questions.question: You are heating frames in your salt pan so that you can insert new lenses into the frame. When you pull the frame out of the pan, you notice that some of the salt is sticking to the frame. What must be done to alleviate this issue?
options: This frame should not be heated in a salt pan
Add talcum powder to the salt
Check the heating element of the salt pan
answers: Add talcum powder to the salt
questions.explanation: When heating frames in a salt pan, the frame should be moved very slowly and continually while under the salt in order to avoid pitting of the frames with salt granules. If after pulling the frame out of the salt, the salt sticks to a dry frame, additional talcum powder should be added to the salt pan. The only two components of the salt pan are the salt and talcum powder. The salt conveys heat well and the talcum powder is added in order to prevent the salt from clumping together and sticking to the frame.

questions.question: What is the ANSI standard number for prescription ophthalmic lens recommendations?
questions.explanation:
- Z80.1 ? Prescription ophthalmic lens recommendations 
- Z80.3 ? Non-prescription sunglasses and fashion eyewear 
- Z80.5 ? Requirements for ophthalmic frames 
- Z80.7 ? Intraocular lenses 
- Z80.9 ? Low vision aids requirements

questions.question: You are measuring the distance power of your patient's habitual progressive addi...
questions.explanation: The distance power of a progressive addition lens (PAL) should be measured by placing the glasses on the lensometer so that the temples are facing away from the clinician (this will measure back vertex power). The lens should be aligned so that the distance power arc is centered on the lensometer aperture. Some people mistakenly will center the cross on the lensometer aperture; this is incorrect.

questions.question: A patient's pupillary response is evaluated and the following is found:
options: In dim illumination, the pupil size is OD 6mm and OS 3mm. In bright illumination, the pupil size is OD 4mm and OS 2mm. Light and near response are normal for each eye. What 3 other findings can you expect? (Select 3)
Both eyes dilate equally after instillation of 10% topical cocaine
Lower intraocular pressure in the left eye when compared to the intraocular pressure of the right eye
Anhidrosis of the left side of the face
answers: Lower intraocular pressure in the left eye when compared to the intraocular pressure of the right eye
Anhidrosis of the left side of the face
questions.explanation:
Horner's syndrome results in anisocoria that is greater in dim illumination. The affected pupil is smaller and dilates less than the normal (larger) pupil in the dark. A triad of miosis, ipsilateral mild ptosis (1-2mm), and ipsilateral anhidrosis can be associated with Horner's syndrome. Other signs include lower intraocular pressure (1-2 mmHg) and lower lid elevation in the affected eye. Iris heterochromia is an indication of congenital Horner's syndrome. 

The cocaine test is used to confirm the diagnosis of Horner's syndrome. Topical cocaine 4-10% is instilled in both eyes and pupils are checked after 30-60 minutes. If both pupils dilate equally, then normal physiologic anisocoria is present. However, if the smaller pupil dilates poorly in comparison to the normal (larger) pupil, the diagnosis of Horner's syndrome is confirmed. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, hydroxyamphetamine 1% can be used to localize the cause and distinguish between preganglionic and postganglionic lesions.

questions.question:
A 5.00 D myopic patient wants to know how thick the edges of his new lenses will be in polycarbonate, based on the following parameters: 
Rx = -5.00 DS 
Minimum lens center thickness is 2.00 mm. 
Lens size = 50 mm
questions.explanation:
Sag = (Fh2)/2000(n - 1) F=lens power, h2=radius of the lens squared 
Sag = (5)(625)/2000(1.59-1) 
Sag = (3125)/2000(0.59)= 2.65 + 2.00 (center thickness)= 4.65 mm 

The sagitta (sag) formula approximates the edge thickness of a minus lens or the center thickness of a plus lens, without taking into consideration the minus lens center thickness or plus lens edge thickness. Add the minus lens center or plus lens edge thickness to the sag resultant to determine the total thickness.

questions.question: An object is located in an unknown medium with an index of 1.45. When perceived from above, the image appears closer to the surface than the object. Which of the following equations will correctly solve for the lateral magnification produced by the optical system below?
questions.explanation: The lateral magnification can be determined by the equation M=L/L' where M=lateral magnification, L=object vergence (n/l), and L'=image vergence (n'/l'). Placing the above values into the formula yields M=(1.45/0.36)/(1.0/0.2512); solving for M, M= 4.028/3.98, M= 1.012. Because object rays are diverging, the object vergence is assigned a negative value. The image vergence is also negative, as the image is virtual. Because both values are negative, the signs would cancel out, resulting in a magnification that is positive, indicating that the image is upright.

questions.question: At which location of the progressive addition lens (PAL) pictured below can prism be measured or verified?
questions.explanation:
Prism can be measured and/or verified at the prism reference point (PRP) which is located at 'C' in the above image. 
'A' is the distance reference point (DRP), which is located in the center of the distance arc. This is the location at which distance power is measured.
