Saline is not an acceptable intraocular irrigating solution because it does not contain the electrolytes needed to maintain proper isotonicity of the corneal endothelium (such as calcium, magnesium, glucose, sodium, potassium, etc.); this will result in swelling and lysis of the endothelial cells. BSS is frequently used for short-term intraocular surgeries as it is isotonic to ocular tissue and contains electrolytes that are needed for normal cell functions.

questions.question: What type of kinetics is displayed by the majority of topical ophthalmic drops?
questions.explanation:
The majority of topical ophthalmic drugs display a first-order rate of elimination. A zero-order rate of elimination will result in a drug being eliminated at a constant rate. A zero-order process is independent of the concentration of the drug; therefore, increasing the amount of the drug will not result in a faster rate of drug elimination. In comparison, a first-order rate of elimination is largely dependent on the concentration of the drug. Increasing the amount or dose of the substance will result in a quicker rate of drug elimination. Second-order and third-order rates of elimination do not exist in pharmacokinetics. 

http://www.revophth.com/content/d/therapeutic_topics/i/1209/c/22787/

questions.question: Which of the following is a common side effect of oral administration of erythromycin?
questions.explanation: Many patients who take erythromycin experience GI upset; it is advised that this medicine be taken either 1 hour before or two hours after a meal. Erythromycin has not been known to cause weight gain or tinnitus, nor has erythromycin been linked to otitis media. It is noteworthy that aspirin use has been associated with tinnitus.

questions.question: Which of the following medications occasionally used to treat meibomian gland dysfunction may cause idiopathic intracranial hypertension when taken orally?
questions.explanation:
Doxycycline, tetracycline, and minocycline belong to the tetracycline class of medications. These antibiotics are frequently used in the treatment of acne, meibomian gland dysfunction, and other infections. Although the mechanism as to why intracranial hypertension occurs remains unclear at this time, all of these medications have the potential to cause idiopathic intracranial hypertension (also known as pseudotumor cerebri or PTC). Because minocycline possesses a high lipid solubility, it has a higher affinity to pass into the cerebrospinal fluid, which may lead to benign (idiopathic) intracranial hypertension. 

Unlike the typical form of PTC, increased intracranial hypertension as a result of 'cycline medication' use occurs equally in males and females and does not have a predilection for overweight females of child-bearing age. The time lag for the development of PTC after the initiation of 'cycline' therapy remains unclear, as some patients may displays signs after two weeks of taking the medication while others do not report symptoms until a year has passed after the commencement of therapy. Patients on a 'cycline' medication who report headaches, diplopia, or present with sixth cranial nerve palsy or swollen optic nerves should cease taking this medication. 

References: 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1125522/ 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/624295

questions.question: A 63-year old female is seen at your office with a chief concern of blurry vision in the morning that takes about an hour to resolve before she can see clearly again. Biomicroscopy reveals endothelial guttata. You correctly diagnose her with moderate Fuch's dystrophy. Which ophthalmic drop would be of MOST benefit to her?
questions.explanation: Sodium chloride is a topical hyperosmotic agent used to relieve stromal edema caused by endothelial decompensation. Topical steroids work well to decrease swelling caused by inflammation. In the above case, the corneal edema is not mitigated by an inflammatory response. Tobramycin and Vigamox® would be of no benefit since there is no active infection, and prescribing either of these would only lead to corneal toxicity or increased pathogen resistance over time.

questions.question: A 65-year old patient presents at your clinic for a baseline glaucoma work-up. The patient's medical history is remarkable for diabetes type II and asthma. Current medications include metformin and fluticasone propionate/salmeterol xinafoate (Advair®). The patient is allergic to sulfa-based drugs. Based upon testing, the patient was found to have early primary open-angle glaucoma in both eyes. What would be the best initial topical treatment?
questions.explanation:
A topical prostaglandin would be the best initial choice in this case because as a stand-alone therapy, prostaglandins are used one drop a day and typically lower IOP the most (anywhere from 20-40%). Beta blockers are contraindicated in this case as the patient suffers from asthma. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are contraindicated in this case as the patient has an allergy to sulfa-based medicationss. As a stand-alone therapy, topical alpha agonist medications are typically used three times a day; therefore, from a compliance stand point, topical prostaglandins would be the better choice. Topical miotics would not be a good choice due to the potential for multiple side effects.
PowerPage
Topical Glaucoma Medications- Part 1

questions.question: Which of the following ophthalmic drops results in the LONGEST duration of cycloplegic effect?
questions.explanation: After its instillation, atropine reaches its maximum cycloplegic effect at 160 minutes, and it can last for up to 12 days. Scopolamine, cyclopentolate, and tropicamide have cycloplegic effects that can last for up to 7 days, 24 hours, and 8 hours respectively.

questions.question: A 54-year old female presents at your office with a very photobic, red right eye. Slit lamp exam reveals 3+ cells and flare in the anterior chamber. There is no evidence of inflammation in the left eye. You correctly diagnose her with iritis and initiate treatment. However, you also notice that her intraocular pressure is 31 mmHg. Which of the following glaucoma medications should NOT be prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Xalatan® should not be prescribed because prostaglandins are contraindicated when there is active ocular inflammation. Trusopt®, Timolol® and Alphagan-P® could all be used to decrease her intraocular pressure (IOP) but Alphagan-P® would be the best drop to prescribe. Alphagan-P® is frequently utilized to reduce IOP following anterior segment laser surgery, such as in argon laser trabeculoplasty, which frequently causes transient, mild inflammation. 

It should be stated that clinically, if the left eye has normal IOP and you see flare due to iritis, this would indicate inflammatory glaucoma which is best treated with a steroid.

questions.question: A 66 year-old male presents to your office with a chief complaint of blurred vision, redness, and pain in his left eye. Upon examination you conclude that he is undergoing an acute angle closure attack. You decide to administer an oral acetazolamide to control IOP. What is the proper initial dosage for this medication in office?
options: One 500mg Diamox Sequel® capsule by mouth
Two 500mg Diamox Sequel® capsules by mouth
questions.explanation:
According to the AOA Clinical Practice Guidelines for Care of the Patient with Primary Angle Closure Glaucoma, an oral carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (CAI) such as acetazolamide (Diamox) should be given immediately upon diagnosis when the patient is not nauseated. Diamox is available in 125-250mg tablets or in a 500mg sustained released capsule (Sequel). A 500mg dose (two 250mg tablets) of Diamox in office is most commonly used. The 500mg Diamox Sequel should be avoided because it is a timed-release formulation; therefore, it has a slower onset of action. When a patient is nauseous, 500mg of intravenous acetazolamide should be administered. 
Remember that acetazolamide should be avoided in patients with kidney problems; in such cases, 100mg of methazolamide (Neptazene) becomes the CAI treatment of choice. CAIs are sulfa-based drugs and should also be avoided in patients with a known sulfa allergy.

questions.question: Which of the following oral medications should NOT be taken by patients at risk for narrow angle closure?
questions.explanation: Benadryl®, along with other oral antihistamines, can lead to mydriasis; therefore, people who have anatomically narrow angles may experience angle closure. Tylenol®, Aspirin, Lipitor® (a medication used to treat cholesterol), and Actos® (a medication used to help manage type II diabetes) do not pose a risk for people who possess narrow angles.

questions.question: Topical ophthalmic medications prescribed in an emulsion form prove to be advantageous over suspensions because of which of the following reasons?
options: Uniform concentration of medication in each drop
The addition of a light dye to allow for easy patient observation to ensure the drop was effectively instilled into the eye
They need to be refrigerated, offering ocular comfort and better compliance with instillation
Decreased retention time, resulting in less burring of vision
answers: Uniform concentration of medication in each drop
questions.explanation:
Ophthalmic medications in suspension form must be shaken well to allow for even concentration and distribution of the medication. If the medication is not re-suspended, uniform dosing of the medication will not be achieved; this can interfere with treatment efficacy, particularly when treating inflammation. Prescribing a medication that does not require shaking, such as an emulsion, ointment, or gel, allows for better therapeutic performance. Studies have demonstrated that the majority of patients do NOT shake the bottle adequately prior to drop instillation, even when explicitly instructed to vigorously agitate the bottle before use. 

Emulsions tend to be somewhat more viscous than suspensions and therefore purport better ocular retention time. However, patients may experience a slightly increased degree of transient blurring of vision with the use of emulsions. 

Refrigeration of medication is dependent upon the property of the medication itself. Emulsions do not necessarily need to be placed in the refrigerator. If the drug permits, some patients prefer to refrigerate their ophthalmic medication because it is easier to ascertain if the drop was successfully instilled into the eye and may also lead to improved ocular comfort upon administration. 

Dyes are not typically added to ophthalmic medications.

questions.question: Which of the following glaucoma medications is classified as a prostaglandin?
questions.explanation: Rescula® is classified as a prostaglandin. Prostaglandins decrease intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral outflow. Iopidine® is an adrenergic alpha-2 agonist; Betagan® is a beta blocker; Azopt® is categorized as a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. Note: Prostaglandins generally end in 'prost' except for unoprostone (Rescula®).

questions.question: Tetracycline should not be prescribed to children because of which of the following potential adverse effects?
questions.explanation: Tetracycline, when administered to children, can lead to short stature due to the fact that tetracycline becomes incorporated into calcifying bone, leading to stunting of growth. Tetracycline also causes yellowing of teeth because it can be integrated into dentin and enamel in developing teeth; this is yet another reason not to prescribe tetracycline to children. Other common side effects of tetracycline include allergic response, photosensitization, and GI distress. Tetracycline has not been known to cause urinary tract infections (it would actually serve to treat them), bone marrow depression, or thromboembolisms.

questions.question: In addition to improving nasal symptoms, intranasal corticosteroids have been shown to reduce which type of allergy symptom(s)?
questions.explanation: Several studies have shown that intranasal corticosteroids improve ocular allergy symptom scores. The hypothesized mechanism is based on the inhibition of the nasal-ocular reflex. Other proposed mechanisms include retrograde diffusion through the nasolacrimal duct and systemic absorption of the corticosteroid.

questions.question: Which of the following antibiotics have been proven to be MOST effective against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections?
questions.explanation:
Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is a dangerous pathogen that is most commonly found in hospital settings and long-term care facilities. Studies have shown that approximately 35% of Staphylococcus aureus isolates in the U.S. are considered methicillin-resistant. MRSA is resistant to all of the beta-lactam antibiotics, which include penicillin derivatives and cephalosporins. Additionally, many MRSA strains are also resistant to all generations of fluoroquinolones, as well as multiple other classes of antibiotics. At the present time, vancomycin has emerged as the most reliable agent for the treatment of MRSA infections and is therefore the drug of choice under these circumstances. 

Hospital Medicine (2nd edition). Wachter, R.M., Goldman, L., Hollander, H. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins.

questions.question: Excessive bleeding tendencies can result from a deficiency of what vitamin?
questions.explanation: Avitaminosis K has been linked with increased bleeding time. Vitamin K plays an important role in mediating the synthesis of several clotting factors. Vitamin K can be found in green, leafy vegetables and in oils such as cottonseed, canola, and olive. There exist many causes of avitaminosis K, some of which include malnutrition, alcoholism, parenchymal liver disease, cystic fibrosis, and certain drugs (antibiotics such as cephalosporins, warfarin, and some sulfa drugs). Symptoms of vitamin K deficiency include hematomas (bruising), ecchymosis (swelling), and increased bleeding time at injury sites.

questions.question: Riboflavin refers to which of the following vitamins?
questions.explanation: Vitamin B2 is also known as riboflavin. Riboflavin is important for the metabolism of nutrients. Because it is yellow or yellow/orange in color, riboflavin is frequency used to color foods. A deficiency (although quite rare) of vitamin B2 can lead to several ocular complications such as photophobia, corneal neovascularization and keratoconjunctivitis sicca. Dry, cracked lips, ulcers of the mouth, and sore throat may also be experienced. Some studies have reported that vitamin B2 supplementation may decrease the risk of cataracts.

questions.question: Scurvy results from a deficiency of what vitamin?
questions.explanation: Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, is a powerful antioxidant. Vitamin C facilitates the absorption of dietary iron. It is also a cofactor in many enzymatic reactions, including the synthesis of collagen. Avitaminosis C results in scurvy caused by the creation of unstable collagen. Scurvy presents with general weakness, anemia, brown spots on the skin, spongy gums, petechial hemorrhages of the skin and mucous membranes, proptosis and feelings of paralysis, amongst other symptoms. Advanced cases are remarkable for open suppurative wounds, loss of teeth, and death. Interesting fact: Broccoli contains more vitamin C than oranges, 90mg/100mg vs. 50mg/100mg. The kakadu plum contains a whopping 3100mg/100mg of vitamin C!! Severe alcoholics can become victims of scurvy due to malnutrition.

questions.question: A 62-year old male presents in your office with macular degeneration. His health history is positive for smoking. Which of the following vitamins or minerals should NOT be recommended in his treatment plan?
questions.explanation: Vitamin A should not be recommended for this patient. Although Vitamin A is recommended by the Age-Related Eye Disease Study I (AREDS I), it cannot be used in patients who currently smoke or have a recent history of smoking. Vitamin A (beta-carotene) is correlated with a higher risk of developing lung cancer. All of the above other vitamins and minerals should be recommended to help slow the progression of macular degeneration. AREDS I suggests the following formula for ocular vitamins: Vitamin A (beta carotene) 25,000 IU, Vitamin E 400 IU, Vitamin C 500 mg, Zinc 80 mg, Copper 2 mg. AREDS 2 is currently underway to evaluate the benefits of adding lutein and zeaxanthin along with omega III long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids to the formula. Vitamin A is also important for maintaining epithelial cells such as those found on the lens, controlling mucous production, and mediating dark adaptation.

questions.question: A deficiency of which of the following vitamins results in rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults?
questions.explanation: Vitamin D plays a large role in regulating calcium and phosphate levels within the body. A major source of Vitamin D is sunlight; however, UV exposure can increase the risk of skin cancer. UV light converts Vitamin D to its active form, allowing for greater absorption of calcium in the gut. The calcium is then deposited into the bones, teeth etc. Dietary forms of Vitamin D include butter, eggs, margarine, fish liver oil, and fortified milk and juice.

questions.question: The use of which 3 of the following medications/supplements has been associated with the development of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri)? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (also known as pseudotumor cerebri) is defined as the presence of elevated intracranial pressure in the absence of an intracranial space-occupying lesion, or enlargement of the ventricles due to hydrocephalus. Eye care professionals are often the first to identify this condition due to the development of visual symptoms resulting from papilledema. Several risk factors for this condition have been identified, with the majority of patients falling into a category of overweight women of childbearing age. Other associations include the use of several medications, most notably tetracyclines, naladixic acid, and oral contraceptives. Steroids, vitamin A, isotretinoin (Accutane®), growth hormones, sulfa drugs, tamoxifen, thyroid replacement therapy, and phenytoin have also been shown to have a correlation with this condition.

questions.question: Which of the following vitamins is also known as thiamine?
questions.explanation: Vitamin B1 is also known as thiamine. Thiamine is important for carbohydrate metabolism and the maintenance of neuronal tissue. Although rarely seen in the United States due to the fact that most foods are enriched with vitamins, a B1 deficiency can result in beriberi. Symptoms of beriberi include difficulty walking, loss of sensation in hands and feet, paralysis (due to deterioration of myelin sheath), nystagmus, speech difficulty/mental confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and congestive heart failure. Alcoholism can lead to beriberi due to malnutrition. Vitamin B2, also known as riboflavin, aids in the metabolism of nutrients. Avitaminosis B2 can result in decreased visual acuity due to corneal neovascularization, keratoconjunctivitis sicca, or cataract formation. Vitamin B3 (a.k.a. niacin) is responsible for fat and carbohydrate metabolism. A deficiency of Vitamin B3 can cause pellagra, which results in diarrhea, dementia, and dermatitis. Niacin can be used to treat hyperlipoproteinemia. Vitamin B6, also called pyridoxine, serves an important role as a coenzyme for the formation of hemoglobin as well as amino acid and protein metabolism.

questions.question: An insufficiency of which of the following vitamins will result in a mucin deficiency?
questions.explanation:
A deficiency of vitamin A also known as beta carotene will lead to a decrease in the number of goblet cells. Because goblet cells are responsible for the secretion of mucin into the tears, a smaller number of them will result in a lower concentration of mucin production. A deficiency of vitamin A also causes prolonged dark adaptation. Vitamin A is classified as a retinoid with its active form being retinol. Retinol is necessary for the formation of rhodopsin, a pigment used by rods. Rods are most active in situations with dim illumination. Less rhodopsin results in fewer rods being able to respond in low levels of light causing prolonged dark adaption. 

Vitamin D plays a significant role in regulating calcium and phosphate levels within the body. A major source of Vitamin D is sunlight, however, UV exposure can increase the risk of skin cancer. UV light converts Vitamin D to its active form allowing for greater absorption of calcium in the gut. The calcium is then deposited into the bones, teeth etc. Dietary forms of Vitamin D include; butter, eggs, margarine, fish liver oil and fortified milk and juice. 

Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid) is water-soluble and stored in white blood cells. Vitamin C is an antioxidant that serves as a co-factor in several enzymatic pathways as well as facilitating absorption of dietary iron. Vitamin C deprivation can result in scurvy. 

Avitaminosis K has been linked with increased bleeding time. Vitamin K plays an important role in mediating the synthesis of several clotting factors. Vitamin K can be found in green, leafy vegetables and in oils such as cottonseed, canola and olive. There exist many causes of avitaminosis K some of which include; malnutrition, alcoholism, parenchymal liver disease, cystic fibrosis and usage of certain drugs (antibiotics such as cephalosporins, Coumadin® and some sulfa drugs). Symptoms of Vitamin K deficiency include hemtomas (bruising), ecchymosis (swelling), and increased bleeding time at injury sites.

questions.question: Which of the following vitamins is NOT a component of the AREDS 1 formulation for macular degeneration?
questions.explanation:
The AREDS 1 (age-related eye disease study) formulation of vitamins and minerals are composed of the following preparations: 
- Vitamin C: 500mg 
- Vitamin E: 400IU 
- Beta-carotene: 15mg 
- Zinc (as zinc oxide): 80mg 
- Copper (as cupric acid): 2mg 

These components have shown a significant benefit in decreasing the risk of progression to further visual loss. 
AREDS 2 formulations include supplements of macular xanthophylls (lutein and zeaxanthin) and/or omega-3s (DHA and EPA).

questions.question: Which 4 of the following vitamins are fat-soluble? (Select 4)
questions.explanation:
Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is water-soluble and stored in white blood cells. Vitamin C is an antioxidant that serves as a cofactor in several enzymatic pathways as well as facilitating absorption of dietary iron. Vitamin C deficiency results in scurvy. 

Vitamin B6, also called Pyridoxine serves an important role as a coenzyme for the formation of hemoglobin as well as amino acid and protein metabolism. 

Vitamin B3 (also known as Niacin) is responsible for fat and carbohydrate metabolism. A deficiency of Vitamin B3 can cause Pellagra which results in diarrhea, dementia, and dermatitis. Niacin can be used to treat hyperlipoproteinemia. 

Vitamins A, D, E, and K (good way to remember: spells ADEK) are all fat-soluble.

questions.question: A deficiency of which vitamin leads to prolonged dark adaptation?
questions.explanation: A deficiency of vitamin A causes prolonged dark adaptation. Vitamin A is classified as a retinoid, and its active form is retinol. Retinol is necessary for the formation of rhodopsin, a pigment used by rods. Rods are most active in situations with dim illumination. Less rhodopsin results in fewer rods being able to respond in low levels of light, causing prolonged dark adaption.

questions.question: Which of the following topical NSAIDS must be used with caution in a person who is allergic to medications that contain sulfa?
questions.explanation: Xibrom® is preserved with BAK and sodium sulfite; therefore, people who are allergic to sulfa-based drugs can be sensitive to this medication. Ocufen® contains thimerosal as one its preservatives, which is another ingredient to which many people are sensitive. It is important to know medications as well as their preservatives because sometimes the therapeutic effect is not achieved due to sensitivity to preservatives that are contained within the medication. When in practice, although it is a daunting if not impossible task to know all medications, choose one or two from each category of drugs that provide the best therapeutic effects while minimizing unwanted side effects and know them well. When in doubt, look up the medication, its ingredients, and side effects.

questions.question: A 52-year old male is seen at your office presenting with a chief concern of distorted color vision. He reports a yellow/green tinge to his vision. Which of the following medications is MOST likely to cause this effect?
questions.explanation: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that is isolated from the foxglove plant. Lanoxin® is prescribed for heart failure and arrhythmias. Although rare, use of this medication can cause xanthopsia where objects can appear more yellow or green than they truly are. Digoxin can also cause blurry vision and the appearance of halos around bright lights.

questions.question: A 31-year old male patient presents to your office for a photorefractive keratectomy (PRK) pre-operative examination. As you review his required ocular medication schedule, which of the following prescribed drops must you remember to tell him to 'shake well' before instillation?
questions.explanation:
Pred Forte® is an ocular medication that is in suspension form; therefore, it is important to shake this medication well before use. Other forms of prednisolone that are suspensions include Pred Mild®, Econopred®, and Econopred Plus®. 

On the other hand, there are prednisolone ocular medications that are solutions, making shaking of the bottle unnecessary. These include AK-Pred®, Inflamase Mild®, and Inflamase Forte®. 

Zymaxid® is a 4th generation fluoroquinolone antibiotic that is bottled in solution form, as well as Acular®, which is an ocular non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). FreshKote® is a prescription artificial tear that also does not need to be shaken before use.

questions.question: Which of the following anti-histamines does NOT have FDA labeling as a non-sedating antihistamine?
questions.explanation: Of the above oral anti-histamines, only Zyrtec® is not considered non-sedating. Clinical trials show an incidence of sedation of 14% vs. 6% in the placebo arm. Trials with Claritin® showed an incidence of sedation of 8% with Claritin® vs. 6% in the placebo arm. Clarinex® showed a sedation incidence of 2%; Allegra's® incidence of somnolence was less than 2% in most study populations, although one pediatric study showed an incidence of 2.8%.

questions.question: In addition to extraocular muscle involvement, Kearns-Sayre syndrome can also present with which of the following ocular signs?
questions.explanation:
Kearns-Sayre syndrome is considered a mitochondrial myopathy in which mitochondrial DNA deletions result in a clinical triad of signs. These signs include ocular features such as progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO) and 'salt and pepper' pigmented retinopathy (with predilection for the macula), as well as one or more systemic complications, which can include heart block, cerebellar ataxia, or abnormally elevated cerebrospinal fluid protein. 

Electrodiagnosis of Retinal Diseases. Miyake, Y. 2006. Springer. 

The Retinal Atlas. Yannuzzi, L.A. 2010. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: You have a patient who is currently taking chloroquine for rheumatoid arthritis. You notice what appears to be early changes suggestive of retinopathy in the macular region and decide to perform an electrooculogram. If the light peak of the right eye measures 7.4 uV and the dark trough measures 4.2 uV, what is the Arden ratio, and what can you conclude from this finding?
questions.explanation:
An electrooculogram uses the electrically positive cornea and electrically negative back of the eye to measure the standing potential between the two regions. The readings reflect the activity and integrity of the photoreceptors and retinal pigmented epithelium; therefore, retinal diseases that affect this area will lead to a reduction in the signal produced. The test is performed in both light and dark adapted states. Interpretation of the results involves measuring the maximal height of the potential in the light and minimal height of the potential in the dark. The Arden ratio can then be calculated by dividing the light peak value by the dark trough value. Normal values are above 1.85. 

For the above case, the light peak is 7.4 and dark trough is 4.2. 
7.4/4.2 = 1.76 
1.76 is below 1.85; therefore the ratio may be considered abnormal.

questions.question: At which location of the retina is the peak density of rod photoreceptors located?
questions.explanation: In the human fovea there are no rod photoreceptors present; cones are the only photoreceptors in this area, and they are perfectly arranged in a hexagonal mosaic pattern. Outside of the foveal region, the rod photoreceptors are introduced, breaking up this tight hexagonal cone packing. However, this architecture is still very organized, as cones are rather evenly spaced around the rods. Cone density rapidly falls outside of the fovea and remains at a steady density in the peripheral retina. As the cone density rapidly declines, the rod photoreceptor density quickly increases to a peak density in a ring around the fovea (also known as the 'rod ring'). This is located about 4.5mm from the center of the fovea (or 18 degrees from the foveal pit).

questions.question: How many photons are necessary to stimulate a rod cell?
questions.explanation: One photon is all that is required to stimulate a rod cell. The photon is absorbed by rhodopsin located in the disc membrane of the outer segment causing a cascade of events. However, in order for a stimulus to be detected, around 10 photons must be experienced. This is can occur either by spatial summation or by temporal summation.

questions.question: Your 68 year-old male patient presents with an idiopathic macular hole in his left eye. He asks what the chances are that a macular hole will also develop in his right eye. What percentage of patients typically develops a macular hole in their fellow eye as well?
questions.explanation:
The following represents the most common profile of a patient presenting with a macular hole: 
- Most commonly idiopathic in otherwise healthy individuals 
- Typically occur in the 6th or 7th decade of life 
- Women are more affected than men (2:1) 
- 10-20% of patients develop bilateral macular holes

questions.question: In approximately what percentage of patients presenting with a stage 1 macular hole will the hole spontaneously resolve without treatment?
questions.explanation:
Approximately 50% of stage 1 macular holes will resolve following spontaneous vitreomacular separation with resolution of symptoms, and are therefore observed and not treated surgically. 
Stage 1 macular hole summary: 
- Patient is typically asymptomatic with both eyes open (difficult to detect and diagnose), but when symptoms are present, patients usually note decreased acuity and/or distorted vision 
- Also known as pre macular holes, macular cysts, or involutional macular thinning 
- In this stage, no true neuroretinal defect is present, and the photoreceptor layer appears to be intact 
- There is further division of stage 1 macular holes into stage 1a, during which there is a small central yellow spot that can be observed on ophthalmoscopy and flattening of the macular contour, and stage 1b, wherein a yellow ring can be seen in the foveal area

questions.question: On average, what is the life cycle of photoreceptor discs?
questions.explanation: Photoreceptor disc production begins in the cell body. The rough endoplasmic reticulum produces proteins which are then packaged by the Golgi apparatus. This complex then moves up through the inner segment to the base of the outer segment. The discs become free-floating in rod cells. The discs move up slowly until they are shed and phagocytized by the retinal epithelial pigment cells. On average, rods shed about 10% of their discs per day. Rods tend to shed their discs during the day while cones get rid of their discs at night.

questions.question: The proliferation of retinal pigmented epithelial cells that can be found at the junction of flat and detached retina typically indicates stability for which of the following minimum periods of time?
questions.explanation: The presence of a pigmented demarcation line at the junction of flat and detached retina in cases of a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (along with other features) can aid in determining the length of time the retinal detachment has been present. These demarcation lines (also known as 'high water marks') occur due to the proliferation of retinal pigment epithelial cells and commonly take about 3 months to develop. Their configuration is usually convex with respect to the ora serrata and represents sites of increased adhesion. With time, the demarcation line tends to lose its pigment and can be less obvious upon fundus examination.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the location of the fovea with respect to the center optic disc?
questions.explanation:
The macula is a circular area that is approximately 5-6mm in diameter, centered at the fovea, which itself is about 1.5 to 2.0mm in size. Anatomically, the macula is defined as the region of the retina in which there are 2 or more layers of ganglion cells present; the fovea rests at the center of this area. The fovea is considered to lie approximately 4mm temporally and 0.8mm inferiorly to the center of the optic disc. 

Age-Related Macular Degeneration: Current Treatment Concepts. Alberti, W.E., Richard, G., Sagerman, R.H. 2001. Springer. New York, NY.

questions.question: What is the approximate volume of the vitreous?
questions.explanation: The vitreous weighs approximately 4.0 grams and has a volume of roughly 4.0 ml. The essentially clear, gel-like fluid occupies about 2/3 of the bulk of the eye.

questions.question: Which of the following wavelengths of visible light has an increased association with the development of macular degeneration?
questions.explanation: Recent studies have demonstrated a correlation between blue-violet light that lies within the range of 415nm-455nm and the development of macular degeneration. Excessive exposure to light that falls within this bandwidth is associated with death of the retinal pigment epithelial cells. However, blue-turquoise light (465-495nm) does not appear to possess detrimental effects to ocular health. Blue-turquoise light is important in activation of the pupillary reflex as well as management of the circadian sleep/wake cycle. There is increasing evidence that compact fluorescent lamps, LED lights as well as sunlight all transmit blue-violet light, which over time may be linked with retinal damage.

questions.question: What is the membrane potential of a photoreceptor in the dark?
questions.explanation:
In the darkness the membrane potential of a photoreceptor is around -40 mV. Some texts quote that the resting potential of an unstimulated photoreceptor cell is -20 mV, others state -50 mV whereas others quote -40 mV. Regardless of the value, the important thing to note is that normal cells have resting potentials of around -70 mV which is more negative than photoreceptors. This fact is attributable to the dark current which makes a photoreceptor's resting potential slightly more positive. 
Reference: Dowling, J. Neurons and Networks: An Introduction to Behavioral Neuroscience. 2001 pages 172-174.

questions.question: The average human eye contains roughly how many rod photoreceptors?
questions.explanation: The average human eye houses approximately 120 million rods per eye, whereas it is thought there are roughly 7 million cones per eye; some research has suggested that there are actually only around 4-5 million cones per eye.

questions.question: Roughly how many ganglion cells are present in a human retina?
questions.explanation: There are approximately 1.2 million ganglion cells per eye. It is the axons of these cells that are at risk from glaucomatous damage. The ganglion cells are extremely important as they conduct information from the eye. The axons of the ganglion cells form the retinal nerve fiber layer. Ganglion cells receive information from bipolar and amacrine cells. On average, a ganglion cell will receive information from 4-6 cones while for rods the ratio is one ganglion cell to 100 rod cells.

questions.question: During assessment of the retina via binocular indirect ophthalmoscopy (BIO), you notice that there is a large circular area of pigmentation. How will you be able to discern whether the pigmentation is located at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) or the choroid?
options: A choroidal lesion will disappear or become more difficult to visualize with a red-free filter
The overlying vasculature of the lesion will appear displaced inferiorly for a choroidal lesion
If it is located at the level of the choroid, its borders will appear well-defined
Lesions located in the region of the retinal pigment epithelium are always larger
answers: A choroidal lesion will disappear or become more difficult to visualize with a red-free filter
questions.explanation:
A red-free filter is useful in determining which layer of the eye is affected. A red-free filter will cause a lesion of the RPE to appear darker and more defined, while a choroidal pigmentation will either become more difficult to visualize or disappear. Also, choroidal lesions tend to appear more grey/green, with borders that are more indistinct than those located at the level of the RPE.
PowerPage
Choroidal Anatomy

questions.question: Your patient has undergone extensive panretinal photocoagulation (PRP) for management of their retinopathy associated with poorly controlled diabetes. What type of visual changes do you expect post-treatment?
options: An increase of the photopic b wave amplitude on electroretinogram (ERG) testing
questions.explanation: PRP may cause decreased peripheral vision and poor night vision because, depending on the extent of the treatment, photoreceptors (rods) in the mid-peripheral and para-central retina are destroyed. The patient may also experience a tritanopic (blue/yellow) color defect. This decrease in color vision has previously occurred to a much greater extent, as the argon laser used to treat the retina was composed of both short and medium wavelengths. The shorter wavelength is capable of causing greater damage, and is currently filtered during the procedure of PRP. ERG testing of a patient with proliferative diabetic retinopathy reveals a decrease in the amplitudes of the photopic and scotopic b waves.

questions.question: A 40-year old patient presents at your office for a retinal exam. You note that all findings are normal except for posterior bilateral staphylomas and a Fuch's spot of the right eye. What retinal disease does this patient most likely have?
questions.explanation:
Posterior staphylomas and Fuch's spots are commonly seen in degenerative myopia. 
Posterior staphylomas are excavations/dips around the optic nerve or in the retina, secondary to a bulging of weakened sclera posteriorly. Fuch's spots are areas of focal hyperpigmentation secondary to old sub-retinal hemorrhages or choroidal neovascular membranes.

questions.question: Retinopathy of prematurity is a developmental disorder of the retina that occurs due to exposure to which of the following in premature infants?
questions.explanation:
Retinopathy of prematurity (also known as retrolental fibroplasia) occurs when premature infants are exposed to high oxygen concentrations which cause vasoconstriction of immature peripheral retinal blood vessels. Subsequent removal of oxygen leads to a hypoxic state in the retinal periphery and subsequent proliferation of new blood vessels that have poor endothelial junctions and are leaky. This in turn leads to neovascular invasion into the vitreous, development of vitreoretinal adhesions, and subsequent hemorrhage and retinal detachment. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 p 113

questions.question: Which 2 of the following represent the main components of the vitreous body? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
Besides water (which comprises 98% of the vitreous), the two major components of the vitreous body are collagen and hyaluronic acid. The network of collagen fibrils (mostly type II) are stabilized by the hyaluronic acid due to its hydrophilic properties, keeping the collagen fibers separated by a distance that is far enough to minimize the scattering of light while also maintaining vitreous transparency. 

Medical Retina: Focus on Retinal Imaging. Holz, F.G., Spaide, R.F. 2010. Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg

questions.question: The outer nuclear layer contains the nuclei of which cell type?
questions.explanation: The outer nuclear layer contains the nuclei of the photoreceptors (rods and cones). The cell bodies of the ganglion cells are found in the ganglion cell layer. The inner nuclear layer contains the nuclei of the bipolar, amacrine and horizontal cells. When in doubt read the name of the layer-it will help you to deduce which layer corresponds with which cell (a study 'pearl'-remember, the outer nuclear layer is the most external of the two nuclear layers and because the name contains the word 'nuclear' it will contain nuclei). The photoreceptors are located more externally than the other cells hence these cell bodies will be located in the outer nuclear layer. Try to break things down a little bit when memorizing layers to help keep things in order, generally the names of things will give you a tip about their functions.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following types of retinal cells undergo a GRADED potential (vs. an action potential)? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
Certain cells of the retina, including bipolar cells, horizontal cells, and photoreceptor cells (rods and cones) do not generate action potentials like most of the rest of the neurons of the human body. Neurological signaling in these types of cells occurs via graded changes in their membrane potential. Graded action potentials allow a greater number of distinct signal amplitudes as compared to single large spikes. This is in contrast to the amacrine and ganglion cells of the retina, both of which produce action potentials. 

Voltage-Gated Calcium Channels. Zamponi, G. 2005. Kluwer Academic / Plenar Publishers. New York, NY. 

On Modeling the Spatiotemporal Processing Characteristics of the Retina: What is the Retina for? Wulf, M. 2001.

questions.question: A patient with high myopia undergoes electroretinogram (ERG) testing. Which of the following results is MOST likely to be observed?
options: An abnormal a-and b-wave amplitude ratio
questions.explanation:
Research has demonstrated that patients with high myopia display a decrease in the amplitude of the b-wave when performing ERG testing. The decrease in amplitude of the b-wave becomes more pronounced as the degree of myopia increases and appears to have an inverse relationship with axial length. The amplitude of the b-wave is adversely affected in patients with chorioretinal degeneration associated with high myopia. Patients with mild-to-moderate myopia do not appear to manifest a decreased b-wave amplitude when compared to emmetropic eyes. Patients with high myopia display decreased S, L and M cone b-wave amplitudes. 

Principles and Practice of Clinical Electrophysiology of Vision 2nd edition. Nusinowitz, S., Holder, G. & Bach, M. Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 2006, page 631. 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3729644/

questions.question: Which 3 of the following statements BEST represent the phenomena responsible for the dark appearance of the fovea during fluorescein angiography imaging? (Select 3)
options: An increased density of carotenes in the foveal region
The retinal pigment epithelial cells in the foveal region are larger and contain more melanin
An increased density of xanthophyll in the foveal region
The retinal pigment epithelial cells in the foveal region are smaller and more densely packed
The absence of choroidal blood vessels in the center of the fovea
The absence of retinal blood vessels in the center of the fovea
answers: The retinal pigment epithelial cells in the foveal region are larger and contain more melanin
An increased density of xanthophyll in the foveal region
The absence of retinal blood vessels in the center of the fovea
questions.explanation:
In a normal fluorescein angiography image, the dark appearance of the fovea occurs as a result of three phenomena. 
- The center of the fovea does not contain retinal blood vessels (foveal avascular zone) 
- The choroid below the fovea does contain a network of blood vessels that fills with fluorescein in the early phase; however, there is blockage of this background choroidal fluorescence due to the increased density of xanthophyll in the foveal region 
- Additionally, background choroidal fluorescence is blocked due to the retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells in the fovea, which contain more melanin and are larger than RPE cells elsewhere in the retina

questions.question: Which of the following structures is NOT found in cones?
options: Free-floating discs in the outer segment
answers: Free-floating discs in the outer segment
questions.explanation: Cones and rods possess outer segments which consist of stacks of disc-like structures containing photopigment however, the discs of cones are not free-floating. The discs of cones remain attached as they migrate outwards. It was previously thought that only rods possessed a cilium but this has been proven to be inaccurate. Both rods and cones possess ciliary processes, inner segments, mitochondria and synaptic terminals. The synaptic terminals of rods differ in their morphology from cones in that they are slightly smaller and rounder and are called spherules while cones display a larger and flatter terminal called a pedicle.

questions.question: Which of the following 3 conditions are associated with a higher incidence of developing a posterior vitreal detachment? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: Syneresis and liquification of the vitreous are part of the normal aging process, but they also may cause a posterior vitreal detachment (PVD). PVDs can occur earlier in one's life if something speeds up the process of vitreal aging. These conditions may include myopia, trauma, diabetes, intraocular surgery, intraocular inflammation, and vitreal hemorrhages.

questions.question: Intraocular inflammation that predominantly involves the vitreous is known as which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
The term 'uveitis' is a non-specific diagnosis that only implies that a patient has inflammation of the uveal tract. There are several sub-categories of uveitis that provide a more specific diagnosis based on the location of the inflammation within the eye (as described below). 
- Anterior uveitis: inflammation involving the anterior segment 
- Iritis: primarily involving the iris 
- Iridocyclitis: involves both the iris and ciliary body 
- Intermediate uveitis: inflammation predominantly involving the vitreous 
- Posterior uveitis: inflammation of the fundus, posterior to the vitreous base 
- Retinitis: inflammation of the retina 
- Choroiditis: inflammation with primary focus in the choroid 
- Vasculitis: inflammation involving veins, arteries, or both 
- Panuveitis: inflammation of the entire uveal tract (no specific site) 
- Endophthalmitis: inflammation involving all tissues of the eye (except the sclera) 
- Panophthalmitis: inflammation of the entire globe

questions.question: The phenomenon, sometimes called tobacco dust, in which pigment is visible in the vitreal chamber and is fairly pathognomonic for a retinal tear is known as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Schafer's sign occurs when there is a release of pigment into the vitreal chamber. The excessive pigment may be noted by the patient as a sudden increase in floaters. This sign usually indicates the presence of a retinal tear because a break in the retina may release retinal pigment epithelium. Pigment in the vitreal chamber may also be associated with a posterior uveitis or trauma or can occur secondary to intraocular surgery. It is of vital importance when a patient enters your clinic complaining of a recent increase in floaters, especially monocularly, or if you visualize pigment in the vitreous, that you rule out a retinal tear. Remember, many patients who suffer from a retinal tear are asymptomatic. 

The ascension phenomenon describes the ability of the practitioner to better visualize vitreal cells or other suspended granules by asking the patient to move their eyes rapidly and then upon stabilization, using the slit lamp, the doctor waits and watches for cells or other details to move across the viewing beam. 

Photopsias are flashes of light that may be perceived by the patient during periods of retinal traction. 

Cloquet's canal is comprised of the primary vitreous, which develops from weeks 3 through 9. The secondary vitreous then begins to form and condenses the primary vitreous, producing Cloquet's canal.

questions.question: The circulatory system of the retina is capable of autoregulation. This property is attributable to which cell?
questions.explanation:
Pericytes are smooth muscle cells that are generally adhered to small blood vessels. They are found at the junction between arterioles and capillaries. Their muscle action alters the flow of blood through the retina's microcirculation. Pericytes are not found in the choroid. 

In poorly controlled diabetics, the pericytes become damaged causing leakage through the microvasculature as seen in diabetic retinopathy. 

Glial cells are non-neuronal cells that serve several functions, depending on the type of glial cell. On the whole, glial cells are responsible for structural and nutritional support as well as insulating and protecting neurons. 

Astrocytes are a type of glial cell that serve many functions including the potential to regulate blood flow, metabolic support, structural support of the neural cells and formation of the blood-brain barrier. 

Schwann cells are also a type of glial cell. These cells are primarily responsible for the production of the myelin sheath in the peripheral nervous system.

questions.question: Which of the following retinal findings is NOT characteristic of a diagnosis of severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy?
options: At least 2 quadrants containing cotton wool spots
At least 1 quadrant of prominent intraretinal microvascular abnormalities
At least 20 intraretinal hemorrhages in each quadrant
At least 2 quadrants of venous beading
answers: At least 2 quadrants containing cotton wool spots
questions.explanation:
A diagnosis of severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) includes the presence of any of the following retinal observations in the absence of proliferative retinopathy: 
- 20 intraretinal hemorrhages in each quadrant 
- 2 quadrants of venous beading 
- 1 quadrant of prominent intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) 

The presence of cotton wool spots is a characteristic feature of diabetic retinopathy but is not involved in the classification of severity of the NPDR.
PowerPage
Diabetic Retinopathy

questions.question: Which 3 of the following retinal findings are known as 'high risk' characteristics for patients diagnosed with proliferative diabetic retinopathy? (Select 3)
options: At least one quadrant of intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
Neovascularization elsewhere (NVE) with a size greater than one half of the disc area when associated with a preretinal or vitreous hemorrhage
Any retinal edema within 500 microns of the center of the fovea
Retinal edema greater than 1 disc area in size and within 1 disc diameter of the center of the fovea
Neovascularization within 1 disc diameter of the optic disc (NVD) with a size greater than 1/4 to 1/3 of the disc area
Any degree of neovascularization of the optic disc (NVD) with an associated preretinal or vitreous hemorrhage
answers: Neovascularization elsewhere (NVE) with a size greater than one half of the disc area when associated with a preretinal or vitreous hemorrhage
Neovascularization within 1 disc diameter of the optic disc (NVD) with a size greater than 1/4 to 1/3 of the disc area
Any degree of neovascularization of the optic disc (NVD) with an associated preretinal or vitreous hemorrhage
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis of high-risk proliferative diabetic retinopathy involves the presence of at least one of the following observations: 
- Neovascularization of the optic disc (NVD) that occurs within 1 disc diameter of the nerve, and with a size greater than 1/4 to 1/3 of the optic disc 
- Any degree of NVD if an associated preretinal or vitreous hemorrhage is also present 
- Neovascularization elsewhere (NVE) greater than 1/2 the size of the optic disc when associated with a preretinal or vitreous hemorrhage 

The above criteria are used to determine if panretinal laser photocoagulation is indicated to prevent further vision loss.
PowerPage
Diabetic Retinopathy

questions.question: Which of the following is the MOST common ocular manifestation seen in patients with AIDS syndrome?
questions.explanation: Cotton wool spots are seen in AIDS retinopathy. It has been described in up to 50% of patients and represents immune complex thrombi that close the blood vessel, causing a nerve layer infarction. It is also notable that cytomegalovirus retinitis is extremely common in patients with AIDS. Less likely, but also potentially causing retinal changes in patients who suffer from AIDS, are toxoplasmosis and syphilitic retinitis. As the disease progresses a severe retinitis usually develops that significantly reduces vision. Fortunately, the incidence of severe end-stage CMV retinitis is now rare due to the availability of anti-retroviral cocktails used in the treatment of the disease.

questions.question: Sub-retinal hemorrhages occur at what level of the retina?
options: Between the internal limiting membrane and the nerve fiber layer
Between the inner and outer nuclear layers
Between the retinal pigment epithelium and the sensory retina
Between the retinal pigment epithelium and the choroid
answers: Between the retinal pigment epithelium and the sensory retina
questions.explanation:
Sub-retinal hemorrhages appear red, can vary in size, and are often very difficult to distinguish from sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) hemorrhages (which appear more gray/green). Sub-RPE hemorrhages occur between the RPE and the choroid. Pre-retinal hemorrhages occur between the internal limiting membrane and the nerve fiber layer. In general, the darker the blood, the more likely that it stems from a vein-based congestive disease, while hemorrhages that are superficial tend to be artery-based.
PowerPage
Retinal Anatomy

questions.question: Which of the following ocular conditions is NOT considered a 'white dot syndrome?'
options: Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy (APMPPE)
questions.explanation:
White dot syndromes (also known as primary idiopathic inflammatory choriocapillaropathies) are ocular inflammatory conditions that are characterized by the presence of white dots on the fundus. The most common visual symptoms of patients presenting with these diseases include blurred vision and visual field loss. The exact etiology of these ocular conditions is unknown; however, some investigators believe there to be a connection with bacterial and viral infections, genetic predispositions, and/or autoimmune associations. Classically recognized white dot syndromes include: acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy (APMPPE), birdshot retinochoroidopathy, multiple evanescent white dot syndrome (MEWDS), serpiginous choroiditis, punctate inner choroidopathy (PIC), and multifocal choroiditis with panuveitis (MCP). 

Polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy is an idiopathic choroidal vascular disease that is characterized by a dilated network of choroidal blood vessels that have multiple terminal aneurysmal protuberances (in a polypoidal appearing fashion). This condition is not considered a 'white dot syndrome.'

questions.question: Which 2 of the following newborn characteristics are considered the PRIMARY risk factors for the development of retinopathy of prematurity? (Select 2)
options: Gestational age of less than 28 weeks
questions.explanation:
The two primary risk factors for development of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) are low birth weight (newborns weighing less than 1500g) and prematurity (babies born less than 32 weeks gestation). 
- Some degree of ROP can be observed in 25-30% of infants weighing less than 1500g 
- 65% of infants weighing less than 1250g at birth 
- Of the two, low birth weight is the greatest risk factor 
- Other risk factors occur at a lower rate, including intraventricular hemorrhage, respiratory distress syndrome, sepsis, and sleep apnea 

It is for these reasons that all newborns that fall under the category of 'higher risk' of retinopathy undergo a thorough retinal examination as soon as possible. This screening should include indirect ophthalmoscopy or wide-field retinal imaging beginning at 4-7 weeks of age with subsequent review at 1-2 week intervals until the retinal vascularization reaches the temporal periphery.

questions.question: The choriocapillaris is separated from the retina by a thin membrane. What is the name of this membrane?
questions.explanation:
Bruch's membrane lies between the choriocapillaris of the choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium of the retina. Although this membrane is very thin (about 2 microns thick) it is very complex. The membrane consists of five facets. The outermost component is the basement membrane of the choriocapillaris followed by the outer collagenous zone, the elastic layer, the inner collagenous zone and most internally the basement membrane of the retinal pigment epithelium. 

Sattler's membrane is actually a layer of vessels in the choroid located externally to choriocapillaris. 

Bowman's and Descemet's membranes are found in the cornea.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT considered an increased risk factor for the development of a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment?
questions.explanation: Patients may possess certain characteristics that can represent an increased risk for the development of a retinal detachment, including a history cataract surgery, myopia, family history, and the presence of certain systemic diseases. Cataract surgery is known to increase the risk for developing a retinal detachment, especially if any complications occur. Patients who are myopic are also more prone to a retinal detachment, with the higher degree of myopia, the higher the risk factor. Family history is also relevant in that there may be certain genetic factors that promote inflammation and photoreceptor degeneration, which can lead to an increased risk of a retinal detachment. Additionally, systemic diseases such as Marfan syndrome, Stickler syndrome, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome have been associated with an increased risk of retinal detachments.

questions.question: Which of the following retinal conditions can lead to the development of neovascular glaucoma during the period of 2-4 months following the onset of disease?
questions.explanation: Patients diagnosed with ischemic central retinal vein occlusion have a very poor long-term prognosis of restoration of vision due to the development of macular ischemia and the possibility of neovascular glaucoma. In about 50% of patients with this condition, rubeosis iridis can present in the 2-4 month period following the diagnosis (this is known as 90-day or 100-day glaucoma). If extensive treatment with panretinal laser photocoagulation is not performed immediately, there is a very high risk of conversion to neovascular glaucoma, which can be both painful and devastating to vision. Therefore, it is extremely important to closely monitor these patients, including careful examination of the iris and gonioscopy, in the months following a central retinal vein occlusion, such that prompt and proper treatment can be initiated if and when necessary.

questions.question: The photoreceptors and the retinal pigment epithelium receive their blood supply directly from what source?
questions.explanation:
The photoreceptors and the retinal pigment epithelium receives their blood supply from the long posterior ciliaries, anterior ciliaries and short posterior ciliaries of the choroid. 

The central retinal artery supplies the nerve fiber layer, the ganglion cell layer, the inner plexiform layer, the inner nuclear layer, and potentially a small portion of the outer plexiform layer.

questions.question: You decide to perform fluorescein angiography on a patient with decreased vision and central metamorphopsia in his left eye. Results show a 'smoke-stack' appearance in which fluorescein enters the subretinal space, ascends vertically, then spreads laterally. Which of the following retinal conditions is your patient MOST likely suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Fluorescein angiography studies of patients with central serous retinopathy typically reveal a classic 'smoke-stack' presentation. This appearance is a result of leakage of fluorescein dye through the retinal pigment epithelium, which causes a small hyperfluorescent spot in the early stage of angiography. During the later venous stage, dye will continue to pass into the subretinal space, where it ascends vertically to the upper limit of the detachment before extending laterally until the entire subretinal space is filled with fluorescein. 

Patients with cystoid macular edema will reveal a 'flower-petal' pattern of hyperfluorescence on fluorescein angiography studies. This is caused by the accumulation of the fluorescein dye inside the microcystic spaces that have developed within the retina. 

Classic choroidal neovascular membranes will show a well-defined membrane that fills with fluorescein in the early phase, creating a lacy appearance. The dye will then eventually leak after 1-2 minutes into the subretinal space surrounding the neovascular membrane.

questions.question: Which of the following vascular events describes the MOST common etiology of a central retinal artery occlusion?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of a central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is atherosclerosis-related thrombus formation at the level of the lamina cribrosa. This etiology accounts for close to 80% of all cases. The presence and severity of atherosclerosis increases with age and is accelerated by hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, obesity, smoking, and a sedentary lifestyle. Vascular changes that are characteristic of atherosclerotic disease include focal arterial wall thickening (as a result of the accumulation of lipid-containing foam cells) and increased thickness of smooth muscle and collagen layers. These features can eventually completely impede the flow of blood through the artery, leading to ischemia of the tissue it supplies. 

Other more common causes of an artery occlusion include cholesterol emboli (Hollenhorst plaques); however, these are often located in the area of smaller arteriole bifurcations and rarely cause significant obstruction of retinal arterioles. Fibrin-platelet emboli appear as dull, grey, elongated particles that may occasionally fill the entire lumen of a retinal artery. They are a common cause of transient ischemic attacks, in which vision loss usually only lasts a couple of minutes and rarely cause a complete obstruction of the central retinal artery. The most dangerous type of embolus is a calcific emboli, which typically originates from atheromatous plaques, or calcified heart valves. These plaques are more likely to cause permanent occlusion of the central retinal artery or one of its branches. 

Other less common causes of retinal arterial occlusive disease are giant cell arteritis, cardiac embolism, periarteritis nodosa, thrombophilic disorders, and sickling hemoglobinopathies.

questions.question: The small, white, vitreal refractile bodies associated with asteroid hyalosis are composed primarily of which substance?
questions.explanation: Asteroid hyalosis is generally a unilateral condition that presents as hundreds of small white calcium soap deposits suspended in the vitreous. The calcium soaps are attached to the collagen in the vitreous; this is the reason that they do not fall to the bottom of the globe. Surprisingly enough, these deposits rarely affect visual acuity!

questions.question: Which of the following layers of the choroid contains blood vessels with the largest diameter?
questions.explanation:
The choroid is a highly vascularized layer that lies between the retina and sclera. It is comprised of a network of blood vessels that supply the outer layers of the retina with essential nutrients and oxygen. The choroid can be divided into 5 layers (anterior to posterior): Bruch's membrane, choriocapillaris, Sattler's layer, Haller's layer, and suprachoroid. The largest diameter blood vessels of the choroid lie within Haller's layer; medium diameter vessels are present within Sattler's layer. The choriocapillaris is a single layer of fenestrated capillaries that have the smallest diameter. 

Fluorescein and ICG Angiography Textbook and Atlas. Richard, G., Soubrane, G., Yannuzzi, L.A. 1998. Georg Thieme Verlag. New York, NY.

questions.question: What is the MOST common cause of persistent decreased visual acuity following a branch retinal vein occlusion?
questions.explanation:
The development of chronic macular edema following a branch retinal vein occlusion is the most common cause of persistent decreased visual acuity. In some cases, patients may benefit from laser photocoagulation procedures; however, this is typically unsuccessful in cases where the macula is significantly ischemic. 

Neovascularization of the disc and retina can also occur following a branch retinal vein occlusion, typically presenting at the border of the ischemic retina drained by the occluded retinal vein. Neovascularization can be a serious complication if it leads to recurrent vitreous or pre-retinal hemorrhages; in some cases, a tractional retinal detachment can develop.

questions.question: The primary component of the vitreous is composed of which of the following elements?
questions.explanation: The vitreous humor is a thick gel-like substance that fills the vitreous cavity, which constitutes about 60% of the globe. The vitreous contains elements that are important for retinal health. The ionic composition of the vitreous includes oxygen, water, sodium, potassium, chloride, phosphate, glucose and proteins (although the blood-vitreal barrier blocks the majority of proteins from getting into the vitreous). The vitreous composition is roughly 99% water.

questions.question: Which of the following special tests will appear unremarkable in a patient with retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.explanation:
Patients diagnosed with retinitis pigmentosa (RP) will demonstrate a normal response on color vision testing due to the fact that this retinal disease preferentially affects the rod photoreceptors; the cones are typically left intact for the most part. Therefore, color vision is usually spared. 

In early stages of RP, electroretinography testing will reveal both reduced scotopic rod and combined responses. As the disease progresses, photopic responses will also become reduced; eventually, the ERG will become completely extinguished. 

Electrooculography testing also produces an abnormal response in which there is an absence of the light rise. 

Dark adaptometry studies in patients with RP will reveal prolonged dark adaptation: this can be helpful in early diagnosis of the condition if the diagnosis is uncertain. 

Classic visual field defects in patients with RP demonstrates an annular scotoma in the mid-periphery in the early stages that eventually expands both centrally and peripherally. Eventually, a tiny island of central vision may be all that is spared, and in severe cases, this may also become extinguished.

questions.question: Which of the following components of the AREDS I ocular vitamin formula used for dry age-related macular degeneration is contraindicated in smokers?
questions.explanation: Based upon research, there may be a link between increased risk of lung cancer and beta-carotene supplementation when used with smokers.

questions.question: Which of the following retinal findings qualifies as proliferative diabetic retinopathy?
questions.explanation:
Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) is divided into three categories: mild NPDR, moderate NPDR, and severe NPDR. Mild NDPR is associated with hard exudates (away from the macular region), microaneurysms, and isolated dot/blot hemorrhages. Moderate NPDR occurs when there is a greater degree of ischemia and vascular leakage, which manifests as an increase in the number of hemorrhages, venous beading/tortuosity, or cotton wool spots, and/or the presence of intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA). Severe NPDR is a worsening of moderate NPDR, with dot/blot hemorrhages and microaneurysms seen in all four quadrants of the eye, in addition to venous beading in at least two quadrants, and IRMA in at least one quadrant. 

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy occurs with pre-retinal new blood vessel growth and proliferation. Neovascularization may be evaluated at the optic nerve (neovascularization of the disc), greater than 1 disc diameter away from the disc (neovascularization elsewhere), and/or new blood vessel growth at the iris (rubeosis iridis). PDR is also associated with large pre-retinal hemorrhages (keel or boat-shaped) and proliferation of fibrovascular tissue that may lead to retinal detachments upon contraction. 

Reference: Wolf, S., Kirchhof, B. and Reim, M. The Ocular Fundus; From Findings to Diagnosis. (2006) pp. 140-143.
PowerPage
Diabetic Retinopathy

questions.question: How do photoreceptors signal the presence of light?
questions.explanation: When enough photons of light are absorbed, a series of events occur, leading to a closure of sodium channels in the outer segments of the photoreceptors. Ultimately, this results in hyperpolarization of the photoreceptor's membrane. The membrane potential changes from -40 mV in the dark to -60 mV in response to light. Some texts quote that the resting potential of an unstimulated photoreceptor cell is -20 mV; others state -50 mV, whereas others quote -40 mV. Regardless of the value, the important thing to note is that normal cells have resting potentials of around -70 mV which is more negative than that of photoreceptors. This fact is attributable to the dark current which make photoreceptor's resting potential slightly more positive.

questions.question: What is the name of the additional retinal layer that many nocturnal vertebrate animals posses that functions to enhance visual sensitivity at low light levels?
questions.explanation: The tapetum lucidum, commonly found in nocturnal vertebrate animals (not present in humans or swine), is an additional retinal layer that has a highly reflective, iridescent appearance. The function of this layer is to reflect light back onto the retina in the exact same path that it was originally oriented. As light passes the rod and cone photoreceptors, it reflects off of the tapetum lucidum, which then allows the light to pass through the photoreceptors yet again. This effectively amplifies the light several fold, significantly enhancing visual sensitivity during low light conditions. This layer is what causes an animal's eyes to shine or glow in the dark.

questions.question: Shining a small spot of light onto the center of the receptive field of a retinal ganglion cell results in an increased frequency of action potentials; however, increasing the size of the light causes a decrease in the frequency of action potentials. Why does this occur?
options: Due to the fact that ganglion cells have receptive fields that are center-surround
The retinal dark current, if overly exposed, results in spatial antagonism by cone cells
Because activation of rods causes the inhibition of ganglion cells
Rhodopsin responds preferentially to small sources of light allowing for high spatial resolution
answers: Due to the fact that ganglion cells have receptive fields that are center-surround
questions.explanation: The majority of ganglion cells possess center-surround receptive fields and therefore exhibit lateral inhibition. This property serves to increase spatial resolution. The receptive fields can be either center on or center off. The receptive field appears like a donut, with the center being excited by light and the surrounding annulus inhibited by light or vice versa. Increasing the size of the stimulus causes summation of both parts of the receptive fields, resulting in a greater reduction in the frequency of action potentials than if the center were to be stimulated alone.

questions.question: Which of the following factors represents the GREATEST risk for the development of diabetic retinopathy?
questions.explanation:
When it comes to the development of diabetic retinopathy, the most important risk factor is the duration of diabetes. Studies have shown that diabetic retinopathy rarely manifests within the first 5 years of onset of the disease. In patients diagnosed prior to the age of 30, there is a 50% incidence of diabetic retinopathy after 10 years, and a 90% occurrence rate after 30 years. Additionally, the duration of diabetes is also the strongest predictor for diabetic maculopathy and proliferative diabetic retinopathy. 

Another very important risk factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy is metabolic control of the disease. It has been shown that early and tight control of blood glucose levels can delay or even prevent development or progression of the condition, while elevated serum glucose levels are associated with an increased risk of diabetic retinopathy. 

Other factors include pregnancy, hypertension, nephropathy, obesity, hyperlipidemia, and anemia.
PowerPage
Diabetic Retinopathy

questions.question: Which of the following systemic diseases are MOST commonly associated with the presence of angioid streaks observed in the retina?
questions.explanation:
Approximately 50% of patients who present with angioid streaks have an associated systemic disease; the other 50% of cases are considered idiopathic. Pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE) is by far the most commonly associated systemic disease in these patients. In general, PXE is a rather uncommon, inherited, generalized connective tissue disorder whereby tissues in the body containing elastin are significantly affected. Up to 85% of patients with PXE will develop ocular complications, usually after the second decade of life. The combination of PXE and ocular involvement with angioid streaks is referred to as 'Gronblad-Strandberg syndrome.' Patients with PXE typically have characteristic signs of very loose skin folds and yellow skin papules that are commonly observed in the neck region, axillae, and on flexor aspects of joints. These patients also frequently suffer from cardiovascular disease caused by accelerated atherosclerosis and have an increased risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeds, which can be life-threatening. 

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is another systemic condition that is occasionally associated with the presence of angioid streaks. It is a rare, usually dominantly inherited disorder of collagen in the body that is caused by a deficiency of hydroxylysine. Systemic features include thin, hyperelastic skin, hyperextensible joints, cardiovascular disease, and other systemic lesions. Besides angioid streaks, patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can also develop other ocular conditions such as lens subluxation, blue sclera, high myopia, keratoconus and retinal detachments. 

Angioid streaks also occur in about 2-10% of patients diagnosed with Paget disease. Paget disease is a chronic, progressive (inherited in some cases) disease that is characterized by an enlarged skull, bone pain, frequent bone fractures, hearing loss, and cardiovascular complications. The disease may be localized to a few bones or may be generalized. In some cases, patients are even asymptomatic; however, in late stages, significant vision loss can ensue due to optic nerve compression from enlarging bone. Lab testing in these patients will show an increased serum alkaline phosphatase and urine calcium level. 

Less common systemic disorders that may cause the formation of angioid streaks include sickle-cell disease, acromegaly, senile elastosis, lead poisoning, and Marfan syndrome.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an indication of wet age-related macular degeneration (ARMD)?
questions.explanation:
Drusenoid pigment epithelial detachments are a sign of dry ARMD, as there is no leakage involved. Instead, a detachment in the retinal pigment epithelium occurs due to the thickness of the soft confluent drusen. The drusen push and displace the retinal pigment epithelium.
PowerPage
Wet Age-related Macular Degeneration

questions.question: All of the following are predictive risk factors for age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) except which choice?
questions.explanation: Age-related macular degeneration has risk factors that are not modifiable, age and family history being prominent among them. It also has a gender predominance of females over males. Obesity, which contributes to a more severe disease condition, and smoking are modifiable. There is increasing evidence that nutrition plays a role, with Omega 3 fatty acid intake associated with lower risk. Based on the AREDS vitamins studies, several vitamin supplements have become available. Omega 3 fatty acids are now being studied prospectively, as are the carotenoids lutein, zeaxanthin, and possibly astaxanthin. The consumption of green leafy vegetables and a diet that is plant-based has potential for prevention and mediation of severity as well.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the phenomenon of Moore's lightening streaks?
options: Flickering light that commonly begins in the center of vision and gradually expands outward; usually precedes a migraine headache
Perception of light that occurs when pressure is applied to the globe
Brief vertical light flashes typically seen in the temporal visual field at night that are elicited by acceleration of the head
Flashes of light that occur when a patient gets up quickly from a period of rest; associated with orthostatic hypotension
answers: Brief vertical light flashes typically seen in the temporal visual field at night that are elicited by acceleration of the head
questions.explanation:
Moore's lightening streaks are defined as the presence of brief, vertical flashes of light that occur in the temporal visual field of one eye, usually in darkness. These flashes can be elicited be the acceleration of the eye or head.
