It is thought that these light flashes are associated with vitreoretinal traction, which leads to activation of photoreceptors as the vitreous tugs or pulls on the retina. 

The flickering of light that precedes a migraine is known as a scintillating scotoma (or visual aura). 

A phosphene is a perception of light that occurs when pressure is applied to the globe. 

A Dictionary of Hallucinations. Blom, J.D. 2010. Springer. New York, NY.

questions.question: Which of these lists of retinal structures is correctly ordered from most central (smallest diameter) to furthest from central (largest diameter)?
options: Foveola, fovea, parafoveal area, perifoveal area
Fovea, foveola, perifoveal area, parafoveal area
Fovea, foveola, parafoveal area, perifoveal area
Foveola, fovea, perifoveal area, parafoveal area
answers: Foveola, fovea, parafoveal area, perifoveal area
questions.explanation:
The foveola is about 0.35 mm in diameter and contains the densest population of cones with the smallest cross-sectional diameter of all photoreceptors. The fovea centralis is a shallow depression in the center of the macular region. It is about 1.5 mm diameter. The annular zone around the fovea contains an inner parafoveal area that contains retinal bipolar cells and ganglion cells and has about a 2 mm diameter. Outside of there is the perifoveal area that contains ganglion cells and has a diameter of about 3.5 mm. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 p 68-71

questions.question: The macula may sometimes appear slightly yellow upon examination with an ophthalmoscope due to the presence of which pigment?
questions.explanation: The macula contains xanthophyll which contributes to its yellowish appearance, hence the name macula lutea which means 'yellow spot'. Xanthophyll is a combination of two carotenoids: zeaxanthin and lutein. Xanthophyll shows spectral selectivity for blue light, a characteristic that helps to decrease the potential formation of free radicals. Current research suggests that xanthophyll becomes depleted in people who suffer from macular degeneration. Unfortunately, xanthophyll is not synthesized by the body and thus it is advised that those diagnosed with macular degeneration take oral supplements to aid in maintaining xanthophyll pigment levels.

questions.question: What are the names of the three photopigments contained within the human cones?
questions.explanation: The human cones contain three different photopigments allowing for the perception of a large spectrum of colors. The three photopigments are erythrolabe, chlorolabe, and cyanolabe. Erythrolabe has a peak absorbency for wavelengths measuring 565 nm and is found in long-wavelength-sensitive cones (LWS cones, L-cones or red cones). Chlorolabe maximally absorbs quanta that measure 535 nm and is found in middle-wavelength-sensitive cones (MWS cones, M-cones or green cones). Lastly, the photopigment cyanolabe displays a higher affinity for absorbing wavelengths that are 430 nm in length. These cones are known as short-wavelength-sensitive cones (SWS cones, S-cones or blue cones).

questions.question: Which of the following layers of the retina is the ONLY layer that receives blood supply from BOTH the choroid and the central retinal artery?
questions.explanation: The outer plexiform layer is unique in that it is the only layer of that retina that receives a supply of blood from both the central retinal artery and the choroidal blood vessels. The central retinal artery supplies the inner retinal layers from the outer plexiform layer to the internal limiting membrane, while the choriocapillaris supplies the external layers of the retina from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) to the outer plexiform layer. Therefore, the OPL receives a supply from both sources.

questions.question: What is the pre-synaptic connection for a rod cell?
questions.explanation: Rod cells do not have pre-synaptic connections. Rhodopsin is embedded in the discs of the outer segment of the rod and absorbs a photon of light, causing an electrical change in the membrane of the rod. It is necessary for several rods to summate in order to signal the presence of a stimulus. Rods then release glutamate postsynaptically to bipolar and horizontal cells.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following characteristics are considered the MOST common risk factors for the development of a retinal detachment? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
The incidence of retinal detachments in patients who are aphakic and have no significant history of ocular trauma is about 1 in 10,000 persons per year. The incidence of retinal breaks in the general population is about 3.3% per year. 

According to the American Optometric Association, the most common risk factors for the development of a retinal detachment are myopia (40-55%), aphakia (30-40%), and ocular trauma (10-20%). 

Trauma significantly increases the risk of detachment because retinal tears or dialysis can occur, both of which can lead to the formation of a retinal detachment. Myopia greater than 8 diopters or patients with an axial length greater than 24mm have been shown to be at an increased risk for detachments as well. Studies have also shown a greater incidence of retinal detachments in patients who are aphakic; this typically occurs within the first year following surgery. It is presumed that this may be correlated to posterior vitreous detachments, which commonly occur during this period.

questions.question: Bipolar cells receive information from photoreceptors. Which type of neurotransmitter do bipolar cells respond to?
questions.explanation: Bipolar cells respond to glutamate released by photoreceptor cells. Glutamate release in the dark causes on-center bipolar cells to hyperpolarize (inhibition) and off-center bipolar cells to depolarize (excitation).

questions.question: Which 3 of the following statements comprise the definition of clinically significant macular edema? (Select 3)
options: Hard exudates within 1 disc diameter of the center of the macula if associated with retinal thickening
Hard exudates within 500 microns of the center of the macula if associated with retinal thickening
Retinal edema within 1 disc diameter of the center of the macula
Retinal edema 1 disc diameter or larger in which any part is within 1 disc diameter of the center of the macula
Retinal edema within 500 microns of the center of the macula
Retinal edema 1 disc diameter or larger in any area of the posterior pole
answers: Hard exudates within 500 microns of the center of the macula if associated with retinal thickening
Retinal edema 1 disc diameter or larger in which any part is within 1 disc diameter of the center of the macula
Retinal edema within 500 microns of the center of the macula
questions.explanation:
Clinically significant macular edema is the leading cause of visual impairment in patients suffering from retinopathy associated with diabetes. 

The presence of at least one of the following retinal observations indicates a diagnosis of clinically significant macular edema: 
- Retinal edema occurring within 500 microns of the center of the macula 
- Hard exudates occurring within 500 microns of the center of the macula if there is associated retinal thickening (which may be outside of the 500 micron distance) 
- Retinal edema that is at least 1 disc diameter in size and in which any part is within 1 disc diameter of the center of the macula 

This characterization of clinically significant macular edema is important because these retinal findings represent the need for consideration of retinal treatment (either photodynamic therapy or anti-VEGF injections), irrespective of the level of visual acuity. Studies have proven that laser photocoagulation procedures performed on these patients can reduce the risk of vision loss by up to 50%.

questions.question: Which one of the main proteins in the vitreous is comprised of a unique type of collagen?
questions.explanation:
Vitrosin is a very unique collagen that is capable of binding large amounts of water (up to two hundred times its weight!). Vitrosin originates from neuroectoderm. There was originally some debate as to whether or not vitrosin was truly a type of collagen due to the fact that it contains a complex polysaccharide within its matrix from which it cannot be separated. However, it was later ruled to be a type of collagen because it contains hydroxyproline (which is specific to collagen) and presents with the same diffractive properties as collagen. 

Hemoglobin and albumin are proteins found in blood. Creatine is a compound used as an energy source, primarily by our muscles.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions may act as a protective factor against progression of diabetic retinopathy?
questions.explanation:
It has been seen in myopic patients, (particularly highly myopic subjects) that myopia may serve as a protective factor against the progression of retinopathy associated with diabetes. Axial elongation, posterior vitreous detachment, altered ocular blood flow and vitreous syneresis are all more commonly observed in patients with high myopia. Proliferation of diabetic retinopathy can be triggered by traction of the retina caused by incomplete detachment of the vitreous, which may lead to fibrovascular tissue formation. Myopic patients with a posterior vitreous detachment possess a decreased risk of traction and therefore a decreased risk of progression of diabetic retinopathy. 

Concurrent systemic conditions such as elevated cholesterol or hypertension may serve to exacerbate retinopathy, as can a high body mass index. To date, a link with iris color and diabetic retinopathy has not been established. 

Are myopic eyes less likely to have diabetic retinopathy? Lim LS, Lamoureux E, Saw SM, et al. Ophthalmology, 2010 Mar;117(3):524-30.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT considered a risk factor for the development of age-related macular degeneration?
questions.explanation:
The main risk factor for the development of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is increasing age. Other important risk factors include positive family history of AMD, Caucasian race, and the presence of age-related maculopathy (especially when associated with soft drusen). Additionally, cataract surgery may also be associated with the progression of macular disease in patients who posses pre-existing high-risk characteristics. Studies have also shown that biomarkers for cardiovascular disease, such as a history of smoking, hypertension, and obesity also represent an increased risk for AMD.
PowerPage
Dry Age-related Macular Degeneration

questions.question: Which type of plaque composition poses the GREATEST risk for causing a central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO)?
questions.explanation:
Calcific plaques, although rare, pose the greatest risk of causing a CRAO or a branch retinal artery occlusion (BRAO). These plaques occur secondarily to damage to the heart valves, causing them to become brittle and break off. Calcific plaques are very hard and do not alter in shape or size, thereby impeding blood flow and causing ischemia. Hollenhorst plaques are comprised of cholesterol and commonly dissolve. Hollenhorst plaques are refractile, and appear larger than the vessel in which they occupy due to their shiny presentations. They commonly lodge transiently at vessel bifurcations. Fibrinoplatelet plaques are composed of aggregations of fibrin and platelets. On occasion, fibrinoplatelet plaques may dissolve on their own. Talc emboli, seen in patients who inject drugs intravenously, may also cause a CRAO, however they do not pose the greatest risk for an occlusion when compared to the above etiologies. 

Reference: Agarwal, A and Jacob, S. Color Atlas of Ophthalmology: The Quick-Reference Manual for Diagnosis and Treatment 2nd edition (2010) pp. 265-266.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following ophthalmologic manifestations are associated with malignant hypertension? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: Though unlikely to present in the office, a sudden significant rise in blood pressure can damage the delicate retinal vessel walls. This leads to flame-shaped hemorrhages or infarction of the nerve layer, producing cotton wool spots, and, in the most severe and long-lasting cases, papilledema. On the other hand, Hollenhorst plaques reflect an embolic phenomenon from thrombotic disease, usually from the carotid artery. Acute angle closure and chorioretinal atrophy are not associated with malignant hypertension.

questions.question: The internal limiting membrane of the retina is formed by a combination of glial cell processes and which other cell type?
questions.explanation: The internal limiting membrane is formed by radial feet processes of Muller cells along with other glial cell constituents. Muller cell processes extend throughout the length of the retina except for the retinal pigment epithelium. Their cell bodies are found in the inner nuclear layer. Muller cells, along with segments of the photoreceptors, create tight junctions and serve to form the external limiting membrane.

questions.question: What is the first cell in the visual processing chain to undergo an action potential?
questions.explanation: The only cells of the retina to undergo action potentials are the ganglion cells and the amacrine cells. All of the other types of retinal cells display graded potentials. Graded potentials, in contrast to action potentials, tend to decay with time. Both horizontal and photoreceptors hyperpolarize in response to light.

questions.question: What is the name of the funnel-shaped region anterior to the optic disc that represents the posterior termination of Cloquet's canal?
questions.explanation:
The area of Martegiani signifies the funnel-shaped dilation surrounding the optic disc representing the posterior termination of Cloquet's canal (also known as the hyaloid canal).

Berger's space is an area between that anterior face of the vitreous body and the posterior lens capsule. It represents the anterior termination of Cloquet's canal. It is also known as Erggelet's space. 

The patellar fossa characterizes the anterior depression of the vitreous body in which the crystalline lens resides. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye. (11th edition). 2011. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.F.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. Saunders Elsevier. 

Ophthalmology: Expert Consult (4th edition). Yanoff, M., Duker, J.S. 2014. Elsevier Saunders.

questions.question: Which of the following ocular diseases represents the MOST common cause of irreversible vision loss in the United States involving individuals over the age of 50?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of vision loss in individuals over the age of 50 (in developed countries) is age-related macular degeneration (AMD). In the United States, at least 10% of patients between the ages of 65 and 75 have some impairment of visual acuity that can be attributed to AMD. Furthermore, of individuals over the age of 75, 30% have some degree of central vision loss as a result of AMD. These statistics show that the prevalence of severe visual loss increases with age.
PowerPage
Dry Age-related Macular Degeneration

questions.question: Which of the following will cause the greatest increase in blood flow to the eye?
options: Increased blood pressure and increased blood vessel resistance
Decreased blood pressure and decreased blood vessel resistance
Increased blood pressure and decreased blood vessel resistance
Decreased blood pressure and decreased blood vessel resistance
answers: Increased blood pressure and decreased blood vessel resistance
questions.explanation: Blood flow is dependent upon blood pressure and vascular resistance. Blood flow is directly proportional to blood pressure and inversely proportional to vascular resistance; in other words an increase, in blood pressure causes an increase in blood flow while an increase in resistance decreases blood flow. Resistance itself is dependent upon the caliber and number of blood vessels.

questions.question: A patient performs a visual field and consistently displays an isolated central scotoma on the right eye. You decide to examine the fundus for any signs of organic causes. Where in the fundus are you MOST likely to see pathology correlating to the field defect?
questions.explanation:
A central scotoma may be attributable to macular disease or an optic nerve disease, especially those that also affect the papillomacular bundle. Any pathology that affects the integrity of the macula generally is associated with a loss of visual acuity (the severity varies with the amount of destruction). Optic nerve disease such as optic neuritis may also cause a central scotoma. Further testing such as acuity, pupil reflexes, and color vision will help to discern whether the origin is macular or optic nerve related. Optic nerve disease will result in an afferent pupillary defect (APD) and/or a red/green color deficit. 

References: Rowe, F. Visual Fields via the Visual Pathway, pp. 11-20. 

Schiefer U., Wilhelm H, and Hart W. Clinical Neuro-Ophthalmology: A Practical Guide 2007 pp. 82-83.
PowerPage
The Visual Pathway

questions.question: You are examining the right peripheral retina of your patient with a retinal detachment in order to locate the primary location of a retinal break. You observe that the detachment of the retina is inferior, and that the subretinal fluid is slightly higher on the temporal side. In which location do you MOST likely expect to find the break?
questions.explanation: The configuration of subretinal fluid in cases of a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is relevant in that it is determined by gravitational forces, the anatomical limits of the eye (ora serrata and optic nerve), and the location of the primary retinal break. Therefore, the conformation of the retinal detachment can aid in determining the suspected location for the offending retinal break, if it is not initially observed. For example, if the retinal break occurs superiorly, the subretinal fluid will first migrate inferiorly on the same side as the break and then will eventually spread superiorly on the opposite side. In the case of the above patient, when the retinal detachment is inferior and the subretinal fluid is higher on one side; therefore, the site of the retinal break is likely to be located inferiorly on that same side.

questions.question: A patient presents to your office with complaints of severely decreased visual acuity and flashes of light that appeared suddenly. Upon dilated retinal evaluation, you observe a retinal detachment that has affected the macula. In which of the following quadrants are you MOST likely to observe the offending retinal break?
questions.explanation:
Retinal breaks leading to the formation of retinal detachments are most commonly found in the superior-temporal region, especially in cases of total retinal detachments or those affecting the macula, due to the nature of gravitational forces. Superior-nasal tears are the next most commonly observed. Additionally, the most likely cause of a retinal detachment is vitreoretinal traction at the attachment of the vitreous base, which leads to a retinal tear as the vitreous detaches from this area; fluid then enters the subretinal space at the site of the tear, resulting in a detachment of the retina. 

The patient history may also provide a clue to the location of the break. When detachments progress rather quickly, the break is usually large and found superiorly closer to the equator than to the ora. Small, inferior, or extremely peripheral tears usually result in much slower progression. The quadrant of visual field loss that is first detected is also valuable in locating the primary retinal break.
PowerPage
Retinal Detachments

questions.question: Between which areas of the retina does fluid accumulate in a patient diagnosed with cystoid macular edema (CME)?
options: Inner limiting membrane (ILM) and nerve fiber layer (NFL)
Retinal pigmented epithelium (RPE) and neurosensory retina
Outer plexiform layer (OPL) and inner nuclear layers (INL)
Bruch's membrane and retinal pigmented epithelium (RPE)
answers: Outer plexiform layer (OPL) and inner nuclear layers (INL)
questions.explanation: Cystoid macular edema is most commonly caused by inflammation or diabetes. These etiologies cause the capillary beds within the retina to breakdown, leading to an increase in permeability of the vessels, and subsequent leakage of fluid within the retina. The capillary beds within the retina are found in the inner nuclear and outer plexiform layers. Edema between the RPE and neurosensory retina occurs in central serous retinopathy, while elevation in wet macular degeneration occurs between Bruch's membrane and the RPE.

questions.question: Which of the following layers of the retina represents Henle's fiber layer in the macular region?
questions.explanation:
In order to maximize cone function and acuity, the fovea displays certain structural differences when compared to the rest of the retina. At the fovea, the bipolar and ganglion cell layers are pushed aside. At the foveola, the inner plexiform layer, inner nuclear layer, ganglion cell layer, and the nerve fiber layer are all pushed aside. 

Essentially, this leaves the retinal pigment epithelium, internal limiting membrane, cone photoreceptors and the outer plexiform layer. In the macula, the outer plexiform layer is known as Henle's fiber layer. It is comprised of an oblique and radially oriented arrangement of axons of cone photoreceptors.

questions.question: Which of the following layers of the retina separates the retinal pigment epithelium from the underlying choriocapillaris?
questions.explanation: Bruch's membrane separates the retinal pigment epithelial layer from the underlying choriocapillaris. Abnormalities that may develop in this layer can lead to the pathogenesis of many macular disorders, such as exudative macular degeneration, etc. Bruch's membrane is composed of 5 different elements, including basal lamina of the retinal pigment epithelium, an inner collagenous layer, a band of elastic fibers, an outer collagenous layer, and basal lamina of the inner choriocapillaris layer.

questions.question: What is the most commonly encountered type of staphyloma?
questions.explanation:
A posterior staphyloma is the most common type of staphyloma. This form of staphyloma tends to occur in individuals with very high degrees of myopia. 

Intercalary staphylomas occur usually secondary to inflammation and are located at the junction between the iris root and the ciliary body. 

Total staphylomas, also known as buphthalmos, are generally seen in conjunction with congenital glaucoma.

questions.question: Which of the following types of tumors represents the MOST common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood?
questions.explanation: Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children. It represents about 3-4% of all childhood cancers, occurring in about 1 in 17,000 live births. About 80% of all children diagnosed with retinoblastoma present with the condition before the age of 3, and an initial diagnosis over the age of 6 is extremely rare. Melanoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in adults.

questions.question: Which of the following statements BEST describes the underlying etiology of the characteristic 'cherry-red spot' observed in patients with a central retinal artery occlusion?
options: Choroidal neovascular membrane underlying the macula
Vitreous hemorrhaging in the macular region
Intact choroidal circulation in contrast to pale surrounding retina
Intact macular circulation through a cilioretinal artery
answers: Intact choroidal circulation in contrast to pale surrounding retina
questions.explanation: A characteristic observation associated with the development of a central retinal artery occlusion is the presence of a 'cherry red spot' at the region of the macula. This retinal finding typically manifests several hours after the artery obstruction and usually gradually subsides in the following weeks. The appearance of the bright red central spot is due to the fact that the macular region is supplied with blood from the underlying choroid, which remains unaffected in a central retinal artery occlusion because it is supplied by the posterior ciliary arteries. This macular area particularly stands out against the surrounding pale retina that is ischemic as a result of the occlusion.

questions.question: Capillaries found in which 2 of the following structures of the eye are considered fenestrated vessels? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
Fenestrated capillaries are present within two structures of the eye, the ciliary processes and the choroid. Contrastingly, the retina and iris contain non-fenestrated capillaries. 

If we examine this concept closely, it makes perfect sense. The choroid supplies the outer retina with nutrients, accounting for about 85% of total blood flow of the eye. In order for the choroid to supply the retina with these nutrients, the vessels must be able to allow the molecules to pass through. Additionally, in the ciliary processes, the fenestrated capillaries create oncotic pressure due to protein leakage through the vessels that allows for aqueous production through the process of ultrafiltration. 

Non-fenestrated capillaries of the retina and iris are essential for the formation of the blood-aqueous and blood-retinal barriers. 

Ocular Therapeutics (3rd edition). Garg, A. 2013. Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers.

questions.question: In patients diagnosed with retinitis pigmentosa, which of the following inheritance patterns leads to the MOST severe presentation of the disease with the WORST prognosis?
questions.explanation:
Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a retinal dystrophy in which the rod photoreceptor cells are initially preferentially affected, with eventual subsequent degeneration of the cone photoreceptors as well. Retinitis pigmentosa may develop as a result of an isolated sporadic disorder without any other family history or secondary to a genetic mutation (usually of the rhodopsin gene). RP has also been shown to be associated with certain systemic conditions. 

The autosomal-dominant form of retinitis pigmentosa, along with the isolated sporadic form are the most common types and usually have the best prognosis. Autosomal-recessive types are less common and typically have an intermediate or guarded prognosis. The least common and most severe form of RP is due to an x-linked genetic mutation and commonly results in complete blindness by the time patients are in their 20's or 30's.

questions.question: A 47 year-old male patient is diagnosed with a secondary choroidal melanoma. Which of the following locations of the body is the MOST common primary site for these types of lesions?
questions.explanation: Secondary ocular tumors most frequently arise from the lung in both sexes and from the breast in women. Occasionally metastasis can also occur from the kidney or gastrointestinal tract, but this is much less common. If metastasis is suspected, patients should undergo a full body scan, chest radiography, rectal examination, serum PSA (prostate-specific antigen) and CEA (carcinoembryonic antigen) levels, and mammography (in females).

questions.question: The presence of which of the following retinal characteristics will result in a corresponding area of hyperfluorescence during fluorescein angiography?
questions.explanation:
Areas of hyperfluorescence that appear during fluorescein angiography occur due to either an absolute increase in the amount of fluorescein in the retinal tissues or as a result of enhanced visualization of a normal quantity of fluorescein in the fundus. Conditions that can lead to hyperfluorescence include leakage of dye from abnormal choroidal vasculature (such as a choroidal neovascular membrane), abnormal retinal neovascularization (as in proliferative diabetic retinopathy), or breakdown of the inner blood-retinal barrier (cystoid macular edema). Hyperflourescence also occurs as a result of pooling of fluorescein secondary to breakdown of the outer blood-retinal barrier in such conditions as central serous retinopathy and pigment epithelial detachments. A transmission (or window) defect caused by an absence or atrophy of the RPE results in unmasking of normal background choroidal fluorescence, leading to the appearance of hyperfluorescent areas. 

Hypofluorescent regions on fluorescein angiography are due to either obstruction (masking) of normal density of fluorescein in the retinal tissue (blood, hard exudates, increased density of RPE, or choroidal nevi) or inadequate perfusion of the retinal tissue (vascular occlusion, or loss of the vascular bed).

questions.question: Which 3 of the following carotenoids are considered the predominant pigments found in the macula lutea? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: The major functional roles of the carotenoid pigments found in the human macula are protection against ultraviolet light-induced retinal damage (as they act as filters for blue light), and limiting oxidative stress (with their high antioxidant potential). The predominant carotenoids that make up this macular pigment include lutein, zeaxanthin, and meso-zeaxanthin (which is a conversion product of lutein). They are selectively concentrated in the macula lutea and are responsible for the yellow appearance of this region. Humans cannot synthesize these pigments de novo; therefore, they must be derived entirely from the diet. Certain eye diseases such as age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and retinitis pigmentosa (RP) have been associated with low levels of lutein, zeaxanthin, and meso-zeaxanthin.

questions.question: The finding of subretinal epithelial deposits between the basement membrane of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and Bruch's membrane in the macular area of a 64-year old white female with a slight loss of visual acuity (20/30) and pseudophakia is the clinical hallmark of what disease?
options: Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) dropout or window defect
Soft exudates or clinically significant macular edema (CSME)
questions.explanation:
Drusen are the hallmark of AMD. Multiple types of drusen have been described, including large (>64 microns) and small (<63 microns), calcified, and basal laminar. Drusen are required to make the diagnosis of AMD as they are the destructive force behind RPE loss. Drusen become more apparent on fluorescein angiography.
PowerPage
Dry Age-related Macular Degeneration

questions.question: Central serous retinopathy (CSR) is associated with an acute decrease in vision along with central distortion. The condition usually occurs unilaterally. Which gender and age group tends to have the highest incidence of CSR?
questions.explanation: CSR is more commonly seen in middle-aged males under high-stress, high anxiety, or with type A personalities. This condition causes fluid to leak from the choriocapillaries into the subretinal area, causing a serous detachment of the neurosensory retina. There is an associated loss of the foveal reflex, a hyperopic shift, a potential relative scotoma, and metamorphopsia. Flourescein angiography will reveal hyperfluorescence that appears like a smoke-stack. Evaluation of the posterior pole will typically display a blister-like elevation of the neurosensory retina. The patient is monitored monthly and intervention is rarely required, as most cases of CSR will resolve within roughly 6 months.

questions.question: Your 20 year-old female patient presents with a single retinal lesion in the temporal equatorial region of her right eye. The lesion appears flat with discrete margins, is 1 disc diameter in size, and is uniformly black in coloration. The lesion does not disappear with red-free filtered light on fundus evaluation. What is the MOST likely diagnosis for this patient?
options: Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE)
answers: Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE)
questions.explanation:
Patients diagnosed with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) lesions typically present with a retinal lesion that is flat, darkly pigmented, round or oval, and with well-defined borders. It usually occurs as a unilateral, solitary lesion that is most commonly found in the temporal equatorial region of the fundus. In some cases, depigmented lacunae may be observed within the lesion, or a lighter pigmented halo may occur just within the border of the lesion. Because CHRPEs are composed RPE cells, they will not disappear with red-free light in the way that choroidal lesions do. 

A melanocytoma is a rare tumor that typically occurs at the optic nerve head. It presents as a darkly pigmented lesion with feathery edges that lies within the nerve fiber layer and may appear elevated.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following are TRUE in regards to macular holes? (Select 3)
options: Men are more often affected than women
Typically occur in the 6th or 7th decade of life
Women are more often affected than men
Typically occur in the 5th or 6th decade of life
answers: Typically occur in the 6th or 7th decade of life
Women are more often affected than men
questions.explanation:
The following represents the most common profile of a patient presenting with a macular hole: 
- Most commonly idiopathic in otherwise healthy individuals 
- Typically occur in the 6th or 7th decade of life 
- Women are more affected than men (2:1) 
- 10-20% of patients develop bilateral macular holes

questions.question: The C-wave seen in an electroretinogram is created by which cells?
questions.explanation: Electroretinograms (ERGs) are created by electric currents across the eye (the cornea is positive relative to the retinal pigment epithelium). They are a summation of the different electrical responses of retinal cells to stimuli. The A-wave of the ERG is formed by the photoreceptors. The B-wave occurs due to the responses from bipolar and Mueller cells. The C-wave is created by responses from retinal pigment epithelial cells, and the D-wave is attributable to activity of the OFF bipolar cells. The C-wave and the D-wave are not used clinically very often because they are susceptible to being obscured by blinking of the eye. It is also noteworthy that oscillations seen in the B-wave are due to responses of the amacrine cells.

questions.question: Which of the following refractive errors has a higher correlation with the development of a posterior vitreal detachment (PVD)?
questions.explanation: Syneresis and liquification of the vitreous are part of the normal aging process, but they also may cause a posterior vitreal detachment. PVDs occur with an earlier onset if something speeds up the process of vitreal aging. These conditions include myopia, trauma, diabetes, intraocular surgery, intraocular inflammation, and vitreal hemorrhages.

questions.question: Degenerative retinoschisis occurs from the separation of which two layers of the retina?
options: Nerve fiber layer and the ganglion cell layer
External limiting membrane and outer nuclear layer
Outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer
Inner nuclear layer and ganglion cell layer
answers: Outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer
questions.explanation:
Degenerative retinoschisis occurs when there is a split within the neurosensory retina. This separation commonly takes place between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer. Patients are usually asymptomatic and the condition tends to be bilateral, and is typically located in the inferior temporal quadrant of the retina. Visual field testing may show an absolute scotoma corresponding to the area of the retinoschisis. 

Retinoschisis is different from a retinal detachment, which is the separation of the neurosensory retina from the RPE. This separation usually takes place between the RPE and photoreceptor layer. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) can assist in differentiating retinoschisis from a retinal detachment. The OCT scan of a retinal detachment would show a separation of the full thickness neurosensory retina from the RPE. On the other hand, a scan of retinoschisis would show a split within the neurosensory retina. This split most commonly occurs between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer.
PowerPage
Retinal Anatomy

questions.question: An epiretinal membrane is caused by proliferation of retinal glial cells that have migrated to the retinal surface through breaks in which of the following layers of the retina?
questions.explanation: Macular epiretinal membranes (also known as macular pucker or cellophane maculopathy) develop at the vitreoretinal interface as a result of abnormal proliferation of retinal glial cells. These retinal glial cells are able to migrate to the retinal surface through breaks in the internal limiting membrane. It is believed that small breaks in the internal limiting membrane may occur secondary to vitreomacular traction in association with a posterior vitreous detachment. Additionally, these breaks can also develop after ocular surgeries, ocular trauma, or following cases of ocular inflammation or retinal vascular disease.

questions.question: The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is continuous anteriorly with what layer of the ciliary body?
options: Non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body
Internal limiting membrane of the ciliary body
Pigment epithelium of the ciliary body
Basal lamina of the ciliary body
answers: Pigment epithelium of the ciliary body
questions.explanation: The RPE is continuous with the pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body. To make this easier to remember, recall that pigment stays with pigment.

questions.question: In an otherwise systemically healthy individual, what is the most common etiology of a full-thickness macular hole?
options: Posterior staphyloma secondary to high myopia
questions.explanation:
Full-thickness macular holes are most commonly idiopathic in an otherwise healthy individual. Macular holes typically affect healthy individuals in their 6th or 7th decade of life, with mean onset at age 65. Women are more commonly affected compared to men (2:1), and approximately 10-20% of patients will eventually develop a macular hole in the fellow eye as well. Macular holes are relatively rare, and the best available research suggests that abnormal tractional forces of the vitreous on the macula are directly correlated to the pathogenesis of idiopathic macular holes. 

Pathological processes can also induce a macular hole (less commonly). These include: 
- ocular trauma, cystoid macular edema, epiretinal membrane, vitreomacular traction syndrome, retinal detachment, laser energy exposure, posterior staphyloma secondary to high myopia, hypertensive retinopathy, and proliferative diabetic retinopathy

questions.question: Which of the following blood vessels offers the greatest resistance and the lowest flow rate?
questions.explanation: Blood vessels of the retina are very small and as such offer high resistance and low flow rate (about 1.7 ml/min/gm) due to their small lumen. In contrast, choroidal vessels are larger and have lower resistance and a higher flow rate (roughly 19/ml/min/gm). The ophthalmic and carotid arteries are even larger than the retinal and choroidal vessels leading to even higher flow rates.

questions.question: In addition to the retinal findings of bone-spicule pigmentation and retinal arteriolar attenuation, patients diagnosed with retinitis pigmentosa MOST commonly develop which of the following optic nerve changes?
questions.explanation: The classic clinical triad of retinitis pigmentosa (RP) includes arteriolar attenuation, retinal bone-spicule pigmentation, and waxy optic disc pallor. Other ocular associations of retinitis pigmentosa may occur at any time during the disease, some of which may be amenable to treatment. These additional signs include the development of posterior subcapsular cataracts, myopia, and vitreous changes, such as posterior vitreous detachment and uveitis. Additionally, keratoconus, optic disc drusen, and open-angle glaucoma may also be associated with RP.

questions.question: What is the name of the congenital retinal vascular anomaly in which a vessel that supplies perfusion to the macula and the papillomacular bundle can be observed emerging from the optic disc, separately from the central retinal artery?
questions.explanation:
Cilioretinal arteries are most frequently a result of an anomalous direct or indirect branch of the posterior ciliary arteries. In some cases, they can also arise from the peripapillary choroid. Cilioretinal arteries are typically observed as emerging from the temporal aspect of the optic disc, separately from the central retinal artery. The incidence of occurrence varies from 6-25% in the relevant literature. A cilioretinal artery has been said to be a possible protective feature that allows for a secondary route of blood flow to the macula in the event of a central retinal artery occlusion. 

Optociliary shunt vessels are venous communications between the retinal and choroidal circulations; these vessels occur on the disc surface when there is impaired venous outflow through the retinal vein. 

Situs inversus is a congenital vascular anomaly found at the optic disc, where the retinal vessels have followed an abnormal course. They enter the disc temporally and proceed towards the nasal retina before turning back and coursing out to the temporal retina. 

An arteriovenous anastomosis of the retina is an abnormal communication between an artery and vein that occurs through collateral channels. It serves to shunt blood away from an artery to a vein in order to bypass a capillary bed.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions BEST describes the congenital anomaly in which temporal vessels emanating from the optic nerve deviate nasally before turning temporally?
questions.explanation:
Situs inversus is a congenital anomaly of the retinal vasculature in which the vascular arcades emanating from the optic disc deviate nasally before turning and coursing temporally. 

A prepapillary loop occurs when a vessel extending from the optic disc loops into the vitreous cavity. 

The appearance of a tilted optic disc is a very common congenital optic nerve anomaly that is usually caused by an oblique insertion of the nerve into the globe. The optic nerve typically appears more oval in shape and the superior pole of the axis appears to be rotated (most commonly infero-nasally). Due to the oblique entry of the optic nerve, there tends to be an associated elevation of the neuroretinal rim tissue and indistinct disc margins, depending on the direction of rotation. 

Optociliary shunt vessels are abnormal venous communications between the retinal and choroidal vasculature that occur on the surface of the optic disc. These vessels indicate chronic venous obstruction of a retinal vein and are not considered a congenital anomaly.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following statements are TRUE in regards to the peripheral retinal structures near the ora serrata? (Select 2)
options: Oral bays are the scalloped edges of the peripheral retina that reside between the dentate processes
Oral bays are the scalloped edges of the pars plana that reside between the dentate processes
Dentate processes are the teeth-like extensions of the pars plana that course onto the peripheral retina
Dentate processes are the teeth-like extensions of the peripheral retina that course onto the pars plana
answers: Oral bays are the scalloped edges of the pars plana that reside between the dentate processes
Dentate processes are the teeth-like extensions of the peripheral retina that course onto the pars plana
questions.explanation: The ora serrata is the ocular landmark of the junction between the peripheral retina and the pars plana of the ciliary body. The ora serrata is characterized by certain observable features, including oral bays and dentate processes. Dentate processes are the teeth-like extensions of the peripheral retina that extend onto the pars plana. They are more marked in the nasal periphery as compared to the temporal ora serrata. Oral bays are the scalloped edges of the pars plana epithelium that reside between the dentate processes of the retina.

questions.question: The biochemical cascade of phototransduction occurs exclusively in which of the following portions of a photoreceptor cell?
questions.explanation:
Photoreceptor cells are highly compartmentalized cells that are densely packed in the outermost layer of the neurosensory retina and are responsible for transmitting light energy into electrical signals, a process known as phototransduction. The actual biochemical cascade of phototransduction occurs in the outer segment of the photoreceptor, which is an elongated membrane compartment that is separated from the rest of the cell. Immediately adjacent to the outer segment is the inner segment, in which active biosynthesis and oxidative metabolism of the photoreceptor occurs, producing the necessary molecules for phototransduction to occur. 

Biochemisty of the Eye: Perspectives in Vision Research. Berman, E.R., Blakeman, C. Plenum Press. New York, NY.

questions.question: Which of the following characteristics can aid in determining whether a central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is ischemic or non-ischemic?
options: Pan-retinal photocoagulation is an effective treatment for non-ischemic CRVOs
Afferent pupillary defects are more common in non-ischemic CRVOs
Visual acuity is typically worse in non-ischemic CRVOs
Non-ischemic CRVOs are more common than ischemic CRVOs
answers: Non-ischemic CRVOs are more common than ischemic CRVOs
questions.explanation:
Non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusions (CRVOs) are more common than ischemic CRVOs, accounting for about 75% of cases. 

Non-ischemic CRVOs typically present with sudden, painless, unilateral vision loss that is usually of a moderate to severe degree. Afferent pupillary defects may be present but are usually only mild (and often absent in most cases). Prognosis in these cases is much more promising than ischemic CRVO, with restoration of vision occurring in around 50% of patients. Treatment of non-ischemic CRVOs is currently inadequate, and laser photocoagulation has shown to be of no benefit in these cases. 

Ischemic CRVOs also present with sudden, severe vision loss, but this loss is much more marked as compared to non-ischemic forms. Visual acuity is typically counting fingers or worse in these patients. An afferent pupillary defect is present in most cases and is usually severe. Patients suffering from an ischemic CRVO have a much poorer prognosis as compared to non-ischemic types, due to the development of macular ischemia and secondary neovascular glaucoma. Pan-retinal photocoagulation treatment is usually performed in patients with associated rubeosis iridis.

questions.question: Which of the following lifestyle choices possesses the HIGHEST risk for the development of macular degeneration?
options: Partaking in high-risk activities such as sky diving
questions.explanation:
Research has demonstrated that lifestyle choices such as smoking, a high body mass index, increased ultraviolet exposure and a poor diet all increase the chances of developing macular degeneration. Smoking alone increases the risk of developing macular degeneration up to 16 to 20 times. The main risk factor for the development of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is increasing age. Other important risk factors include positive family history of AMD, Caucasian race, and the presence of age-related maculopathy (especially when associated with soft drusen). 

Review of Optometry. February 15, 2014. The Lowdown on Blue Light: Good vs. Bad and its Connection to AMD.

questions.question: Cone photoreceptors are neatly organized in which of the following arrangements in the macula?
questions.explanation: In the macula, cone photoreceptors are densely packed in a hexagonal arrangement. As the location moves peripherally in the retina, the size and separation of the cone photoreceptors grow, and rods fill in the spaces between cones. This organization of the photoreceptor mosaic represents an optimum arrangement for efficient visual processing under a wide range of stimulus conditions.

questions.question: Upon fundus examination of a patient presenting with an acute episode of flashes of light, you observe a small horseshoe retinal tear with surrounding subretinal fluid. Histopathologically, this fluid is located between which of the following layers?
options: Photoreceptor layer and retinal pigment epithelium
Retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane
Photoreceptor layer and outer limiting membrane
Nerve fiber layer and ganglion cell layer
answers: Photoreceptor layer and retinal pigment epithelium
questions.explanation:
A retinal detachment with surrounding subretinal fluid represents a separation of the neuroretina (photoreceptors) and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). The classic pathogenesis of a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment usually begins with vitreous liquefaction, followed by a posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) and a subsequent retinal tear at the site of significant vitreoretinal adhesion. Liquid in the vitreous cavity then passes through the retinal break and enters the subretinal space. 

It is important to note that the majority of patients with retinal breaks do not typically develop retinal detachments because there are several normal physiological forces that work to keep the retina in place. These forces are a result of several factors: the presence of an interphotoreceptor matrix in the subretinal space, differences in the oncotic pressure between the choroid and subretinal space, hydrostatic forces related to intraocular pressure, and the metabolic transfer of fluid and ions by the RPE. A retinal detachment however, will occur when the combination of factors that promote the development of a retinal detachment overwhelm the normal physiologic attachment forces.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following characteristics of retinal photoreceptor cells are TRUE? (Select 3)
options: Photoreceptors release less neurotransmitter in response to light
Photoreceptors release more neurotransmitter in response to light
Photoreceptors hyperpolarize in response to a light stimulus
Photoreceptors depolarize in response to a light stimulus
answers: Photoreceptors release less neurotransmitter in response to light
Photoreceptors hyperpolarize in response to a light stimulus
questions.explanation:
Photoreceptors of the retina have many characteristics that are unlike most other neurological cells in the human body. For example, photoreceptors produce graded potentials in which the signal varies in intensity; this is in contrast to action potentials, which display an all-or-none response. Additionally, photoreceptors hyperpolarize in response to light. Therefore, bright light will lead to a greater degree of hyperpolarization, whereas dim light produces less hyperpolarization. When hyperpolarization of a photoreceptor occurs, the cell releases less of its neurotransmitter (glutamate). Therefore, photoreceptors release a greater amount of glutamate while in darkness. 

Discovering Biological Psychology (2nd edition). Freberg, L.A. 2010. Wadsworth Cengage Learning. Belmont, CA.

questions.question: While performing binocular indirect ophthalmoscopy (BIO), you notice a retinal nevus in the left eye as you are viewing the temporal aspect of a patient's retina. The nevus is displaced towards the left portion of your condensing lens (YOUR left). How should you maneuver in order to center the image of the nevus in your lens?
options: Pivot yourself and the lens towards your right
Pivot yourself and the lens towards your left
Pivot yourself to your right and move the lens to your left
Pivot yourself to your left and move the lens to your right
answers: Pivot yourself and the lens towards your left
questions.explanation: If you wish to center an image in your condensing lens, you must move as a unit (you and the lens both move together) towards the image or structure that you wish to view.

questions.question: Which chamber lies adjacent to the retina?
questions.explanation: The vitreous chamber is the largest of the three spaces within the eye and lies next to the retina. The anterior chamber, as its name implies, is the most anterior space and is bound by the cornea and iris. The posterior chamber is bounded by the iris, lens, and retina. There is no retinal chamber.

questions.question: What agent is primarily responsible for the viscosity of the vitreous?
questions.explanation:
The vitreous humor is a thick gel-like substance that fills the vitreous cavity which constitutes about 60% of the globe. The vitreous contains elements that are important for retinal health. The ionic composition includes oxygen, water, sodium, potassium, chloride, phosphate, glucose, and proteins (although the blood-vitreal barrier blocks the majority of proteins from getting into the vitreous). The vitreous composition is roughly 99% water. 

Sodium hyaluronate is hydrophilic and is responsible for maintaining the viscosity of the vitreous. It is greatly concentrated in the cortical vitreous. As we age the liquid portion of the vitreous increases.

questions.question: You correctly diagnose a 3-month old baby with unilateral anterior persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV). What is the MOST appropriate treatment?
options: Prescribe patching therapy of the good eye
Refer to ophthalmology for a lensectomy
Prescribe sunglasses to ensure UV protection
answers: Refer to ophthalmology for a lensectomy
questions.explanation: Anterior PHPV, also known as persistent fetal vasculature, occurs from a failure of the hyaloid artery system to regress along with hyperplasia of the primary vitreous, forming a dense mass on the posterior surface of the lens and extremely poor vision. Associated findings include leukocoria, a shallow anterior chamber, cataracts, micro-ophthalmia, elongated ciliary processes and colobomas of the uveal tract. Potential complications include glaucoma and very dense amblyopia. Treatment requires early removal of the lens and management of any glaucoma and amblyopia. The visual outcome for these patients remains poor at this time.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the MOST common cause of a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment in adults?
questions.explanation:
Rhegmatogenous retinal detachments are caused by a full-thickness retinal break in which liquid vitreous is allowed to enter the subretinal space and separate the neuroretina from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). The most common cause of a rhegmatogenous detachment is a retinal tear at the site of a vitreoretinal adhesion during the advancement of a posterior vitreous detachment (PVD). Factors that may put patients at higher risk of developing this condition include the presence of lattice degeneration and previous intraocular surgery. 

Tractional retinal detachments are not associated with retinal breaks but are due to tractional forces secondary to a diseased vitreous. The most common cause of tractional retinal detachments is proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Occasionally, patients with a tractional retinal detachment can develop retinal tears, leading to a combined tractional/rhegmatogenous detachment. 

Exudative retinal detachments occur as a result of breakdown of the blood-retinal barriers or the RPE due to choroidal or retinal disease. Common causes of this type of detachment include choroidal tumors and posterior scleritis.
PowerPage
Retinal Detachments

questions.question: Which of the following ocular conditions represents the MOST common initial sign associated with retinoblastoma in children?
questions.explanation: Children diagnosed with retinoblastoma typically present within the first or second years of life (very rarely does it manifest after the age of 6). The most common initial sign that raises suspicion for possible retinoblastoma is the presence of a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) in about 60% of patients. The second most common initial presentation involves the existence of strabismus (about 20% of patients). Other less common initial signs include secondary glaucoma with buphthalmos, orbital inflammation, proptosis, or ocular redness due to tumor-induced uveitis.

questions.question: The vasculature of the choroid is regulated by which system?
questions.explanation:
The choroidal vasculature is controlled by the sympathetic nervous system, specifically the superior cervical ganglion. Stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system leads to constriction of the choroidal blood vessels. 

The vasculature of the retina is not under autonomic control. Retinal vessels maintain an even flow rate by reacting to local alterations in carbon dioxide and oxygen levels.

questions.question: A 68-year old male patient presents to your office with a chief complaint of a dark spot in the center of his vision in his left eye. Upon dilated retinal examination, you observe what appears to be a macular hole; however, you do not have access to an OCT to determine if it is a full thickness or lamellar macular hole. Which of the following tests could you use in-office to aid in determining the thickness of the retinal defect?
questions.explanation:
The most effective and sensitive method of evaluating a suspected macular hole is by use of optical coherence tomography (OCT); however, many general optometric practices do not have this instrument available in the their offices. Another helpful clinical test that is utilized to assess for a suspected full thickness macular hole is the Watzke-Allen slit lamp test. A narrow vertical slit-beam of light is placed over the foveal region using the slit-lamp and condensing lens. The patient is then asked to describe the line of light. The test is considered positive if the patient reports a break or significant thinning of the bar of light. Most patients with a full-thickness macular hole will report a positive Watzke-Allen test. 

Amsler grid testing is great for macular disease in that it is sensitive for detecting the presence of macular lesions; however, it is not specific to the type of lesion that may be present.

questions.question: You wish to evaluate the macular function of your 25-year-old patient who reports decreased visual acuity by using the macular photostress test. Which of the following results is considered a NORMAL recovery time?
options: Recovery of visual acuity within 155 to 200 seconds
Recovery of visual acuity within 105 to 150 seconds
Recovery of visual acuity within 60 seconds or less
Recovery of visual acuity within 65 to 100 seconds
answers: Recovery of visual acuity within 60 seconds or less
questions.explanation:
The macular photostress test can be useful to differentiate between macular and optic nerve dysfunction in the event of decreased best corrected acuity. The test is administered monocularly by projecting one line larger than the best corrected visual acuity. Spectacle or contact lens correction is then removed and the patient dark adapts for one minute. With the symptomatic eye occluded, a penlight or transilluminator is held roughly 3 cm from the eye, and the patient is asked to fixate on the light source for 10 seconds. Best correction is then replaced and the patient is asked to focus on the projected line until it can be read clearly again. A photostress test is considered normal if acuity is recovered within 60 seconds or less. Recovery time is expected to increase in patients over the age of 40. In the event of macular function disruption, visual recovery will be prolonged, or there will be a significantly large recovery difference between the eyes. 

Reference: Levin, L. Neuro-ophthalmology: The Practical Guide (2005) page 9

questions.question: In general, what color is a healthy retina?
options: It depends on the pigmentation of a person's skin
questions.explanation: As a whole, the retina is clear. This is an important property as light must pass through eight layers prior to being absorbed by the photoreceptors. If the retina did possess a color, this would interfere with the absorption of light of specific wavelengths. The vasculature behind the retina gives the perception, in general, of an overall pink/red hue. A detached retina or a dead retina will appear white. The choroid can appear as different colors based upon skin pigmentation, but the retina itself does not vary in color.

questions.question: Upon examining your 51 year-old male patient, you observe what appears to be a subtle retinal nerve fiber layer defect. Which of the following colored filters will allow for enhanced visualization of this tissue?
questions.explanation: Localized damage to the retinal nerve fiber layer typically presents as a slit or wedge defect emanating from the margin of the optic disc. The retinal nerve fiber layer is best visualized utilizing a green (red-free) filter during fundus evaluation with the slit-lamp biomicroscope. Red-free filters enhance contrast and allow for a better view of subtle nerve fiber layer defects.

questions.question: Which of the following structures has the greatest oxygen consumption rate?
questions.explanation: The retina utilizes roughly 67 ul/gm/hr of oxygen. This oxygen consumption rate is roughly two times higher than that of the brain, two to five times higher than the cornea, and ten times greater than the oxygen consumption rate of the lens!

questions.question: According to the Keith-Wagener-Barker method of classification, hypertensive retinopathy is categorized as stage four when which ocular sign is present?
options: Hard exudates in a star configuration
questions.explanation:
Grading of hypertensive retinopathy according to the Keith-Wagener-Barker system is as follows: 
Stage 1- narrowing of the retinal arteries 
Stage 2- stage 1, plus focal constriction of the retinal vasculature (arteriovenous nicking) 
Stage 3- stage 2, plus retinal hemorrhages, hard exudates (likely in a star configuration), cotton wool spots, and retinal edema 
Stage 4- stage 3, plus swelling of the optic disc. This patient must be hospitalized immediately.
PowerPage
Hypertensive Retinopathy

questions.question: The INNER blood-retinal barrier is formed in order to restrict the movement of macromolecules within the retina. At which of the following levels of the retina does this occur?
questions.explanation:
The inner blood-retinal barrier is established by the tight junctions that reside between the endothelial cells of the retinal blood vessels. This barrier functions to very tightly regulate the movement of macromolecules from the lumen of the non-fenestrated retinal blood vessels into the interstitial space. 

In addition to the inner blood-retinal barrier, there is also an outer blood-retinal barrier that is created by the tight junctions present between the retinal pigment epithelial cells. The presence of both an intact inner- and outer-blood retinal barrier is essential in maintaining the precise structure and functional integrity of the retina. 

The Retina and its Disorders. Besharse, J. Bok, D. 2011. Academic Press. San Diego, CA. 

Principles of Diabetes Mellitus. Poretsky, L. 2012. Springer. New York, NY.

questions.question: The OUTER blood-retinal barrier is formed in order to prevent the leakage of fluid into the retina. At which of the following levels of the retina does this occur?
questions.explanation:
The outer blood-retinal barrier is established by the tight junctions that are present between the adjacent cells of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). The RPE is a single layer of cells that rests upon the underlying Bruch's membrane. It is this layer that separates the neural retina from the fenestrated vessels of the choriocapillaris. Therefore, the RPE plays an extremely important role in preventing the leakage of fluid from the choroid into the retina. Furthermore, it tightly regulates the passage of nutrients to the photoreceptors while also aiding in eliminating its waste products. 

In addition to the outer blood-retinal barrier, there is also an inner blood-retinal barrier that is created by the tight junctions that reside between the endothelial cells of the retinal vasculature. The presence of both an intact inner- and outer-blood retinal barrier is essential in maintaining the precise structure and functional integrity of the retina. 

The Retina and its Disorders. Besharse, J. Bok, D. 2011. Academic Press. San Diego, CA. 

Principles of Diabetes Mellitus. Poretsky, L. 2012. Springer. New York, NY.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly lists the layers of the retina beginning with the retinal pigment epithelium and moving anteriorly?
options: Retinal pigment epithelium, external limiting membrane, outer nuclear layer, photoreceptor layer, outer plexiform layer, inner nuclear layer, inner plexiform layer, nerve fiber layer, ganglion cell layer, internal limiting membrane

Retinal pigment epithelium, photoreceptor layer, outer nuclear layer, external limiting membrane, outer plexiform layer, inner plexiform layer, inner nuclear layer, ganglion cell layer, nerve fiber layer, internal limiting membrane

Retinal pigment epithelium, photoreceptor layer, external limiting membrane, outer nuclear layer, outer plexiform layer, inner nuclear layer, inner plexiform layer, ganglion cell layer, nerve fiber layer, internal limiting membrane

Retinal pigment epithelium, outer nuclear layer, external limiting membrane, photoreceptor layer, outer plexiform layer, inner plexiform layer, inner nuclear layer, nerve fiber layer, ganglion cell layer, internal limiting membrane
answers: Retinal pigment epithelium, photoreceptor layer, external limiting membrane, outer nuclear layer, outer plexiform layer, inner nuclear layer, inner plexiform layer, ganglion cell layer, nerve fiber layer, internal limiting membrane
questions.explanation:
In order: 
1) The retinal pigment epithelium is a single layer of pigmented cells that functions to form part of the blood-retinal barrier, phagocytose fragments from shedding of photoreceptor discs, and metabolize and store vitamin A which is used in forming photopigment 
2) The photoreceptor cell layer contains the outer and inner segments of rods and cones 
3) The external limiting membrane consists of intercellular junctions of photoreceptor cells
4) The outer nuclear layer contains the cell bodies and nuclei of the rods and cones 
5) The outer plexiform (synaptic) layer is made up of the fibers of rods and cones and synapses between photoreceptor cells and cells from the inner nuclear layer 
6) The inner nuclear layer contains cell bodies of several types of neurons and Muller cells. 
7) The inner plexiform (synaptic) layer contains the synapses of bipolar cell axons and gangion cell dendrites 
8) The ganglion cell layer contains amacrine cells, Muller cell bodies, and astroglial cells 
9) The nerve fiber layer contains the ganglion cell axons 
10) The internal limiting membrane forms the innermost boundary and is composed of footplates of Muller cells 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 p 59-65
PowerPage
Retinal Anatomy

questions.question: Midget ganglion cells receive information pre-synaptically from which cells?
questions.explanation:
Midget bipolar cells synapse onto midget ganglion cells. These are very selective and exclusive channels as one cone cell synapses with one midget bipolar cell which then in turn relays the information to a midget ganglion cell. There is no additional input from other cells or synapses. These types of monosynaptic cells are most common in the central retina thus explaining the ability to visually discern fine details. 

Flat bipolar cells receive information from many cone cells and in turn synapse with many ganglion cells. 

Rod bipolar cells, as their name suggests, convey information from many rod cells to several ganglion cells. Rods relay information only to rod bipolar cells.

questions.question: Which type of cell is responsible for lateral integration of information within the retina?
questions.explanation:
Both amacrine and horizontal cells laterally integrate information, that is, they summate information horizontally across the retina rather than linearly across different layers. Ganglion, bipolar and photoreceptor cells transmit information across layers and not within them. Amacrine cells amalgamate information from ganglion and bipolar cells. There are at least 35 different types of amacrine cells. 

Horizontal cell bodies are located at the outer edge of the inner nuclear layer and combine information from rods and cones. There are at least two or three different types of horizontal cells.

questions.question: Which of the following are TRUE in regards to the structural differences between rod and cone retinal photoreceptor cells?
options: Rods have a greater number of discs in the outer segment than cones
Rods have a larger synaptic terminal as compared to cones
Cones have a longer outer segment than rods
Cones have a higher concentration of photopigment than rods
answers: Rods have a greater number of discs in the outer segment than cones
questions.explanation:
When comparing the structural differences between rod and cone photoreceptors, the following are true: 
- Rods have a longer outer segment than cones and a greater number of membranous discs present in their outer segments 
- Most of these discs are also discrete membranous discs as compared to cone discs, which are formed by folds of the surface membrane of the outer segment 
- Rods have a higher concentration of photopigment than cones 
- Because of this, rods are more highly sensitive to light as compared to cones 
- Cones have a larger synaptic terminal than rods

questions.question: The presence of 'sea-fan' retinopathy is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Sea fan retinopathy is characterized by abnormal, new blood vessel growth in the retina that occurs in association with sickle cell hemoglobinopathies. The anomalous red blood cell shape in sickle cell anemia, along with the increased rigidity of these red blood cells can result in obstruction of small peripheral retinal blood vessels. The occlusion of retinal arteries can cause retinal ischemia, particularly in the peripheral retina, that may lead to the development of arteriovenous anastomoses of pre-existent capillary channels. In some cases, sprouting of new blood vessels from these anastomoses can result, leading to the classic 'sea-fan' configuration that is characteristic of retinopathy associated with sickle cell anemia. In more severe cases, the abnormal new blood vessel growth can continue to proliferate and cause bleeding into the vitreous, or even worse, retinal detachment due to associated fibrovascular proliferation.

questions.question: What is the name of the ocular layer responsible for the appearance of 'eyes that glow in the dark' when a light source is shone at a cat's eyes?
questions.explanation:
The tapetum lucidum is a highly reflective layer that is found in the majority of animals and is located just external to the retina in the upper half of the posterior aspect of the globe. The function of this layer is to reflect incoming light back onto the retina so as to increase the amount of light absorbed by the retinal layer; this enhances vision, particularly in low-light conditions. 

Sattler's layer is a division of the choroidal stroma and contains small caliber blood vessels. 

The choroid is a highly vascular layer that lies external to the retina. This darkly pigmented layer aids in the absorption of stray light, which serves to enhance visual acuity. The choroid also has an important role in nourishment of the retina. 

Muller cell processes extend throughout the length of the retina except the retinal pigment epithelium. Their cell bodies are found in the inner nuclear layer. Muller cells, along with segments of the photoreceptors, create tight junctions and serve to form the external limiting membrane. 

Reference: 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14738502

questions.question: Which type of laser technology depends on the birefringence properties of the retinal nerve fiber layer to measure its thickness?
questions.explanation: Birefringence is the splitting of a light ray (or wave) into two components as it passes through an anisotropic material. In an anisotropic material, the index of refraction is dependent on the direction of light within the material. There are several components of the ocular structure that can be considered birefringent, including the cornea, lens, and retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL). The basis of measuring RNFL thickness in a scanning laser polarimeter (such as the GDx VCC) is due to the birefringent properties of the RNFL. The RNFL is composed of highly ordered parallel axon bundles that contain microtubules and other cylindrical intracellular organelles that have a diameter smaller than the wavelength of light. This highly ordered structure is the source of birefringence of the RNFL. When light waves from the instrument are incident on the birefringent RNFL, the waves are split into two different components that travel at different velocities, creating a phase shift. This phase shift is also known as retardation and is directly proportional to the thickness of the RNFL. Because the cornea and lens are also considered birefringent structures, this instrument must compensate for the anterior segment birefringence in order to produce an accurate measure of the RNFL thickness.

questions.question: The deflection of retinal veins at arteriovenous crossings that occurs in association with hypertensive retinopathy is known as which of the following signs?
questions.explanation:
Salus' sign is a clinical indication of hypertensive retinopathy that is characterized by the deflection of retinal veins at arteriovenous crossings. The presence of this sign indicates Grade 2 hypertensive retinopathy. 

Bonnet sign involves the funduscopic observation of the banking of veins distal to the site of arteriovenous crossings, while Gunn sign is characterized by tapering of veins occurring on either side of the crossings. Both Bonnet and Gunn signs are clinical findings associated with Grade 3 hypertensive retinopathy.

questions.question: A retinal detachment in which vitreous contraction leads to the neurosensory retina being pulled away from the retinal pigment epithelium in the absence of a retinal break is known as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
A tractional retinal detachment occurs secondary to the contraction of vitreoretinal membranes, which leads to the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). Tractional retinal detachments occur in the absence of a retinal break or tear. 

Serous retinal detachments (also known as exudative or secondary retinal detachments) do not occur as a result of a retinal tear or retinal traction but as a result of subretinal fluid that accumulates between the neurosensory retina and RPE, leading to a separation of the tissue. This subretinal fluid is derived from the vessels of the neurosensory retina, the choroid, or in some cases, both. 

Cases in which there is a full thickness defect in the sensory retina that causes a detachment of the retina can be classified as a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (rhegma=break). In these cases, the retinal break permits liquefied vitreous fluid to gain access to the subretinal space, subsequently creating a separation of the tissue. 

There are some instances of a retinal detachment that can occur as a result of a combination of a retinal break and retinal traction. Typically, the retinal break is caused by tractional forces from an adjacent area of fibrovascular proliferation and contraction. This is most commonly observed in advanced cases of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

questions.question: Which of the following 2 conditions are associated with angioid streaks? (Select 2)
questions.explanation: Angioid streaks, which are breaks in Bruch's membrane, usually appear to diverge from the optic nerve. The breaks appear as well-demarcated red/orange or brown lines (depending upon the amount of pigment involved). Angioid streaks are associated with sickle-cell retinopathy, Paget's disease, pseudoxanthoma elasticum, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

questions.question: You decide to use your Goldmann 3-mirror lens to better evaluate a retinal hole at the temporal periphery of your patient's retina. Which mirror would afford the best view of this region, and which direction would you orient the lens?
options: Square mirror / Oriented in the same direction as the lesion
Square mirror / Oriented 180 degrees from the lesion
Trapezoid mirror / Oriented in the same direction as the lesion
Bullet mirror / Oriented 180 degrees from the lesion
Trapezoid mirror / Oriented 180 degrees from the lesion
Bullet mirror / Oriented in the same direction as the lesion
answers: Square mirror / Oriented 180 degrees from the lesion
questions.explanation:
The Goldmann 3-mirror lens is comprised of a central Hruby lens surrounded by 3 viewing mirrors of different sizes and viewing angles, allowing for evaluation of different ocular structures. The central lens is a 64 diopter lens that is used for viewing of the posterior pole (also known as the Hruby lens). The smallest mirror is the bullet (or thumbnail) shaped mirror, which is used for examination of anterior chamber structures (angles) as well as the ora serrata, due to the angle that the mirror is positioned (59 degrees). The middle-sized lens is square-shaped and has a different angle of orientation (67 degrees) permitting the observation of the retina anterior to the equator or the peripheral retina. Lastly, the larger trapezoidal-shaped mirror is oriented such that it allows for viewing of the retina between the equator and the macula (73 degrees). 

Because these are mirrors, the location of the area that is examined is 180 degrees opposite from the position of the mirror. It is also helpful to understand that if the patient looks toward a mirror, the observer will view a less peripheral region of the retina. Mirrored lenses also posses a shallow depth of focus, which is valuable when a questionable retinal break cannot be clearly defined on ophthalmoscopy. 

Steidl, S, Hartnett, M.A. (2003). Clinical Pathways in Vitreoretinal Disease. New York, NY: Thieme Medical Publishers, Inc. 

Brinton, D.A., Vilkinson, C.P. (2009). Retinal Detachment: Principles and Practice. New York, NY: Oxford University Press, Inc.

questions.question: Your 62 year-old female patient presents with complaints of a dark spot in the center of her vision in her right eye. A dilated fundus examination reveals a full-thickness macular hole with a small surrounding cuff of subretinal fluid and yellow deposits at the base of the defect. There is no observable posterior vitreous detachment. What stage would you categorize this macular hole?
questions.explanation:
Stage 3 macular holes typically have the following appearance: 
- A full-thickness macular hole (350-600um) is present, having a smooth-edged appearance and a small, surrounding, donut-shaped cuff of subretinal fluid 
- Yellow deposits can be observed at the base of the neuroretinal defect, along with perifoveal cystic changes
