- At this stage an operculum may be present, but vitreofoveal separation still has not occurred

questions.question: The presence of 'copper-wiring' of the retinal arterioles observed in association with hypertension is indicative of which stage of hypertensive retinopathy?
questions.explanation:
The grading of hypertensive retinopathy is summarized below: 
- Stage 1 
- Subtle broadening of the arteriolar light reflex 
- Mild general attenuation of the retinal arteries 
- Stage 2 
- More obvious broadening of the arteriolar light reflex 
- Salus' sign: deflection of vein observed at arteriovenous crossings 
- Stage 3 
- 'Copper-wiring' of retinal arterioles 
- Bonnet sign: banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings 
- Gunn sign: tapering of retinal veins on either side of arteriovenous crossings 
- Right-angled deflection of retinal veins 
- Stage 4 
- 'Silver-wiring' of retinal arterioles in associated with findings observed in Stage 3 hypertensive retinopathy
PowerPage
Hypertensive Retinopathy

questions.question: Which of the following juvenile onset macular diseases results in the development of a macular lesion consisting of an accumulation of lipofuscin within the retinal pigment epithelium?
questions.explanation:
Juvenile Best disease, or vitelliform macular dystrophy, is a rare hereditary macular disease (autosomal dominant with variable penetrance) that typically presents in childhood or early adulthood. The progression of Best disease is very characteristic, as the appearance of the vitelliform lesions are classically grouped into 5 stages: 
- Stage 0 (pre-vitelliform): Children in this stage are usually asymptomatic and possess a normal fundus appearance; an electrooculogram (EOG) performed in this stage will reveal a subnormal result 
- Stage 1: Patients will begin to develop pigmentary mottling in the area of the macula 
- Stage 2 (vitelliform): This stage commonly begins in early childhood and typically does not impair visual acuity; the classic 'sunny-side up' egg yolk appearance in the area of the macula develops due to an accumulation of lipofuscin within the retinal pigment epithelium 
- Stage 3 (pseudo-hypopyon): This stage usually occurs near puberty in which part of the macular lesion becomes absorbed; over time, absorption may continue, and the entire lesion can become completely absorbed with minimal effect on vision 
- Stage 4 (vitelliruptive): Fundus examination in this stage will reveal the classic 'scrambled egg' appearance in which the vitelliform lesion begins to break up; visual acuity typically begins to drop as patients may develop fibrous scarring in the macular region, geographic atrophy, or a choroidal neovascular membrane (this usually occurs around the fifth decade)

questions.question: At which location in the eye is the most common site of occurrence for a branch retinal vein occlusion (BRVO)?
questions.explanation:
Branch retinal vein occlusions (BRVO) are the most common type of vascular occlusion encountered in clinic. Common associations include, but are not limited to: hypertension, diabetes, and congestive heart failure. The superior temporal vein is the most frequently involved, followed by the inferior temporal vein. The nasal quadrants are rarely involved. The pathogenesis of a BRVO results from compression of the vein by the overlying artery impeding blood flow return. The blood accumulates and eventually leaks out of the vessel, resulting in retinal hemorrhages. Some researchers have suggested that the superior temporal quadrant of the eye has the greatest amount of arterial/vein crossing junctions, and therefore possesses a higher likelihood of involvement. Visual acuity may be compromised, depending upon the presence of macular involvement. Greater amounts of ischemia increase the chances of complications such as neovascularization of the retina and rubeosis iridis. 

Reference: Joussen, A. Gardner, T and Kirchhof, G. Retinal Vascular Disease (2007) pp. 467-476.

questions.question: Which of the following regions of the retina is considered the MOST common site of a retinal break in patients with a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment?
questions.explanation: The most common site for a retinal break in eyes with a retinal detachment is the superior temporal quadrant, which accounts for approximately 60% of cases. This is followed by the superior nasal and inferior temporal quadrants (both of which comprise roughly 15% of cases), and the least common area is the inferior nasal quadrant (10%). Therefore, in cases where a retinal break is suspected, the superior temporal quadrant should be carefully examined initially. It is also important to note that close to 50% of eyes with a retinal detachment will have more than one retinal break, typically within 90 degrees of each other.

questions.question: Which lamina of the choroid does NOT contain melanocytes?
questions.explanation:
The suprachoroid is the outermost layer of the choroid and serves as a transition junction between the sclera and the choroid. The suprachoroid is comprised mostly of 10-15 layers of collagen which bind to the lamina fusca of the sclera. Many melanocytes and fibroblasts are located in this layer. 

Haller's layer and Sattler's layer together form the vessel layer or the stroma. This layer is largely comprised of blood vessels. Haller's layer lays external to Sattler's layer and contains larger vessels (one way to remember the caliber of the vessels is that the 'll' in Haller matches the 'l' in large). Sattler's layer is characterized by smaller blood vessels (the 'S' in Sattler matches the 's' in small). In general, the diameter of the blood vessels becomes smaller as one proceeds from the outer edge to the inner edge of the stroma. The stroma appears brown in color due to the presence of melanocytes. 

The choriocapillaris is located internally to the stroma. This layer is characteristic of a network of capillaries that serve to maintain the outer retina. The capillaries in the choroid differ from those of the rest of the body in that they are slightly wider and allow the passage of several blood cells at a time, whereas those of the body are narrower and only allow blood cells to pass one by one in a linear fashion. Choriocapillaris does not contain melanocytes.

questions.question: What is the correct order of the choroidal lamina from most external to most internal?
options: Suprachoroid-> Bruch's membrane-> Choriocapillaris-> Stroma (vessel layer)
Choriocapillaris-> Stroma (vessel layer)-> Suprachoroid-> Bruch's membrane
Suprachoroid-> Stroma (vessel layer)-> Choriocapillaris-> Bruch's membrane
Stroma (vessel layer)-> Suprachoroid-> Bruch's membrane-> Choriocapillaris
answers: Suprachoroid-> Stroma (vessel layer)-> Choriocapillaris-> Bruch's membrane
questions.explanation:
The correct order of the choroidal lamina from the most external to most internal is the suprachoroid followed by the stroma (or the vessel layer) which is succeeded by choriocapillaris and lastly Bruch's membrane. 

The suprachoroid is the outermost layer of the choroid and serves as a transition junction between the sclera and the choroid. The suprachoroid is comprised mostly of 10-15 layers of collagen which bind to the lamina fusca of the sclera. Many melanocytes and fibroblasts are located in this layer. 

Haller's layer and Sattler's layer together form the vessel layer or the stroma. This layer is largely comprised of blood vessels. Haller's layer lays external to Sattler's layer and contains larger vessels (one way to remember the caliber of the vessels is that the 'll' in Haller matches the 'l' in large). Sattler's layer is characteristic of smaller blood vessels (the 'S' in Sattler matches the 's' in small). In general, the diameter of the blood vessels becomes smaller as one proceeds from the outer to the inner edge of the stroma. The stroma appears brown in color due to the presence of melanocytes. 

The choriocapillaris is located internally to the stroma. This layer is characteristic of a network of capillaries that serve to maintain the outer retina. The capillaries in the choroid differ from those of the rest of the body in that they are slightly wider and allow the passage of several blood cells whereas those of the body are narrower allowing for blood cells to pass one by one in a linear fashion. Choriocapillaris does not contain melanocytes. 

Bruch's membrane lies between the choriocapillaris of the choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium of the retina. Although this membrane is very thin (about 2 microns thick) it is very complex. The membrane consists of five facets. The outermost component is the basement membrane of the choriocapillaris which is followed by the outer collagenous zone, the elastic layer, the inner collagenous zone and most internally the basement membrane of the retinal pigment epithelium.

questions.question: A 35 year-old male presents to your office with sudden loss of vision in his left eye that began a few days ago following a chest-compressing injury that occurred at his work. Dilated fundus evaluation reveals multiple, superficial, white retinal patches, along with several superficial peripapillary hemorrhages. What is the MOST likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Purtscher's retinopathy is a retinal condition that typically occurs following severe trauma (especially to the head) or in patients with a history of a recent chest compressive injury. Patients will commonly present with severely decreased visual acuity in one or both eyes that develops either immediately or within 48 hours following the event. Retinal observations commonly include superficial, white, retinal patches resembling cotton-wool spots, pre-retinal and/or retinal hemorrhages, macular edema, dilated retinal veins, and possible optic disc edema or optic disc pallor. 

The underlying pathophysiology of the development of Purtscher's retinopathy is not fully understood; however, the classic mechanism proposes that the injury creates an intravascular hydrostatic shock wave that travels to the retinal vasculature and results in endothelial cell damage of the retinal veins, macular capillaries, and radial peripapillary capillaries. The problem with this theory is that it does not account for the development of this type of retinopathy in patients without a traumatic event (emboli, pancreatitis, connective tissue diseases, bone marrow transplantation, etc.). There is no known treatment for Purtscher's retinopathy except for proper management of the underlying cause. Prognosis for visual recovery is variable because, although retinal findings tend to resolve within a few weeks, about 50% of patients will experience persistent prolonged blurring of central vision due to irreversible macular or optic nerve damage. 

Terson syndrome occurs when a vitreous hemorrhage is accompanied by a subarachnoid hemorrhage. Commotio retinae appears as a grey-white discoloration of the retina that occurs following blunt ocular trauma. It is a result of the disruption of the photoreceptor outer-segments. This condition can present peripherally and may cause severe or permanent visual loss if damage occurs in the region of the macula.

questions.question: A central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) causes tremendous damage to the retina. How will the electroretinogram (ERG) of a person who has suffered a CRAO be affected?
options: The a-wave will remain while the b-wave will disappear
Both the a-wave and the b-wave will remain
The a-wave will disappear while the b-wave will remain
Both the a-wave and the b-wave will disappear
answers: The a-wave will remain while the b-wave will disappear
questions.explanation: A central retinal artery occlusion will cause a loss of the b-wave which is formed by responses from the bipolar and Muller cells, both of which are nourished by the central retinal artery. The a-wave results from excitation of the photoreceptors. The a-wave will not be lost in the event of a CRAO due to the fact that photoreceptors receive their oxygen supply via the choroid.

questions.question: Retinal detachments most commonly occur between which layers of the retina?
options: The choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium
The retinal pigment epithelium and the photoreceptor cell layer
The photoreceptor cell layer and the external limiting membrane
The ganglion cell layer and the nerve fiber layer
The nerve fiber layer and the internal limiting membrane
answers: The retinal pigment epithelium and the photoreceptor cell layer
questions.explanation:
Retinal detachments usually occur between the RPE and the photoreceptor cell layer because there are no intercellular connections joining them. The RPE cells are tightly attached to the choroid. As a result, retinal detachment separates the photoreceptors from their blood supply in the choroid; this leads to photoreceptor necrosis if the detachment is not repositioned quickly. 

Ref: Remington, LA. Clinical Anatomy of the Visual System, 1998 p 52

questions.question: The perichoroidal space of the eye is continuous anteriorly with a potential space between which two structures?
options: The ciliary body and the sclera
The ciliary body and the lens
answers: The ciliary body and the sclera
questions.explanation: The perichoroidal space is a potential space between the lamina fusca of the sclera and the choroid. This potential space allows for arteries and nerves to pass through en route to their appropriate destinations. The perichoroidal space is continuous anteriorly with a potential space that lies between the sclera and the ciliary body.

questions.question: The uveal tract is comprised of which three structures?
options: The ciliary body, the lens and the retina
The iris, ciliary body and the choroid
The optic nerve, the lens and the episclera
The choroid, the retina and the episclera
The iris, the retina and the optic nerve
answers: The iris, ciliary body and the choroid
questions.explanation: The uveal tract is comprised of (from most anterior to posterior) the iris, the ciliary body and the choroid.

questions.question: Choriocapillaris, one of the lamina of the choroid, is continuous anteriorly with what layer of the ciliary body?
options: The basal lamina of the ciliary body
None, choriocapillaris ends with the retina
answers: None, choriocapillaris ends with the retina
questions.explanation: The choriocapillaris of the choroid does not extend past the retina and therefore is not continuous with any layers of the ciliary body.

questions.question: Which retinal layer serves as an interface between the retina and the vitreous?
questions.explanation:
The layers progress in the following way: 
Retinal pigment epithelium-> photoreceptor cell layer-> external limiting membrane-> outer nuclear layer-> outer plexiform (synaptic) layer-> inner nuclear layer-> inner plexiform (synaptic) layer-> ganglion cell layer-> nerve fiber layer-> internal limiting membrane 

The internal limiting membrane forms the innermost boundary and is composed of footplates of Muller cells. This layer serves as the interface between the vitreous humor and the retinal tissue. It is attached at the ora, optic nerve, and macula. The external limiting membrane consists of intercellular junctions of photoreceptor cells. The nerve fiber layer contains the ganglion cell axons. The retinal pigment epithelium is a single layer of pigmented cells that functions in three ways: to form part of the blood-retinal barrier, to phagocytosize fragments from shedding of photoreceptor discs, and to metabolize and store the vitamin A used in forming photopigment.

questions.question: Drusen typically deposit between which layers of the retina?
options: The ganglion cell layer and the nerve fiber layer
The retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane
The inner and outer plexiform layers
The inner and outer nuclear layers
answers: The retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane
questions.explanation: Drusen deposits collect between the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and Bruch's membrane. The retinal pigment epithelium plays a very important role in phagocytosis of shed outer segments of photoreceptors. If the RPE fails to rid the retina of this debris, it will begin to accumulate, which can have a significant impact on vision and may lead to macular degeneration.

questions.question: You wish to evaluate the posterior pole of your patient's retina using the central Hruby lens of your Goldmann 3 mirror lens. Which of the following is an ADVANTAGE to using the Hruby lens of your Goldmann 3 mirror lens versus a 90 D condensing lens?
options: The Hruby lens allows for a resultant upright image
The resultant views are equal for the Goldmann 3 mirror lens and a 90 D condensing lens
You cannot examine the posterior pole with a Goldmann 3 mirror lens
There is less patient discomfort associated with the Goldmann 3 mirror lens
answers: The Hruby lens allows for a resultant upright image
questions.explanation: The Hruby lens of the Goldmann 3 mirror offers excellent views of the posterior pole, while also affording stereopsis and a virtual, upright image. However, due to the fact that the cornea of your patient must be anesthetized and many patients may become anxious having a lens physically placed on their eye, overall patient comfort is better with a 78 D or 90 D condensing lens used in conjunction with the slit lamp.

questions.question: Flame hemorrhages that are characteristic of hypertensive retinopathy occur in what layer of the retina?
questions.explanation:
Flame hemorrhages occur at the level of the nerve fiber layer and stem from blood loss from the inner capillary network of the retinal vasculature. These types of hemorrhages are commonly seen in hypertensive patients, vein occlusions, as well as optic neuropathies such as papilledema. The characteristic flame shape occurs because the blood will take the path of least resistance and follow the structure of the nerve fiber layer.
PowerPage
Hypertensive Retinopathy

questions.question: Which layer of the retina is responsible for phagocytosis of the outer segments of the photoreceptors once they have been shed?
questions.explanation:
The retinal pigment epithelium plays a very important role in phagocytosis of shed outer segments. If the RPE fails to rid the retina of this debris, it will begin to accumulate which can have a significant impact on vision and may lead to macular degeneration. 

The outer plexiform layer is the location at which rods and cones synapse onto horizontal and bipolar cells. 

The inner nuclear layer contains the cell bodies of bipolar, horizontal and amacrine cells. 

The external limiting membrane serves as a distinction between the inner segments of the photoreceptors and their respective nuclei. 

The inner plexiform layer consists of synapses between bipolar, amacrine and ganglion cells.

questions.question: The patellar fossa of the vitreous is bounded by which other structure of the eye?
options: The posterior surface of the lens
answers: The posterior surface of the lens
questions.explanation: The vitreous is essentially spherical in shape except for its anterior portion, which abuts the posterior surface of the lens and ciliary body, creating a saucer or knee-shaped depression into the vitreous (hence the term 'patellar fossa').

questions.question: What retinal landmark of the peripheral fundus is typically located at the 3 o'clock and 9 o'clock meridians?
questions.explanation: There are several retinal landmarks in the peripheral fundus. The long ciliary nerves are generally white/tan in color and located in suprachoroidal space. The nerves usually extend from the mid-equatorial region to the ora serrata along the 3 o'clock and 9 o'clock meridians. The vortex vein ampullae are located in the four quadrants of the eye, with the number per quadrant varying between individuals. The posterior edge of the vortex vein ampullae marks the posterior edge of the equatorial region. The short ciliary nerves may sometimes be difficult to visualize. The short ciliary nerves vary in location; they are commonly located at the 12 o'clock and 6 o'clock positions, but they may also be oriented radially. The macula, the optic nerve head, and the vascular arcades are located in the posterior pole, which is considered a part of the central fundus and not the peripheral fundus.

questions.question: The rhodopsin molecule is found at which location in a rod photoreceptor?
options: The membrane of the inner segment
The membrane of the outer segment
answers: The membrane of the outer segment
questions.explanation: Rhodopsin is embedded in the discs of the outer segment of the rod and absorbs a photon of light, causing an electrical change in the membrane of the rod. It is necessary for several rods to summate in order to signal the presence of a stimulus. Rods then release glutamate post-synaptically to bipolar and horizontal cells.

questions.question: The cells of which layer of the retina serve as a storage site for vitamin A?
questions.explanation:
Cells found in the retinal pigment epithelial layer serve as a storage site for vitamin A. Vitamin A is classified as a retinoid with its active form being retinol. Retinol is necessary for the formation of rhodopsin, a pigment used by rods. Rods are most active in situations with dim illumination. Less rhodopsin results in fewer rods being able to respond in low levels of light causing prolonged dark adaption. 

The outer plexiform layer is the location at which rods and cones synapse onto horizontal and bipolar cells. 

The nerve fiber layer is comprised of ganglion cell axons. 

The inner nuclear layer contains the cell bodies of bipolar, horizontal and amacrine cells. 

The external limiting membrane serves as a distinction between the inner segments of the photoreceptors and their respective nuclei.

questions.question: Which of the following structures serves as the strongest attachment point of the vitreous?
questions.explanation: The ora serrata, which also serves as the anterior vitreous base is the strongest point of attachment of the vitreous. The second strongest point of attachment is the optic nerve head. A detachment of the posterior hyaloid from the optic nerve head results in a posterior vitreal detachment (PVD) commonly reported in the elderly as the sudden appearance of a large floater that is oval or circular in shape (Weiss ring). The macula is the third strongest point of attachment, followed by the blood vessels.

questions.question: Which area of a retinal photoreceptor contains many mitochondria responsible for the overall metabolism of the cell?
questions.explanation: The inner segment of a photoreceptor can be divided into two regions, the myoid region and the ellipsoid region. The myoid region lays internal to the ellipsoid area and tends to be less ordered. The myoid region contains vesicles derived from the Golgi apparatus and the endoplasmic reticulum. One also sees ribosomes in this area as the synthesis of proteins occurs in the myoid. The ellipsoid region is more structured and houses many mitochondria (30-50 on average).

questions.question: Which 3 of the following layers are pushed aside at the foveola? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: In order to maximize cone function and acuity, the fovea displays certain structural differences when compared to the rest of the retina. At the fovea, the bipolar and ganglion cell layers are pushed aside. At the foveola, the inner plexiform layer, the inner nuclear layer, the ganglion cell and the nerve fiber layer are all pushed aside. Essentially, at the center of the foveola the cones, internal limiting membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium are the only layers that are present. Remember, the fovea is also avascular.

questions.question: Electroretinograms (ERGs) are used to help determine if certain cells of the retina are deficient. Which cells are responsible for producing the A-wave?
questions.explanation: Electroretinograms (ERGs) are created by electric currents across the eye (the cornea is positive relative to the retinal pigment epithelium). ERGs are formed via the summation of the different electrical responses of the retina to various stimuli. In other words, when the retina is stimulated, specific cells become excited forming the electrical wave that creates the ERG. The A-wave of the ERG is formed by the photoreceptors. The B-wave occurs due to the responses from bipolar and Mueller cells. The C-wave is created by responses from retinal pigment epithelial cells, and the D-wave is attributable to activity of the OFF bipolar cells. The C-wave and the D-wave are not used clinically very often because they are susceptible to being obscured by blinking of the eye. It is also noteworthy that oscillations seen in the B-wave are due to responses of the amacrine cells.

questions.question: Which layer of the retina is heavily pigmented and serves to absorb stray light in order to allow for glare reduction?
questions.explanation:
The retinal pigment epithelial (RPE)layer contains pigment that aids in the reduction of light scatter by absorbing stray light. 

The choroid, although pigmented, is not considered a part of the retina. 

The outer plexiform layer is the location at which rods and cones synapse onto horizontal and bipolar cells. 

The rod and cone layer contains the receptive segments of the photoreceptors whose primary function is to absorb light. However, stray light that has not been absorbed by the cones and rods passes through to the RPE where it is then absorbed.

questions.question: The greatest concentration of hyaluronic acid is found in which portion of the vitreous?
questions.explanation:
The vitreal cortex is formed of condensed collagen fibrils, mucopolysaccharides and proteins which serves to envelop the vitreous body. The concentration of hyaluronic acid is approximately five to ten times greater than the inner vitreous. 

The primary vitreous develops at around the third week of gestation. It is formed by mesoderm. The secondary vitreous begins to develop during the ninth embryonic week. This later becomes the mature vitreous. The secondary vitreous stems from primary vitreal cells and retinal glial cells and therefore originates from neuroectoderm. The secondary vitreous expands to fill the globs while compacting the primary vitreous in the center of the globe. 

The hyaloid artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery and is important for delivering nutrients to the lens and structures behind the lens during development. The artery disintegrates before birth leaving a canal in the primary vitreous called Cloquet's canal. Remnants of this artery are often perceived as 'floaters'.

questions.question: Your 67 year-old male patient presents with flame-shaped and dot-blot hemorrhages in the inferior retina of his left eye secondary to a branch retinal vein occlusion. Which of the following statements best describes the MOST common etiology of this ocular condition?
options: Thickening of an overlying retinal arteriole compressing the vein, resulting in a focal venous occlusion
Intimal thickening of a vein resulting in progressive narrowing of the central lumen and eventual venous occlusion
A migrating emboli, most commonly from an atheromatous plaque, becomes lodged at a vessel bifurcation, leading to the occlusion of a retinal vein
Significantly elevated intraocular pressure leading to compression of a retinal vein and subsequent venous occlusion
answers: Thickening of an overlying retinal arteriole compressing the vein, resulting in a focal venous occlusion
questions.explanation:
Retinal venous occlusive diseases (such as branch retinal vein occlusions and central retinal vein occlusions) have an important association with arteriosclerotic disease. Retinal arterioles and their corresponding retinal veins share a common adventitial sheath at arteriovenous crossings. It is because of this characteristic that when a retinal artery becomes hardened and thickened as a result of arteriosclerosis, significant compression on the adjacent retinal vein can occur. Progressive and prolonged venous compression also causes changes in the retinal veins, which includes loss of venous endothelial cells and thrombus formation. Eventually, the artery will compress the vein enough that this, in conjunction with the other associated microvascular changes, will result in occlusion of the retinal vein leading to a central, or more commonly, branch retinal vein occlusion. 

Elevated intraocular pressure can also cause a venous occlusion; however, this most commonly results as a central retinal vein occlusion wherein the site of occlusion involves the edge of the optic cup.

questions.question: Which of the following medications/supplements, if used in high doses, may produce crystalline retinopathy, whereby bilateral, fine, yellow deposits can be observed in the inner layers of the retina?
questions.explanation:
Canthaxanthin is a carotenoid supplement that was previously used by individuals to enhance sun tanning. If it is used in high doses over a long period of time, tiny yellow, discrete, glistening deposits may present in a symmetric doughnut shape surrounding the macula. 

Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are systemic medications that also may produce retinal toxicity. The classic signs of retinopathy in these cases involves a 'bulls-eye' macular lesion that presents as a central island of pigment, surrounded by a hypopigmented zone of RPE atrophy that is also encircled by another area of hyperpigmentation. 

Chlorpromazine and thioridazine belong to the phenothiazines class of medication and also may cause retinal toxicity in high daily dosages. Retinopathy is typically characterized by pigmentary granularity and clumping in the mid-periphery and posterior pole. In addition to pigmentary changes, chlorpromazine may also cause focal or diffuse atrophy of the RPE and choriocapillaris.

questions.question: Junctions between which cells in the retina prevent proteins from entering the retina from the choroid?
options: Tight junctions between the retinal pigment epithelial cells
answers: Tight junctions between the retinal pigment epithelial cells
questions.explanation:
The blood ocular barrier, specifically the blood retinal barrier, is the result of tight junctions at the base of retinal pigment epithelial cells and non-fenestrated capillaries. Normally, oxygen, carbon dioxide, ions, and glucose are free to enter the retina while the tight junctions prevent the passage of proteins from any leaky choroidal vessels. 

Circulating drugs and hormones are capable of affecting the choroid as these vessels are more permeable than retinal vessels. The retina is mostly impervious to the effects of systemic drugs and hormones due to the blood-retinal barrier created by the RPE. Circulating drugs that affect blood pressure are capable of altering retinal blood flow.

questions.question: On binocular indirect ophthalmoscopy of your 43 year-old patient, you see what appears to be a small U-shaped retinal tear in the far periphery at the 12 o'clock position of the left eye. You decide to use your 3-mirror Goldmann lens to obtain another view of the retina. Which 2 of the following modifications can be made in order to allow for the furthest possible peripheral view? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
There are some cases where a more peripheral view of the retina is desired than that which can be achieved with the patient in primary gaze and the Goldmann lens held in the upright position. In these situations, certain modifications can be made such as tilting the Goldmann lens or having the patient move their eyes. The lens should be tilted in the opposite direction of the location of the lesion, and the patient should be instructed to look in the actual direction of the area being viewed. 

For example, in the above question, the suspected lesion is at the 12 o'clock position. To obtain a more peripheral view, the lens should be tilted down, and the patient should be asked to look up.

questions.question: During routine ophthalmoscopy, a 'bright refractile plaque' is identified in a retinal arteriole. What is the most important test to order?
options: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain
questions.explanation: These plaques represent embolic phenomena referred to as Hollenhorst plaques. They are associated with atherosclerosis and a risk of stroke, possibly making all four tests appropriate. An MRI of the brain seeking other embolic activity, a treadmill to rule out coronary artery disease, and an EKG to establish a baseline are all reasonable, but the urgently needed test is a carotid ultrasound. The majority of Hollenhorst plaques comes from the carotid arteries and implies a risk of stroke in the near-term. This makes the rapid identification and institution of anti-platelet therapy with a referral to a vascular surgeon for a possible carotid an urgent referral. Hollenhorst plaque is a strong risk factor for stroke and is associated with atherosclerosis throughout the body but most particularly in the carotid artery. Therefore, a carotid Doppler ultrasound is the most important test to order.

questions.question: A patient is concerned with an acute reduction of the acuity in the right eye. You correctly diagnose central serous retinopathy, and confirm your diagnosis with an optical coherence tomography (OCT). What is the standard treatment protocol?
options: Treat the patient with prism as they are likely to develop diplopia
Refer for cryotherapy of the retina
Refer for laser treatment of the retina
questions.explanation: CSR is more commonly seen in middle-aged males under high-stress, who are very anxious, or with type A personalities. This condition causes fluid to leak from the choriocapillaries into the subretinal area, causing a serous detachment of the neurosensory retina. There is an associated loss of the foveal reflex, a hyperopic shift, a potential relative scotoma, and metamorphopsia. Flourescein angiography will reveal hyperfluorescence that appears like a smoke-stack. Evaluation of the posterior pole will typically display a blister-like elevation of the neurosensory retina. The patient is monitored monthly and intervention is rarely required, as most cases of CSR will resolve within roughly 6 months.

questions.question: Lipemia retinalis is a retinal finding associated with markedly high levels of which of the following?
questions.explanation: There remains much controversy about the importance of triglycerides. They are an independent risk factor, but does treatment alter the outcome of cardiovascular disease? The treatment includes fish oil (or a prescription form, Lovaza), fenofibrate (common brand names include Trilipix and Tricor) and formally Gemfibrozil. Lipemia retinalis indicates that the triglyceride level is probably greater than 1000, indicating a possibility of the development of pancreatitis, so treatment is unequivocally indicated. The best treatment approach for modestly elevated triglycerides is diet, weight loss, alcohol avoidance, and restriction of simple carbohydrates such as wheat, flour, and sugar.

questions.question: Although controversial, it has been purported that supplementation of vitamin A is important in the management of retinitis pigmentosa. Which of the following agents, when taken in excess amounts, may interfere with the uptake of Vitamin A?
questions.explanation:
Vitamin A plays an important role in vision, and it is currently believed that daily supplementation of 15,000IU of Vitamin A may aid in decreasing the progression of retinitis pigmentosa. Research has demonstrated that taking increased levels of vitamin E simultaneously with higher doses of vitamin A may interfere with the uptake and distribution of vitamin A. Therefore, it is recommended that patients taking vitamin A for the management of retinitis pigmentosa avoid ingestion of higher amounts of vitamin E. 

Review of Optometry. Vol. 151 No. 2, February 15, 2014, page 83. 
http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/70/5/793.full

questions.question: Which of the following retinal structures represents the WEAKEST attachment site for the posterior cortical vitreous?
questions.explanation:
The vitreous body is normally attached posteriorly to several structures of the eye including the peripheral retinal blood vessels, macula, optic nerve head, and the vitreous base (which straddles the ora serrata). As the vitreous degenerates with age, a posterior vitreous detachment is a common observation that occurs as a result of the separation of the posterior hyaloid membrane from the internal limiting membrane of the retina; this can occur at any point posterior to the vitreous base. The most common location of a posterior vitreous detachment is at the site of vitreopapillary separation. 

The strongest area of attachment of the vitreous is at the ora serrata (vitreous base), followed by the optic nerve head. The adhesion in the area of the fovea is fairly weak, while the weakest attachment site of the vitreous body is along the peripheral retinal blood vessels.

questions.question: What is the MOST common complication of a posterior vitreal detachment?
questions.explanation: Syneresis and liquification of the vitreous are part of the normal aging process, but they also may cause a posterior vitreal detachment (PVD). Generally, PVDs occur without complication except for the perception of an annoying floater by the patient which will regress somewhat with time. Rarely, a PVD can cause a retinal tear which may lead to a retinal detachment, epiretinal membranes, and vitreal and retinal hemorrhages. Monitor the patient carefully to ensure that none of these complications develop and be sure to educate patients regarding the signs and symptoms of a retinal detachment.

questions.question: A breakdown of the vitreous gel due to an increase in the liquid portion of the vitreous is known as which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
Vitreous syneresis occurs with advancing age, with a higher incidence noted in myopes and diabetics. Syneresis is caused by a separation of the fluid and solid components of the vitreous, resulting in the gel-like matrix of the vitreous becoming more liquefied. This liquification can lead to a posterior vitreous detachment. 

Asteroid hyalosis is generally a unilateral condition that presents as hundreds of small white calcium soap deposits suspended in the vitreous. The calcium soaps are attached to the collagen in the vitreous; hence, they do not fall to the bottom of the globe. Surprisingly, these deposits rarely affect visual acuity. 

A vitrectomy is surgical removal of the vitreous from the eye; this procedure is generally undertaken secondary to a large vitreal hemorrhage or in the event of a retinal detachment. 

Synchysis scintillans is generally a bilateral condition in which cholesterol crystals are found in the vitreous. The crystals are not attached and therefore tend to sink to the bottom of the globe due to gravitational forces. These crystals have not been linked to any systemic condition.

questions.question: You are examining your 67 year-old patient who reports a sudden onset of a floater in her left eye. Dilated fundus exam reveals a solitary annular floater representing the detachment of the vitreous from the margin of the optic disc. What is this observation known as?
questions.explanation:
A Weiss ring is a solitary vitreal floater that typically has an annular shape, which represents the detachment of the vitreous from the margin of the optic disc. Patients will commonly report observing a large floater that is typically located slightly off to the temporal portion of their vision (due to the location of the optic nerve with respect to the macula). A Weiss ring is the most common finding associated with an acute posterior vitreous detachment. 

Bergmeister's papilla is a small tuft of fibrovascular tissue attached to the optic nerve, representing a remnant of the hyaloid artery. The anterior segment remnant of the hyaloid artery, which is apparent on the posterior surface of the crystalline lens in some patients, is known as a Mittendorf dot. Cloquet's canal is the small transparent canal that runs through the vitreous connecting the lens to the optic nerve, which once contained the hyaloid artery during fetal development.

questions.question: You wish to examine the nerve fiber layer of a patient while using the direct ophthalmoscope. Which filter will serve to enhance your views and any possible nerve fiber layer defects?
options: No filter yields the most accurate assessment
questions.explanation:
The red-free filter serves to enhance the assessment of the nerve fiber layer, choroidal lesions, and retinal vasculature. 

The yellow filter helps to protect the ocular structures by blocking infrared and UV light. 

The cobalt blue filter, used in conjunction with sodium fluorescein, is useful for the evaluation of the integrity of the cornea.

questions.question: You wish to evaluate the ora serrata of your patient's retina using a Goldmann 3-mirror. Which mirror will allow for the MOST extensive evaluation of the ora serrata?
options: You can only evaluate the ora serrata using binocular indirect ophthalmoscopy
The trapezoidal mirror (angled at 73 degrees from the corneal plane)
The square mirror (angled at 67 degrees from the corneal plane)
The bullet mirror (angled at 59 degrees from the corneal plane)
answers: The bullet mirror (angled at 59 degrees from the corneal plane)
questions.explanation: The center contact lens is used to visualize the structures of the posterior pole. The bullet mirror (angled at 59 degrees from the corneal plane) is used to assess the ora serrata (although sometimes difficult in some patients) and the structure of the anterior chamber angle. The square mirror (angled at 67 degrees from the corneal plane) may be used to investigate the area between anterior equatorial retina and the ora serrata. Lastly, the trapezoidal mirror (angled at 73 degrees from the corneal plane) is used at evaluate the retinal equatorial region.

questions.question: While performing binocular indirect ophthalmoscopy you wish to assess the patient's superior retina (12 o'clock). Where should you place yourself and where should the patient direct their gaze to maximize retinal views?
options: You should be position yourself at 12 o'clock and the patient should look down (towards 6 o'clock)
You should be position yourself at 6 o'clock and the patient should look up (towards 12 o'clock)
You should be position yourself at 6 o'clock and the patient should look down (towards 6 o'clock)
You should be position yourself at 12 o'clock and the patient should look up (towards 12 o'clock)
answers: You should be position yourself at 6 o'clock and the patient should look up (towards 12 o'clock)
questions.explanation: When performing BIO, in order to achieve maximal retinal views you should always position yourself 180 degrees away from the fundus area that you wish to assess. The patient in turn, should be instructed to look towards the area that you wish to view. For example, if you wish to assess the inferior retina, the patient should be asked to divert their gaze towards the floor and you should attempt to place yourself as close to 12 o'clock as possible.

questions.question: A woman who is colorblind mates with a man who is normal. What are the chances that their daughter will be a carrier?
questions.explanation: Color blindness is an X-linked recessive gene. As we know, it is the male that determines the sex of the child, either contributing an X or a Y. The female only contributes an X to her offspring. Therefore, if the female possesses an X-linked recessive gene (she manifests the phenotype, X'X'), she will pass it on to 100% of her sons; however, her daughters will all only be carriers but will not manifest the genetic defect (see image 1).

questions.question: Using the inverse-square law, solve the following problem. What is the amount of illumination produced by a point source of light that has an intensity of 200 candelas at a distance of 5 feet?
questions.explanation:
According to the inverse-square law, as one increases the distance between a surface and its point source, the amount of lumens falling on the surface decreases with the square of this distance. Mathematically, this can be represented as: 
E=I/d(squared) 
Where E= the illumination falling onto the surface 
I= the intensity of the point source 
d(squared)= the distance between the light source and the surface 

E= (200cd)/5(squared) = 8 foot-candles

questions.question: You are measuring your post-LASIK patient's contrast sensitivity utilizing charts with different levels of contrast. She is able to correctly identify 20/20 letters on a chart with a contrast as low as 1 percent. Based on this finding, what is her contrast sensitivity?
questions.explanation: A patient's measurement of contrast sensitivity can be evaluated by viewing different sets of charts in which the contrast between the target (either letters or gratings) and the background become progressively less. The point at which the patient can correctly identify the pattern, and nothing further, represents the patient's contrast threshold (i.e., the patient will not be able to identify targets of any lower contrast). The patient's contrast sensitivity can then be calculated by simply taking the reciprocal of that fraction. For this question, the patient's contrast threshold is 1 percent, or 1/100. The reciprocal of this fraction is 100; therefore, her contrast sensitivity is determined to be 100. In some studies, a measurement of contrast sensitivity is preferably described in logarithmic terms. In this case, the above patient's contrast sensitivity would be 2 (log100 = 2).

questions.question: What is the approximate visual angle subtended by the foveola?
questions.explanation: The foveola is roughly 0.3 mm in diameter and possesses the greatest concentration of cone photoreceptors cells. The foveola is the area of the retina that corresponds to maximal visual acuity and resolution. The foveola subtends a visual angle of roughly 1.2 degrees.

questions.question: Most individuals have the ability to notice a discrepancy in the alignment of dots or lines (also known as vernier acuity) of what amount?
questions.explanation:
The concept of vernier acuity is based on the ability to detect discontinuity in a line, or between a row of dots or lines. Vernier acuity is also known as hyperacuity due to the fact that it is approximately an order of magnitude better than standard resolution or letter acuity. In fact, this degree of acuity is well beyond the basic optical diffraction limit of the eye; therefore, we know that brain processing plays an integral role in this type of acuity. On average, most normal-sighted people can distinguish a discrepancy in the alignment of dots or lines as small as about 3-5 seconds of arc, or sometime even less, while standard acuity testing with letters has a threshold of about 1 minute of arc. 

Diagnosis and Management of Ocular Motility Disorders. Ansons 4th Edition, A.M., Davis, H. 2014. Wiley Blackson. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye 11th Edition. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. 2011. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: What is the high-spatial frequency cut-off for a young adult free of ocular pathology?
questions.explanation: The highest spatial frequency (finest grating) detectable by the human eye is limited by the number of cone photoreceptors that are densely packed in the fovea. This concept is also known as the Nyquist Sampling Limit, which states that spatial frequencies can only be detected when they are less than one half of the sampling frequency. Therefore, the human visual system cannot detect sampling frequencies greater than 60 cycles per degree (cpd), because the cones of the fovea provide a sampling rate of about 120 cpd.

questions.question: At a certain level of brightness, the rods become saturated and are unable to respond to an increase in stimulus intensity. How much rhodopsin must become bleached in order for rods to reach this level of saturation?
questions.explanation: Although one would initially believe that 100% of the available rhodopsin must be bleached in order for rods to become saturated, the true value is only 10%. That is, once 10% of the available rhodopsin becomes bleached, the rods are said to be saturated and can no longer respond to a change in stimuli. The reason for this lack of response is that this level of bleached pigment is attributable to the outer segment rod sodium channels. Exposure of rods to light causes closure of sodium channels leading to hyperpolarization. When approximately 10% of rhodopsin has become bleached, a certain number of sodium channels are closed and the rod is hyperpolarized to its fullest extent; further closure of sodium channels will no longer change the level of hyperpolarization.

questions.question: One section of the scotopic portion of a light adaptation curve is depicted as a line with a corresponding slope of infinity. This slope signifies that the rods of the visual system are saturated. What percentage of rhodopsin molecules is bleached in order for rod saturation to occur?
questions.explanation: A light adaptation curve is generated by conducting an increment threshold procedure. An increment threshold procedure is carried out by presenting a test spot (stimulus) against a background of a given luminance. The luminance of the stimulus is increased until detected by the observer, allowing for threshold determination. Once a threshold is ascertained, the brightness of the background is increased and the threshold for the increment is again established. The scotopic portion of the light adaptation curve can be broken into four sections. The final division of the scotopic section is a straight vertical line, which has a slope of infinity, thereby signifying rod saturation. Rod saturation occurs when 10% of the rhodopsin molecules have become bleached. At this point, a key number of sodium channels are closed, rendering the rod cell incapable of further signaling any information regarding the stimulus.

questions.question: How much light is needed to trigger a single molecule of rhodopsin?
questions.explanation: Rhodopsin is the biological molecule present in the photoreceptors of the retina that has the ability to absorb visible light and transduce that event into an electrical nerve impulse. Only one quanta (the smallest amount of light possible) of visible light is required in order to trigger a rhodopsin molecule, changing the molecule into a new shape that initiates the reaction. Not only is this molecule's sensitivity amazing, the stability of the molecule is also very impressive in that a rhodopsin molecule will never trigger accidentally.

questions.question: A typical human contrast sensitivity function (CSF) is a band-pass function with a peak of how many cycles per degree?
questions.explanation: The human contrast sensitivity function allows researchers to determine over what range of contrasts humans can detect various sine wave gratings. Essentially, a subject views a sine wave grating on a computer screen that is below threshold so that the screen appears blank. The contrast of the grating is increased until the subject reports that he or she is able to perceive it. This is repeated again with sine waves of various spatial frequencies. The threshold contrasts are plotted as a function of spatial frequency, resulting in the contrast sensitivity function. This graph demonstrates that humans are capable of detecting a grating of 4 cycles per degree at a much lower contrast than any other spatial frequency.

questions.question: A person can just barely detect the difference between two weights; one weighs 12 pounds and the other weighs 10 pounds. What is the just noticeable difference for a weight of 70 pounds?
questions.explanation:
Weber's Law deals with the just noticeable difference and can be expressed mathematically as: 
K= delta I/I, where K= Weber's constant, delta I= that difference threshold, and I= the original stimulus intensity (weight etc.) 

For the above example, we must first solve for Weber's constant. 12-10/10=0.2. Using this Weber's constant we can then solve for the just noticeable difference or the increment threshold for 70 pounds. 
X-70/70=0.2, X= 14 pounds. Therefore, the above person will just be able to discern the difference between a 70-pound weight and an 84-pound weight.

questions.question: A spatial frequency of 15 cycles per degree (cpd) is equivalent to which of the following Snellen notations?
questions.explanation: When converting cycles per degree (cpd) into Snellen units, one must divide the cpd measurement into 600. This will give the denominator of the Snellen fraction. For the above question 600/15 = 40. Therefore, a notation of 15 cpd is equivalent to a Snellen measurement of 20/40.

questions.question: A patient who has a high spatial frequency cut-off of 40 cycles per degree will have what predicted Snellen acuity?
questions.explanation: In order to convert from cycles per degree to Snellen acuity, simply divide 600 by the cycles per degree; this will solve for the denominator of the Snellen acuity. For the above example 600/40 = 15. Therefore, the predicted Snellen acuity would be 20/15.

questions.question: A piece of paper is held 2 feet away from a point source of light with an intensity of 60 candelas. What is the resultant illumination on the surface of the paper?
questions.explanation: If a surface is held to the normal of a point source of light, the illumination of the surface will decrease by the square of the distance between the source of light and the surface. This can be expressed mathematically by the formula E=I/d2 (squared), where E=illumination falling on the surface, I=intensity of the point source of light and d=the distance between the point source of light and the surface. Inputting the numbers from the above problem and solving for E yields: E= 60cd/2ft2(squared), E= 60cd/4ft , E=15 foot-candles.

questions.question: When viewing a Snellen acuity chart, the clear spaces between the black elements of the letters should measure how thick for 20/20 optotypes?
questions.explanation: The Snellen acuity chart is designed in such a way that correct identification of the letters depends on the patient's ability to resolve the clear spaces between the black elements of each letter. When viewing a 20/20 sized optotype, the entire height of the letter should be 5 minutes of arc. For example, for the letter 'E,' if the entire height is 5 minutes, the black bars and the spaces between will each measure 1 minute of arc.

questions.question: A patient with a visual acuity of 20/30 will likely display a high spatial frequency cut-off of how many cycles per degree (cpd)?
questions.explanation: In order to convert from Snellen acuity to cycles per degree, simply divide 600 by the Snellen denominator. For the above example: 600/30 = 20 cycles per degree.

questions.question: What wavelength of light is most readily absorbed by the photopigment rhodopsin?
questions.explanation: The absorption spectrum curve for rhodopsin shows peak absorption for wavelengths that are roughly 507 nm. This is determined by taking a sample of rhodopsin and projecting a fixed quantity of monochromatic light onto it and measuring the amount of light that is transmitted. Light that is not transmitted is absorbed; therefore the absorption curve and the transmitted curve are reciprocals of each other. The procedure is repeated with many different wavelengths. The wavelength that results in the greatest amount of absorption (or the least amount of transmitted light) is obviously the one that has the highest probability of absorption by rhodopsin. 555 nm is the peak sensitivity for photopic conditions.

questions.question: A colored filter is placed in front of an illuminated Tungsten light bulb, resulting in emergent light that appears red. Which of the following wavelengths is LEAST likely to be absorbed by the filter?
questions.explanation: Colored filters are used to block (absorb) some wavelengths while transmitting others, resulting in the perception of transmitted light that is a different color than the light that was incident upon the filter. A red filter that is placed in front of a white light source will strongly absorb the majority of the wavelengths, except for those in the red region (roughly 620 to 700 nm).

questions.question: At which age do children begin to develop the ability to distinguish between different colored stimuli?
questions.explanation:
At birth, the cone photoreceptors, which are responsible for the perception of color, are poorly developed. Therefore, one would expect that a newborn would display poor color vision. Within the first few months of birth, the cone photoreceptors mature to the point where color vision and color discrimination are possible. Studies done on infants have revealed that color discrimination typically begins to appear at about 3-4 months of age. Additionally, it has also been found that infants categorize colors the same way that adult trichromats do. 

Visual Development, Diagnosis, and Treatment of the Pediatric Patient. Duckman, R.H. 2006. Philadelphia, PA. Lippincott, Williams & Wilkins 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye 11th Edition. Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. 2011. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: A person who is completely dark-adapted and is shown scotopic stimuli will report that light of which wavelength will appear the brightest?
questions.explanation: The scotopic system is meditated by rods and contains the photopigment rhodopsin, whose peak absorbency is 507 nm. The scotopic system cannot discern colors and is very sensitive to dim illumination; the scotopic system also possesses poor spatial resolution, good spatial summation, good temporal summation, poor temporal resolution, and poor contrast sensitivity. The photopic system, on the other hand, possesses three photopigments - erythrolabe, cyanolabe, and chlorolabe. This system has phenomenal color discrimination as well as spatial and temporal resolution. Cones display poor temporal and spatial summation. The photopic system displays a peak spectral sensitivity to wavelengths that are 555 nm.

questions.question: What is the contrast of a projected visual acuity chart in which the target luminance is measured as 50 units of light and the background luminance measures 100 units of light?
questions.explanation:
In order to calculate contrast, one must use a photometer to measure the luminance of the target (letters) and the luminance of the background. Once this information is obtained, the equation to calculate contrast is below: 

Contrast = (target luminance - background luminance) / 
(target luminance + background luminance) 

In this question, the target luminance is reported as 50 units of light while the background is measured as 100 units of light. 

Contrast = (50-100) / (50+100) = 50/150 = 33 percent

questions.question: A person who is missing the photopigment chlorolabe is categorized as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
There are several classifications of color-vision defects; hereditary defects are the most common. The two broad categories are dichromacy and anomalous trichromacy. In dichromacy, one of the photopigments is missing; the type of dichromacy is categorized based on which photopigment is lacking. A deuteranope is missing chlorolabe, a tritanope is missing cyanolabe, and a protanope is missing erythrolabe. It is theorized that the missing photopigment is replaced by the photopigments that are present; otherwise, the person would likely suffer a deficit in visual acuity. Anomalous trichromats are in possession of all three photopigments but the absorption spectrum of one of the pigments has been shifted. For a protanomalous trichromat, the spectrum for erythrolabe is shifted towards the shorter wavelengths. A deuteranomalous trichromat displays a shift of the maximum sensitivity of chlorolabe towards the longer wavelengths. Protans and deutans are said to be red-green colorblind while tritans tend to mix up blues and yellows and are said to possess a blue-yellow defect; this is usually acquired rather than hereditary.
PowerPage
Color Vision Anomalies

questions.question: The fact that 100 quanta of 507 nm and 200 quanta of 580 nm produce the same effect on rhodopsin is known as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The principal of univariance is derived from the fact that once quanta are absorbed by rhodopsin, all of the information pertaining to the light, such as wavelength, is lost. Therefore, if the photopigment rhodopsin is bleached, the wavelength does not matter because the final result will be equivalent. 

The Purkinje shift describes the shift in peak spectral sensitivities during the change from scotopic to photopic vision. Ultimately, this means that as lighting increases, longer wavelengths appear brighter because the peak spectral sensitivity for scotopic conditions is 507 nm and 555 nm for photopic vision. 

Mesopic conditions are those in which both rods and cones function simultaneously, such as during twilight. 

The retina is sometimes referred to as being duplex due to the fact that it possesses two separate groups of photoreceptors which function under different lighting conditions.

questions.question: What is the common unit of radiant power?
questions.explanation: The following table outlines common terms and their associated units.

questions.question: Typical ultraviolet (UV) coatings that are utilized for ophthalmic lenses to help protect the eye against the harmful effects of UV light serve to act as what type of filter?
questions.explanation:
Long-pass filters absorb short wavelengths while allowing for the passage of longer wavelengths. UV filters serve to absorb high-energy (short wavelength) UV light while allowing for the transmission of longer visible wavelengths. 

Interference filters possess a very small half-height bandwidth (the range of the spectrum over which the filter has a peak transmission of 50% or more). Because these filters block the majority of all wavelengths, they can essentially be considered monochromatic. 

Broad-band filters transmit wavelengths within a certain selected range. Narrow-band filters, like broad-band filters, allow for the transmission of wavelengths within a certain range; however, the extent of the narrow-band filter range is much more limited than that of a broad-band filter.

questions.question: A person who possesses a strict criterion level will display which of the following combinations on a threshold test?
options: A low number of false positives and a low number of hits
A low number of false positives and a high number of hits
A high number of false positives and a low number of hits
A high number of false positives and a high number of hits
answers: A low number of false positives and a low number of hits
questions.explanation:
A correct rejection occurs in the presence of only noise and no signal, and the observer correctly will not report seeing a stimulus. A false positive is the event in which the observer reports seeing a stimulus even though the stimulus truly was not present. A hit occurs when the observer correctly signals the presence of a stimulus. A miss occurs when the observer fails to report seeing a presented stimulus. 

An observer with a lax threshold criterion will demonstrate a high number of hits but also a high number of false positives, whereas a person possessing a strict threshold criterion will exhibit a low number of hits as well as low false positives.

questions.question: What term is used for the event where an observer correctly reports the lack of a stimulus on a threshold test?
questions.explanation: A correct reject occurs in the presence of only noise and no signal, and the observer correctly will not report seeing a stimulus. A false positive is the event in which the observer reports seeing a stimulus even though the stimulus truly was not present. A hit occurs when the observer correctly signals the presence of a stimulus. A miss occurs when the observer fails to report seeing a presented stimulus.

questions.question: Visual field instruments are important tools used to detect and determine the extent of field loss. Which 3 of the following items are associated with causing a false superior field defect? (Select 3)
options: A ptosis of the lower lid
Setting the upper edge of the trial lens too low during testing
Having the patient tilt their head back during testing
Deep set eyes with a prominent brow ridge
Placing a trial lens too close to the eye
Performing a visual field while dilated
answers: Setting the upper edge of the trial lens too low during testing
Having the patient tilt their head back during testing
Deep set eyes with a prominent brow ridge
questions.explanation: Anything that impedes the upper portion of the visual field may result in a superior defect or superior depression of the field. Placing a trial lens too far from the eye may potentially cause a superior defect, as might deep set eyes, a trial lens with a dirty superior edge, a ptosis or drooping of the upper lid, tilting back of the head during testing, placing a trial lens too low during testing, and upper lashes that interfere with the superior visual field.

questions.question: Your 76 year-old patient asks you to complete a DMV vision form in order to renew his driver's license. One of the requirements involves a measurement of the extent of his visual field in all quadrants. You obtain values of 65 degrees nasally, 75 degrees temporally, 65 degrees superiorly, and 85 degrees inferiorly. Based on standard values, which of the following quadrants of the visual field is considered to be 'reduced'?
options: All quadrants are within normal range
questions.explanation:
Although there is variation in these measurements according to several sources, the outer limits of the visual field extend approximately 60 degrees nasally, 90-110 degrees temporally, 60 degrees superiorly, and 70-80 degrees inferiorly. 
In the above patient, the temporal quadrant is mildly reduced.

questions.question: A patient wishes to purchase sunglasses. He reports that although he works outdoors, it is vital that while wearing his sunglasses he maintains optimal color distinction. Which of the following lenses would be the best option for him?
questions.explanation: Neutral density filters transmit all wavelengths equally and therefore result in the least amount of color distortion. A commonly prescribed color is a grey lens, again due to the property of good color retention. Green-tinted lenses filter out the majority of UV and infrared light; however, due to this characteristic, blue, orange, violet and red wavelengths are somewhat visually muted. Green-tinted lenses are useful for patients who are exposed to large amounts of reflected light. Yellow-tinted lenses block a good amount of UV light as well as blue and violet wavelengths. Yellow-tinted lenses are useful in diminished lighting cirumstances because these lenses enhance contrast. Hunters and sharpshooters frequently use amber lenses to enhance contrast, but these colored lenses also result in decreased color discrimination of certain wavelengths.

questions.question: For which of the following situations would the X-Chrome contact lens be MOST beneficial?
options: A normal trichromat with a unilateral cataract
questions.explanation: Essentially an X-Chrome contact lens is a red contact lens that acts as a long-pass filter that blocks short wavelengths and allows longer wavelengths to pass through. Patients with abnormal color vision such as dichromats can benefit from this lens in that it aids in color distinction. Wearing the contact lens in one eye effectively shifts the color absorption curve of that eye so that it is different from the other eye; thus allowing the confusion lines of the patient to be altered between the eyes. In order for the lens to work properly, it is essential that the patient be able to easily alternate vision between the eyes for comparison. One of the drawbacks of the lens is that many patients will suppress the eye with the red lens or fuse the images, thereby reducing its effectiveness.

questions.question: A cortical hypercolumn is comprised of which of the following?
options: An ocular dominance column for one eye only and orientation columns for one specific orientation only
Ocular dominance columns for both eyes and a complete set of orientation columns
A complete set of ocular dominance columns for one eye only and a complete set of orientation columns
Ocular dominance columns for both eyes and orientation columns for one specific orientation only
An ocular dominance column for one eye only and a complete set of orientation columns
answers: Ocular dominance columns for both eyes and a complete set of orientation columns
questions.explanation: The striate cortex is organized into discrete rows and columns that help to code for specifics of the stimulus. A hypercolumn consists of both a right and left eye ocular dominance column as well as orientation columns for every orientation. An electrode that penetrates the cortex perpendicularly will encounter cells with the same ocular dominance, and they all respond to stimuli of the same orientation. However, an electrode that penetrates the cortex parallel to its surface will encounter neurons that all possess the same ocular dominance but respond preferentially to stimuli of different orientations. In order for ocular dominance columns to form properly, it is essential that normal vision is present in both eyes during the early years of life.

questions.question: Spatial summation of the scotopic system follows Ricco's law so long as the test spot is not greater than 10 minutes of arc (critical diameter). Which of the following statements CORRECTLY describes the relationship between stimulus intensity and stimulus area according to Ricco's law?
options: As we decrease the diameter of the stimulus, the total number of quanta needed for detection decreases
There is no relationship between stimulus intensity and stimulus area
Within the critical diameter, as the stimulus intensity increases, the stimulus area decreases
As we increase the diameter of the stimulus (keeping it below the critical diameter), the total number of quanta needed for detection increases
answers: Within the critical diameter, as the stimulus intensity increases, the stimulus area decreases
questions.explanation:
Ricco's law holds only for stimuli that are below a critical diameter. Mathematically, the relationship is expressed as: 
IA=K, with I= stimulus intensity (quanta/area), A= stimulus area, and K=constant. Therefore, according to Ricco's law, the threshold number of quanta necessary for stimulus detection is constant, with stimulus intensity and stimulus area having a reciprocal relationship. As the value of I increases, the value of A must decrease in order for K to remain the same. Plug some numbers into the formula to verify. 
I A K 
6 2 12 
2 6 12 
12 1 12

questions.question: A stimulus (the mask) is first presented to a subject followed by another stimulus (the target). The situation in which the mask precedes the presentation of a target is known as which type of masking?
questions.explanation: Masking involves the presentation of two stimuli to the visual system, one being the mask and the other being the target, to help gather information regarding how the visual system processes spatial and temporal information. The mask is supposed to interfere with the visibility of the target. Forward masking describes the situation in which the mask is presented before the target. Backward masking is when the target is presented first followed by the mask (the mask being brighter). Simultaneous masking occurs when the mask and the target are presented at the same time. Metacontrast is considered to be a type of backward masking in which the target is presented first followed by the mask, but the two stimuli are spatially adjacent. For example, an x is presented followed quickly by an O that is larger and surrounds the x but does not occupy the same space. Remember, the name of the masking type describes the location of the mask. Therefore, in forward masking the mask is presented before the target, and in backward masking the target precedes the mask, etc.

questions.question: What is the reason that we do not constantly visualize the blood vessels that reside on top of our photoreceptors in the retina?
options: Because the brightness levels at this stage are too low
Because the blood vessels are too small to be seen
Because their proximity to each other is too great
Because they are stabilized retinal images
answers: Because they are stabilized retinal images
questions.explanation: Due to the fact that the eye does not respond to low temporal frequencies, stabilized retinal images are unable to be detected. Blood vessels that lie on top of the photoreceptors are considered stable relative to the retina. However, if you shine a penlight against your eyelid and move it rapidly, you will be able to see the shadows cast by the blood vessels on your retina. This is called a Purkinje tree. The penlight must be moving to ensure that the temporal frequency is great enough to be visualized.

questions.question: An observer is presented with left-tilted bars seen exclusively by the left eye and bars that are tilted to the right viewed only by the right eye. The observer reports seeing alternating images of the right- and left-tilted bars, but the images do not fuse. This is an example of what type of phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Binocular rivalry, as the name implies, occurs when two non-identical stimuli are displayed monocularly to corresponding retinal points but the images are not fusible. The observer's perception alternates between the two eyes/images; however, the alternation may be but is not necessarily equal between the eyes. 

Motion parallax refers to motion of two or more objects relative to an observer who is also moving. A way to remember this phenomenon is to imagine riding in a car while looking out the window. The objects that are closest to you will move faster and further across your visual field; those that are further away will move more slowly or appear to be stationary. 

Akinetopsia refers to a rare event in which a person cannot see movement in their visual field; this likely arises from a lesion to the middle temporal cortex (MT), which is important in the processing of motion. 

Stereopsis is a product of binocular retinal disparity. Stereopsis as a cue to depth works best if the objects are not too far away. In order for stereopsis to occur, the retinal disparity must be within a certain limit to result in a perception of depth.

questions.question: A protanope has a neutral point of 492 nm. Light with a wavelength of 502 nm will MOST likely be perceived as what color by this individual?
questions.explanation: Protanopes lack the photopigment erythrolabe and possess a neutral point of 492 nm. Wavelengths above the neutral point are perceived as various hues of yellow, and those below the neutral point are seen as blue that increases in saturation towards the shorter wavelengths.

questions.question: Which of the following acquired color vision deficiencies would you MOST expect to see in optic nerve disease and macular disease, respectively?
questions.explanation: Dr. Kollner, an ophthalmologist, reviewed an extensive amount of literature on the nature of color vision impairment in patients with acquired ocular diseases. He concluded that most patients with diseases of the optic nerve tended to have difficultly discriminating red from green hues, while most patients with retinal disease (primarily macular) possessed a greater loss of discrimination between blue and yellow hues. This general dichotomy of red/green defects in optic nerve disease, and blue/yellow defects in macular disease has since come to be known as Kollner's rule. It is important to note that not all cases of acquired color vision deficiencies conform to this rule, however this theory holds true for the majority of patients.

questions.question: Which of the following filters essentially transmits a single wavelength of light?
questions.explanation:
Interference filters possess a very small half-height bandwidth (the range of the spectrum over which the filter has a peak transmission of 50% or more). Because these filters block the majority of all wavelengths, they may be, in essence, deemed monochromatic. 

Long-pass filters absorb short wavelengths while allowing for the passage of longer wavelengths. Broad-band filters transmit wavelengths within a certain selected range. Narrow-band filters, like broad-band filters, allow for the transmission of wavelengths within a certain range; however, the extent of the narrow-band filter range is much more limited than a broad-band filter.

questions.question: Visual information can be said to undergo parallel processing by the magno and parvo cells, which both respond differently to the same type of stimulus. Which of the following combinations BEST describes parvo neuronal characteristics?
options: Central retinal distribution, color coding capabilities, and spatial sensitivities to high frequencies
Central retinal distribution, very little to no color coding capabilities, and spatial sensitivities to high frequencies
Peripheral retinal distribution, color coding capabilities, and spatial sensitivities to low frequencies
Peripheral retinal distribution, very little to no color coding capabilities, and spatial sensitivities to low frequencies
answers: Central retinal distribution, color coding capabilities, and spatial sensitivities to high frequencies
questions.explanation:
Parvo neurons are found in layers 3, 4, 5, and 6 of the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus (dLGN). These neurons tend to be smaller in caliber and display color opponency, central retinal distribution, respond to high spatial frequencies, and display a sustained response when shown a long-duration stimulus; therefore, parvo cells respond preferentially to low temporal frequencies. Parvo cells also transmit action potentials more slowly than magno cells due to their decreased diameter. 

Magno cells are located in layers 1 and 2 of the dLGN. These neurons are larger in diameter and possess very little if any color opponency, are located more peripherally in the retina, prefer low spatial frequencies, and display a short and transient response at the outset and the end of a stimulus presentation, regardless of the stimulus duration. Magno cells respond well to high temporal frequencies and transmit action potentials at higher speeds than parvo cells.

questions.question: The receptive field of which type of cell of the visual system displays a heightened sensitivity to a stimulus moving in a specific direction (the cell is directionally selective)?
questions.explanation:
The receptive fields of rod cells, ganglion cells and amacrine cells do not possess any preference for stimulus direction. They do respond differently to various brightness intensities and spot sizes.
