The receptive fields of simple cells respond preferentially to dark and light edges or bars that are of a specific orientation and thus have receptive fields that are split into antagonistic inhibitory and excitatory areas. 

Complex cells, like simple cells, prefer elongated stimuli of specific orientation; however, unlike simple cells, placement of the stimulus within a specific area of the receptive field is not critical. The stimulus can be placed anywhere within the receptive field of a complex cell and will elicit a response from the cell. Complex cells do, however, display a preference for direction. A stimulus moving in a certain direction will manifest a cellular response, whereas the same stimulus, if moved in the opposite direction, will not elicit a response. Also, the receptive fields of complex cells do not possess inhibitory and excitatory regions.

questions.question: The low-frequency drop-off seen in a typical human contrast sensitivity function (CSF) is attributable to which of the following phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
The human contrast sensitivity function (CSF) allows researchers to determine over what range of contrasts humans can detect various sine wave gratings. Essentially, a subject views a sine wave grating on a computer screen that is below threshold so that the screen appears blank. The contrast of the grating is increased until the subject reports that he/she is able to perceive it. This is repeated again with sine waves of various spatial frequencies. The threshold contrasts are plotted as a function of spatial frequency, resulting in the contrast sensitivity function. This graph demonstrates that humans are capable of detecting a grating of 4 cycles per degree at a much lower contrast than any other spatial frequency. 

The CSF demonstrates a low-frequency drop-off which due to lateral inhibition of retinal cells. Lateral inhibition is best described in terms of the receptive field of a ganglion cell. The center of the receptive field is stimulated by light while the surround is inhibited by it. Therefore this type of cell would best respond to a grating whose spatial frequency would result in a light band aligning with the center and dark bands falling on the surround. With a spatial frequency that is too low (for example, 1 cycle per degree), the light band will fall upon both the center and the surround, resulting in a poor response from that cell. 

The CSF typically shows a cut-off of 60 cycles per degree even at 100% contrast for high spatial frequencies. There are several reasons for this cut-off. One of them is the system's inherent natural optical aberrations; another is the retinal distribution of photoreceptors. Photoreceptors that are more tightly packed are able to discern a greater amount of detail than those that are loosely packed. Think of alternating light and dark bands. In order to properly appreciate these bands, one bright band must fall on one photoreceptor and an adjacent dark band must stimulate an adjacent receptor. If the receptors are too big or loosely packed a light band may fall on half of one receptor and half of another; receptors then sum the information, causing a loss of visual information and the inability to properly discern the grating. The above is referred to as the Nyquist sampling theorem.

questions.question: Clinical measurement of Snellen acuity is an example of which type of visual acuity?
questions.explanation:
Snellen acuity is an example of both recognition and resolution acuity. Recognition is the ability to recognize a target such as a letter or number. However in order for recognition to occur one must first be able to resolve the target. Resolution acuity is defined as the capacity to discern two or more targets that are spatially separated. The human threshold for resolution acuity is approximately 30 seconds of arc. 

Detection acuity is described as the ability to determine whether a target is present or absent in an empty field. The minimum threshold for humans is one second of arc. 

Vernier acuity is defined as the capacity to detect lateral misalignment of two objects that are separated by space. The minimum threshold for humans is 3 seconds of arc.

questions.question: While performing saccadic eye movements from one place in space to another such as looking from the television to a chair, why does the background not appear as a blur as it moves across the retina?
options: Due to lateral inhibition of rod cells
Due to summation of ganglion cells
questions.explanation: While performing a saccade, vision is suppressed just before, during and just after the saccadic motion. This ensures that the background does not appear as a blurred image. The postulation has been put forth that selective suppression of the magno pathway maintains a clear retinal image during eye movements. In terms of function, this would make sense because the magno pathway is considered the 'where' pathway and responds to quickly-moving objects as well as high temporal frequencies, both of which occur to the background during a saccade.

questions.question: A patient who is fitted with monovision reports good retained depth perception. How is this possible when you know that monovision disrupts binocular clarity?
options: Due to the abundant presence of monocular cues to depth in our world
Because of informational gain due to the crossing of fibers at the optic chiasm
Due to the fact that monovision patients display strong ocular dominance
Because most patients alternate vision between the eyes so rapidly that the images become fused
answers: Due to the abundant presence of monocular cues to depth in our world
questions.explanation:
Although monovision purposely disrupts binocular clarity and sometimes fusion, most patients maintain a surprising amount of depth perception due to the fact that we are surrounded by monocular cues to depth. Several of these monocular cues fall under the category of pictorial depth cues; that is, cues that can be represented in a two-dimensional image such as a painting. The pictorial cues to depth are clarity, texture, interposition, linear perspective, size, shadow, and lighting. Other monocular depth cues include motion parallax and accommodation. Size can be further sub-divided into relative size and familiar size. Relative size, as its name infers, is the ability to discern depth based on the size of an object relative to another; for example, given two trees that are assumed to be the same size, a tree that stimulates less retinal space would be perceived as further away than one that subtends a larger retinal area. 

A good example of linear perspective is a drawing of a building. The bottom of the building is very wide and the space between the left and right contour lines is large, however to infer depth as one moves up the page, the left and right contour lines get closer together and appear to be farther away from the observer. 

Motion parallax refers to motion of two or more objects relative to an observer who is also moving. A good way to remember this is to imagine riding in a car and looking out the window. The objects that are closest to you will move faster and further across your visual field while those that are further away will move more slowly or appear to be stationary. 

Although a successful monovision candidate displays ocular dominance, without monocular depth cues one would not be able to attain good depth perception.
PowerPage
Monocular Cues to Depth

questions.question: An ocular dominance histogram of neurons in the visual cortex depicts cells that are monocular, equally binocular, or binocular but with an ocular dominance. Cells from category 1 are classified as which of the following?
options: Binocular but with a preference for input from the ipsilateral eye
Binocular but with a preference for input from the contralateral eye
questions.explanation: The majority of cells in the visual cortex are considered binocular. An ocular dominance histogram of neurons in the visual cortex classifies cells into one of seven categories. Cells in category one and seven are solely monocular, with category one cells receiving input from the contralateral eye and cells from category seven receiving input exclusively from the ipsilateral eye. Cells in categories two and three are binocular but receive a disproportionate amount of input from the contralateral eye; cells in categories five and six are also binocular but display a dominance for input from the ipsilateral eye. Neurons from category four receive input from both the right and left eye equally.

questions.question: A patient performing a Humphrey visual field test fails to respond to a brighter than threshold stimulus at a location where sensitivity has previously been determined. What is the name of this type of reliability index?
questions.explanation:
False negatives during Humphrey perimetry testing are detected by presenting a stimulus that is brighter than the previously determined threshold value in a certain location. If the patient fails to respond to the stimulus, a false negative is recorded. 

False positives occur when the patient responds without an accompanying light stimulus. 

The recording of a fixation loss will occur when the patient responds to a stimulus that is presented in the portion of the visual field that is associated with the physiologic blind spot.

questions.question: The fact that a red shirt is perceived as red under various different light levels is known as which of the following phenomena?
questions.explanation: Color constancy describes the fact that colors are perceived as being the same under various lighting conditions. For example, if you are wearing a red shirt, that shirt will be perceived as red both indoors and outdoors, despite the fact that the situational light levels are usually quite different.

questions.question: Color vision tests are best administered under which type of illumination?
questions.explanation:
A MacBeth lamp is considered the best type of illumination under which to perform a color vision test as it closely parallels the illumination provided by illuminant C. However, this type of light is very expensive and can be hard to find. Clinically, a good alternative is a nonstandard fluorescent tube like the Varilux F15T8/VLX. However, should incandescent light be used, the patient should wear filtered lenses to simulate the appropriate lighting conditions, or, if all else fails, one should use indirect sunlight.
PowerPage
Color Vision Testing

questions.question: White light projected onto a prism will result in a spectrum of wavelengths resembling a rainbow. Which of the colors experiences the greatest amount of deviation from the apex of the prism?
questions.explanation: Because white light is a blend of various wavelengths, it can be split apart into its individual wavelengths by projecting it onto a prism. Keep in mind that the degree of deviation is inversely proportional to the wavelength; therefore, longer wavelengths experience less deviation while shorter wavelengths will deviate to a greater degree. Out of the above choices, violet is the shortest wavelength and therefore will be bent to the greatest extent towards the base of the prism. The wavelength for red light is roughly 650 nm, orange 600 nm, yellow 570 nm, green 520 nm, blue 470 nm and violet 400 nm.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes a hereditary color vision defect?
options: High propensity to worsen with time
Tends to be asymmetrical between the eyes
It is typically blue-yellow in nature
questions.explanation: Red-green color defects are much more frequent than blue-yellow color defects. Red-green defects also tend to be hereditary, while blue-yellow defects are more likely to be acquired. Color defects that are hereditary are found predominantly in males and are stable with time, equal between the eyes, and are relatively easily categorized via regular clinical color vision tests. In contrast, acquired color defects are more likely to be asymmetrical between the eyes, may change or worsen with time, and are found in equal ratio between women and men, occurring secondary to some type of pathology.

questions.question: Which of the following statements BEST describes the scotopic system when compared to the photopic system?
options: High sensitivity to dim illumination, poor spatial resolution, increased spatial summation, decreased temporal summation
Low sensitivity to dim illumination, good spatial resolution, decreased spatial summation, decreased temporal summation
Low sensitivity to dim illumination, good spatial resolution, decreased spatial summation, increased temporal summation
High sensitivity to dim illumination, poor spatial resolution, increased spatial summation, increased temporal summation
answers: High sensitivity to dim illumination, poor spatial resolution, increased spatial summation, increased temporal summation
questions.explanation: The scotopic system contains rhodopsin as its photopigment whose peak absorbency is 507 nm. The scotopic system cannot discern colors and is very sensitive to dim illumination, possesses poor spatial resolution, good spatial summation, good temporal summation, poor temporal resolution, and poor contrast sensitivity. The photopic system, on the other hand, possesses three photopigments-- erythrolabe, cyanolabe, and chlorolabe. This system has phenomenal color discrimination as well as spatial and temporal resolution. Cones display poor temporal and spatial summation.

questions.question: During the determination of visual thresholds, an observer who possesses a lax criterion will display which of the following combinations for the detection of visual stimuli?
options: High sensitivity and a low threshold
answers: High sensitivity and a low threshold
questions.explanation: A person who possesses a lax criterion will report seeing a stimulus even though they may not be sure if they actually saw it. This type of person displays a low threshold and high sensitivity (remember that threshold and sensitivity are reciprocals of each other). On the other hand, an observer who maintains a strict threshold will have a high threshold and low sensitivity. This person will not respond to seeing a stimulus unless they are absolutely certain that they see it.

questions.question: How is visual acuity impacted as the velocity of a moving stimulus is increased?
options: It remains constant until the target reaches a speed of roughly 60 degrees per second
Acuity degrades rapidly for slowly moving targets but remains unchanged for high-velocity stimuli
Acuity remains unchanged regardless of target speed
As soon as the target begins moving, acuity declines at a rapid pace
answers: It remains constant until the target reaches a speed of roughly 60 degrees per second
questions.explanation: Visual acuity remains unchanged for a moving stimulus until its velocity reaches between 60 to 80 degrees per second. The ability to clearly track a moving target is termed dynamic visual acuity. Our limited visual acuity at high speeds is likely due to the fact that we are unable to move our eyes quickly enough to follow the stimulus.

questions.question: The scotopic system displays a greater degree of temporal summation than the photopic system. According to Bloch's law, as long as the stimuli are delivered within the critical period, as the stimulus intensity increases what happens to the stimulus duration?
options: It remains unchanged for all stimuli intensities
It is unrelated to stimulus intensity
questions.explanation:
Bloch's law applies to temporal summation and therefore to stimuli that are separated by time. According to Bloch, as long as stimuli are presented within a critical period (100 msec for the scotopic system and 10-50 msec for the photopic system), the total number of quanta necessary for threshold to be reached remains the same for different flash durations. Mathematically the relationship is expressed as: 
I(t)=K where I= stimulus intensity (quanta/time), t= stimulus duration, and K= constant. For this relationship to hold true, I and t are inversely proportional to each other. As the stimulus intensity increases, the flash duration must decrease.

questions.question: A patient presents in your office concerned with blurry vision. Biomicroscopy reveals corneal edema secondary to contact lens overwear. How will the corneal edema affect this patient's contrast sensitivity function (CSF)?
options: It will decrease the CSF of high and low-spatial frequencies
It will decrease the CSF of only high-spatial frequencies
It will decrease the CSF of only low-spatial frequencies
It will decrease the CSF of moderate-spatial frequencies
It will decrease the CSF of all spatial frequencies
answers: It will decrease the CSF of all spatial frequencies
questions.explanation: As clinicians, we tend to test only high-spatial frequency functioning. However, in the above case, as well as with cataracts, patients may present complaining of blurry vision even though acuity may be measured to be 20/20 or 20/25. Both cataracts and corneal edema can diffuse or scatter light causing a decrease across all spatial frequencies. Therefore it is important not to dismiss the patient too quickly when they note decreased vision, even though they may possess 20/20 vision. In the above case, one should consider performing a visual acuity test with low contrast such as the Bailey-Lovie low contrast acuity chart or the Pelli-Robson test to assess for a deficit in contrast sensitivity.

questions.question: Although the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus is comprised of six layers, it can be divided into two distinct regions based upon neuronal size. Which of the six layers make up the region known as the magnocellular layers?
questions.explanation: The magnocellular layers constitute the two most ventral layers, or layers 1 and 2, of the dLGN. These neurons tend to be larger in caliber and are generally called M-cells or magno cells. The four most outer layers of the dLGN make up the parvocellular layers. Cells of layers 3, 4, 5, and 6 of the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus have smaller neurons and are known as P-cells. The magno and parvo pathways constitute parallel processing streams because they both process different information about visual details. The parvo pathway streams information pertaining to color and detail whereas the magno pathway codes information regarding fast motion. Some researchers describe the parvo system as the 'what' system and the magno pathway as the 'where' system.

questions.question: Visual information from ganglion cells of the ipsilateral eye project to which layers of the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus (dLGN)?
questions.explanation: Information flows from the optic tracts to the dorsal lateral geniculate nuclei (there is one located in each cerebral hemisphere). However, information from the ipsilateral eye is projected to layers 2, 3, and 5 of the dLGN, whereas visual input from the contralateral eye is found in layers 1, 4, and 6.

questions.question: A patient who is illiterate would NOT be able to use which of the following optotypes for measurement of visual acuity?
questions.explanation: Lea symbols, Landolt Cs and Tumbling Es are used primarily for children or illiterate patients. With Landolt Cs and Tumbling Es, children can use their hands to mirror the direction of the letter projected on the screen without having to recognize the letter. Lea symbols use shapes- a circle, a square, a heart etc. which most children are familiar with and are capable of reporting to you what they are able to discern. Sloan letters are optotypes which are equally difficult to discriminate. These letters include Z, R, N, O, C, V, S, K, H and D.

questions.question: The typical human contrast sensitivity function (CSF) for a young adult free of ocular pathology displays a high-spatial frequency cut-off of around 60 cycles per degree. What is the cause for this cut-off of high-frequency resolution?
options: Loss of visual information due to cross-over at the optic chiasm
questions.explanation: The human contrast sensitivity function (CSF) allows researchers to determine over what range of contrasts humans can detect various sine wave gratings. Essentially, a subject views a sine wave grating on a computer screen that is below threshold so that the screen appears blank. The contrast of the grating is increased until the subject reports that he/she is able to perceive it. This is repeated again with sine waves of various spatial frequencies. The threshold contrasts are plotted as a function of spatial frequency, resulting in the contrast sensitivity function. This graph demonstrates that humans are capable of detecting a grating of 4 cycles per degree at a much lower contrast than any other spatial frequency. The CSF typically shows a cut-off of 60 cycles per degree even at 100% contrast for high spatial frequencies. There are several reasons for this cut-off. One of them is the system's inherent natural optical aberrations. Another is the retinal distribution of photoreceptors. Photoreceptors that are more tightly packed are able to discern a greater amount of detail than those that are loosely packed. Think of alternating light and dark bands. In order to properly appreciate these bands, one bright band must fall on one photoreceptor and an adjacent dark band must stimulate an adjacent receptor. If the receptors are too big or loosely packed, a light band may fall on half of one receptor and half of another; receptors then sum the information, causing a loss of visual information and the inability to properly discern the grating. The above is referred to as the Nyquist sampling theorem.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a binocular cue to depth?
questions.explanation:
There are several pictorial depth cues, that is, cues that can be represented in a two-dimensional image such as a painting. The pictorial cues to depth are clarity (also known as aerial perspective), texture, interposition, linear perspective, size, shadow, and lighting. Other monocular depth cues include motion parallax and accommodation. Size can be further sub-divided into relative size and familiar size. Relative size, as its name infers, is the ability to discern depth based upon the size of an object relative to another. For example, given two trees that are assumed to be the same size, the tree that stimulates less retinal space would be perceived as further away than one that subtends a larger retinal area. 

A good example of linear perspective is a drawing of a building. The bottom of the building is very wide and the space between the left and right contour lines is large; however, to infer depth as one moves up the page, the left and right contour lines get closer together and appear to be farther away from the observer. 

Motion parallax refers to motion of two or more objects relative to an observer who is also in motion. A good way to remember this is to think of riding in a car and looking out the window. The objects that are closest to you will move faster and further across your visual field, while those that are further away will move more slowly or appear to be stationary. 

Binocular cues to depth are stereopsis and convergence. Stereopsis is a product of binocular retinal disparity. Stereopsis as a cue to depth works best if the objects are not too far away. In order for stereopsis to occur, the retinal disparity must be within a certain limit to result in a perception of depth.

questions.question: In order to fully reproduce a sine wave grating, four attributes must be specified. What are these four attributes?
options: Grating, Fourier analysis, reflectance, and transmittance
questions.explanation: Sine wave gratings are specified by frequency, phase, orientation and contrast. Frequency denotes the number of cycles of alternating dark and light bands per degree. Contrast describes the luminance profile of the grating; this is basically the difference in luminance between the light and the dark bands. Mathematically, this can be calculated as contrast= the difference in luminance between the peak and trough/the total luminance of the peak and the trough. The phase of the sine wave grating is relative to another grating. Two gratings are in phase if their positions are the same (i.e., their peaks and troughs align) or 180 degrees out of phase (i.e., the trough of one grating is aligned with the peak of the other). The orientation refers to the angle of the grating in reference to horizontal or vertical.

questions.question: What is the basic unit used to measure retinal illumination?
questions.explanation:
Retinal illumination is measured in trolands. The amount of retinal illumination can be measured via the equation T=LA, where T=the retinal illumination (in trolands), L= the luminance of the viewed surface, and A=the area of the pupil. This concept is important, especially for experimental purposes where it is important for all of the subjects to experience the same amount of retinal illumination irrespective of pupil size. 

Lux units are used for illuminance, and lumens are the unit for measuring luminous power. Foot-lamberts are the units utilized to quantify luminance.

questions.question: What is the common unit for luminous power?
questions.explanation: Luminous power is defined as the total light power that is emitted by a source and is measured in lumens. Luminous intensity is described as the light power that is generated by a point source in any given direction and is measured in candelas. Luminance is essentially the brightness of a surface and is measured in foot-lamberts or candelas per square meter. Luminance does not change with viewing distance. Illuminance is a measure of the amount of light that falls onto a surface and is measured in lumens/square meter or lumens/square foot. Luminance measures the amount of light reflected off of a surface while illuminance describes how much light falls onto a surface.

questions.question: A sign that gives the illusion of a person drinking a soda through the use of apparent motion caused by flashing lights is an example of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Within our visual world there are many examples of apparent motion in which the observer perceives motion that physically does not occur. Consider a lighted sign such as in the above question. The advertising makes use of the phi phenomenon or stroboscopic motion to create illusory motion. By flashing lights in sequence within a certain timed interval (60-200 milliseconds apart) one can create the illusion that the light is moving when really it is just one light being turned off while the light adjacent to it is flashed on and so forth. 

Troxler's effect occurs when the eye is fixated (although the eye is truly always moving) on a point in space and the surrounding background begins to blend together. There must be several factors that come into play in order for the Troxler effect to transpire. The best example of the Troxler effect is the figure in which there are two squares that are superimposed. The smaller square is centered in the larger square and is slightly lighter than the larger surrounding square. The border between the squares is blurred, resulting in a distinction of the two squares based upon brightness alone. When fixating upon an X placed in the center of the smaller square, the border completely disappears as does the smaller square, resulting in the perception of one uniformly-colored large square. 

Mach bands are typically observed when there is a smooth transition between white/gray to black. Bands are perceived within the transition zones. These bands are created by the visual system due to the augmentation of high spatial frequencies. This augmentation results in the perception of bands at transition zones.

questions.question: Color vision deficits and their respective confusion lines can be plotted on a CIE curve. What is the locus of origin for all of the confusion lines for a deuteranope called?
questions.explanation:
There are several classifications of color-vision defects; hereditary defects are the most common. The two broad categories are dichromacy and anomalous trichromacy. In dichromacy, one of the photopigments is missing; the type of dichromacy is categorized based on the photopigment that is lacking. A deuteranope is missing chlorolabe, a tritanope is missing cyanolabe, and a protanope is missing erythrolabe. It is theorized that the missing photopigment is replaced by the photopigments that are present; otherwise, the person would likely suffer a deficit in visual acuity. Anomalous trichromats are in possession of all three photopigments, but the absorption spectrum of one of the pigments has been shifted. For a protanomalous trichromat, the spectrum for erythrolabe is shifted towards the shorter wavelengths. A deuteranomalous trichromat displays a shift of the maximum sensitivity of chlorolabe towards the longer wavelengths. Protans and deutans are said to be red-green colorblind while tritans tend to mix up blues and yellows and are said to possess a blue-yellow defect; this defect is usually acquired rather than hereditary. 

Dichromats possess different confusion lines depending on which photopigment they are lacking. All of the colors that reside upon a confusion line are indistinguishable from each other. All of the respective confusion lines for each type of dichromat originate from a position called the copunctal point. The copunctal points for each dichromat reside at different locations on the CIE diagram, allowing for easy distinction between the different types of dichromat. 

Neutral points on the CIE diagram are those wavelengths that intersect with the copunctal point, the white point (W) and the chromaticity diagram and will be perceived as white (think of a line originating at the copunctal point passing through W and the curve; this point on the curve is the wavelength that will appear white). Neutral points vary for each dichromat. 

The CIE can be used to determine the dominant wavelength and the excitation purity of a mixture of two colors. Complementary colors are those that can be mixed together to produce the color white and can be calculated by drawing a line from one side of the CIE curve to the other ensuring to pass through the white locus. The complementary wavelength can then be read off of the diagram. The Planckian locus is a small arc within the diagram that contains variations of white created by blackbody radiators at various temperatures.

questions.question: Elderly patients who suffer from nuclear sclerosis generally tend to display which type of color defect?
options: Nuclear sclerosis does not cause a color defect
questions.explanation: Color vision can become slightly disrupted with age due to nuclear sclerosis, which causes a yellowing of the lens and leads to a decreased ability to perceive blue.

questions.question: The inability to adequately see in low lighting situations ('night blindness') is known as which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
- Nyctalopia: a condition in which vision is normal in daylight or strong lighting conditions but is abnormally weak or completely lost in dim or poor lighting conditions; it is also known as 'night blindness' and is commonly associated with vitamin A deficiency or other retinal diseases (such as retinitis pigmentosa) 
- Prosopagnosia: the ability to recognize faces is impaired while other aspects of visual processing remain intact 
- Akinetopsia: a condition in which patients cannot perceive motion but can acknowledge stationary objects without trouble; this is also known as 'motion blindness' 
- Amblyopia: impaired vision in an otherwise healthy-appearing eye, usually due to high or unequal refractive errors or strabismus. 
- Achromatopsia: a disorder in which patients are unable to perceive color

questions.question: On the CIE diagram, where would be the location of two complementary colors?
options: On opposite sides of the diagram, passing through the white point
Along the arc of the curve
Adjacent to each other on either side of the curve
answers: On opposite sides of the diagram, passing through the white point
questions.explanation:
The CIE color specification system was designed to help create a standard system to designate colors. Its design is based upon the RGB system, which basically takes a bipartite field (a split field) and determines the degree to which the three primaries (red, green, and blue) must be manipulated to match a wavelength displayed on the right side of the field. This process is repeated for every spectral wavelength, creating a tristimulus value for each wavelength. The only flaw was that negative values of the primaries occasionally needed to be used. The CIE system overcame this problem by introducing imaginary primaries and mathematically manipulating the numbers so that they could be easily plotted on a graph. The CIE diagram displays the quantities of each of the three imaginary primaries necessary to match a real color. With the CIE chromaticity diagram, given only two coordinates for a wavelength (or two of the three tristimulus values), it is possible to easily solve for the third. On the CIE diagram, the imaginary primaries are located outside of the diagram because they are not obtainable. The diagram resembles a horseshoe. The arc of the horseshoe contains the monochromatic hues and is called the spectral locus. The two ends of the horseshoe can be connected, and the nonspectral purples (which are not monochromatic) are located on this line. White is located in the center of the diagram. 

The CIE can be used to determine the dominant wavelength and the excitation purity of a mixture of two colors. Complementary colors are those that can be mixed together to produce the color white and can be calculated by drawing a line from one side of the CIE curve to the other, ensuring to pass through the white locus. The complementary wavelength can then be read off of the diagram. The Planckian locus is a small arc within the diagram that contains variations of white created by blackbody radiators at various temperatures. 

Source: Schwartz, Steven. Visual Perception; A Clinical Orientation 2nd edition 1999 pp. 121-130

questions.question: While performing a visual field using Frequency Doubling Technology (FDT), what visual correction should be worn by an undilated patient?
options: Only the astigmatism correction is required
questions.explanation: FDT was designed to simulate optical infinity as a viewing distance, and therefore patients should wear their best distance correction to ensure optimal results. Many other visual field instruments such as the Dicon, the Humphrey Field Screener, and the Synemed have a bowl distance of roughly 30 cm, and therefore appropriate near correction is required depending on the patient's age, accommodative abilities and whether or not the patient is dilated.

questions.question: What is the correct order of structures through which visual information is processed, beginning at the optic nerve?
options: Optic nerve-> optic chiasm-> optic tract-> striate visual cortex-> extrastriate visual cortex-> dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus
Optic nerve-> optic tract-> optic chiasm-> striate visual cortex-> dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus-> extrastriate visual cortex
Optic nerve-> dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus-> optic chiasm-> extrastriate visual cortex-> optic tract-> striate visual cortex
Optic nerve-> optic chiasm-> optic tract-> dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus-> striate visual cortex-> extrastriate visual cortex
Optic nerve-> striate visual cortex-> optic tract-> optic chiasm-> extrastriate visual cortex-> dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus
answers: Optic nerve-> optic chiasm-> optic tract-> dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus-> striate visual cortex-> extrastriate visual cortex
questions.explanation: Visual information is funneled to the optic nerve, where it travels to the optic chiasm; at that point, information from the nasal retina crosses over and joins with information from the temporal retina of the opposite eye. The visual input then moves down the optic tract to the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus and onto the striate cortex. The striate cortex (also known as visual area 1 (V1), the primary visual cortex or Brodmann area 17), is where cortical magnification of foveal input occurs because foveal vision is largely over-represented in V1. Some axons then project to the extrastriate cortex areas for higher processing.

questions.question: The disappearance of stimuli of low temporal frequencies with continual viewing is known as which of the following?
questions.explanation: The Troxler effect occurs when the eye is fixated (although the eye is truly always moving) on a point in space and the surrounding background begins to blend together. There must be several factors that come into play in order for the Troxler effect to transpire. The best example of the Troxler effect is the figure in which there are two squares that are superimposed. The smaller square is centered in the larger square and is slightly lighter than the larger surrounding square. The border between the squares is blurred, resulting in a distinction of the two squares based upon brightness alone. When fixating upon an X placed in the center of the smaller square, the border completely disappears as does the smaller square, resulting in the perception of one uniformly-colored large square. Some patients experience the Troxler effect while performing a visual field via FDT. They report, especially during testing of the second eye, that the entire field appears to go gray. When this occurs, make sure to inform the patient to blink.

questions.question: While performing the red lens test at 40.0 cm with the red lens placed over the patient's right eye, the patient reports seeing one light. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate step at this time?
options: Perform a cover test with the red lens in place, observing for any monocular eye movements
Place base-out prism over the dominant eye and ask how many lights the patient perceives
No extra testing is required as this is the expected result
Ask the patient what is the color of the perceived light
answers: Ask the patient what is the color of the perceived light
questions.explanation: The red lens test can be performed at both distance and near. When evaluating a patient's second-degree fusion at near, a transilluminator is held at 40.0 cm and a red lens is placed over the preferred eye. The patient is directed to look at the transilluminator. The patient should be asked how many lights they perceive. If the patient answers that only one light is seen, then the clinician should ask the patient the color of the light source. The patient should report seeing a pinkish or red/white shimmering circle, which would represent a composite image of the two eyes. If a white light is seen, the patient is suppressing the eye behind the red lens. If the patient reports seeing a red circle, she is suppressing the eye without the red lens. If the patient reports seeing two lights, she should be asked where the red light is in relation to the white light (i.e., is the red light to the left or right of the white light?) to establish the presence of crossed or uncrossed diplopia.

questions.question: While examining your 16 year-old patient's fundus using a slit-lamp biomicroscope, she reports that she can see what appear to be blood vessels in her eye. What is the name of this type of phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Entoptic phenomena are visual perceptions that are caused by a source within the eye itself. In most cases, these phenomena occur under certain lighting conditions in which certain objects within the eye can become visible. Examples of entoptic phenomena include floaters, the blue field entoptic phenomena (white blood cells can be seen moving in capillaries), Haidinger's brush, and phosphenes. The Purkinje tree is another entoptic phenomenon in which an image of the retinal blood vessels can be observed by one's own eye (as in the above patient). 

Palinopsia is a type of visual disturbance that is characterized by the persistence of images in the vision, even after the stimulus is gone. These are also known as afterimages but are observed in a significantly greater degree in patients with palinopsia. 

Prosopagnosia is a visual disorder in which patients do not have the ability to adequately recognize faces while other areas of visual perception remain intact. 

Phosphenes are a subcategory of entoptic phenomenon in which a person will perceive light without light actually entering the eye. These light images are commonly observed when a person puts mechanical pressure on the globe but can also be seen in cases of optic neuritis or other stimulation of the retina or visual cortex. 

A scintillating scotoma is a common visual aura that occurs preceding the development of a migraine.

questions.question: Weber's law states that as the background brightness is increased, the increment threshold of the test stimulus must also increase such that the ratio of the increment intensity to the background intensity remains the same. If the Weber fraction for scotopic vision is 0.14 and the Weber fraction for photopic vision is 0.015, which of the following can be concluded?
options: Photopic vision is more sensitive to contrast than scotopic vision
Photopic vision displays better temporal summation than the scotopic system
Scotopic vision possesses better spatial resolution than photopic vision
Scotopic vision is more sensitive to color detection than the photopic system
answers: Photopic vision is more sensitive to contrast than scotopic vision
questions.explanation: The scotopic system cannot discern colors and is very sensitive to dim illumination, and it possesses poor spatial resolution, good spatial summation, good temporal summation, poor temporal resolution, and poor contrast sensitivity. The photopic system, on the other hand, possesses three photopigments - erythrolabe, cyanolabe, and chlorolabe. This system exhibits excellent color discrimination as well as superior spatial and temporal resolution. Cones display poor temporal and spatial summation.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an additive color mixture?
options: Placing two colored filters in sequence and shining a light through them
Placing drops of different colored food coloring into a glass of water
Combining two different colors of paint
questions.explanation: An additive color mixture is that in which light from two different origins are added together such that the combined effect possesses a greater amount of light than either of the two sources alone. Examples include T.V. projection systems or spot lights with colored filters directed at the same target. Subtractive color mixtures transmit less light when combined than either of the two sources individually.

questions.question: Spatial summation displayed by certain photoreceptors of the retina results in which of the following properties?
questions.explanation: Spatial summation is utilized by the scotopic system and allows for greater sensitivity at the cost of resolution. Information from several rods across space is funneled indirectly onto one ganglion cell (rods do not directly synapse onto ganglion cells). Because the information is received from several rods, this combines to increase the chances of detecting an object (i.e., increased sensitivity). However, because the area over which the information is gathered is large and it is sent to one ganglion cell, the resolution is poor. This is in opposition to the photopic system, which displays a much smaller degree of spatial summation, leading to decreased sensitivity but greater resolution. For example, two lights that are flashed close together both in time and space will be coded as one flash by the scotopic system because the information is sent to one ganglion cell. However, the same stimuli will be perceived as two lights by the photopic system due to the stimulation of two adjacent ganglion cells, thereby enabling this system to code for two different stimuli, resulting in greater resolution.

questions.question: In order to properly perform keratometry, what type of acuity are you utilizing?
questions.explanation: Vernier acuity is defined as the capacity to detect lateral misalignment of two objects that are separated by space. The minimum threshold for humans is 3 seconds of arc. When using the keratometer, one must properly align the crosshairs both vertically and horizontally which is the essence of Vernier acuity also known as hyperacuity.

questions.question: Which form of visual acuity possesses the smallest threshold, otherwise stated, which of these types of acuities is most sensitive?
questions.explanation:
Detection acuity is described as the ability to determine whether a target is present or absent in an empty field. The minimum threshold for humans is one second of arc. 

Vernier acuity is defined as the capacity to detect lateral misalignment of two objects that are separated by space. The minimum threshold for humans is 3 seconds of arc. 

Snellen acuity is an example of both recognition and resolution acuity. Recognition is the ability to recognize a target such as a letter or number. However in order for recognition to occur one must first be able to resolve the target. Resolution acuity is defined as the capacity to discern two or more targets that are spatially separated. The human threshold for resolution acuity is approximately 30 seconds of arc.

questions.question: A new patient is seen at your office and reports that he has been told previously that he is colorblind. You perform the Ishihara pseudoisochromatic plates color test and his results are normal. Assuming he does possess a color vision deficit, given these findings, which of the following color vision anomalies is he MOST likely to possess?
questions.explanation:
Pseudoisochromatic plate tests are the most frequently used color tests in the clinical setting. They are relatively easy and quick to administer. In essence, a figure (usually a symbol, number or letter) must be discerned from a background, using color as a cue to help create contours. Patients who suffer from a color defect will be unable to see the figure. The one drawback to this test is that very few renditions of this test offer the ability to detect blue-yellow deficits. Therefore, because the above patient suffers from a color vision anomaly and he performed normally on color vision testing, it is likely that he suffers from a blue-yellow deficit. 

Primary Care Optometry 5th edition. Grosvenor, T. Butterworth-Heinemann, 2007, page 126.

questions.question: Which of the following types of visual acuity is MOST affected by defocus?
questions.explanation: Resolution acuity deals with the ability to discern a figure or pattern from a background. Snellen visual acuity is a type of resolution acuity. As optometrists, we provide the patient with the best possible resolution acuity through the use of optical aids and devices; therefore, this type of acuity is greatly affected by defocus. Vernier acuity is also known as hyperacuity. This type of acuity deals with differences in alignment and direction. Humans have excellent vernier acuity that is very minimally affected by defocus. Minimum detectable acuity is the ability of the visual system to detect the presence of an object. Consider a very fine wire against the background of a blue sky. Minimum detectable acuity begs the question, how thin can the wire be made before the visual system can no longer perceive it? This type of acuity is also affected by defocus to a very small extent.

questions.question: The change in peak spectral sensitivity from higher wavelengths to lower wavelengths as the surrounding illumination decreases is the basis for which of the following theories?
questions.explanation:
Purkinje observed that as illumination increases, we transition from viewing with the scotopic system to the photopic system, and the peak spectral sensitivity changes from shorter to longer wavelengths. Under dim illumination, we tend to rely on rods to maximize visual sensitivity. Scotopic vision is primarily mediated by rods; as a result, this leads to heightened sensitivity to low light conditions but at the cost of poor acuity (20/200) and little to no color vision. The scotopic system is most sensitive to detecting wavelengths that are 507 nm. Photopic vision, on the other hand, occurs in bright light and is characterized by phenomenal acuity (20/20), color discrimination, and is dominated by cones. The photopic system is most sensitive to wavelengths that are 555 nm. 

Ricco's law holds only for stimuli that are below a critical diameter. Mathematically, the relationship is expressed as, IA=K, with I= stimulus intensity (quanta/area), A= stimulus area, and K=constant. Therefore, according to Ricco's law, the threshold number of quanta necessary for stimulus detection is constant, with stimulus intensity and stimulus area having a reciprocal relationship. As the value of I increases, the value of A must decrease in order for K to remain the same. 

Weber's Law deals with the just noticeable difference and can be expressed mathematically as, K= delta I/I, where K= Weber's constant, delta I= that difference threshold, and I= the original stimulus intensity (weight, etc.). 

Bloch's law applies to temporal summation and therefore to stimuli that are separated by time. According to Bloch, as long as stimuli are presented within a critical period (100 msec for the scotopic system and 10-50 msec for the photopic system), the total number of quanta necessary for threshold to be reached remains the same for different flash durations. Mathematically, the relationship is expressed as, I(t)=K where I= stimulus intensity (quanta/time), t= stimulus duration, and K= constant. For this relationship to hold true, I and t are inversely proportional to each other. As the stimulus intensity increases, the flash duration must decrease.

questions.question: A patient with acquired macular disease is MOST likely to experience which type of color vision deficiency?
questions.explanation: Acquired macular disease tends to produce blue-yellow color defects, while optic nerve lesions typically produce red-green defects.

questions.question: As applied to color vision, what is the proper term for two stimuli that appear the same but are physically different?
questions.explanation: Two stimuli that are physically different but appear to be the same are called metamers. A dichromat is a person who, if given three wavelengths of light that are divided into two separate patches, is able to adjust the intensities of the wavelengths so that the two patches appear the same. For example, on one side of the patch is wavelength A and on the other side are wavelengths B and C. A dichromat would be able to adjust the intensities of wavelengths B and C so that they appear to be identical; however, a trichromat would not. Grassmann's laws of metamers consists of the additivity property, the scalar property, and the associative property. The additive property states that if you add an equal amount of a new wavelength to each metamer, they will remain metamers. The scalar property of metamers states that if the intensities of the metamers are increased or decreased equally, they will remain metamers. Lastly, the law of associative property of metamers explains that if a metamer is substituted for another, the two metamers will still match. For example, wavelength A+B= wavelength C+D. However, wavelength A= wavelength K+J; therefore, wavelength K+J+B= wavelength C+D.

questions.question: Scotopic vision is mediated primarily by which type of receptor in the retina?
questions.explanation: Under dim illumination, we tend to rely on rods to maximize visual sensitivity. Scotopic vision is mediated primarily by rods; as a result, this leads to heightened sensitivity to low lighting but at the cost of poor acuity (20/200) and little to no color vision. Photopic vision, on the other hand, occurs in bright light and is characterized by phenomenal acuity (20/20), color discrimination, and is dominated by cones.

questions.question: Distortion of perceived images in which straight lines appear wavy is known as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Metamorphopsia is a type of visual distortion in which perceived linear images appear wavy or broken. This commonly occurs in macular diseases such as macular degeneration, clinically significant macular edema, central serous retinopathy, etc. Clinicians typically test for this visual symptom using an Amsler Grid. 

Micropsia is a type of visual distortion in which images appear to be decreased in size; this is caused by the spreading apart of foveal cones. Contrastingly, macropsia is a perceived increase in image size as a result of a crowding together of foveal cones. Both of these visual symptoms are very uncommon. 

Photopsia is a perceived flash of light that is most commonly associated with traction of the retina in cases of a retinal break, tear, or detachment, or most commonly, a posterior vitreous detachment. 

Scotomas are areas of the visual field whereby vision is a partially or entirely degenerated.

questions.question: Peak photoreceptor sensitivity occurs when light passes through which part of the pupil as it enters the eye?
options: Slightly superior to the center of the pupil
Slightly nasal to the center of the pupil
Slightly inferior to the center of the pupil
Slightly temporal to the center of the pupil
answers: Slightly nasal to the center of the pupil
questions.explanation: Photoreceptors inner and outer segments are thin cylinders that posses a higher index of refraction than the surrounding tissues; therefore, they act as optic fibers that exhibit total internal reflection when light is incident along the fiber's axis. Light that enters the photoreceptor from peripheral angles is more likely to escape into surrounding tissue and has a lesser chance of isomerizing a photopigment molecule than light that is incident in the same direction; this concept is known as the Stiles-Crawford effect. Experiments have shown that there is a large variance of sensitivity to light as it passes through different areas of the pupil. For most individuals, the center of the pupil and the orientation of the photoreceptor axes that provides the greatest sensitivity are not at the exact same location. The peak photoreceptor sensitivity location is actually about 0.2 to 0.5mm nasal to the center of the pupil.

questions.question: Which of the following visual acuity charts uses the LogMAR sizing system?
questions.explanation:
The Bailey-Lovie chart is a unique visual acuity chart that was designed on a logarithmic basis, with the visual acuity measurement designated on the basis of the logarithm of the minimum angle of resolution (LogMAR). For example, visual acuity of 20/20 represents a minimum angle of resolution (MAR) of 1 minute of arc. The logarithm of 1 is 0. Therefore, 20/20 is equivalent to LogMAR 0.0. Another example we could use would be a visual acuity of 20/200. This represents a minimum angle of resolution (MAR) of 10 minutes of arc. The logarithm of 10 is 1. Therefore, 20/200 is equivalent to LogMAR 1.0. 

Additionally, there is a standard size progression ratio from line to line, each line has the same number of optotypes, and there is a constant spacing utilized between each row and each letter of the chart. This is the type of acuity chart that was used in the ETDRS protocol.

questions.question: Which of the following 3 items can be determined using the CIE chromaticity diagram? (Select 3)
options: The amount of photopigment in a molecule of rhodopsin
The regeneration time of a photopigment
The excitation purity of a stimulus
The dominant wavelength of a stimulus
The maximal contrast sensitivity function of the photoreceptors
answers: The excitation purity of a stimulus
The dominant wavelength of a stimulus
questions.explanation:
The CIE color specification system was designed to help create a standard system to designate colors. Its design is based upon the RGB system, which basically takes a bipartite field (a split field) and determines the degree to which the three primaries (red, green and blue) must be manipulated to match a wavelength displayed on the right side of the field. This process is repeated for every spectral wavelength, resulting in a tristimulus value for each wavelength. The only flaw was that negative values of the primaries occasionally needed to be used. The CIE system overcame this problem with the introduction of imaginary primaries and mathematical manipulation of the numbers so that they could be easily plotted on a graph. The CIE diagram displays the quantities of each of the three imaginary primaries necessary to match a real color. With the CIE chromaticity diagram, given only two coordinates for a wavelength (or two of the three tristimulus values), it is possible to solve for the third. On the CIE diagram, the imaginary primaries are located outside of the diagram because they are not obtainable. The diagram resembles a horseshoe. The arc of the horseshoe contains the monochromatic hues and is called the spectral locus. The two ends of the horseshoe can be connected, and the nonspectral purples (which are not monochromatic) are located on this line. White is located in the center of the diagram. 

The CIE can be used to determine the dominant wavelength and the excitation purity of a mixture of two colors. Complementary colors are those that can be mixed together to produce the color white and can be calculated by drawing a line from one side of the CIE curve to the other, making sure to pass through the white locus. The complementary wavelength can then be read off of the diagram. The Planckian locus is a small arc within the diagram that contains variations of white created by blackbody radiators at various temperatures. 

Reference: Schwartz, Steven. Visual Perception; A Clinical Orientation. 2nd edition, 1999. pp 121-130.

questions.question: Information received by the photoreceptors of the retina from the ganglion cells is an example of what type of pathway?
questions.explanation: The photoreceptors transmit information to the bipolar cells and the ganglion cells in a feed-forward fashion also known as centripetal organization. The retina also exhibits lateral transmission of visual information. Amacrine and horizontal cells are responsible for lateral integration of data within the retinal tissue. Some input is also fed back to the photoreceptors by the ganglion cells via the interplexiform cells in a feedback loop called the centrifugal pathway.

questions.question: How does a dark adaptation curve of a patient with early retinitis pigmentosa differ from that of a patient free of any ocular pathology?
options: The cone portion of the curve will be non-existent for a person suffering from retinitis pigmentosa
The cone section of the curve will display a slope equal to infinity for a person with retinitis pigmentosa
The rod portion of the curve will plateau at a higher than normal threshold for a person with retinitis pigmentosa
The rod portion of the curve will exhibit a very steep slope for a person with retinitis pigmentosa
answers: The rod portion of the curve will plateau at a higher than normal threshold for a person with retinitis pigmentosa
questions.explanation:
In order to generate a dark adaptation curve, an observer is exposed to a bright light that bleaches almost all of the photopigments. Once the light is turned off, the observer is left in a totally dark room and asked to detect large, centrally fixated, flashing stimuli allowing for depiction of the detection threshold as a function of time to be measured. The result is a dark adaptation curve. The initial portion of the curve displays a rapid decrease in threshold during the first five minutes, which correlates with the regeneration of cone pigments and cone thresholds. The curve then plateaus and is followed by another, more gradual decrease in threshold after about 10 minutes. This section of the curve is called the rod-cone break; at this point, the rods become more sensitive than the cones. The second dip is caused by regeneration of the rods, allowing detection of the stimulus. Cones take about 10 minutes to fully recover; rods have a total recovery time of 35 minutes (see image 1). 

A patient with early retinitis pigmentosa will exhibit a dark adaptation curve wherein the rod section of the curve shows that a prolonged regeneration time. The rod portion of the curve will also display a plateau at a higher than normal threshold (see image 2).

questions.question: A patient suffering from dichromacy lacks one of the three photopigments necessary for normal color vision but possesses 20/20 vision. What is the MOST likely reason that this patient is able to retain good visual acuity despite the fact that he is missing a photopigment?
options: The cortical area associated with color vision is more complex in these individuals
The missing photopigment is replaced by the remaining photopigments that are present
The color processing pathway allocates more neurons to color vision in people with dichromacy
Patients with dichromacy possess more cone receptors than patients with normal color vision
answers: The missing photopigment is replaced by the remaining photopigments that are present
questions.explanation: In dichromacy, one of the photopigments is missing; the type of dichromacy is categorized based on which photopigment is lacking. A deuteranope is missing chlorolabe, a tritanope is missing cyanolabe, and a protanope is missing erythrolabe. It is theorized that the missing photopigment is replaced by the photopigments that are present; otherwise, the person would likely suffer a deficit in visual acuity. In the instance of a protanope, it is likely that erythrolabe is replaced with chlorolabe. Protanopes and deuteranopes confuse red and green. Tritanopes confuse blues and yellows. Deuteranopes possess a neutral point of 498 nm. Wavelengths above the neutral point are perceived as various saturated levels of yellow, and those below the neutral point are viewed as shades of blue that become more saturated as the wavelength decreases. Protanopes possess a neutral point of 492 nm. Wavelengths above the neutral point are perceived as various hues of yellow, and those below the neutral point are seen as blue. A tritanope has a neutral point of 570 nm. Wavelengths above 570 nm are seen as shades of red, and those below are observed as green. Wavelengths at the neutral point are seen as white.

questions.question: The contrast sensitivity function of an 80-year old person compared to that of a 20-year old will display which of the following characteristics?
options: The curve will be shifted to the right
The curve will be shifted up
The curve will be shifted down and to the right
The curve will be shifted to the left
The curve will be shifted up and to the left
answers: The curve will be shifted to the left
questions.explanation: The contrast sensitivity function of an elderly person will be shifted slightly towards the left due to a loss of high spatial frequencies. There are several reasons that an elderly patient will display a loss of high spatial frequencies. The most obvious is due to pupil miosis, which decreases retinal illumination. Other elements include the aging of neural components and the increased incidence of light scatter due to nuclear sclerosis.

questions.question: During the generation of a dark adaptation curve, the stimulus is changed from 420 nm to 650 nm. How will the resulting dark adaptation curve vary from the original?
options: The curve will lack a rod-cone break
The portion of the curve that depicts the rod adaptation will be much steeper
The portion of the curve that depicts the cone adaptation will be longer
The overall time period for dark adaptation will be considerably longer
answers: The curve will lack a rod-cone break
questions.explanation:
In order to generate a dark adaptation curve, an observer is exposed to a bright light that bleaches almost all of the photopigments. Once the light is turned off, the observer is left in a totally dark room and asked to detect large, centrally fixated, flashing stimuli, typically 420 nm, allowing for depiction of the detection threshold as a function of time to be measured. The result is a dark adaptation curve. The initial portion of the curve displays a rapid decrease in threshold during the first five minutes, which correlates with the regeneration of cone pigments and cone thresholds. The curve then plateaus and is followed by another, more gradual decrease in threshold after about 10 minutes. This section of the curve is called the rod-cone break; at this point the rods become more sensitive than the cones. The second dip is caused by regeneration of the rods, allowing detection of the stimulus. Cones take about 10 minutes to fully recover; rods have a total recovery time of 35 minutes. 

If the wavelength of the stimulus is changed to 650 nm, the rod portion of the curve essentially disappears and, therefore, a rod-cone break is lacking. With a stimulus of 650 nm, the dark adaptation curve consists of only the cone portion of the curve. The reason that the fraction of curve attributable to rod adaptation disappears can be explained by the photochromatic interval. The photochromatic interval is a measure of the difference in sensitivities between the photopic system and the scotopic system for a given wavelength. The scotopic system is more sensitive than the photopic system for all wavelengths, except those that are perceived as red (the longer wavelengths like 650 nm). Within this region of the spectrum, the photochromatic interval is essentially zero. Therefore, because the scotopic system is not more sensitive than the photopic system when using a stimulus of 650 nm, there is no rod-cone break.

questions.question: Which of the following color vision tests is able to differentiate between a dichromat and an anomalous trichromat?
questions.explanation:
Pseudoisochromatic plate tests are the most frequently used color tests in the clinical setting. They are relatively easy and quick to use. In essence, a figure (usually a symbol, number or letter) must be discerned from a background using color as a cue to help create contours. Patients who suffer from a color defect will be unable to see the figure. The one drawback to this test is that very few renditions of this test offer the ability to detect blue-yellow deficits. 

The Farnsworth dichotomous test is comprised of 15 colored caps. The patient is asked to place the caps in order of a sequence of successive hues. The manner in which the caps are placed allows the clinician to determine if the patient is a deutan, protan or tritan because each defect will cause a mix-up of the colors in a specific manner according to the patient's respective confusion lines. 

The desaturated D-15 test is the same as the Farnsworth except that the hues are desaturated, making the test more difficult but enabling the clinician to detect certain pathologies such as glaucoma. 

The Nagel anomaloscope is the only clinical device capable of distinguishing a dichromat from an anomalous trichromat. The patient looks through an eyepiece and assesses a split field. The upper portion consists of a mixture of green and red (which are variable) with a fixed luminance. The lower portion of the field displays a yellow color whose radiance can be manipulated. The wavelengths in both fields stimulate only the M- and L-cones, effectively rendering all persons dichromats. Normal trichromats are fairly consistent with the values to which they will assign to both of the fields. How the wavelengths of the mixture field and the radiance values are manipulated by the patient allows the clinician to differentiate between a dichromat and an anomalous trichromat.
PowerPage
Color Vision Anomalies

questions.question: Rods and cones are distributed unevenly throughout the human retina. Which location in the retina displays the greatest density of rods?
questions.explanation:
Rods are found at their highest concentration 20 degrees from the fovea. The fovea itself does not contain any rods, hence the reason we are unable to see a dim star with foveal fixation but looking slightly away from it allows for detection of the dim object. This is because we place the object on the part of our retina where there is maximal sensitivity, or 20 degrees from the fovea. The optic nerve does not contain any photoreceptors and is therefore known as the physiological blind spot.
PowerPage
Photoreceptors

questions.question: Which area of the retina is most sensitive to detecting light flicker?
questions.explanation: The peripheral retina is most sensitive to flicker because it is a part of the magno system which is also known as the 'where' system. The magno system is noted for its poor spatial resolution but good temporal resolution. The fact that the peripheral retina is more sensitive to flicker is in accordance with the Granit-Harper law, which states that as the log of the area of the stimulus is increased, the critical flicker fusion frequency also increases accordingly. This helps to explain why the chances of perceiving flicker are greater for a larger stimulus for a given modulation. Remember that the receptors of the peripheral retina display increased summation; therefore, a larger stimulus will take up more area of the retina, increasing the chances of detection.

questions.question: How is the human contrast sensitivity function (CSF) expected to change for a myope who is uncorrected?
options: The high spatial frequency cut-off will shift to a lower frequency
The low-frequency drop-off will increase to higher frequencies; thereby shifting to the right
The peak sensitivity will shift from 4 cycles/degree to 8 cycles/degree
The entire CSF will shift downwards
answers: The high spatial frequency cut-off will shift to a lower frequency
questions.explanation: An uncorrected myope will experience defocus especially regarding fine image details; therefore, one would expect the high spatial frequencies to be most affected. The high spatial frequency cut-off portion of the CSF of an uncorrected myope would shift towards the left (down to a lower spatial frequency).

questions.question: Illuminance is directly related to which of the following?
options: The index of refraction of the surface onto which the light is falling
The density of the material onto which the light is falling
The wavelength of the surface onto which the light is falling
The total amount of lumens emitted from a source
answers: The total amount of lumens emitted from a source
questions.explanation: Illuminance is a measure of the amount of luminous power falling onto a surface. The total illuminance does not depend upon any properties of the surface, only the source from which the lumens are being emitted. To better understand this concept, think of snow. The amount of snow falling is independent of the surface onto which it falls but only depends upon the total quantity of snow emitted from the clouds.

questions.question: Two spots of light are flashed simultaneously and are detected by the scotopic system, which transmits the information and signals as if there were one spot of light. This observation can be explained, in part, by which of the following?
options: The information from many rods cells is summated indirectly onto one ganglion cell
The photopic system possesses greater temporal summation than the scotopic system
The receptive field of ganglion cells that receive information from rod cells is on-center surrounded by on-surround
The information from the second flash of light is not transmitted because the available rhodopsin has been bleached and therefore cannot signal the presence of the second light
answers: The information from many rods cells is summated indirectly onto one ganglion cell
questions.explanation:
Spatial summation is utilized by the scotopic system and allows for greater sensitivity at the cost of resolution. Information from several rods across space is funneled indirectly onto one ganglion cell (rods do not directly synapse onto ganglion cells). Because the information is received from several rods, this combines to increase the chances of detecting an object (i.e., increased sensitivity). However, because the area over which the information is gathered is large and the information is sent to one ganglion cell, the resolution is poor. This is in opposition to the photopic system, which displays a much smaller degree of spatial summation, leading to decreased sensitivity but greater resolution. For example, two lights that are flashed close together in both time and space will be coded as one flash by the scotopic system because the information is sent to one ganglion cell. However, the same stimuli will be perceived as two lights by the photopic system due to the stimulation of two adjacent ganglion cells, thereby enabling this system to code for two different stimuli, resulting in greater resolution. 

The receptive field of a ganglion cell is antagonistic and is either on-center surrounded by off-surround or off-center surrounded by on-surround.

questions.question: Information from the left visual field of the right eye ultimately ends up being processed at which location?
options: The left dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus
The right dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus
answers: The right dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus
questions.explanation: Information from the left visual field projects onto the temporal retina of the right eye, whereas information from the right visual field projects onto the nasal retina of the right eye. The input from the nasal retina crosses over and joins with information from the temporal retina of the opposite eye. It then moves down the optic tract to the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus and onto the striate cortex and extrastriate cortex for further processing. Visual input from the right portion of the visual field is processed in the left cortical hemisphere; images from the left half of the visual field are processed in the right cortical hemisphere.

questions.question: During the determination of visual thresholds, different observers possess varying levels of threshold criterion. For example, some observers have a very lax criterion and will report seeing a stimulus even though he or she does not actually see it. Which method enables the examiner to overcome the problem of observer threshold criterion?
questions.explanation:
All of the above methods suffer from the drawback of variable observer threshold criterion except for the forced choice method. The brilliance of this method lies in the fact that no matter what the observer's criterion level, the observer must respond. In the forced choice method, the observer must choose between several options, one of which displays the stimulus. For example, an observer is presented with four windows and they must choose which window contains the stimulus. 

The method of ascending limits presents a stimulus below threshold, gradually increasing its intensity until it is reported as visible by the observer. This method is flawed in that the observer begins to report seeing the stimulus due to expectations. This inherent flaw can be overcome by varying the intensity of the initial stimulus at the beginning of each trial. 

The method of descending limits is similar to the method of ascending limits except that the stimulus is changed to visible from non-visible. The drawbacks and the solutions are identical to the method of ascending limits. 

The method of constant stimuli gives valuable information but requires a lot of time. In this method, several stimuli of varying intensities are presented multiple times in random fashion; the observer reports whether or not he/she can see them. 

In the method of adjustment, the observer himself adjusts the intensity of the stimulus until he can no longer see it. Although this method is very quick, its flaw lies in the fact that the observer's threshold criteria are variable.

questions.question: There are several methods used to determine visual thresholds. Which method displays a stimulus below threshold then its intensity is gradually increased by the examiner until it is reported as visible?
questions.explanation:
The method of ascending limits presents a stimulus below threshold, gradually increasing its intensity until it is reported as visible by the observer. This method is flawed in that the observer begins to report seeing the stimulus due to expectations. This inherent flaw can be overcome by varying the intensity of the initial stimulus at the beginning of each trial. 

The method of descending limits is similar to the method of ascending limits except that the stimulus is changed to visible from non-visible. The drawbacks and the solutions are identical to the method of ascending limits. 

The method of constant stimuli gives valuable information but requires a lot of time. In this method, several stimuli of varying intensities are presented multiple times in random fashion; the observer reports whether or not he/she can see them. 

In the method of adjustment, the observer themselves adjusts the intensity of the stimulus until he or she can no longer see it. Although this method is very quick, its flaw lies in the fact that the observer's threshold criteria are variable.

questions.question: In order for the visual system to detect a stimulus as flickering which of the following must hold true?
options: The temporal frequency should be greater than the critical flicker fusion frequency
The modulation depth should be very low
The modulation depth should be moderate
The temporal frequency should be very high
answers: The modulation depth should be moderate
questions.explanation: If a stimulus is to be perceived as flickering, the modulation depth (the amplitude of the luminance change) should not be too low or the stimulus will appear steady. Also, if the temporal frequency of the stimulus is too rapid, the visual system will register a steady light rather than rapid flickering. The critical flicker fusion frequency denotes the temporal frequency above which the stimulus will be perceived as a continual light without flicker.

questions.question: What is the name for the phenomenon in which a flickering light that is 10 Hz is seen as brighter than a steady light (one that does not flicker) that possesses the same average luminance?
questions.explanation:
The Brucke-Bartley effect describes the fact that a flickering stimulus that is 10 Hz will appear brighter than a non-flickering light with the same average luminance. This fact also holds true for stimulus presentation duration. A light that is presented for 50 milliseconds will appear brighter than stimuli presented for longer or shorter durations. 

The Troxler effect occurs when the eye is fixated (although the eye is truly always moving) on a point in space and the surrounding background begins to blend together.
