There must be several factors that come into play in order for the Troxler effect to transpire. The best example of this phenomenon is the figure in which there are two squares that are superimposed. The smaller square is centered in the larger square and is slightly lighter than the larger surrounding square. The border between the squares is blurred, resulting in a distinction of the two squares based upon brightness alone. When fixating upon an X placed in the center of the smaller square, the border completely disappears as does the smaller square, resulting in the perception of one uniformly-colored large square. Some patients experience the Troxler effect while performing the FDT visual field and they report, especially during testing of the second eye, that the entire field appears to go gray. When this occurs make sure to inform the patient to blink. 

The peripheral retina is most sensitive to flicker because it is a part of the magno system which is also known as the 'where' system. The magno system is noted for its poor spatial resolution but good temporal resolution. The fact that the peripheral retina is more sensitive to flicker is in accordance with the Granit-Harper law, which states that as the log of the area of the stimulus is increased, the critical flicker fusion frequency also increases accordingly. This helps to explain why the chances of perceiving flicker are greater for a larger stimulus for a given modulation. Remember that the receptors of the peripheral retina display increased summation; therefore, a larger stimulus will take up more area of the retina, increasing the chances of detection. 

Due to the fact that the eye does not respond well to low temporal frequencies, stabilized retinal images are unable to be detected. Blood vessels that lie on top of the photoreceptors are considered stable relative to the retina. However, if you shine a penlight against your eyelid and move it rapidly, you will be able to see the shadows cast by the blood vessels on your retina. This is called a Purkinje tree. The penlight must be moving to ensure that the temporal frequency is great enough to be visualized.

questions.question: During a saccadic movement, which of the following pathways is MOST likely selectively suppressed?
questions.explanation:
While performing a saccade, vision is suppressed just before, during, and just after the saccadic motion. This ensures that the background does not appear as a blurred image. It is postulated that selective suppression of the magno pathway maintains a clear retinal image during eye movements. In terms of function, this makes sense because the magno pathway is considered the 'where' pathway and responds to quickly-moving objects as well as high temporal frequencies, both of which occur to the background during a saccade.
The ventral processing stream (also known as the temporal pathway or the 'what' system) receives a vast majority of its input from parvo cells, which respond preferentially to low temporal frequencies.

questions.question: Physiological diplopia will occur for which of the following conditions?
options: The viewing of objects whose images fall on corresponding points on the retina
The viewing of objects that fall within Panum's fusional area
An emmetrope who views a distant object monocularly through a -5.00 D lens
The viewing of objects that lie significantly in front of a horopter
answers: The viewing of objects that lie significantly in front of a horopter
questions.explanation: Stereopsis is based upon binocular disparity within a certain limit that causes the perception of depth. In order for binocular fusion to occur, retinal images must remain within Panum's fusional area, which denotes the area of the retina that will result in fusion. Each point on the retina of one eye corresponds to a point on the retina of the other eye, called corresponding points. For a given object distance, if each corresponding point is plotted, a curved line called a horopter will be generated. An object placed at any location along the horopter will result in fusion. If the object is placed too far ahead or behind the horopter, physiological diplopia will occur. If an object is located slightly ahead or behind the horopter and falls within Panum's fusional area, the resulting retinal disparity will produce stereopsis.

questions.question: In the signal detection theory, what occurs as the detectability of the stimulus is increased?
options: There is greater overlap between the signal and the signal plus noise distributions
There is a decreased chance that they observer will report seeing a presented stimulus
The two curves, signal and signal plus noise completely superimpose upon one another
There is less overlap between the signal and signal plus noise distributions
answers: There is less overlap between the signal and signal plus noise distributions
questions.explanation: Observers possess different levels of threshold criterion. The threshold levels can be influenced by the level of noise within a person's visual system. Each of us has baseline neural activation which fluctuates. In order for a signal to be detected, it must be distinguishable from the background neural noise. The signal detection theory states that there are two distributions--one is comprised of the neural noise, the other is the signal added to the neural noise. The theory demonstrates that as the detectability of the signal increases, the difference, or the separation between the two distributions, also increases. If there is a lot of overlap between the curves then there is a smaller chance of the signal being detected.

questions.question: Humans are capable of viewing wavelengths of around 380 nm to 700 nm. What is the relationship between the frequency and the wavelength of electromagnetic radiation?
options: There is no correlation between the two
questions.explanation: The frequency and the wavelength of electromagnetic radiation are inversely proportional. As the frequency increases, the wavelength decreases. The formula is as follows: v=c/λ where v= the frequency of the light, c= the speed of light (3x10 to the power of 8 m/s) and λ= the wavelength of light.

questions.question: Recent studies have demonstrated that S-cones may be more vulnerable and subject to damage in the earlier stages of glaucoma; therefore, short wavelength autoperimetry (SWAP) is now recommended to monitor for early changes in the visual field. How is SWAP performed?
options: Using a blue test target and a yellow background
Using a red test target and a green background
Using a green test target and a red background
Using a red test target and a blue background
Using a yellow test target and a blue background
answers: Using a blue test target and a yellow background
questions.explanation: SWAP can be performed through the use of a visual field instrument by changing the target to blue, thereby ensuring that the S-cones respond maximally to this stimulus against a yellow background. A yellow background enforces M- and L-cone suppression because this wavelength will cause bleaching of their photopigments.

questions.question: According to the Munsell color system, what nomenclature describes the wavelength of a stimulus?
questions.explanation: The Munsell color system can be visualized as a cylinder. Chroma represents the purity of the color or its saturation. On the cylinder, chroma is located at the radius of the center of the cylinder and increases as one moves away from the center. Otherwise stated, the calorimetric purity increases as one moves more distally from the center of the cylinder. Hue is used to describe the wavelength. On the cylinder, hue is located along the perimeter of the cylinder. Value denotes the brightness of the stimulus. Value is located along the length of the cylinder and increases from black to white with various shades of grey in between.

questions.question: Which of the following colors possesses the greatest wavelength?
questions.explanation: As one moves to the right in the electromagnetic spectrum, the wavelengths progressively decrease while the frequency of the emitted radiation increases. On the left of the spectrum are radio waves; moving to the right we find radio waves, microwaves, and infrared light (IR). Sandwiched between IR and ultraviolet light is the visible portion of the spectrum; it is truly a very small slice of the entire spectrum. As we continue to the right, we encounter x-rays then gamma rays, which are very high in frequency but possess a small wavelength. Radiation emitted by rays at the far right of the spectrum can be quite dangerous. Remember the mnemonic ROY G BIV. This will help you to remember color wavelengths because red possesses the longest wavelength and appears first on the electromagnetic spectrum while violet is last with the smallest wavelength. Red is roughly 650 nm, orange 600 nm, yellow 570 nm, green 520 nm, blue 470 nm and violet 400 nm.

questions.question: Which area of the extrastriate cortex is involved in the perception of motion?
questions.explanation: Beyond the striate cortex, visual information is thought to split into two separate streams: the ventral (also known as the 'what' or temporal stream), and the dorsal (also known as the 'where' or parietal stream). V5, also known as the middle temporal cortex (or MT), is considered to be a part of the dorsal stream and is believed to code for motion. V4 and IT are a part of the ventral stream. V4 serves to play a role in processing color while IT is important in classifying complex shapes and form recognition such as faces. V1 is the primary visual cortex and is not considered a part of the extrastriate cortex.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered to be a part of the primary visual cortex?
questions.explanation: The striate cortex is also known as the primary visual cortex, visual area 1 (V1), and Brodmann's area 17. The striate cortex sends its projections to the extrastriate cortex, which itself contains many areas including IT, MT, V2, V4, and V5. MT and V5 are different names for the same region.

questions.question: A 1' arc test spot is presented to an observer and is detected by the observer's scotopic system; a second 5' arc test spot emitting the same number of quanta as the previous test spot is also detected by the observer. The amount of quanta necessary for detection by the scotopic system remains constant for stimuli that are below 10' arc. This observation is an example of which of the following laws?
questions.explanation:
Ricco's law holds only for stimuli that are below a critical diameter. Mathematically, the relationship is expressed as, IA=K, with I= stimulus intensity (quanta/area), A= stimulus area, and K=constant. Therefore, according to Ricco's law, the threshold number of quanta necessary for stimulus detection is constant, with stimulus intensity and stimulus area having a reciprocal relationship. As the value of I increases, the value of A must decrease in order for K to remain the same. Therefore, as the area of the stimulus increases (as long as it remains below the critical diameter), the stimulus intensity must decrease such that the value of K remains constant. 

Weber's Law deals with the just noticeable difference and can be expressed mathematically as K= delta I/I, where K= Weber's constant, delta I= that difference threshold, and I= the original stimulus intensity (weight, etc.). 

Bloch's law applies to temporal summation and therefore to stimuli that are separated by time. According to Bloch, as long as stimuli are presented within a critical period (100 msec for the scotopic system and 10-50 msec for the photopic system), the total number of quanta necessary for threshold to be reached remains the same for different flash durations. Mathematically the relationship is expressed as, I(t)=K where I= stimulus intensity (quanta/time), t= stimulus duration, and K= constant. For this relationship to hold true, I and t are inversely proportional to each other. As the stimulus intensity increases, the flash duration must decrease.

questions.question: When looking at an image depicting light gray on one side, black on the other and a smooth transition in between, observers report the appearance of light and dark bars. What is the name of this phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Mach bands are typically observed when there is a smooth transition between white/gray to black. Bands are perceived within the transition zones. These bands are created by the visual system due to the augmentation of high spatial frequencies. This augmentation results in the perception of bands or bars at transition zones. 

Xanthopsia is a type of chromatopsia generally induced by certain medications and causes the appearance of a yellow tinge to everything. 

Photoreceptors that are more tightly packed are able to discern a greater amount of detail than those that are loosely packed. Think of alternating light and dark bands. In order to properly appreciate these bands, one bright band must fall on one photoreceptor and an adjacent dark band must stimulate an adjacent receptor. If the receptors are too big or loosely packed, a light band may fall on half of one receptor and half of another; receptors then sum the information, causing a loss of visual information and the inability to properly discern the grating. The above is referred to as the Nyquist sampling theorem.

questions.question: The scotopic system is more sensitive than the photopic system for all wavelengths except those of which color?
questions.explanation:
The photochromatic interval is a measure of the difference in sensitivities between the photopic system and the scotopic system for a given wavelength. The scotopic system is more sensitive than the photopic system for all wavelengths except those that are perceived as red (the longer wavelengths). Within this region of the spectrum, the photochromatic interval is essentially zero. An interesting fact to note is that for wavelengths measuring greater than 650 nm, the photopic system is actually more sensitive than the scotopic system, causing a reversal of the photochromatic interval.
PowerPage
Photoreceptors

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of the Stiles-Crawford effect of the first kind?
options: Your patient reports an image size difference when wearing a -10.00 D lens over the right eye and -2.00 D over the left eye
Your patient notes that the overhead light appears green after the removal of a red filter that was previously placed in front of the eyes
A patient reports a decrease in perceived brightness when incident light is not perpendicular to the cone surface
A patient reports diplopia when viewing a target binocularly with a 10 diopter prism placed base up over the right eye
answers: A patient reports a decrease in perceived brightness when incident light is not perpendicular to the cone surface
questions.explanation: The Stiles-Crawford effect describes the fact that rods and cones respond differently to incident light that is not perpendicular to their surface. Cones are oriented such that when light enters the pupil it will strike the cones perpendicularly to their surface, ensuring maximal absorption. Incoming light that fails to do so will be reported as less bright. This observation is not noted with the scotopic system. Interestingly enough, cones will orient themselves so as to increase the chances of light striking them perpendicularly.

questions.question: A typical dark adaptation curve can be divided into two sections. The initial section is characterized by a steep decline in threshold until about 5 minutes have elapsed. What is this initial rapid decline attributable to?
options: Dark adaptation by the ganglion cells
questions.explanation:
In order to generate a dark adaptation curve, an observer is exposed to a bright light that bleaches almost all of the photopigments. Once the light is turned off, the observer is left in a totally dark room and asked to detect large, centrally fixated, flashing stimuli allowing for detection threshold as a function of time to be measured. The result is a dark adaptation curve. The initial portion of the curve displays a rapid decrease in threshold during the first five minutes, which correlates with the regeneration of cone pigments and cone thresholds. The curve then plateaus and is followed by another, more gradual decrease in threshold after 10 minutes. This section of the curve is called the rod-cone break at which point the rods become more sensitive than the cones. The second dip is caused by regeneration of the rods, allowing detection of the stimulus. Cones take about 10 minutes to fully recover; rods have a total recovery time of 35 minutes. 

(Image adapted from Hecht S, Shlaer S and Pirenne M. Energy, Quanta, and Vision. J Gen Physiol. 1942;25:819-840).
PowerPage
Photoreceptors

questions.question: 64. Preferential looking suggests that visual acuity reaches adult levels of maturity at which age?
questions.explanation:
Preferential looking is a method used in developmental psychology to assess the visual capabilities of infants. This technique involves presenting infants with two visual stimuli and observing their preferences, assuming that infants will look longer at stimuli they find more interesting or are able to see more clearly.

Regarding visual acuity, research shows that infants' visual acuity improves over the first few years of life. While newborns have relatively poor vision, by around 6 months, they can see much better and can detect patterns, faces, and contrasts more clearly. However, their visual acuity continues to develop beyond the first year, and it generally reaches adult-like levels by around 3 to 5 years of age (36 to 60 months). At this stage, children typically have near-adult levels of sharpness in vision, meaning their ability to distinguish fine details is on par with that of an adult.

Thus, the period between 36 and 60 months is when visual acuity reaches maturity.

7. To optimize the rod–cone break of the dark adaptation curve for clinical testing, the stimulus should be
options: a. 0.50 degree in diameter and green
b. 0.50 degree in diameter and orange
c. 5.0 degrees in diameter and green
d. 5.0 degree in diameter and orange
answers: c. 5.0 degrees in diameter and green

questions.question: 31. A patient reads the line designated as 20/80 plus two letters on the next smallest line of an EDTRS acuity chart. What is the logMAR?
18. The colorimetric purity of a monochromatic patch of 440 nm is closest to

9. Assume that the absorption of 10 quanta of 510 nm by the eye of a rod monochromat results in vision. If the wavelength was 450 nm, how many quanta would need to be absorbed to produce vision?

13. When measured at an angle of 30 degrees to its surface, a matte surface with a reflectance factor of 0.70 has a luminance of 50 foot-lamberts. What is the luminance when measured perpendicular to the surface?
1. What percentage of the eye’s refractive power is provided by the cornea?
5. A rod monochromat views the following four patches of monochromatic light: 440 nm, 510 nm, 555 nm, and 565 nm. Each patch produces 20 quantal absorptions. Which is brightest?
options: e. All of the above are equally bright
answers: e. All of the above are equally bright

questions.question: 20. A sample has chromaticity coordinates of y  0.6 and z  0.1. What is the dominant wavelength of this sample?
21. What is the dominant wavelength of a mixture that consists of 33% of 490 nm and 66% of 580 nm?
19. The following five pairs of wavelengths are viewed by a person with trichromatic vision. Which pair contains wavelengths that appear most similar to each other?
49. The interblob region of striate cortex receives its primary input from layer
questions.explanation:
In the striate cortex (also known as the primary visual cortex or V1), the input from different layers and regions is organized in a highly structured manner.

Layer 4 is particularly important for sensory input in the cortex, and it is subdivided into several parts (4A, 4B, and 4C), each of which receives input from different sources.
The interblob regions are part of the cortical column system in the striate cortex and are involved in processing motion and spatial orientation. These interblob regions receive their primary input from layer 4B.
Layer 4B receives input from the magnocellular pathway, which is associated with processing motion and depth.
Layer 4C, on the other hand, primarily receives input from the parvocellular pathway, which is involved in color and fine detail processing and sends its outputs to the blob regions of the cortex, not the interblob regions.
Thus, the interblob regions mainly receive their primary input from layer 4B.

questions.question: 58. When tested using a forced-choice procedure, a patient with blind sight manifests
questions.explanation:
Blindsight refers to a condition where individuals who are clinically blind due to damage in the primary visual cortex (V1) can still respond to visual stimuli in ways that are not consciously perceived. These individuals are typically unable to consciously see or report objects in their visual field, yet they can demonstrate the ability to detect or localize stimuli above the level of chance.

When tested using a forced-choice procedure (where the patient is given two or more options to choose from), a person with blindsight tends to perform above chance. This means they can correctly identify or respond to visual stimuli at a rate higher than random guessing would predict, even though they do not have conscious awareness of the stimuli. The ability to perform above chance suggests that some unconscious visual processing is still occurring, likely through pathways other than the damaged primary visual cortex, such as the superior colliculus or other subcortical structures involved in visual processing.

In contrast, chance performance (answer b) would indicate that the patient was unable to detect the stimulus in a way that exceeds random guessing, which does not typically occur in blindsight.

Random responses (answer c) imply a lack of any systematic response, which also wouldn't align with the typical findings of blindsight, where the patient is able to demonstrate some level of visual ability despite lacking conscious vision.

41. Ocular disease is expected to cause the slope of the psychometric function to
questions.explanation:
A psychometric function typically describes the relationship between stimulus intensity (or some other stimulus characteristic) and the likelihood of a correct response. It is commonly used in sensory testing to assess how well a subject can detect a stimulus at various intensities.

In the case of ocular disease, which affects vision, the slope of the psychometric function typically decreases. This means that individuals with ocular diseases may have a reduced ability to discriminate between different stimulus intensities. As a result, their performance becomes less sensitive to changes in the stimulus intensity, which makes the slope of their psychometric function flatter.

Steeper slopes usually indicate that the individual can distinguish between small differences in stimulus intensity with high sensitivity.
Flatter slopes (i.e., a decrease in the slope) indicate that the individual is less sensitive to changes in stimulus intensity and may require more significant differences in the stimulus to perceive them.
Ocular diseases, such as cataracts, macular degeneration, or glaucoma, impair visual processing, leading to reduced sensitivity to visual stimuli. This reduction in sensitivity causes the slope of the psychometric function to decrease, as it becomes harder for the individual to detect differences in visual stimuli.

questions.question: 21. As the mixture field of the Nagel anomaloscope is adjusted
options: c. both luminance and radiance remain constant
questions.explanation:
The Nagel anomaloscope is a device used to assess color vision and specifically to diagnose color vision deficiencies, particularly red-green color deficiencies. The test works by asking the subject to match the color of a mixture of red and green light with a reference yellow light.

In the context of the Nagel anomaloscope, the term 'mixture field' refers to the adjustable portion of the device where the subject mixes red and green lights to match the yellow light.

Luminance refers to the perceived brightness of the light. When adjusting the mixture of red and green in the anomaloscope, the luminance of the mixture field remains constant. This means that while the hue (the color) of the mixture changes as the ratio of red and green light is adjusted, the overall brightness of the field doesn't change, ensuring that the color match is based on hue, not brightness.

Radiance, on the other hand, refers to the total power of light emitted per unit area and can change as the red and green light intensities are adjusted.

Therefore, as the mixture field of the anomaloscope is adjusted, the luminance remains constant, while the radiance (which includes both the intensity and the spectrum of the light) can change depending on the adjustment of the red and green components.

questions.question: 36. Which of the following will not be appreciated by a patient with monocular vision?
55. A hypercolumn contains a complete set of
options: a. ocular dominance and orientation columns
b. thin and thick dark stripes
answers: a. ocular dominance and orientation columns
questions.explanation:
hypercolumn is a concept in the organization of the visual cortex, specifically in the striate cortex (V1). It refers to a small, repeating unit of the cortical structure that contains a complete set of visual processing information for a given region of the visual field. This includes:

Ocular Dominance Columns: These columns correspond to the dominance of input from either the left or right eye. In the striate cortex, neurons are organized into columns that preferentially respond to input from one eye or the other, alternating across the cortex in a columnar fashion.

Orientation Columns: These columns correspond to the preference of neurons for particular orientations of edges or lines. Neurons within each column are tuned to a specific angle of line orientation, and this preference is mapped across the visual cortex in a systematic way.

A hypercolumn contains all the information required to process the visual input from a specific part of the visual field, combining ocular dominance and orientation columns, making it a functional unit for processing both depth (binocular input) and the basic visual features like edges and lines.

Why the other options are incorrect:
b. Thin and thick dark stripes: These are actually a feature of the organization of the visual areas V2 and not a defining feature of a hypercolumn in V1. These stripes are associated with processing different aspects of visual stimuli, but they do not directly define a hypercolumn.

c. Blobs: Blobs are areas in V1 that are involved in color processing, particularly related to the parvocellular pathway, but a hypercolumn does not specifically contain just the blobs; it refers to a larger unit that incorporates ocular dominance, orientation columns, and sometimes blobs.

Thus, the correct definition of a hypercolumn is a region that includes both ocular dominance and orientation columns.

29. The visual acuity of amblyopic patients is poorer when measured using a Snellen chart than with isolated optotypes because of
questions.explanation:
Amblyopia, commonly known as 'lazy eye,' is a condition where the vision in one eye doesn't develop properly during early childhood, leading to decreased visual acuity that cannot be fully corrected with glasses or contact lenses. One of the key aspects of amblyopia is that the brain favors the stronger eye, and the weaker eye is often not used effectively for visual tasks.

When measuring visual acuity, there is a difference between how a person with amblyopia performs on a Snellen chart versus when the optotypes (letters or symbols) are presented in isolation.

Snellen chart: The letters on the Snellen chart are often displayed in a sequence or in a crowded arrangement, which can cause difficulty in visual processing. For patients with amblyopia, the interaction between multiple letters and the visual field can lead to interference in recognition. This is known as simultaneous masking, where the presence of surrounding letters or stimuli reduces the ability of the amblyopic eye to resolve the target letter clearly.

Isolated optotypes: When the target letters are presented in isolation (one letter at a time), there is less visual interference from surrounding stimuli, allowing the patient to focus on the individual letter and perform better. This minimizes the effect of simultaneous masking.

Why the other options are incorrect:
b. Metacontrast: This refers to a phenomenon where an object is presented briefly and is followed by a second stimulus that contrasts with the first, but this second stimulus does not overlap with the first. Metacontrast mainly affects the perception of temporal stimuli rather than spatial stimuli like optotypes on a Snellen chart.

c. Paracontrast: This term refers to the effect where objects are perceived more clearly when they are surrounded by a field of stimuli that are similar to them. Paracontrast is less relevant to the case of amblyopia, where the issue is primarily related to interference from surrounding stimuli rather than enhancement from similar surrounding fields.

Thus, the poorer visual acuity in amblyopic patients when using a Snellen chart is primarily due to simultaneous masking, where the presence of multiple nearby optotypes reduces the clarity of the target optotype.

Brown hair is a dominant trait while blond hair is recessive. If a person who is heterozygous for this trait mates with a person who is homozygous recessive for this trait, what is the probability that their first child will have blond hair?
questions.explanation:
A simple Punnett square can be used to help solve this question. One mate is heterozygous for the trait and is represented as Bb. The other person is homozygous recessive with the notation of bb. The Punnett square is as follows: 
B b 
--------------------------------- 
B { Bb } bb 
b { Bb } bb 

Therefore, the probability of their first child having blond hair is 1/2 or 50%, and the probability of the child having brown hair is also 50%.

questions.question: A woman who is NOT a carrier of a gene that codes for color blindness mates with a man who is color blind. What are the chances that their DAUGHTER will be a carrier?
questions.explanation: Color blindness is an X-linked recessive gene. As we know, it is the male that determines the sex of the child, either contributing an X or a Y. The female only contributes an X to her offspring. Therefore, if the male possesses an X-linked recessive gene, he will pass it on to 100% of his daughters but none of his sons. However, if the mother is not a carrier herself, her daughters will only be carriers but will not display the phenotype associated with the genetic defect because it is recessive and they will inherit a normal X from their mother. It is for this reason that females rarely express an X-linked genetic defect, while males are affected to a much higher degree.

questions.question: What is the average lifespan of a typical red blood cell?
questions.explanation: Red blood cells are vital for the delivery of oxygen to tissues of the body. These cells develop in red bone marrow and reach maturity in 7 days, revealing a biconcave disc that lacks a nucleus. Erythrocytes circulate in the blood for around 100-120 days before being broken down by macrophages.

questions.question: Your 66 year-old female patient with a history of type 2 diabetes reports during case history that her last tested A1c level was about 6.0%. Which of the following MOST closely corresponds to her average blood sugar level in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL)?
questions.explanation:
Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) levels can be translated to an estimated average blood sugar level, which can help a patient and doctor better understand the values and more easily compare them to random and fasting blood sugar levels. 

An easy way to remember this conversion is to begin with an HbA1c value of 5.0, which corresponds to an average blood sugar value of approximately 100mg/dL. For each increase in the HbA1c of 1.0, the estimated average blood sugar value increases by a factor of about 30. In this case, an A1c level of 6.0% would correspond to an average blood sugar of about 130mg/dL. 

This is a table with the actual conversion values: 
5 % = 97 mg/dL 
6 % = 126 mg/dL 
7 % = 154 mg/dL 
8 % = 183 mg/dL 
9 % = 212 mg/dL 
10 % = 240 mg/dL 
11 % = 269 mg/dL 
12 % = 298 mg/dL 
13 % = 326 mg/dL 
14 % = 355 mg/dL 

For someone who does not have diabetes, a normal A1c level will typically range from 4.5 to 6.0%, while a person who has had uncontrolled diabetes for several years may have an A1c level of closer to 8.0 or 9.0%. 

When A1c levels are used to help in the diagnosis of diabetes, a value of 6.5% or higher on two separate occasions indicates that the patient has diabetes (5.7 to 6.4% is considered pre-diabetic). For most patients who have been diagnosed with diabetes, a common treatment target level tends to be 7.0%; however higher or lower targets may be recommended in certain cases.

questions.question: A typical sperm contains how many chromosomes?
questions.explanation: A typical sperm and a normal egg each contain 23 chromosomes. During reproduction the two join, eventually resulting in the creation of a baby with 46 chromosomes.

questions.question: A glycosylated hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) measurement reflects the average levels of blood glucose over which of the following time periods preceding the test?
questions.explanation: According to the American Diabetes Association, the A1c test provides a measurement that reflects the average blood glucose level over a period of 2-3 months. This is in contrast to a fasting blood sugar measurement, in which the level reflects only the blood glucose level at that specific moment. A1c measurements are used for monitoring how well a patient's treatment plan is working and for making decisions on further management for each individual case. The A1c measurement also tends to be more convenient for patients in that it does not require fasting and may be performed at any time during the day. Normal A1c levels are typically below 5.7%, while patients are considered pre-diabetic if their A1c levels are between 5.7% and 6.5%. Patients who exhibit an A1c level above 6.5% on at least two measurements are diagnosed as having diabetes.

questions.question: A chin fissure is a dominant trait. If a father who is homozygous-dominant for this trait and a mother who is homozygous-recessive for this trait mate, what are the chances that their first child will have a chin fissure?
questions.explanation:
Because the father is homozygous-dominant, it is indicated that he possesses a dominant gene pair for the chin fissure trait (FF). On the other hand, the mother is homozygous-recessive for this trait; therefore, phenotypically she would have a 'normal chin' because she has an identical gene pair that does not code for a chin fissure (ff). Each child would receive an allele from each parent, but the pair of genes would not be identical (this is termed heterozygous (Ff)). 

However, because they would inherit a dominant form of the allele, this is the form of the gene that would influence the phenotype, resulting in the appearance of a chin fissure.

questions.question: You suspect possible giant cell arteritis in your 79-year old female patient based on her presenting symptoms. An erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) test result ABOVE which of the following values is considered abnormal and presents an increased cause for concern?
questions.explanation:
Patients presenting with signs and symptoms suggestive of giant cell arteritis (GCA) should immediately undergo erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) testing. Although there are no positively definitive studies on the range of ESR in normal patients, there is a formula that allows an estimation of the normal maximum ESR, which is dependent on gender and age. 

- For females, the maximum ESR can be calculated by adding 10 to her age and then dividing that number by two 
- For males, the maximum ESR is equivalent to his age divided by two 

Even if ESR testing is normal in patients exhibiting symptoms of GCA, these patients should still undergo a temporal artery biopsy due to the fact that 8-22% of patients with biopsy-proven GCA will show a normal ESR. Additionally, it is important to remember that an elevated ESR is not specific for GCA as it may occur in several other types of inflammatory diseases; however, an elevated ESR with an elevated CRP is considered much more sensitive in diagnosing GCA.

questions.question: How many bones of the skull articulate to form the orbit?
questions.explanation:
The orbit is a pyramidal shaped area formed by bones of the skull in order to protect the eye. There are seven bones that articulate to form this cavity. 
- Frontal bone 
- Lacrimal bone 
- Ethmoid bone 
- Zygomatic bone 
- Maxillary bone 
- Palatine bone 
- Sphenoid bone 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye (11th edition). Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.F.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. 2011. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: A female who is homozygous for hemophilia A mates with a normal male. What are the chances that her SONS will suffer from hemophilia A?
questions.explanation: Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive gene. As we know, it is the male that determines the sex of the child, either contributing an X or a Y. The female only contributes an X to her offspring. Therefore, if the male possesses an X-linked recessive gene, he will pass it on to 100% of his daughters but none of his sons. However, if the mother is not a carrier herself, her daughters will only be carriers but will not display the phenotype associated with the genetic defect; this is because the trait is recessive, and the daughters will inherit a normal X from their mother. In the above case, the mother is homozygous for hemophilia A; therefore, all of the Xs that she will contribute to her sons will carry this gene and, as the sons only have one X, they will also suffer from hemophilia A. However, although all of her daughters will be carriers, they will not express the genetic defect because they will have inherited a normal X from the father. It is for this reason that females rarely express an X-linked genetic defect, while males are affected to a much higher degree.

questions.question: Arterial stenosis within which of the following ranges is MOST likely to produce the sound of a carotid bruit upon auscultation?
questions.explanation:
A bruit is a 'whooshing' sound that may be heard between quick beats of the heart (mid-systole), commonly representing irregular flow of blood around a thrombus in the carotid artery. However, many carotid bruits are discovered incidentally in an asymptomatic patient, and the presence of a bruit does not necessarily indicate artery stenosis. On the other hand, the absence of a bruit does not rule out the possibility of carotid artery occlusion, because a bruit is unlikely to be heard if the stenosis blocks less than 40-50% of the diameter of the artery, as there is not enough turbulence to be heard. It is also unlikely to be heard if the stenosis is more than 85-90% (as the flow may be too low). A higher pitch associated with a carotid bruit indicates a greater extent of occlusion of the artery.
PowerPage
Congestive Heart Failure

questions.question: What is the normal core temperature of the human body?
questions.explanation: Remember the body is a delicate system whose enzymes, hormones, and proteins function optimally within a certain temperature and pH range. The core temperature of a healthy person's body is 37 degrees Celsius or 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit. If the core temperature drops below 35 degrees Celsius, the breathing and heart rates slow and consciousness may be lost.

questions.question: What is a pneumothorax?
options: An inflammation of the pleural membranes
questions.explanation: A pneumothorax occurs when air collects in the space that surrounds the lung. This increases the pressure on the lung and may lead it to collapse. Common causes are chest trauma and lung diseases such as asthma or COPD; however, sometimes a pneumothorax may occur spontaneously in the absence of these causes.

questions.question: Which of the 2 following symptoms are required for the diagnosis of chronic bronchitis? (Select 2)
options: A chronic cough that exists for more than three months a year for more than two years
Chronic wheezing that exists for more than three months a year for more than two years
answers: A chronic cough that exists for more than three months a year for more than two years
questions.explanation:
Chronic bronchitis is considered an underlying condition in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). A diagnosis of chronic bronchitis is made when a patient has developed a chronic cough that exists for a period of more than three months a year over a period of more than two years. Additionally, a patient must have significant sputum production with no other possible causative factor. 

Emphysema is another underlying condition associated with COPD. It is a destructive process involving the lung parenchyma, which is defined as an abnormal permanent enlargement of the air spaces distal to the terminal bronchioles in addition to destruction of the alveolar walls. Patients with emphysema typically develop wheezing and difficulty breathing. In some cases, individuals will develop a 'barrel' chest due to the lungs being full of air that can't be exhaled. 

Encyclopedia of Occupational Health and Safety (4th edition). Stellman, G.M. 1998. 

Swanson's Family Medicine Review: Problem Oriented Approach (6th edition). Tallia, A.F., Scherger J.E., Dickey, N. 2009. Mosby Elsevier. Philadelphia, PA.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a Type III hypersensitivity reaction?
options: A delayed hypersensitivity reaction involving antigen-presenting cells, antigen, and T lymphocytes
An immediate hypersensitivity reaction involving the interaction of IgE and mast cell degranulation
An immune complex hypersensitivity reaction involving the interaction of circulating antigen-antibody complexes in blood vessel walls causing neutrophil emigration and tissue damage
An immediate hypersensitivity reaction involving the interaction of IgG to antigens on body tissues
answers: An immune complex hypersensitivity reaction involving the interaction of circulating antigen-antibody complexes in blood vessel walls causing neutrophil emigration and tissue damage
questions.explanation: There are four types of hypersensitivity reactions. Type III is characterized by antigen-antibody complexes. Type I is the immediate hypersensitivity reaction mediated by IgE. Type II involves IgG and body tissues (i.e. RBCs). The delayed hypersensitivity reaction (Type IV) involves the presentation of antigen through antigen-presenting cells to lymphocytes.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a monocyte?
options: A leukocyte that triggers the formation of membrane attack complexes
A type of leukocyte responsible for mast cell release
A type of granulocytic white blood cell
An immature macrophage located in the blood
answers: An immature macrophage located in the blood
questions.explanation:
There are two major classes of leukocytes: granulocytes and agranulocytes. Neutrophils, basophils and eosinophils all fall under the category of granulocytes due to the fact that they contain a lobed nucleus and possess cytoplasmic granules visible upon staining. 

The second class of leukocytes is agranulocytes, aptly named because they do not possess cytoplasmic granules. This class contains two types of cells, monocytes and lymphocytes. Monocytes are immature macrophages that move into an infection site and divide and differentiate into macrophages and dendritic cells that destroy microbes and debris via phagocytosis. Lymphocytes, the T cells and the B cells, are involved in hosting specific immune responses. 

Basophils release histamine, along with other substances, that prolong the inflammatory response.

questions.question: A father brings in his two-year old son for evaluation at your office. The father remarks that his son was born with what appears as a small red birthmark on his forehead. He wishes to know if it requires treatment or warrants removal. Applying pressure over the area of interest causes blanching of the lesion, and the father reports that the birthmark appears darker when his son cries. What is your prognosis?
options: A pre-cursor to a malignant condition and will continue to increase in size with time
Benign and will likely regress by the time the child is 5 years of age
Benign but is likely to be permanent and will darken will time
answers: Benign and will likely regress by the time the child is 5 years of age
questions.explanation: The above findings describe a capillary hemangioma (also called a strawberry mark), which is a patch of blood vessels or a vascular birthmark. Most hemangiomas occur at birth or shortly thereafter. There are several different types of hemangiomas, but the most common is the capillary type. The capillary hemangioma will blanch with applied pressure and tends to change color with Valsalva maneuvers, crying, or straining due to changes in blood flow. The majority of these types of vascular lesions will regress by the time the child is 5 years old. If the lesion is still present past puberty, then the lesion is likely permanent and may be removed if the patient is unhappy with the cosmesis.

questions.question: What is the functional unit of a muscle contraction?
questions.explanation:
A sarcomere is the functional unit of a muscle contraction. Myofibrils are composed of multiple sarcomeres. Within one sarcomere are small filaments called actin and myosin that slide past each other resulting in motion. 

Multiple molecules of myosin form a thick filament with the myosin head exposed. Actin proteins form thin filaments. Upon contraction of a muscle, a cross bridge forms between the heads, shortening the sarcomere length.

questions.question: Which of the following infections must be reported to the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)?
questions.explanation: According to the CDC, all health care providers and laboratories must report new cases of syphilis to local and state health departments. Gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis must also be reported along with many other serious types of infections that are easily spread and can produce long-term systemic effects.

questions.question: Which of the following neurotransmitters causes muscle contraction?
questions.explanation:
For muscle contraction to occur, Acetylcholine (ACh) is released from the presynaptic terminals of the motor neurons. At the neuromuscular junction, the neuron becomes stimulated, and calcium causes vesicles that contain ACh to fuse with axon endings and release ACh into the synapse. The ACh then binds with receptors on the muscle cell membrane, resulting in muscle contraction. 

Depleted levels of serotonin have been correlated with depression. 

Dopamine is a type of catecholamine and plays a large role in Parkinson's disease. This neurotransmitter, if injected intravenously, also stimulates the sympathetic nervous system and causes increased heart rate and blood pressure. Overall dopamine plays a large role in cognition, memory, motivation, and mood to name a few functions. 

Glutamate is the main excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system and plays an important role in learning and memory.

questions.question: You correctly diagnose your 23 year-old male patient with herpes zoster ophthalmicus based on characteristic skin and corneal lesions. Due to his young age, which of the following possible associated systemic conditions should you rule out?
questions.explanation: Herpes zoster occurs most frequently in patients in their 6th and 7th decades of life. Younger patients presenting with this condition should prompt further testing for possible immunodeficiency, as the development of herpes zoster does not typically occur in children or young adults. Other conditions that may lead to early development of herpes zoster include malignancy (leukemia or lymphoma), patients who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation, or those who are concurrently taking immunosuppressive medications (steroids or chemotherapy).

questions.question: The presence of a chromosomal abnormality known as the 'Philadelphia chromosome' is highly SENSITIVE for which of the following systemic conditions?
questions.explanation:
In up to 95% of patients diagnosed with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), the cancer cells contain a chromosomal abnormality known as the Philadelphia chromosome (named after the city where it was discovered). The Philadelphia chromosome results from a reciprocal translocation involving chromosomes 9 and 22. In the 5% of CML patients who do not exhibit the classic Philadelphia chromosome, there are translocations involving the same chromosomal regions, but these appear to be structurally more complex. 

The Philadelphia chromosome is highly sensitive for CML because 95% of CML patients posses this abnormality; however, the chromosome can also be present in a subset of patients with acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) or (occasionally) in those with acute myelogenous leukemia (AML). Therefore, the presence of the chromosome is not sufficiently specific to diagnose CML. 

Principles of Cancer Genetics. Bunz, F. 2008. Springer Science + Business Media. Baltimore, MD.

questions.question: Of the four major variants of leukemia, which type typically presents in children and has the BEST prognosis following proper treatment?
questions.explanation:
Acute lymphocytic (lymphoblastic) leukemia (ALL): This type of leukemia predominantly affects children but can affect adults as well (typically over the age of 65). The standard treatment for ALL involves chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Survival rates for children are very high, as about 85-90% of cases respond to treatment and close to 70% of patients become cured. Prognosis is more guarded in older populations, with an observed survival rate of about 50%. 

An easy way to remember the answer to this question is that 'ALL kids survive' (in ALL cases, the prognosis for children is very good). 

Acute myelocytic (myeloblastic) leukemia (AML): AML is most frequently found in older populations and rarely affects children. The treatment of choice in these cases is chemotherapy, and remission rates are about 30% (for those under the age of 60). 

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL): CLL typically affects adults over the age of 55. It may rarely affect younger adults, but almost never occurs in children. There is no cure for this type of leukemia, but there are many effective treatments. CLL has a very chronic course and is not typically fatal. 

Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML): CML more frequently affects older populations more frequently than younger adults or children. It has a progressive, chronic course with a less favorable prognosis. The mainstay of treatment for these patients is imatinib (a tyrosine-kinase inhibitor).

questions.question: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease that affects which of the following types of receptors in the body?
questions.explanation:
Myasthenia gravis is autoimmune neuromuscular disease in which circulating antibodies mediate damage and destruction of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in striated muscle. The subsequent impairment of function at the neuromuscular junction results in weakness and fatigue of the skeletal musculature (with no affect on cardiac or involuntary muscles). This disease most commonly occurs in women and typically presents in the third decade of life. The earliest presenting signs of this condition are usually the development of ptosis or diplopia.
PowerPage
Myasthenia Gravis

questions.question: Haversian canals are found in which type of tissue?
questions.explanation: Haversian canals are located within compact bone tissue. This type of tissue is organized into small circular layers that form around canals. The canals are connected to one another and house blood vessels and nerves used to maintain osteocytes.

questions.question: What is the correct sequence of structures through which blood passes as it travels through a nephron in the kidney?
options: Afferent arteriole-> proximal tubule-> loop of Henle-> distal tubule-> glomerulus-> collecting duct
Afferent arteriole-> loop of Henle-> glomerulus-> distal tubule-> proximal tubule-> collecting duct
Afferent arteriole-> glomerulus-> distal tubule-> loop of Henle-> proximal tubule-> collecting duct
Afferent arteriole-> glomerulus-> proximal tubule-> loop of Henle-> distal tubule-> collecting duct
answers: Afferent arteriole-> glomerulus-> proximal tubule-> loop of Henle-> distal tubule-> collecting duct
questions.explanation: Blood is delivered to the kidneys via the renal artery, which eventually branches into many afferent arterioles. One afferent arteriole is linked with one nephron. The afferent arteriole then branches to form capillary clusters; these form the glomerulus, which filters into the glomerular capsule. The glomerulus capillaries then leave the capsule by way of the efferent arteriole, which branches into the peritubular capillaries for cortical nephrons; the efferent arteriole branches into the vasa recta for juxtamedullary nephrons. The peritubular capillaries and vasa recta surround the tubular parts of the nephron and reabsorb water and solutes from the tubule. The capillaries then merge into venules and carry filtered blood away from the kidneys. Water and solutes leave the blood from the glomerulus and are carried from Bowman's capsule to the proximal tubule then into the loop of Henle, where they continue their journey to the distal tubule. The filtrate is then transferred to the collecting duct.

questions.question: Once a patient has been diagnosed with Grave's disease, which of the following is considered the MOST significant risk factor for developing thyroid eye disease?
questions.explanation: The most significant clinical risk factor for developing thyroid eye disease in patients diagnosed with Grave's disease is smoking. Studies have shown that the more cigarettes a patient smokes per day, the greater the chance of subsequent ocular complications. Conversely, giving up smoking has been shown to decrease the risk. All patients with thyroid eye disease must be explicitly told of the dangers of continued tobacco use. It is important that this conversation is clearly documented in the patient's medical record.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the MOST significant risk factor for the development of ophthalmic manifestations in a patient diagnosed with Grave's disease?
questions.explanation: Once a patient is diagnosed with Grave's disease, the most significant clinical risk factor for developing thyroid eye disease is smoking. Studies have shown that the more cigarettes a patient smokes per day, the greater the chance of subsequent ocular complications. Conversely, giving up smoking has been shown to decrease this risk. All patients with thyroid eye disease must be explicitly told of the dangers of continued tobacco use. It is also important that this conversation is clearly documented in the patient's medical record.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following blood tests are used in the analysis of kidney function? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
Healthy kidneys are responsible for removing wastes and excess fluids from the body. Several blood and urine tests can be utilized in order to assess proper kidney function. Three of the major blood tests include analysis of serum creatinine levels, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and a measure of glomerular filtration rate (GFR). 

Serum creatinine 
- Creatinine is a waste product produced by muscles of the body 
- A creatinine level greater than 1.2 for women and 1.4 for men may be an early indicator that the kidneys are not working properly 
- As kidney disease progresses, levels of creatinine in the blood will rise 

Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 
- Urea nitrogen originates from the breakdown of protein in food 
- A normal BUN level is between 7 and 20 
- As kidney function decreases, BUN levels will rise 

Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) 
- Measurement of how well the kidneys are removing waste and excess fluid from the blood 
- It may be calculated from serum creatinine level using patient age, weight, gender, and body size 
- Normal GFR values are 90 or above; a GFR below 60 indicates kidney disease; GFR below 15 indicates that treatment for kidney failure is necessary 

National Kidney Foundation

questions.question: The synthesis of testosterone by cells in the testicles is governed by which of the following hormones secreted by the anterior pituitary?
questions.explanation: In the event where the level of blood testosterone decreases, the hypothalamus releases GnRH, which causes the anterior pituitary to secrete LH and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH). The testicles possess receptors for these two hormones. LH stimulates Leydig cells to synthesize more testosterone (causing an increase in sperm levels); FSH release acts upon Sertoli cells, which help to nourish developing sperm. When testosterone levels increase, a negative feedback loop is created wherein GnRH production decreases. When sperm levels are high, Sertoli cells release inhibin which inhibits the release of GnRH and FSH.

questions.question: A 32 year-old Caucasian male presents to your office with a complaint of severe pain and light sensitivity in his right eye for 1 day. Upon slit lamp examination, you notice cells and flare in the anterior chamber with several areas of posterior synechia. You question him about other systemic symptoms, and he reveals that he has been having lower back pain and stiffness in the morning for the past 3 months. You suspect that he may have ankylosing spondylitis. Which test is the MOST confirmatory for this condition?
options: Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein blood testing
questions.explanation: Patients with ankylosing spondylitis will test positive for HLA B27; however, there are several other inflammatory diseases that will also give a positive result, such as Reiter's syndrome, inflammatory bowel disease, and psoriatic arthritis. ESR and C-reactive protein, and alkaline phosphatase levels will also be elevated in this disease, but they are non-specific and will be elevated in other disease processes as well. The only test that is absolutely confirmatory for ankylosing spondylitis is an x-ray of the affected area, which will show inflammation of the spine that leads to the formation of bone protuberances, and eventual fusion of discs (this is known as 'bamboo spine').

questions.question: Which of the following biochemical structures can act as antigenic material?
questions.explanation: Any of the above biochemical structures have antigenic potential. Proteins are excellent T lymphocyte-dependent antigens. Examples include diphtheria and tetanus. Polysaccharide antigens are T lymphocyte-independent antigens and hence do not require T cell input. Examples of polysaccharide immunizations include meningococcal and pneumococcal immunizations.

questions.question: Which of the following types of ultraviolet (UV) light exposure possesses the GREATEST link with sunburn?
options: All types of UV light have an equal affinity for causing sunburn
questions.explanation:
UV-A is the longest of the three types of UV light, ranging between 315-380 nm. UV-A is considered the least damaging of the types of UV light and penetrates into the deeper layers of the skin. UV-A radiation is much more abundant than any of the other types of UV light that reaches the surface of the earth. UV-B light ranges between 280 and 315 nm, and over-exposure to this type of UV light can lead to sunburn. UV-B exposure has a higher correlation with skin cancer and cataract formation than UV-A. UV-C light ranges from 100 to 280 nm, and because it has a shorter wavelength, it is also very high-energy; therefore, prolonged exposure can lead to solar keratitis. The majority of UV-C light is absorbed by the ozone layer. 

The cornea absorbs the majority of UV-C when the eye is exposed to this very short wavelength of light. The crystalline lens absorbs the majority of UV-A and UV-B, protecting the retina from potential UV damage. However, over time, the lens may become impaired and result in the formation of a cataract.

questions.question: Which of the following types of ultraviolet (UV) light is considered the LEAST damaging to the eye?
options: All UV light is equally damaging to the ocular structures
questions.explanation:
UV-A is the longest of the three types of UV light, ranging between 315-380 nm. UV-A is considered the least damaging of the types of UV light and penetrates into the deeper layers of the skin. UV-A radiation is much more abundant than any of the other types of UV light that reaches the surface of the earth. UV-B light ranges between 280 and 315 nm, and over-exposure to this type of UV light can lead to sunburn. UV-B exposure has a higher correlation with skin cancer and cataract formation than UV-A. UV-C light ranges from 100 to 280 nm, and because it has a shorter wavelength, it is also very high-energy; therefore, prolonged exposure can lead to solar keratitis. The majority of UV-C light is absorbed by the ozone layer. 

Handbook of Nutrition and Ophthalmology. Semba, D. Humana Press, 2007, page 143. 
Review of Optometry. February 15, 2014. The Lowdown on Blue Light: Good vs. Bad and its Connection to AMD. 
http://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/ultraviolet-light-rays-uva-and-uvb 
http://www.skincancer.org/prevention/uva-and-uvb/understanding-uva-and-uvb

questions.question: Destruction of myelin sheath in the brain and the spinal cord are associated with which disease?
questions.explanation:
Multiple sclerosis (MS) is attributable to destruction of myelin sheath around the axons of the brain and spinal cord nerves. Characteristic signs of this disease include numbness, fatigue, and muscle weakness. Vision may also be affected. In your office, always analyze visual fields; an altitudinal defect may be associated with multiple sclerosis. Optic neuritis is also a commonly linked with MS. 

Epilepsy can result from drug use, trauma, or infection. A common cause for epilepsy cannot be identified. Epilepsy occurs due to abnormal brain activity, leading to seizures. 

Alzheimer's disease is associated with memory loss, confusion, and dementia. For reasons that remain unclear at this time, neurons in the brain degenerate alongside an abnormal increase in amyloid protein. 

Parkinson's disease causes tremors and difficulty with movement. Cells within the brain that secrete dopamine become destroyed; it is unclear why.

questions.question: Alteration of the electric gradient across an axon's membrane such that the inside becomes momentarily positively charged relative to the outside of the membrane is known as which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
An action potential is triggered when enough input summates to cause a reversal of the voltage difference across the axonal membrane, causing the inside of the cell to briefly become positively charged relative to the outside of the cell. 

The resting potential of a typical neuron is roughly -70 millivolts. This electric charge is maintained across the membrane in a cell that is at rest and thus is not undergoing an action potential. 

A stimulus, if it reaches the threshold level, is capable of causing an action potential but is not an action potential itself. 

The nodes of Ranvier are the naked portions of the axon that are not enveloped in myelin sheath. It is here at the nodes where the action potential conduction occurs. Once an action potential is initiated, it spreads down the axon and actually jumps from node to node between the myelinated sections. This is termed saltatory conduction, which in Latin means 'to jump'. The nodes contain high numbers of voltage-gated sodium channels. It is via this manner that myelination increases the conduction speed of an action potential.

questions.question: Infectious diseases can spread quite rapidly. What is the term for a rapid outbreak of a disease within a given time span across several countries?
questions.explanation:
A pandemic is defined as an epidemic breakout of a disease across a large geographical area (i.e. several countries) for a given time span. An example of a pandemic disease is AIDS. 

An epidemic is a rapid outbreak of a disease that affects many individuals at the same time and is well above a predicted rate for a given area or community. 

Sporadic diseases don't occur very often and affect very few individuals. 

Endemic diseases are those that occur frequently or continuously with predictability. Examples of endemic conditions include ringworm and the common cold.

questions.question: During which phase of the cell cycle does DNA replication occur?
questions.explanation: The first stage of mitosis is prophase. During early prophase, DNA begins to condense inside of a nuclear envelope. During late prophase, the process involves further condensation of the chromosomes, the beginning of breakdown of the nuclear envelope, and the movement of one of a pair of centrioles to the other pole of the cell. During the transition into metaphase (sometimes called prometaphase), the centrioles send out microtubules, forming a spindle apparatus which attaches to sister chromatids of each chromosome. The microtubules attach at a site called a kinetochore on the centromere. At this time, the nuclear envelope has completely disintegrated. Metaphase is marked by the chromosomes aligning along the cellular equator, guided by the microtubules. Anaphase follows. During this phase, the sister chromatids of each chromosome are pulled apart and are directed to opposite poles towards the centrioles by the microtubules. This is now telophase. During this stage, the chromosomes are no longer attached to the microtubules and begin to become less condensed. Nuclear envelopes also form around the de-condensing chromosomes, separating the DNA from the cytoplasm. At this point, cytoplasmic division begins and is generally complete before the end of telophase. Both new cells are diploid and contain the same number of chromosomes as the parent cell. The cells then transition into interphase, in which the DNA is duplicated and the cytoplasm and its components increase in number. Interphase is the longest portion of the cell cycle and is not a part of mitosis. After interphase, the cell will then either move on to mitosis, or it will no longer divide.

questions.question: All of the following play a significant role in the innate immune system except for which choice?
questions.explanation: The innate immune system relies on natural anatomical barriers, the production of antimicrobial peptides, phagocytic activities by neutrophils (among other cell types), non-specific activation of complement, and the recognition of pathogen-associated molecular patterns that are then presented to pattern recognition receptors. Although the latter process involves pattern recognition, it differs from the adaptive immune system in that it only recognizes highly conserved microbial structures. Neutrophils phagocytose foreign materials and utilize oxidative burst to neutralize microbes. Other cells involved that are considered phagocytes include mast cells, basophils, eosinophils, macrophages, and dendritic cells. T lymphocytes' main function involves cell-mediated immunity and regulating humoral immunity.

questions.question: Progressive narrowing of the arterial lumen is BEST known as which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
When excess cholesterol or other lipids build up on the inside of the arterial wall, the lumen of that blood vessel narrows. This narrowing can become aggravated if a platelet becomes stuck on the rough edges of the plaque stimulating a blood clot. The artery may become so clogged that blood flow is impeded and the tissue or organs normally supplied by the vessel may become ischemic. If a coronary artery is affected, chest pains (angina pectoris) or a heart attack may ensue. Atherosclerosis is a type of arteriosclerosis. 

Arteriosclerosis results from thickened and hardened arterial walls. Arteriosclerotic blood vessels have lost much of their elasticity. 

Arrhythmias are irregular heartbeats. Remember, not all arrhythmias are evil. Endurance athletes can exhibit bradycardia (low cardiac rate).
PowerPage
Congestive Heart Failure

questions.question: The muscle point that inserts onto a skeletal bone that does not move upon stimulation is known as what?
questions.explanation:
The origin is the end of the muscle that is attached to the portion of a bone that remains relatively motionless during movement. The other end of the muscle is attached to the portion of the bone that displays the greatest degree of movement. 

Synergistic movement is created by muscles that work together to bring about a particular movement. 

Antagonistic movement ensues from groups of muscles that work in an opposing manner to create the desired motion. For example, the bicep contracts while the tricep relaxes to allow the raising of the forelimb.

questions.question: Which hormone is released by the hypothalamus and inhibits the secretion of the growth hormone and thyrotropin-stimulating hormone (TSH)?
questions.explanation: Somatostatin is produced and secreted by the hypothalamus and serves to inhibit the growth hormone as well as TSH. ACTH and prolactin are produced by the anterior pituitary lobe. The antidiuretic hormone is synthesized by the hypothalamus but is stored in the posterior pituitary lobe.

questions.question: If an antibody binds to an antigen and opsonizes the antigen, this will most directly lead to which of the following processes?
questions.explanation: Opsonization is process by which an antibody binds to an antigen and identifies it as a target for phagocytosis by a phagocytic cell. Antigen-antibody binding can lead to complement fixation, but this process is not known as opsonization. After an antigen is phagocytosed, further signaling can ultimately lead to antigen presentation and stimulation of secretion of specific antibodies, but this question asks for the direct effect of the opsonization of an antigen by an antibody, which is phagocytosis.

questions.question: Which of the following congenital disorders classically presents with ocular findings including limbal dermoids, microphthalmos, and upper eyelid notching?
questions.explanation:
Ocular features associated with Goldenhar syndrome include epibulbar or limbal dermoids, microphthalmos, anophthalmos, blepharophimosis, upper eyelid notching, and optic disc colobomas. Additional systemic features can include malar, maxillary, and mandibular hypoplasia, mental deficiency, facial skin tags, macrostomia (wide mouth), and microtia (underdeveloped outer ear). 

Patients with Crouzon, Apert, and Pfeiffer syndromes typically present with proptosis secondary to shallow orbits, hypertelorism (widely spaced orbits), and exotropia. Visually threatening conditions such as exposure keratopathy and optic atrophy can occur as a result of the shallow orbits and compression at the optic foramen. 

Ocular associations of Treacher Collins syndrome include microphthalmos, cataracts, punctal atresia, antimongoloid slanting of the palpebral apertures, and lateral lower eyelid colobomas.

questions.question: When describing epithelial cells of the integumentary system, which layer is in contact with the underlying connective tissue?
questions.explanation: The basal layer is in close contact with the underlying connective tissue. The apical layer or surface is the 'free' surface. A stratified layer implies multiple layers of epithelial cells. Keratinized epithelium implies that there is a layer on top of stratified epithelium with cytoplasm that has transformed into keratin. This provides a protective layer.

questions.question: Which of the following vessels lack a layer of smooth muscle?
questions.explanation: Smooth muscle that lines the walls of blood vessels helps to regulate blood flow through the vessels via relaxation or constriction. Capillaries are extremely important for diffusion and exchange of gases. These vessel walls are very thin and therefore lack muscle so as to maximize diffusion. The velocity of blood flow decreases tremendously by the time that it reaches the capillaries, many of which possess lumens that are so small that red blood cells must pass through in single file.

questions.question: The colon is divided into four regions. What is the order that undigested matter will pass through it prior to expulsion from the anus?
options: Ascending colon, transverse colon, sigmoid colon, descending colon, rectum
Ascending colon, transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, rectum
Ascending colon, sigmoid colon, transverse colon, descending colon, rectum
Ascending colon, descending colon, transverse colon, sigmoid colon, rectum
answers: Ascending colon, transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, rectum
questions.explanation: The colon appears like an inverted U. Undigested matter will first pass through the ascending colon located on the right side of the abdominal cavity, pass through the transverse colon to the left side of the body, and travel down through the descending colon. Lastly the matter will pass through the s-shaped sigmoid colon into the rectum and out the anus.

questions.question: Which of the following terms BEST describes the hardening and thickening of an arterial wall?
questions.explanation:
Arteriosclerosis occurs when the wall of a blood vessel loses its elasticity and becomes abnormally thickened and hardened, which can lead to coronary, carotid or peripheral artery disease. 

Atheromatosis results from plaque depositing on the inner wall of the blood vessel leading to damage to that vessel. 

Atherostasis is not a medical term.

questions.question: Which hormone is secreted by the heart and helps to regulate blood pressure?
questions.explanation:
The atrial natriuretic hormone (ANH) is secreted by the atria in response to increased fluid volume signaled by atrial stretch. ANH causes the kidney to excrete greater quantities of sodium as well vasodilation of blood vessels, leading to a decrease in blood pressure. 

Calcitonin is released by the thyroid; it inhibits osteoclast activity in bones and absorption of calcium by the intestines, leading to diminished blood calcium levels. 

Melatonin is produced by the pineal gland in response to diminished light levels and causes the hypothalamus to ready the body for sleep. 

Erythropoietin is released by the kidneys and stimulates the production of red blood cells by the bone marrow.

questions.question: The cardiac cycle is quite complex requiring delicate muscle coordination. What is the correct sequence of signal conduction through the heart?
options: Atrioventricular node (AV node)-> purkinje fibers-> sinoatrial node (SA node)
Atrioventricular node (AV node)-> sinoatrial node (SA node)-> purkinje fibers
Sinoatrial node (SA node)-> atrioventricular node (AV node)-> purkinje fibers
Sinoatrial node (SA node)-> purkinje fibers-> atrioventricular node (AV node)
answers: Sinoatrial node (SA node)-> atrioventricular node (AV node)-> purkinje fibers
questions.explanation:
The SA node is considered the cardiac pacemaker. Located in the upper right atrium, an excitatory impulse is generated at this node causing contraction of the atria. The signal is then transmitted to the AV node where it is received by Purkinje fibers in the ventricles. There is a slight delay of the signal when it reaches the AV node, allowing for completion of atrial contraction. The SA node generates on average 70 to 80 excitatory waves per minute!
PowerPage
Circulatory System

questions.question: Which of the following regions of cardiac tissue is known as the 'pacemaker' of the heart?
questions.explanation:
The sinoatrial node (SA node) of the heart is a group of specialized cells known as cardiomyocytes that are positioned within the wall of the right atrium near the superior vena cava. They are considered the 'pacemaker' of the heart, as they produce the electrical impulses that generate the normal rhythm of the cardiac tissue. From the sinoatrial node, the route of depolarization of the heart then spreads across the atria to the atrioventricular node. The impulse is slightly delayed here until atrial contraction is completed. The wave of depolarization then quickly proceeds to the bundle of His, where it splits along the right and left bundle branches. The impulse eventually travels the length of these bundle branches along the path of the interventricular septum until it reaches the base of the heart, where the bundles divide into the Purkinje fiber system. The wave of depolarization is then distributed to the ventricular walls, causing contraction of the ventricles. 

Cardiology Explained. Euan, A.A., Niebauer, J. 2004. Remedica.

questions.question: Myerson's sign results from a failure to inhibit which reflex?
questions.explanation:
Myerson's sign occurs in people who are suffering from Parkinson's disease and in all infants younger than 2 months of age. Most people when tapped between the eyes can inhibit themselves from blinking. Patients with Parkinson's cannot inhibit the facial reflex and will always blink, which is referred to as Myerson's sign. The facial reflex is as follows: tap proximal to orbit-> ophthalmic division or maxillary division of trigeminal (depends on the location of tapping)-> midbrain-> pons-> stimulation of orbicularis, inhibition of levator palpebrae superioris. 

The corneal reflex occurs when something touches the cornea and stimulates the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve which sends a signal to the post-central gyrus. This signal is relayed to the midbrain stimulating the orbicularis and the lacrimal gland while inhibiting the levator palpebrae superioris. 

The dazzle reflex occurs as follows: bright light-> optic nerve-> visual cortex-> post-central gyrus-> superior colliculus-> stimulation of orbicularis and inhibition of levator palpebrae superioris. 

The menace reflex is outlined as follows: foreign object approaching globe-> optic nerve-> cortical association area-> post-central gyrus-> stimulation of orbicularis and inhibition of levator palpebrae superioris. 

The auditory reflex occurs as follows: loud noise-> auditory nerve-> pons-> stimulation of orbicularis and inhibition of levator palpebrae superioris.

questions.question: Which type of leukocyte is responsible for producing antibodies?
