questions.explanation: T and B cells both fall under the heading of lymphocyte. During an immune response, an antigen is swallowed by a macrophage. The antigens are broken apart into fragments and become bound to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules, forming antigen-MHC complexes. The complexes are recognized by virgin cytotoxic T cells and virgin helper T cells. The virgin cytotoxic T cells divide into effector T cells and memory T cells. The virgin T helper cells undergo differentiation into memory T cells and effector helper T cells. The memory T cells are stored for future encounters. The effector helper T cells promote mitosis of T and B cells to help combat the pathogens. Helper T cells do not kill any pathogens but help direct the immune system and the appropriate cells. Cytotoxic T cells are also known as killer T cells because upon contact with a target, they inject chemicals that cause death to the target cell. Virgin B cells, upon activation by effector helper T cells and interleukins, begin mitosis and differentiate into memory B cells and effector B cells. The new memory B cells are stored for future encounters. The effector B cells produce antibodies which serve to inactivate the offending agent.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms is the causative pathogen in Lyme disease?
questions.explanation:
Lyme disease is an infectious tick-borne disease that is caused by a flagellated spirochete known as Borrelia burgdorferi. 

Treponema pallidum is the causative organism in syphilis. 

Bartonella henselae is responsible for cat scratch disease. 

Onchocerca volvulus causes onchocerciasis (also known as river blindness). 

Cysticercus cellulosae is the organism that leads to cysticercosis (infection that results in cysts throughout the body). 

Cryptococcus neoformans causes a potentially fatal fungal infection known as cryptococcosis.

questions.question: Which of the following plays a critical role in directing B lymphocytes to initiate immunoglobulin class switching?
questions.explanation: Helper T lymphocytes are required for a B2 lymphocyte to switch from producing IgM to either IgG, IgA, or IgE. The type of helper cell, TH1 or TH2, determines if a cell will produce IgG, IgA, or IgE. The cytokines released by TH1 cells that promote switching to IgG1, IgG2, IgG3, and IgA include TGF-Beta and IL-5. The cytokines released by TH2 cells that promote switching to IgG4 and IgE include IL-4 and IL-13.

questions.question: A young male presents with significant conjunctivitis. In discussing the patient's review of symptoms, he describes the following findings: arthritis, burning when urinating, rash around the head of the penis, and rash around the plantar aspect of the feet. This is highly suggestive of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Reiter's syndrome is associated with conjunctivitis (and occasionally uveitis), with other immunologic manifestations of the skin and joints. It is considered a serum RF-negative, HLA-B27-linked arthritis, affecting men more than women. The trigger is commonly thought to be infections, particularly sexually transmitted Chlamydia or other infections such as Shigella, Yersinia, and Campylobacter. (Remember this little rhyme to help recall the triad of findings associated with Reiter's: Can't see, can't pee, can't dance with me.) 

Behcet's syndrome shares the finding of uveitis and the association with HLA-B27. Sarcoid can produce uveitis and arthritis but is unlikely to produce the other clinical findings.

questions.question: Glucagon helps to regulate glucose levels. This hormone is secreted by the pancreas from which type of cells?
questions.explanation: Between meals, glucose levels drop. In order to maintain an adequate supply of glucose for muscles and other cells, glucagon (synthesized by alpha cells), causes the breakdown of glycogen. Beta cells of the pancreas produce insulin, which helps to shuttle glucose into tissues after a meal, thereby decreasing blood glucose levels. Delta cells of the pancreas secrete somatostatin. This hormone inhibits the secretion of glucagon, insulin, and the growth hormone. Kappa cells of the pancreas do not exist.

questions.question: The brown color of human feces is attributable to which of the following components?
questions.explanation: Human feces typically displays a beautiful brown color due to the presence of bile pigments from the liver and gallbladder used in the digestion of fat. Although the food that we ingest can alter the color of fecal matter, it is generally colored brown. If blood is found in the stool it will change the color to black if the bleeding occurs in the stomach or small intestine or red if the bleeding results from rectal tears, hemorrhoids or other problems.

questions.question: The vast majority of nutrients are absorbed in the small intestine. This ability is facilitated by microvilli. What property of microvilli enables increased absorption?
questions.explanation:
The lumen of the small intestine is lined with microvilli which are essentially digit-like extensions of the mucosa that serve to increase the surface area over which nutrients can be absorbed. Monosaccharides and amino acids are moved across the cellular membrane via active transport where they then enter into the bloodstream by facilitated diffusion. 

The intestines also employ a type of peristalsis called segmentation. Segmentation creates oscillatory movements via repeated relaxation and contraction of smooth muscles in the intestines helping to mix its contents and increase absorption. Segmentation is not carried out by microvilli but rather by smooth muscle. 

Bile is an important substance used in the breakdown of fat. It is produced by the liver and stored in the gallbladder. 

Hydrochloric acid is secreted by cells in the stomach, not the microvilli; the acid serves to denature proteins, thus increasing their digestibility.
PowerPage
Small & Large Intestines

questions.question: What is the correct order of stages of human development during the prenatal period?
questions.explanation: The first stage is a zygote in which the sperm and egg fuse together. The developing baby is then termed a morula. At this stage, multiple cleavages occur, forming a solid ball of cells. The next stage is the blastocyst, which is marked by the presence of a ball of cells possessing a surface layer along with an inner mass of cells. The embryonic stage is next, which encompasses all development from 2 weeks post-fertilization to the end of the 8th week. Lastly, the fetal stage occurs. The fetal stage lasts from the beginning of the ninth week of pregnancy until delivery, which is generally 39 weeks from fertilization.

questions.question: When a blood vessel becomes ruptured due to trauma or injury, what is the body's first response to prevent blood loss?
options: Blood coagulation and formation of a blood clot
The formation of a platelet plug
Smooth muscle contraction in the wall of the blood vessel
answers: Smooth muscle contraction in the wall of the blood vessel
questions.explanation:
Once a blood vessel becomes ruptured, the body's first response is hemostasis. This is a process by which blood flow is stopped or slowed to prevent blood loss by contracting the smooth muscle of the blood vessel (termed a spasm). Spasms serve to constrict the blood vessel in order to slow or stop blood flow from the injured vessel. Once a spasm is initiated, platelets begin to clump together and serve as a temporary plug in the vessel wall. Next, blood coagulates and forms a clot either via the intrinsic or extrinsic clotting mechanism. 

The intrinsic clotting mechanism involves the production of prothrombin which becomes converted to thrombin. Thrombin then acts on fibrinogen, causing the formation of fibrin which is essentially consists of long sticky strands that clump together. The fibrin creates a net that entangles red blood cells and platelets resulting in a blood clot. This mass of cells and platelets closes the wound. 

The extrinsic clotting mechanism occurs due to the receipt of signals from enzymes and other substances that do not reside in the blood which causes the clotting of blood. Blood clotting in this instance is triggered by injured vessels or tissues surrounding the damaged vessels. Aspirin interferes with the extrinsic pathway.
PowerPage
Blood-thinning Agents

questions.question: What common ocular finding is seen in patients with Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI)?
questions.explanation: Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is a congenital, autosomal dominant condition that is characterized by brittle bones due to the production of abnormal type I collagen. There are four subtypes of OI, each with different severities and prognoses. Common symptoms include multiple bone fractures (due to brittle bones), potential hearing loss at an early age, and a blue hue to the sclera. Currently a cure does not exist for this condition; however, some drugs such as bisphosphonates and calcium supplements are delivering promising results. Therapies include caution with and minimization of dangerous or high-impact activities and practicing exercises geared towards building strong muscles and bones. Occasionally leg bones may need to be surgically reinforced with metal rods or braces. Some sources state that patients with OI are more likely to suffer from a retinal detachment due to poor scleral rigidity as well as the presence of subdural hematomas and retinal hemorrhages.

questions.question: In patients diagnosed with obstructive lung disease, which of the following is TRUE in regards to the calculated FEV1 / FVC ratio?
options: Both FEV1 and FVC are equally reduced; therefore, ratio is normal
Both FEV1 and FVC are equally elevated; therefore, ratio is normal
questions.explanation:
The ratio of FEV1 to FVC (forced expiratory volume over one second to forced vital capacity) is used in the diagnosis of obstructive and/or restrictive lung disease. This ratio indicates the amount of air that can be exhaled in one second in relation to the amount of total moveable air of the lungs. Studies have shown that normal individuals are able to exhale approximately 80% of their forced vital capacity in one second (and about 98% in 3 seconds). 

Patients with obstructive lung disease will typically show a decreased ratio (usually less than 70%) due to some obstruction of air escaping the lungs. On the contrary, patients with restrictive lung disease, the FEV1 and FVC are commonly equally reduced due to the presence of fibrosis or other lung pathology. Therefore, in these cases, the ratio tends to be approximately normal but may even be elevated as a result of increased FEV1 value relative to the FVC. 

Basic Skills in Interpreting Laboratory Data (4th edition). Lee, M. 2009. American Society of Health-System Pharmacists, Inc. Bethesda, MD.

questions.question: Respiration produces carbon dioxide as a waste product. The majority of carbon dioxide in the body is transported to the lungs via which mechanism?
options: Dissolved in plasma as carbon dioxide
questions.explanation:
The majority of carbon dioxide found in the body (about 70%) is transported to the lungs dissolved in plasma as bicarbonate; this serves as an important buffering system to help maintain a certain pH range. 

Around 10% of carbon dioxide is dissolved in the plasma, and roughly 20% is bound to hemoglobin in the form of carbaminohemoglobin.

questions.question: Where is the site of gas exchange in the lungs?
questions.explanation:
The alveoli are the sites of gas exchange within the lungs. The bronchi branch into bronchioles which terminate in alveoli. The lungs contain about 150 million of these small outpouchings. The alveoli are surrounded by pulmonary capillaries that enable rapid gas exchange. 

The lungs are surrounded by a pair of thin membranes called pleurae. These membranes actually fold back on themselves and encase the lungs. The pleural membranes are separated by an intrapleural space lined with a small amount of pleural fluid.

questions.question: Rigor mortis occurs due to the inability of myosin cross bridges to detach. What component is DIRECTLY necessary for cross bridge deactivation?
questions.explanation:
Upon contraction of a muscle, calcium is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR). This is a type of modified endoplasmic reticulum that surrounds myofibrils and is responsible for calcium storage and release. Once the calcium is released, it binds to troponin, causing the binding site on the actin filament to become exposed. Actin is then free to bind to myosin, causing muscle contraction. Adenosine triphosphate (ATP) initiates calcium uptake by the SR. In the absence of calcium, the binding site on the actin filament becomes blocked, allowing for muscle relaxation. 

When a person dies, ATP ceases to be formed. With the lack of ATP, the myosin cross-bridges cannot detach; this causes constant muscle contraction, or rigor mortis.

questions.question: Which of the following circumstances represents a limitation of the use of computed tomography (CT) in a patient requiring neuroimaging?
options: Cannot be utilized in patients with metallic foreign objects
Computed tomography poorly images bony structures
Imaging is difficult to perform on claustrophobic patients
Imaging requires patients to remain completely still during the long testing time
Computed tomography exposes patients to ionizing radiation
answers: Computed tomography exposes patients to ionizing radiation
questions.explanation:
Computed tomography (CT) imaging is widely available, relatively inexpensive, and generally quick and easy to perform when compared to other imaging techniques. Due to the instrumentation and faster testing time, claustrophobic patients and those with difficulty staying motionless tend to tolerate this test better. 

CT scans are typically indicated in conditions such as orbital trauma, bony involvement of tumors, detection of intraorbital calcification, and in cases of acute cerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhages. CT scans provide bone images of much greater detail than magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans. Additionally, CT is also used in patients with contraindications to MRIs, such as the presence of metallic intraocular foreign bodies, cardiac pacemakers, and ferromagnetic aneurysm clips. 

However, unlike magnetic resonance imaging, computed tomography does expose patients to ionizing radiation.

questions.question: An accumulation of which of the following metabolic wastes is associated with gout?
questions.explanation:
Uric acid is a waste product created when nucleic acids are broken down. If uric acid is not eliminated in the urine, it may accumulate and crystallize in joints, causing gout. Initially, patients who experience gout will often complain of pain in their big toe, knee, or ankle; these are the most common joints to be affected. 

Ammonia is formed during the process of deamination, wherein the amino groups are removed from amino acids that contain nitrogen. 

Protein metabolism results in the formation of urea in the liver; this is caused by the joining of two ammonia molecules with carbon dioxide. Some urea that is filtered by the kidneys is reabsorbed; the rest of it is eliminated in the urine. 

Kidney function is measured by evaluation of blood urea nitrogen. If these levels are found to be elevated, then the culprit is either depressed kidney function, body dehydration, heart failure, or a poor diet. 

The body rids itself of the waste product carbon dioxide via exhalation through the lungs.

questions.question: All of the following blood tests are appropriate in the evaluation of a patient who presents with central retinal vein thrombosis except for which choice?
questions.explanation: CEA is a biomarker for cancer, mainly colon cancer, but also lung cancer. It is not a screening test; rather, is used to follow people with a known disease. Central retinal vein thrombosis is usually due to hypercoagulability/hyperviscosity. When an elevated IgG or a distinctive spike is observed with IEP, myeloma or macroglobulinemia (which is much rarer) is suggested. Both of these conditions are associated with central retinal vein thrombosis. Diabetes is very common, and a blood glucose determination is appropriate. The most common cause of central retinal vein thrombosis is long-standing hypertension.

questions.question: The hip joint is an example of which type of joint?
questions.explanation:
Joints are points of contact or near contact between bones. Synovial joints are the most common type. This joint type separates bones via a cavity, and the involved ends of the bones are covered with a layer of cartilage that helps to cushion the joint. Cells that line the capsules also secrete fluid called synovial fluid into the cavity of the joint. Ball-and-socket joints allow for a full range of movement. Hinge-like joints, like the knee and elbow, allow for movement in one plane. 

Cartilaginous joints are found between the vertebrae and some of the ribs. In this joint type, the space between the bones is filled with cartilage, which allows for little if any movement. 

Fibrous joints do not exhibit cavities. This joint type serves to unite bones and is found on the skull bones of a newborn baby.

questions.question: In motor neurons and interneurons, the electrical signal is initiated at which location of the cell?
questions.explanation:
In motor neurons and interneurons, the action potential is initiated at the axon hillock (which literally means 'little hill'). The axon hillock, also known as the trigger zone, is located at the junction between the cell body and the axon and possesses a much higher density of voltage-gated ion channels. 

The cell body of the axon contains the cellular nucleus and integrates input from its respective dendrites. 

The axon terminal is literally the end of the axon and is responsible for releasing neurotransmitter into the synaptic cleft. 

Dendrites receive input from other cells and typically extend from the cell body. Multipolar neurons have many dendrites, whereas bipolar neurons have only one dendrite and one axon. 

The nodes of Ranvier are the naked portions of the axon that are not enveloped in myelin sheath. It is here at the nodes where the action potential conduction occurs. Once an action potential is initiated, it spreads down the axon and actually jumps from node to node between the myelinated sections. It is via this manner that myelination increases the conduction speed of an action potential.

questions.question: Chromosomes that are the same length, possess the same shape, and carry genes coding for the same traits are known as which of the following terms?
questions.explanation: A karyotype is essentially a plot of all 46 chromosomes lined up and ordered in homologous pairs (except for the sex chromosomes). Homologous chromosomes are the same size and shape and contain genes that code for the same traits. Sister chromatids are duplicate threads of DNA and are linked by a centromere, creating a chromosome that resembles an 'X' (the centromere's location can vary, resulting in unequal legs of the X). A diploid cell contains two sets of each chromosome type (one from each of the parents) and is sometimes symbolized as '2n'. Human haploid cells (like the sperm and egg) contain 23 chromosomes.

questions.question: Which region of an antibody acts as the antigen-binding site?
questions.explanation: Immunoglobulins are polypeptide heterodimers that are composed of 2 identical light chains and 2 identical heavy chains. The variable region VL/VH (variable light chain/variable heavy chain) composes the antigen binding site and accounts for antibody diversity.

questions.question: In order to enhance digestion, which hormone is released by stomach endocrine cells and serves to promote the secretion of acid into the stomach?
questions.explanation: Gastrin is produced by G cells in the stomach lining and is released in response to amino acids and peptides in the stomach. Gastrin stimulates the secretion of gastric acid by parietal cells to promote digestion. Somatostatin is secreted in several different locations in the digestive tract: the stomach, intestine, and the pancreas. This hormone inhibits acid secretion. Secretin is produced by the small intestine and is secreted in response to the presence of acid in the duodenum. Once released, it promotes the secretion of bicarbonate by the pancreas to help maintain a specific pH range in the small intestine. Cholecystokinin (CCK) is secreted if fat is detected in the small intestine. CCK results in the enhancement of secretin, gallbladder contractions and promotes pancreatic enzyme secretion. Both secretin and CCK slow the rate of stomach emptying to enhance digestion in the small intestine.

questions.question: Which of the following structures of the brain are primarily responsible for producing and draining cerebrospinal fluid, respectively?
questions.explanation: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is produced by modified ependymal cells in the choroid plexus residing in the ventricles of the brain. Its primary function is to cushion the brain within the skull and act as a shock absorber for the central nervous system. Additionally, it aids in circulating nutrients and filtering waste products from the brain. Cerebrospinal fluid circulates from the lateral ventricles to the third ventricle through the interventricular foramen (foramina of Monro). From the third ventricle, CSF flows through the cerebral aqueduct (Sylvian aqueduct) to the fourth ventricle. It then passes through the foramina of Luschka and Magendie to enter the subarachnoid space surrounding the brain and spinal cord. CSF will then eventually return to the vascular system by entering the cerebral venous drainage system through the arachnoid villi.

questions.question: During case history, your patient reports that he has a family history of Gardner's syndrome. Which of the following ocular conditions is MOST closely associated with this disease?
questions.explanation: Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigmented epithelium (CHRPE) has been associated with some inherited gastrointestinal polyposis disorders such as familial adenomatous polyposis, Gardner's syndrome, and Turcot's syndrome. These diseases are autosomal dominant syndromes that have a very high risk of developing adenocarcinoma of the colon. An observation of multiple CHRPE lesions upon fundus evaluation may provide very useful diagnostic information as they often precede the polyposis of the gastrointestinal tract, and therefore can be considered a marker for the disease.

questions.question: The presence of Reed-Sternberg cells on cytologic analysis is pathognomonic for which of the following systemic conditions?
questions.explanation:
Approximately 20% of newly diagnosed lymphomas fall into the category of Hodgkin's lymphoma; all other forms of lymphoma are considered to be of the Non-Hodgkin's form. Diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma is primarily made upon cytologic analysis, which will be positive for the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. These cells are large binuclear or multinucleated cells with abundant pale cytoplasm that contains nuclei with reticulated chromatin and prominent macronucleoli. It is the Reed-Sternberg cells that induce the accumulation of benign inflammatory cells, leading to enlargement of the lymph nodes. In addition to Reed-Sternberg cells, patients with Hodgkin's lymphoma also possess Hodgkin's cells (large mononuclear cells with reticulated chromatin) and either one or two prominent nucleoli. These cells; however, are not fully diagnostic of Hodgkin's lymphoma, but are considered highly suggestive of the condition. 

Koss' Diagnostic Cytology and its Histopathologic Bases (5th edition; Volume 2). Koss, L.G., Melamed, M.R. 2006. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. Philadelphia, PA. 

Hardcore Pathology. Wahl, C.E. 2007. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. Baltimore, MD.

questions.question: Which of the following systemic conditions can cause a falsely low measurement of a patient's hemoglobin A1c level?
questions.explanation:
There are a few conditions that may cause a reading of hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) to measure either falsely high or falsely low, therefore altering the reliability of the lab test. 

Conditions that falsely elevate A1c levels: 
-Iron deficiency anemia 
-Any process that slows erythropoiesis increases A1c by maintaining an older 
erythrocyte cohort in the blood plasma (e.g. aplastic anemia) 
-Alcoholism 
-Hyperbilirubinemia 
-Certain medications (high doses of salicylates, chronic opioid use) 

Conditions that falsely lower A1c levels: 
-Any process that shortens the lifespan of erythrocytes (e.g. hemolytic anemia, 
chronic kidney or liver disease) 
-Vitamins C and E (by inhibiting glycosylation of glucose to hemoglobin) 
-Pregnancy 
-Splenomegaly 
-Rheumatoid arthritis 
-Certain medications (antiretrovirals, ribavirin, and dapsone) 
-Hypertriglyceridemia 

In these cases, HbA1C levels may still be used to monitor blood sugar levels in patients with diabetes by comparison to previous readings in the same patient. However, goal values must be altered with respect to the underlying condition that is the cause of the unreliable result.

questions.question: Parietal stomach cells secrete a glycoprotein necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12 by the small intestine. What is the name of this glycoprotein?
questions.explanation: Intrinsic factor is secreted by the parietal cells that line the stomach. This glycoprotein is later used by the small intestine to help increase the absorption of vitamin B12. Hydrochloric acid is also secreted by cells in the stomach and serves to denature proteins, thereby increasing their digestive ability. Carboxypeptidase is secreted by the pancreas and passes into the small intestine to aid in the digestion of proteins. Food becomes broken down in the stomach and mixes with acid and enzymes to form a liquid called chyme which is then propelled into the small intestine for further breakdown.

questions.question: How does cigarette smoking contribute to hypertension?
options: Cigarette smoke leads to endocarditis, forcing the heart to work harder
Carbon monoxide causes the tissues to take up more oxygen resulting in ischemia
Nicotine stimulates the release of epinephrine which is a powerful vasoconstrictor
Nicotine causes an increase in high-density lipoproteins
answers: Nicotine stimulates the release of epinephrine which is a powerful vasoconstrictor
questions.explanation:
Nicotine causes the adrenal gland to release epinephrine which causes constriction of blood vessels and increases the heart rate, both of which can increase blood pressure. Carbon monoxide found in cigarette smoke displays a greater binding affinity to sites on hemoglobin than oxygen, forcing the heart to work harder to deliver oxygen to tissues. In addition to the above negative effects, carcinogens found in cigarette smoke may also play a role in plaque development. 

Myocarditis and endocarditis, inflammation of the heart muscle and heart valves respectively, is generally caused by viral or bacterial infections. 

Nicotine use has been linked to an increase in low-density lipoproteins (LDLs) and a decrease in high-density lipoproteins (HDLs). Remember, HDLs are the good form of cholesterol. Increased LDLs are related to atherosclerosis.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the physiology behind the second heart sound (also known as the 'dub' of 'lub-dub)?
options: Closing of the tricuspid and mitral valves
Opening of the aortic and pulmonary valves
Opening of the tricuspid and mitral valves
Closing of the aortic and pulmonary valves
answers: Closing of the aortic and pulmonary valves
questions.explanation:
The primary sounds of the heart are caused by vibrations created by pressure differentials that occur during the closure of the heart valves. The opening of heart valves is typically very slow, occurring without an audible sound, while the rapid closure of the valves creates the 'lub-dub' sound that can be easily heard with a stethoscope. 

The first heart sound ('lub' or S1) arises from the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves (also known as the atrioventricular valves). The mitral valve closes slightly earlier than the tricuspid valve because contraction of the ventricles begins with the left ventricle. 

The second heart sound ('dub' or S2) occurs as a result of the closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves (also known as the semilunar valves). The aortic valve closes just before the pulmonary valve due to the fact that the ejection of blood ends first in the left ventricle. 

Handbook of Cardiac Anatomy, Physiology, and Devices. (Second edition). Iaizzo, P.A. 2009. Springer. Minneapolis, MN.

questions.question: When determining a newborn's APGAR score, which 2 of the following are NOT included in the 5 items that the physician evaluates? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
The APGAR scoring system is a quick and accurate way of evaluating a baby's physical status directly after delivery. A physician or nurse will observe 5 signs and record a score for each on a scale of 0-2 based upon the degrees to which the sign is present (0-poor, 1-fair, 2-good). The 5 scores are then added together and range from 0-10. A score of 10 implies that the baby is in the best possible condition. A score of 8 or 9 indicates that the baby is in good condition, 4-7 indicates a fair condition, and 0-3 indicates a poor condition and the need for prompt diagnosis and treatment. The 5 signs are: 

1. Heart rate: 0-not detectable, 1-slow (less than 100), 2-Above 100 
2. Respiratory effort: 0-absent, 1-slow, irregular, 2-good; crying 
3. Muscle tone: 0-flaccid, 1-some flexion of extremities, 2-active motion 
4. Reflex irritability: 0-no response, 1-grimace, 2-cry, cough, or sneeze 
5. Color: 0-blue, pale, 1-body pink, extremities bluish, 2-completely pink or absence of cyanosis 

Weight and length of the baby are not related to the APGAR score. 

Price, D.L., Gwin, J.F. (2008). Pediatric Nursing: An Introductory Text (10th ed.). St. Louis, MO: Saunders Elsevier

questions.question: Which of the following signs is considered pathognomonic for rubeola?
questions.explanation:
Rubeola, also known as the red measles, is an infection seen in children between the ages of 5 and 15 caused by the paramyxovirus. This condition is extremely contagious causing a fever, blood-shot eyes, sore throat, and coughing followed by a maculopapular rash on the trunk, limbs, arms, face and neck. Koplik's spots occur on the buccal mucous membranes and appear as white-blue spots surrounded by red halos. The virus is self-limiting and treatment is palliative in nature. Conjunctivitis can occur with rubeola and is best managed via ocular lubricants, vasoconstrictor drops, and sunglasses if the patient is photosensitive. Topical antivirals are ineffective. Thankfully, a vaccination exists for rubeola that limits the outbreak incidence of this virus. 

Parotiditis is an infection or swelling of the salivary glands and is often seen with mumps. 

A maculopapular rash can be caused by a variety of viruses and is not a tell-tale sign of measles.

questions.question: Which of the following systemic conditions occurs as a result of prolonged exposure to significantly elevated levels of glucocorticoids?
questions.explanation:
Cushing's syndrome is a systemic condition that is caused by prolonged elevation of glucocorticoid levels in the bloodstream. The most common etiology of Cushing's syndrome is iatrogenically induced as a result of systemic administration of steroids. It may also be caused by hypersecretion of glucocorticoids by the adrenal glands or by hypersecretion of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) by a pituitary adenoma. 

Addison's disease is a chronic endocrine disorder in which the adrenal glands do not produce a sufficient amount of steroid hormones. 

Conn's syndrome occurs secondary to an aldosterone-producing adenoma of the adrenal glands. 

Hashimoto's disease is an autoimmune condition in which the thyroid gland is affected, most commonly resulting in hypothyroidism, with occasional bouts of hyperthyroidism. 

Paget's disease is a chronic, progressive bone disease characterized by abnormal bone destruction and regrowth.

questions.question: What is the primary route of infection of patients diagnosed with hepatitis C?
questions.explanation:
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), hepatitis C is most commonly spread to others by sharing needles or other equipment used in connection with intravenous drug use. Before the early 1990s (when widespread blood screening began), hepatitis C was also commonly transmitted through organ transplants and blood transfusions. Other, more common routes of infection include needle-stick injuries in healthcare settings and transmission of infection from mothers to children at birth. Less commonly, a person may also become infected with hepatitis C by sharing personal items that may have come into contact with another person's blood (such as toothbrushes or razors), or by having sexual contact with an infected individual. 

Hepatitis A is typically spread when the virus is taken in by mouth from objects that have been contaminated with fecal matter from an infected person. This may occur due to improper hygiene during food preparation, caregivers not washing hands after changing diapers, or certain sexual activities with infected individuals. Hepatitis A may also be contracted by eating or drinking contaminated food or water, although this avenue of infection tends to occur more often in countries other than the United States where hepatitis A is common and sanitary conditions are poor. The foods and drinks most likely to be contaminated with this virus are fruits, vegetables, shellfish, ice, and water. 

Infection with the hepatitis B virus occurs when blood, semen, or other bodily fluids of an infected person enter the body of another. Activities that can lead to spread of the virus include exposure from needle-sticks, direct contact with blood or open sores, sharing items such as razors or toothbrushes, sharing needles or other drug-injection equipment, sexual contact, and transmission to children during birth.

questions.question: On an electrocardiogram readout, what causes the generation of the T wave?
questions.explanation: Electrocardiograms (ECGs) are used as a non-invasive method of measuring the heart's electrical activity and allow for the diagnosis of many heart conditions. The first wave, called the P wave, lasts for about 80 ms and is generated by atrial depolarization. The QRS complex results from depolarization of the left and right ventricles. This complex generally displays larger amplitude than the P wave as the ventricles contain more muscle and therefore generate a more powerful contraction. The T wave results from recovery of the ventricles.

questions.question: The P wave seen on an electrocardiogram is generated by which of the following?
questions.explanation: Electrocardiograms (ECGs) are used as a non-invasive method of measuring the heart's electrical activity and allow for the diagnosis of many heart conditions. The first wave, called the P wave, lasts for about 80 ms and is generated by atrial depolarization. The QRS complex results from depolarization of the left and right ventricles. This complex generally displays a larger amplitude than the P wave as the ventricles contain more muscle and therefore generate a more powerful contraction. The T wave results from recovery of the ventricles.

questions.question: Exophthalmos is MOST often associated with which of the following systemic conditions?
questions.explanation: Grave's disease is a specific, immunologic cause of hyperthyroidism. Inflammatory cells can proliferate in the back of the eye, filling the orbit and forcing the globe forward (exophthalmos). It can also infiltrate the extra-ocular muscles causing muscle thickening and restriction of movement, leading to double vision. Hodgkin's disease is a specific form of lymphoma which could theoretically infiltrate the orbit and produce exophthalmos, although this is much less likely and would be seen late in the course of the disease. Cushing's disease (hyperadrenocorticism) is an excess of cortisone; Addison's disease (hypoadrenocorticism) is an insufficiency in cortisone. Neither Cushing's nor Addison's are associated with exophthalmos.

questions.question: What is the proper term for division of the cytoplasm during mitosis?
questions.explanation: During late anaphase/telophase, a layer forms at the center of the cell around the microtubules. An indent forms above this layer that leads to a cleavage furrow in which actin, a contractile protein, pulls at the plasma membrane of the cell, pulling it inwards and using it to essentially cut the cell in half, creating two daughter cells.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following anterior segment changes are MOST likely to occur during pregnancy? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
In addition to changes in corneal thickness that occur during pregnancy, other anterior segment findings also commonly appear during this time. These observations include a decrease in corneal sensitivity, which typically returns to normal by eight weeks postpartum. A decrease in intraocular pressure has also been observed during the second half of pregnancy. This finding may also persist for several months after giving birth. The reduction in IOP is likely caused by an increase in the outflow facility of aqueous as a result of a combination of several factors, including an increase in uveoscleral outflow (due to hormonal changes), decreased episcleral venous pressure, and a decrease in the overall pressure in the upper extremities. For these reasons, there have been cases of pre-existing glaucoma that have actually improved during pregnancy. 

Reduced tear production resulting from a disruption of lacrimal acinar cells commonly causes an increase in the possibility of dry eyes, infection, and contact lens intolerance. Some studies have also reported a development of Krukenberg spindles in pregnant women. This observation is not typically associated with other commonly seen findings in pigment dispersion, and the presence usually decreases during the third trimester and postpartum. The development of eyelid ptosis and other ocular motility defects have also been reported both during and after normal pregnancies; this is commonly related to fluid retention and hormonal changes.

questions.question: Which of the following microvascular events occur in response to prolonged hyperglycemia?
questions.explanation:
Prolonged hyperglycemia in patients with diabetes appears to have the following effects on hematologic and microvascular structures, potentiating the development of diabetic retinopathy: 
- Degeneration and loss of pericytes: these cells envelope capillaries and are thought to aid in the autoregulatory processes of microvascular circulation 
- Thickening of capillary basement membrane and proliferation of endothelial cells: this change can result in eventual capillary occlusion and retinal non-perfusion 
- Increased plasma viscosity and amplified platelet aggregation and adhesiveness: decreased capillary blood flow

questions.question: The exposed portions of the axon that remain unmyelinated and serve to increase the speed of the action potential are known as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The nodes of Ranvier are the naked portions of the axon that are not enveloped in myelin sheath. It is here at the nodes where the action potential conduction occurs. Once an action potential is initiated, it spreads down the axon and actually jumps from node to node between the myelinated sections. The nodes contain high numbers of voltage-gated sodium channels. It is via this manner that myelination increases the conduction speed of an action potential. 

The axon terminal is literally the end of the axon and is responsible for releasing neurotransmitter into the synaptic cleft. The cleft is a gap between the post- and pre- synaptic cells. 

Dendrites receive input from other cells and typically extend from the cell body. Multipolar neurons have many dendrites, whereas bipolar neurons have only one dendrite and one axon.

questions.question: White matter of the spinal cord is comprised of which of the following?
questions.explanation: White matter of the spinal cord is located on the outside of each disc. The gray matter is compacted towards the center of the cord and cross-sectionally resembles a butterfly. This is in opposition to the brain in which the gray matter is found on the outside while the white matter is located internally. White matter is comprised of bundles of myelinated tracts of nerves. The white appearance is attributable to the myelination. Grey matter is composed of dendrites, axonal cellular bodies, glial cells, and interneurons.

questions.question: Which type of connective tissue lacks blood vessels?
questions.explanation:
Cartilage is a type of flexible, specialized connective tissue that serves to cushion and helps to maintain the shape of certain body parts. Cartilage is avascular and as such, if injured, takes a very long time to heal. 

Bone connective tissue forms the weight-bearing tissue of the skeleton. This tissue type differs from other connective tissue in that its matrix is hardened and is abundant in calcium. 

Adipose tissue is important for fat storage. Fat is used as an energy source as well as a shock absorber. Common fat storage sites are above the kidneys, behind the eyes, under the skin as isolation, hips, abdomen and thighs. How much and where the fat accumulates is determined by genetics. Diet and exercise also serve to regulate the quantity of fat that is deposited. 

Dense, regular connective tissue is composed of parallel bundles of fibers which rows of fibroblasts located between them. Because they fibers are oriented in this manner, they are quite resistant to pulling forces along their axis of orientation and thus are ideal for supporting other organs and supplying elasticity. This type of connective tissue is generally found in tendons and skin.

questions.question: Elastic ligaments which serve to attach bones together are formed from which type of connective tissue?
questions.explanation:
Dense, regular connective tissue is composed of parallel bundles of fibers with rows of fibroblasts located between them. Because the fibers are oriented in this manner, they are quite resistant to pulling forces along their axis of orientation and therefore are ideal for supporting other organs and supplying elasticity. This type of connective tissue is generally found in tendons and skin. 

Dense, irregular connective tissue is also comprised of fibroblasts and fibers which are pre-dominantly collagen; they do not display structured orientation like dense, regular connective tissue does. This type of tissue protects organs that do not display a lot of stretching. 

Loose connective tissue contains many types of cells but lacks an abundance of fibers. The fibers that are present are very loosely arranged. This type of tissue is generally located around blood vessels and nerves as well as organs. 

Adipose connective tissue is specialized for storage of fat.

questions.question: The right atrium receives what type of blood and delivers it to which structure (via the right ventricle)?
questions.explanation:
The right atrium receives deoxygenated blood from tissues and delivers it to the right ventricle and then to the lungs. The lungs then oxygenate the blood and return it to the left side of the heart. Oxygenated blood is transferred from the left atrium to the left ventricle where it is pumped via the aorta to the body.
PowerPage
Circulatory System

questions.question: Which of the following is a co-morbid condition that simultaneously affects a large percentage of patients diagnosed with myasthenia gravis?
questions.explanation:
Approximately 75% of patients diagnosed with myasthenia gravis have concurrent thymus gland abnormalities; of these patients, 85% show hyperplasia or germinal center formation. Encapsulated tumors or thymomas occur in the remaining 10-30% of these patients. In patients diagnosed with ocular myasthenia only, the overall risk of thymoma is reduced to approximately 4%. Due to the relationship between the occurrence of myasthenia gravis and thymus gland abnormalities, it is thought that the thymus may play a significant role in the autoimmune response seen in this condition. In addition to thymus gland abnormalities, patients with myasthenia gravis also tend to have an association with hyper and/or hypothyroidism (3-15%), rheumatoid arthritis (5%), and systemic lupus erythematosus (2%).
PowerPage
Myasthenia Gravis

questions.question: You are on a cruise and one of the fellow passengers asks you about their sudden inability to read. Which of the following causes are you MOST likely to suspect as the etiology?
questions.explanation: A scopolamine patch is commonly prescribed to alleviate motion sickness or sea sickness. It is a powerful anti-cholinergic and can reduce accommodation and therefore result in an unexpected inability to read. The other conditions might produce ocular effects but not impaired accommodation or difficulty reading.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following symptoms are the MOST common presenting features in patients with myasthenia gravis? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
In cases of myasthenia gravis, ocular involvement may occur in about 90% of patients. In about 60% of patients, ocular symptoms are the presenting feature that leads to the diagnosis of this disease. Two-thirds of these patients will present with both diplopia and ptosis, less than 30% will have diplopia alone, and less than 10% will develop ptosis only. 

Other common signs of myasthenia gravis include lack of facial expression (myopathic facies), difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), difficulty speaking (dysarthria), and trouble chewing. Patients may also develop weakness of muscles, particularly of the arms and proximal regions of the legs. Difficulty breathing is a very serious symptom but rarely occurs in myasthenia gravis cases.
PowerPage
Myasthenia Gravis

questions.question: Your 34 year-old female patient reports to you that her previous optometrist diagnosed her with Holmes-Adie's syndrome. In addition to pupil abnormalities, what other systemic associations do you expect her to exhibit?
questions.explanation: Holmes-Adie's syndrome is a condition that involves pupillary signs (enlarged pupil with poor response to light), loss of deep tendon reflexes, and abnormalities of sweating. Other associated signs may include photophobia, hyperopia due to accommodative paresis, and difficulty reading. These ocular signs and symptoms occur as a result of inflammation and damage of post-ganglionic parasympathetic pupillary fibers that course from the ciliary ganglion to the pupil sphincter. Systemic associations are thought to be caused by damage to the dorsal root ganglia of the spinal cord. Although the underlying etiology is not fully understood, most investigators believe that Adie's syndrome occurs following a viral or bacterial infection that leads to damage to the nerve fibers.

questions.question: Meiosis results in the formation of which of the following cell types?
questions.explanation: Meiosis is classified as reductional division because the end result is four daughter haploid cells with 23 chromosomes each (the gametes). Somatic cells (body cells) contain 46 chromosomes; therefore, they may also be referred to as diploid cells. Mitosis of a cell results in the formation of two diploid daughter cells.

questions.question: Filtration occurs at which location within a nephron?
questions.explanation:
Filtration begins and ends in the glomerulus. Blood is filtered at the glomerular capillaries, and water and solutes are passed to the glomerular capsule. The filtrate is then passed to the proximal tubule, the loop of Henle, and the distal tubule for secretion and reabsorption. 

Ref: Staar, C and McMillan, B. Human Biology 3rd edition.(1999) pg 204-215

questions.question: Which of the following systemic neuromuscular conditions preferentially spares the extraocular muscles?
questions.explanation:
Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) affects most of the muscles of the human body due to an x-linked genetic mutation of the dystrophin gene. DMD is characterized by the progressive weakness and necrosis of striated muscle, with the exception of the extraocular muscles, which appear to be clinically unaffected. Although the etiology behind this exclusion is controversial, it is believed that the extraocular muscles have a better intrinsic ability to maintain calcium homeostasis as compared to other groups of striated muscle. 

Kearns-Sayre syndrome, Grave's ophthalmopathy, myasthenia gravis, and myotonic dystrophy (both types 1 and 2) are all conditions in which the extraocular muscles are either preferentially or exclusively involved. 

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy: Advances in Therapeutics. Chamberlain, J.S., Rando, T.A. (2006). Taylor & Francis Group. New York, N.Y. 

Adler's Physiology of the Eye (11th edition). Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.F.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. 2011. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: The reversible replacement of one differentiated cell type with another mature differentiated cell type (as seen in patients with Barrett's esophagus) is known as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Metaplasia refers to the reversible substitution of one differentiated cell type for another fully differentiated cell type within a given tissue. Metaplasia most commonly occurs in epithelial tissues and can be part of the normal maturation process or can be a result of some abnormal stimulus. This occurs in cases of Barrett's esophagus, thought to be the result of cellular damage from chronic stomach acid exposure. The original cells lining the lower esophagus are not robust enough to withstand this harsh environment and change into a cell type that is better suited for the environment. 

Dysplasia refers to a disorderly arrangement of cells due to an alteration of size, shape, and organization of cells within a tissue. Also, it usually affects epithelial tissues and is typically reversible. Dysplasia generally consists of an expansion of immature cells and a decrease in number and location of mature cells. An example of this type of growth is evident in epithelial dysplasia of the cervix (commonly identified on a pap smear), in which there is an increased population of immature basal-like cells of the mucosal surface that have not invaded through the basement membrane to the deeper soft tissues. 

Anaplasia refers to an alteration of differentiation. Anaplastic cells are usually poorly differentiated or undifferentiated. These types of cells divide rapidly but do not resemble normal cells structurally or functionally. 

Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells in a tissue. It may eventually result in the gross enlargement of a tissue or organ. One example of this type of cell growth is benign prostatic hyperplasia in which there is enlargement of the prostate in males. 

Neoplasia refers to a new growth composed of cells that were originally derived from normal tissue but have undergone a change that results in them becoming unresponsive to normal growth controls; this creates a tumor. Prior to neoplastic growth, cells often undergo another abnormal pattern of growth, such as metaplasia or dysplasia. 

Fundamentals of Toxicologic Pathology (2nd edition). Haschek, W.M., Wallig, M.A., Rousseaux, C. 2010. Academic Press. Burlington, MA.

questions.question: The most common type of excretory gland in which secretory products are excreted via exocytosis into a duct is known as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Merocrine glands are a type of exocrine gland in which secretion of the substance occurs as a result of exocytosis without any loss of the original cellular components. The pancreas and sweat glands of the body are examples of merocrine glands. 

Holocrine glands excrete their substances via rupturing of their plasma membranes; the cell is also destroyed during this process. Therefore, the cells themselves become part of the excretory product that accumulates in the gland. Sebaceous glands of the skin and meibomian glands of the eyelids are considered holocrine glands. 

Apocrine glands discharge part of the cell in order to release the secretory substance. It is less damaging to the original cell than holocrine but more damaging than merocrine. An example of this type of gland is the mammary gland. 

DiFiore's Atlas of Histology with Functional Correlations (12th edition). Eroschenko, V.P., DiFiore, M.S.H. 2013. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. Philadelphia, PA.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with a complaint of abnormal swelling of the face and hands and sudden excessive weight gain. She is sent for urine testing, which is positive for protein. This patient is most likely experiencing which of the following complications?
questions.explanation:
Pre-eclampsia is a combination of several classic factors that occur during pregnancy, including high blood pressure, fluid retention, and high levels of protein in the urine. This condition typically occurs in women after their 20th week of pregnancy and usually affects about 1 in 20 women. Some women may be asymptomatic; however, most patients experience symptoms of a reduction in the amount of urine produced, swelling of the face, hands, and feet, and/or sudden or excessive weight gain over a period of a couple of days. In addition, blood pressure is commonly elevated to levels above 140/90. 

Pre-eclampsia is a dangerous condition, and if not properly treated, it can progress to eclampsia, which is a potentially fatal condition that involves seizures and comas. It is unclear as to the cause of pre-eclampsia, but certain women have been shown to posses a higher risk (first pregnancy, women over 40, African-American women, women who have already suffered from pre-eclampsia, and women who have a history of high blood pressure, diabetes, or kidney disease). Treatment typically involves bed rest, drinking a lot of water, and close monitoring of blood pressure. In some cases, inducing labor early may be necessary.

questions.question: Which of the following chromosomal disorders occurs as a result of the absence or abnormality of either all or part of one of the sex chromosomes?
questions.explanation:
Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder in which all or part of one of the sex chromosomes is missing or abnormal. It typically occurs in about 1 in 2,000 live female births (this number varies slightly according to literature). 

Edward syndrome is a genetic chromosomal disorder cause by the presence of either all or a portion of an extra 18th chromosome (also known as trisomy 18). It occurs in about 1 in 6,000 births. 

Klinefelter syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality that results from additional genetic material on the X chromosome in males (also known as XXY). It exists in roughly 1 in 500 and 1 in 1000 live male births, but many of these males do not show symptoms. If the physical characteristics inherent in this abnormality have not become apparent earlier, they typically appear after the onset of puberty. 

Down syndrome is considered as the most prevalent chromosomal disorder and is the most frequently recognizable cause of mental or intellectual disability. It is caused by extra genetic material on chromosome 21 (also known as trisomy 21). Down syndrome occurs once in about every 700 births, is seen in all ethnic groups, and has a slight predilection for males over females, although this predilection is very small. 

Down Syndrome: The Facts (3rd edition). Selikowitz, M. 2008. Oxford University Press. New York, NY.

questions.question: An African-American woman presents with granulomatous uveitis and you correctly suspect sarcoidosis. What two tests do you recommend she obtain?
options: Back x-ray and Human leukocyte antigen (HLAb27)
Chest X-ray (CXR) and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) level
answers: Chest X-ray (CXR) and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) level
questions.explanation:
Sarcoid is a multi-system disease involving the eyes, skin, heart, and primarily the lungs. It is much more frequently found in African-Americans. There also appears to be an association with Scandinavian origins. 

Each of the answers has some element of applicability, but a chest x-ray with hilar adenopathy and an elevation of the angiotensin-converting enzyme is diagnostic. A back x-ray and HLAb27 are associated with uveitis, particularly the HLAb27. There is cardiac involvement in sarcoid so an EKG is appropriate but not diagnostic. CRP is a nonspecific measure of inflammation. Patients often suffer from shortness of breath and a spirometry is appropriate to assess breathing, but again, it is not diagnostic. Alpha I antitrypsin deficiency is associated with premature emphysema but is not specific for sarcoid.

questions.question: Which of the following ophthalmic manifestations represents the MOST common initial ocular sign in patients with an acoustic neuroma?
questions.explanation:
An acoustic neuroma is a benign intracranial tumor involving the myelin-forming Schwann cells of the vestibulocochlear (8th) cranial nerve. These tumors are typically very slow growing over the period of several years and may not exhibit any obvious symptoms in early stages. Eventually, when symptoms become apparent, these will include ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss (most common), diminished sense of balance, vertigo, a feeling of pressure in the ear, and tinnitus. 

As the tumor grows, it may lead to compression of the adjacent areas of the brainstem, resulting in involvement of other nearby cranial nerves. The most commonly affected is the trigeminal nerve (5th cranial nerve), causing diminished corneal sensitivity. Due to its location, the sixth cranial nerve may become involved, and very large tumors can result in elevated intracranial pressure; however, these signs are much less commonly observed.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following statements are TRUE in regards to the physiology of endocrine glands? (Select 2)
options: Endocrine glands secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream
Endocrine glands are also known as ductless glands
A sebaceous gland is an example of an endocrine gland
Merocrine and holocrine glands are considered types of endocrine glands
answers: Endocrine glands secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream
Endocrine glands are also known as ductless glands
questions.explanation:
Glands of the human body can be categorized into two major groups, endocrine glands and exocrine glands. An endocrine gland secretes chemical regulators (hormones) directly into the bloodstream to act on tissues near the release site, while an exocrine gland secretes its products into ducts in order to reach some other environment external to itself (whether it be on the surface of or inside the body). Therefore, endocrine glands do not have ducts, while exocrine glands do. 

Exocrine gland types can be further classified by their method of excretion. Merocrine glands excrete their substances by exocytosis. Apocrine glands have a portion of their plasma membrane that buds off of the cell, containing the substance to be excreted. Holocrine glands excrete their substances via rupturing of their plasma membranes; the cell is also destroyed during this process. 

Examples of endocrine glands include the pituitary, thyroid, hypothyroid, etc. 

Sebaceous glands of the skin and meibomian glands of the eyelids are considered holocrine exocrine glands. 

Barron's Anatomy and Physiology: The Easy Way (2nd edition). Alcamo, I.E., Krumbardt, B. 2004. Barron's Educational Series, Inc. Hauppauge, NY.

questions.question: A cell that secretes a chemical messenger which then binds to a receptor on that same cell to produce a change within that cell is known as which type of signaling?
questions.explanation: Autocrine signaling occurs when a cell secretes a chemical messenger which binds to a receptor on that same cell. Paracrine signaling occurs when a cell secretes a chemical messenger that stimulates the receptors of nearby cells, initiating a change in those cells ('para' means nearby). Exocrine and endocrine signaling generally are carried via the circulatory system to affect target sites that are further away. Remember, endocrine glands do not possess ducts; a good mnemonic is: enDocrine glands Don't have Ducts (remember the Ds).

questions.question: Based on your 83 year-old patient's subjective complaints, you suspect that he may be experiencing symptoms associated with giant cell arteritis. Which 2 of the following tests would you initially recommend to help confirm your diagnosis? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
Patients presenting with signs and symptoms suggestive of giant cell arteritis (GCA) should immediately undergo erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) testing. Although there are no positively definitive studies on the range of ESR in normal patients, there is a formula that allows an estimation of the normal maximum ESR, which is dependent on gender and age. 

- For females, the maximum ESR can be calculated by adding 10 to the patient's age and then dividing that number by two: (age+10)/2 
- For males, the maximum ESR is equivalent to the patient's age divided by two: age/2 

If ESR testing is normal in patients exhibiting symptoms of GCA, these patients should still undergo a temporal artery biopsy due to the fact that 8-22% of patients with biopsy-proven GCA will show a normal ESR. Additionally, it is important to remember that an elevated ESR is not specific for GCA as it may occur in several other types of inflammatory diseases; however, an elevated ESR with an elevated CRP is considered much more sensitive in diagnosing GCA.

questions.question: Which of the following tests is MOST sensitive for the screening and diagnosis of genital chlamydial infections?
questions.explanation:
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are the most sensitive test for the screening and diagnosis of chlamydial infections. NAATs have been shown to be 20-30% more sensitive than previously utilized diagnostic tests (cultures, antigen detection, etc). 

Venereal disease research laboratory tests (VDRL) and rapid plasma regain (RPR) tests are used in confirming a diagnosis of syphilis. 

Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) tests are designed to detect the presence of a certain substance (usually an antigen) and are commonly used in the diagnosis of HIV. Western blot tests detect specific proteins in a given sample and are also frequently used in HIV diagnosis.

questions.question: Which of the following cells have major histocompatibility complex 2 (MHC II) on their surface?
options: All of the cells listed have MHC II on their surface
questions.explanation: MHC II is only displayed by antigen-presenting cells. Antigen-presenting cells include macrophages and neutrophils. MHC II interacts with T- helper cells and activates them when the corresponding antigen is displayed. In contrast, MHC I is displayed on all nucleated cells and is under surveillance by CD8+ cytotoxic T cells.

questions.question: Digestion is a complex process that allows for food to be broken down. What is the correct order of components as food passes through the digestive system?
options: Esophagus-> pharynx-> stomach-> large intestine-> small intestine
Pharynx-> esophagus-> small intestine -> stomach -> large intestine
Esophagus-> large intestine ->stomach-> small intestine-> pharynx
Pharynx-> large intestine-> esophagus-> stomach-> small intestine
Pharynx-> esophagus-> stomach-> small intestine-> large intestine
answers: Pharynx-> esophagus-> stomach-> small intestine-> large intestine
questions.explanation:
Once ingested, food travels through the oral cavity into the pharynx which pushes food down through the esophagus. This muscular tube propels the food into the stomach which in turn passes the food to the small intestine. The last stop for undigested matter is the large intestine and rectum.
PowerPage
Small & Large Intestines

questions.question: A 45-year old Hispanic male with a 10 year history of NIDDM (non-insulin-dependant diabetes mellitus, or diabetes mellitus type 2) states in his history that his last HbA1c level was 8.0% and additionally states his FBS (fasting blood sugar) is 120mg/dL. Based on this information, what type of control does this patient have on his diabetes?
questions.explanation:
Daily blood sugar levels should be less than 110mg/dL before eating breakfast and less than 140 mg/dL two hours after eating a meal. Furthermore, an HbA1c of 8% correlates to an average glucose level of 183mg/dL. 

Reference: Ocular Therapeutic Handbook a Clinical Manual (3rd edition. pp 404-405) 2010.
PowerPage
Diabetes Mellitus

questions.question: Grave's disease is an autoimmune disease affecting the thyroid and resulting in over-activity or hyperthyroidism. It is also associated with multiple ocular manifestations. Which 3 of the following findings are expected in a patient with Grave's disease? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: The ocular manifestations of Grave's disease include unilateral and bilateral exophthalmos, which is usually secondary to inflammatory materials being deposited behind the eye. The sympathetic stimulation causes the upper lid to retract therefore leading it to lag when looking downward or to create the appearance of a stare even in the absence of significant exophthalmos. The condition of exophthalmos often makes it difficult to close the eye at night, making patching and taping necessary in some cases to prevent exposure of the cornea and consequential corneal ulcerations.

questions.question: Antibodies secreted from plasma cells CANNOT bind to which of the following?
options: Pathogens hidden within a host cell
answers: Pathogens hidden within a host cell
questions.explanation: Plasma cell are terminally differentiated B lymphocytes that secrete antibodies. B cells' primary targets are extracellular toxins or pathogens circulating within the body's tissues or fluids. On the other hand, T cells inactivate or attack intracellular pathogens, organ transplants or tumor cells.

questions.question: A 13 year-old patient is seen at your office reporting headaches for the past 2 months. She reports that the headaches are dull and occur above her eyes. The headaches are typically not present upon wakening and worsen towards mid-day, especially with reading. She typically does not experience any headaches on the weekend unless she is using the computer or reading. Based upon the patient's case history alone, what is the MOST likely etiology of her headaches?
questions.explanation:
Ocular-related headaches or those due to eyestrain present with prolonged use of the eyes. The majority of patients will note an absence of headache in the morning (although some will report headaches in the morning due to excessive ocular use the night before). The headaches are typically dull in nature and occur around or above the eyes. Occasionally, the eyestrain can occur concurrently with a tension headache, and the patient may also report tightness of the neck or pain in the occipital region. 

Tension headaches, also known as muscular contraction headaches, are most commonly caused by stress and may be also be attributed to poor posture, hunger and fatigue. This type of headache is associated with stiffness of the muscles in the neck region and pain around the occipital region or a vice-like pain in the frontal area. Patients typically report the presence of a throbbing pain. 

Migraine headaches are thought to be neurological in nature and can be triggered by several mechanisms such as hormonal changes or neurotransmitter imbalances. Typically patients will note a unilateral throbbing/pulsating pain. Patients will generally experience associated symptoms of nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia. Some patients will perceive an aura immediately preceding the headache. 

Sinus headaches are more commonly 'associated acute' rather than 'chronic nasal sinusitis' and usually present with a deep and constant pain in the frontal region of the head. Pain in these cases is usually associated with other sinus symptoms such as rhinorrhea, feeling of fullness in the ears, fever, facial swelling, and lacrimation. Patients typically report a transient loss of the sense of smell. The majority of patients will note an increase in pain/pressure when bending down. 

Primary Care Optometry 5th edition. Grosvenor, T. Butterworth-Heinemann, pages 104-106, 2007.

questions.question: According to the American Diabetes Association, which of the following statements BEST describes the criteria for a diagnosis of diabetes based on fasting plasma glucose levels?
options: Fasting plasma glucose of 115mg/dL or higher is diagnostic for diabetes
Fasting plasma glucose of 100mg/dL or higher is diagnostic for diabetes
Fasting plasma glucose of 120mg/dL or higher is diagnostic for diabetes
Fasting plasma glucose of 126mg/dL or higher is diagnostic for diabetes
Fasting plasma glucose of 132mg/dL or higher is diagnostic for diabetes
answers: Fasting plasma glucose of 126mg/dL or higher is diagnostic for diabetes
questions.explanation:
Current criteria for the diagnosis of diabetes include the following, explained in detail below: 

- HbA1c of 6.5%. The HbA1c test is a blood test that reflects average blood glucose levels over a 3-month period and does not show daily fluctuations. This test does not require fasting and may be performed at any time during the day. 

- Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG) of 126 mg/dL (7.0 mmol/L). Fasting is defined as no caloric intake for at least 8 hours. This test has been the most commonly used for diagnosing diabetes because it is convenient and cost-effective. 

- 2-hour plasma glucose of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) during an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). This measures blood glucose after a person fasts for at least 8 hours then drinks a liquid containing 75 grams of glucose dissolved in water; the patient is then tested 2 hours after ingestion. 

In a patient with classic symptoms of hyperglycemia or hyperglycemic crisis, a random plasma glucose of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) may be observed. 

In the absence of unequivocal hyperglycemia, the result should be confirmed by repeat testing.

questions.question: Which cell is responsible for producing the ground substance found in connective tissue?
questions.explanation: All cell types listed in this question are found within connective tissue. However, the only cell that produces ground substance is the fibroblast. Ground substance along with fibers make up the connective tissue matrix. Mast cells produce and release heparin and histamine. Macrophages are involved in phagocytosing foreign material or other infectious organisms.

questions.question: Cartilage is an important transition tissue during development. The cartilage matrix is composed of which type of cell?
questions.explanation:
Chondroblasts are important for the production of the cartilage matrix. Once mature, chondroblasts become chondrocytes and reside in cavities within the cartilage matrix called lacunae. 

Osteocytes are found in the bone matrix in small cavities, lacunae. Osteocytes are derivatives of osteoblasts and are important in bone remodeling. These cells serve an important role in releasing calcium from bones when the body's calcium level becomes depleted. 

Fibroblasts are found in abundance throughout the body and are important in the secretion of ground substance or extracellular matrix (generally proteins and polysaccharides) as well as the secretion of collagen fibers. 

Oligodendrocytes are important for the production of the myelin sheath in the central nervous system.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of specific immunity in the eye?
options: Flushing of the eye by tears when the eye is traumatized
Secretion of specific antibodies into the tear film by T- lymphocytes
Interferon production in response to viral infection
Regular turnover of corneal epithelial cells
Destruction of virally infected conjunctival cells by cytotoxic T- lymphocytes
answers: Destruction of virally infected conjunctival cells by cytotoxic T- lymphocytes
questions.explanation: Specific immunity indicates a response that is specific to the offending agent and requires recognition of that agent by the immune system. Regular epithelial cell turnover and properties of the tears are both examples of non-specific immunity. Interferon production is also a non-specific response. T- lymphocytes are not capable of secreting antibodies; this is a role of B- lymphocytes. The activation of cytotoxic T- lympocytes (CTL) to recognize and remove virally infected cells is a role of the specific immune system. Other examples of specific immune functions include production of specific antibodies by B- lymphocytes and plasma cells after activation by an antigen.

questions.question: Which of the following types of migraines is characterized by the presence of visual disturbances without the development of a headache?
questions.explanation:
Acephalgic migraines are characterized by the presence of visual disturbances but without the development of a headache. 

Classical migraines involve the presence of a visual aura that precedes the development of a headache. 

Retinal migraines involve symptoms of acute, transient, unilateral vision loss. If patients are examined during an episode, retinal blood vessels will typically appear constricted. Headaches may or may not occur in these cases. 

Ophthalmoplegic migraines usually begin in patients under the age of 10. It is characterized by a recurrent, transient third nerve palsy, which develops after the headache.

questions.question: What is the name of the foramen that serves as the opening at the base of the skull to allow the spinal cord to exit the brain and enter the spinal column?
questions.explanation: The foramen magnum lies at the base of the occipital lobe and serves as the opening for the spinal cord. Foramen magnum literally means 'great hole'. The foramen ovale courses through the posterior portion of the sphenoid bone; the opening serves as a passageway for several nerves including the mandibular nerve. The foramen rotundum allows the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve to pass through the sphenoid bone and the pterygopalatine fossa. The foramen spinosum is located on the greater wing of the sphenoid bone and basically transmits the middle meningeal artery. The foramen ovale, rotundum and spinosum lie in close proximity to each other.

questions.question: Which of the following laboratory measurements would be below normal in a patient with hyperthyroidism?
questions.explanation:
Patients with hyperthyroidism will have low levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and elevated levels of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) present in the bloodstream. These principles are the basis for laboratory tests used to diagnose an underactive or overactive thyroid gland. 

In cases of hyperthyroidism, the thyroid gland is producing an excessive amount of the thyroid hormones (both free and total). The pituitary gland then senses that there is too much circulating thyroid hormones, and in turn shuts down production of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) in order to subsequently cause the thyroid to slow down its production of thyroxine and triiodothyronine (T3 and T4). Therefore, a decline in TSH is an attempt by the pituitary gland to return the circulating thyroid hormones to normal levels. On the other hand, in hypothyroidism, the thyroid gland is not producing an adequate amount of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4), so the pituitary gland will produce more TSH in order to stimulate the thyroid gland to produce more hormones. Consequently, patients with hypothyroidism will show low levels of T3 and T4 and elevated TSH values.

questions.question: Which of the following hormones is secreted by the adrenal medulla?
questions.explanation:
Epinephrine and norepinephrine are secreted by the adrenal medulla and serve to help regulate blood circulation as well as the metabolism of carbohydrates when the body is stressed (the fight-or-flight response). 

Cortisol is secreted by the adrenal cortex. Aldosterone is a mineralocorticoid and is also synthesized by the adrenal cortex. Glucagon is secreted by the alpha cells of the pancreas.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the most common type of pituitary tumor?
questions.explanation:
Lactotrophic adenomas are also known as prolactinomas, and are prolactin-secreting tumors of the pituitary gland. Prolactinomas are the most common secretory pituitary tumor; they account for about 40% of all pituitary adenomas. In addition to increasing the secretion of prolactin, prolactinomas may also secrete other hormones, most commonly growth hormone. Symptoms of a prolactinoma vary based on the size of the tumor but can include galactorrhea and hypogonadism (as a result of increased prolactin in the blood), as well as headache and visual field defects (due to mass effect from an expanding tumor). 

It is also important to note that about 25% of pituitary adenomas are non-secretory. 

The Washington Manual Subspecialty Consult Series: Endocrinology Subspecialty Consult (Third edition). McGill, J., Clutter, W., Baranski, T. 2013. Wolters Kluwer.

questions.question: Action potentials are directly initiated by which component of the ear?
options: Hair cells in the organ of Corti
answers: Hair cells in the organ of Corti
questions.explanation:
Sound is funneled by the pinna (the outer ear) into the auditory canal to the tympanic membrane. Vibration of this membrane transfers the sound energy to the malleus (or the hammer), which then passes it to the incus (anvil) and on to the stapes (stirrup). The energy is transmitted to the oval window, which is considerably smaller than the tympanic membrane, causing amplification of the original sound vibrations. The oval window conveys the sound to the cochlea, a fluid-filled, snail-shaped apparatus consisting of the scala vestibuli and the scala tympani; these surround the central cochlear duct. It is within the cochlear duct that the magic happens. The floor of the cochlear duct houses the basilar membrane, which serves as a bed for the organ of Corti. Hair cells of the organ of Corti protrude upwards onto a membrane called the tectorial membrane. Sound waves cause the fluid in the cochlea to move, vibrating the basilar membrane. This vibration in turn pushes the hair cells against the tectorial membrane, causing the hair cells to bend. The bent hair cells release neurotransmitters, resulting in action potentials of the auditory nerve. Pressure waves travel through the cochlea and are released to the round window, which helps to release some of the pressure caused by the force of the sound waves. 

Remember: physiologically, the oval window transmits the sound waves before the round window.
