questions.question: Which of the following BEST reflects an optometrist's duty to promote patient welfare?
options: Having boxes of contact lenses in stock to ensure that patients will not order contact lenses online
Having contact lens trials available for purchase to ensure that patients do not go without clear vision
Purchasing a GDx-VCC (variable corneal compensator) scanning machine to help increase office profits
Purchasing an OCT (optical coherence tomography) machine to allow for better detection of glaucoma
answers: Purchasing an OCT (optical coherence tomography) machine to allow for better detection of glaucoma
questions.explanation:
An important part of an optometrist's role in promoting ocular health is to ensure that he or she keeps up to date with important technological advancements and current treatment options thereby ensuring continued competence. Decisions regarding purchase of diagnostic equipment should be based on optimizing patient welfare rather than financial gain. Two statements taken from the optometric oath reflect this principle: 

'I will strive continuously to broaden my knowledge and skills so that my patients may benefit from all new and efficacious means to enhance the care of human vision.' 

'I will place the treatment of those who seek my care above personal gain and strive to see that none shall lack for proper care.

questions.question: According to the American Diabetes Association, which of the following statements BEST describes the criteria for diagnosis of diabetes based on hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) level?
options: HbA1c of 6.8% or greater is diagnostic for diabetes
HbA1c of 5.7% or greater is diagnostic for diabetes
HbA1c of 5.0% or greater is diagnostic for diabetes
HbA1c of 6.0% or greater is diagnostic for diabetes
HbA1c of 6.5% or greater is diagnostic for diabetes
answers: HbA1c of 6.5% or greater is diagnostic for diabetes
questions.explanation:
Current criteria for the diagnosis of diabetes include the following, explained in detail below: 

- HbA1c of 6.5%. The HbA1c test is a blood test that reflects the average blood glucose levels over a 3-month period and does not show daily fluctuations. This test does not require fasting and may be performed at any time during the day. 

- Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG) of 126 mg/dL (7.0 mmol/L). Fasting is defined as no caloric intake for at least 8 hours. This test has been the most commonly used for diagnosing diabetes because it is convenient and cost-effective. 

- 2-hour plasma glucose of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) during an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). This measures blood glucose after a person fasts for at least 8 hours then drinks a liquid containing 75 grams of glucose dissolved in water; the patient is then tested 2 hours after ingestion. 

In a patient with classic symptoms of hyperglycemia or hyperglycemic crisis, a random plasma glucose of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) may be observed. 

In the absence of unequivocal hyperglycemia, the result should be confirmed by repeat testing.

questions.question: The fluid portion of the blood responsible for carrying dissolved ions and molecules as well as clotting factors like fibrinogen is known as which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
Blood plasma constitutes roughly 55% of the blood volume. The plasma portion keeps blood cells in suspension and is comprised of water, extracellular fluid, dissolved proteins, minerals, glucose, carbon dioxide, hormones, and clotting factors. 

Blood serum constitutes the blood plasma minus the clotting factors 

Hematocrit is essentially the amount of blood that is occupied by cells and cellular components per a given volume of blood. 

Hemoglobin is a metalloprotein that contains iron and is found in red blood cells. Hemoglobin aids in the transport of oxygen to (and carbon dioxide away from) body tissues.

questions.question: In the absence of trauma, excessive eye rubbing or use of any medication, a patient who experiences recurrent subconjunctival hemorrhages should undergo further testing as they are MOST likely to exhibit which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Research has demonstrated that in a healthy young population, the most common causes of subconjunctival hemorrhages are contact lens wear and trauma; whereas, in older patients the most common etiologies are systemic vascular disorders (i.e. diabetes, hypertension). 
Recurrent subconjunctival hemorrhages may also indicate a problem with blood clotting; therefore further investigation such as a bleeding time, prothrombin time, partial thromboplastin time, and a complete blood count with platelets (to ensure no leukemia) are warranted. It is also important to rule out repeated trauma (such as aggressive eye rubbing) as the culprit of a re-occurring subconjunctival hemorrhage. 
Rarely subconjunctival hemorrhages may be caused by a neoplasm occurring below the conjunctival space such as in Kaposi's sarcoma or lymphoma; however, there exists little to no association between subconjunctival hemorrhages and arthritis, acromegaly and ciliary body melanomas. 

Reference: 

Clin Ophthalmol. 2013; 7: 1163?1170. Subconjunctival hemorrhage: risk factors and potential indicators.

questions.question: Skin serves a major protective role to our health. The majority of the cells in the epidermis are of what cell type?
questions.explanation:
Keratinocytes produce keratin, a type of protein that is both tough and water-insoluble. Keratin is produced continually in the mid-epidermis. Eventually the cells flatten out and die as they reach the outer level of the epidermis, also known as the stratum corneum, creating the skin's tough barrier. 

Megakaryocytes are found in bone marrow and are responsible for producing thrombocytes, which are required for blood clotting. 

Osteocytes are found in the bone matrix in small cavities called lacunae. Osteocytes are derivatives of osteoblasts and are important in bone remodeling. These cells serve an important role in releasing calcium from bones when the body's calcium level becomes depleted. 

Hepatocytes are cells located within the liver.

questions.question: A chancre is a painless ulcerative lesion that occurs on the skin, indicating a primary infection of which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation: Primary syphilis infections typically occur after a 2-4 week incubation period and are characterized by the development of a chancre at the site of infection. A chancre is a painless ulcer that is most commonly found on the penis in males and vulva in females. The presence of a chancre is also associated with enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes that are present in the groin area. If left untreated, these skin lesions will typically resolve within a period of 2-6 weeks, leaving an atrophic scar in the region.

questions.question: Which of the following human leukocyte antigen (HLA) types is associated with Bechet's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
- HLA-B51: Bechet's syndrome 
- HLA-B27: Spondyloarthropathies (ankylosing spondylitis) 
- HLA-A29: Birdshot chorioretinopathy 
- HLA-B7 & HLA-DR2: Presumed ocular histoplasmosis syndrome (POHS) and acute multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy (AMPEE)

questions.question: A patient presents to your office with decreased vision of the right eye. Dilated fundus exam shows midperipheral retinal hemorrhages in the right eye and a clear and healthy fundus in the left eye. In addition, you note iris neovascularization to be present on slit lamp evaluation. What test should be ordered next for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Unilateral, midperipheral hemorrhages are characteristic of Ocular Ischemic Syndrome (OIS). OIS is typically a result of carotid disease where 90% or more of the ipsilateral carotid artery is blocked. This limits blood flow to the eye resulting in signs such as midperipheral hemorrhages, iris neovascularization, and posterior segment neovascularization. More than 50% of patients with OIS will also manifest iris neovascularization. 

A carotid Doppler is indicated in these patients in order to evaluate the extent of the carotid artery occlusion and to determine if a carotid endarterectomy is needed. There is a sense of urgency for care in these patients because of the possibility of a stroke. Additionally, the prognosis is generally poor with a 40% mortality rate within 5 years.

questions.question: Decompression sickness, also known as the bends, may be experienced by divers and is caused by rapid movement of which gas from the tissues into the blood stream?
questions.explanation: Underwater, the greater the depth, the greater the increase in pressure; therefore, many divers must breathe pressurized air to increase the pressure of the gas in their lungs. However, as the divers begin their return to the surface, the pressure of the water decreases; this can cause nitrogen to rapidly exit from the tissues into the bloodstream. Rapid ascents do not allow divers to exhale the excess nitrogen quickly enough, leading to the formation of nitrogen bubbles, which can block blood flow to their brain tissues.

questions.question: Inhibitory postsynaptic potentials have which type of effect on a neuron?
options: Brings the neuronal membrane closer to threshold
questions.explanation: Many neurons receive input from multiple other neurons. Some of the input is excitatory in nature, termed excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs), and others are inhibitory (IPSPs). Inhibitory signals push the membrane of the neuron away from its threshold point and therefore cause hyperpolarization because the inside of the membrane becomes even more negatively charged. When excitatory potentials cause the membrane of the neuron to become more positively charged relative to its resting state, they are hypopolarizing. All of the synaptic signals that reach the input zone at the same time are integrated together. If the resulting message causes the membrane to reach its threshold, an action potential ensues.

questions.question: Which of the following 4 systemic conditions have been associated with oculoglandular syndrome? (Select 4)
questions.explanation:
Oculoglandular syndrome can be caused by a myriad of organisms and presents as a unilateral follicular conjunctivitis along with lymphadenopathy on the same side as the affected eye. Causes include but are not limited to cat scratch disease, tularemia, syphilis, tuberculosis, sporotrichosis, mononucleosis, coccidioidomycosis, sarcoidosis, Hansen's disease, mumps, actinomycosis, Listeria and Herpes simplex. 

Reference: Holland, E. Cornea 2nd edition, volume 1, Fundamentals, Diagnosis and Management, 2005. pp 653-659.

questions.question: What class of antibodies are you MOST likely to observe in a patient who is suffering from a bee sting (i.e., a type I hypersensitive reaction)?
questions.explanation:
A type I hypersensitive reaction (a.k.a., anaphylactic, immediate, or IgE-mediated) results when the offending antigen causes production of IgE antibodies, which then attach to mast cells. Subsequent exposure to the antigen causes degranulation of mast cells, resulting in release of histamine, leukotrienes, serotonin, and other allergy and inflammatory mediators. 

IgM is the antibody responsible for activation of the complement pathway and is the first antibody produced in response to an infection. 

IgA antibodies are known as the secretory antibodies and are located in mucous membranes. They are primarily responsible for protection of the lungs and gastrointestinal tract from infection. IgA antibodies can also be detected in some mammal's milk transferred for passive immunity. 

IgD antibodies are typically bound to the surfaces of B-lymphocytes and are only a minor blood component. 

IgG antibodies are responsible for long-term protection (i.e., from viruses) and are the predominant antibodies found in blood.

questions.question: Which class of antibody crosses the blood-placenta barrier and protects newborns for the first months of life until they produce their own antibodies?
questions.explanation:
IgG is the predominant type of antibody found in the bloodstream and is the only class of immunoglobulin that crosses the blood-placenta barrier. 

IgA is the antibody that is primarily found in secretions. It is the second most abundant type of antibody in the body. 

IgM is usually the first antibody made in the immune response and is the largest antibody of the five. IgM can form pentamers with other IgM molecules in the secreted form. 

IgE is implicated for an important role in hypersensitivity and allergic reactions and interacts strongly with mast cells. 

The primary role of IgD is unknown.

questions.question: Antibodies play a vital role in the immune response. Which of the following antibodies has the greatest molecular weight due to its ability to be secreted as a pentamer?
questions.explanation:
IgM possesses the heaviest molecular weight and is the antibody responsible for activation of the complement pathway as well as being the first antibody produced in response to an infection. 

IgA antibodies are known as the secretory antibodies and are located in mucous membranes. They are primarily responsible for providing protection of the lungs and gastrointestinal tract from infection. IgA antibodies can also be detected in some mammalian milk transferred for passive immunity. 

IgD antibodies are typically bound to the surfaces of B-lymphocytes and are only a minor blood component. 

IgG antibodies are responsible for long term protection (i.e. from viruses) and are the predominant antibodies found in blood. IgG is the lightest antibody and is the only type of immunoglobulin that can cross the placenta to help protect the fetus. IgG is also found in milk produced shortly after the delivery of a child. 

IgE antibodies are involved in allergic reactions as well as inflammatory responses.

questions.question: Which of the following antibodies is the first to be secreted during an immune response?
questions.explanation:
IgE antibodies are involved in allergic reactions as well as inflammatory responses. 

IgM is the antibody responsible for activation of the complement pathway and is the first antibody produced in response to an infection. 

IgA antibodies are known as the secretory antibodies and are located in mucous membranes. They are primarily responsible for protection of the lungs and gastrointestinal tract from infection. IgA antibodies can also be detected in some mammalian milk transferred for passive immunity. 

IgD antibodies are typically bound to the surfaces of B-lymphocytes and are only a minor blood component. 

IgG antibodies are responsible for long-term protection (i.e., from viruses) and is the predominant antibody type found in blood. IgG is the only type of immunoglobulin that can cross the placenta to help protect the fetus. IgG is also found in milk produced early after the delivery of a child.

questions.question: Which class/isotype of immunoglobulins is responsible for the primary immune response?
questions.explanation:
There are 5 classes of immunoglobulins that are produced by B lymphocytes. IgM is found as a monomer on naive B lymphocytes or as a pentamer in its secreted form. Its role is to recognize antigens and initiate the primary immune response. IgD is found as cell bound monomer whose function is not understood. 

IgG, IgE and IgA are only produced after the primary immune response and require isotype switching for their production. IgG has 4 subclasses and carries out a wide range of effector functions, including antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity, opsonization, and complement fixation. IgG is the most abundant isotype present in the serum and is the only isotype that crosses the placenta. 

IgA has 2 subclasses and is found in secreted form as monomers and dimers. It is present in the serum, but its main effector function occurs in the respiratory and intestinal tracts. It is the most actively produced isotype and confers mucosal immunity. 

IgE is a monomer that mediates allergic disease. It is the only isotype that binds to mast cells and has the shortest half-life of all isotypes.
PowerPage
Immunoglobulins

questions.question: Which class of immunoglobulin is primarily found in secretions such as tears and saliva?
questions.explanation:
IgA is the antibody that is primarily found in secretions. It is the second most abundant type of antibody in the body. 

IgG is the predominant type of antibody found in the bloodstream and is the only class of immunoglobulin that crosses the placenta. 

IgM is usually the first antibody made in the immune response and is the largest antibody of the five. IgM can form pentamers with other IgM molecules in the secreted form. 

IgE is implicated for an important role in hypersensitivity reactions and allergy and interacts strongly with mast cells. 

The primary role of IgD is unknown.

questions.question: Which class/isotype of immunoglobulins is responsible for mediating allergic disease?
questions.explanation:
There are 5 classes of immunoglobulins that are produced by B lymphocytes. IgM is found as a monomer on naive B lymphocytes or as a pentamer in its secreted form. Its role is to recognize antigens and initiate the primary immune response. IgD is found as cell bound monomer whose function is not understood. 

IgG, IgE, and IgA are only produced after the primary immune response and require isotype switching for their production. IgG has 4 subclasses and carries out a wide range of effector functions, including antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity, opsonization, and complement fixation. IgG is the most abundant isotype present in the serum and is the only isotype that crosses the placenta. IgA has 2 subclasses and is found in secreted form as monomers and dimers. It is present in the serum, but its main effector function occurs in the respiratory and intestinal tracts. It is the most actively produced isotype and confers mucosal immunity. IgE is a monomer that mediates allergic disease. It is the only isotype that binds to mast cells and has the shortest half-life of all isotypes.
PowerPage
Immunoglobulins

questions.question: A person who suffers from hypothyroidism would be expected to demonstrate which of the following lab results?
questions.explanation: An individual who suffers from hypothyroidism would possess elevated levels of TSH and low levels of thyroxine (T4). This result can be attributed to the fact that the pituitary would detect low levels of T4 and continually stimulate the thyroid by releasing TSH; however, because the thyroid is unable to produce thyroxine, these levels would remain depressed, signaling the system's increased release of TSH.

questions.question: What is the proper term for the situation in which both alleles for a trait are expressed?
questions.explanation:
Co-dominance describes the event where both alleles of a trait are expressed, for example a person who possesses the blood type AB. 

Independent assortment was established by Gregor Mendel as a principal of inheritance and basically states that the alleles that code for different traits (i.e., eye color and hair color) are sorted into the sex cells independently of one another. 

Heterozygous denotes a genotype that contains both types of an allele, one that is dominant and one that is non-dominant or recessive. The dominant allele is generally the one that tends to be expressed phenotypically. 

Pleiotropy is defined as the instance in which an allele can display several different phenotypic results. An example of this is sickle-cell anemia.

questions.question: Which 4 of the following blood vessels are found in the infratemporal fossa? (Select 4)
questions.explanation:
The temporal fossa contains the branches of the internal maxillary vessels including the middle meningeal artery, the inferior alveolar artery, the deep temporal artery, and the buccal artery. Other contents of the infratemporal fossa include the lower part of the temporalis muscle and the lateral and medial pterygoid muscles. The pterygoid venous plexus is also located here as well as several important nerves such as the mandibular nerve, inferior alveolar nerve, lingual nerve, buccal nerve, chorda tympani nerve, and the otic ganglion. 

The superficial temporal artery arises from the external carotid where it bifurcates into the maxillary artery and superficial temporal artery. The superficial temporal artery begins in the substance of the parotid gland and passes superficially over the posterior root of the zygomatic process of the temporal bone. 

The anterior ethmoidal artery travels with the nasociliary nerve through the anterior ethmoidal canal. It branches into the anterior meningeal artery after entering the cranium.

questions.question: Which 3 of the following signs are pathognomonic for patients with congenital syphilis, also known as Hutchinson's triad? (Select 3)
questions.explanation:
The clinical triad of congenital syphilis is known as Hutchinson's triad. It consists of interstitial keratitis, peg-shaped and widely spaced incisors, and deafness. Untreated or incompletely treated early congenital syphilis will progress to the classic manifestations of late congenital syphilis. Other possible signs of congenital syphilis include saddle nose, saber shins, mental retardation, hydrocephalus, general paresis, optic nerve atrophy, and Clutton's joints; however, the presentation of Hutchinson's triad is pathognomonic for congenital syphilis. These signs are a result of scarring induced by early lesions or reaction to persistent inflammation that was left untreated. 

The WHO estimates that up to 1.4 million cases of congenital syphilis occur worldwide each year; the WHO has also estimated that more babies die worldwide from syphilis than any other single curable disease.

questions.question: During digestion, food is mixed and moved through the stomach via which type of muscle movements?
questions.explanation:
Peristalsis is used by the stomach and esophagus as a type of wave-like muscle contraction that mixes and propels food for digestion from one region to the next. In this type of muscle movement, circular muscle contracts behind the food while the muscles in front of it relax to allow for passage. 

The intestines also employ a type of peristalsis called segmentation. Segmentation creates oscillatory movements via repeated relaxation and contraction of smooth muscles in the intestines helping to mix its contents and increase absorption. 

Isometric contraction occurs when a muscle is contracting but is not shortening. This type of muscle tension is used for load-bearing situations such as holding a plate of food in front of oneself. 

When the eyes are fixated upon a moving object, the resulting movement is called a smooth pursuit.

questions.question: Which of the following pairing of a neurotransmitter with its respective receptor is INCORRECT?
questions.explanation: Muscarinic receptors are stimulated by muscarine and acetylcholine. Once bound to muscarinic receptors, the neurotransmitters cause an increase in intracellular calcium or activate potassium channels in its respective muscle, tissue, gland, or organ.

questions.question: A contracting muscle that develops tension but does not shorten displays which type of muscle tension?
questions.explanation: Isometric contraction occurs when a muscle is contracting but is not shortening. This type of muscle tension is used for load-bearing situations such as holding a plate of food in front of you. Muscles that shorten but maintain the same amount of tension are said to display isotonic contraction. An isovelocity contraction follows when the force of the contraction varies while the velocity remains constant.

questions.question: What role does the antidiuretic hormone (ADH) play in the formation of urine?
options: It increases the reabsorption of water by the ascending loop of Henle
It causes the distal tubules to become more permeable to water
It decreases the reabsorption of water by the proximal tubules
It makes the collecting ducts less permeable to water
answers: It causes the distal tubules to become more permeable to water
questions.explanation: In the event of increased solute concentration in the extracellular fluid or a drop in blood pressure, the hypothalamus signals the release of ADH from the posterior pituitary. ADH increases the permeability of the distal tubules and the collecting ducts to water. Water then flows out of the tubules into the cortex of the kidney, essentially decreasing the amount of fluid to be excreted as urine. As the collecting ducts traverse through the medulla (remember, the solute concentration increases as one moves internally in the medulla), even more water leaves the tubules and is reabsorbed by the kidneys.

questions.question: Histamine is released from mast cells. What effect does histamine have on the body in response to localized infections?
options: It results in vasodilation of arterioles
It leads to contraction of smooth muscle
answers: It results in vasodilation of arterioles
questions.explanation:
Histamine is released by mast cells in response to inflammatory conditions. Histamine causes vasodilation of arterioles leading to blood engorgement (hence the redness experienced during an infection). Vasodilation occurs when the smooth muscle that lines the blood vessels relaxes. Histamine also promotes increased capillary permeability, causing the vessels to leak water and solutes, which produces localized edema. 

Nociceptors are pain receptors and are not inhibited by histamine release.

questions.question: A neuron is stimulated 12 points above threshold, resulting in an action potential. The same neuron is stimulated a few minutes later 60 points above threshold; how will the neuron respond?
options: It will generate an action potential of greater magnitude
It will generate an action potential equal to the first
It will generate an action potential that involves more potassium channels
It will generate an action potential involving a greater number of sodium channels
It will generate an action potential of longer duration
answers: It will generate an action potential equal to the first
questions.explanation:
Action potentials fire based upon an all-or-none principle. That is, once threshold is reached, an action potential will ensue, and its signal will not decay along the length of the axon. The magnitude and length of the action potential is always the same, regardless of the strength of the stimulus. However, in order to code for the strength of the stimulus, more action potentials will be generated with increased frequencies, which in turn determines the amount of neurotransmitter released by the pre-synaptic terminals. 

Ref: Kandel, E, Schwartz, H and Jessell T. Principles of Neural Science 4th ed. 2000 pg. 21

questions.question: A red blood cell is placed into a solution of 100% distilled water. What will happen to the red blood cell?
questions.explanation: The cell will swell because the replacement surrounding solution (distilled water) is hypotonic to the cell. Because the cell contains a higher concentration of solutes, water will diffuse into the cell in an attempt to equalize the solute concentration. If a red blood cell is placed into a solution that contains a higher concentration of solutes than the cell (that is, the solution is hypertonic to the cell) water will rush out of the cell due to osmosis and the cell will shrink and become crenated. If both the cell and the surrounding medium contain equal concentrations of solute then the two are said to be isotonic, and water will not leave or enter the cell.

questions.question: Which of the following types of melanocytic nevi are formed by nevus cells located solely at the border of the epidermis and dermis?
questions.explanation:
Junctional nevi are composed of nevus cells that are located at the junction between the epidermis and dermis. They are usually flat and brown or black in color. 

Compound nevi are comprised of nevus cells that extend from the epidermis into the dermis layers of the skin (mixture of junctional and intradermal proliferation). They are usually slightly raised and the shade of pigment varies from tan to dark brown. 

Intradermal nevi are the most common form of an acquired nevus. The nevus cells are completely confined to the dermis. This type of nevi is typically raised, and most are flesh-colored (not pigmented). 

Blue nevi are composed of spindle-shaped nevus cells that are located deep within the layers of the dermis. The covering epidermis is normal, leading to a bluish-colored lesion. 

Spitz nevi are a variant of an intradermal nevus that commonly presents as a raised, reddish lesion.

questions.question: Which of the following tumors is considered the MOST common human malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Basal cell carcinoma is that most common human malignancy. About 90% of all cases present on the head and neck, with 10% of those involving the eyelid. Basal cell carcinoma is also the most prevalent malignant eyelid tumor, accounting for close to 90% of all cases. Most occur in the lower eyelid, followed by the medial canthus, upper eyelid, and lateral canthus. 

Squamous cell carcinoma is much less common than basal cell carcinoma, but it is potentially more aggressive due to a higher risk of regional lymph node metastasis. 

Sebaceous gland carcinoma is a very rare tumor that typically arises from the meibomian glands. Malignant melanomas rarely occur on the eyelids but are potentially lethal; Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular tumor that most commonly affects patients infected with AIDS.

questions.question: Which of the following neuromuscular disorders affecting extraocular muscle movements develops as a result of abnormalities in the DNA of mitochondria?
questions.explanation:
Kearns-Sayre syndrome is considered a mitochondrial myopathy in which mitochondrial DNA deletions result in a clinical triad of signs. These signs include ocular features such as progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO) and 'salt and pepper' pigmented retinopathy (with predilection for the macula), as well as one or more systemic complications, which can include heart block, cerebellar ataxia, or abnormally elevated cerebrospinal fluid protein. 

Grave's ophthalmopathy occurs as a result of an autoimmune disease that results in thickening of the extraocular muscles. 

Ocular myasthenia gravis is also an autoimmune disease that causes weakness of the extraocular muscles and levator palpebrae superioris. 

Myotonic dystrophy is caused by mutations of the DMPK gene (type 1) and CNBP gene (type 2). Extraocular muscle symptoms of this type of disease include rebound nystagmus, saccadic dysfunctions, and optokinetic nystagmus. 

Electrodiagnosis of Retinal Diseases. Miyake, Y. 2006. Springer. 
The Retinal Atlas. Yannuzzi, L.A. 2010. Saunders Elsevier. 
Adler's Physiology of the Eye (11th edition). Levin, L.A., Nilsson, S.F.E., Ver Hoeve, J., Wu, S.M. 2011. Saunders Elsevier.

questions.question: Saliva aids in the initial digestion of food. Saliva is secreted by which of the following glands?
questions.explanation:
Saliva is secreted by three main pairs of glands. The parotid gland is located in front of each ear. The sublingual glands are found beneath the tongue and the submandibular glands are nestled in the lower jaw in the floor of the mouth. By secreting saliva, these glands aid in the initial stages of digestion. 

The lacrimal glands secrete the aqueous portion of the tears. 

The pterygoid plexus is a collection of veins that drain from the pterygoid muscles into the facial vein. 

Apocrine glands are sweat glands and are thus implicated in body temperature regulation.

questions.question: The kidneys produce and release a substance that promotes the production of red blood cells. What is the name of this hormone?
questions.explanation:
Erythropoietin is released by the kidneys in order to simulate red blood cell production by stem cells in red bone marrow. On average three million red blood cells are introduced into the blood stream each second. Red blood cells have an average lifespan of 120 days. As they mature, they lose their nucleus as well as other organelles. When an erythrocyte nears the end of its life cycle, it undergoes a change to its plasma membrane, making it easy for macrophages to recognize and engulf it. Once it has been phagocytized, the amino acids are returned to the blood stream and the heme groups can be recycled in the red bone marrow. Unusable heme groups are converted to bilirubin and make their way to the liver where they become mixed with bile. 

Erythropoesis is the actual process in which new red blood cells are produced. 

Eryptosis is basically programmed red blood cell death. 

Lactoferrin is a glycoprotein found in milk, tears and saliva. It possesses antimicrobial activity.

questions.question: Which of the following physical examination findings are found in an allergic individual?
options: Lateral crease of the distal nose
Hyperpigmentation of the inferior periorbital skin
questions.explanation: Hyperpigmentation of the inferior periorbital skin are commonly called allergic shiners. This is due to engorgement of superficial capillaries due to downstream vascular congestion from inflammation of the nasal mucosa. The lateral crease of the distal nose occurs (commonly called a nasal crease) due to frequent rubbing of the nose as a result of nasal pruritus. Finally, lymphoproliferation of the posterior oropharynx ('cobblestoning') is due to the chronic inflammatory response that is the basis of allergic rhinitis.

questions.question: Which of the following walls of the orbit is MOST susceptible to a blowout fracture secondary to blunt ocular trauma?
questions.explanation: All of the walls of the orbit are relatively thin, making them susceptible to injury and fracture when blunt force trauma to the eye is incurred. Increased pressure in the orbit often results in one or more areas of the orbit to break and 'blow out' into the sinuses. The inferior and medial walls tend to be the most susceptible to this type of injury, although an orbital floor fracture is the most common. In certain patients, a blowout fracture of the floor will require surgical repair. These circumstances include cases in which there is rectus muscle entrapment, enophthalmus greater than 2mm, and large fractures that include over 50% of the involved wall (this is typically decided after a 2-week waiting period).

questions.question: Which 3 of the following are thought to be risk factors for Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: COPD is an irreversible, progressive narrowing of the airways which eventually leads to fibrosis and destruction of alveolar tissue. Symptoms include a cough (with or without sputum), shortness of breath that worsens with activity, wheezing, fatigue and/or difficulty catching one's breath. The biggest risk factor is smoking cigarettes. Other risk factors include: a low birth weight, age, a dusty work environment, decreased levels of alpha-1 antitrypsin levels, damp housing quarters, a diet that is low in fish, fruits and antioxidants, frequent childhood infections, and exposure to environmental pollution. It is also purported that a history of atopy and a hyper-responsive airway (the Dutch hypothesis), as well as persistent bronchopulmonary infections (the British hypothesis) may also increase the risk for COPD. There exists much debate surrounding COPD and its relationship to asthma. Currently it is believed that both conditions lie along opposite ends of a spectrum. While both conditions cause limited airflow, the mechanisms and the permanence of the destruction differs. With COPD, the instigator is typically cigarette smoke, which leads to the release of alveolar macrophages, neutrophils and CD8 T-cells. COPD typically affects the peripheral pulmonary pathways, eventually leading to parenchymal destruction, metaplasia of squamous cells and mucous causing irreversible airflow constriction. COPD does not respond well to steroid therapy. In contrast, asthma involves mast cells, eosinophils, macrophages and CD4 T-cells that become activated by exposure to allergens. Asthma affects the proximal pulmonary pathways leading to bronchoconstriction, fragile epithelial tissue, and mucous metaplasia, causing reversible airflow constriction which responds well to steroid therapy. In the event of severe asthma, there is more overlap between the two conditions, since neutrophils, macrophages, CD4 and CD8 T-cells are involved, which lead to airflow limitations of both proximal and peripheral airways. Severe asthma responds mildly to steroid therapy.

questions.question: Which of the following hormones is NOT secreted by the anterior pituitary gland?
questions.explanation:
Major hormones secreted by the anterior pituitary: 
- Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH): Target is the adrenal glands, promoting the secretion of glucocorticoid, mineralcorticoid, and androgens 
- Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH): Target is the gonads, promoting growth of the reproductive system 
- Luteinizing hormone (LH): Target is the gonads, promoting sex hormone production 
- Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH): Target is the thyroid gland, promoting secretion of thyroid hormones 
- Prolactin: Target is the mammary gland, stimulating milk production 
- Growth hormone: Targets are liver and adipose tissue, promoting growth (indirectly), and control of protein, lipid, and carbohydrate metabolism 

An easy pneumonic to remember the hormones secreted by the anterior pituitary is FLATPeG

questions.question: Female ovulation is triggered primarily by a surge in which of the following hormones?
questions.explanation: At the beginning of the menstrual cycle, GnRH is released and stimulates the secretion of FSH and LH. FSH and LH cause growth of a follicle in the ovary. The oocyte and the glycoprotein surrounding the oocyte grow, forming the zona pellucida. FSH and LH stimulate the cells around the zona pellucida to secrete estrogen. As estrogen levels rise and the follicle matures, it completes meiosis, resulting in a secondary oocyte and a polar body. The increase in blood estrogen levels is detected by the pituitary gland; the pituitary responds by releasing LH, causing the mature secondary oocyte to rupture through the wall of the ovary and subsequent ovulation.

questions.question: Membrane attack complexes are an example of which type of host defense?
questions.explanation:
The complement pathway is activated in two different ways. Firstly, circulating complement can bind to an antigen-antibody complex and become activated. Another manner in which complement can be activated is by directly binding to bacterial surfaces. Once activated, complement causes a cascade of reactions that become amplified with each step. In one instance, membrane attack complexes are formed, which are essentially a group of proteins that form a pore through the membrane of the pathogen and cause lysis. Alternatively, complement may cause inflammation, which triggers phagocytes. Phagocytes possess receptors for complement and engulf the complement proteins that have bound to a microorganism. 

Fast-acting white blood cells include neutrophils, eosinophils and basophils. 

Lysozymes are enzymes found in tears, saliva, and the mucous that lines the lumen of the bronchi. This enzyme promotes the destruction of invading microorganisms.

questions.question: Which of the following actions does not require input from the brain and therefore is referred to as a spinal reflex?
options: Maintaining balance while riding a bicycle
Dodging out of the way when an object is thrown in your direction
Pulling your hand away from a hot stove
answers: Pulling your hand away from a hot stove
questions.explanation: A spinal reflex does not require input from the brain to achieve the goal at hand. The simplest form of a spinal reflex is a reflex arc that is monosynaptic. This type of pathway involves only one synapse. In its most basic form, a sensory neuron synapses directly onto a motor neuron in the spinal cord, allowing for an almost instant reaction to sensory input. These types of reflexes can be inhibited. For instance, when grasping a hot plate your initial reaction is to drop that plate; however, your brain can override this reaction because cognitively there are negative consequences to dropping the plate (i.e., it may break or the food may spill). Catching a ball, painting and dodging out of the way require the integration of visual input from the brain in order to correctly accomplish the task. Riding a bicycle successfully can be done without visual input; however feedback from the cerebellum is crucial in order to maintain balance.

questions.question: What is the name of the region on the antibody that reacts with the antigen?
questions.explanation: The region of the antibody that reacts with the antigen is termed a paratope. The location of the antigen that reacts with the antibody is termed an epitope. Many viruses are able to infect hosts by escaping the protective defenses of our immune system via alteration of their epitopes. Manitope and antitopes do not exist.

questions.question: Which of the following anatomical layers of an artery represents the outermost layer?
questions.explanation:
The outermost layer of an artery is known as the adventitia (may also be referred to as tunica adventitia or tunica externa). It is composed of loose connective tissue. 

The innermost layer of an artery is referred to as the intima (or tunica intima). It is composed of a single layer of endothelial cells and is supported by an internal elastic lamina. This layer is in direct contact with the flow of blood. 

The media (or tunica media) is the middle layer of the artery (between the intima and adventitia), and is composed of smooth muscle and elastic tissue. 

The internal elastic lamina is a thin layer of elastic tissue that represents the outermost portion of the intima. It separates the intima from the media layer.

questions.question: Which type of receptor is found in the fingertips, lips, eyelids and genitals and responds to low frequency vibrations?
questions.explanation:
There are several different types of receptors near the body's surface that serve to code and respond to different types of stimuli. The simplest of these receptors are free nerve endings, which are basically open nerve endings of sensory receptors in the skin. Free nerve endings respond to pain, touch, pressure, temperature, chemicals, and so forth. 

Encapsulated receptors are also found near the surface of the body and are surrounded by a capsule of either connective or epithelial tissue. Meissner's corpuscles are found more superficially and detect and adapt slowly to low-frequency vibrations. The end-bulb of Krause is important for reacting to temperatures less than twenty degrees Celsius. Ruffini endings respond to constant pressure and touch as well as temperatures above 45 degrees Celsius. Pacinian corpuscles (PC) are located deeper in the dermis and are sensitive to rapid pressure changes related to vibrations and touch. PCs are also found in some internal organs and in membranes that lie in close proximity to freely-movable joints.

questions.question: Which type of cell is involved in cell-mediated immune responses?
questions.explanation:
Cell-mediated responses do not involve antibodies or complement. This type of immune response is controlled by cytotoxic T cells and helper T cells along with macrophages and cytokines. 

Antibody-mediated immune responses (sometimes called humoral response) involve memory B cells, effector B cells, and the production of antibodies as well as helper T cells. 

T and B cells both fall under the heading of lymphocyte. During an immune response, an antigen is swallowed by a macrophage. The antigens are broken apart into fragments and become bound to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules forming antigen-MHC complexes. The complexes are recognized by virgin cytotoxic T cells and virgin helper T cells. The virgin cytotoxic T cells divide into effector T cells and memory T cells. The virgin T helper cells undergo differentiation into memory T cells and effector helper T cells. The memory T cells are stored for future encounters. The effector helper T cells promote mitosis of T and B cells to help combat the pathogens. Helper T cells do not kill any pathogens but help direct the immune system and the appropriate cells. Cytotoxic T cells are also known as killer T cells because upon contact with a target, they inject chemicals that cause death to the target cell. Virgin B cells, upon activation by effector helper T cells and interleukins, begin mitosis and differentiate into memory B cells and effector B cells. The new memory B cells are stored for future encounters. The effector B cells produce antibodies which serve to inactivate the offending agent.

questions.question: What is another name for the midbrain?
questions.explanation: The brain is divided into three main parts: the forebrain (prosencephalon), the midbrain (the mesencephalon), and the hindbrain (the rhombencephalon). The forebrain contains the cerebrum (telencephalon) and the diencephalon (the thalamus, hypothalamus, and pineal gland). The midbrain and the hindbrain together are known as the brainstem.

questions.question: Which of the following granulocytes is involved in seeking and destroying by following a chemical trail to cells that that are infected or damaged?
questions.explanation:
There are two major classes of leukocytes: granulocytes and agranulocytes. Neutrophils, basophils and eosinophils all fall under the granulocyte category due to the fact that they contain a lobed nucleus and possess cytoplasmic granules visible upon staining. Neutrophils comprise the largest number of leukocytes, roughly two-thirds. These leukocytes seek and destroy cells that are infected or damaged. Eosinophils are involved in allergic responses as well as in mounting attacks against parasites. Basophils are the least common granulocyte and play a role in inflammatory as well as allergic reactions. Remember, neutrophils neutralize (a.k.a., they kill stuff). Eosinophils are 'eoitchy' (allergy). 

The second class of leukocytes are the agranulocytes, aptly named because they do not posses cytoplasmic granules. This class contains two types of cells: monocytes and lymphocytes. Monocytes become macrophages when necessary and destroy microbes or debris via phagocytosis. Lymphocytes (the T cells and B cells) are involved in hosting specific immune responses.
PowerPage
Leukocytes

questions.question: You have a patient who you correctly diagnose with idiopathic demyelinating optic neuritis. The presence of which of the following characteristics on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) testing represents the greatest risk for the future development of multiple sclerosis?
options: MRI shows one ovoid white matter lesion greater than 3mm in size
MRI shows one ovoid grey matter lesion greater than 3mm in size
MRI shows six or more white matter lesions
MRI shows six or more grey matter lesions
answers: MRI shows six or more white matter lesions
questions.explanation:
Patients diagnosed with idiopathic optic neuritis are at a very high risk of subsequent development of multiple sclerosis; the risk can be as high as 74% at 15 years. The results of initial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) testing are highly correlated with this risk and can help predict the chances of future development of multiple sclerosis (MS). 

• The overall risk for development of MS after optic neuritis is 50% (at 15 years) 
• When an MRI of the brain is normal, there is still a 23% chance of MS at 15 years 
• If a brain MRI shows one T-2 weighted ovoid lesion of the white matter (greater than 3mm in diameter), the 15-year risk of MS increases to 56% 
• The highest risk factor for MS is an MRI that shows at least six T2-weighted white matter lesions. These patients have a 74% chance of developing MS at 15 years. 

Therefore, patients with normal MRIs may develop MS, and patients with abnormal MRIs may never develop MS. It is important to closely follow these patients with regular eye examinations and to coordinate care with their primary care physician.

questions.question: A 34-year old patient walks into your office concerned with distance blurry vision. During review of her case history, she also reports that she cannot stand cold temperatures, her skin is very dry, she feels sluggish, depressed and her heart rate is slowed. Which of the following conditions do you suspect is the culprit of her systemic concerns?
questions.explanation:
The above case history is a textbook case of hypothyroidism. People who suffer from hypothyroidism are intolerant of the cold, have a slowed heart rate, display dry skin, possess dry, brittle nails and hair, have unintentional weight gain, and have feelings of sluggishness, fatigue, and depression. The most common treatment includes increasing TSH levels via medication (Levothyroxine). 

Individuals who suffer from hyperthyroidism often complain of increased heart and metabolic rates, heat intolerance, weight loss, trouble sleeping, and excessive nervousness. Hyperthyroidism can also lead to Grave's condition, an autoimmune disorder that attacks the thyroid gland and results in increased levels of thyroxine. A common sign of Grave's disease is proptosis caused by inflammation of orbital fat and the extraocular muscles. Treatment includes radioactive iodine to destroy thyroid function. 

Cretinism is a severe form of hypothyroidism that occurs in children due to a genetic defect that affects the thyroid gland of the fetus. Proper and early treatment is of essence; otherwise, the child's growth is stunted and mental retardation occurs. 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder that results in a weakness of skeletal muscles. Muscle weakness worsens with activity but will improve with rest.

questions.question: A 33-year old female patient is seen at your office complaining of bilateral ptosis and diplopia that worsen towards the end of the day. Her pupils are round and equally reactive to light. She was recently seen by a neurologist, and all of her imaging scans were negative. She also reports difficulty swallowing and breathing. Given the above findings, what is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Myasthenia gravis is caused by an autoimmune reaction in which the receptors for acetylcholine (Ach) on the motor endplate become destroyed. The decreased number of Ach receptors leads to weakness of voluntary muscles, which worsens with activity and improves with rest. Patients frequently report difficulty with swallowing and breathing. A ptosis may present bilaterally, or it may alternate between eyes along with extraocular muscle involvement causing diplopia. In-office testing will reveal a worsening of the ptosis after having the patient look up for about 20 seconds, which will cause muscle fatigue. Placing an ice pack on the eye will improve the ptosis, purportedly because the cool temperature will cause a decrease in acetylcholinesterase activity, allowing for greater amounts of Ach available in the neuromuscular junction. Another test to confirm a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis is the Tensilon (endrophonium chloride) test. Injection of Tensilon into a patient with myasthenia gravis will result in improvement of symptoms for roughly 5 minutes. However, the Tensilon test does have a slightly lower sensitivity rate and is an invasive procedure with potential complications. 

A cranial nerve III palsy, an aneurysm and CPEO will not display diurnal variations. An aneurysm will usually demonstrate pupil involvement and the patient frequently suffers from an extremely painful headache.
PowerPage
Myasthenia Gravis

questions.question: Once bound, what molecule exposes the active site on the actin filament and allows for muscle contraction?
questions.explanation: Upon contraction of a muscle, calcium is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR). This is a type of modified endoplasmic reticulum that surrounds myofibrils and is responsible for calcium storage and release. Upon release, the calcium binds to troponin which results in the movement of tropomyosin away from the binding site on the actin filament. Actin is then free to bind to myosin causing muscle contraction. Adenosine triphosphate (ATP) initiates calcium uptake by the SR. In the absence of calcium, the binding site on the actin filament becomes blocked, allowing for muscle relaxation.

questions.question: What is the correct order in which inhaled air reaches our lungs?
options: Nasal cavity-> larynx-> trachea-> pharynx-> bronchi-> lungs
Nasal cavity-> larynx -> pharynx ->trachea-> bronchi-> lungs
Nasal cavity-> pharynx-> bronchi ->larynx-> trachea -> lungs
Nasal cavity-> bronchi-> pharynx-> trachea-> larynx-> lungs
Nasal cavity-> pharynx-> larynx-> trachea-> bronchi-> lungs
answers: Nasal cavity-> pharynx-> larynx-> trachea-> bronchi-> lungs
questions.explanation: Inhaled air enters through the nasal or the oral cavity and is then swept down the pharynx. The pharynx, also known as the throat, connects the mouth and the nose to the larynx. The pharynx is also attached to the esophagus. Air then passes through the larynx (also called the voice box). From the larynx, air flows through the trachea which divides into 2 bronchi leading to the right or left lung.

questions.question: After a corneal transplant, which of the following cells is most likely to cause rejection of the graft?
questions.explanation: When a host rejects a graft, it is usually due to a response against antigens that are displayed on major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I proteins by the graft that are subsequently recognized by cytotoxic T cells. The cytotoxic T cells then bind to the cells and destroy them.

questions.question: Upon slit-lamp examination of your patient, you observe what appear to be Lisch nodules in the iris. After you complete biomicroscopy, you examine the exposed skin of his arms and also notice several areas of light brown pigmentation. Which of the following genetic disorders commonly presents with these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Iris Lisch nodules, patchy hyperpigmentation of the skin (cafe au-lait spots) and small bump-like tumors that grow under the skin (neurofibromas) are characteristic features of neurofibromatosis type I (previously known as Von Recklinghausen disease). Neurofibromatosis type I (NF-1) is a human genetic disorder that is caused by mutations in neurofibromin. In addition to the previously mentioned signs, NF-1 also variably involves the brain, bones, adrenal glands, and vasculature, and can cause disturbances in puberty and growth. 

Neurofibromatosis type II (NF-2) also presents with neurofibromas; however, the appearance of cafe au-lait spots and Lisch nodules are generally not associated with this form of the disease. The main manifestation of NF-2 is the development of non-malignant tumors of the brain in the area of cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve). Visual symptoms can occur in NF-2 and are usually related to the development of posterior subcapsular cataracts.

questions.question: Which of the following white blood cells secretes histamine?
questions.explanation:
There are two major classes of leukocytes, granulocytes and agranulocytes. Neutrophils, basophils, and eosinophils all fall under the category of granulocytes due to the fact that they contain a lobed nucleus and possess cytoplasmic granules visible upon staining. Neutrophils comprise the largest number of leukocytes, roughly two-thirds. These leukocytes seek and destroy cells that are infected or damaged. Eosinophils are involved in allergic responses as well as mounting attacks against parasites. Basophils are the least common granulocyte and play a role in inflammation as well as allergy. Basophils release histamine, along with other substances, that prolong the inflammatory response. Remember, neutrophils neutralize (e.g., they kill). Eosinophils are 'eoitchy' (allergy). 

The second class of leukocytes is agranulocytes, aptly named because they do not possess cytoplasmic granules. This class contains two types of cells: monocytes and lymphocytes. Monocytes can move quickly to an infection site and divide/differentiate into macrophages and dendritic cells when necessary, and destroy microbes or debris via phagocytosis. Lymphocytes, the T cells and the B cells, are involved in hosting specific immune responses.

questions.question: The type of juvenile idiopathic arthritis in which five or more joints are affected during the first six months of the disease is known as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), also known as juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (JRA), is a type of inflammatory arthritis that occurs in children under the age of 16, for a duration of at least 6 weeks. It is the most common form of arthritis in children and adolescents, as well as the most common systemic disease associated with childhood anterior uveitis. JIA is classified based upon the extent of joint involvement in the first 6 months of the disease. These subtypes are as follows: 
- Pauciarticular (aka Oligoarticular): JIA in which 4 or fewer joints are affected within the first 6 months. This type accounts for 50-60% of all cases of JIA, and uveitis affects about 20% of these children. Large joints are most commonly affected in these patients. 
- Polyarticular: JIA in which 5 or more joints are affected within the same time period. This type accounts for 20% of cases of JIA, and uveitis occurs in about 5% of these cases. Usually the smaller joints are affected in these children. 
- Systemic: In addition to polyarticular JIA, children with systemic JIA also experience symptoms such as fever and a salmon pink rash in conjunction with the arthritic conditions. This type of JIA typically involves both the small and large joints.

questions.question: Each kidney contains approximately how many nephrons?
questions.explanation: Each kidney contains over a million nephrons; they serve as extremely important sites for the reabsorption of water and solutes needed for proper bodily function.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the physiology behind the first heart sound (also known as the 'lub' of 'lub-dub)?
options: Opening of the aortic and pulmonary valves
Closing of the tricuspid and mitral valves
Closing of the aortic and pulmonary valves
Opening of the tricuspid and mitral valves
answers: Closing of the tricuspid and mitral valves
questions.explanation:
The primary sounds of the heart are caused by vibrations created by pressure differentials that occur during the closure of the heart valves. The opening of heart valves is typically very slow, occurring without an audible sound, while the rapid closure of the valves creates the 'lub-dub' sound that can be easily heard with a stethoscope. 

The first heart sound ('lub' or S1) arises from the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves (also known as the atrioventricular valves). The mitral valve closes slightly earlier than the tricuspid valve because contraction of the ventricles begins with the left ventricle. 

The second heart sound ('dub' or S2) occurs as a result of the closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves (also known as the semilunar valves). The aortic valve closes just before the pulmonary valve due to the fact that the ejection of blood ends first in the left ventricle. 

Handbook of Cardiac Anatomy, Physiology, and Devices. (Second edition). Iaizzo, P.A. 2009. Springer. Minneapolis, MN.

questions.question: Which of the following types of headaches is characterized by the presence of a severe unilateral headache with periocular pain and an ipsilateral Horner syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Raeder's paratrigeminal neuralgia is a severe unilateral headache with periocular pain that follows the first distribution of the trigeminal nerve. In addition to the headache, these patients will also present with an ipsilateral Horner's syndrome. These symptoms may last from hours to weeks but will eventually resolve spontaneously. 

Ice-pick syndrome is characterized by multifocal, sharp, quick, intense pains that occur around the areas of the skull, face, and eyes. This can be differentiated from trigeminal neuralgia in that pain in these cases does not follow the anatomical distribution of the trigeminal nerve. 

Ophthalmoplegic migraines usually occur in patients under the age of 10. It is characterized by a recurrent, transient third nerve palsy, which develops after the headache. 

Cluster headaches are typically unilateral and oculotemporal in location, associated with deep, sharp, excruciating pain that may last 10 minutes to 2 hours. These headaches will typically occur on a daily basis for a period of several weeks; thus the name 'cluster.' 

Tension headaches are the most common type of primary headache in adults. The pain in these headaches usually radiates from the lower back of the head, the neck, or the eyes. The pain is commonly bilateral and is usually mild to moderate but can be severe in some patients.

questions.question: Sjogren's syndrome is associated with many diseases except for which of the following?
questions.explanation: Sjogren's syndrome is a concurrence of a dry eye and a dry mouth, either from destruction of salivary and tears glands or infiltration with lymphocytes. It is associated with autoimmune diseases of the rheumatic or collagen vascular variety. Osteoarthritis is wear-and-tear arthritis often referred to as degenerative joint disease. Though there is a low-grade inflammatory and metabolic component in the destruction of the cartilage, OA is largely a mechanical disease and although some textbooks and articles associate it with Sjogren's syndrome, this is incorrect.

questions.question: Bone is a type of specialized connective tissue. Bone is derived from which type of cell?
questions.explanation:
Osteoblasts are required for bone formation. 

Chondroblasts are important for the production of the cartilage matrix. Once mature, chondroblasts become chondrocytes and reside in cavities within the cartilage matrix called lacunae. 

Osteocytes are found in the bone matrix in small cavities called lacunae. Osteocytes are derivatives of osteoblasts and are important in bone remodeling. These cells serve an important role in releasing calcium from bones when the body's calcium level becomes depleted. 

Megakaryocytes are found in bone marrow and are responsible for producing thrombocytes, which are required for blood clotting.

questions.question: The process by which bones become progressively hollow and brittle is known as which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
Osteoporosis results when bones become broken down faster than they can be renewed. This condition is more common in older women. Contributing factors include: smoking, sedentary lifestyle, ingestion of too much protein, and calcium deficiency. Strategies to prevent osteoporosis consist of eating plenty of calcium-rich foods and maintaining an active lifestyle. 

Osteocytes are found in the bone matrix in small cavities, lacunae. Osteocytes are derivatives of osteoblasts and are important in bone remodeling. These cells serve an important role in releasing calcium from bones when the body's calcium level becomes depleted. 

Osteoblitis is not a condition. 

Osteogenesis entails the formation of bone tissue.

questions.question: A constant ringing of the ears is known as which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
Tinnitus is caused by damage to hair cells in the inner ear from exposure to excessive noise, medications (like aspirin), aging, and some diseases. Sound waves cause the hair cells to bend, releasing a neurotransmitter and causing action potentials of the auditory nerve. Sometimes the hair cells break or are left in the 'on' position, causing the perception of ringing. 

Otitis media is an infection or inflammation of the middle ear. 

Sinusitis is an inflammation of the sinuses. 

The malleus, also known as the hammer, is one of the tiny bones in the ear that help to transmit and amplify sound to the auditory nerve.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following hormones are secreted by the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
The two hormones secreted by the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland (also known as neurohypophysis) are antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and oxytocin. These hormones are synthesized by the hypothalamus, but stored in the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland until released. ADH mainly targets the kidneys and arterioles, stimulating water retention by the kidneys, and increasing blood pressure by contracting the arterioles. Increased levels of ADH can also induce aggression in males. Oxytocin mainly targets the uterus and mammary glands, leading to uterine contractions and lactation in females. 

The anterior lobe of the pituitary gland (also known as adenohypophysis) secretes the other listed hormones (prolactin, adrenocorticotropic hormone, and thyroid stimulating hormone), in addition to follicle stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, and growth hormone.

questions.question: Which of the following landmarks of an electrocardiogram represents repolarization of the atria?
options: Atrial repolarization is obscured by the QRS complex
answers: Atrial repolarization is obscured by the QRS complex
questions.explanation:
An electrocardiogram machine processes electrical signals picked up through electrodes placed on the patient's skin. It then produces a graphical representation of the electrical activity of the patient's heart. The basic pattern of electrical activity is comprised of three waves: the P wave, QRS complex, and T wave. These landmarks are summarized below. 

- P wave: small upward deflection wave that represents atrial depolarization 
- Q wave: beginning of the QRS complex (depolarization of ventricles) that corresponds to the depolarization of the interventricular septum 
- S wave: the end of the QRS wave complex that represents the final depolarization of the ventricles at the base of the heart 
- T wave: signifies ventricular repolarization 
- PR interval: time between the first deflection of the P wave and first deflection of the QRS wave complex 
- There is no specific wave or landmark for the repolarization of the atria as it occurs during the same time at the main QRS complex and is obscured by this large wave 

Cardiology Explained. Euan, A.A., Niebauer, J. 2004. Remedica.

questions.question: Nerves that carry sensory information to the central nervous system are classified as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Afferent essentially means 'to bring to'. Afferent nerves carry sensory information to the central nervous system for processing. Efferent nerves carry signals away from the central nervous system to the body's effectors, which are motor neurons or glands. 

Autonomic nerves carry information from the central nervous system to smooth muscle, glands, and cardiac muscle. There are two types of autonomic nerves: those that deal with the sympathetic system and those that are allocated to the parasympathetic system. In general, these systems work antagonistically.
PowerPage
The Nervous System

questions.question: Which of the following actions occurs by the body in response to a rise in environmental temperature?
questions.explanation:
In the event of an external rise in temperature, the body attempts to maintain a stable core temperature in several ways. Initially, the body signals for vasodilation of blood vessels in the skin. Dilation of vasculature close to the skin allows for dissipation of excess heat. The hypothalamus also promotes sweating via the sweat glands. The body also reduces the activity of its muscles in order to decrease heat production. Heat exhaustion occurs when too much water is lost from heavy sweating and increased vasodilation, causing a decrease in blood pressure. Heat exhaustion can lead to fainting. Heat stroke ensues when the core temperature of the body can no longer be adequately controlled. With heat stroke, sweating ceases and the body temperature rises to a point that may be lethal. 

In the presence of decreased temperatures, the body responds by peripheral vasoconstriction, promoting heat retention. Smooth muscle also contracts resulting in the pilomotor response (body hair is caused to stand erect, creating air pockets that serve to retain heat). The hypothalamus may also signal for the contraction of skeletal muscle, resulting in shivering that produces heat. If there is a prolonged drop in temperature, the body will react via non-shivering heat production, which increases the metabolic rate. This type of hormonal temperature control is most noteworthy in brown adipose tissue. Heat is generated by metabolism of this tissue. Brown adipose tissue is commonly found in the neck, armpits and near the kidneys of babies and people who are cold-adapted.

questions.question: Sound waves travel through the structures of the ear to the cochlea in which order?
options: Pinna-> oval window-> the malleus-> the incus-> the stapes-> tympanic membrane-> cochlea
Pinna-> tympanic membrane-> the malleus-> the incus-> the stapes-> oval window-> cochlea
Pinna-> oval window-> the incus-> the stapes-> the malleus-> tympanic membrane-> cochlea
Pinna-> tympanic membrane-> the incus-> the stapes-> the malleus-> oval window-> cochlea
answers: Pinna-> tympanic membrane-> the malleus-> the incus-> the stapes-> oval window-> cochlea
questions.explanation: Sound is funneled by the pinna (the outer ear) into the auditory canal to the tympanic membrane. Vibration of this membrane transfers the sound energy to the malleus (or the hammer) which then passes it to the incus (anvil) and on to the stapes (stirrup). The energy is transmitted to the oval window, which is considerably smaller than the tympanic membrane, causing amplification of the original sound vibrations. The oval window conveys the sound to the cochlea, a fluid-filled, snail-shaped apparatus consisting of the scala vestibuli and the scala tympani, which surround the central cochlear duct. It is within the cochlear duct that the magic happens. The floor of the cochlear duct houses the basilar membrane, which serves as a bed for the organ of Corti. Hair cells of the organ of Corti protrude upwards onto a membrane called the tectorial membrane. Sound waves cause the fluid in the cochlea to move, which vibrates the basilar membrane. This vibration in turn pushes the hair cells against the tectorial membrane, causing the hair cells to bend. The bent hair cells release a neurotransmitter, resulting in action potentials of the auditory nerve. Pressure waves travel through the cochlea and are released to the round window, which helps to release some pressure caused by the force of the sound waves.

questions.question: Excessive production of the growth hormone during adulthood can lead to which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Acromegaly is a condition that results from the synthesis and release of too much growth hormone during adulthood. In adults, the plates of long bones have fused and therefore are no longer capable of growth. In response to the growth hormone, bone and connective tissue of the jaw, hands, and feet will grow wider and thicker. The epithelia of the lips, eyelids, nose, and tongue will also continue to grow. 

Gigantism is caused by excessive release of the growth hormone during childhood resulting in a person that is abnormally taller than the average human. On the other hand, diminished levels of the growth hormone during childhood leads to an adult of small stature but of normal proportion when compared to an average adult (i.e., arms, legs, and body are shorter than an average person but of proper proportion for their body size). 

People afflicted with Marfan's syndrome have a genetic defect of their connective tissue and tend to be very tall with unusually long fingers and limbs.

questions.question: The sella turcica is a deep depression in the superior surface of the sphenoid bone that houses which of the following glands?
questions.explanation: The sella turcica is a deep, saddle-shaped depression in the sphenoid bone of the skull that holds the pituitary gland. The floor (or seat of the saddle) is known as the hypophyseal fossa in which pituitary gland rests. Due to the configuration of the sella turcica, a tumor of the pituitary gland will typically extend upward into the suprasellar region, which can result in compression of the optic chiasm, causing a bitemporal hemianopic field defect.

questions.question: Vaccines protect the body from subsequent infection due to the presence of which type of cell?
questions.explanation: Memory T cells are maintained after exposure to a vaccine or infectious agent and allow the body to mount a more rapid and pronounced specific immune response during subsequent exposures to the agent. Helper T cells are responsible for interacting with antigen-presenting cells and stimulating proliferation of specific B and T lymphocytes. Plasma cells are differentiated B cells with the principle function of antibody secretion. Suppressor T cells inhibit the response of specific B and T cells and play an important role in immune tolerance and suppression of autoimmune disease. Memory B cells and suppressor B cells have not been described.

questions.question: What is the term for when normal breathing stops briefly and then resumes?
questions.explanation:
Apnea occurs when breathing suddenly stops for a very brief instant and then resumes. Causes of apnea can include trauma, neurological disease, and drug effects, to name a few.

A pneumothorax occurs when air collects in the space that surrounds the lung. This increases the pressure on the lung and may lead to its collapse. Common causes are chest trauma and lung diseases such as asthma or COPD; however, sometimes a pneumothorax may occur spontaneously. 

The pleural membranes of the lungs are separated by an intrapleural space filled with intrapleural fluid that serves to prevent the two membranes from rubbing against one another. Some illnesses like pneumonia can cause inflammation of the pleurae, leading to chafing and painful ventilation called pleurisy. 

Emphysema results in destruction of alveolar walls leading to decreased gas exchange. This condition is most commonly caused by smoking.

questions.question: Patients diagnosed with diabetes mellitus commonly experience signs of chronic excessive thirst. What is the name of this symptom?
questions.explanation: Polydipsia is the symptom of excessive chronic thirst that is characteristically found in diabetic patients. It typically occurs as one of the initial symptoms of the disease, along with polyphagia (excessive hunger), and polyuria (excessive urination).

questions.question: You see a patient with a subluxated lens; you suspect which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Marfan's syndrome is a genetic condition demarcated by height, a high arch palate, and very long fingers. With Marfan's syndrome there are collagen deficiencies, one of which has lead to the subluxation of the lens. Homocystinuria is another condition that may cause lens subluxation and is associated with very high levels of homocysteine and susceptibility to heart disease.

questions.question: Genetic recombination, which allows for genotypic and phenotypic variations, occurs during which phase of meiosis?
questions.explanation: During prophase I, in which chromosomes begin to condense, homologous chromosomes pair up with each other in a process that is termed synapsis. This sets the stage for the swapping of DNA between non-sister chromatids. At cross over points along the chromosomes, chiasmata may form (they resemble an X), which allow for genetic exchange between chromosomes (literally, the swapping of chromosomal segments).

questions.question: During which phase of mitosis do chromosomes line up at the cellular equator?
questions.explanation: The first stage of mitosis is prophase. During early prophase, DNA begins to condense inside of a nuclear envelope. During late prophase, the process involves further condensation of the chromosomes, the nuclear envelope, and the movement of one of a pair of centrioles to the other pole of the cell. During the transition into metaphase (sometimes called prometaphase), the centrioles send out microtubules, forming a spindle apparatus which attaches to sister chromatids of each chromosome. The microtubules attach at a site called a kinetochore on the centromere. At this time, the nuclear envelop has completely disintegrated. Metaphase is marked by the chromosomes aligning along the cellular equator, guided by the microtubules. Anaphase follows. During this phase the sister chromatids of each chromosome are pulled apart and are directed to opposite poles towards the centrioles by the microtubules. This is now telophase. During this stage, the chromosomes are no longer attached to the microtubules and begin to become less condensed. Nuclear envelopes also form around the de-condensing chromosomes, separating the DNA from the cytoplasm. At this point, cytoplasmic division begins and is generally complete before the end of telophase. Both new cells are diploid and contain the same number of chromosomes as the parent cell. The cells then transition into interphase, in which the DNA is duplicated and the cytoplasm and its components increase in number. Interphase is the longest portion of the cell cycle and is not a part of mitosis. After interphase, the cell will then either move on to mitosis, or it will no longer divide.

questions.question: Which type of epithelium lines the throat, nasal passages, sinuses and trachea?
questions.explanation:
The throat, nasal passages, sinuses, and trachea are lined with pseudostratified columnar epithelium. This type of tissue is actually a type of modified simple epithelium. It is actually a single layer but resembles stratified tissue due to the placement of its nuclei. Pseudostratified epithelium generally possesses cilia to help sweep mucous or fluid across its surface. 

Simple epithelium is found lining the body's cavities, tubes, and ducts. It is composed of a single layer of cells which is important for its function of absorption, secretion, filtering or diffusion. Stratified epithelium comprises two or more layers of cells and serves an important role in protection. 

Epithelium always has one free surface whether it faces a lumen, cavity, or the environment. The other surface is anchored to a basement membrane.

questions.question: What is the correct sequence of blood flow beginning from the lungs?
options: Pulmonary artery-> right atrium-> tricuspid valve-> right ventricle-> semilunar valves-> aorta
Pulmonary artery-> right atrium-> mitral valve-> right ventricle-> semilunar valves-> aorta
Pulmonary vein-> left atrium-> mitral valve-> left ventricle-> semilunar valves-> aorta
Pulmonary vein-> left atrium-> tricuspid valve-> left ventricle-> semilunar valves-> aorta
answers: Pulmonary vein-> left atrium-> mitral valve-> left ventricle-> semilunar valves-> aorta
