questions.question: Which 2 of the following items are true regarding the sympathetic nervous system? (Select 2)
options: The sympathetic system is responsible for pupil constriction
Preganglionic fibers are short and postganglionic fibers are long
It is also known as the 'fright, fight, or flight' system
answers: Preganglionic fibers are short and postganglionic fibers are long
It is also known as the 'fright, fight, or flight' system
questions.explanation:
Postganglionic fibers of the sympathetic system release norepinephrine. The neurotransmitter released between the preganglionic and postganglionic fibers is acetylcholine. This is in contrast to the parasympathetic nervous system, wherein the neurotransmitter released between the preganglionic and postganglionic fibers is acetylcholine, which is also released by the postganglionic fibers. The sympathetic nervous system is also known as the 'fright, fight, or flight' system; whereas the parasympathetic nervous system is sometimes referred to as the 'rest and digest' system. The sympathetic nervous system has a thoracolumbar outflow; the parasympathetic nervous system has a craniosacral outflow. 

Sympathetic fibers innervate the dilator muscles of the iris and cause mydriasis of the pupil.

questions.question: Fertilization of the human female egg primarily occurs at which site of the female reproductive system?
questions.explanation: The fallopian tubes (also known as the oviducts) are generally the site of fertilization. The egg is released from the ovary and is directed into the oviducts via fimbriae, the finger-like extensions of the fallopian tubes that act like beating cilia to move the egg into the tubes. Once fertilization occurs, rapid cell division creates an embryo that continues to travel down the fallopian tubes for about 3 or 4 days before it moves into the uterus; here it will implant itself onto the uterine wall. The cervix secretes mucus to help sperm motility and also serves to help protect the developing fetus from bacterial infections (post-fertilization).

questions.question: Which of the following female reproductive organs secretes estrogen and progesterone?
questions.explanation: The ovaries produce oocytes as well as the female sex hormones estrogen and progesterone. The oviducts serve as a passageway for eggs from the ovaries to the uterus. Also, the oviducts are the primary site of fertilization. The uterus is a chamber capable of enlargement in order to accommodate a developing baby. The cervix secretes mucus to help sperm motility and also serves to help protect the developing fetus from bacterial infections (post-fertilization).

questions.question: Travelling on an airplane can cause the ears to make a 'popping' sound. This noise is attributable to an equalizing of air pressure between the middle ear and the atmosphere. Which of the following structures serves to aid in this equalizing process?
questions.explanation:
The Eustachian tube runs from the middle ear to the pharynx. When pressure builds inside the ear, the tube helps to circumvent the excess pressure by allowing for equalization of air between the middle ear and the atmosphere. Rapid change in altitude can result in ear 'popping' due to this equalization process. 

The cochlea contains the organ of Corti, which is vital for hearing. 

The utricle is part of the vestibular apparatus and plays an important role in balance and spatial orientation.

questions.question: The nerve tract that serves to maintain communication between the cerebral hemispheres is named which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The brain is divided into two hemispheres, both of which are capable of functioning independently. In terms of function, the left hemisphere is thought largely to govern spoken language skills while the right houses the centers for math, music and other nonverbal, abstract thinking. The two hemispheres are connected by a nerve tract called the corpus callosum which facilitates communication between the two sides. 

The exact purpose of the red nucleus is still not fully understood but it is widely believed to be involved in motor function. 

The thalamus serves as a relay for sensory information; it projects sensory signals to the appropriate destination. 

The ventricles total four in number and function to synthesize and secrete cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

questions.question: The pressure exerted on vessel walls is the lowest at which point in the systemic circuit?
questions.explanation: Blood pressure drops as blood is pumped through the body. Fluid pressure for a given volume of blood is highest in the arteries and then decreases as it flows through the arterioles, capillaries, venules, and finally the veins. Veins act as blood reservoirs containing approximately 50-60 % of the total blood in the body. Veins contain smooth muscle which, along with adjacent skeletal muscle, helps to pump blood back towards the heart. Some veins also possess one-way valves that help to prevent backflow.

questions.question: Taste buds are an example of which type of specialized receptor?
questions.explanation:
Chemoreceptors detect changes in chemical substances that are dissolved in the surrounding media. Both the special senses of taste and smell have pathways that are initiated with chemoreceptors. 

Mechanoreceptors are designed to respond to different types of mechanical stimuli such as touch, pressure, acceleration, and position. These types of receptors include muscle spindles, Pacinian corpuscles and baroreceptors in the carotid sinuses. 

Thermoreceptors are important for detecting the presence of heat (infrared energy). 

Nociceptors are responsible for signaling pain or tissue damage.

questions.question: Which type of receptor responds primarily to changes in pressure?
questions.explanation:
Mechanoreceptors are designed to respond to different types of mechanical stimuli such as touch, pressure, acceleration, and position. These types of receptors include muscle spindles, Pacinian corpuscles and baroreceptors in the carotid sinuses. 

Thermoreceptors are important for detecting the presence of heat (infrared energy). 

Nociceptors are responsible for signaling pain or tissue damage. 

Chemoreceptors detect changes in chemical substances that are dissolved in the surrounding media.

questions.question: Research has recently discovered ocular signs associated with Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following two findings display a correlation with Alzheimer's disease? (Select 2)
options: Amyloid deposits on/in the crystalline lens
answers: Amyloid deposits on/in the crystalline lens
questions.explanation:
Alzheimer's disease is characterized by progressive memory loss. Ocular manifestations of this condition include a decrease in the amount of retinal nerve fibers along with a reduction and degeneration of neurons, causing increased optic cupping. It was also discovered that patients with Alzheimer's disease possess lenticular amyloid deposits that are observed on the equatorial zone of the lens. 

MF Visual Neurosciences, UCL Institute of Ophthalmology. Guo, L; Duggan J, Cordeiro London UK Current Alzheimer Research, 2010, 7(1):3-14

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain?
options: Third ventricle --> cerebral aqueduct --> fourth ventricle --> intraventricular foramen --> lateral ventricle --> subarachnoid space
Lateral ventricle --> cerebral aqueduct --> third ventricle --> intraventricular foramen --> fourth ventricle --> subarachnoid space
Third ventricle --> intraventricular foramen --> fourth ventricle --> cerebral aqueduct --> lateral ventricle --> subarachnoid space
Lateral ventricle --> intraventricular foramen --> third ventricle --> cerebral aqueduct --> fourth ventricle --> subarachnoid space
answers: Lateral ventricle --> intraventricular foramen --> third ventricle --> cerebral aqueduct --> fourth ventricle --> subarachnoid space
questions.explanation: Cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) is produced mainly by a structure known as the choroid plexus in the lateral, third, and fourth ventricles of the brain. CSF circulates from the lateral ventricle into the third ventricle through the intraventricular foramen (also known as the foramina of Monro). From the third ventricle, it flows through the cerebral aqueduct (Sylvian aqueduct) into the fourth ventricle. From the fourth ventricle, CSF passes through the foramina of Luschka (2) and Magendie (1) and enters the subarachnoid space. Some of the CSF flows around the spinal cord and the rest of it bathes the cerebral hemispheres. Absorption of the CSF back into the bloodstream takes place in the superior sagittal sinus through the arachnoid villi. In order for absorption to occur, the CSF pressure must be greater than the venous pressure.

questions.question: The right lung possesses how many lobes?
questions.explanation: The right lung is tri-lobed and the left lung has two lobes. A good way to remember this fact is that the word right has more letters than the word left; therefore, the right lung should have more lobes than the left.

questions.question: Which of the following organs plays a role in the lymphatic system and is a disposal site for red blood cells?
questions.explanation: The spleen is part of the lymphatic system along with the lymph nodes, thymus, tonsils, appendix, portions of the small intestine, and the bronchi. The spleen plays a large role as a site of antibody production as well as a dump site for the disposal of old red blood cells. T cells originate from stem cells in bone marrow, travel to the thymus, then differentiate into helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells. The kidneys are not a part of the lymphatic system but are necessary for many bodily functions including: maintaining homeostasis, filtering the blood, and regulating blood pressure and proper urinary function, to name a few. The liver is also not considered part of the lymphatic system but has many roles and is vital for detoxification.

questions.question: In what organ are T-lymphocytes primarily produced?
questions.explanation: All lymphocytes (and other blood cells) are produced in the bone marrow. B lymphocytes continue to mature in the bone marrow, while T lymphocytes mature in the thymus. After maturation, many lymphocytes localize to lymph nodes or other areas.

questions.question: Which of the following hormones is synthesized in the hypothalamus and stored in the pituitary lobe?
questions.explanation:
Both oxytocin and vasopressin (or the antidiuretic hormone (ADH)) are synthesized by the hypothalamus and stored in the posterior lobe of the pituitary. All of the other above-listed hormones are synthesized by the pituitary and stored in the anterior pituitary lobe. 

Ref: Rosenzweig, Leiman and Breedlove, Biological Psychology 2nd ed. An Introduction to Behavioral, Cognitive, and Clinical Neuroscience 1999 pages 117-119

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is commonly associated with patients demonstrating a history of pica and/ or who are in close contact with puppies?
questions.explanation:
Toxocariasis is caused by the parasite Toxocara canis. This intestinal roundworm is commonly found in dogs and may be present in the feces of infected canines. Toxocariasis may develop in humans via contact with contaminated soil or food. Once the ova are ingested, they may transform into larvae, which can then travel to the rest of the body and infect various organs such as the eyes, liver, brain, lungs, and skin. Once the larvae perish, the body may mount an inflammatory reaction to the remnants of their carcasses. 

Toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoa Toxoplasma gondii. T. gondii is commonly associated with improper handling of raw meat or cat fecal matter from an animal that has ingested infected meat; however, it rarely leads to illness in healthy individuals. 

Presumed ocular histoplasmosis is caused by the organism Histoplasma capsulatum; it typically enters the body via inhalation into the lungs. This condition is most prominent in the Ohio-Mississippi River valley region and in the southern United States. 

Onchocerciasis, also known as river-blindness, is caused by an infection with Onchocerca volvulus, which is a parasitic helminth. The most common vector responsible for transmission is the black fly. 

Cysticercosis is a parasitic infection in which pigs are the intermediate hosts. Transmission of this disease commonly occurs via the host ingesting cysts of a pork tapeworm (Taenia solium) from contaminated pork meat, vegetables, or water.

questions.question: Which 4 of the following conditions represent the TORCH complex in which certain perinatal infections are passed from a pregnant woman to her fetus? (Select 4)
questions.explanation:
TORCH is an acronym for a group of perinatal infectious diseases that may cause congenital conditions if a fetus is exposed to them in utero. TORCH stands for: 
- T: Toxoplasmosis 
- O: Other (such as HIV, varicella, syphilis, mumps, and parvovirus) 
- R: Rubella 
- C: Cytomegalovirus 
- H: Herpes Simplex 

Most of these infections result in only mild complications in the mother; however, they can potentially have serious fetal consequences. Treatment of the infection in the mother typically does not have a significant impact on the fetal sequelae from the infection. Therefore, it is important to recognize the presence of these maternal diseases as early as possible in order to properly and closely monitor the fetus.

questions.question: A patient walks into your office complaining of heat intolerance, weight loss, increased heart rate and proptosis. You suspect hyperthyroidism. Which of the following lab tests would MOST accurately confirm your suspicions?
questions.explanation: Although a person who suffers from hyperthyroidism may experience abnormal blood glucose, triglyceride, and cholesterol levels, these tests will not definitively aid in a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism. A person who has this condition will be expected to have low levels of TSH and increased levels of T3 and free T4. The most commonly ordered test is a measurement of the serum thyroid hormone T4 by radioimmunoassay. Because 80% of the thyroid's output is T4, this test generally gives a good idea of overall thyroid function; however, for a more accurate analysis a measurement of the serum thyroid hormone T3 by radioimmunoassay is also generally ordered in addition to T4 levels because T3 levels will likely also display elevation.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the most common genetic chromosomal disorder?
questions.explanation:
Down syndrome is considered the most prevalent chromosomal disorder and is the most frequently recognizable cause of mental or intellectual disability. It is caused by extra genetic material on chromosome 21 (also known as trisomy 21). Down syndrome occurs once in about every 700 births, is seen in all ethnic groups, and has a slight predilection for males over females, although this predilection is very small. The most commonly associated risk factor for Down syndrome is increased maternal age, as the chances of having a child with Down syndrome increases significantly with a maternal age of about 35 years and older. 

Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder in which all or part of one of the sex chromosomes is missing or abnormal. It typically occurs in about 1 in 2,000 live female births (this number varies slightly according to literature). 

Edward syndrome is a genetic chromosomal disorder cause by the presence of either all or a portion of an extra 18th chromosome (also known as trisomy 18). It occurs in about 1 in 6,000 births. 

Klinefelter syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality that results from additional genetic material on the X chromosome in males (also known as XXY). It exists in roughly 1 in 500 and 1 in 1000 live male births, but many of these males do not show symptoms. If the physical characteristics inherent in this abnormality have not become apparent earlier, they typically appear after the onset of puberty. 

Down Syndrome: The Facts (3rd edition). Selikowitz, M. 2008. Oxford University Press. New York, NY.

questions.question: You present for your annual tuberculin skin test (PPD) that is required once you begin seeing patients in clinic. The nurse explains that you need to return in 48-72 hours in order to read the results of the test. After a couple of days you notice that a large area of induration has formed around the injection site. This finding is due to which of the following types of reactions?
questions.explanation:
In patients with no known risks of tuberculosis (TB), a 15mm diameter (or more) area of firm swelling at the injection site indicates a positive result. This reaction that occurs in the skin is an example of a delayed (type IV) hypersensitivity reaction. The test can be positive within 4 weeks after exposure to the mycobacterium, although a positive skin test does not always mean that a person has active TB. 

In other populations, smaller reactions (such as 5mm or 10mm diameter areas) can be considered a positive result. These are typically people who are healthcare workers, HIV-positive, have had an organ transplant, injection drug users, or children, among others.

questions.question: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction (Gell and Coombs classification) is responsible for contact dermatitis?
questions.explanation: According to the Gell and Coombs classification of hypersensitivity reactions, Type I reactions are IgE-mediated reactions that result in an immediate response occuring within minutes of exposure. This type of reaction is seen in allergic disease. Type II reactions are antibody-dependent cytotoxic reactions that are mediated by IgM/IgG and complement. Type III reactions are due to immune complex formation. Immune complex diseases include systemic lupus erythematosus, arthus reactions and serum sickness. Type IV hypersensitivity is delayed-type hypersensitivity and is the result of T lymphocyte response. Typically, symptoms will occur 2 days after exposure. Prime examples include the PPD test for TB, contact dermatitis, and chronic organ transplant rejection.

questions.question: A person who has type A blood can receive a successful blood transfusion using which of the following blood types?
questions.explanation:
A person who has type A blood has A markers on their red blood cells and therefore does not possess antibodies against A markers but does manufacture antibodies for B markers. This individual can receive a transfusion from type O blood as red blood cells of this type do not display any markers and therefore do not result in antibody production. 

A person who has type B blood can receive type B and type O blood but not type A because they possess antibodies for the A markers. 

A person who has type AB blood can receive blood from types A, B, AB, and O. Type AB is considered the universal recipient because they will not surmount an immune reaction to any type of blood. 

A person with type O blood is considered the universal donor (an easy way to remember this is that dOnor has an O in it!). Individuals with type O blood can only receive type O blood because they carry antibodies against both the A and B markers. 

If two incompatible blood types are mixed, agglutination or clumping of the blood will occur, which can block blood vessels and lead to damage of the tissues and/or death.
PowerPage
Blood Typing

questions.question: Your patient reports to you that she recently started noticing that her vision becomes dim for several minutes after she takes a shower or has a strenuous workout at the gym. When reviewing her medical history, she also tells you that she was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis within the last year but is not currently on any treatment. What is the name of the sign/phenomenon that she is most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation: Some patients with multiple sclerosis (or other demyelinating diseases) experience deterioration of their vision during physical activity, or any other activity in which a rise in body temperature occurs (hot shower/bath, illness, stress, etc.). The observable changes in vision can range from blurriness to double vision or blind spots within the patient's visual field. These symptoms are temporary and reversible once the body temperature returns back to normal levels. Uhthoff's phenomenon is typically seen in about 4% of patients with demyelinating disease and can also include other transient neurological deficits such as muscle weakness, severe fatigue, and cognitive dysfunction. This phenomenon is thought to be due to an interference in nerve conduction secondary to an intolerance to heat (but the exact cause is still controversial).

questions.question: Urine formation is important for waste elimination. What is the correct sequence through which urine passes prior to being expelled from the body?
questions.explanation: Urine is formed by the kidneys via the nephrons; it passes through a ureter into the urinary bladder for storage. Once the bladder signals that it is full and stretched to a certain capacity, the urine exits the body via the urethra.

questions.question: You have correctly diagnosed your 31 year-old patient with anterior uveitis secondary to a concurrent syphilis infection. Which of the following serology tests will aid in monitoring the body's response to appropriate medical treatment?
questions.explanation:
The Venereal Disease Research Laboratory Test (VDRL) is a non-treponemal serological test for syphilis. It is designed to test whether a patient is currently infected with the Treponema palladium organism. VDRL is useful for monitoring a patient's response to medical treatment because the values will wane with successful treatment of the condition. 

Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption assay (FTA-ABS) is a treponemal test for syphilis. This serological test will produce a positive result in patients who are currently or have previously been infected with the T. palladium organism. Therefore, this test is not valuable for follow-up therapy because it will continue to be positive for the life of the patient, even after successful treatment. 

Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA) are helpful in the diagnosis of certain conditions such as toxoplasmosis, cat-scratch disease, and toxocariasis. It has no use in diagnosing or monitoring syphilis. 

Antinuclear antibody (ANA) testing is mainly utilized to identify antibodies that target normal proteins within the nuclei of cells in the body. A positive test typically indicates the presence of an autoimmune disease such as systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, Sjogren's syndrome, and juvenile arthritis.

questions.question: How do helper T cells of the immune system communicate with other effector cytotoxic T cells?
questions.explanation:
In response to binding with an antigen-MHC complex (major histocompatibility complex), a helper T cell will secrete interleukins and stimulate mitosis of cytotoxic T cells and helper T cells to produce an army of memory T cells, cytotoxic T cells, and helper T cells. 

Prostaglandin release is associated with inflammation and the pain pathway but is produced by all cells that contain a nucleus except for lymphocytes. 

Cytotoxic T cells secrete perforins to destroy pathogens. The release of perforins causes the formation of holes in the plasma membranes of infected cells, resulting in death. 

Histamine is released by mast cells and basophils in response to inflammatory conditions. Histamine causes vasodilation of arterioles, leading to blood engorgement (hence the redness experienced during an infection). Vasodilation occurs when the smooth muscle that lines the blood vessels relaxes. Histamine also promotes increased capillary permeability, causing the vessels to leak water and solutes, which produces localized edema.

questions.question: The volume of air that remains in the lungs after forced maximal expiration is known as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Using spirometry, lung volumes and lung capacities can be measured during difference phases of the respiratory cycle. This information is very helpful in the diagnosis of certain lung conditions, most commonly restrictive and obstructive lung disease. Some of these terms are defined below. 

- Residual volume: the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation 
- Expiratory reserve volume: the maximal volume of air that can be exhaled at the end of a tidal exhalation 
- Functional residual capacity: the amount of air in the lungs following a tidal exhalation (expiratory reserve volume plus residual volume) 
- Vital capacity: the maximal volume of air that can be exhaled after the deepest inhalation possible 
- Total lung capacity: the total volume of the lungs at maximal inhalation (vital capacity plus residual volume) 
- Tidal volume: the volume of air that is inhaled and exhaled during quiet breathing 

Physiology: Cases and Problems (3rd edition). Costanzo, L.S. 2009. Wolters Kluwer. Baltimore, MD.

questions.question: Homocysteine levels can be reduced by which of the following vitamins?
questions.explanation: The B vitamins, B12, B6, and folic acid (also known as B9) can reduce homocysteine levels. The other vitamins have no impact on homocysteine. Homocysteine is a metabolic product of the metabolism of methionine. It is associated with premature atherosclerosis and thrombotic complications such as thrombophlebitis. There is great excitement in the medical community about the ability of B vitamins to reduce homocysteine levels; they have been found to do so in multiple studies. Unfortunately, a reduction in cardiovascular disease has not occurred as a consequence of the reduction in this risk factor. It is probably appropriate to maintain homocysteine within a healthy range by restricting foods that are high in methionine and by maintaining an adequate supply of these B Vitamins.

questions.question: What is the name of the multisystem idiopathic autoimmune disease that results in inflammation of melanocyte-containing tissues including the ears, skin, meninges, and uvea?
questions.explanation:
Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome is a systemic autoimmune disease in which the body attacks melanocytes. This results in an inflammatory response of tissues in the body that contain melanocytes, including the ear, skin, meninges, and uveal tissue of the eye. A common ocular association includes anterior uveitis, which is typically non-granulomatous in the acute phases but can exhibit granulomatous features in recurring cases. Additionally, posterior uveitis can also occur in conjunction with Harada disease. It is typically bilateral, and can result in severe loss of vision due to retinal detachment, choroidal neovascular membrane formation, and subretinal fibrosis in advanced cases. 

Behcet's syndrome is an idiopathic, multisystem disease in which episodes of recurrent orogenital ulceration and vasculitis of small, medium, and large arteries and veins occur. 

Sarcoidosis is a non-caseating, granulomatous, T-lymphocyte-mediated, inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology. In this disease, abnormal collections of chronic inflammatory cells form nodules in multiple organs of the body (most often in the lung and lymph nodes). 

Systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disease in which there are numerous autoantibodies and circulating immune complexes that result in widespread vasculitis and damage to tissues of the body.

questions.question: In general, most of the water that we ingest largely ends up in which of the following states?
options: Secreted out of our pores as sweat
questions.explanation: In a healthy individual with normal kidney function, the majority of ingested water is reabsorbed and returned to the blood. Roughly 1% of water that is taken in becomes excreted by the body. The composition and concentration of the water that is not retained is altered accordingly based upon the body's needs.

questions.question: Which 2 of the following vector-borne diseases are transmitted through the bite of a hard-shelled tick? (Select 2)
questions.explanation:
Lyme disease and Rocky Mountain spotted fever are vector-borne diseases that are caused by an infection transmitted through the bite of a hard-shelled tick. Specifically, the organism responsible for Lyme disease is a flagellated spirochete known as Borrelia burgdorferi, while Rocky Mountain spotted fever is caused by a bacterium known as Rickettsia rickettsii. 

- Mosquitos are vectors of malaria, dengue fever, and yellow fever 
- Domestic cats are the primary host species for toxoplasmosis caused by a parasitic protozoan known as Toxoplasma gondii 
- Fleas are responsible for transmission of certain diseases such as the bubonic plague

questions.question: Which type of junction directly links the cytoplasm between cells and allows for the swift transfer of ions across adjacent cells?
questions.explanation: Gap junctions are open channels between two adjacent cells that directly connect the cytoplasm between the cells, allowing for quick transfer of ions or small molecules. These types of junctions are generally found in the heart and other locations in the body where swift coordination is essential. Tight junctions adhere cells together and ensure that whatever molecules enter the cell will not slip in between cells. Maculae adherens and zonula adherens are types of adhering junctions that help weld cells together that are prone to being stretched. The zonula adherens form bands or collars that encircle cells.

questions.question: You are performing binocular indirect ophthalmoscopy on a patient and drop and crack your 20D condensing lens. You are able to find an old 30D condensing lens to complete the examination. How will the magnification and field of view change with the 30D lens as compared to the 20D lens?
options: Both the magnification and field of view will decrease
The magnification will increase, and the field of view will decrease
Both the magnification and field of view will increase
The magnification will decrease, and the field of view will increase
answers: The magnification will decrease, and the field of view will increase
questions.explanation:
As the power of the condensing lens increases, the field of view increases but the magnification decreases. Additionally, the working distance will decrease as well. 

It may be easier to think about this concept in terms of fundus lenses because we commonly switch back and forth between powers depending on pupil size, while most practitioners only use one condensing lens (20D). The field of view is larger with a 90D lens, and the magnification is less with a 90D lens as compared to a 78D lens; this can be applied to condensing lenses used with binocular indirect ophthalmoscopy as well.
